site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit bags S$174m HDB contract
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation announced a S$173.5 million contract with the Housing and Development Board for building works in Hougang, including a community club and a park. Construction will begin in June and take 48 months. The company stated that the contract is not expected to have a material impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year ending December.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

site_title: New Apple museum opens in former Warsaw factory
summary: A new Apple museum has opened in a former Warsaw factory, featuring 1,600 exhibits showcasing the company's history, from its early days with the Apple 1 to modern devices like iPhones and MacBooks. The collection, amassed by Polish collector Jacek Lupina over years, is considered the largest and most complete in the world. The museum includes original computers, advertising posters, and signed memorabilia, offering a unique glimpse into Apple's development and evolution.

site_title: Euro zone inflation hits new record, adding to case for big ECB rate hikes
summary: Euro zone inflation hit a new record high of 8.1% in May, exceeding expectations and challenging the European Central Bank's view that gradual rate hikes from July would be enough to tame fast price growth. This has boosted government bond yields and increased pressure on the ECB to tighten its monetary policy. The ECB's 2% inflation target is now four times higher than the current rate, and policymakers may need to consider more aggressive measures to control inflation, which is expected to peak at 9.3% in September.

images.alt_text: Eurozone government bond yields jumped on Monday after preliminary data showed inflation rising more than expected while risk appetite grew across financial markets.

site_title: US consumer confidence dips in May: survey
summary: US consumer confidence eased slightly in May, dipping to a reading of 106.4, driven by concerns about high inflation and a softening labour market. However, views of current business conditions improved. The decline was solely due to labour market perceptions, with other indices showing slight improvements.

site_title: Alibaba, JD.com jump on easing Covid curbs, economic data
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks surged, wiping out monthly losses, as easing lockdown measures and better-than-expected economic data reassured investors. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index rose 3.7% on Tuesday, its first monthly gain since October, with Alibaba Group Holding, JD.com, and Baidu also seeing significant gains. China's daily coronavirus cases fell below 100 for the first time since March, and the country is easing restrictions, including allowing Shanghai's public transportation to resume. This optimism has led some analysts to predict the worst of the economic fallout may be nearing an end.

images.alt_text: Alibaba, along with Baidu, reported sales growth that were higher than expected, suggesting some of China’s largest businesses have found ways to wade through strict Covid restrictions in key cities.

The financial technology, cloud and artificial intelligence (AI) arm of JD.com applied to the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) in late January seeking an offshore listing, according to the regulator’s website.

site_title: Seafarer wages are ‘going up’, thanks to crew shortages
summary: Asian shipowners warn that crew shortages are driving up seafarer wages, with well-qualified and loyal crews becoming a more valuable commodity. This trend is a reversal from the 1970s, when qualified officers were in high demand. Companies are urged to offer jobs quickly to avoid losing out to higher bidders. As a result, seafarer wages are "going up" due to the crew shortages, according to Danica Crewing Specialist's CEO Henrik Jensen.

images.alt_text: Being environment friendly is one of several challenges faced by the shipping industry worldwide.

site_title: K-pop supergroup BTS visits Biden in White House; says ‘devastated’ by US hate crimes
summary: US President Joe Biden met with K-pop supergroup BTS, making statements against anti-Asian hate crimes and advocating for inclusion and representation. The group expressed their "devastation" over the recent surge of hate crimes in the US. BTS members Park Ji-min and Suga appealed for tolerance, emphasizing the importance of embracing differences. The visit garnered significant media attention, with over 300,000 viewers watching the White House briefing on YouTube. The meeting marked a rare moment of cultural exchange and solidarity between the US and South Korea.

site_title: South-east Asia may have to reduce food, fuel subsidies to save public purses
summary: South-east Asian governments may need to reduce food and fuel subsidies to save public funds due to rising commodity prices and pandemic expenses. Economists say fiscal pressures are increasing, making it difficult for governments to maintain subsidies. Policymakers are unlikely to completely scrap subsidies, which have cushioned consumers from price increases in markets like Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand. A price cap on raw materials will replace a subsidy on bulk cooking oil in Indonesia starting June, while regional fuel and food subsidy schemes are headed for reform.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Several factors have acted to shelter Asian consumers’ wallets,  such as the more structured post-pandemic reopening of Asian economies.
Shanghai, China’s financial hub with more than 28 million people, remains in lockdown for almost 2 months, though more residents are recently allowed to go out to shop for groceries.
A worker assembles a vehicle at a factory in Qingzhou, in China's eastern Shandong province on September 28, 2021. (Photo by STR / AFP) / China OUT##########china29##########

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced Singapore's Monetary Authority will pilot a project to explore financial asset tokenisation and develop finance infrastructure, despite the risks of the crypto space. Meanwhile, Income At Raffles is being marketed for sale at S$3,300 per square foot, and CapitaLand Investment has achieved green building certifications for 48% of its global portfolio. Crude oil prices surged past US$120 a barrel, driven by China's easing of lockdown curbs and the EU's ban on Russian oil.

images.alt_text: The improvement in industry-wide room revenue comes as both occupancies and average room rates have picked up further in April.

site_title: Euro’s losses deepen after inflation data
summary: The euro's losses deepened after data showed euro zone inflation hit a record high of 8.1% in May, beating expectations. Despite this, the single currency was up nearly 2% on a monthly basis, its best monthly gain in a year, due to expectations of European Central Bank (ECB) rate hikes. The ECB is cautious about tightening policy to avoid a recession, while oil prices surged after European Union leaders agreed to cut most oil imports from Russia by the end of the year.

site_title: UK credit card borrowing soars by most since 2005 as cost-of-living squeeze tightens
summary: Credit card borrowing in the UK surged by 11.6% in April, the largest annual increase since 2005, as households struggled with the cost-of-living squeeze. Consumer credit rose 5.7% in annual terms, despite business surveys indicating a slowdown in demand. The data suggests households may be using credit to support spending, while also pointing to a possible slowing of the housing market.

images.alt_text: The charity that sets Britain's "real living wage", a voluntary pay rate adopted by thousands of employers, said on Sunday it will bring forward the announcement for the 2022/23 rate to September from November because of high inflation.

site_title: Global chip shortage likely to last through 2023: US official
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo warns the global chip shortage is likely to last through 2023 and possibly longer. The shortage, caused by shutdowns of key Asian suppliers due to the Covid-19 pandemic, has crippled supplies and led to increased demand for chips. Raimondo calls for Congress to act on legislation to stimulate domestic chip manufacturing, citing concerns that other countries may receive subsidies and build chip production facilities elsewhere. The US Senate and House of Representatives have approved $52 billion bills for chip research and manufacturing, but have yet to agree on the final form of the legislation.

site_title: Germany's Merck to open semiconductor base in China
summary: Germany's Merck to open a 69-acre semiconductor base in Zhangjiagang, China, marking its largest single electronics business investment in the country. The base will produce thin film materials and electronic specialty gases, with an additional investment of 1 billion yuan (S$205.8 million) planned by 2025. Merck believes China's semiconductor industry is entering a "golden era" due to unprecedented capacity investment and expansion of domestic chip manufacturers.

site_title: Hong Kong airline body wants 3-day quarantine, no Covid test: sources
summary: A Hong Kong airline lobby group is urging the government to cut the hotel quarantine period for travelers to 3 days and scrap pre-flight Covid-19 tests. The Board of Airlines Representatives of Hong Kong also requested the abolition of a rule suspending flights for certain numbers of Covid-positive passengers. The push comes as Hong Kong moves to ease its pandemic border regime, with the city set to stop banning airlines that meet travel requirements on their first offense. The industry expects a step-by-step approach to reduce Covid restrictions, with the current 7-day quarantine period seen as outdated.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will relax some Covid-19 testing requirements for incoming travellers.

site_title: Myanmar junta likely using air strikes as ‘collective punishment’: Amnesty
summary: Myanmar's military has likely used air strikes and artillery barrages as "collective punishment" against civilians opposing its coup, Amnesty International said. Deadly clashes have ravaged the country since the 2021 coup, with troops carrying out extrajudicial killings and looting. Air strikes killed nine civilians and wounded at least nine others, with Amnesty accusing the junta of war crimes and crimes against humanity. The military's operations reflect its policy of collective punishment of civilian communities perceived to support an armed group or the protest movement.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file handout from Ei Tu Hta community leaders taken and received on March 29, 2021, Karen people, who had crossed the Salween river into Thailand to seek refuge after air strikes in eastern Myanmar's Karen state following the February military coup, being requested by the Thai authorities to leave Mae Hong Son and head back in boats across to the Myanmar side of the river. - Myanmar's military has likely used air strikes and artillery barrages as "collective punishment" against civilians, Amnesty International said on June 1, 2022, accusing the junta of "a new wave of war crimes". site_title: Indonesia cancels plan to send workers to Malaysia's palm plantations
summary: Indonesia has cancelled plans to send 164 migrant workers to Malaysia's palm oil plantations, which were facing a labour shortage. The workers were set to arrive on a chartered flight after Malaysia's ministry of human resources scheduled a monitoring session. The cancellation was due to "unavoidable circumstances" and a potential misunderstanding over the regulation of work permit issuance. This move comes amid growing concerns over the treatment of migrant workers in Malaysia, with 7 Malaysian companies banned by the US for using "forced labour".

site_title: Biden considering move on Chinese goods tariffs
summary: US Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo announced that the Biden administration is considering cutting some tariffs on Chinese imports, weighing short-term price reduction goals against long-term unfair competition concerns. The tariffs, imposed by the Trump administration in 2018, are seen as a way to address high inflation, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen advocating for cutting "non-strategic" tariffs on consumer goods. The decision will be influenced by whether the tariffs create a level playing field for American firms and workers.

images.alt_text: epa09257513 People work in the Ningbo Zhoushan Port in Ningbo, Zhejiang province, China, 09 June 2021. The Ningbo-Zhoushan is a port that claims to be the busiest in the world in terms of cargo tonnage. China?s exports grew by 27.9 percent year-to-year in May 2021. Furthermore, imports grew by 51.1 percent last month, according to the National Bureau of Statistics report on 7 June 2021.  EPA-EFE/Alex Plavevski##########kelchina##########EPA-

site_title: China to halve purchase tax for small-engine cars
summary: China's Ministry of Finance announced a tax cut on small-engine cars to boost auto sales. The tax will be halved to 5% for cars priced under 300,000 yuan (S$61,728) with 2.0-liter or smaller engines. The measure, effective from June 1, 2022, aims to relieve car buyers of 60 billion yuan worth of purchase taxes amid a 48% decline in sales in April. The tax cut applies to popular models such as Nissan's Sylphy, Volkswagen's Lavida, and Great Wall Motor's Haval H6.

site_title: German unemployment falls more than expected in May as pandemic curbs ease
summary: Germany's unemployment rate fell by 4,000 in May, reaching 2.285 million, exceeding expectations of a 15,000 decrease. Despite the war in Ukraine and supply bottlenecks, trade and services benefited from the easing of pandemic restrictions. The jobless rate remained at 5.0% in seasonally adjusted terms. Demand for new personnel grew rapidly, with 865,000 jobs registered in May, and short-time work decreased.

images.alt_text: Employees work in a production hall of German ladder, stool and scaffold-maker Guenzburger Steigtechnik, at the company's headquarters in Guenzburg, southern Germany, on January 25, 2022. - On January 28, 2022, the federal statistics agency will publish German growth figures for the fourth quarter, with early signs indicating Europe's largest economy shrank by "between 0.5 and one percent," curtailed by supply chain woes. At Munk, the company has had difficulties sourcing rubber feet for ladders and aluminium, the production of which was troubled by a short supply of magnesium from China. (Photo by THOMAS KIENZLE / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY by Sebastien ASH

site_title: US home-price appreciation accelerates for fourth month
summary: US home prices rose 21.2% in the 20 cities tracked by the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index, the fourth consecutive month of growth. Tampa, Florida, saw the largest gains, with prices jumping 34.8% year-over-year. Despite higher mortgage rates and economic uncertainty, prices are expected to continue growing, with Craig Lazzara warning that a deceleration may be on the horizon.

site_title: As supply chain patterns evolve, Asean is more relevant than ever
summary: Standard Chartered's Patrick Lee and Andrew Chia argue that Asean offers the best advantages when businesses take a regional approach, rather than focusing on a single country or business area. As global trade is becoming increasingly regionalized, Asean is poised to become the world's fourth-largest economy by 2030, driven by its diverse markets, high growth rates, and sustainable development goals. Companies can capitalize on Asean's unique opportunities by adopting a comprehensive, pan-Asean strategy, leveraging the region's position at the intersection of global trends.

site_title: First non-enhanced dollar bond from a China property developer in 2022 is just US$100m
summary: SEAZEN Group, a Shanghai-based property developer, has issued the first non-enhanced dollar bond from a China property developer since 2022, worth US$100 million. The bond has a 7.95% coupon rate and matures in June 2023. The sale may signal a market recovery, but Fitch Ratings notes that Seazen's liquidity is adequate and the developer's credit ratings were downgraded to "BB" in April due to concentrated debt maturities. The bond sale is seen as a test of investor appetite for China's highly indebted property development sector, which has been battered by a liquidity squeeze.

images.alt_text: Bonds in almost every corner of the US$63 trillion global debt market are bouncing back as investors begin to see value once again in fixed-income assets.
RATINGS agency Standard & Poor's (S&P) on Monday (May 30) downgraded Chinese state-backed property developer Greenland over fears the company would default on a bond payment.
There has been little corporate bond activity from Chinese real estate developers after much of the industry became gripped by a liquidity squeeze last year.

site_title: Singapore’s May market cap up 0.7% largely on Nio inclusion; STI value falls 3.3%
summary: Singapore's market capitalization rose 0.7% to S$880.8 billion in May, driven by the secondary listing of Chinese EV maker Nio, which debuted on the Singapore Exchange in May and became the 7th largest stock by market cap. However, the STI value fell 3.3% to S$535.3 billion, with 358 losers outweighing 138 gainers. Analysts attribute the decline to global risk-off mood and ex-dividend date for major banks. Despite this, the STI remains in positive territory year-to-date with a 6% total return.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Of the 30 STI constituent stocks, two-thirds have managed to generate positive total returns.
Of the 657 counters listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in April, losers outnumbered gainers 259 to 227.

site_title: Salesforce raises profit forecast on resilient demand for business software
summary: Salesforce raised its annual profit forecast, citing resilient demand for business software despite macroeconomic instability. The company now expects fiscal-year earnings of $4.74-$4.76 per share, a 12-cent increase from its previous forecast. Revenue is projected at $31.8 billion. The shares rose about 6% in extended trading. This move suggests business software demand is holding up, contrasting with the tech sector's slowing hiring and travel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: People pass by the Salesforce Tower and Salesforce.com offices in New York City, U.S., March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Keppel unit begins arbitration proceedings to claim S$173 million in Qatar project spat
summary: Keppel Corporation's subsidiary, Keppel Seghers Engineering Singapore (KSES), has initiated arbitration proceedings against the Qatar Public Works Authority (PWA) over a disputed contract for the Doha North Sewage Treatment Works project in Qatar. The arbitration seeks approximately S$173 million in damages, including interest. The proceedings are expected to take at least 3 years to complete. Keppel aims to resolve the claims through amicable settlement discussions with PWA. The arbitration is not expected to significantly impact Keppel's operations or financial performance in the current year.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

pixkeppel - Keppel provides solutions for sustainable urbanisation. The picture depicts staff at the Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant inspecting the filtration membranes used in the water treatment process.

site_title: Treasuries slide as inflation fears eat away at May rally
summary: Treasuries slid as inflation fears resurfaced, partially undoing a rally that had put the securities on track for their first monthly gain since November. US sovereign yields rose, driven by oil's 2-month high and European inflation data exceeding forecasts. Hawkish comments from Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller and month-end portfolio rebalancing also contributed to the sell-off. Despite the decline, the 10-year yield remains 40 basis points below its peak earlier this month, as investors seek value in fixed-income assets amid the trade-off between inflation and monetary policy tightening.

images.alt_text: Bonds in almost every corner of the US$63 trillion global debt market are bouncing back as investors begin to see value once again in fixed-income assets.
Bond bulls have regained the upper hand in the Treasury market, on course for its first monthly gain since November.,

site_title: Dimensional ESG chief adds to criticism of investing style
summary: Dimensional Fund Advisors' head of responsible investment, James Whittington, has expressed doubts about the effectiveness of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investing, citing a lack of hard evidence that it alters companies' cost of capital or achieves change. Whittington's comments join a growing chorus of criticism, with some ESG strategies being characterized as "blah, blah, blah." A recent study found that ESG funds generally perform better than conventional products, but ESG equity funds have had a poor start to 2022, with many losing significant value.

images.alt_text: Staff inside the bank have sought reassurances about its policies amid concerns about how HSBC will be perceived by clients, 2 other sources said.

The solar farm of Marcoussis, south of Paris;  the demand to shift away from fossil fuels is, if anything, now accelerating due to the current Ukraine situation; Europe has increased its renewable energy target from 40 per cent to 45 per cent by 2030.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 27.08 points to 1,570.10. The market saw a gain of 535 to 395 gainer-to-loser ratio. The total trading volume was 3.798 billion lots worth RM6.116 billion.

site_title: Ukrainian troops hold out as Russia assaults Sievierodonetsk wasteland
summary: Ukrainian forces are holding out in the besieged city of Sievierodonetsk, resisting Russia's all-out assault to capture the city. Despite both sides claiming control of the city, fighting continues, and thousands of residents remain trapped. Russia has drained manpower and firepower from other fronts to concentrate on Sievierodonetsk, hoping to secure surrounding Luhansk province for separatist proxies. The EU has agreed to ban Russian oil imports, which could halt two-thirds of Russia's oil exports to Europe, but critics say the sanctions are too slow and inadequate.

images.alt_text: European Union leaders agreed to pursue a partial ban on Russian oil, paving the way for a sixth package of sanctions to punish Russia and its president, Vladimir Putin, for the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Prices of mass market property launches could hit record high as developers face cost constraints
summary: Mass market property launches in Singapore may see record-high prices due to cost constraints. Elevated land costs, increased construction and material costs, and limited inventory are driving prices up, with suburban projects trending close to or above S$2,000 per square foot (psf). Analysts expect prices in the Outside Central Region (OCR) to range from S$1,900 to S$2,300 psf, while Core Central Region (CCR) launches could see prices averaging S$2,800 to S$2,900 psf. Rising interest rates will also impact developers, with buyers potentially turning to the HDB market or seeking inflation-hedge real estate assets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Price gap between RCR and CCR homes narrows in March
City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land has launched its 407-unit condominium Piccadilly Grand, with previews starting Saturday (Apr 23) and sales booking scheduled for 2 weeks later on May 7.
Bukit Sembawang Estates' Liv @ MB sold more than 75 per cent of its 298 units on its launch weekend.

site_title: Corporate espionage is entering a new era
summary: Corporate espionage is entering its golden age due to the increasing value of intellectual property and the growing sophistication of online hackers. A recent court case awarded $2bn in damages to Appian after it accused Pegasystems of illegally snooping to gain a competitive edge. This case illustrates how business espionage is no longer limited to sensitive industries, but is now a general business risk targeting smaller companies in various sectors.

images.alt_text: A laptop screen displays a warning message in Ukrainian, Russian and Polish. The message appeared on the official website of the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry after a cyberattack, Jan 14, 2022.

site_title: Australia heading for third bumper crop on record plantings
summary: Australia is poised for a potential "hat trick" of bumper crops, with winter plantings forecast to reach a record 23.8 million hectares. Canola seeding is up 20% from last year, while wheat sowing is expected to climb 1.4%. Favorable seasonal conditions are bolstering the production outlook, with Australia set for an "above-average" grain harvest for the third consecutive year.

site_title: Sri Lanka appeals for farmers to plant more rice as food shortage looms
summary: Sri Lanka urges farmers to plant more rice to avert a severe food shortage, amid a 50% predicted drop in production that would worsen its financial crisis. The country, facing its worst crisis in over seven decades, has run out of foreign exchange reserves and is struggling to import fuel, food, and medicine. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera requested farmers to cultivate paddy in the next five to ten days to address the looming food shortage.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said on May 26 that he’s looking to fast-track talks with the IMF as the nation will need about US$4 billion this year from the multilateral lender and creditors including China and Japan.

site_title: Britain's GSK to buy Affinivax for up to US$3.3b in vaccines push
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) plans to acquire privately held biopharmaceutical firm Affinivax for up to $3.3 billion to bolster its vaccine pipeline. The deal aims to strengthen GSK's position as the world's largest vaccine maker by sales. Affinivax is developing next-generation vaccines for pneumococcal diseases, including pneumonia and meningitis. This acquisition follows GSK's recent $1.9 billion purchase of Sierra Oncology to bolster its cancer business, demonstrating the company's appetite for further deals to expand its pipeline.

site_title: A Strategic Compass for security and defence
summary: The European Union has approved the Strategic Compass, a plan to strengthen its security and defence policy by 2030. The EU has responded to Russia's aggression against Ukraine with measures, including supporting the Ukrainian Armed Forces. However, a deteriorating security environment in Asia and growing global threats, including climate change, pose significant challenges. The EU must balance its security priorities with interdependence and soft power competition, as conflicts and instability are increasingly linked to economic and energy coercion. The EU must navigate this complex landscape to ensure stability and security.

images.alt_text: Advancing the EU's strategy for cooperation in the Indo-Pacific

site_title: Sri Lanka inflation hits close to 40% as shortages persist
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation soared to 39.1% in May, exceeding expectations and hitting a record high, as food and fuel shortages persist. Food inflation surged 57.4% and non-food items rose 30.6%. The country needs $4 billion in emergency funds but a deal with the International Monetary Fund remains elusive, requiring structural reforms that could worsen the economic crisis.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank initiates ‘buy’ on ST Engineering amid aerospace sector recovery
summary: Maybank Securities has initiated a "buy" call on ST Engineering with a target price of S$4.75, citing the company's recent acquisition and contract wins, as well as the recovering aerospace landscape, as key drivers of revenue visibility. The research team expects compound annual growth rate of 9.9% for urban and satellite communications solutions, and rising defence spending to boost international sales. However, the team is "prudentily below consensus" with its estimates due to concerns on a slower Asia's aviation sector and global chip shortage.

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil giant FGV swings to profit in Q1 earnings
summary: Malaysia's palm oil giant FGV reported a net profit of RM369.2 million in the first quarter, a significant turnaround from a loss of RM35.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue jumped 73% to RM5.85 billion, driven by higher crude palm oil prices and improved sales volume. The company attributes the profit to elevated crude palm oil prices and expects a positive impact on its financial result for 2022. FGV also expects a gradual recovery in labour shortages, with migrant workers expected to arrive from the third quarter onwards.

images.alt_text: Malaysian authorities will discuss a possible review of the policy on palm kernel cake exports, which can be used as animal feed, in an effort to stabilise chicken supplies in the country, the commodities ministry said on Tuesday.
Malaysian plantations have been struggling to harvest palm fruit due to a labour shortage exacerbated by pandemic-related border closures.

Indonesia, the world’s top palm oil producer, allowed exports of the vegetable oil to resume from May 23, but companies have faced regulatory hurdles that have slowed the process of getting shipments out.
Malaysia is still reviewing the viability of a temporary cut of a crude palm oil export tax, the Commodities Ministry said on Friday, after Indonesia lifted an export ban that has rattled the market.

site_title: Singapore equities: Shelter in the storm
summary: Singapore equities are seen as a safe haven amid global market uncertainties, with bank stocks likely to lead the way. Despite rising interest and inflation rates, Singapore's macro conditions appear robust, supporting the market's potential for further upside over the next 12 months. The country is set for above-trend GDP growth in 2022, driven by recovery in the domestic-oriented and travel-related sectors. Bank stocks, in particular, are well-positioned given their historical correlation with GDP growth, interest rates, and SGD appreciation, making them a viable alternative to real estate stocks as an inflation hedge.

site_title: British airport disruption ominous for global travel recovery
summary: Disruptions at British airports, including cancelled flights and staff shortages, have caused chaos during the half-term break, potentially foreshadowing summer strife for the global aviation sector. Airlines have cancelled dozens of flights and removed seats to address staffing issues, with some tempering summer growth forecasts. The British government has urged airlines to have enough staff to meet demand, while consumer rights groups have called for airlines to not sell tickets for routes with insufficient staff. Similar issues have been reported at airports in Germany, Ireland, and Sweden.

images.alt_text: The time needed to get security badges for newly hired staff has risen from 3 to 4 weeks in Britain, for example, to as long as 3 months, Willie Walsh, director general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA), said.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz lays first stone of new battery cell campus in Germany
summary: Mercedes-Benz has laid the first stone of a new research and development campus in Germany, investing a 3-digit-million euro sum to research, design, and produce battery cells starting in 2023. The campus, set to include a battery safety lab by 2025, aims to secure the carmaker's control over its battery supply chain, with CEO Ola Kallenius stating that the battery is a key component of electromobility.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Mercedes logo is seen during the Munich Auto Show, IAA Mobility 2021 in Munich, Germany, September 8, 2021. REUTERS/Michaela Rehle/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas says Q1 profit doubles, but cautious over outlook
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas reported a higher profit of RM23.4 billion (S$7.3 billion) for its first quarter, driven by a 50% increase in revenue to RM78.8 billion. The profit was 154% higher than the previous year, but Petronas' President and Group CEO expressed caution over an uncertain outlook due to geopolitical conditions and the shift towards renewable energy sources, despite benefiting from an elevated price environment.

site_title: Russian central bank downplays role of US dollar, euro at home and globally
summary: Russia's central bank suggests the decline of the US dollar and euro as global currencies due to Western sanctions freezing around half of Russia's gold and forex reserves. The bank may consider imposing negative interest rates on US dollar and euro deposits to speed up the decline. This trend is expected to prompt other central banks, primarily in Asia and the Middle East, to rethink their strategies for their savings. The decline in foreign currency assets and increase in gold demand are also expected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: National flag flies over the Russian Central Bank headquarters in Moscow, Russia May 27, 2022. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on brighter China outlook, strong foreign buying
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index rose 16.24 points, or 0.61%, to 2,685.90, its highest close since May 2, driven by strong foreign buying amid improved China's economic outlook. The won hit a near 6-week high, while bond yields jumped. Foreigners bought 1.06 trillion won worth of shares, the largest daily purchase since August 2021, and the won strengthened 1.51% against the dollar for the month.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 31.61 points, or 1.2 per cent, at 2,669.66, the highest close since May 4.

site_title: Hyundai has a climate dilemma at one of world’s top car plants
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. is reviewing alternatives to a gas-fired power station at one of its major automobile plants in South Korea, amid criticism that the decision contradicts the company's pledge to shift entirely to clean energy by 2040. The Ulsan factory, which produces 1.4 million vehicles annually, is set to be supplied with electricity from a liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility. Climate-focused groups argue that the LNG plant won't align with Hyundai's climate goals, citing volatility in gas prices and declining renewable energy costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Hyundai Motor Company is pictured at the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 13, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Philippines complains of Chinese fishing ban and 'harassment' at sea
summary: The Philippines has filed a diplomatic protest with China for imposing a fishing ban in the South China Sea and for harassing and violating its jurisdiction by Beijing's coast guard. The protest comes after a joint marine scientific research mission and energy exploration activities were disrupted by Chinese vessels. The Philippines' foreign ministry accused China's actions as "clear violations of the Philippine maritime jurisdiction" and "not consistent with innocent passage." The move may pose a challenge for President-elect Ferdinand Marcos, who aims to balance economic ties with China while defending the country's sovereignty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Philippine Coast Guard personnel survey several ships believed to be Chinese militia vessels in Sabina Shoal in the South China Sea, in a handout photo distributed by the Philippine Coast Guard on May 5 and taken according to source on April 27, 2021. Philippine Coast Guard/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES./File Photo

site_title: Europe: Record high inflation pushes shares to session lows
summary: Europe's shares plummeted to session lows on Tuesday as a record-high inflation rate of 8.1% in May fueled bets of larger interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank. The Stoxx index dropped 1.3% and the Stoxx 600 index fell 0.7%, with eurozone banks sliding 1.6% due to concerns over the economy's impact from surging prices. Despite some outperforming sectors, investors remain cautious about the economic outlook and ECB's stance, with market expectations of quicker rate hikes.

site_title: Which side of an EY breakup do you want to be on?
summary: EY may split its audit and consulting businesses, creating a standalone auditor to address conflicts of interest and regulatory scrutiny. The UK's competition watchdog previously called for operational separation, and EY may preempt tougher regulation by creating distinct companies. A breakup could make audit more attractive, offering sophisticated checks on non-financial performance and potentially improving audit quality. However, attracting and retaining talent without consulting services remains a challenge, and regulators will need to make audit more enticing as a long-term career.

images.alt_text: audit, auditor, analysis

site_title: More than 50% of global car buyers considering electric vehicles for the first time: EY
summary: Global car buyers are increasingly considering electric vehicles, with 52% of buyers interested in EVs, a 22% rise in two years. The main motivators for this shift are environmental concerns and rising penalties on internal combustion engine vehicles. Consumers are willing to pay a premium for EVs, with 88% willing to pay more. The top motivators for second-time EV buyers are longer ranges and improved charging infrastructure, with 81% using home-charging facilities at least once a week.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Motor insurance is big business in Singapore, and insurers have to enter the electric vehicle market eventually, said experts.

The small number of EVs in Singapore, its more expensive parts, wariness over new technologies, as well as the lack of equipped mechanics have been cited by insurers, industry experts as well as academics as the main reasons for the lack of EV insurance, despite the wider push for EV adoption.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open lower on inflation fears; Powell-Biden talks in focus
summary: The S&P 500 and Dow Jones opened lower on Tuesday due to soaring oil prices and hawkish comments from a Federal Reserve official. Investors are also focused on talks between US President Joe Biden and Fed Chair Jerome Powell later in the day. The Dow Jones fell 0.16% to 33,160.59, while the S&P 500 opened 0.17% lower at 4,151.09, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.05%.

site_title: After delay, IOI Properties’ Central Boulevard office project may be coming to market at opportune time
summary: IOI Properties' long-awaited office project along Central Boulevard in Singapore is scheduled to receive a Temporary Occupation Permit in the third quarter of 2023. The project, which was initially targeted for completion this year, has faced delays due to technical constraints and construction disruption. Tech giants Amazon and Meta are reportedly in advanced discussions to lease offices at the project, which could pave the way for IOI to achieve its target of S$12-14 psf a month in gross effective average rent. The developer may also consider selling one of the two towers, given its overall breakeven cost of about S$3,030 psf.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
IOI Central Boulevard Towers will have about 1.26 million sq ft of offices and 30,000 sq ft of retail space.
IOI Properties' S$1.508b sole bid for Marina View white site surprises market
IOI's lone bet on Marina View is on an endemic future, 7 years on

site_title: Companies should set measurable, practical targets in their sustainability reports: KPMG
summary: Companies in Singapore should set measurable and practical targets in their sustainability reports, rather than lofty and aspirational ones, to demonstrate their active management of environmental, social, and governance risks. This is according to Ian Hong of KPMG, who emphasizes the need for companies to collect operational data to measure performance against set targets. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) requires listed companies to issue sustainability reports, which must include measurable targets, to ensure transparency and accuracy.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Pure Senses, a leading retailer of fragrance and beauty products such as Yankee Candle rolled out Purely – a new retail concept incorporating circularity.

There has been a perceptible change in the mindsets of retail investors in their investment preference for sustainable eco-friendly public-listed businesses as opposed to merely buying on hope, holding in greed and selling in fear.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares slip on rising US yield
summary: Tokyo stocks slipped 0.33% on May 31, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 89.63 points to 27,279.80, due to rising US yields. The broader Topix index also dropped 0.51% to 1,912.67. Investors are concerned about the impact of rising US yields on the global market.

site_title: Japan's April factory output slumps in sign of pressure on economy
summary: Japan's factory output dropped 1.3% in April from the previous month, with sharp falls in electronic parts and production machinery production. The decline was weaker than expected and the first in three months. Supply disruptions, including China's Covid-19 lockdowns, and higher material prices due to Russia's war in Ukraine are putting pressure on the economy. Despite this, retail sales rose 2.9% in April, and consumer confidence is expected to continue improving. Analysts predict a 4.5% annualized GDP growth this quarter, with a majority expecting a recovery to pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Japan's consumer confidence index rose in May for a second straight month
Toyota has managed to continue outpacing VW, despite coming up short of a production target last month that the company had pared back due to the spread of Covid-19 in Japan and overseas.

JAPAN'S government made no mention of a timeframe for balancing the primary budget in its draft mid-year annual long-term economic policy roadmap, 2 government sources with knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Europe: Markets mainly dip at open
summary: Europe's main equity markets dropped at the open on May 31, 2022, amid stubborn inflation fears. The Frankfurt DAX index fell 0.7% and the Paris CAC 40 dropped 0.6%, while London's FTSE 100 gained 0.1%. The French economy shrank in the first quarter, contributing to the market decline. Asian markets fluctuated due to ongoing inflation concerns and rising oil prices, with a top Federal Reserve official pressing for interest rate hikes.

site_title: China rushes bond sales to spur Covid-hit economy, more seen needed
summary: China is rushing to issue $225 billion in bonds in June to revive its Covid-battered economy, with analysts calling for further debt issuance in the second half. The government has approved new infrastructure and energy projects, and aims to complete $3.45 trillion in special bond issuance by the end of June. This move may increase market liquidity pressure and prompt the central bank to inject more cash into the economy. Economists expect China's economy to contract in the April-June quarter, and more stimulus may be needed to sustain growth.

images.alt_text: China's cabinet unveiled a package of 33 measures covering fiscal, financial, investment and industrial policies on Tuesday (May 31) to revive a pandemic-ravaged economy, saying it will inspect how provincial governments implement them.

site_title: US: Stocks resume decline amid inflation, consumer worries
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, retreating from last week's rally, amid concerns over inflation, Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, and weakening consumer confidence. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.4%. The decline was partly due to record eurozone inflation and US consumer confidence slipping in May, with investors expressing unease about the job market. Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller's comments on interest rate hikes also contributed to the market's downturn.

site_title: BNP Paribas to hire 7,000 people in France in 2022
summary: BNP Paribas plans to hire up to 7,000 people in France this year, focusing on retail and corporate services, IT, and support functions. The recruitment effort is part of its strategy to drive growth through technology and sustainable finance through 2025. The bank will allocate 3,000 roles to permanent employees and the rest to apprentices and interns. This hiring announcement comes as the financial sector faces increased competition for staff, with peers warning of higher pay demands.

site_title: Ukraine’s Zelenskiy blasts ‘crazy’ Russia over chemical plant hit
summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy accused Russia of "madness" after Russian troops hit a chemical plant in Severodonetsk, a key eastern city, amid the ongoing war. The attack has caused heavy casualties and damaged infrastructure, with Zelenskiy warning of the risks to civilians. Meanwhile, European Union leaders are split over banning Russian gas, with some calling for action to tighten economic pressure on Moscow. The US State Department has expressed support for EU efforts to cut off Russia's war machine, while Russia's invasion threatens a global food crisis and Ukraine's grain harvest.

site_title: India’s economy lost speed on virus curbs and war in Ukraine
summary: India's economy grew 8.7% in the year to March 2022, slower than estimated, due to virus curbs and the war in Europe adding inflation hurdles. The January-March quarter expansion of 4.1% marked the low point of the year, indicating a slower-than-expected growth.

images.alt_text: A daily wage worker goes about with his routine work at an wholesale market in the walled city area of the capital near New Delhi on February 1, 2022. (Photo by Sajjad HUSSAIN / AFP)

site_title: SBF pilots ‘Landing Pad’ programme to introduce more Singapore firms to Indonesia
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has launched the "Landing Pad" programme, a 21-day immersion experience for Singapore-based companies to enter the Indonesian market. The programme aims to provide networking opportunities and ongoing support to accelerate international business. Indonesia is a key market for Singapore, with bilateral trade valued at S$59.1 billion in 2021, and SBF hopes to help more Singapore businesses achieve success in the country. The programme is part of the Singapore Enterprise Centre (SEC) @ Jakarta, which was launched in 2021.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in China's economy  could mean less investment in Indonesia's infrastructure sector, but what would hurt the Southeast Asian country more is the export ban of palm oil

site_title: 4,985 new Covid-19 cases reported in Singapore, up from 2,389 cases on May 30
summary: Singapore reported 4,985 new Covid-19 cases on May 31, more than double the 2,389 cases on May 30. Hospitalized cases totaled 330, with 11 in intensive care and 38 requiring oxygen support. Three deaths were reported. Locally transmitted cases accounted for 4,774 new cases, with 211 imported cases. The weekly infection growth rate stood at 0.82, down from 0.95 the day before. Singapore has recorded a total of 1,303,294 Covid-19 cases and 1,389 deaths.

images.alt_text: People from different walks of life at a pedestrian crossing at Jurong East (Jurong Gateway Road), April 8, 2022.

site_title: Fidelity's crypto unit to double down on hiring this year
summary: Fidelity's digital assets arm plans to double down on hiring this year to expand its resources and serve clients investing in 24/7-trading crypto assets. The company aims to fill 110 new positions in client services, technology, and operations, focusing on assets beyond bitcoin. As demand for digital assets continues to grow, Fidelity Digital Assets, which currently employs nearly 200 people, will continue to expand its hiring efforts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of virtual cryptocurrencies are placed on U.S. Dollar banknotes in this illustration taken November 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Bankrupt Sri Lanka hikes taxes
summary: Sri Lanka has implemented steep tax hikes, including a 4% increase in the value-added tax (VAT) to 12% and a 6% increase in corporate taxes to 30%, in an effort to shore up revenue amid its worst economic downturn. The tax increases, which take effect immediately, also lower the personal income tax exemption threshold from 3 million rupees to 1.8 million rupees. The moves are part of the country's efforts to secure an IMF bailout and address a budget deficit of around 800 billion rupees.

images.alt_text: SRI LANKA’S headline inflation quickened more than expected in May amid continuing food and fuel shortages, even as the country struggles to lift itself out of its worst economic crisis.

site_title: Iata says post-pandemic airport chaos will get fixed
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) director general, Willie Walsh, has called for calm amidst recent travel chaos at some airports, citing temporary delays in getting clearances for new staff. The time needed to get security badges for new staff has risen from 3 weeks to 3 months in some countries. Walsh attributed the issue to the gridlock and warned that growing pilot shortages in the US could spread. Despite concerns about inflation and lower disposable incomes affecting future travel spending, Walsh stated that demand is currently "very, very strong" and expected to recapture 2019 pre-pandemic levels by 2023.

site_title: Malaysia may review palm kernel cake exports to secure chicken feed supply
summary: Malaysian authorities plan to review the export policy on palm kernel cake, which can be used as animal feed, to stabilize chicken supplies amid soaring prices. The country will halt all chicken exports from June and discuss steps to ensure the availability of palm kernel waste as animal feed for the domestic poultry industry. The review aims to address the global shortage of chicken feed caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and uncertain weather patterns.

images.alt_text: Malaysian plantations have been struggling to harvest palm fruit due to a labour shortage exacerbated by pandemic-related border closures.

Bunches of fresh palm oil fruit from Indonesia's Riau province.  Uncertainty over sunflower oil supplies due to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has spurred demand for rivals palm and soy oil as importers seek alternatives, fuelling a red-hot vegetable oil market.

site_title: Crude oil prices could scorch this summer
summary: Crude oil prices surged past $120 a barrel on May 31, driven by China's easing of lockdown curbs, the EU's ban on Russian oil, and the start of the US and European summer driving seasons. Experts predict further upside, with some forecasting prices could reach $150, $180, or even $250 a barrel in 2023. The global supply crunch, worsened by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, is expected to remain tight, with limited spare capacity from Opec and potential sanctions on Russian oil further increasing the risk of higher prices.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
European Union leaders agreed to pursue a partial ban on Russian oil, paving the way for a sixth package of sanctions to punish Russia and its president, Vladimir Putin, for the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Australian house prices drop for first time since September 2020
summary: Australian house prices have dropped for the first time in 20 months, with Sydney and Melbourne leading the decline. Sydney fell 1% and Melbourne 0.7% in May, resulting in a 0.3% drop in the combined capital cities index. Higher interest rates and a rising supply of properties are dampening demand, according to CoreLogic. This marks a shift from the significant gains seen during the pandemic, as rising expectations of further policy tightening and high house prices are cooling buyer ardor. Annual growth in home values in capital cities slowed to 11.7%.

site_title: China’s home sales slump persisted in May during lockdowns
summary: China's home sales plummeted 59% in May from a year earlier, with Covid outbreaks in key cities overshadowing efforts to revive buyer confidence. The decline matches April's drop, adding to the sector's woes due to strict lockdowns and liquidity crisis. Authorities stepped up efforts to salvage the market by urging banks to lend more and easing rules on owning multiple properties. This is the second consecutive month of decline in home sales, further exacerbating the property sector's struggles.

site_title: Oil turns negative as Opec eyes Russia suspension from output deal
summary: Oil prices turned negative on June 1, 2022, after reports suggested OPEC+ might suspend Russia's participation in the production deal. This move could lead to an increase in output from Saudi Arabia and the UAE. Despite this, oil prices rose 1% in May, with Brent crude reaching $122.84 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate settling at $114.67 a barrel. The European Union agreed to a partial ban on Russian oil, while China lifted Covid-19 restrictions, supporting prices.

images.alt_text: Gas prices over the $8.00 mark are advertised at a Chevron Station in Los Angeles, California, U.S., May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson

site_title: Trade liberalisation remains central to US Pacific strategy
summary: US President Joe Biden has unveiled the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF), a critical geo-economic and geo-strategic initiative to promote economic prosperity in the region. The framework, supported by 12 regional partners, aims to encourage cooperation on supply chain resiliency, digital economy rules, and clean energy infrastructure. However, the lack of access to US markets remains a key concern for IPEF participants, and the Biden administration must convince lawmakers to liberalize US trade policies to achieve its goals.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida attend the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) launch event at Izumi Garden Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, May 23. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst
US President Joe Biden speaks about the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity at the Izumi Garden Gallery in Tokyo.

US President Joe Biden, now on a tour of Asia, with India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida at the launch of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) in Tokyo on Monday (May 23).

site_title: Conservation hotel in Little India put on the market with S$62-66m guide price
summary: Aqueen Heritage Hotel Little India, a 68-key conservation hotel in Singapore, has been put up for sale with a guide price of S$62-66 million. Located at 22 Belilios Lane, the property features 12 adjoining conservation shophouses with attics, retail and F&B spaces, and 2 passenger lifts. The hotel is a 6-minute walk from Little India MRT Interchange Station. The sale is via expression of interest, with joint marketing agents Savills Singapore and CBRE handling the process.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The improvement in industrywide room revenue came as both occupancies and average room rates picked up further in April.

site_title: Malaysia Airport Holdings narrows losses in Q1 as tourism picks up
summary: Malaysia Airport Holdings Berhad (MAHB) reported a narrowed loss of RM104.76 million in Q1 2022, compared to a loss of RM221.3 million in the same period last year, due to increased revenue and passenger traffic. International travel is picking up, with daily average international passengers reaching 33,407 in May 2022. The company expects passenger traffic to spike by 5 times year-on-year in 2022, reaching 60% of pre-pandemic levels. Analysts are positive on the company's future growth prospects, with some predicting a return to profitability in the near future.

images.alt_text: As Malaysia reopens to the world, airlines see healthy pick-up in flight bookings

site_title: DeLorean shows off electric car, says it will arrive in 2024
summary: DeLorean Motor Co. has unveiled its new electric car, the Alpha5, set to arrive in 2024. The modern gullwing coupe features a softly rounded design, thin white headlights, and a long red taillight band. It boasts a 0-60 mph time of 2.9 seconds and a top speed of 155 mph. Unlike its predecessor, the Alpha5 is designed to be street-legal and will not have hypercar speed. The company is registering interest in the Alpha5 on its website, but it is unclear if deposits are being taken.

images.alt_text: THE number of car buyers worldwide looking to buy an electric vehicle (EV) has exceeded 50 per cent for the first time.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing on new inflation, rates concerns
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Tuesday amid concerns over inflation and interest rates, with oil prices rising after the European Union reached a deal on a partial embargo of Russian imports. Crude prices broke above $122 for the first time in two months, further fueling inflation and pressure on central banks to tighten monetary policy. US Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expressed support for sharp interest rate hikes to slow inflation, increasing the likelihood of extended rate hikes and a stronger US dollar.

site_title: Global regulators push ahead with crypto bank capital rules
summary: Global regulators plan to complete work by year's end on establishing capital rules for banks holding cryptocurrencies. Proposed capital requirements for banks to cover losses on bitcoin holdings are expected to be finalized. Certain tokenized traditional assets and stablecoins will be subject to existing capital rules, potentially being treated like bonds or commodities.

images.alt_text: If you need a reminder that memories are short in the world of crypto, look no further than the relaunch of the Luna token that played a key role in the collapse of the Terra blockchain ecosystem that cost investors billions little more than 2 weeks ago.

site_title: Richard Li-backed insurer FWD said to postpone Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: FWD Group Holdings, an Asian insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, has postponed its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) due to market volatility. The company had won approval for its IPO in May but decided to delay the share sale. FWD is seeking to raise about US$1 billion and had previously filed an application for the first-time share sale in February. The insurer's decision comes amid a slump in new share sales in Hong Kong due to market woes, including rising inflation and the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start with small loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, May 31, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.08% to 21,106.41, following a 5% gain over the previous two days. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were also barely moved. This comes after a brief trading break, allowing investors to reassess their positions after the recent market surge.

site_title: China's services sector activity contracts less sharply in May: official PMI
summary: China's services sector activity contracted less sharply in May, according to an official survey, as Covid-19 restrictions in some cities were relaxed. The non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 47.8, from 41.9 in April, indicating a contraction but less severe than in the previous month. This easing of restrictions suggests a potential slowdown in China's economic contraction, although the overall GDP growth is still expected to slow.

site_title: Smart ring that acts as wallet and key gets backing from big Japanese firms: sources
summary: Japanese companies Itochu, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, and Daiwa House Industry are investing in Evering, a chip-embedded smart ring that acts as a wallet and key. The ring, developed by Evering Corp., can lock and unlock doors, and pay for goods without touching anything. MTG, the listed Japanese health and beauty company, has partnered with Visa and is raising about 1 billion yen from investors. The smart ring may eventually seek a public listing, with potential backers including Toppan. The investment aims to capitalize on the trend of touchless payments.

images.alt_text: THE parent company of India's ShareChat has raised nearly US$300 million in fresh funding from Alphabet's Google, media giant Times Group and Singapore's Temasek Holdings, valuing the social media firm at nearly US$5 billion, 2 sources involved in the deal discussions told Reuters.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap two-day winning streak as tech, financials drag
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.3% on Tuesday, snapping a two-day winning streak, as tech and financial stocks fell. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 2.2% for the month. Global markets were lifted by eased Covid-19 restrictions in China and new stimulus measures. Technology stocks dropped 1%, with Block Inc. down 3.3%, while financials fell 0.4%. Energy stocks remained steady despite rising oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6%.

site_title: Christie's to offer rare first edition 'Harry Potter' book in private sale
summary: A rare first edition of J.K. Rowling's 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone' is up for private sale at Christie's auction house in London, starting from £200,000. The 1997 hardback copy, one of 500 printed, has errors such as a misspelled word on the back cover and a repeated item on page 53. The book is among 200 copies being sold as part of Christie's 'The Art of Literature' exhibition, which is open to the public from June 7-15. The sale is highly desirable due to its connection to the beloved book series.

images.alt_text: A person holds a rare first edition and signed by the author copy of 'Harry Potter and the Philosophers Stone' by British author J.K. Rowling, which is to be put up for auction at Christie's auction house in London, Britain May 31, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Macquarie Asset Management raises US$4.2b for Asia-Pacific fund
summary: Macquarie Asset Management has raised US$4.2 billion for its third Asia-Pacific regional infrastructure fund, exceeding its US$3 billion target. The fund, launched in 2020, received commitments from institutional investors, including pension funds and sovereign wealth funds. This brings the total capital managed for Asia-Pacific infrastructure to over US$15 billion. The fund's head, Frank Kwok, attributes the success to the region's maturing infrastructure markets and positive long-term outlook.

site_title: Hot stock: SATS hits 2-week low after earnings miss analyst expectations
summary: SATS, a food solutions and gateway services provider, hit a 2-week low after reporting a net profit of S$7.2 million for the second half of 2022, missing analyst expectations. The stock dropped 4.2% to S$4.35, with an operating loss of S$46.6 million due to higher costs and lower government grants. Despite this, analysts believe recovery in the travel segment will see stronger traction in the coming quarters, with DBS Group Research maintaining a "buy" rating and a target price of S$4.90.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The exterior of Sats Coolport, a purpose-built airfreight terminal that can handle commodities with different temperature requirements on 21 Dec 2020.

site_title: NZ prime minister to meet Biden to discuss US engagement in Indo-Pacific
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is set to meet US President Joe Biden on May 31 at the White House to discuss ongoing US engagement in the Indo-Pacific region. Ardern emphasized the importance of economic engagement and strengthening ties between the two countries. The meeting comes amid concerns about China's growing influence in the region, following a security pact with the Solomon Islands. Ardern also plans to meet with Vice-President Kamala Harris, Secretary of State Antony Blinken, and US Indo-Pacific coordinator Kurt Campbell.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is scheduled to meet senior members of the US Senate when she visits Washington but a hoped-for meeting with President Joe Biden may now not happen because of health protocols.

site_title: Rise of the US dollar: Déjà vu all over again?
summary: The US dollar has surged in recent times, mirroring past periods of sustained appreciation, primarily driven by the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat inflation. This strength poses a significant risk to emerging economies, particularly those with weak macroeconomic fundamentals, as they accumulate USD-denominated debt and are exposed to currency risks. Despite the damage being manageable so far, experts warn that prolonged USD strength could lead to debt defaults and global economic instability, as the US dollar's dominance faces challenges from other currencies, albeit with underlying structural issues.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment says nearly half of global portfolio is green building-certified
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) has achieved green building certifications for 48% of its global portfolio by square meters, with 67% of its Singapore properties being green-certified. The real estate investment manager reported S$320 million in utilities cost avoidance since 2009 by reducing carbon emissions, energy, and water intensities.

images.alt_text: CAPITALAND Investment (CLI) posted a 16 per cent growth on year in revenue to S$598 million for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, amid a healthy growth in fee-related earnings (FRE) from its fund and lodging management businesses.

site_title: China unveils detailed stimulus policies to support virus-hit economy
summary: China's cabinet has unveiled a 33-measure stimulus package to revive its pandemic-ravaged economy, aiming to support investment, consumption, and infrastructure development. The package includes promoting platform companies, expanding private investment, and stimulating car and home appliance purchases. It also aims to boost financing efficiency, reduce borrowing costs, and strengthen financial support for infrastructure projects. The measures are part of China's efforts to meet its 5.5% growth target for the year, after the economy was severely impacted by COVID-19 control measures.

images.alt_text: Workers remove barriers previous surrounding a neighborhood placed under lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai, China, on Monday, May 30, 2022. China reported the fewest new Covid-19 cases in almost three months, with the easing of outbreaks in Shanghai emboldening authorities to relax some of the strictest virus controls of the pandemic and move to stimulate the country’s faltering economy. Source: Bloomberg
China's factory activity likely contracted at a slower pace in May, a Reuters poll showed, as some virus curbs were lifted in key manufacturing hubs.

site_title: India's Jan-Mar GDP growth seen at one-year low on weak consumption
summary: India's January-March GDP growth is expected to be at a one-year low, with economists forecasting a 4.0% growth rate, down from 5.4% in the previous quarter. Rising inflation and soaring prices are likely to further dampen the economy, with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) facing a delicate balance between taming inflation and avoiding a slowdown in economic growth. The RBI has already raised interest rates, and economists predict further hikes to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: INDIA will continue to buy "cheap oil" from Russia but has not finalised terms of the discount, a senior government official familiar with the matter said on Wednesday (May 25).
India will restrict sugar exports as a precautionary measure to safeguard its own food supplies, another act of protectionism after banning wheat sales just over a week ago.

site_title: Japan’s May consumer confidence improves for second month
summary: Japan's consumer confidence index rose for a second straight month in May, increasing to 34.1 from 33.0 in April. The government upgraded its assessment, citing the end of a decline in sentiment. This improvement coincided with Japan's first restriction-free spring holiday season since the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: A customer looks at shoes on display at an ABC-Mart Inc. store in Kumamoto, Japan, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Japan is scheduled to release its consumer price index (CPI) figures for March on May 20. Photographer: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia's Icon Offshore in advanced talks to buy MRO business
summary: Malaysia's offshore oil and gas services firm Icon Offshore is in advanced talks to buy a maintenance, repair and operations (MRO) business, aiming to diversify earnings and boost profitability. The acquisition, expected to be completed by the end of the year, is estimated to increase net income by at least 30%. Icon, which owns 20 active offshore supply vessels and a jack-up drilling rig, currently derives 60% of its profits from Malaysia and Brunei. The deal will provide a new earnings stream and help mitigate the cyclical nature of the company's earnings.

images.alt_text: Malaysian plantations have been struggling to harvest palm fruit due to a labour shortage exacerbated by pandemic-related border closures.

site_title: Singapore stocks pull back on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks closed lower on Tuesday, down 0.2% or 6.43 points to 3,232.49, as traders reacted to macroeconomic news including Shanghai easing restrictions and the European Union's ban on most Russian oil imports. Despite this, markets in the region ended on a more upbeat note, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index adding 1.4% and Malaysia's KLCI jumping 1.8%. Analysts warn that macroeconomic uncertainty will remain high, with the war in Ukraine being a key factor in determining market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
A man with mask on seen walking near Singapore Exchange (SGX) Centre at Shenton Way in the Central Business District on 7 January 2021.

site_title: UK business confidence rises with firms planning to boost prices
summary: UK business confidence rose for the first time in 3 months in May, with 57% of firms planning to increase prices, according to Lloyds Bank's business barometer. This marks the fifth consecutive monthly gain, as companies seek to rebuild margins through price hikes. Confidence among retailers fell to 27%, while 46% cited higher costs as their biggest concern. The increase in business confidence adds to pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates to quell inflation, which has reached a 40-year high.

site_title: Higher interest rates: Some hedge fund strategies may benefit
summary: Higher interest rates are expected to benefit certain hedge fund strategies, including commodity trading advisers (CTAs), reinsurance, and short-term relative value fixed income. CTAs, which use leverage to take long and short positions in various markets, are expected to gain from rising interest rates due to their neutral or negative correlation with equity and fixed-income markets. Reinsurance strategies, which assume insurance company liabilities for natural disasters, also benefit from rising interest rates as they are less correlated with capital markets. These strategies are expected to grow their market share at the expense of other approaches, and institutional investors may request a performance hurdle for hedge fund fees.

images.alt_text: Total hedge fund capital remained roughly flat from December, at US$4 trillion, as performance of equity and event-driven funds was poor in the first quarter.
The most powerful approach to achieving gender parity may be gender lens investing

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.38 points or 0.15% to 1,540.64. Losers outnumbered gainers 176 to 150, with a total trading volume of 135 million lots worth RM77.8 million.

site_title: China urges UN rights chief to look into school shootings in US
summary: China has urged the UN human rights chief to investigate mass shootings in the US, shifting focus from allegations of abuses in its Xinjiang region. The call comes amid China's criticism of the US human rights record, following recent killings in Buffalo and Uvalde. China's Communist Party newspaper claims the US lacks courage to address domestic issues, while the US has accused China of carrying out genocide in Xinjiang. The UN human rights chief, Michelle Bachelet, faced criticism for her visit to Xinjiang, with some calling for her resignation.

images.alt_text: China and Russia vetoed on Thursday a US-led push to impose more United Nations sanctions on North Korea over its renewed ballistic missile launches, publicly splitting the UN Security Council for the first time since it started punishing Pyongyang in 2006.

site_title: MAS to pilot project in financial asset tokenisation: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will pilot a project to explore tokenisation of financial assets, dubbed Project Guardian, in collaboration with industry players. The project aims to develop finance infrastructure and explore DeFi applications in wholesale funding markets. Heng emphasized the need for an open mind when approaching Web 3.0 technologies, while warning retail investors to steer clear of cryptocurrencies due to their high risks.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Cryptocurrencies face a reckoning; prices have fallen more steeply than traditional markets
How are regulators managing crypto? There is no one answer. Check out this interactive map for the patchwork of crypto regulations around the world.
Do Kwon

site_title: China’s foreign minister visits Tonga after Pacific islands delay regional pact
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi visited Tonga on a tour through the Pacific region, amid concerns from US allies about Beijing's ambitions for wider security ties. The visit comes after a virtual meeting with island nations, including Samoa, Niue, and Tonga, which deferred consideration of a proposed regional trade and security pact due to lack of time. Samoa's Prime Minister Fiame Naomi Mataafa urged fellow Pacific islands to stay united in the face of big powers seeking more sway, while also calling for major decisions to go through the Pacific Islands Forum group.

site_title: Thai economy improves in May on easing Covid curbs
summary: Thailand's economy showed gradual improvement in May as restrictions eased following declining Covid-19 cases. The Bank of Thailand reported a 3.2% economic growth forecast for 2022, with 5.6 million foreign arrivals expected. However, the central bank noted concerns over increased costs, prices, and shortages in production parts, as well as a recovery in the tourism sector. The Thai government plans to lift curbs on nightlife from June to revive tourism, a key driver of the economy.

images.alt_text: Thailand's government on Tuesday proposed higher spending at 3.185 trillion baht (S$127.28 billion) in the 2023 draft budget bill.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Singtel’s growth prospects despite earnings miss
summary: Analysts remain optimistic on Singtel's growth prospects despite its latest earnings miss, with target prices raised for the telco. Maybank increased its target price to S$3.02, while RHB raised it to S$3.55, citing potential growth engines in regional data centers and digibank areas. OCBC Investment Research also raised its fair value estimates to S$3.06, noting the telco's reopening tailwinds. However, CGS-CIMB cut its target price to S$3.20 after adjusting its estimates for lower earnings from Singapore and Australia units.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Both Singtel and the Mittal family are shareholders in Bharti Telecom, as well as own direct shares directly in Bharti Airtel.

“This industry-first deployment proves that 5G networks can be used for high-precision quality control and manufacturing operations which previously was not possible with the limitations of Wi-Fi,” said Bill Chang, Singtel’s chief executive officer of Group Enterprise.
Replying to a question about Singtel leadership’s takeaways from the digital life investments, group chief executive Yuen Kuan Moon pointed to “lessons learned in the past”.
A man walking pass the Singtel Shop Comcentre at 31 Exeter Road on 11 Nov 2021.

site_title: Bonds rally everywhere in May with bulls saying selloff is over
summary: Global bond markets are experiencing a rebound, with investors seeking value in fixed-income assets amid recession fears and speculation on central-bank interest-rate hikes being priced in. US Treasuries and global investment-grade debt have returned almost 1% in May, their first monthly gain since July, while emerging-market sovereigns are also showing signs of recovery. Yields have fallen, making bonds attractive, with asset managers increasing bullish wagers on Treasuries. However, renewed inflation concerns and credit risks in China may derail the recovery.

images.alt_text: The 10-year Treasury yield slid about 10 basis points to 2.88 per cent as the S&P 500 slumped 4 per cent, its worst day since June 2020.

site_title: Hedge fund star’s bullish turn points to end of China stock rout
summary: A top-performing Chinese macro hedge fund, Shanghai Banxia Investment Management Center, is turning more positive on the market after a benchmark index reached its likely low for the year. The fund, which had zero stock exposure earlier in the year, rebuilt long positions to 65% in early May. Founder Li Bei stated that the recent rally has helped Banxia erase this year's losses and that stocks will likely fluctuate for the next few months. Li expressed a more bullish stance, saying the fund is "not yet in a bull market, but no longer in a bear market."

images.alt_text: ashanghai - An electronic ticker displays stock figures in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Monday, Feb. 7, 2022. Asian stocks were mixed amid a rally in China on Monday as the nation’s markets reopened from a holiday, while the prospect of global monetary tightening continued to weigh on bonds. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Participants at the 'Grow Your Portfolio with ETFs' roundtable flagged regional ETFs as a potential diversification strategy.
RATINGS agency Standard & Poor's (S&P) on Monday (May 30) downgraded Chinese state-backed property developer Greenland over fears the company would default on a bond payment.

HONG KONG shares closed on Monday (May 30) with more strong gains as traders welcomed an easing of Covid containment measures in Shanghai and Beijing, which raised hopes for the world's number 2 economy.

site_title: EU leaders downplay chances of rapid Russian gas ban
summary: EU leaders have downplayed the chances of a rapid Russian gas ban in the next round of sanctions, citing the complexity of the issue and the need to balance economic interests with the need to pressure Russia over its war in Ukraine. The EU has agreed to a sixth package of sanctions, which will stop most Russian oil exports but exempt pipeline supplies to Hungary.
