Russia's Gazprom has already cut off gas supplies to EU countries that refused to pay in roubles, and EU leaders are instead discussing a massive investment package to help wean Europe off Russian gas before the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Russia's Gazprom will halt gas supplies to the Netherlands’ partly state-owned energy firm GasTerra on Tuesday after it refused to pay in roubles, the Dutch company said.
Sberbank, Russia's biggest lender will be excluded from the Swift financial messaging system.

site_title: Gold slips as yields, dollar climb; faces 2nd monthly drop
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.5% to $1,847.50 per ounce, marking its second straight monthly loss, as a higher dollar and rising US Treasury yields weighed on demand. The dollar index rose, making gold more expensive for non-dollar holders, while benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields jumped, lowering the appeal of zero-yield gold. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates to curb inflation, further reducing the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

images.alt_text: Gold prices eased slightly on Monday, as investors turned to riskier assets in Asia, although a weakened dollar provided some support to greenback-priced bullion.

site_title: Foxconn predicts more stable supply chain in the second half of 2022
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, expects a more stable supply chain in the second half of 2022 following Shanghai's easing of Covid-19 lockdowns. Chairman Liu Young-way expressed confidence in the stability of the supply chain, citing a better direction for the second half of the year. Foxconn aims to capture around 5% of the global electric vehicle market by 2025 and boost its capacity to make EV chips.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo shows a Foxconn logo on a building in Tucheng district, New Taipei City on May 6, 2022. (Photo by Sam Yeh / AFP)

site_title: Qualcomm wants to buy Arm stake in upcoming IPO, CEO tells FT
summary: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon revealed plans to buy a stake in SoftBank's Arm chipmaker in its upcoming initial public offering (IPO). Amon stated that Qualcomm may invest alongside rivals, potentially joining a large consortium to purchase Arm outright. SoftBank is seeking a valuation of at least $60 billion for Arm after an Nvidia takeover bid collapsed earlier this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, Yangzijiang Financial, Singtel
summary: SATS reported earnings of S$7.2 million for the second half of FY21-22, a significant improvement from a net loss of S$2 million in the same period last year. Yangzijiang Financial upped its dividend payout policy for 3 financial years and announced a proposed share buyback mandate. Shares of both companies rose on the news.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Crypto ETFs, ETPs net inflows significantly lower on year at US$303m YTD, but remain second-highest
summary: Global crypto exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and exchange-traded products (ETPs) saw year-to-date net inflows of US$303 million, significantly lower than the previous year's US$2.69 billion. Total assets invested in crypto ETFs and ETPs fell 18.8% to US$13.21 billion as of end-April. The largest individual net inflow was contributed by CoinShares FTX Physical FTX Token, with US$37.9 million. Despite lower inflows, crypto ETFs and ETPs remain the second-highest globally.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
cryptocurrency, concept, blockchain

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday, STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.1% to 3,243.11 points, following 82.8 million securities worth S$47.3 million in trades. Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH) saw significant gains, while Singtel and SATS also traded actively. European shares rose to their highest level in almost a month, driven by China's easing of Covid-19 restrictions and new stimulus.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
SATS on Monday reported earnings of S$7.2 million for the second half of FY21-22 ended March, compared to a net loss of S$2 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

site_title: EU leaders back push to ban some Russian oil over Putin's war
summary: European Union leaders agreed to pursue a partial ban on Russian oil, which would forbid the purchase of crude oil and petroleum products from Russia delivered to member states by sea. The ban would cover more than 2/3 of Russian oil imports, cutting a significant source of financing for Russia's war machine. The sanctions package also includes a ban on insurance related to shipping oil to third countries, with some countries to have longer transition periods. The measures aim to increase pressure on Russia to end the war in Ukraine, with the potential to cut 90% of Russian crude oil sales to the EU by year's end.

images.alt_text: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban in Budapest in April. He won a resounding recent re-election to a 4th term as premier. An ally of Russian president Vladimir Putin, he has argued that an oil embargo would be an 'atomic bomb' against his country’s economy.

site_title: EU to exclude Russia’s biggest bank from Swift
summary: EU leaders agreed to exclude Russia's largest bank, Sberbank, from the Swift financial messaging system as part of their sixth sanctions package targeting Moscow over its invasion of Ukraine. This move aims to further isolate Russia's financial system, which has been under increasing sanctions for over three months.

site_title: UK electric-car battery hopeful plans £200m pilot plant
summary: Britishvolt, a UK electric vehicle startup, plans to spend over £200 million on a pilot facility near Birmingham, aiming to start battery production by the end of 2023. The 1.2 gigawatt-hour facility will support the company's planned £2.6 billion-pound plant in Northumberland in 2024, employing 150 people. Britishvolt is close to announcing a second major investor, following existing agreements with UK carmakers, and plans to fund the pilot facility from existing funds and future fundraising rounds.

site_title: Tokyo: stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.25% and the broader Topix index down 0.31%. The decline comes after strong rallies in the previous session, as investors await Chinese economic indicators.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past an electronic quotation board displaying the numbers of the Nikkei 225 Index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange (L) and a foreign exchange board showing the yen's rate against US dollar (R) in Tokyo on April 20, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Thailand plans 3.2t baht in 2023 spending as budget debate starts
summary: Thailand's government proposed a 3.185 trillion baht (S$127.28 billion) budget for 2023, a 2.74% increase from the current year, to accelerate the country's economic recovery. The budget aims to support growth, driven by increased domestic demand and tourism, with projected GDP growth of 3.5-4.5% this year and 3.2-4.2% next year. The government also expects a 0.7% drop in deficit to 695 billion baht, or 3.9% of GDP. The budget is crucial for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's premiership and will require two more readings before being sent for senate and royal approval.

site_title: Aviation sector on hiring spree but Asian airlines, except for SIA, in no rush to recruit flight crew
summary: Singapore Airlines is hiring 2,000 flight attendants, while few Asian airlines have accelerated recruitment of flight crew, except for SIA. Middle Eastern airlines, such as Emirates, are actively hiring cabin crew to capitalize on the post-pandemic travel surge. Asian airlines like Eva Air and Korean Air have managed to turn a profit, and SIA reported a 78% reduction in net loss and a 77.5% increase in passenger capacity. The airline's recruitment drive is its first after a 2-year freeze, with a focus on hiring from Singapore and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

The time needed to get security badges for newly hired staff has risen from 3 to 4 weeks in Britain, for example, to as long as 3 months, Willie Walsh, director general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA), said.
Malaysia Airports recorded daily average international passengers movement of 33,407 in May 2022, after the Malaysian government lifted border restrictions on April 1.
Business Class SilverKris Lounge has a bar now, one of the amenities SIA flyers have asked for.

site_title: London unveils watered-down audit reform plans
summary: London has unveiled watered-down audit reform plans, aiming to break the dominance of the "big four" auditors and increase accountability for large businesses. The plans, which will be enforced by a new regulator, target unlisted companies with over 750 employees and £750m annual turnover, down from initially proposed thresholds. The reforms will require large companies to separate their audit functions, increase transparency, and prohibit dividend distributions before bankruptcy. However, smaller companies will be spared, and the plans have been criticized for being less ambitious than initially proposed.

site_title: Bitcoin surges nearly 8% to US$31,780
summary: Bitcoin surged nearly 8% to US$31,780.51 on Monday, reaching its highest point since May 12, when it hit a low of US$25,401.05. This increase brings the cryptocurrency up 25.1% from its year-low. Ether, linked to the ethereum blockchain network, also rose 9.8% to US$1,989.38.

site_title: Income At Raffles quietly on market; S$3,300 psf guide price works out to about S$900m
summary: Income At Raffles, a 37-storey office building in Singapore, is being marketed for sale via a closed expression of interest exercise with a guide price of S$3,300 per square foot (psf), totaling about S$900 million. The property has a net yield of nearly 2.5% and is held by Savu Investments, fully owned by NTUC Income Insurance Co-operative, which is in the process of being corporatised. Market watchers predict office deals may slow due to rising interest rates, but ultra-high net worth individuals and family offices may still be keen on the sector in search of safe harbour.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
NTUC Income to corporatise in bid to raise its competitiveness and fuel growth
NTUC Income's corporatisation: striking a balance between profits and purpose

site_title: Chemicals company Borouge’s US$2b Abu Dhabi IPO draws US$83b of orders
summary: Borouge, a chemicals joint venture between Abu Dhabi National Oil Co and Borealis, raised US$2 billion in its initial public offering, drawing US$83 billion of orders. The IPO is Abu Dhabi's biggest-ever listing and values Borouge at US$20 billion. Strong demand, driven by oil's surge to over US$120 a barrel, has attracted foreign investors, including BlackRock and Fidelity, to the region's markets, which have bucked global volatility.

images.alt_text: Malaysian offshore oil and gas services firm Icon Offshore is in advanced talks to buy a maintenance, repair and operations business that will help it diversify earnings and boost profitability, its top executive said on Monday.
Russia's Gazprom will halt gas supplies to the Netherlands’ partly state-owned energy firm GasTerra on Tuesday after it refused to pay in roubles, the Dutch company said.
Oil prices climbed above US$121 a barrel on Monday, hitting a two-month high.

site_title: Italy scraps coronavirus entry rules
summary: Italy has dropped the requirement to show proof of coronavirus vaccination, recent recovery, or a negative test before entering the country, effective immediately. The move comes as cases continue to rise, with 7,537 new cases and 62 deaths reported on Monday. This decision marks a shift in Italy's COVID-19 measures, which had previously been among the strictest in Europe. The requirement to show a "Green Pass" will not be extended when it expires on May 31.

site_title: Malaysia PM downplays early poll talk, citing inflation risks: Nikkei
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has downplayed calls for an early election, citing inflationary pressures and rising food costs. An election is not due until 2023, but Sabri has been pressured by his party, Umno, to call an early vote to capitalize on their recent local poll gains. Sabri stated that the government will wait for the "right time" to call an election, considering the current inflationary pressures, and has also expressed interest in re-introducing a Goods and Services Tax (GST).

images.alt_text: No more election play? Analysts said the excitement of the upcoming general election will be less pronounced due to political uncertainties and depleting government coffers.

site_title: Russia’s Gazprom cutting Dutch gas supplies
summary: Russia's Gazprom will halt gas supplies to the Netherlands' GasTerra on Tuesday after the Dutch company refused to pay in roubles, following Moscow's request to clients from "unfriendly countries" to sidestep Western financial sanctions. This move affects 2 billion cubic meters of gas, equivalent to six billion cubic meters per year, and is the latest in a series of European countries to be hit with reduced Russian gas supplies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed natural gas pipeline is placed in front of displayed Gazprom logo in this illustration taken February 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Deep under the ocean, a fresh source of green power takes shape
summary: Japan's IHI has successfully tested a subsea turbine system called Kairyu, which harnesses deep ocean currents to generate a steady and reliable source of electricity. The 330-ton prototype, designed to be anchored to the seafloor, has been tested in the Kuroshio Current and has proven to generate 100 kilowatts of stable power. The system could potentially generate up to 200 gigawatts, about 60% of Japan's current generating capacity, and has a capacity factor of 50-70%, compared to 29% for onshore wind and 15% for solar.

images.alt_text: IHI's deep-ocean Kairyu has two counterrotating turbines.Source: IHI Corp./NEDO

site_title: Mapletree posts 6.2% rise in FY22 profit to S$1.96b
summary: Mapletree Investments reported a 6.2% year-over-year increase in FY22 profit to S$1.96 billion, driven by record recurring earnings and property revaluation gains. Recurring earnings grew 27.9% to S$810.2 million, while revenue rose 4.6% to S$2.9 billion. The group maintained its return on equity above 10% and increased shareholder funds by 10.5% to S$19.5 billion. Mapletree's total assets under management (AUM) reached S$78.7 billion, up 18.7% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Commercial Trust H2 DPU down 3% to S$0.0514
Vivocity tenant sales in the fourth quarter ended Mar 31 has picked up and recovered to pre-Covid levels.
THE Singapore market rebounded on Thursday (May 26) after 3 days of losses, tracking Wall Street gains.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields jump after inflation beats forecasts
summary: Eurozone government bond yields surged on Monday after inflation rose 8.7% annually, beating forecasts. This increase in inflation, along with growing risk appetite, pushed bond yields higher. Consumer prices in Germany also saw their largest increase since 1974. The Spanish 12-month inflation rate resumed its upward trend after a dip in April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The European Central Bank (ECB) logo in Frankfurt, Germany, January 23, 2020. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: ESG investing accelerates
summary: Investors expect ESG trends to dominate the sustainability agenda, with energy security, food security, and cybersecurity emerging as key areas. The shift towards decarbonization will benefit green tech, clean air, and carbon reduction, while companies that outperform in energy cost management and climate resilience will be rewarded. The renewable energy space is expected to attract significant attention, with Asia-Pacific set to become a major offshore wind market by 2030. The transition to a green economy will also require significant infrastructure investment, estimated at US$2 trillion in South-east Asia over the next decade.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Green Plan 2030 advances Singapore's national agenda on sustainable development.

site_title: London homes beckon despite economic uncertainties
summary: Singaporeans are increasingly looking to invest in London homes despite economic uncertainties. The UK remains a leading global financial and business hub, drawing talent for good jobs and business opportunities. London home prices have grown by 6.8% annually over the past 30 years, and the prime central London residential property market is expected to see a 7.5% price growth this year. Singaporeans can take advantage of the strength of the Singapore dollar, with the UK pound down by around 5% year-to-date. However, risks include weak economic growth, inflation, and higher interest rates, which may impact rental returns and capital values.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Asking prices for UK homes rose to a new record for a fourth-straight month, though there are signs the market is starting to ease.
NATIONWIDE BUILDING SOCIETY reported its annual profit nearly doubled on Friday (May 20), but warned rocketing inflation in Britain could dent the economy and lower house prices.

site_title: Archaeologists uncover trove of ancient Egyptian mummies
summary: Archaeologists in Egypt have discovered a trove of ancient Egyptian mummies, including 250 coffins and 150 bronze statues of deities, at a cemetery in Saqqara. The discovery dates back to the Late Period, around 500 BC, and includes artifacts such as a sistrum, bronze vessels, and cosmetics. The coffins were found intact with mummies, amulets, and wooden boxes, and one contained a well-preserved papyrus. The artifacts will be transferred for display at the Grand Egyptian Museum, furthering the region's rich archaeological heritage.

images.alt_text: Workers in Marseille, France build an almost life-sized recreation of undersea Stone Age cave paintings found off the coast nearby.

site_title: Britain’s top CEO salaries back to pre-pandemic levels
summary: Britain's top CEO salaries have returned to pre-pandemic levels, averaging £3.62 million (S$6.3 million) for the largest companies on the London Stock Exchange in 2021, according to Deloitte research. This figure is below the 2017 peak of £4.04 million but higher than the £2.78 million in 2020 due to the return of bonuses. Despite rising costs and a uncertain environment, the UK has maintained strict remuneration governance standards, with shareholders generally supporting proposed salaries.

site_title: US airlines cancel 2,500 flights over Memorial holiday weekend
summary: US airlines cancelled over 2,500 flights over the Memorial Day holiday weekend due to thunderstorms, staffing issues, and Covid-19 cases among employees. Airlines, still rebuilding flight crews, attributed the cancellations to weather, air traffic control, and other staffing issues. Despite the disruptions, Delta Air Lines reported that 94% of passengers were accommodated on alternative flights within 10 hours of their original departure time. Airlines are working to ramp up staffing to handle expected record summer travel demand.

images.alt_text: Travelers wait in line at Delta Airlines check-in at Los Angeles International Airport  in Los Angeles, California, on December 23, 2021. - Over 2,000 flights have been cancelled and thousands delayed around the world as the highly infectious Omicron variant disrupts holiday travel. According to tracking website Flightaware.com at 1540 GMT on Friday, a total of 2,118 flights had been cancelled worldwide, including 500 flights originating from or headed to US airports, and over 5,700 delayed. (Photo by DAVID MCNEW / AFP)

site_title: Biden to meet Powell for talks on economy as inflation bites
summary: US President Joe Biden will hold a meeting with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on May 30 to discuss the economy amid high inflation. The meeting comes as the personal consumption expenditures price index rose 6.3% last month, exceeding the Fed's 2% target. Powell has signaled plans to raise interest rates to cool price pressures, which has triggered financial-market volatility. The meeting aims to address concerns over the Fed's aggressive rate hikes and potential recession.

site_title: UEFA to compensate 2,700 Champions League ticket holders
summary: UEFA has agreed to compensate 2,700 Champions League ticket holders who were prevented from entering the stadium due to chaotic scenes at the Stade de France in Paris. The delay, caused by Liverpool fans being blocked at turnstiles, led to some being pepper-sprayed and tear-gassed. Many fans were eventually allowed in, but others missed the match entirely. French Sports Minister Amelie Oudea-Castera confirmed that UEFA will identify and compensate those affected.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as China growth hopes boost luxury, tech stocks
summary: European shares rose 0.6% to their highest level in almost a month, boosted by China's easing of Covid-19 restrictions and new stimulus. Luxury firms, which derive significant demand from China, led the gains. The Stoxx 600 index reached 447.79, a level not seen since early May. Technology stocks also jumped 2.0% and the gains were largely broad-based. Despite expected data showing further euro zone inflation, European stocks enjoyed their best week since mid-March, driven by upbeat US consumer sentiment data and clarity on the Federal Reserve's plans.

site_title: ETFs a useful tool for investors amid market volatility: BT roundtable panellists
summary: Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are being touted as a useful tool for investors amid market volatility, according to a roundtable discussion by experts. Regional ETFs are seen as a potential diversification strategy, with Indonesia and Brazil performing strongly year to date. ETFs can provide instant diversification and are often cheaper than unit trust funds, with fees declining over the past two decades. However, investors need to be cautious of overvaluation and educate themselves on conventional and synthetic ETFs. Experts also noted the importance of incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
FILE PHOTO: A representation of cryptocurrency Bitcoin is seen in this illustration taken August 6, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Oil climbs above US$121 a barrel as China eases restrictions, EU meets
summary: Oil prices rose to a two-month high above $121 a barrel on Monday, driven by China's easing of Covid-19 restrictions and expectations of an EU oil import ban. The Brent crude futures contract settled up 1.9% at $121.67 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 1.7% to $117.06 a barrel. The EU is set to agree on an oil embargo in principle, but details are yet to be decided. Opec+ is expected to stick to its existing output target despite Western calls to increase production.

site_title: For Singapore, a pressing need to build up its food supply resilience
summary: Singapore faces a pressing need to build up its food supply resilience due to Malaysia's surprise ban on exporting 3.6 million chickens a month, affecting the country's chicken imports. The ban, set to last until domestic prices stabilize, exacerbates the uncertainty for Singapore's food supplies, which rely heavily on imports. The government has assured preparedness, but the need for buffer stocks and diversified sources is crucial to cope with global food supply disruptions. Consumers can minimize the impact by considering alternative sources and frozen options until the situation clarifies.

images.alt_text: A poultry seller at Tekka Market at 11.45am on May 21, 2020.

site_title: Putin tells Erdogan Russia ready to work to reopen shipping
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin told Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan that Moscow is ready to work with Ankara to free up maritime shipping blocked in Ukraine, including grain exports. This comes as Russia's offensive in Ukraine and Western sanctions have disrupted global food supplies. Putin also repeated claims that Western policies are causing global food shortages, stating Russia is willing to export fertilizers and agricultural products if sanctions are lifted.

site_title: Tourists are back, but staycations are here to stay
summary: Singapore hotels expect to continue filling rooms with local staycations, despite the recovery in international arrivals. International guests made up 85% of pre-pandemic reservations, but local demand remains strong, with many hotels promoting experiential concepts and dining offers. The industry is also targeting business travelers and promoting packages for pandemic-fatigued guests. International bookings now account for 70% of accommodation packages booked through Trip.com, but the tourism industry still faces headwinds due to curbs on outbound travel from mainland China.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.
Singapore's Changi Airport Terminal 2, which has been closed since May 2020, will be progressively opened from next Sunday (May 29).
Room rates in Singapore have gone up in recent months as hotels limited occupancies amid an industrywide staff shortage.

site_title: Big tobacco’s environmental impact is ‘devastating’: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has released a report stating that the tobacco industry is a significant environmental polluter, causing widespread deforestation, driving global warming, and contaminating water resources. The industry is responsible for the loss of 600 million trees annually, using 200,000 hectares of land and 22 billion tonnes of water, and emitting 84 million tonnes of carbon dioxide. The report also highlights the industry's contribution to plastic pollution, including cigarette filters, and calls for the industry to be held accountable and foot the bill for cleanup efforts.

site_title: China's factory activity likely contracted more slowly in May
summary: China's factory activity likely contracted at a slower pace in May, with the manufacturing PMI expected to rise to 48.6, marking the third straight month of contraction. Virus curbs were lifted in key manufacturing hubs, including Shanghai, Changchun, and Shenyang, and supply chain disruptions eased. However, factories are only slowly ramping up production levels, reflecting weak growth in steel production and depressed power generation. The relatively weak reading suggests a slow recovery in the Yangtze River Delta supply chain and subdued new orders due to weak domestic consumption and softening global demand.

images.alt_text: Employees wearing face masks work on a car seat assembly line at Yanfeng Adient factory in Shanghai, China, as the country is hit by an outbreak of a new coronavirus, February 24, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Fed's Waller favours multiple big interest rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller suggests the central bank needs to raise interest rates in big steps until inflation comes down. Waller supports multiple half-point rate hikes "for several meetings" and is not ruling out 50 basis-point hikes. The Fed aims to tame the highest inflation in over 40 years, following a 0.75-point increase in March. Markets expect 2.5 percentage points of tightening this year, but Waller warns that if inflation momentum is not brought under control, it will be harder to contain.

site_title: China to accelerate local bond issuance to cushion economic slowdown
summary: China plans to accelerate local bond issuance to stabilize its slowing economy, with local governments having issued a net 1.85 trillion yuan in special bonds as of May 27, accounting for 54% of the year's quota. The finance ministry aims for basic completion of special bond issuance by the end of June and fund usage by the end of August. This move is part of a broader effort to achieve reasonable economic growth and stem rising unemployment, with Premier Li Keqiang emphasizing the need for steady economic growth in the second quarter.

site_title: All eyes on the Philippines’ new economics team to steer recovery post-pandemic
summary: The Philippines' new economics team, led by President-elect Ferdinand Marcos Jr, has announced key appointments to steer the economy post-pandemic. Former BSP governor Benjamin Diokno will head the Department of Finance, while Felipe Medalla and Arsenio Balisacan will lead the central bank and National Economic Development Authority, respectively. The appointments have been welcomed by business associations, citing their experience and potential to promote liberal yet inclusive policies for economic recovery. The team's ability to address pressing issues such as inflation, debt, and unemployment will be crucial in shaping the country's economic future.

images.alt_text: Customers dine in a restaurant in Batangas City, Philippines. The central bank governor Benjamin Diokno is optimistic that the country will post an even better performance following a solid rebound last year.

site_title: Roman era ends as Abramovich completes sale of Chelsea to Boehly-led consortium
summary: Roman Abramovich has completed the sale of Chelsea to a consortium led by Todd Boehly and Clearlake Capital, ending a 3-month process. The sale was finalized after receiving approval from the Premier League, British government, and Portugal government. The new owners, who will share joint control and equal governance, aim to invest in the club for the long-term and build on Chelsea's history of success. The sale allows Chelsea to renew transfer activity and permit players to sign new contracts, which was prohibited due to sanctions on Abramovich.

site_title: Credit Suisse weighs options to strengthen capital: sources
summary: Credit Suisse is considering a capital boost of over 1 billion Swiss francs (S$1.4 billion) to bolster its financial buffers after a string of losses and costly legal headaches. The bank is exploring options, including selling shares to major investors or tapping all shareholders, and has not ruled out a sale of its asset management division. This move comes after Fitch and Standard & Poors downgraded its debt ratings, and the bank's shares have fallen by more than a fifth in the past year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen at its headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland February 22, 2022. Picture taken February 22, 2022.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: UK doubles down on reviving London IPOs by tweaking rules
summary: The UK is revamping rules for London initial public offerings (IPOs) to boost listings and attract more startups, following a decline in the number of companies listing on the London Stock Exchange. The proposed changes include simplifying the listing process and reducing costs, but it's unclear if these efforts will be enough to stem the decline in the market. London's IPO market is on track for its worst first half since 2009, with only £604 million raised in 2022, as companies consider alternative listings in the US.

images.alt_text: Britain wants to bolster London’s attractiveness as a global location for listings as it continues to trail New York in bringing tech companies to the market, and faces added competition from Amsterdam since Brexit.

Arrival's Denis Sverdlov (above), who was worth US$11.7 billion a year ago, lost his billionaire status last month as shares of the electric-vehicle maker he founded have cratered since combining with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC).

site_title: Retail subscription rates for Astrea 7 bonds suggest investors may be better at assessing risk than regulators think
summary: Retail investors in Singapore may be better at assessing risk than regulators think, as evidenced by the strong demand for Astrea 7 bonds. The junior Class B tranche, with a 6% coupon and higher credit risk profile, sold out quickly, while the senior Class A-1 tranche, with a 4.125% coupon, was also oversubscribed. This suggests that investors are willing to take on more risk for higher yields, challenging the assumption that regulators are better at assessing risk.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
dollars, currency, money

site_title: Sri Lanka urges airlines to fly full tank — or top up  elsewhere
summary: Sri Lanka is urging airlines to carry enough jet fuel for return trips or refuel elsewhere due to a shortage of aviation fuel and other essential supplies. Airlines like Emirates are tankering, while Sri Lanka's flag carrier is using Indian cities to refuel. The country is grappling with a foreign-exchange crisis, power cuts, and inflation, leading to public protests and IMF bailout talks. Measures to minimize flight disruptions include fuel tankering and technical stops at foreign airports.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said on May 26 that he’s looking to fast-track talks with the IMF as the nation will need about US$4 billion this year from the multilateral lender and creditors including China and Japan.

THE International Monetary Fund (IMF) said it made "good progress" in analyzing Sri Lanka's economic situation and identifying policy priorities, while cautioning that a loan would require adequate assurances that debt sustainability will be restored.
Russian oil is being supplied to Sri Lanka to produce fuel at its sole refinery as the bankrupt nation faces crippling shortages of everything from gasoline to diesel.

site_title: European banks led by BNP to benefit from Basel rule change
summary: European banks, particularly those led by BNP Paribas, are set to benefit from a change in Basel rules. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision will treat cross-border exposures within the euro area as domestic ones, considered less risky. This change is expected to reduce capital requirements for top lenders like BNP Paribas, which has the highest surcharge. The shift could also facilitate cross-border takeovers and deals within the bloc without stricter capital demands. The planned changes are expected to be announced soon.

images.alt_text: A stack of ten euro banknotes sit on a pile of U.S. dollar bills in this arranged taken photograph inside a Travelex store, operated by Travelex Holdings Ltd., in London, U.K., on Monday, Jan. 12, 2015. The euro approached a nine-year low against the dollar as European Central Bank officials fueled speculation the institution will start a program of government-bond buying as early as next week to stave off deflation. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Singtel, Micron partner to deploy commercial 5G mmWave solution
summary: Singtel and Micron Technology have partnered to deploy a commercial 5G mmWave solution at Micron's 3D NAND flash memory fabrication plant in Singapore. This is the first time a company in Singapore is piloting 5G for industry 4.0 manufacturing applications, supporting high-precision quality control and manufacturing operations. The 5G mmWave network offers up to 2 Gbps bandwidth and ultra-low latency, enabling the development of digitally enabled and enhanced applications such as automated visual inspections and augmented reality. The partnership aims to accelerate enterprise 5G adoption and serve as a case study for other 5G-enabled manufacturing sites.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Micron's US$150b global expansion plan aims to capture demand for memory
Replying to a question about Singtel leadership’s takeaways from the digital life investments, group chief executive Yuen Kuan Moon pointed to “lessons learned in the past”.

site_title: GIC in joint venture to acquire UK’s third-largest purpose-built student accommodation provider
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has formed a joint venture with Greystar Real Estate Partners to acquire Student Roost, the UK's third-largest purpose-built student accommodation provider. The deal includes a portfolio of over 23,000 beds and a secured development pipeline of 3,000 more beds. GIC expects growing demand for student accommodation due to rising student enrollment, and plans to deliver value-add by refurbishing existing assets. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2022, subject to customary closing conditions.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

site_title: CFO clarion call: From financial stewardship to custodian of ESG strategy
summary: The CFO's role is evolving to become a key custodian of ESG strategy as investors and lenders integrate ESG into investment decisions. The linkage between ESG and financial performance is becoming more evident, and CFOs must take ownership of ESG management. The pandemic has accelerated this shift, and deeper CFO involvement is required to provide financial and human capital investments to address pressing ESG challenges. Over the mid-to-long term, the CFO will emerge as a central figure in ESG strategy, replacing the traditional roles of the CSO and COO.

images.alt_text: Going forward, there is a need to ensure environmental policies are aligned with businesses and individuals

site_title: Faster room rate recovery fuels industry cheer despite ongoing labour shortages
summary: Room rates in Singapore have increased as hotels limit occupancies amid an industry-wide staff shortage. Despite this, rates are nearing pre-pandemic levels, with some expecting a full recovery by the end of 2022. Hoteliers are optimistic due to growing inbound travel and a shift away from quarantine and staycation demand. Occupancy and average room rates are expected to rise, providing a boost to hotel owners and operators. This rebound is seen as a positive sign for the industry ahead of the mid-year peak period.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

Assistant manager of housekeeping Le Nguyen Dang Khoa, 25, disinfecting a room at Shangri-La Hotel Singapore on April 28, 2021. Amid the challenges of the Covid-19 outbreak in 2020, the hotel prioritised cutting non-essential expenses over trimming labour costs.

site_title: Bigger pay hikes in 2022 as employers price in higher cost of living: HR firms
summary: Singapore is likely to maintain real wage growth in 2022 despite inflation concerns, according to the Ministry of Manpower's wage practices report. Employers are expected to provide larger-than-usual salary adjustments to stay ahead of soaring inflation, with companies like Singtel already doing so. Headline inflation is forecast to be 4.5-5.5% in 2022, and core inflation is expected to be between 2.5-3.5%. This is expected to lead to nominal pay rises outpacing inflation, allowing wages to grow in real terms.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Tessa Oh
Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday as investors were seen taking profits after three days of rallies and as fears over the US government shutdown weighed on the market.

site_title: US dollar resumes slide as stock markets tentatively pick up
summary: The US dollar resumed its slide, marking its first monthly drop in 5 years, as risk appetite strengthened globally. US consumer spending rose more than expected in April, and inflation slowed, weakening the dollar. The dollar index is on track for a 1.5% drop in May, despite being up 6% for the year. Global share markets rose as easing Covid-19 restrictions and new stimulus in China supported investor risk appetite.

images.alt_text: The weakening ringgit has impacted many Malaysian businesses but some are benefited from it.

site_title: German inflation beat firms case for bigger ECB rate hike
summary: German inflation rose to its highest level in nearly half a century in May, driven by soaring energy and food prices. The 8.7% increase, exceeding expectations, strengthens the case for a half percentage point European Central Bank interest rate hike in July. This marks a new era of rapid price growth in Europe, following a decade of ultra-low inflation. The rapid price growth is attributed to supply chain problems post-pandemic and Russia's war in Ukraine.

site_title: Turning sustainability commitments into action
summary: The UBS APAC Sustainable Finance Conference 2022 focused on transitioning to net zero, climate tech innovations, and carbon markets. Despite the ongoing global geopolitical situation, investors remain optimistic about green technology investments, with 7 in 10 UBS clients in Asia preferring sustainable investments for equal or superior returns. The conference saw significant growth in ESG awareness, with UBS extending its sustainability leadership and advancements in its climate strategy. Key speakers emphasized the need for "stubborn optimism" and a longer-term view on the energy transition and sustainability.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.74 points, or 0.24%, to 1,543.02 on Monday, with 497 losers outweighing 412 gainers. The market saw a total of 3.054 billion lots worth Rm1.821 billion.

site_title: Sterling rangebound near one-month high
summary: The British pound edged higher against the US dollar, reaching a one-month high, as markets adjusted their expectations for the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. The US dollar index weakened 3.5% from its mid-May peak, benefiting sterling. However, analysts remain bearish on sterling due to signs of a weakening economy and the Bank of England's interest rate hikes. The net short position in sterling stands at $6.3 billion, the largest since 2019, and Bank of America's Kamal Sharma described the outlook for GBP as "grim."

site_title: Poulet boleh for kampong chickens in Singapore
summary: Malaysia's impending export ban on premium organic and free-range poultry to Singapore, set to take effect on June 1, has been partially mitigated. Free-range or kampong chickens have received special approval for export, allowing farms like Aqina Farm to continue supplying the Singapore market. The ban primarily targets mass-market 'broiler' chickens, which are in higher demand in Malaysia due to their accessibility. This move aims to ensure an adequate supply of chicken to Malaysians at an accessible price, despite the tariffs.

images.alt_text: Customers queue to buy fresh chickens from Malaysia at NTUC FairPrice Vivocity on May 24, 2022. Malaysia said it will halt the export of 3.6 million chickens a month from June to address surging prices and the shortage of chickens in the country.

site_title: Banking for a better world
summary: DBS Bank is shifting its focus from wealth management to a "bank for a better world," prioritizing responsible banking, sustainable investments, and social impact. The bank aims to achieve net-zero operational carbon emissions by 2022 and net-zero financed emissions by 2050. DBS Private Bank has over 53% of its assets under management in sustainable investments, with a goal to reach 50% by 2023. The bank also supports social enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through its DBS Foundation, which has disbursed over $10 million in grants.

site_title: Taking ESG to the next level
summary: Fidelity International has launched Sustainability 2.0, a forward-looking framework for evaluating a company's sustainability performance. The framework, which includes double materiality, assesses both financial risks and societal impacts. Fidelity aims to take ESG integration to a new level by embedding internal ESG ratings, engaging with companies, and collaborating with portfolio managers and analysts. The company has identified three key themes: deforestation, a "just transition," and a 10-year view to assess long-term impacts. Fidelity's approach seeks to allocate capital towards societally positive outcomes and ensure that companies improve their business practices.

images.alt_text: 'ESG is not about putting inplace policies andprocesses. It's aboutchanging the hearts andminds of our investmentprofessionals, what they doand how they do it,' saysJennHuiTan, Fidelity International's global head of stewardshipand sustainable investing

site_title: Franklin Templeton eyes long, attractive runway for growth in green infrastructure
summary: Franklin Templeton, a global investment manager, is shifting its focus towards sustainable investing as governments worldwide push for a net-zero carbon emissions future by 2050. The company believes that stock selection and active management will be crucial in identifying long-term winners in the green infrastructure sector. Infrastructure projects such as electrification of public transport systems, incentivizing electric vehicle adoption, and modernizing power grids are expected to see significant growth, driven by increasing demand for sustainable investment products. Franklin Templeton is committed to incorporating sustainability into its investment processes, working with various organizations to promote best practices and is planning to hold a sustainable investing forum in Singapore later this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares closed with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with strong gains on May 30, 2022, as traders welcomed the easing of Covid containment measures in Shanghai and Beijing, raising hopes for the world's number 2 economy. The Hang Seng Index climbed 2.06% to 21,123.93, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose.

site_title: Banking on a sustainable future
summary: Financial institutions are being urged to play a crucial role in financing a sustainable economy, as the world transitions towards a net-zero or carbon-neutral economy. With 60% of investors in UOB's sustainability bond offering in 2021 being sustainability-focused, the bank has seen a significant increase in its sustainable finance portfolio, tripling from $6.6 billion to $18 billion. To address the needs of smaller companies, UOB is developing solutions such as the Greentech Accelerator programme and partnering with industry players to create ecosystems that support sustainable growth. Regulatory efforts, such as the Paris Agreement, aim to align sustainability goals and standards across economies, driving meaningful progress towards a sustainable future.

site_title: Russians lose Netflix in latest pullout over Ukraine
summary: Russian subscribers lost access to Netflix on May 27 after the US-based streaming giant withdrew from the Russian market due to the conflict in Ukraine. Netflix confirmed the move, citing the end of the current billing cycle, and had previously lost 700,000 paid subscribers in Russia. The company's withdrawal marks the latest pullout of a Western company from Russia, following others such as Apple, Google, and Facebook.

site_title: Xi hails 'new atmosphere' in Hong Kong, welcomes next leader
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has welcomed Hong Kong's next leader, John Lee, and expressed trust in his ability to bring about a "new atmosphere" in the city. Lee, a former police chief and security official, was chosen by a Beijing-backed committee to succeed outgoing leader Carrie Lam. Xi praised Lee's commitment to national security and Hong Kong's prosperity, and Lee vowed to unite the government and people to strive for the well-being of Hong Kong. Lee will assume office on July 1, the 25th anniversary of Hong Kong's transfer to Chinese rule.

images.alt_text: As part of a 4-day trip, John Lee will be officially appointed and is expected to meet with top Chinese leaders, according to local media.

Hong kong's central bank plans to hold a major conference in November it hopes will draw global banking bosses, sources said, as the financial hub seeks to welcome back international business following 2 gruelling years of closed borders.

Soaring property prices during more than a decade of ultra-low interest rates have become a major political risk for governments all around the world. The problem in Hong Kong is particularly acute as not only are homes expensive, they are mostly small.

“We have been bad mouthed by some politicians for political reasons, criticising unfairly the system that is being practiced in Hong Kong,” John Lee said at a press briefing Tuesday afternoon. “It is important we tell the true story and reflect the true situation of Hong Kong to the world.”

site_title: S&P downgrades Chinese state-backed developer Greenland
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded Chinese state-backed property developer Greenland to CC due to fears it would default on a bond payment. The downgrade follows a government drive to curb excessive debt in the property sector, which has led to massive borrowing by Chinese developers. Greenland has asked for a one-year extension on a US$488 million note, but S&P views the proposal as a "distressed maturity extension" equivalent to a default. The developer's cash flow has been adversely affected by the recent coronavirus outbreak in Shanghai, further exacerbating its liquidity woes.

site_title: Tesla Shanghai plant restores weekly output to 70% of pre-lockdown level: sources
summary: Tesla's Shanghai plant has restored weekly output to nearly 70% of pre-lockdown levels, according to sources. The factory, which had been shut for 22 days due to the COVID-19 lockdown, reopened on April 19 and produced 10,757 vehicles by the end of April. The company is expected to increase output further this week after adding a second shift of workers. Despite challenges such as worker shortages and logistics issues, Tesla is working to bring production back to pre-lockdown levels.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial ups dividend payout policy to at least 40% of earnings, up to FY2024
summary: Yangzijiang Financial (YZJFH) has increased its dividend payout policy to at least 40% of earnings, up to FY2024. This follows a proposed mandate to buy back up to 10% of its own shares, announced a week prior. The company will hold an EGM on June 8 to seek shareholder approval for the share buyback. Shares rose 2.1% on the news.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

site_title: Toyota already leads VW by over 1 million vehicles in global car sales race
summary: Toyota has continued to lead Volkswagen in global car sales, surpassing its rival by over 1 million vehicles through April. Despite a 5.8% decline in worldwide deliveries, Toyota managed to limit the damage from COVID-19 lockdowns, while Volkswagen's sales plummeted 26% in the same period. Toyota's production target was pared back earlier in the year, but the company has maintained its lead, poised to repeat its performance as the world's largest auto-maker for a third straight year.

images.alt_text: In this Thursday, Nov. 22, 2012 photo, a Toyota car is displayed at the company's booth during Guangzhou 2012 Auto Show in China's southern city of Guangzhou. (AP Photo/Vincent Yu)

site_title: Japan govt drops timeframe for budget balancing target
summary: Japan's government has dropped a timeframe for balancing its primary budget, a goal previously set for the end of fiscal 2025, in its draft mid-year economic policy roadmap. The absence of a target year may indicate a shift towards prioritizing growth over fiscal discipline. The decision comes amid pressure from fiscal doves within Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's ruling party and amid concerns about Japan's public finances. The government still plans to tackle its fiscal target, but the lack of a specific deadline may raise questions about its resolve to address its tattered public finances.

site_title: Thai, Vietnam rice price hike plan 'impossible', Thai export body says
summary: Thailand's government planned a pact with Vietnam to boost bargaining power and mitigate rising production costs, but a top Thai industry official stated that raising rice prices would be "impossible" amid a global food crisis. Vietnam has yet to confirm the plan, which was announced on Friday. The proposal aims to counter rising costs and maintain competitiveness in the global rice market.

images.alt_text: THAILAND and Vietnam should jointly raise rice prices to boost their bargaining power in the global market, according to Thai premier Prayuth Chan-Ocha, a move that threatens higher food costs for consumers worldwide.
A poultry seller at Tekka Market at 11.45am on May 21, 2020.
THAILAND -- a major exporter of sugar, chickens and rice -- looks set to benefit as many of its Asian neighbours limit shipments of agricultural commodities to shelter consumers from surging prices.

site_title: SATS back from the red with H2 earnings of S$7.2 million
summary: SATS reported earnings of S$7.2 million for the second half of FY21-22, a significant improvement from a net loss of S$2 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 14.7% to S$607.3 million, driven by recovering travel and increased gateway services. However, expenditure surged 29.8% due to higher costs, leading to an operating loss of S$46.6 million. The group did not recommend a final dividend, citing the need to preserve cash for future growth and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Singapore Airlines is ramping up its workforce as travel to one of Asia’s largest aviation hubs rebounds.

site_title: GoTo’s Q1 loss soars to 6.5 trillion rupiah as marketing expenses rise
summary: GoTo Group, an Indonesian tech giant, reported a 6.5 trillion rupiah (S$609.8 million) net loss for Q1, more than triple the loss from the previous year. Despite a 65.5% year-on-year increase in net revenue to 1.5 trillion rupiah, the company's bottomline was weighed down by heavy sales and marketing costs, which rose over 7 times to 3.3 trillion rupiah. Management emphasized cost discipline to pursue profitability, with a focus on optimizing costs across its core businesses, including on-demand services and e-commerce.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Sharanya Pillai

2 top executives at Grab Holdings’ fintech business have quit, adding to other senior departures in recent months, as the Southeast Asian ride-hailing and delivery firm rejigs the key unit at the loss-making group, two sources said.

As co-founder of multi-billion dollar ride-hailing and food delivery firm Grab, Tan Hooi Ling is already smashing stereotypes in tech but she's also trying to blaze a trail for the next generation of female entrepreneurs in the industry.
INDONESIA'S biggest tech company GoTo Gojek Tokopedia intends to issue a maximum amount of 118.44 billion of shares worth around 10 per cent of its total capital through a private placement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Hotel room revenue reached its highest level since the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by international visitor numbers recovering after border reopenings. Real wage growth in 2021 was 1.6%, slightly higher than the previous year. Sultan Plaza is set to relaunch for collective sale on May 31 with an unchanged reserve price of S$360 million. In local news, Singapore stocks kicked off the week in the black, with the STI up 0.3%, despite concerns about inflation and economic growth.

images.alt_text: The transport and storage industry saw the biggest year-on-year growth at 41.7 per cent.

The aerospace segment expanded 24.2 per cent on the back of higher production of aircraft parts and more maintenance, repair and overhaul jobs from commercial airlines as a result of the lifting of border restrictions globally.

site_title: Sustainability at the heart of business
summary: OCBC Bank has embedded sustainable and responsible practices into its business strategy, aligning with its purpose and values. The bank has set 5 key pillars to achieve its sustainability goals, including putting customers first, building a sustainable future, and valuing its people. OCBC has made significant commitments, such as becoming the first bank in Southeast Asia to stop financing coal-fired power plants, adopting the Poseidon Principles, and launching initiatives to support SMEs and individuals in achieving sustainability. The bank aims to measure its performance against the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and reduce its carbon footprint through investments in energy-efficient technology and solar energy systems.

images.alt_text: 'Through the use of financing instruments including green loans, green bonds and sustainability-linked loans, we have actively supported our client's decarbonisationand sustainability efforts,' says Chng Bee Leng, OCBC's Group Head of Risk Policy

site_title: Man arrested after smearing Mona Lisa with cake at Louvre
summary: A 36-year-old man was arrested and placed in psychiatric care after smearing cake on the protective glass surrounding the Mona Lisa at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday. The incident was a protest against artists not focusing enough on environmental issues. The man, who was dressed as an elderly woman, was tackled by security guards after attempting to smash the glass and throwing roses. The painting was unharmed due to its bulletproof glass case. An inquiry into the incident has been opened.

images.alt_text: Visitors take pictures and video of the painting "Mona Lisa" after cake was smeared on the protective glass at the Lourve Museum in Paris, France May 29, 2022 in this screen grab obtained from a social media video. Twitter/@klevisl007/via REUTERS  THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: Russia readies new bond-payment plan in bid to avoid default
summary: Russia is planning a new bond-payment mechanism to avoid default, following the expiration of a 30-day grace period on missed coupon payments. The proposal, announced by Finance Minister Anton Siluanov, would allow foreign investors to open accounts in Russian banks in both roubles and hard currency, enabling unrestricted access to funds. This move aims to sidestep US sanctions and avoid default, as coupon payments worth around $100 million in euros and dollars had yet to reach foreign investors' accounts.

images.alt_text: The United States pushed Russia closer to the brink of a historic debt default on Wednesday by not extending its license to pay bondholders, as Washington ramps up pressure following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
RUSSIA initiated payment on 2 of its external bonds on Friday (May 20) in an attempt to stave off a looming sovereign default ahead of a key US licence allowing such transfers expiring next week.
Russia made what appeared to be a late U-turn to avoid a default on Friday, as it made a number of overdue interest payments in dollars on its overseas bonds.

site_title: Google backs India's ShareChat in US$300m funding round at US$5b valuation
summary: Google has invested nearly US$300 million in ShareChat, India's social media firm, valuing it at nearly US$5 billion. This deal comes after Google backed Josh, a short video app, in a bearish market for Indian startups. ShareChat has 180 million monthly active users and Moj, its sister firm, has a combined 300 million users. The investment from Google, Times Group, and Temasek Holdings is seen as a sign of the appetite for the short video sector in India, where tech startups have been struggling to raise funds due to corporate governance concerns.

site_title: Shedding light on audit vs non-audit fees
summary: ComfortDelGro's shareholders rejected the reappointment of auditor Deloitte due to non-audit fees exceeding 50% of audit fees. The company paid Deloitte non-audit fees for initial public offering (IPO) work in Australia, raising questions about the 50% threshold. The ACRA Code of Professional Conduct and Ethics does not prohibit non-audit fees from exceeding 50% of audit fees, but auditors must disclose and discuss safeguards with those charged with governance. The incident highlights the importance of transparency and adequate disclosures to protect investor interests and maintain auditor independence.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro head office located along Braddell Road on Nov 25, 2021.

site_title: “The Next Frontier”: Towards the metaverse and immersive data
summary: Singaporean businesses are poised to capitalize on the metaverse and immersive data, offering new ways to connect with customers. This emerging frontier combines augmented reality, virtual reality, and depth perception to engage multiple senses, including touch and smell. By leveraging these technologies, SMEs in Asia Pacific can create more immersive relationships with prospective customers and stay ahead in the competitive market. The metaverse is expected to revolutionize communication and persuasion, providing a new platform for businesses to innovate and thrive.

images.alt_text: A participant at VR World in Manhattan on Monday, Nov. 1, 2021. NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future. (Jeenah Moon/The New York Times)##########mlcrypto13##########

site_title: A global genomic surveillance system to thwart pandemics
summary: A global genomic surveillance system is needed to track and respond to emerging diseases, including the recent outbreaks of unidentified hepatitis, monkeypox, and avian flu. The current system is flawed, with limited data sharing, inadequate technology, and insufficient metadata to inform policy decisions. A new system would require real-time tracking of virus evolution, rapid characterization of new outbreaks, and screening of viral species found across the animal kingdom. International cooperation, data governance frameworks, and access to technology are essential to make the system work, and it could save billions in economic costs and millions of lives.

images.alt_text: Scientists working on a nasal spray for SARS-CoV-2 are also developing a single vaccine for a broad range of coronaviruses, that could protect against future variants.
The leading hypothesis remains that adenovirus 41 has a major role, but the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is looking at other factors too.

site_title: China, Pacific islands unable to reach consensus on regional pact
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi urged Pacific island nations not to be "too anxious" about China's aims after a meeting with counterparts from 10 island nations deferred consideration of a sweeping trade and security communique. The draft communique, which proposed security exchanges and a free trade zone, prompted opposition from at least one nation and was met with concerns from US allies about China's growing influence in the region. Wang said further discussions were needed to shape more consensus, and China will release its own position paper on cooperation proposals with Pacific island countries.

site_title: More than a third of STI constituents log double-digit total returns year to date
summary: More than a third of the 30 Straits Times Index (STI) constituent stocks have registered double-digit total returns in the year to date, with Sembcorp Industries leading with a 44% return. Two-thirds of the STI constituents have generated positive total returns, outpacing the FTSE Developed Index's 11% decline. The 30 constituents have seen net institutional inflows of S$538 million, with Singtel leading the way with S$666 million of net buying, while DBS saw the largest net institutional outflow with S$608 million of net selling.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Participants at the 'Grow Your Portfolio with ETFs' roundtable flagged regional ETFs as a potential diversification strategy.
Daily turnover came in at 1.7 billion securities worth a collective S$1.3 billion, after advancers outnumbered decliners 312 to 175.

site_title: UK’s Johnson ‘disappointed’ by treatment of Liverpool fans in Paris, says spokesman
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed disappointment over the treatment of Liverpool soccer fans at the Champions League final in Paris, citing footage of crowd trouble as "upsetting and concerning." Dozens of fans, including children, were tear-gassed by riot police after attempting to force their way into the stadium.

images.alt_text: Liverpool supporters greet their team during an open top bus parade where the English Premier League football club displays the FA Cup and the Carabao Cup trophies through the streets of Liverpool, Britain, May 29, 2022.

site_title: Singapore Airlines’ upgraded lounges reflect its confidence in premium travel
summary: Singapore Airlines has upgraded its lounges at Changi Airport, spending S$50 million on the improvements, which include new resting pods and a bar in the Business Class SilverKris Lounge. The airline's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, expressed confidence in premium travel, citing the expected growth of economies in the region and the airline's plans to increase passenger capacity to 67% of pre-pandemic levels by September. The upgrades signal the airline's confidence in the premium travel market and come as passenger traffic has taken off dramatically following Singapore's relaxation of border restrictions.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Singapore Airlines is ramping up its workforce as travel to one of Asia’s largest aviation hubs rebounds.
The industry is currently producing only 200,000 tonnes or 240 million litres of SAF a year: less than 0.1 per cent of the jet fuel consumed a year.
Singapore Airlines is expected by analysts to be profitable from FY2023.
Singapore's Changi Airport Terminal 2, which has been closed since May 2020, will be progressively opened from next Sunday (May 29).
Singapore Airlines chief Goh Choon Phong said extending the sponsorship of F
Singapore will strive to keep its borders open and stay connected to the rest of world even if a new variant of Covid-19 emerges, Transport Minister S Iswaran said.

site_title: China bringing in new rules for celebrity management agencies
summary: China will implement new rules on June 30 to govern the operation of multi-channel network (MCN) firms that manage celebrities and online influencers. The regulations aim to curb behaviors such as unfettered celebrity worship and fan club fights involving minors. MCN firms will need to obtain licenses, follow content and client management rules, and be held accountable for fan group management. The move follows China's regulatory crackdown on the livestreaming sector and the growth of the MCN industry, which has over 28,000 agencies in China.

site_title: EU struggles to clear Hungary’s block on Russian oil ban
summary: EU ambassadors made a final push to persuade Hungary to accept a watered-down oil embargo against Russia, but Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban refused, citing concerns about the economic impact. The EU is struggling to finalize a 6th package of sanctions against Russia amid concerns over Ukraine and European defense spending. Hungary imports 65% of its oil from Russia, and Orban has requested a 4-year delay and nearly $1.1 billion in European funding to adapt its refineries. The EU is trying to find a compromise solution that would exclude the Druzhba pipeline from the embargo.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose to two-month highs on Monday.
A monitoring instrument seen on the gas distribution pipeline in Beregdaroc, Hungary, one of several points where Russian gas crosses into the European Union.

site_title: Thailand poised for record sale of bonds to retail investors
summary: Thailand plans to sell 55 billion baht (S$2.2 billion) of sovereign bonds to retail investors next month, aiming to raise a record amount and lower its reliance on the volatile institutional market for funding. The Finance Ministry's issuance of savings securities will total 165 billion in the fiscal year ending Sep 30, 33% higher than last year. The move aims to achieve the government's dual goal of reducing borrowing costs and developing a savings alternative to bank deposits.

site_title: China uses digital yuan to stimulate virus-hit consumption
summary: China is using its digital yuan to stimulate consumption in its pandemic-hit economy, distributing 30 million yuan in free digital cash in Shenzhen and 50 million yuan in "red packets" in Xiong'an New Area. The move aims to boost transparency and effectiveness of government policies, with more e-CNY applications expected. Transactions using e-CNY totalled 87.6 billion yuan at the end of 2021, and the central bank plans to use e-CNY for pension payments, fiscal subsidies, and infrastructure spending in the future. The campaign aims to revive consumption and aid businesses, amid a global race to develop central bank digital currencies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign indicating digital yuan, also referred to as e-CNY, is pictured at a shopping mall in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Treasury bulls brace for reckoning with forces driving inflation
summary: The Treasury market has experienced a rebound, with benchmark 10-year yields extending their retreat from a May peak of 3.2%. The rally is attributed to signs of worsening liquidity and consumer struggles with surging energy and food costs, while higher interest rates are cooling housing. Investors are bracing for a potential recession, with the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike and expectations for further hikes. May employment data is expected to highlight labor market strength, but the Treasury market's ability to cope with sentiment shifts remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: With US inflation rising at the fastest pace in nearly four decades, the Fed’s policy committee early this month hiked the key rate by a half point – the biggest increase since 2000.
The move into bonds and out of equities underscores rising doubts that the Fed will be able to avoid triggering a recession.

site_title: Shanghai to lift lockdown restrictions on June 1
summary: Shanghai, China announced the end of its 2-month-long Covid-19 lockdown on May 30, allowing residents in virus-free areas to leave their homes and drive their cars. The easing of curbs applies to about 22.3 million people, with residents still required to wear masks and discouraged from gathering. The move is seen as a step towards restoring normal life, but concerns remain about the lack of an exit strategy and the impact on the economy. China's zero-Covid policy is at odds with other countries, and the country reported fewer than 100 new cases on May 29.

images.alt_text: Workers remove barriers previous surrounding a neighborhood placed under lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai, China, on Monday, May 30, 2022. China reported the fewest new Covid-19 cases in almost three months, with the easing of outbreaks in Shanghai emboldening authorities to relax some of the strictest virus controls of the pandemic and move to stimulate the country’s faltering economy. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil association expects 52,000 migrant workers to enter by year-end
summary: Malaysia's palm oil association expects approximately 52,000 migrant workers to arrive by the end of the year, but this influx is deemed insufficient to address the labour shortage exacerbated by pandemic-related border closures. The shortage has driven production to multi-year lows due to the Russia-Ukraine war and export restrictions in Indonesia, contributing to the world's edible oil shortage. Malaysian plantations, reliant on foreign workers mostly from Indonesia, are struggling to meet demands.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, the world’s top palm oil producer, allowed exports of the vegetable oil to resume from May 23, but companies have faced regulatory hurdles that have slowed the process of getting shipments out.
Jakarta’s flip flop over palm-oil exports will help Malaysia-listed planters with lower exposure to Indonesia such as Kuala Lumpur Kepong, said Bloomberg Intelligence analyst Alvin Tai.

INDONESIA will allocate about 1 million tonnes of palm oil for export, prioritising companies that have been registered for the government's bulk cooking oil programme, a senior trade ministry official said on Friday (May 27).

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Monday, May 30, driven by economic optimism. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX gained 0.6%, and Paris's CAC 40 climbed 0.6%. Asian equities also surged as investors rediscovered confidence after healthy US data and China easing COVID curbs. The rally was attributed to relief and investors' anticipation of an economic recovery.

site_title: Toyota misses April global production target due to Covid-19, parts shortage
summary: Toyota missed its April global production target due to Covid-19 outbreaks and a parts shortage, producing 692,259 vehicles, a 9.1% drop from last year. The automaker fell short of its 750,000 vehicle target. This setback marks a slowdown in Toyota's post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: Singapore stocks kick off week in the black, STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% on Monday, closing at 3,238.92 points, driven by advancers outnumbering decliners 312 to 175. Notable gains included Nio and Jardine Matheson Holdings, while Jardine Cycle and Carriage was the biggest loser. The local market shrugged off concerns about inflation, pandemic-induced economic troubles, and interest rates, with Asia's broader markets also ending higher. Analysts attribute the rally to a weaker US dollar and a recovery in Asia's equities, with some speculating that China's economic recovery may be underway.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index  down 3.74 points or 0.24 per cent to 1,543.02.

HONG KONG shares closed on Monday (May 30) with more strong gains as traders welcomed an easing of Covid containment measures in Shanghai and Beijing, which raised hopes for the world's number 2 economy.

site_title: Thailand's Kasikornbank to buy majority stake in Indonesia firm
summary: Thailand's Kasikornbank agreed to purchase a majority stake in Indonesia's Bank Maspion for $220 million, giving the Thai lender 67.5% of the shares. The deal, expected to be finalized by the end of the year, aims to establish a permanent foothold in Indonesia as the Thai bank seeks investment abroad due to stagnating local economy and high household debt. This move follows Kasikornbank's previous investments in Vietnam and Myanmar, and its existing stake in Ayeyarwaddy Farmers Development Bank in Myanmar.

site_title: After Chinese property sector battered, Seazen tests market with dollar bond issue
summary: SEAZEN Group, a Chinese property developer, plans to issue a US dollar 364-day green bond with an expected yield of 7.95% to refinance debt and fund green projects. This marks one of the few corporate bond issues from Chinese real estate developers this year, amid a debt crisis triggered by tighter debt cap rules and liquidity squeeze. Seazen's bond issue comes after Moody's cut its corporate family rating to Ba2, citing weakening sales, lower liquidity buffer, and constrained funding access.

images.alt_text: Stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen each accepted an application for residential Reits backed by rental incomes from affordable housing, exchange filings show.
Greenland Holdings, China’s 11th-largest builder, is seeking investor approval for a possible bond-repayment extension, triggering fresh concerns about its financial health.
Evergrande said in March that it will unveil a preliminary debt restructuring proposal by the end of July.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes at over 1-month high on China growth optimism
summary: The Nikkei share average closed at its highest in over a month, rising 2.19% to 27,369.43, driven by machinery and technology stocks following China's easing of Covid-19 curbs and stimulus measures. Shanghai authorities will cancel conditions for businesses to resume work, boosting risk appetite. Japanese machinery makers and electronics companies like Sony and Fanuc also gained, while shipping firms fell.

images.alt_text: Asian markets rose on Monday as investors rediscovered some verve after the release of healthy US data and the easing of some of China's Covid-19 curbs.
The Hang Seng Index added 1.14 per cent, or 236.14 points, to 20,933.50.
Australian shares rose on Monday.

site_title: Bank of Japan sticks to powerful easing, sees inflation as short-lived
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has maintained its powerful monetary easing policy, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda pledging to stick to stimulus measures to aid the economy's recovery. The yen has regained stability after a recent weakening, attributed to the dollar's pullback. The BOJ's decision has been criticized for allowing the currency to decline to 2-decade lows, sparking concerns about rising inflation. The BOJ's stance contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's tightening policy, fueling debate over the effectiveness of the BOJ's approach.

images.alt_text: THE Bank of Japan (BOJ) will keep interest rates ultra-low as inflation won't pick up much, governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Friday (May 20), underscoring the view that Japan will remain an outlier among G7 nations eyeing monetary policy tightening.

JAPAN'S government will urge the central bank to aim at achieving its 2 per cent inflation target in a "sustainable and stable fashion," a draft of its long-term policy outline seen by Reuters showed on Wednesday (May 25).

site_title: Hotel revenues continue recovery in April as high-end room rates inch higher
summary: Hotel revenues in Singapore have reached their highest level since the Covid-19 pandemic, with S$180.5 million in April, according to the Singapore Tourism Board. This marks a significant improvement from March, when revenue was S$151.9 million. The increase in revenue is attributed to rising occupancies and average room rates, pushing up revenue per available room (RevPAR). Visitor arrivals also surged to 294,304 in April, from 121,197 in March, as international travel continues to recover following border reopenings.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.
The restrained outlook comes as several major source markets remain effectively shut, one economist told The Business Times.

site_title: Pokemon Psyduck becomes symbol of China's lockdown headaches
summary: A Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) promotion in China has led to a surge in demand for a Pokémon character toy, Psyduck, due to its depiction of a character experiencing headaches and expressing frustration with Covid-19 lockdowns. The toy, which was given away in children's meals, has sold for up to $200 on the black market, with some users using it to vent their frustrations on social media. KFC has denied supporting the reselling of the toy at inflated prices, while public figures, including the founder of XPeng Motors, have used Psyduck to express their own frustrations with the lockdowns.

images.alt_text: Yum China, BYD say China's Covid curbs have hit operations

site_title: HSBC Singapore appoints new head of SME banking
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed Alan Ng as its new head of business banking, focusing on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Ng, previously head of global trade and receivables finance at HSBC Vietnam, will report to Regina Lee, head of commercial banking. The appointment aims to capture more share of the growing SME market, benefiting customers from Ng's decades of experience in Singapore and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Australia: Shares ends at over 3-week high on tech, mining boost
