summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.5% higher at 7,286.6, its highest since May 6, driven by gains in tech stocks and commodity firms. The rally followed a Wall Street rally on optimism about a stable economy and peaking inflation. Tech stocks like Block and Xero rose 10.9% and 5.2%, respectively. Export-reliant miners also advanced, with BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group climbing 0.3-2.8%. AGL Energy fell 1.7% after shelving its demerger plan.

images.alt_text: A man stands in front of an electronic board displaying stock information inside the Australian Securities Exchange, operated by ASX Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Sept. 9, 2013. The Australian dollar's strongest weekly advance since December 2011 is a reminder to Prime Minister-Elect Tony Abbott that his plans to revive a slowing economy will be hostage to currency markets. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
Participants at the 'Grow Your Portfolio with ETFs' roundtable flagged regional ETFs as a potential diversification strategy.
The Nikkei share average gained 2.19 per cent to 27,369.43, its highest close since Apr 21.
Asian markets rose on Monday as investors rediscovered some verve after the release of healthy US data and the easing of some of China's Covid-19 curbs.

site_title: Sultan Plaza set for relaunch with unchanged S$360m reserve price
summary: Sultan Plaza, a 45-year-old property in downtown District 7, Singapore, will relaunch for collective sale on May 31 with an unchanged reserve price of S$360 million. The site, located near Nicoll Highway and Lavender MRT stations, comprises 211 commercial units and 33 offices. The development has received in-principle approval for a potential sale of adjoining state land, allowing for expansion to a gross floor area of 317,198.9 sq ft. The tender will close on June 28, with no additional buyer's stamp duty payable.

images.alt_text: Sultan Plaza collective sale closing date extended to Mar 3

site_title: What’s changed over 30 years of sustainable investing in Asia?
summary: Over 30 years of sustainable investing in Asia has seen significant changes, with the region transforming into an economic powerhouse. By 2040, Asia is expected to account for 52% of global GDP and 40% of global consumption. Asian companies are leading in innovation, e-commerce, 5G, gaming, and social media, with Chinese social media platform TikTok having twice as many users as US invention Twitter. Investing in Asia requires a focus on Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) principles, with companies that ignore ESG factors exposing themselves to serious risk. Despite immediate challenges, Asia offers abundant opportunities for investment, particularly with sustainability and climate change at the forefront.

images.alt_text: Buying shares of ExxonMobil in the secondary market does not benefit Exxon in any way. Subscribing to a new bond or a new share issuance, however, does benefit Exxon.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rally as inflation and China concerns ease
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.2% to a near 4-week high, driven by easing concerns over global inflation and China's Covid-19 lockdown. The benchmark Kospi ended at 2,669.66, its highest close since May 4. Technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix surged, while LG Energy Solution jumped 2.09%. The won also rose, its best day in over 2 months, as foreigners were net buyers of 351.2 billion won worth of shares.

images.alt_text:
epa07270620 A South Korean dealer works in front of monitors at the KEB Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 09 January 2019.
The benchmark South Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 39.44 points or 1.95 percent to close at 2,064.71, in expectations of a rise trade negotiation between the US and China.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN
The benchmark Kospi closed up 25.60 points, or 0.98 per cent, at 2,638.05.

site_title: Hwa Hong mired in intergenerational shareholding dispute
summary: The Ong family, controlling shareholders of property player Hwa Hong Corporation, are embroiled in an intergenerational dispute over the company's privatization offer. The dispute centers on former group managing director Ong Choo Eng's privatization offer, which includes a S$0.37 per-share offer price. The Ong family members, including Ong Mui Eng, Ong Kwee Eng, Ong Choo Eng, Steven Ong, Ong Hian Eng, and Ong Hoo Eng, are vying for control of the company. The dispute has led to a series of changes in the company's board and leadership, including the resignation of Ong Eng Yaw and the appointment of new directors.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
meeting room, board room, conference hall

site_title: Tata Motors looks to buy Ford India plant in electric vehicle push
summary: Tata Motors has signed a memorandum of understanding to potentially buy a Ford India manufacturing facility in Gujarat, aiming to increase its electric vehicle production capacity to 300,000 units per year. The deal, which includes the land, assets, and eligible employees, will support Tata's expansion in the electric mobility space. The company, which already dominates India's electric car market, plans to invest in new machinery and equipment to boost production. This move follows Ford's decision to stop production in India and seek options for its two factories.

images.alt_text: Tata Motors  said on Friday it plans to launch electric cars with a minimum range of 500km and advanced technology features, targeting buyers in India and beyond.

FORD MOTOR said on Thursday (May 12) it had dropped plans to make electric vehicles (EVs) in India for exports, while it explores options for its 2 factories in the country that stopped production last year.

site_title: Commonwealth’s future in spotlight with Queen’s Jubilee
summary: Queen Elizabeth marks 70 years on the throne, her Platinum Jubilee, amid uncertainty about the future of the monarchy and the Commonwealth. With her declining health, preparations are intensifying for her eventual passing, sparking questions about the relevance of the Commonwealth and the UK's future. The Queen's legacy is being highlighted, but her personal popularity is declining, and there are growing signs of division within the UK, particularly in Scotland and Northern Ireland. The future of the monarchy, with Prince Charles potentially succeeding her, is also uncertain, and whether she will choose to abdicate before her death remains a possibility.

images.alt_text: Momin Rashid and Sangita Bhunia, students who will perform at Queen's Platinum Jubilee Pageant, at the George Harris Academy in Birmingham earlier this month. ,

While nearly all attention will be focused next week on Queen Elizabeth as she celebrates her 70th anniversary on the throne this year, for those with eyes on the future of the British monarchy, attention is switching to her grandson Prince William.

site_title: Real wage growth up 1.6% in 2021: MOM
summary: Singapore's real wage growth rose 1.6% in 2021, slightly higher than the previous year but lower than the 3.3% recorded in 2019. Despite inflation exceeding wage growth, wages still increased in real terms. The Ministry of Manpower expects real wage growth to slow next year due to elevated inflation and supply chain disruptions. Economists predict a wage-price spiral, but some see it as manageable, with nominal wages catching up to inflation. Total wage growth, including employer CPF contributions, reached 3.9% in 2021, double the 2020 figure.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Inflation partially erodes Singaporeans' wage gains, but recovery still ongoing

Vendors selling fish at a street market in the Tondo district of Manila. Sonal Varma, an economist at Nomura, said that “we are still far from a recession, higher unemployment rate and double-digit inflation” in the region.

site_title: Data and engagement can create powerful customer loyal strategies for Asean brands
summary: Asean brands can leverage data and engagement to create powerful customer loyalty strategies, as customer loyalty remains the least evolved dimension in marketing and sales plans. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated online shopping, and customers now prioritize convenience, driving brands to focus on data-driven engagement. Research shows that loyalty programs can increase customer spending by 50% and that building experiential benefits is key to creating a loyal customer base. Brands can use first-party data, gamification, and personalized experiences to foster meaningful relationships with customers and drive sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Meeting the demands of the young, nationalistic and exacting Gen Z will require an immense shift in how Western companies - who have bet that decades of demand for foreign goods will endure - do business in China and poses an unprecedented challenge to their market dominance.

site_title: Bitcoin rallies above US$30,000 as crypto complex stages comeback
summary: Bitcoin surged above US$30,000 for the third consecutive day, breaking the key level after being stuck for 4 days. The largest cryptocurrency jumped 4.4% to US$30,441.43, with other altcoins such as Avalanche and Cardano also gaining significant ground. The rally comes as concerns about inflation and the collapse of the Terra ecosystem have weighed on the market, but some analysts see the recent price movements as a sign of a potential comeback for the crypto complex.

site_title: Indonesia could issue palm oil export permits today: official
summary: Indonesia's trade ministry is set to issue palm oil export permits today, allowing the country's top palm oil producer to resume exports after a 3-week ban. The government aims to allocate 1 million tonnes of palm oil for export, with the volume dependent on refining capacity and domestic demand. Companies have faced regulatory hurdles, but officials expect permits to be issued soon, with exports potentially returning to pre-ban levels of 2.5-3 million tonnes per month.

images.alt_text: Jakarta’s flip flop over palm-oil exports will help Malaysia-listed planters with lower exposure to Indonesia such as Kuala Lumpur Kepong, said Bloomberg Intelligence analyst Alvin Tai.

INDONESIA will allocate about 1 million tonnes of palm oil for export, prioritising companies that have been registered for the government's bulk cooking oil programme, a senior trade ministry official said on Friday (May 27).
Packages of cooking oil on display at a traditional market in Jakarta. From June, a subsidy in Indonesia on bulk cooking oil will be replaced with a price cap on raw materials.

site_title: Nepal army finds wreckage of missing plane
summary: Nepal's army has found the wreckage of a missing Twin Otter aircraft that crashed on Sunday, killing 22 people. The plane, operated by Tara Air, was flying from Pokhara to Jomsom when it lost contact 15 minutes into the flight. The wreckage was discovered on a mountainside in Nepal, with debris including a visible registration number. The search operation had resumed after a pause due to bad weather, and rescue teams are now working to gather more information.

site_title: Meta Oculus impasse in Germany has startups facing harsh reality
summary: Meta's removal of Oculus headsets from the German market has created a stumbling block for the country's nascent virtual reality industry, with local startups forced to choose between developing applications using rival headsets or giving up on the US$4.4 billion market. The dispute between Meta and German regulators has sparked concerns over data protection and market dominance, with some developers opting for alternative headsets like the Pico Neo. The situation has led to a significant impact on the country's virtual reality sector, with some firms struggling to adapt to the lack of Meta's headsets.

images.alt_text: Mark Zuckerberg said he plans to invest heavily in his company's metaverse ambitions and that will mean losing "significant" amounts of money on the project in the next 3 to 5 years.

site_title: Shell greenlights US$2.5b Crux gas project off Australia
summary: Shell has approved a US$2.5 billion project to develop the Crux gas field off Australia, which is expected to start construction in 2023 and produce first gas in 2027. The project will help Shell's Asian customers transition from coal to gas and provide a secure supply source, particularly following sanctions on Russia. The use of existing infrastructure will reduce development costs, making the project competitive and commercially attractive.

images.alt_text: Shareholders of ExxonMobil Corp and Chevron Corp on Wednesday voted in favour of the energy transition strategies proposed by the two largest US oil producers.

Six months after the world agreed in Glasgow to a UN climate pact with bold, new targets, political and business leaders facing an energy crisis, volatile markets and an economic downturn are grappling with how to cut carbon emissions.

Climate issues are set to take centre stage at Shell's annual general meeting on Tuesday, with a key group saying the energy giant isn't abiding by a landmark court order requiring it to cut emissions by 45 per cent by 2030.

site_title: From baristas to inspectors: Singapore's robot workforce plugs labour gaps
summary: Singapore businesses have increasingly turned to deploying robots to address labor gaps, particularly in the wake of the pandemic. Robots are being used for various tasks such as surveying construction sites, scanning library bookshelves, and making coffee for commuters. The city-state relies on foreign workers, but their number has fallen, prompting companies to adopt automation. Robots have been found to be efficient, reducing labor needs and costs. However, some customers still prefer human interaction, highlighting the need for a balance between technology and human touch.

images.alt_text: Workers using a drone to spray pesticide on durian trees at the Top Fruit durian farm in Batu Pahat on April 26, 2022.
This handout photo provided by Yuman Gao and Rui Jin on May 4, 2022 shows a new flight path planning system enables drone swarms to fly through crowded forests without collisions.

site_title: HSBC clients query bank on climate, one to review engagement: sources
summary: HSBC is facing queries from clients about its commitment to fighting climate change after a senior banker downplayed the risks, sparking concerns about how the bank will be perceived by clients. The bank's global head of responsible investing, Stuart Kirk, was suspended after making comments that climate change is not a financial risk. The bank's chief executive, Noel Quinn, has distanced himself from Kirk's remarks, but the controversy has led to at least one large institutional investor reconsidering its relationship with HSBC. The bank is also facing internal concerns and criticism from campaigners.

images.alt_text: A logo of Standard Chartered is displayed at its main branch in Hong Kong, China, Aug. 1, 2017. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

The solar farm of Marcoussis, south of Paris;  the demand to shift away from fossil fuels is, if anything, now accelerating due to the current Ukraine situation; Europe has increased its renewable energy target from 40 per cent to 45 per cent by 2030.
The Singapore Green Plan 2030 advances Singapore's national agenda on sustainable development.
HSBC Holdings has been examining an initial public offering of its Indonesian business to tap buoyant investor demand in the world's fourth-most populous country.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend Wall Street rally as China eases curbs
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as investors regained confidence after the release of healthy US data and China easing some of its Covid-19 curbs. The gains extended a positive end to last week for global equities, with hopes that the months-long sell-off may have run its course. China's easing of lockdown measures in Shanghai and Beijing lifted hopes for the world's number two economy, while US data showed an easing of the key personal consumption expenditures price index.

site_title: Safe as houses? Rising rates test foundations of property boom
summary: A decade-long housing boom is facing its first test as rising interest rates and inflation erode households' budgets, causing homebuyers to become scarce. Home prices are already falling in some markets, such as China, New Zealand, and parts of Australia. Lenders and regulators warn that inflated home prices may stagnate or fall by up to a quarter, with the US average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate surging to 5.5% from 2.7% in 2020. This threatens to prick property bubbles and affects affordability, with economists cutting forecasts for home price growth.

site_title: Tech giant Grab's female co-founder blazes a trail
summary: Grab's female co-founder, Tan Hooi Ling, is blazing a trail for women in the tech industry. She co-founded the multi-billion dollar ride-hailing and food delivery firm Grab in 2012 and now oversees hundreds of engineers. The company aims to increase women in leadership positions to 40% by 2030 and ensure equal pay. Tan uses data to keep the company honest and address sexism and inequality. Despite challenges, Grab remains committed to developing talent and empowering women in the tech sector, with Tan hoping to create a more inclusive environment for future generations.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on March 18, 2022 shows ride-hailing and food delivery company Grab's co-founder and chief operating officer Tan Hooi Ling speaking during an interview in Singapore. - As co-founder of the multi-billion company, Tan Hooi Ling is already smashing stereotypes in tech -- but she's also blazing a trail for the next generation of female entrepreneurs in the industry. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP) / TO GO WITH Singapore-Grab-transport-women, INTERVIEW by Martin Abbugao

2 top executives at Grab Holdings’ fintech business have quit, adding to other senior departures in recent months, as the Southeast Asian ride-hailing and delivery firm rejigs the key unit at the loss-making group, two sources said.

site_title: Golden Gate Ventures to open 2 new offices in Vietnam
summary: Golden Gate Ventures, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, is opening two new offices in Vietnam, in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, to tap into the country's growing tech scene. The firm has also signed a memorandum of understanding with the Vietnam National Innovation Centre to support local entrepreneurship. Founded in 2011, Golden Gate has backed over 60 South-east Asian startups, including Carousell and Xendit, and sees the new offices complementing its presence in Singapore and Indonesia to form a "startup golden triangle" in the region.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
How S-E Asia's thriving tech ecosystem has led the regional VC/PE expansion

Vietnam’s VinFast is shifting its headquarters to Singapore as the fledgling electric vehicle (EV) maker readies for a public listing and the first production run of cars for US and European markets, its chief executive told Reuters.

site_title: High UK inflation hastens 'real living wage' announcement
summary: The Living Wage Foundation has announced it will bring forward the 2022/23 "real living wage" rate to September due to high inflation, which reached 9% in April, the highest since 1982. The current rate is £9.90 per hour, and the charity will encourage employers to pay the new rate as soon as possible. This decision aims to reflect the rising cost of living and follows the charity's usual annual announcement in November.

images.alt_text: BRITISH finance minister Rishi Sunak said on Friday (May 27) his new £15 billion (S$25.9 billion) cost-of-living support package would have an impact of less than 1 percentage point on inflation.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report reveals a shift in the tanker and dry bulk market, with the Capesize market experiencing headwinds. The Pacific Ocean trade saw charterers achieve lower fixing levels, while the Atlantic region followed suit due to low spot market cargo levels and tonnage building. The Transatlantic C8 dropped to $22,100, and backhaul trade was quieter this week, with the C16 Backhaul route halving in value to $17,350. The market is now expected to continue downward trend.

images.alt_text: An oil tanker near the Marathon Anacortes Refinery in Anacortes, Washington, U.S., on Monday, March 7, 2022. Oil had its biggest daily swing ever, with Brent surging to nearly $140 after the U.S. said it was considering a ban on Russian petroleum imports.. Photographer: David Ryder/Bloomberg
A bulk carrier for coal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.22 points or 0.14% to 1,544.54 at 9:07 am on Monday, with 185.4 million lots traded at RM62.2 million. The market saw 204 gains and 157 losses.

site_title: China prepares final missions to complete its own space station
summary: China has released details on the final stages of its Tiangong space station, including the upcoming launch of the Shenzhou XIV mission in June, followed by the arrival of space labs in July and October. The station, which will be China's only space station, is expected to be complete by the end of the year. This marks a significant achievement under President Xi Jinping's efforts to match the US as the dominant power in space. China's space program has also included landing on Mars and the far side of the moon, and the country is now racing with the US to govern future space activity.

images.alt_text: Space is a key area of cooperation for Japan with the United States, its closest ally, amid heightened tensions with an increasingly assertive China, which itself aims to become a space power.
The US has blocked China from taking part in the International Space Station (pictured) - a move that simply prompted Beijing to build its own.

site_title: Race to save undersea Stone Age cave art masterpieces
summary: French archaeologists are racing to preserve ancient Stone Age cave art masterpieces, "Cosquer," submerged off the coast of southern France, before climate change and pollution damage the 15,000-year-old paintings. A 137-meter-long tunnel leads to a 2,500-square-meter cavern, home to 600 signs, images, and carvings, including prehistoric marine life. A replica of the cave, almost life-sized, is being built in Marseille, with 3D data gathered from the site. The project aims to preserve the art and artifacts before they are lost, with the French government launching a major push to record everything about the cavern.

images.alt_text: Ivorian artist Mounou Desire Koffi making an artwork with used telephone keyboards at his residence in Bingerville.

site_title: MoneyGram CEO sees a future in stablecoin remittances
summary: MoneyGram International is launching a service in partnership with the Stellar blockchain, allowing users to send stablecoins and convert them to hard currency. The move aims to broaden the adoption of digital currencies, particularly in emerging markets where remittances are becoming increasingly popular. The partnership is seen as a bridge between the crypto and fiat worlds, with stablecoins providing a 1-to-1 relationship with a commodity or currency like the US dollar. MoneyGram CEO Alex Holmes is confident in digital currencies, despite recent market volatility, and believes the service will help spread crypto usage in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: The current crypto crash could be a new bullish signal for Bitcoin, and possibly Ethereum, as extreme volatility brings a sharper focus to the market.

site_title: Billionaire’s AGL win jolts Australia awake to climate activism
summary: Australian billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes halted AGL's demerger plans, forcing the company to scrap plans to operate coal-fired power plants for another 2 decades. Cannon-Brookes, Atlassian founder, joined activist shareholders like Exxon Mobil's Engine No 1 in successfully fighting big polluters using shareholder activism tactics. This move may shake the status quo on climate issues in Australia, where shareholder activism is relatively rare.

site_title: China aiming for greater influence with Pacific Islands summit
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi is set to meet with Pacific Island nations to discuss trade, policing, and cybersecurity, amid a push for greater influence in the region. China is proposing a free-trade deal and a special envoy, while the US and Australia compete for sway. Fiji has joined the US's Indo-Pacific Economic Framework, while Micronesian President David Panuelo has warned China's plans could spark a Cold War. Wang has called for "fair competition" but warned it should not turn "vicious".

images.alt_text: FIJI is joining US President Joe Biden's Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF), the White House said on Thursday (May 26), making it the first Pacific Island country in the plan that is part of a US effort to push back on China's growing regional influence.

site_title: Australian regulator sues ANZ over alleged overstatement of credit card balances
summary: Australia's market regulator, ASIC, has commenced civil penalty proceedings against ANZ Banking Group for allegedly misleading customers over their credit card accounts. Approximately 165,750 clients were charged incorrect fees and interest between 2016 and 2018 due to system errors. ANZ has already remediated over A$10 million in affected customers, but ASIC seeks further remedies for those wrongly charged since 2018. The regulator's deputy chair, Sarah Court, described the alleged misconduct as resulting from system errors and a lack of effort to fix the issues.

images.alt_text: ANZ beat estimates for first-half profit on Wednesday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades The Hour Glass to ‘hold’ on moderating revenue outlook
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its call on The Hour Glass to "hold" from "buy" due to moderating revenue outlook in FY2023 amid macroeconomic uncertainties. The research team expects revenue to slow down due to recession and inflation fears, as well as the return of tourists and Chinese tourists. The target price was cut to S$2.54 from S$2.62, and shares were trading at S$2.40, up 1.3% on the day.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The Hour Glass posted a net profit of S$92.1 million for its fiscal second half ended Mar 31, 2022.
There were 10 primary-listed companies that filed notifications on share buybacks over the 4 sessions, with a total consideration of S$7.7 million.
Brokers' take: DBS initiates The Hour Glass with 'buy' on Asia's growing wealth

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday tracking US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking US gains, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 1.21% and the broader Topix index up 1.01%. Investors are focusing on global economic indicators due this week.

site_title: Isetan Singapore names new managing director
summary: Isetan Singapore has appointed Shioji Hiramatsu, 53, as its new managing director and executive director, effective May 30. Hiramatsu, previously president of Isetan Mitsukoshi Human Solutions, will oversee the department store operator's business. Outgoing CEO Koji Oyama, 55, will take on an executive position in Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings, the holding company for Mitsukoshi and Isetan department stores. This transition is expected to facilitate the handover of Oyama's duties.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Facade of Isetan Singapore outlet at Parkway Parade on August 13, 2021.

site_title: Blackstone targets US$5b for Asia private credit business
summary: Blackstone is targeting a tenfold increase in its Asia-Pacific private credit business to reach at least $5 billion, up from $500 million as of the fourth quarter of last year. The US alternative asset manager aims to tap into a growing market with increasing demand for debt financing away from bank loans. Blackstone plans to focus on high-growth sectors like life sciences and technology, with a current pipeline of 6-8 deal opportunities in the region. The firm will use global capital to fund the expansion, which comes as most of Asia's economies reopen and traditional capital pulls back.

images.alt_text: A logo of Standard Chartered is displayed at its main branch in Hong Kong, China, Aug. 1, 2017. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
One Animation CEO, Sashim Parmanand (left) and creative director Richard Thomas.

site_title: Bangkok’s popular new governor faces plenty of speedbumps ahead
summary: Bangkok's new governor, Chadchart Sittipunt, faces several challenges in fulfilling his campaign promise to make the city more livable for its 10.7 million inhabitants. He must settle the dispute over the BTS Green Line concession, which expires in 2029, and lower fares on the city's mass transit system to make it more popular and reduce traffic. Chadchart's administration will need to reform the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration and address corruption, bureaucratic inertia, and opposition from big business, with potential subsidies of 2-3 billion baht required to lower fares to 35 baht.

images.alt_text: Chadchart Sittipunt has won support across the political spectrum as he focused on policies rather than politics, analysts say.

site_title: Insurance premiums for electric cars can go up to S$5,000 a year
summary: Singapore's insurance market for electric cars (EVs) is struggling to provide affordable coverage due to the lack of claims data and high repair costs. Insurers cite the small EV population, costlier components like batteries, and limited workshops for EV maintenance as challenges. As a result, premiums for EVs are significantly higher than comparable combustion engine models, with some quotes ranging from 8.6% to 59.1% more expensive. Industry players are working to improve coverage, but owners are questioning the need for specialized treatment and increased costs.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Climate focus pushes Singapore insurers to reshape business models
NTUC Income offering usage-based coverage for electric vehicles

site_title: Japan PM Kishida’s support hits highest ever as election nears: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has reached his highest approval rating of 66% since taking office, a five-point increase from the previous April survey. This surge in support comes ahead of critical upper house elections in July, which could give him three years of uninterrupted rule. Kishida's approval ratings have risen following talks with US President Joe Biden, during which they agreed on security cooperation and a substantial increase in Japan's defense budget. Domestic issues, such as the economy and coronavirus, are expected to be more influential in the upcoming elections.

site_title: Australia: Miners, tech lift shares higher; AGL falls on shelving demerger plans
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to a three-week high on Monday, driven by technology stocks and mining companies. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7251.4. Technology stocks gained over 3% and miners rose 1.5% as commodity prices strengthened. AGL Energy fell 4.2% after withdrawing demerger plans due to insufficient shareholder support. The global market followed a Wall Street rally, with Asia-Pacific shares also rising, led by New Zealand's benchmark index, which climbed 0.7%.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday’s open, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% on Monday, tracking gains on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,237.81 points. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also gained. The rally follows US stocks' weekly gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reaching new highs. European shares marked their best week since mid-March, driven by upbeat US data and easing interest rate hike bets.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Bukit Sembawang Estates posted a fall in net profit to S$29.6 million. for the second half of the year.

site_title: Gold prices dip as risk appetite climbs
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,849.37 per ounce, following investors' shift to riskier assets in Asia. A weakened dollar provided some support, as investors wagered on a potential slowdown in US monetary tightening. This comes after sharp hikes in June and July, and as US consumer spending rose more than expected in April, with inflation slowing.

images.alt_text: Gold was little changed on Friday, but the metal was on track for a second weekly gain following a retreat in the US dollar from 20-year highs.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank cuts borrowing from Mizuho, Goldman Sachs
summary: SoftBank Group reduced its borrowing from Mizuho Financial Group by 4.5% to 812 billion yen (S$8.7 billion) in the year ended March. Borrowing from JPMorgan Chase & Co fell 23% to 637 billion yen and from Goldman Sachs Group fell 39% to 364 billion yen. This comes after SoftBank reported a record investment loss due to weakness in tech stock valuations. Founder Masayoshi Son has pledged to "play defence" by cutting investments and preserving cash.

site_title: Yamada Green Resources allowed to resume trading on June 1
summary: Yamada Green Resources has been cleared to resume trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on June 1, 2022, after meeting certain conditions. The conditions include appointing a Singapore-based chief financial officer and performing quarterly reporting with financial statements reviewed by its statutory auditor. The company had its shares suspended in September 2017. Yamada Green Resources will make a request to resume trading after market closes on May 31.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Musk wants market access for Tesla before building local plants
summary: Elon Musk stated that Tesla won't establish auto manufacturing plants in locations where it can't first sell and service its vehicles. The company is seeking tax relief to import cars and test the Indian market before committing to local production. Musk also mentioned that his company, Space Exploration Technologies, is awaiting government approval for its Starlink Internet service in India.

site_title: US Justice Deparment to review Texas school shooting police response
summary: The US Justice Department will conduct an independent review of the police response to the May 2022 mass shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, where 19 children and two teachers were killed. The review aims to identify lessons learned and best practices for responding to active-shooter events. Texas authorities have admitted that 19 police officers were in the school hallway for nearly an hour before breaching the room where the gunman was, mistakenly thinking he had stopped killing. The review will be fair, transparent, and independent, following a request from Uvalde Mayor Don McLaughlin.

site_title: Nato has right to deploy in eastern Europe: deputy chief
summary: NATO's deputy secretary general, Mircea Geoana, stated that the alliance is no longer bound by past commitments to hold back from deploying its forces in eastern Europe due to Russia's actions. Russia's attack on Ukraine and halt of dialogue with NATO have effectively voided the 1997 Founding Act, which aimed to prevent aggressive neighbor behavior. Geoana anticipated a "robust, flexible and sustainable presence" in the region, with no restrictions to deploy forces to ensure NATO's territory is protected under Article 5.

images.alt_text: NATO Deputy Secretary General Mircea Geoana addresses journalists as he arrives for an informal meeting of NATO Foreign Ministers on the conflict in Ukraine on May 15, 2022 in Berlin. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started with healthy gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.14% to 20,933.50. This follows an easing of long-running Covid curbs in Shanghai, boosting confidence. Mainland Chinese stocks also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.37% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.49%. The gains are in line with Asian markets and come after a rally on Wall Street.

site_title: Oil climbs ahead of EU meeting on Russia sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose to two-month highs on Monday, driven by traders' anticipation of the European Union's decision on banning Russian oil. The EU is set to meet on Monday and Tuesday to discuss a sixth package of sanctions, which could lead to a ban on seaborne deliveries of Russian oil. This would tighten the global crude market, already strained by rising demand for gasoline and diesel ahead of peak summer demand. Brent crude futures gained 46 cents, or 0.4%, to $119.89 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures jumped 60 cents, or 0.5%, to $115.67 a barrel.

site_title: StanChart to invest S$1b in Singapore over 5 years, launch virtual bank in H2
summary: Standard Chartered plans to invest S$1 billion in Singapore over 5 years and launch its virtual bank, Trust Bank, in the second-half of 2022. The bank's Asia CEO, Benjamin Hung, sees strength in the global footprint as it aims to facilitate trade flows, particularly with China's opening up. StanChart's Asia generates over two-thirds of its income, with Singapore and Hong Kong contributing the highest income in 2021. The bank's China trade income increased 28% in Q1 2022 and is now more than twice the pre-pandemic level.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

FILE PHOTO: A woman wearing a mask walks past the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, in Beijing, China, as the country is hit by an outbreak of the new coronavirus, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
StanChart veteran named CEO of Singapore digital bank venture with NTUC

site_title: China's first residential Reits to be launched soon
summary: China's first residential Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) backed by rental incomes from affordable housing are set to be launched soon. Stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen have accepted applications for these Reits, which aim to channel fresh capital into the struggling real estate sector and aid the virus-hit economy. The launches will expand the investment scope of China's Reits, which have previously focused on infrastructure projects. The move is expected to help solve the problem of housing affordability and prevent major risks in the real estate market.

images.alt_text: China's property market woes are likely to worsen this year with prices remaining flat and sales and investment falling further, according to a Reuters poll.

site_title: EV startup Electric Last Mile warns it may run out of cash in June
summary: Electric Last Mile Solutions, an EV startup, warned it may run out of cash in June, earlier than projected, due to higher costs in areas like employee retention and supplier payments. The company is seeking additional capital to bolster its finances. This comes after the company faced financial reporting challenges, including a delayed 10-Q filing and the need to redo past financial statements. Electric Last Mile has until May 31 to submit a plan to Nasdaq to regain compliance with its listing rules.

site_title: Monkeypox presents moderate risk to global public health: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has classified monkeypox as a "moderate risk" to global public health due to reported cases in countries not typically affected by the disease. As of May 26, 257 confirmed and 120 suspected cases have been reported from 23 countries, with no reported fatalities. The WHO attributes the sudden appearance of cases in non-endemic countries to undetected transmission and recent amplifying events. The agency expects more cases to be reported as surveillance expands.

site_title: Indonesian q-commerce startup raises US$60m in Series B round from Accel, Tiger Global
summary: Astro, an Indonesian q-commerce startup, raised $60 million in Series B funding led by Accel, Tiger Global, and existing investors. The funds will be used to expand its team size, improve customer service, and reach more customers. Founded in 2021, Astro offers 15-minute grocery delivery services at nearly 50 locations in Jakarta. The startup has received over $90 million in funding, including a previous $27 million Series A round. Astro aims to deliver great customer experience and build a great company with great talents across Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

The fresh funds will be used for the launch of new products and services, technology development, hiring talent and strengthening the company’s financial programmes to create investment awareness in the country.
Oktoriksa Mandasari and Jason Lee, the co-founders of BintangGO.
From left: Herston Powers and Scott Krivokopich, co-founders and managing partners of 1982 Ventures.

site_title: Aviation jobs up for grabs as Singapore races to recruit
summary: Singapore Airlines is ramping up its workforce to cope with a rebound in air travel, hosting a 2-day job fair that attracted over 6,600 applicants. The airline is seeking to fill available positions at its airport, which has been struggling with staff shortages and queues. The move aims to address the industry's labor shortage, which has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, and follows similar efforts by other airports such as Sydney and London's Heathrow.

images.alt_text: Chee Hong Tat, Senior Minister of State for Transport delivering the keynote address on Friday (May 27)

site_title: Volkswagen accused of ‘slavery’ practices under Brazil dictatorship
summary: Volkswagen faces accusations of "slavery" practices in Brazil during the country's military dictatorship (1970s-80s) for allegedly using forced labor and human trafficking to clear land for agricultural projects. The company has been summoned to appear before a labor court in Brasilia on June 14. Former employees and their families have been seeking compensation for years, with allegations of abuse, violence, and suspicious disappearances. The case covers 70,000 hectares of land and involves hundreds of workers.

site_title: Lippo tycoon eyes hospitals, schools for Jokowi’s new capital
summary: Lippo Group's John Riady is exploring opportunities to build hospitals or education centers in Indonesia's new capital city, Nusantara, as part of the country's ambitious project to build a new capital city from scratch. The project, estimated to cost $34 billion, aims to spread wealth more evenly across the nation and is expected to be completed by 2024. Riady, who is also the president director of Lippo Karawaci, sees the project as a chance to replicate the success of his company's previous township development.

images.alt_text: A general view of the city skyline of Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia, August 5, 2021. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana

site_title: Softbank executive pay slashed after historic Vision Fund loss
summary: SoftBank's top executives saw steep cuts in pay following a record US$20.5 billion loss for its Vision Fund unit. The company's founder and CEO Masayoshi Son kept his pay unchanged at 100 million yen, while four of the top six executives saw their compensation drop. Simon Segars, Ronald Fisher, Ken Miyauchi, and Yoshimitsu Goto received pay cuts ranging from 40% to 86% compared to the prior year. The cuts come as the company tries to regain its footing after a series of money-losing investments.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group trimmed borrowing from its main bank Mizuho Financial Group by 4.5 per cent in the year ended March to 812 billion yen (S$8.7 billion).
SoftBank plans to re-elect the remaining 8 members of the board while Chao’s appointment will be subject to approval at the upcoming annual general meeting of shareholders on Jun 24.

INDIAN Prime Minister Narendra Modi and SoftBank Group founder Masayoshi Son met on Monday (May 23) to discuss more investments by the country's biggest tech backer, as a startup boom appears to cool in India amid worries about the global economy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Bukit Sembawang, Cortina, Stamford Land, KSH, Isetan
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 75% fall in net profit to S$29.6 million for the second half of 2022, mainly due to lower profit recognized on development projects. Cortina Holdings posted a 72.3% increase in net profit to S$43.3 million, while Stamford Land's net profit jumped 130.7% to S$15.6 million. KSH Holdings also saw an increase in net profit to S$14.5 million. In contrast, Econ Healthcare lost S$3.4 million due to a stake sale.

site_title: Week-on-week infection ratio for Covid-19 falls below 1 for first time in 3 weeks
summary: Singapore's weekly infection ratio for Covid-19 fell below 1 for the first time in 3 weeks, with 0.98 cases reported on May 29. The total number of locally transmitted cases decreased to 2,448, while hospitalizations increased to 334. Of the hospitalized cases, 39 required oxygen supplementation and 9 were in the intensive care unit. There were zero deaths on Sunday, with 2,185 cases detected via antigen rapid tests and 103 new imported cases. Singapore has recorded 1,295,920 Covid-19 cases and 1,383 deaths.

images.alt_text: Shanghai is offering some tax rebates for companies, and allowed all manufacturers to resume operations from June.
Hong Kong will relax some Covid-19 testing requirements for incoming travellers.

site_title: Pride and anger as Liverpool return to heroes' welcome
summary: Liverpool returned to a hero's welcome after winning the League Cup and FA Cup, despite falling short of a quadruple in the Champions League final. Thousands of fans lined the streets of Liverpool to celebrate, with players and officials displaying the two trophies on an open-top bus parade. Despite chaotic scenes at the Champions League final in Paris, where Liverpool lost to Real Madrid, manager Jurgen Klopp expressed pride in the team, calling them "the best club in the world." Fans praised the team's season, with many hoping star players Sadio Mane and Mohamed Salah will stay at the club.

images.alt_text: Russian clubs and its national side have been barred from all European competitions since Mar 1. Russia have also been banned from the 2022 World Cup by FIFA.

There were 8 Premier League clubs on last year's list, with Aston Villa and West Ham United making their debut in 2022 and joining Manchester United, Liverpool, Manchester City, Chelsea, Tottenham Hotspur, Arsenal, Leicester City and Everton.

site_title: Diageo to sell 32 Indian brands to Inbrew for 8.2b rupees
summary: Diageo to sell 32 Indian liquor brands to Inbrew Beverages for 8.2 billion rupees (S$144 million). The sale aims to achieve sustainable long-term profitable growth by pruning low-margin products. The deal includes 32 brands, including Haywards and Romanov, and a 5-year franchise arrangement for 11 other United Spirits brands. Inbrew will acquire the brands to expand its presence in India and leverage distribution synergies, focused ownership, and growth capital. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of September 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Campari bottles are seen in a bar downtown Milan, Italy, September 4, 2018. Picture taken September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Stefano Rellandini/File Photo

site_title: Relativity's 3D printed rocket on path for summer debut flight
summary: Relativity Space, a Los Angeles-area startup, is set to debut its 3D printed rocket, Terran 1, this summer. Pre-launch testing has concluded, and the rocket will be transported to Cape Canaveral, Florida. The Terran 1 can carry payloads up to 1,000 kilogrammes into orbit, with demonstration flights contracted with NASA and the Department of Defense. The company's flagship Terran R rocket, under development, is expected to be more attractive for heavy cargo like commercial satellites. Relativity has raised $1.3 billion from investors and aims to use its 3D-printing technology to establish an industrial base on Mars.

images.alt_text: Terran 1 Stage 1 with all 9 Aeon rocket engines.

site_title: Are Reits really real estate?
summary: Singapore's Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) have grown significantly since their debut in 2002, with 36 S-Reits and a market capitalization of S$113.55 billion. However, their performance relative to physical property and investment considerations differ. The dual market structure for Reits, where physical asset values are determined by the private market and Reit unit pricing by the stock market, can lead to price deviations. These deviations are influenced by factors such as property information accessibility, asset enhancement initiatives, and market sentiment. Despite these differences, Reits remain an attractive vehicle for broad investor exposure to the physical real estate market.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) will merge to create one of Asia’s 10 largest Reits.
StarHub's lease renewal will boost the occupancy rate at Plaza Singapura and add to CICT's income
DBS maintained “buy” on all 3 counters, but said it prefers Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) to Prime US Reit and Manulife US Reit.

site_title: Potential recovery for Hang Seng Index
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) continued its downtrend in May 2022, but may see a potential recovery due to China's planned economic stimulus measures and reopening of affected cities. The index has stayed above the 20,000 psychological support level, and a short-term rebound is possible if it breaks above the 20,800 to 21,000 level. However, a bearish scenario is unlikely if the government measures instill confidence in China's economic growth, and a correction could result in a longer downward pressure into the third quarter.

site_title: Crypto giant FTX ready with billions of dollars for acquisitions
summary: FTX, a crypto giant, is preparing to spend billions of dollars to acquire stakes in other companies, according to CEO Sam Bankman-Fried. The firm has raised over $2 billion in recent fundraising rounds, which could be used for acquisitions. FTX has already made significant investments, including buying LedgerX and IEX Group, and has expressed interest in acquiring companies with substantial user bases or expertise in areas it is not well-versed in. The company aims to expand its product offerings and is engaging with Washington regulators as it pursues its growth strategy.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin is created by a process called “proof of work” that requires computers to “mine” the currency by solving complex puzzles. Powering these computers needs large amounts of electricity.

It is well-known that cryptocurrency billionaire and FTX Chief Executive Officer Sam Bankman-Fried wants to give away his entire fortune. Next on his agenda is fixing social media's "broken model" through blockchain technology.

site_title: OCBC appoints Lee Hwee Boon as head of group HR
summary: OCBC Bank appoints Lee Hwee Boon as head of group human resources, effective June 24, 2022. Lee, 51, currently head of enterprise banking and middle market services, succeeds retiring Jason Ho. Helen Wong, group CEO, praised Lee as the "strongest candidate" after evaluating internal and external candidates. The appointment aims to accelerate talent acquisition, retention, and development, as well as prepare the workforce for the future.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
OCBC releases financial results .

site_title: BT Money Hacks: DeFi - next-level investing not for the faint-hearted (Ep 119)
summary: Decentralized finance (DeFi) investing offers high returns of up to 20-30%, but requires effort to understand and navigate its nascent stage. In a recent podcast, correspondent Howie Lim spoke to Kenneth Lou, co-founder and CEO of Seedly, to discuss DeFi's basics, strategies for success, and the volatile nature of decentralized applications. While DeFi can be lucrative, investors should exercise caution and consult financial experts before making decisions. With DeFi's current underpricing, investors may be able to capitalize on its growth potential.

site_title: Goldman says bull market in battery metals is finished for now
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a short-term decline in prices of key battery metals cobalt, lithium, and nickel over the next two years due to investor overexuberance. Despite long-term prospects remaining strong, the bank attributes the oversupply to rapid adoption of electric vehicles. Lithium prices are expected to average under $54,000/ton this year and fall to $16,000/ton in 2023, while cobalt prices are forecast to drop to $59,500/ton next year. The analysts believe a "sharp correction" is necessary to correct the fundamental mispricing, with prices potentially soaring again after 2024.

images.alt_text: Stellantis chief executive officer Carlos Tavares is racing to transform the sprawling manufacturer after it was formed in the mega-merger between Fiat Chrysler and PSA Group last year.

site_title: Zero-Covid, big money: China’s anti-virus spending boosts medical, tech, construction
summary: China's "zero-Covid" policy has boosted growth in the medical, technology, and construction sectors, despite battering the economy. The government is spending over $71 billion this year on testing, medical facilities, and monitoring equipment, benefiting companies like Dian Diagnostics, Adicon, and Shanghai Runda. These companies' revenues have more than doubled, with some generating millions of dollars in revenue per month. China aims to have Covid-19 testing facilities within 15 minutes of everyone in big cities and continues to impose mass testing. The policy is defended as crucial to saving lives, but its economic toll is mounting, with many private-sector economists expecting the economy to shrink in the next quarter.

images.alt_text: A healthcare worker takes a swab sample at a Covid-19 testing center in Shanghai, China, on Friday, May 27, 2022. Shanghai will reopen some schools after a three-month shutdown as coronavirus infections there ebb, while attention is shifting to the simmering outbreak in Beijing that’s underscoring the relentless strain of China’s adherence to it’s zero-tolerance Covid strategy. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong eases some testing requirements for inbound travel
summary: Hong Kong has relaxed some Covid-19 testing requirements for incoming air passengers. Starting June 1, travellers will no longer need documentary proof of lab accreditation and transit passengers will not require a pre-flight PCR test. However, a PCR test within 48 hours of departure is still required. Airlines that trigger the flight-suspension mechanism for Covid-positive travellers will receive a warning and a HK$20,000 penalty for repeated breaches.

site_title: Zelensky visits Ukraine’s east for first time since invasion
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky visited the war-ridden east of Ukraine for the first time since the Russian invasion, focusing on the Kharkiv region. Zelensky fired the local head of the SBU security service for not defending the city, and condemned the occupiers' efforts to squeeze out results. He called on local officials to find projects to rebuild destroyed areas, stating that this is a chance for districts to have a new face. The region has seen 2,229 buildings destroyed, and Zelensky vowed to restore and rebuild the area.

site_title: Binance registers with Italy's regulator amid plans to expand in Europe
summary: Binance, a major cryptocurrency exchange, has registered its legal entity in Italy with the country's regulator, the Organismo degli Agenti e dei Mediatori (OAM). This move aims to expand the company's presence in Europe and increase accountability, potentially reducing the risk of money laundering. Binance can now open offices in Italy and expand its local team, solidifying its position in the European crypto market.

images.alt_text: Binance app is seen on a smartphone in this illustration taken, July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic

site_title: Nutryfarm clarifies that it is considering legal action against ex-CEO over settlement agreements
summary: NutryFarm International has clarified that it holds its former CEO, Cheng Meng, personally responsible for two settlement agreements totaling 33.4 million yuan (S$6.8 million) related to a durian delivery shortfall. The company claims the agreements were entered into without its knowledge, and Cheng Meng is responsible for economic and financial losses. NutryFarm is considering reports to relevant authorities and taking legal action against Cheng Meng. The company's shares have been voluntarily suspended since April.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Japan governor wins re-election, NHK says, in race seen key to nuclear restart
summary: Japan's governor, Hideyo Hanazumi, won re-election in the Niigata prefecture, a key vote on nuclear power. The result, seen as a gauge of voter readiness for nuclear power, was closely watched by LDP heavyweights in Tokyo. Hanazumi, backed by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's ruling party, defeated Naomi Katagiri, an anti-nuclear activist, by a large margin. The win is seen as a boost to the ruling party's efforts to revive Japan's idled nuclear energy plants.

images.alt_text: Japan’s government aims to lift a requirement for entrepreneurs to pledge personal assets as security when raising initial funding for startups.

site_title: Compulsory acquisition loophole back in spotlight as TTJ minorities get lowball offer
summary: Singapore's market regulators have failed to challenge a market practice that allows controlling shareholders to exploit a loophole in the Companies Act, enabling them to acquire minority shareholders' shares at a low price. TTJ Holdings, a structural steel specialist, is facing a compulsory acquisition offer at S$0.23 per share, a 36.1% discount to its market price. The offeror, TTJ's executive chairman Teo Hock Chwee, is using a special purpose vehicle to reach the 90% threshold, allowing him to acquire the remaining shares at a significantly lower price. The CAWG has recommended changes to the Companies Act to close the loophole, but regulators have yet to take action.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Time to close compulsory acquisition loophole that helps lowball privatisation offers succeed
piximage
The Securities Industry Council (SIC) needs to move urgently to close a gaping loophole that exists in our corporate takeover rules.
The executive chairman of mainboard-listed T T J Holdings is looking to take the structural steel specialist private at an offer price of S$0.23 per share.

site_title: From pipes to medtech, Vicplas International eyes expansion in China and Americas
summary: Vicplas International, a medical technology company, plans to open its third manufacturing outlet in Changzhou, China, despite pandemic restrictions. The new 7,000 sqm plant will increase production capacity by 60% and is expected to start production in June. The company aims to grow its revenue streams by diving deeper into the extrusion space, making medical tubings for various medical areas. Vicplas has seen steady growth in its medical devices segment, with a compound annual growth rate of 15.7% over the past 5 financial years. The company is also exploring opportunities to build a manufacturing plant near the US.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Topline: Walter Tarca, Deputy Group CEO of Mainboard-listed VicPlas International.

site_title: Singapore banks, tech, Reits favoured by analysts amid growth, inflation concerns
summary: Analysts predict that Singapore's banks, Reits, and tech-linked stocks will benefit from inflation and growth concerns in the second half of 2022. With interest rates expected to rise, banks are seen as well-positioned beneficiaries, while Reits may outperform in a recession. Technology-linked stocks, such as Venture Corp, offer opportunities for long-term growth. Despite global economic uncertainty, Singapore is considered a safe haven, and local equity markets have outperformed the MSCI All Country World Index this year. DBS, UOB, and Keppel Corp are among top picks for analysts.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
While small-cap stocks are set to have a good run, the Straits Times Index's returns could be stuck in the mid-to-low single digits, said RHB analyst Shekhar Jaiswal.
Hawkers are already feeling the pinch of rising cooking oil prices. The price of oils and fats was up by 9.9 per cent in April, while hawker fare was up by 4.2 per cent.

site_title: It’s not enough to just be sustainable, we need to be regenerative as well
summary: Companies are shifting from solely focusing on sustainability to regeneration, which involves actively replenishing the planet rather than just reducing its impact. Regeneration requires new products, supply chains, and business models that promote environmental recovery. Forward-thinking companies, such as Avery Dennison, are embracing this approach, which goes beyond the traditional goal of sustainability. This move aims to create a more sustainable environment for future generations.

images.alt_text: Every business is deeply intertwined with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns and can contribute to business performance in the ways of investment and asset optimisation
renewable, energy, environment

site_title: Vietnam housing market to get busier on foreign demand rebound, urbanisation
summary: Vietnam's housing market is expected to see increased activity as foreign demand rebounds and urbanization continues to drive growth. Foreign buyers made up 20% of buyers at a luxury residential project in Ho Chi Minh City, and demand outweighs supply in every market segment, with high capital appreciation. The country's infrastructure spend is also high, reshaping urban areas and land values. With the country's economic growth and middle-class expansion, Vietnam is likely to attract more expatriate workers and foreign investors, boosting demand for housing.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

At Frasers Property's Q2 Thao Dien project in Ho Chi Minh City, foreigners made up about 30 per cent of the primary buyers, with Singapore, China and South Korea as the top 3 overseas nationalities. The selling prices averaged S$5,172 per square metre as at end-September 2021.
Singapore property firms deepening presence in Vietnam
Golden hotels and luxe apartments: The rise of Vietnam's ultra-rich
Infrastructure projects, regulatory changes seen driving strong recovery in Vietnam construction
CapitaLand sells entire Ho Chi Minh City luxury residential development Define

site_title: Pound fights for reprieve as economy flails
summary: The pound has gained for two weeks, ending a month of losses, primarily due to decreasing demand for the US dollar. Despite this, the UK's economy is facing significant challenges, including a sharp slowdown, a cost-of-living crisis, and a collapse in consumer sentiment. The Bank of England is expected to continue hiking interest rates, but its ability to do so is becoming increasingly uncertain. The pound's future is uncertain, with some strategists predicting it could fall to $1.20 and others warning of a recession or weak growth ahead.

images.alt_text: Rampant inflation and the BOE’s string of interest-rate increases to the highest since 2009 are fuelling the surge in corporate bond yields, but so is the prospect of slower economic growth and concern over corporate earnings.

site_title: Big oil TotalEnergies charging into electric vehicles
summary: TotalEnergies, a French energy giant, has signed a deal to manage and operate a Singapore electric vehicle charging network with over 1,500 charge points. This move aims to expand the company's 'green involvement' in Singapore and the region. Under the leadership of Liang Ting Wee, the country chair of TotalEnergies Singapore, the company has also been working on low-emission fuels for ships at the Singapore port and climate-friendly efforts across its operations in over 40 countries.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: S Korea parliament approves  62t won extra budget days before local elections
summary: South Korea's National Assembly approved a 62 trillion won (S$68 billion) supplementary budget, exceeding the initial 59.4 trillion won announced last month. The budget will primarily fund cash handouts to small businesses and self-employed individuals affected by Covid-19 restrictions. The finance ministry plans to use tax revenue from existing spending plans, avoiding bond issuance. The move comes ahead of local elections on June 1, where South Koreans will vote for mayors and provincial governors.

site_title: Premiums for EVs still relatively high as insurers struggle to price risk
summary: Singapore's electric vehicle market faces challenges, with insurance premiums higher than comparable combustion engine models and limited online quotes available. Insurers struggle to price risk due to the small EV population and lack of claims data. However, experts believe that as more people turn to EVs, these challenges will decrease, and premiums will eventually equal those of internal combustion engine cars. The Singapore government's goal to phase out conventional vehicles by 2040 is expected to drive growth, with some insurers already launching EV insurance products and others planning to enter the market.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Climate focus pushes Singapore insurers to reshape business models
NTUC Income offering usage-based coverage for electric vehicles

site_title: OCBC’S first ride out in two years with Care Corner seniors
summary: OCBC Bank organized a ride-out event for 20 seniors from Care Corner Singapore on May 24, marking the first group outing for the seniors since the pandemic. The initiative is an extension of OCBC's annual mass-cycling event, which started in 2015. The event aims to provide seniors with opportunities for socialization and exercise, while also promoting active ageing. The partnership with Care Corner aims to address the need for organized outings, which can help seniors stay engaged and active.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: 'Triangle of Sadness' wins Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or
summary: Swedish director Ruben Ostlund won the Palme d'Or for his film "Triangle of Sadness" at the Cannes Film Festival on May 28. The film's Best Picture award marked Ostlund's second Palme d'Or win. Ostlund stated his goal was to create an exciting film that would encourage discussion and thought-provoking content. South Korean actor Song Kang-Ho won the Best Actor Prize for his role in "Broker".

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Swedish film director Ruben Ostlund poses during a photocall after he won the Palme d'Or for the film "Triangle of Sadness" during the closing ceremony of the 75th edition of the Cannes Film Festival in Cannes, southern France, on May 28, 2022. (Photo by PATRICIA DE MELO MOREIRA / AFP)

TOPSHOT - South Korean actor Song Kang-Ho poses with his trophy during a photocall after he won the Best Actor Prize for his part in "Broker (Les Bonnes Etoiles)" during the 75th edition of the Cannes Film Festival in Cannes, southern France, on May 28, 2022. (Photo by LOIC VENANCE / AFP)

(FromL) Cannes Film Festival director Thierry Fremaux, French director and member of the Jury of the Official Selection Ladj Ly, French actor and President of the Jury of the 75th Cannes Film Festival Vincent Lindon and US film director Jeff Nichols wave from a balcony of the Grand Hyatt Cannes Hotel Martinez on the eve of the opening ceremony of the 75th edition of the Cannes Film Festival in Cannes, southern France, on May 16, 2022.

site_title: Jury deliberations in Depp, Heard case to resume on Tuesday
summary: A 7-person jury in the defamation trial of Johnny Depp and Amber Heard will resume deliberations on Tuesday after a 2-hour break on Friday. The jury had not delivered a verdict after more than 2 hours of deliberation on Friday, and the trial is expected to conclude next week. Depp sued Heard for $50 million, claiming she defamed him in an opinion piece, while Heard countersued for $100 million, alleging Depp smeared her. The jury will now continue discussing the case after the US Memorial Day holiday.

images.alt_text: British model Kate Moss is expected to testify in the high-profile defamation case between Johnny Depp and his ex-wife Amber Heard.
Amber Heard gestures during a defamation case against her by ex-husband, actor Johnny Depp, at Fairfax County Circuit Courthouse in Fairfax, Virginia on May 17, 2022.

JOHNNY Depp was to have been paid US$22.5 million for a sixth Pirates of the Caribbean movie but the project was scrapped by Disney after his ex-wife Amber Heard accused him of domestic abuse in a Washington Post op-ed, the actor’s agent said Monday (May 2).
Johnny Depp calls Amber Heard accusations 'heinous', says he never struck ex-wife
Johnny Depp lawyers seek to discredit ex-wife domestic violence claims

site_title: Shanghai unveils fresh policies to support economy hit by Covid
summary: Shanghai has unveiled policies to support its economy, which was hit by COVID-19 lockdowns. The city will offer tax rebates, allow all manufacturers to resume operations from June, and increase car ownership quotas. Residential developments will also be accelerated, with subsidies for electric cars. The measures aim to stabilize the city's economy after a 2-month lockdown and are part of 50 measures to address the economic impact of COVID-19.

images.alt_text: Worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) prepare the opening of a supermarket during a lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Shanghai, the epicenter of China’s worst outbreak since the early days of the pandemic, starts to emerge from a grueling lockdown. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: UK companies to trial four-day work week
summary: The UK is launching a six-month trial of a four-day work week, with 3,000 employees from 60 companies participating. The trial aims to improve productivity, employee well-being, and reduce carbon footprint without cutting salaries or sacrificing revenues. Companies such as Pressure Drop Brewery and the Royal Society of Biology are participating, with some hoping to retain employees amid severe staff shortages. The trial follows similar experiments in Spain, Iceland, the US, Canada, and Australia, and experts suggest that a shorter working week could lead to higher productivity, as seen in countries like Denmark and Sweden.

images.alt_text: A worker pours a pint of beer at Pressure Drop Brewery, in north London, on May 21, 2022. - Members of staff at the Pressure Drop brewery are taking part in a six-month trial of a four-day working week, with 3,000 others from 60 UK companies. The pilot -- touted as the world's biggest so far -- aims to help companies shorten their working hours without cutting salaries or sacrificing revenues. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Incoming Philippine central bank governor signals June rate rise
summary: Incoming Philippine central bank governor Felipe Medalla signals a possible interest-rate increase in June, with a likely 25 basis points hike. Medalla, set to take office on July 1, agrees with outgoing governor Benjamin Diokno on a rate hike, following a similar statement from Diokno earlier this month. The move aims to combat inflation and stabilize the country's economy.

site_title: Uefa prevents Ukrainian, Belarusian teams from facing each other
summary: UEFA has barred Ukrainian and Belarusian teams from being drawn against each other in European competitions "until further notice" due to Belarus' support for the Russian invasion of Ukraine. This decision aims to ensure the "safety and security of the teams." Meanwhile, Russian clubs and the national side have been barred from European competitions since March 1, and Russia has been banned from the 2022 World Cup by FIFA.

site_title: Jordan's plastic trash turned into art with a message
summary: Jordan-based artist Maria Nissan is using plastic waste to raise awareness about single-use plastics and their environmental impact. She collects and repurposes trash to create art, including a giant mural in Amman made from over 2,000 plastic bottles and 1,000 shopping bags. Nissan advocates for a tax on single-use plastics, reusable bags, and changing public habits to reduce plastic pollution, citing that the consequences of single-use plastic pollution are often delayed and difficult to hold individuals accountable.

images.alt_text: Ivorian artist Mounou Desire Koffi making an artwork with used telephone keyboards at his residence in Bingerville.

site_title: ESG haters think climate investors are controlling everything. If only
summary: Climate investors are often misunderstood as controlling the energy market, but evidence suggests this is not the case. Despite the US Republican party's claims, climate-minded investors are not diverting capital away from fossil fuels, and energy companies are instead choosing not to invest in new projects due to declining demand. In fact, investors are doubling down on their climate commitments, with many countries and companies setting ambitious targets for renewable energy. The current energy crisis has accelerated the shift towards clean energy, but investment moves at a slower pace than energy markets, highlighting the need for governments and the financial sector to take action to accelerate the transition.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on October 4, 2021 shows the solar farm of Marcoussis, south of Paris, inaugurated by French energy group Engie and the Sigeif (Syndicat Intercommunal pour le gaz et l'electricite en Ile-de-France). - With two photovoltaic farms and a third planned in their town, residents of Bessens (Tarn-et-Garonne), south-western France, are mobilizing to avoid becoming "the capital of the solar panel", believing that they have already contributed enough to the ecological transition. (Photo by Eric PIERMONT / AFP)

site_title: How the market is severely punishing growth traps
summary: The US stock market has severely punished companies that failed to meet growth expectations, labeling them as "growth traps." Despite relatively minor issues, companies such as Nvidia, Walmart, and Target saw their shares plummet after disappointing revenue forecasts. The market's harsh reaction highlights the high expectations for growth companies and the lack of tolerance for weakness. This phenomenon may be the final stage of erasing pandemic-driven distortions, with growth stocks experiencing a sharp decline in gains over the past few months.

images.alt_text: Snap Inc’s shares plunged nearly 40 per cent on Tuesday after a profit warning from the Snapchat parent signalled tough times ahead for the once-booming digital ad industry, sparking a sector-wide selloff.
Nvidia slid in late trading after China’s Covid-19 lockdowns and the war in Ukraine weighed on its sales forecast.

site_title: UK’s credit market tells a grim story of a looming cash crunch
summary: The UK's credit market is experiencing a cash crunch, with corporate bond yields surging and borrowers struggling to access funding. The Bank of England's interest-rate hikes and inflation concerns are driving up borrowing costs, making it difficult for companies to service debts or raise capital. The market capitalization of sterling securities has shrunk £38 billion, and new sterling corporate bond issuance has virtually ground to a halt. Economists expect slower economic growth, and the government's recent measures may prompt further interest-rate hikes, exacerbating the crisis.

images.alt_text: The pound has gained for two weeks to end a month of losses, mostly thanks to ebbing demand for the US dollar as a haven rather than positive local factors.

site_title: Reflections on BT’s path to a digital newsroom
summary: The Business Times (BT) has shifted its focus towards a digital newsroom, a change that has required both workflow and technology adjustments. Initially, the online version was a digital replica of print content, but in 2000, it was published earlier and breaking news was filed throughout the day. However, it wasn't until 18 months ago that BT began to decisively steer towards digital readiness, introducing new tools and workflows to monitor audience engagement and file most stories digitally first. The publication recently adopted a unified content management system, allowing journalists to work on a single version of their content that can be repurposed for print with minimal manual intervention. This shift marks a reversal of BT's print-to-digital flow, with a greater emphasis on digital marketing, social media, and online presentation.

images.alt_text: Chen Huifen
BT On-line : SPH assistant general manager Cheah Cheng Poh at the briefing on 15 June 1995

site_title: Why Britain is spending £37b to make energy-supply crisis worse
summary: The UK government has announced £37 billion in funding to subsidize energy consumption, mostly fossil fuels, amid a cost-of-living crisis. This move contradicts the country's promise to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. Critics argue that the funding does not address the root cause of the crisis and fails to promote energy efficiency measures, such as home insulation. The government's policy failures have led to a reliance on short-term fixes, exacerbating the energy-supply crisis.

images.alt_text: The British government will impose a so-called windfall tax on the profits of oil and gas companies such as BP to help fund at least £5 billion (S$8.7 billion) of support for Britons facing a cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: A global stock trader’s guide to navigating food protectionism
summary: A global wave of food protectionism is affecting companies worldwide, with export curbs imposed by Asian countries causing ripple effects. Local producers such as India's Shree Renuka Sugars are likely to be adversely affected, while global players like China's Cofco Sugar Holding Co and Brazil's JBS SA are expected to benefit. Rising costs of grains, palm oil, and chicken are forcing investors to rethink their positions, with profit estimates of global exporters like Singapore-listed Wilmar International and Hong Kong's WH Group on the rise.

images.alt_text: A poultry stall at a market in Kuala Lumpur. Malaysia will begin a suspension on chicken exports from June 1, a move that affects scores of countries including neighbouring Singapore.
Singapore imports over 90 per cent of its food, and diversification is a key strategy to ensure a supply of safe food.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks end with weekly gains for first time in 2 months
summary: US stocks ended the week with gains for the first time in about two months, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 6.2% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also gaining. The gains followed signs of moderating inflation and were driven by a rally that began on Wednesday. The Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy tightening has led to a decline in stocks, but Friday's data suggests inflation may be plateauing, supporting the market's sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 97.90 points or 0.30 per cent at the open to 32,735.09.

site_title: Sri Lanka looks to rely more on India until IMF funding agreed
summary: Sri Lanka is seeking more financial assistance from India until it secures an International Monetary Fund (IMF) program, which is expected to unlock aid from other lenders. The country needs about $4 billion this year, with $1 billion coming from a potential swap facility with the Reserve Bank of India.
