Meanwhile, talks with the IMF are being fast-tracked, and discussions with India are ongoing for increased credit and balance-of-payment support to address foreign-exchange shortages. The next three months will be a critical period for Sri Lanka's economy.

images.alt_text: THE International Monetary Fund (IMF) said it made "good progress" in analyzing Sri Lanka's economic situation and identifying policy priorities, while cautioning that a loan would require adequate assurances that debt sustainability will be restored.

site_title: US retailers' ballooning inventories set stage for deep discounts
summary: US retailers are facing a surplus of merchandise due to soaring inflation and higher gas prices, prompting some to discount unsold goods. Major retailers like Costco, Gap Inc, and Macy's reported ballooning inventories, with some seeing a 26% increase in Costco's fiscal third quarter. To clear out excess inventory, retailers are offering deeper promotions and discounts, which could erode margins. Despite this, some retailers are still battling high costs of sourcing goods and labor, limiting the breadth and depth of promotions.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, increased 0.9 per cent last month.

site_title: Japan to lower hurdle for initial funding for startups: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government plans to lower the hurdle for initial funding for startups by dropping the requirement for entrepreneurs to pledge personal assets as security. The proposal, part of Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's new form of capitalism, also aims to require companies to disclose gender pay gaps and invest 150 trillion yen in decarbonization efforts over the next decade. Additionally, the plan encourages people to channel their savings into investments, doubling household asset income. The proposal will be submitted to a government panel on May 31 and is expected to be approved in early June.

site_title: Apple Atlanta workers drop bid for union vote next week, claiming intimidation
summary: Apple's labor group, the Communications Workers of America (CWA), has withdrawn its request for a union vote at an Atlanta store, citing alleged intimidation and union-busting tactics by the company. The CWA claims that Apple's actions, including forced captive audience meetings, have made a free and fair election impossible. This setback comes as several US unions are trying to organize Apple's retail stores, with workers in New York, Maryland, and Kentucky also announcing campaigns.

images.alt_text: The starting pay for Apple's hourly workers in the US will rise to US$22, or higher based upon the market, a 45 per cent increase from 2018 levels, WSJ said, citing an internal email.

An Amazon manager in March told workers that if they voted to organise, unions could bargain for a contract clause that “would require Amazon to fire you if you don’t want to join the union and pay union dues."

site_title: Oil settles up ahead of US driving season, EU embargo decision
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, closing the week with gains ahead of the US Memorial Day holiday weekend and European negotiations over a potential Russian crude oil ban. Brent crude rose 1.7% to $119.43, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.9% to $115.07. Strong worldwide demand for fuel, particularly gasoline and heating oil, supported the price increases, outpacing crude prices this year. The gains come as the US starts peak driving season and European nations consider imposing an embargo on Russian crude oil.

images.alt_text: US motorists face soaring costs as the nation heads into its peak holiday driving period with gasoline stockpiles at the lowest seasonal level since 2014.

site_title: Signs of an inflection point for S-Reits with Europe, US office assets
summary: Signs of an inflection point for S-Reits with office assets in Europe and the US are emerging. European office occupier activity remains robust, while US leasing activity rose 5.4% in Q1 2022, driven by pent-up demand. S-Reits such as Cromwell European Reit, IReit Global, and Elite Commercial Reit reported positive rent reversion and occupancy rates, with Cromwell's office portfolio registering a 1.6% positive rent reversion. The recovery is tempered by the Ukraine-Russia war, but S-Reits are focusing on asset management and sustainability initiatives to maintain occupancy and long-term attractiveness.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.

site_title: Hong Kong's next leader visits Beijing for official nod
summary: Hong Kong's next leader, John Lee, has begun his 4-day trip to Beijing to receive official approval and meet with top Chinese leaders. Lee, 64, was chosen as chief executive by a Beijing loyalist committee in May, following China's 2021 electoral system reforms. The move is seen as a tightening of Beijing's grip on Hong Kong. Lee's appointment is expected to be finalized during his visit, marking the beginning of his one-year term as Hong Kong's leader.

images.alt_text: John Lee, Hong Kong's chief executive-elect, speaks at the Legislative Council in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, May 9, 2022. Lee vowed to further efforts to bolster national security and accelerate integration with mainland China, as he prepared to take power after a near-unanimous election by Beijing-controlled committee. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg

Soaring property prices during more than a decade of ultra-low interest rates have become a major political risk for governments all around the world. The problem in Hong Kong is particularly acute as not only are homes expensive, they are mostly small.

site_title: Trump loses bid to thwart New York AG's probe of his businesses
summary: US District Judge Brenda Sannes dismissed a lawsuit filed by Donald Trump, allowing a 3-year investigation into his business practices by New York state Attorney General Letitia James to move forward. Trump had sought to halt the investigation, claiming James was using the case to further her political career. The judge stated there was "no evidence" that James' investigation was undertaken in bad faith, and James vowed to continue the investigation undeterred.

images.alt_text: FILE — Former President Donald Trump during a rally in Selma, N.C., April 9, 2022. In the latest legal blow to Trump, a federal judge on Friday, May 27, dismissed a lawsuit the former president filed that sought to halt the New York attorney general’s civil investigation into his business practices. (Veasey Conway/The New York Times)

site_title: European gas prices fluctuate as Russian supply fears Wane
summary: European natural gas prices fluctuated on Friday, influenced by reduced Norwegian shipments and easing concerns over Russian supply disruptions. Despite initial gains, prices closed the day higher due to Norwegian production cuts. Russian shipments remained stable, with major European buyers finding ways to meet Moscow's demands for rubles. European gas imports surged to five-year highs, with at least 10 US LNG cargoes expected to arrive in June. Prices rose for UK gas for June delivery, while LNG imports are expected to remain a key factor in stabilizing European gas markets.

images.alt_text: Energy security has become a top priority for importers as forecasts of tighter gas supplies and volatile prices in the next few years are keeping buyers on edge and impeding the push towards decarbonisation, energy executives said.

site_title: US dollar slides for second week as traders adjust Fed rate hike views
summary: The US dollar declined for the second consecutive week, falling 1.24% to 101.66 against a basket of 6 major currencies, as traders reduced expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate hikes and easing recession fears. The dollar's decline was driven by improved inflation and consumer spending data, and as investors priced in rate hikes from the European Central Bank. The greenback hit a nearly two-decade peak earlier this month but has since declined.

images.alt_text: THE US dollar edged back towards a 1-month low on Thursday (May 26), as minutes from the Federal Reserve’s May meeting contained few surprises.

site_title: US SEC looking into Musk's Twitter stake purchase
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Tesla CEO Elon Musk's disclosure of his 9.2% stake in Twitter, citing concerns over a late filing and improper paperwork. The SEC asked Musk to explain why he used a form meant for passive investors instead of an activist investor form, which he later amended. Despite potential fines, experts believe the investigation is unlikely to jeopardize Musk's $44 billion Twitter deal, as the financial consequences are limited and the SEC has previously opted to urge compliance rather than take Musk to court.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk faces a lawsuit accusing him of pushing down Twitter's stock price in order to either give himself an escape hatch from his US$44 billion buyout bid, or room to negotiate a discount.
The new structure could reduce the risk of the deal for both Musk and his lenders, particularly given the recent slide in Tesla’s stock price.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk said on Thursday that "Tesla is on my mind 24/7," trying to soothe investor worries about him being distracted by a Twitter deal that has depressed stocks at the electric car company.
Elon Musk spent Wednesday on Twitter, announcing his political switch from Democrat to Republican, trashing ESG and replying to several users of the social-media website he's agreed to buy.
The world's most famous electric-vehicle maker has lost its spot on the ESG version of the S&P 500 Index.
Elon Musk may be directing his buyer's remorse at Twitter's bot problem. But underpinning the deal is a US$13 billion debt bill that's looking like a bigger burden by the day.
Twitter's directors voted earlier to unanimously recommend that shareholders approve Musk’s US$54.20-a-share offer.

Elon Musk declared he won’t proceed with his US44 billion takeover of Twitter unless the social media giant can prove bots make up fewer than 5 per cent of its users, casting yet more uncertainty over the deal.
Elon Musk stoked speculation that he could seek to renegotiate his takeover of Twitter, saying a viable deal at a lower price wouldn't be "out of the question".

site_title: S&P cuts Ukraine debt rating amid Russia conflict, outlook negative
summary: S&P Global Ratings cut Ukraine's debt rating to CCC+/C from B-/B, citing ongoing macroeconomic instability due to the Russian invasion. The outlook is negative, with a forecasted 40% contraction in Ukraine's economy this year. The downgrade is the second since the invasion began in late February, following a similar cut by Moody's. The Ukrainian government relies on donor support to meet foreign-currency debt payments, with President Zelensky stating the country needs $7 billion a month to keep its economy afloat.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said his government needs US$7 billion a month to keep its economy afloat.

site_title: Centurion’s David Loh raises stake; Keppel leads buyback tally
summary: Institutions sold Singapore stocks over May 20-26, with a net outflow of S$109 million. The Straits Times Index gained 0.6%, while the FTSE China A50 Index declined 1.1%. DBS Group Holdings, OCBC, and other companies led the net institutional outflows. Meanwhile, Centurion's David Loh raised his stake, and Keppel led the buyback tally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the SGX signage outside their office in Singapore March 2, 2017. Picture taken March 2, 2017. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Singapore has been working to secure food supply: PM Lee
summary: Singapore has been working to secure its food supply for several years, building a buffer of food stocks and diversifying its sources of imports to minimize disruptions. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong noted the global food supply crunch caused by the war in Ukraine and high inflation, but said Singapore is prepared to withstand shocks. The country imports over 90% of its food and has a stockpile of frozen chicken that can last several months. Lee emphasized the importance of diversifying sources and being prepared for disruptions, saying "if you can't buy chicken from one place, you can buy from other countries."

images.alt_text: Customers queue to buy fresh chickens from Malaysia at NTUC FairPrice Vivocity on May 24, 2022. Malaysia said it will halt the export of 3.6 million chickens a month from June to address surging prices and the shortage of chickens in the country.
A poultry stall at a market in Kuala Lumpur. Malaysia will begin a suspension on chicken exports from June 1, a move that affects scores of countries including neighbouring Singapore.
A poultry seller at Tekka Market at 11.45am on May 21, 2020.
India will restrict sugar exports as a precautionary measure to safeguard its own food supplies, another act of protectionism after banning wheat sales just over a week ago.
"So far, we have no worries because we definitely have no shortages at all," Plantation Industries and Commodities Minister Zuraida Kamaruddin said in an interview on Tuesday (May 24).
Chicken rice is found at almost every dining spot in Singapore, from hawker centres to high-end restaurants, and consists of poached chicken, rice and a garlic chili dip.

Malaysia will halt exports of 3.6 million chickens a month from Jun 1 and scrap the approved permit requirement for importing wheat until production and prices stabilize, Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob said.

site_title: Shanghai takes further steps towards reopening, Beijing eases Covid curbs
summary: Shanghai and Beijing, China, have taken steps towards reopening as the country eases COVID-19 curbs. Shanghai will lift a two-month lockdown, allowing more businesses to reopen and people to leave their flats, while Beijing has eased restrictions on public transport, malls, and gyms. The moves come as China's economy shows signs of recovering, but experts warn that the highly transmissible Omicron variant poses a risk to the recovery. Shanghai reported just over 100 daily COVID cases, while Beijing recorded 21, mirroring a nationwide downtrend.

images.alt_text: People use attractions at Sun Park on the day of its reopening after the government eased some of the restrictions, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Beijing, China May 29, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins

Shanghai took further gradual steps on Friday toward lifting its Covid-19 lockdown while Beijing was investigating cases where its strict curbs were affecting other medical treatments as China continues its uneven exit from restrictions.

site_title: Europe’s push to punish Putin is falling short of the rhetoric
summary: The European Union's efforts to punish Russia's President Vladimir Putin for invading Ukraine are facing challenges, with member states failing to deliver on promises to hit Russia's lucrative energy industry. Despite repeated proposals for an oil embargo, Hungary's refusal to back sanctions has stalled talks, and other countries are yielding to Putin's demands for gas payments in roubles. EU diplomats are now leaning towards a diluted agreement that would allow deliveries through a key pipeline to continue for Hungary and others, weakening the package of sanctions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags fly outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, March 6, 2019. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Amazon investor proposal to review plastic use narrowly fails to clear
summary: Amazon's investor-led proposal to review its use of plastic narrowly failed to clear, receiving 49% support at the company's annual general meeting. The proposal, which aimed to assess Amazon's cloud, surveillance, and other capabilities for human rights violations, was the only one to gain significant backing. However, proposals on worker safety, unionization, and facial recognition technology were overwhelmingly rejected. The resolutions are non-binding, but companies often take action if they receive 30-40% backing.

images.alt_text: AMAZON.COM said on Wednesday (May 25) it had opened its first brick-and-mortar clothing retail store, as people start to venture out to shop following easing Covid-19 curbs.
A labour coalition on Tuesday said that Amazon delivery workers are getting hurt due to pressure by the e-commerce giant to quickly distribute heaps of packages to customers.

Amazon.com, stuck with too much warehouse capacity now that the surge in pandemic-era shopping has faded, is looking to sublet at least 10 million square feet of space and could vacate even more by ending leases with landlords, according to people familiar with the situation.
Amazon.com has held preliminary discussions with Metropolis, according to a source.

site_title: Bitcoin breaks from stocks and keeps on falling as crypto slides
summary: Bitcoin has fallen 2.4% to $28,700, marking its eighth consecutive weekly loss, as cryptocurrencies decline despite stocks rising. The crypto market has lost $500 billion in value, a 29% plunge, due to macro headwinds and the collapse of the TerraUSD algorithmic stablecoin. Bitcoin now accounts for 44% of the total market's value, but is down 60% from its all-time high in November. Experts warn of a potential downtrend, with a move below $28,000 or $20,000 potentially leading to further losses.

images.alt_text: Size your allocation to crypto according to your risk appetite and circumstances if you choose to include it in your portfolio.

site_title: Robinhood agrees to settle customer lawsuit over 2020 outages
summary: Robinhood has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit over 2020 outages, which allegedly caused users to lose money due to service disruptions. The lawsuit, filed in a San Francisco federal court, seeks damages for users who lost money during outages on March 2, 3, and 9, 2020. The company will seek court approval of the settlement within 60 days, but details of the agreement remain undisclosed.

images.alt_text: Robinhood Markets, the financial upstart that drew millions of novice investors during the early days of the pandemic, is struggling to prove itself as a public company.
Robinhood Markets was supposed to upend the way people trade. Instead, the way people trade is starting to upend Robinhood.

site_title: Germany denies VW China investment guarantees over human rights concerns: Spiegel
summary: Germany's Economy Ministry has denied Volkswagen investment guarantees in China due to human rights concerns in the Xinjiang region. The ministry cited forced labor and mass internment of Uyghurs, despite China's claims of "voluntary" detention camps. Volkswagen had submitted applications for guarantees, but the decision was made over concerns about Xinjiang ties, not direct investments in the region. Germany is reassessing its ties to China and prioritizing human rights, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Chinese retail car sales data for May has added to a picture of a grinding economic recovery from severe anti-pandemic measures.
Volkswagen Chief Executive Herbert Diess said he sees "clear improvement" in semiconductor supplies and expects the automaker's global production can recover during the rest of this year.

site_title: White House welcomes Fiji to its Indo-Pacific economic plan
summary: The White House announced that Fiji has joined the US President Joe Biden's Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF), making it the first Pacific Island country to participate. This move is part of the US effort to counter China's growing influence in the region. Fiji's inclusion brings the total number of countries in IPEF to 14, excluding China. The framework aims to promote free, open, and prosperous trade and security in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Foreign investors in Vietnam keep focus on Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi homes
summary: Foreign investors in Vietnam are focusing on cities like Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi, with 30% of buyers at Frasers Property's Q2 Thao Dien project in Ho Chi Minh City being foreigners. Top overseas nationalities include Singapore, China, and South Korea. This trend is expected to continue as regional travel recovers faster than intercontinental trips. Experts attribute this to the growing demand for regional investment opportunities, with London-based real estate agency Chestertons noting that Asia-based investors are driving the demand.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

Hanoi's urban metro train running along the Cat Linh-Ha Dong line. Proportionally, infrastructure spend in Vietnam is one of the highest in the region, which will continue to reshape urban areas and land values, said Savills Vietnam's Troy Griffiths.
Singapore property firms deepening presence in Vietnam

Golden hotels and luxe apartments: The rise of Vietnam's ultra-rich
Frasers Property scraps plan to acquire Vietnam property development company

site_title: Signs of an inflection point for S-Reits with Europe and US Office assets
summary: Signs of an inflection point for S-Reits are emerging in Europe and US office assets. European office occupier activity remains robust, with robust rents and a 94.8% overall portfolio occupancy rate reported by Cromwell European Reit. In the US, leasing activity rose 5.4% over Q1 2022, driven by pent-up demand. The recovery is tempered by ongoing Ukraine-Russia developments, which has reduced appetite for office expansions in some European countries. This trend may indicate an inflection point for S-Reits with pure Europe and US office properties.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.

site_title: Country music stars distance themselves from NRA after school massacre
summary: Several country music stars, including Lee Greenwood and Don McLean, have distanced themselves from the National Rifle Association (NRA) following the mass shooting at a Texas school, canceling their appearances at the NRA's annual convention. Their withdrawal is seen as indicative of shifting attitudes, with some experts citing a growing divide between country music's traditional conservative roots and a more progressive stance on gun control. The move marks a shift in the genre's stance on gun culture, with some artists calling for more regulations, while others have praised the NRA's Second Amendment rights.

images.alt_text: Flowers placed at a makeshift memorial in front of Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, May 25, 2022.
People react outside the Ssgt Willie de Leon Civic Centre, where students had been transported from Robb Elementary School after a shooting, in Uvalde, Texas, May 24, 2022.

site_title: Does crypto deserve a place in your investment portfolio?
summary: Cryptocurrencies have gained mainstream attention, with popular coins reaching record highs. However, investing in crypto comes with significant risks, including volatility, legal risks, and operations risks. Despite the potential for outsized returns, investors should size their allocation according to their risk appetite and circumstances. A low, single-digit allocation may be suitable, and investors should minimize the use of leverage and conduct thorough research before investing in new coins. Notable examples of crypto's risks include the 99% decline of Luna and the collapse of TerraUSD stablecoin.

images.alt_text: TerraUSD, a stablecoin, has lost its peg to the US dollar. The history of currency pegs can help us understand why.

This file photo taken in London on December 30, 2021 shows a PsychoKitty NFT (Non-Fungible Token) created by psychedelic artist Ugonzo displayed on a phone and a NFT logo displayed on a computer screen from a Crypto.com NFT marketplace.  The market for certified digital objects, also known as NFTs, is suffering a rout at the moment with all the major cryptocurrencies slumping in value.
Cryptocurrencies face a reckoning; prices have fallen more steeply than traditional markets

site_title: Europe: Shares end strongly on upbeat US data
summary: European shares ended the week on a strong note, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index rising 1.5% and gaining 3% for the week, as upbeat US data and easing bets on aggressive interest rate hikes lifted sentiment. Technology stocks led gains, while banks rose 6% amid central banks' interest rate hike plans. The US Federal Reserve's meeting minutes showed the bank could pause rate hikes in the next two months, calming market concerns about slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: EUROPEAN stock markets edged higher at the open on Friday (May 27), as investors took their cue from gains elsewhere.

site_title: The museum of unbearable sorrow
summary: A mass shooting in Uvalde, Texas, has claimed 19 children and two teachers, the latest in a series of deadly gun violence incidents in the US. The tragedy has sparked a familiar cycle of reaction, with memes, statistics, and calls for action circulating online. This phenomenon has created a "museum of unbearable sorrow," where each tragedy adds to a growing list of names and faces, making it difficult to feel hope for change. The response to these tragedies feels reflexive, rather than rooted in actual belief that things can change, leading to a sense of helplessness and guilt that the US, as a wealthy and powerful country, cannot protect its children.

images.alt_text: Flowers are placed on a makeshift memorial in front of Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, on May 25, 2022. - The tight-knit Latino community of Uvalde was wracked with grief Wednesday after a teen in body armor marched into the school and killed 19 children and two teachers, in the latest spasm of deadly gun violence in the US. (Photo by CHANDAN KHANNA / AFP)
Flowers placed at a makeshift memorial in front of Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, May 25, 2022.

site_title: Investing through adversity
summary: Economies face market volatility due to surging oil prices and increasing interest rates, with core inflation in Singapore reaching a 10-year high of 3.3% in April 2022. Investors can navigate this uncertainty by adopting a long-term investment horizon and focusing on research, data, and proven strategies. Additionally, dollar asset diversification is expected to drive growth in Asia, while retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains and shifting safe havens will also play a key role in wealth creation.

images.alt_text: The outlook for dividend growth appears positive

site_title: Stamford Land H2 net profit jumps 130% on fair-value gains
summary: STAMFORD Land reported a 130.7% increase in net profit for the fiscal second half, reaching S$15.6 million, driven by fair-value gains of S$12.5 million on its investment properties. Revenue rose 5.4% to S$77.7 million, with earnings per share increasing to 3.83 cents. The company's businesses were not significantly affected by seasonal or cyclical factors, and a final dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share is proposed.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Sydney's Sir Stamford at Circular Quay, one of Stamford Land's hotels.

site_title: From Justin Bieber to Liverpool, live events in Singapore are back with a vengeance
summary: Singapore's live events scene has made a strong comeback, with international artists such as Justin Bieber, Jay Chou, and A-Lin set to perform, alongside major sporting events like the English Premier League and e-sports tournaments. The Singapore Sports Hub expects to host more events in 2022 and 2023, with ticket sales doubling compared to pre-pandemic levels. The industry is adapting to new trends, including virtual and hybrid experiences, e-sports, and cashless transactions, to stay ahead of consumer expectations and maintain its status as a global events hub.

images.alt_text: Sports Hub ready to stage much larger events, but only if it makes economic sense: CEO
Singapore must do all it can to maintain status as global events hub

site_title: NutryFarm unit could lose 33.4 million yuan on durian delivery shortfall compensation
summary: NutryFarm's indirectly wholly-owned subsidiary, Global Agricapital (Thailand) Co, may lose 33.4 million yuan (S$6.8 million) due to a delivery shortfall compensation for durian supplies to two customers. The shortfall occurred in a 2021 purchase agreement for 200 containers of fresh durians. Settlement agreements were entered into in January with Moonda (Beijing) Agricultural Science and Technology Co and China Railway Production Control (Chengdu) Industrial Co. The outcome may impact NutryFarm's financial performance.

images.alt_text: Creditors of KTL, NutryFarm may not share boards' faith in chairman Wu Yongqiang
NutryFarm requests trading suspension pending review of ongoing concerns
NutryFarm requests trading suspension pending review of ongoing concerns

site_title: Goldman’s move to unlimited vacation is good for… Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs has introduced an unlimited vacation policy, allowing employees to take as much time off as they want, but some observers see it as a cost-saving move. The policy shift is seen as a departure from the bank's traditional hard-charging culture, where employees are often expected to be available to clients anytime. While the policy is touted as a way to promote employee wellness, critics argue it may actually benefit the employer by reducing the financial burden of unused vacation days. The policy applies to senior bankers, who will no longer have a cap on their time off, but all employees are expected to take a minimum of 15 days off per year.

images.alt_text: Outside the headquarters of Goldman Sachs in New York, May 25, 2022. The investment bank will let workers take as much time off as they want, but some observers see the policy as more of a cost-saving move, with no more unused vacation days and no need to pay them out later. (An Rong Xu/The New York Times)

FILE Ñ David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, in New York, Jan. 29, 2019. (Jeenah Moon/The New York Times)

Robert Sweeney, who started the tech-recruiting company Facet, in Lehi, Utah, May 24, 2022. The company had an unlimited-paid-time-off policy, but changed it because employees were taking few days off. (Kim Raff/The New York Times)

The offices of the tech-recruiting company Facet in Lehi, Utah, May 24, 2022. The company had an unlimited-paid-time-off policy but changed it because employees were taking few days off. (Kim Raff/The New York Times)

More than 85 per cent of UK finance workers no longer view the office as their main place of work, highlighting the challenge the industry faces if it tries to persuade bankers to return to pre-pandemic norms.

site_title: Fed carrying US$330b in unrealised losses on its assets according to Q1 financial statement
summary: The US Federal Reserve holds nearly US$9 trillion in assets, including US$330 billion in unrealised losses on its US Treasury and mortgage-backed securities as of March. Despite these losses, the Fed still remitted US$32.2 billion to the US Treasury in the first quarter of 2022. The losses pose a challenge for the central bank, particularly as interest rates continue to rise, affecting the market value of the Fed's balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates will act as a tailwind to certain hedge fund strategies, the writer says.

site_title: Plant-based proteins are no longer a side dish in diets
summary: Plant-based protein alternatives have made significant strides in recent years, with revenues expected to reach $290 billion by 2035. Companies like Oatly and Impossible Foods have received substantial investments, and major brands like Nestle have acquired plant-based companies. Improved manufacturing techniques and lower prices have made plant-based products more appealing to consumers, including flexitarians who forgo meat but not always. However, the industry still faces challenges, including nutritional value, sustainability, and limited global appeal.

images.alt_text: A marketing stunt from Peta, the animal-rights group and a longtime McDonald's adversary, has given a short-term sales boost to the fast-food chain's plant-based burger.

site_title: KSH Holdings H2 net profit soars to S$14.5m after share of results from associates, JVs
summary: KSH Holdings posted a second-half net profit of S$14.5 million, up from S$269,000 year-on-year, driven by the progress of property development projects in Singapore and a revaluation gain of hotel properties. Revenue rose 5% to S$124.5 million, with earnings per share increasing to 2.57 cents. The group reversed a full-year loss to post a net profit of S$24.3 million, with an order book of over S$530 million. KSH is proposing a final dividend of 1 cent per share.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
En bloc die-hard Peace Centre finally nails it with S$650m deal

site_title: Preventing the next stock heist means beating the cyborgs
summary: Singaporean businessman John Soh Chee Wen and his partner Quah Su-Ling were convicted of multiple counts of market manipulation and cheating charges in a 194-day trial. They used sophisticated "wash trading" techniques to manipulate three penny stocks, driving their value up 800% before crashing and wiping out S$8 billion in shareholder value. The case highlights the challenge of regulators competing with technologically-advanced criminals in a "tech arms race" to protect investors and prevent financial crimes. To prevent similar schemes, market supervisors need to analyze vast amounts of data and identify connected patterns of suspicious activity across various asset classes.

images.alt_text: $8b penny stock crash trial. Quah Su-Ling (picture), along with John Soh Chee Wen, are accused of masterminding Singapore’s most serious case of stock market manipulation.
Quah Su-Ling (left) and John Soh Chee Wen are accused of masterminding Singapore’s most serious case of stock market manipulation.

site_title: Are our supply chains ready for the next global health crisis?
summary: The world's healthcare supply chains are not adequately prepared for the next global health crisis, with significant disparities in vaccine distribution, diagnostic testing, and therapeutic access between high- and low-income countries. To address this, governments, multilateral organizations, and private companies must collaborate to design supply chains that balance effectiveness with equity. This includes sharing market risks, increasing production flexibility, and investing in resilient manufacturing facilities in diverse locations. The "resilience premium" for investing in production capacity in countries like Senegal can provide long-term benefits for global health security.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization’s member states agreed on Tuesday to overhaul how they fund the UN health agency, giving it much more money to spend on its own priorities.

site_title: Russia captures centre of Lyman, encircles most of Sievierodonetsk
summary: Russian forces captured the center of Lyman and encircled most of Sievierodonetsk, Ukraine, in a significant advance in the eastern Donbas region. Ukrainian officials acknowledged the losses, but said their forces remained strong in new defensive lines. The advance comes after a Ukrainian counter-offensive pushed Russian forces back from Kharkiv earlier this month. Western countries, including the US, are considering supplying Ukraine with long-range weaponry, including the M142 High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, to help counter Russian aggression.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings destroyed after weeks of fighting in Irpin, Ukraine, May 2, 2022.

site_title: Bankrupt Sri Lanka takes Russia oil as fuel shortage persists
summary: Sri Lanka has accepted Russian oil to fuel its sole refinery amid crippling shortages of gasoline and diesel. The country's only refinery will restart and produce fuel in six days after receiving a shipment of Siberian Light crude. This move comes as Sri Lanka faces its worst financial crisis, with the government struggling to pay for oil that's been sitting on tankers off its coast. The refinery will use the Russian oil to produce fuel, with the cost of the shipment unclear.

site_title: The crypto carnage shouldn’t blot out blockchain
summary: The article discusses the ongoing crypto carnage and its potential impact on the blockchain industry. Despite the turmoil, moves towards legitimizing digital assets on the blockchain are gaining momentum, with courts in several jurisdictions leading the charge. The US Congress has introduced 50 bills impacting digital assets, while the World Economic Forum at Davos has featured panel discussions on the industry. The article concludes that dismissing the blockchain industry entirely may be fraught with its own risks, highlighting the need for a balanced approach to regulation and innovation.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrencies face a reckoning; prices have fallen more steeply than traditional markets

site_title: Asti seeks 2nd time extension for AGM due to difficulties finalising accounts
summary: Asti Holdings, a semiconductor manufacturing services company, is seeking a second month's extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) due to difficulties in finalizing its 2021 financial accounts. The company cited six reasons for the extension, including issues with the accounts of its associate, Advanced Systems Automation, and its subsidiaries. Asti's shares closed 9.5% lower on the day of the announcement. The company's AGM was initially set for May 31 but now aims to take place by June 29.

site_title: Singtel’s digital investments must yield dividends, not dead ends
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has embarked on a "strategic reset" to revamp its business and drive growth. The company has invested in digital life initiatives, including a digital bank joint venture with Grab, and data centre expansion. However, analysts warn that these investments may burn cash in the short term. Singtel's group CEO, Yuen Kuan Moon, acknowledges "lessons learned" from past digital investments, which have been unsuccessful. The company aims to generate returns on invested capital-driven growth, with a focus on core businesses and dividend payments.

Singtel to 'exploit tailwinds of digitalisation' with strategic reset

Singtel's tech-services unit recast as pan-Asian B2B digital services provider

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as economic data allays growth worries
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Friday, with the Dow Jones rising 97.90 points or 0.30% to 32,735.09, driven by strong consumer spending and signs of peaking inflation. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 opening 19.59 points or 0.48% higher at 4,077.43 and the Nasdaq Composite rising 129.04 points or 1.10% to 11,869.69. The positive start follows concerns about a slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: Oil falters despite tight supply while economic anxieties grow
summary: Oil prices slipped 0.6% to near $113 a barrel amid concerns about the global economy, despite tight supply levels. US motorists face soaring costs as gasoline stockpiles hit a 2014 low. The Group of Seven urged OPEC to pump more oil, while Bank of America warned of a potential "80s-style oil crisis" if Russian exports are lost. Analysts predict oil demand may ease if supply doesn't recover, with Brent futures potentially reaching $150 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil prices climbed about 3 per cent to a 2-month high on Thursday on signs of tight supply ahead of US summer driving season, as the European Union (EU) wrangled with Hungary over plans to ban crude imports from Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX up 0.5%, and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.7%. The positive mood followed gains on Wall Street and minutes from the Federal Reserve suggesting a potential easing of interest rate hikes if inflation shows signs of easing later in the year.

site_title: Court grants No Signboard and subsidiaries moratorium till Oct 29
summary: The Singapore High Court granted No Signboard Holdings and two subsidiaries a 6-month moratorium until October 29, allowing them to avoid winding up and protect their assets. The company must disclose its financial accounts and cash flow projections to creditors and submit information about any property transactions. The court also granted super priority status to a $5 million rescue financing secured by Gazelle Ventures, which has agreed to invest in the group. Trading of No Signboard's shares has been suspended since January 2022.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The Singapore High Court was scheduled to hear moratorium requests by No Signboard and 2 of its subsidiaries at 2.30pm on May 26.
In No Signboard’s application, it requested that OCBC, which is the creditor of S$3 million under a temporary bridging loan facility, be excluded from the terms of the moratorium order.

site_title: US consumer spending beats expectations in April; inflation likely peaked
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.9% in April, beating expectations, while annual inflation appears to have peaked, potentially supporting economic growth in the second quarter. Strong wage gains and record job openings are driving spending. The Federal Reserve's monetary policy stance has fueled recession worries, but the data suggests a slowdown in inflation. Economists expect the Fed to hike interest rates further, with growth estimates for the second quarter above a 2.0 annualized rate.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians carry shopping bags in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. US retail sales grew at a solid pace in April, reflecting broad-based gains and suggesting demand for merchandise remains resilient despite rampant inflation. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Applications for US unemployment insurance declined last week by more than forecast, underscoring a persistently tight labour market.

site_title: China opens exchange bond markets to overseas investors
summary: China has opened its exchange bond markets to qualified foreign institutional investors, allowing central banks, sovereign funds, commercial banks, and pension funds to invest in bonds on the exchange market starting June 30. This move aims to widen global access to China's financial markets, which are valued at $28.2 billion. The decision is part of efforts to boost a flagging economy, with the government seeking to sell more debt to stimulate growth.

site_title: S Korea's pension fund to keep boosting stock holdings
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service plans to maintain its strategy of increasing stock holdings in its total assets to boost earnings, while cutting bond holdings over the next 5 years. The pension fund aims to boost the ratio of stocks to around 55% by 2027, from 44.1% this year, and reduce bond holdings to around 30% from 42.5% over the same period. This shift is expected to boost earnings and diversify the pension fund's assets.

site_title: Monkeypox can be contained if we act now, WHO says
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has emphasized the need to contain monkeypox in non-endemic countries through quick action. According to Sylvie Briand, WHO director for Global Infectious Hazard Preparedness, the virus can be contained with the right measures in place now. Targeted vaccination for close contacts and case investigation, contact tracing, and isolation at home are recommended. The WHO does not currently advocate for mass vaccination, citing a slower transmission rate compared to other viruses like the coronavirus.

site_title: US goods-trade gap shrinks by most since 2009 as imports drop
summary: The US merchandise-trade deficit narrowed by 15.9% in April to $105.9 billion, the largest decline since 2009, due to a 5% drop in imports amid lockdowns in China and a 3.1% increase in exports to a record $173.9 billion. This improvement suggests economic growth is off to a strong start for the second quarter, despite inflation concerns and global supply chain disruptions. The trade deficit's shrinkage is attributed to a decrease in industrial supplies, capital goods, and consumer merchandise, and a rise in wholesale inventories and retail stockpiles.

site_title: Econ Healthcare posts H2 S$1.3m net loss after losing S$3.4m from selling Crosstec stake
summary: Econ Healthcare (Asia) posted a net loss of S$1.3 million for the 6 months ended Mar 31, 2022, reversing from a net profit of S$2 million in the same period last year. The loss was attributed to a S$3.4 million investment loss from selling its stake in Crosstec Group Holdings. Despite this, revenue rose 1.3% to S$19.3 million, driven by a rise in revenue from medicare centres and nursing home fees. The company's cash and cash equivalents remained healthy at S$26.1 million.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Econ Healthcare's audit committee to review investment policy
Econ Healthcare posts 41.2% rise in full-year net profit to S$5.7m

site_title: G-7 calls on Opec to play key role to ease global energy supplies
summary: The G-7 countries have called on Opec to act responsibly to ease a global energy crunch brought on by the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Despite announcing a commitment to phase out coal-fuelled power, the G-7 failed to set a date for doing so, citing Japan and the US's inability to support a 2030 target. The group also agreed to largely decarbonise their power sectors by 2035 and stop public financing for "unabated" fossil fuel projects abroad by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: The Group of Seven countries has reached concrete agreements on phasing out coal power generation and expanding renewable energy production.

site_title: China's Pinduoduo beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: Chinese e-commerce platform Pinduoduo reported better-than-expected quarterly revenue due to a surge in online shopping amid a resurgence of Covid-19 cases in parts of the country. The Shanghai-based company's US-listed shares rose nearly 10% in trading. The "zero-Covid" policy has led to strict lockdowns, keeping people dependent on online platforms for essential items, driving up demand for Pinduoduo's services.

site_title: Indonesia to allocate about 1 million tonnes of palm oil for export
summary: Indonesia will allocate approximately 1 million tonnes of palm oil for export, prioritizing companies registered for the government's bulk cooking oil programme. This comes after a 3-week export ban aimed at controlling cooking oil prices at home, which was lifted on May 23. Exporters must comply with the Domestic Market Obligation (DMO) to determine the volumes they can ship. The move aims to support the country's palm oil industry while managing the domestic market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.61 points to 1,546.76 on Friday, closing higher. The index saw 2.777 billion lots worth RM2.008 billion, with losers outnumbering winners 535 to 400.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang H2 net profit tumbles 75% on weaker revenue
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 75% decline in net profit to S$29.6 million for the second half of 2022, due to a 75% decrease in revenue to S$89.4 million. Gross profit fell 79% to S$30 million, mainly due to lower profit from development projects. The group has fully sold several projects and launched the successful LIV @ MB project, selling over 75% of units on its launch weekend. A final dividend of 4 cents per share and a special dividend of 12 cents per share are proposed.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Bukit Sembawang Estates' Liv @ MB sold more than 75 per cent of its 298 units on its launch weekend.

site_title: China regulator approves including ETFs in stock connect schemes with Hong Kong
summary: China's securities regulator has agreed to include exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in stock connect schemes with Hong Kong, expanding investment options for mainland Chinese and Hong Kong investors. The formal launch date will be announced later, following a 2-month preparation process. This move aims to increase trading opportunities and promote economic integration between the two regions through stock connect schemes, which enable investors to trade stocks listed on both exchanges.

site_title: Prince William holds future of British monarchy in his hands
summary: Prince William is poised to shape the future of the British monarchy, with many considering him the key person in maintaining the institution's long-term viability and popularity. As the second in line to the throne, William has garnered significant media attention and public support, with polls showing he is the most liked royal after Queen Elizabeth. However, with a decade of changing societal values and increasing scrutiny, William will face the challenge of modernizing the monarchy while navigating the complexities of his family's past controversies, including Prince Harry's departure and police investigations into Prince Charles's charity.

images.alt_text: Elizabeth II marks Platinum Jubilee with 'Queen Camilla' announcement

site_title: How might more PLH flats affect the HDB market?
summary: The HDB market in Singapore is expected to see a rise in million-dollar flat transactions as the government launches more Prime Location Housing (PLH) BTO projects. As of May 2022, 27.2% of million-dollar flat transactions were in Pinnacle@Duxton, with Bukit Merah and Queenstown also seeing a significant number. The introduction of PLH flats in these areas may drive up demand and prices, potentially leading to more million-dollar transactions. However, when these flats become eligible for resale after 10 years, it may introduce fresh supply into the market, potentially cooling the market in the long run.

images.alt_text:
Bukit Merah Ridge is bounded by Bukit Merah View, Henderson Road, Tiong 
Bahru Road and Lower Delta Road.

site_title: Toyota cuts June output plan again, to 800,000 vehicles
summary: Toyota cuts its global production plan for June by 50,000 vehicles to 800,000, citing the Covid-19 lockdown in Shanghai. This is the second reduction in a week, following a 100,000-vehicle cut on Tuesday due to a semiconductor shortage. Despite this, Toyota still expects to produce 9.7 million vehicles worldwide in the current financial year, with a possibility of a lower estimate. The lockdown has added uncertainty to the industry, which is already grappling with microchip shortages.

site_title: Pandemic endgame
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed 6.2 million lives, with an estimated 15 million excess deaths due to overwhelmed healthcare systems globally. Despite the development of vaccines and antivirals, variants like Delta, Omicron, and others have pierced through the wall of vaccinated individuals, resulting in ongoing transmission. Long COVID affects 10-30% of patients, with diabetics, autoimmune disease sufferers, and those with latent viruses more likely to experience it. As the pandemic enters its endgame, experts recommend keeping boosters current, masking indoors, and seeking medical attention if symptoms persist, with a hopeful future where COVID becomes a manageable part of society.

images.alt_text: Scientists working on a nasal spray for SARS-CoV-2 are also developing a single vaccine for a broad range of coronaviruses, that could protect against future variants.
Clues to next variant are all around us
The next Covid-19 wave is probably already on its way

site_title: Cortina Holdings posts 72.3% jump in H2 net profit on recovery from supply chain disruption
summary: Cortina Holdings reported a 72.3% increase in 2nd half net profit to S$43.3 million, driven by a recovery from supply chain disruption. Revenue grew 49.2% to S$392.2 million, with full-year revenue up 64.5% to S$716.9 million. The company attributed the growth to easing Covid-19 restrictions and additional revenue from the acquisition of Sincere Watch. A 73% increase in net profit for the full year resulted in earnings per share of 41.5 Singapore cents, up from 24 cents in the previous year.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Stocks of firms that diversified into hot sectors, crude oil plays among best performers for 2021
The Hour Glass posted a net profit of S$92.1 million for its fiscal second half ended Mar 31, 2022.

site_title: Taiwan lowers 2022 GDP growth forecast, hit by Covid and inflation
summary: Taiwan's statistics office has lowered its 2022 GDP growth forecast to 3.91% due to global inflation and Covid-19 dampening consumer demand. The downward revision is despite a raised export growth forecast of 14.62% for the year, driven by strong demand for technology products. Consumer spending at home is expected to be impacted by the spike in Covid cases, leading to a 0.5-0.7% downward revision to growth. The revision is also influenced by the slowdown in China's economy, Taiwan's top trading partner, and the prolonged lockdown of economic hub Shanghai.

site_title: Profits before IPO, says founder of co-working unicorn JustCo
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working operator, has shifted its focus to profitability amid market volatility. The company, which had explored going public in the US last year, now aims to turn earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) positive by year-end. JustCo's revenue rose 62% to $64.8 million in 2020, but net loss widened to $38.2 million due to depreciation expenses. The company is prioritizing financial prudence and government support, and is considering merger and acquisition deals to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
WeWork's flagship property 21 Collyer Quay will start operations from July 2022

krbrunch23 - The auditorium at the WeWork facility at 21 Collyer Quay opening in 2022.

Copyright: WeWork

site_title: Didi is said to draw China FAW's interest in buying stake
summary: State-owned Chinese automaker China FAW Group is considering acquiring a significant stake in troubled ride-hailing giant Didi Global. FAW has reached out to Didi's top executives, expressing interest in becoming a major shareholder and helping resolve data security issues. This move comes after Didi's shares jumped 10% in premarket trading following the report. Discussions are at an early stage, and FAW is not the only firm exploring a stake in Didi, with Shouqi Group and other Beijing-based companies also looking into the opportunity.

site_title: Japanese buyout firms JIP, Polaris considering bids for Toshiba: sources
summary: Japanese buyout firms Japan Industrial Partners (JIP) and Polaris Capital Group are considering participating in bids for Toshiba Corp, according to sources. Toshiba has set up a special committee to explore strategic options, including deals to go private, after a restructuring plan was rejected by shareholders. The participation of local funds is seen as critical due to the strategic importance of Toshiba's assets, including defence equipment and nuclear power. The deadline for initial proposals is Monday, with Toshiba saying it will provide transparent updates on the process to its shareholders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Toshiba Corp. is seen at the company's facility in Kawasaki, Japan June 10, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

TOSHIBA nominated an executive from M&A advisory firm Houlihan Lokey as chairperson and activist shareholders as outside directors on Thursday (May 26), in a board overhaul that could intensify pressure to take the conglomerate private.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices reverse 3-month drop to climb 0.5% in April
summary: Hong Kong private home prices reversed a 3-month decline in April, rising 0.5% from the previous month, as the financial hub stabilized after Covid-related woes. The reversal was driven by new development launches and the relaxation of restrictions. However, some analysts, including Spacious, expect prices to drop another 5% in the rest of the year due to a weaker local economy and deteriorating mortgage rate outlook.

images.alt_text: HONG KONG'S accountant body said it failed to reach an accord to prolong an 11-year mutual recognition agreement (MRA) with the US amid a dispute over local qualifications.

site_title: RBI calls on banks to arrest repayment slippages, support credit growth
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has urged banks to closely monitor restructured loans and potential repayment slippages from sectors exposed to the pandemic. The central bank warned that some restructured accounts may face solvency concerns, impacting banks' balance sheets in the upcoming quarters. As the economy recovers, banks will need to focus on supporting credit growth while being vigilant of evolving risks. The RBI emphasized the need for banks to be proactive in addressing these challenges.

images.alt_text: INDIA'S headline inflation accelerated for a seventh month to the fastest since May 2014, further challenging the central bank's efforts to contain surging prices and sustain an economic recovery.

site_title: The last of a flying breed
summary: The Audi RS 3 Sportback is a high-performance vehicle that boasts impressive speed and agility. With a 2.5-liter 5-cylinder engine producing 400 horsepower, it can accelerate from 0-100 km/h in just 3.8 seconds and reach a top speed of 250 km/h. The RS 3 features a unique "RS Torque Splitter" system that divides engine power between each rear wheel, allowing for tighter turns and increased performance. The vehicle's cabin is designed with a sporty tone, featuring quilted upholstery, colored stitching, and a synthetic suede steering wheel. With various settings and accessories available, the RS 3 can be tailored to suit different driving styles, making it a formidable competitor on the road.

images.alt_text: Chinese retail car sales data for May has added to a picture of a grinding economic recovery from severe anti-pandemic measures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally into the weekend
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 2.89% to 20,697.36, driven by a rally on Wall Street following forecast-beating earnings from tech giants Alibaba and Baidu. The Shanghai Composite Index also edged up 0.23%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat.

site_title: As KL probes poultry cartels, Malaysia firms are feeling the pain too
summary: Malaysia will suspend chicken exports from June 1, affecting countries including Singapore, amid a supply shortage and spiralling prices. The move aims to stabilize domestic chicken prices, which have been driven up by a 60% reliance on foreign imports and the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war. The government has also launched an investigation into reports of cartels controlling the poultry market, with a report due in June. The chicken export ban, expected to last until the domestic supply stabilizes, has sparked concerns about shortages and price increases for businesses such as KFC and Nando's.

images.alt_text: A poultry seller at Tekka Market at 11.45am on May 21, 2020.

site_title: SIAS says no objection to Hwa Hong appointing IFA ahead of independent reviewer
summary: SIAS does not object to Hwa Hong's appointment of an independent financial adviser (IFA) ahead of its appointment of an independent reviewer. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) had advised Hwa Hong to first appoint an independent reviewer before appointing an IFA, following a notice of compliance from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo). Hwa Hong appointed the IFA on Thursday to assess a privatization offer by Sanjuro United, a substantial shareholder of Hwa Hong.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

A man wearing a protective face mask walks past the Singapore Exchange (SGX) which stays open during "circuit breaker" measures to curb coronavirus COVID-19) in central business district area in Singapore, April 7, 2020. REUTERS/Edgar Su

In a bourse filing on Thursday, Hwa Hong said Provenance Capital was appointed as its IFA as it is the directors’ responsibility to decide on the appointment under the Singapore Code on Takeovers and Mergers.
Noting that it has been “business as usual” for Hwa Hong since the shortlisting of the 2 IDs, Gerald urged the board to “do more” to safeguard shareholder interests, especially minority shareholders.

SUBSTANTIAL shareholders of property player Hwa Hong Corporation have made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.370 per share to take the company private.

site_title: Chemical Industries H2 net profit up 344% on higher revenue
summary: Chemical Industries (Far East) posted a 344.2% jump in net profit to S$9.4 million for the second half ended March 31, 2022, driven by higher revenue of 53.7% to S$50.2 million. Despite a 5% decline in gross profit margin due to rising energy and raw material costs, the company's net profit rose 22.1% for the full year to S$6.8 million. The group declared a final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of 1.8 Singapore cents per share to commemorate its 60th anniversary.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

Energy security has become a top priority for importers as forecasts of tighter gas supplies and volatile prices in the next few years are keeping buyers on edge and impeding the push towards decarbonisation, energy executives said.

site_title: Thailand to join hands with Vietnam to control rice trade
summary: Thailand and Vietnam are considering a joint effort to control rice trade by raising prices to boost bargaining power in the global market. This move, proposed by Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha, aims to benefit millions of rice farmers struggling with rising costs. The plan comes amid growing food protectionism and inflation, with India potentially restricting rice exports. However, rice prices are expected to remain subdued due to abundant supplies and record crop production until 2023, according to experts.

site_title: G-7 reaches agreements on phasing out coal: German minister
summary: The Group of Seven countries has reached agreements to phase out coal power generation and expand renewable energy production. German Environment Minister Steffi Lemke stated that the commitments include phasing out coal and protecting biodiversity, amid a backdrop of rising energy costs and fuel supply worries sparked by the war in Ukraine. The G-7 meeting in Berlin aims to combat climate change while finding alternative fossil fuels that do not compromise environmental goals.

images.alt_text: According to a McKinsey report, more than one-quarter of assets under management globally are now being invested based on how ESG factors affect a company’s performance and market value.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The transport and storage industry saw the largest year-on-year growth at 41.7%, according to recent data. Singapore's services sector saw a 13.2% rise in receipts for the first quarter, while Malaysia will suspend chicken exports from June 1, affecting neighboring countries. The Housing and Development Board launched 4,583 Build-To-Order flats, and JustCo, a co-working unicorn, reported profits before an IPO. Singapore stocks rose 0.7% amid a regional rally, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,230.55 points.

images.alt_text: The aerospace segment expanded 24.2 per cent on the back of higher production of aircraft parts and more maintenance, repair and overhaul jobs from commercial airlines as a result of the lifting of border restrictions globally.

site_title: Singapore services receipts up 13.2% in Q1
summary: Singapore's services industries saw business receipts rise 13.2% year on year in Q1, according to the Department of Statistics. The transport and storage industry experienced the largest growth at 41.7%, driven by air and water transport segments. The information and communications industry also saw significant growth at 22.6%. However, the professional services industry declined 10.9% and health and social services industries saw mixed performance. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, business receipts were down 1.6%.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

epa08153859 A Singapore Airlines Boeing 787 Dreamliner (back) taxies past a Scoot Boeing 787 Dreamliner at the Changi Airport in Singapore,  23 January 2020. Budget carrier Scoot has cancelled its daily flight to Wuhan, China after the city was locked down by Chinese authorities following the coronavirus outbreak. As of 23 January, there have been nearly 600 cases and a total of 17 reported deaths in China. Passengers arriving from China in Singapore are subject to temperature screening and will isolate pneumonia patients who have a history of recent travel to China.  EPA-EFE/WALLACE WOON

site_title: Zilingo’s fired CEO responds to questions of mystery payments
summary: Zilingo's fired CEO Ankiti Bose denies wrongdoing in the wake of her termination due to "serious financial irregularities." Bose claims she was fired for lack of cooperation in the investigation, not for actual financial improprieties. The investigation found payments to service providers totaling millions of dollars signed by Bose without senior executives' knowledge. Bose maintains that the payments are legitimate and not made to benefit her personally. She is seeking to clear her name and protect her reputation, stating that her career and life are at stake. The company has not publicly detailed its allegations against Bose and has reserved the right to pursue legal action.

images.alt_text: Zilingo ousted Bose “with cause” after an investigation led by an independent forensics firm into complaints of serious financial irregularities, it said.
The board suspended its CEO and co-founder Ankiti Bose in March with the backing of major investors, pending a probe by an independent firm they hired.

site_title: Aviation sector to launch job portal in Q3 2022 as industry continues to recover: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's aviation sector is launching a new job portal, OneAviation Careers Hub, in Q3 2022, providing a one-stop platform for job seekers, career advice, and recruitment services. The initiative, led by CAAS, NTUC, and e2i, aims to facilitate end-to-end job facilitation and equip job seekers with necessary skills and competencies. The portal will offer career opportunities and conversion programs, as well as relevant training courses, to support the industry's recovery.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Minister for Transport and Minister-in-charge for Trade Relations S. Iswaran delivers his opening address at the Changi Aviation Summit in Singapore on May 17, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP) (Photo by ROSLAN RAHMAN/AFP via Getty Images)
Singapore had planned for air passenger volume to recover to 50 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by this year.

site_title: STI up 0.7% amid regional rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% or 21.37 points to 3,230.55, following a regional rally driven by a strong finish on Wall Street. Asian markets tracked the US overnight rally, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 2.9% and Japan's Nikkei 225 rising 0.7%. Local stocks also gained, with Jardine Matheson climbing 4.1% and three local banks - UOB, OCBC, and DBS - rising 0.9%, 0.3%, and 0.2% respectively.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Wall Street stocks jumped Thursday as strong results from retailers combined with investor bargain-hunting to produce a second straight positive session.

site_title: MiRXES opens S$8m in-vitro diagnostic manufacturing facility
summary: MiRXES, a biotech startup, has opened an S$8 million in-vitro diagnostic manufacturing facility in Singapore, the largest in South-east Asia. The facility, spanning 15,000 square feet, will produce RNA early detection tests for cancer, cardiovascular, and pulmonary diseases. Utilizing Industry 4.0 solutions, it can increase production capacity by up to 5 times and employ up to 50 people on-site by 2023. The facility is part of MiRXES' efforts to commercialize its biotech research into products, with plans to explore opportunities with government agencies and explore a possible listing via a US$1.2 billion business combination.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
MiRXES eyes fuss-free early cancer tests; road ahead not easy
Singapore biotech startup Mirxes in talks for US$1.2b SPAC listing in US
Singapore's MiRXES raises US$77m to treble valuation as biotech craze catches on

site_title: UK household support package will have 'minimal impact' on inflation: Sunak
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak announced a £15 billion cost-of-living support package, which he believes will have a minimal impact of less than 1 percentage point on inflation. The package aims to alleviate household pressure, following a 40-year high inflation rate of 9.0% in April. The measures are partly funded by a 25% windfall tax on oil and gas producers' profits, and Sunak is considering a similar tax on electricity generators. The package is expected to add 0.4-0.7% to GDP, with some experts predicting a reduced risk of recession.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades Maybank to ‘hold’ on limited price upside
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded its call on Malayan Banking (Maybank) to "hold" citing fair valuations and limited upside potential. Analyst Keith Wee maintained a target price of RM9.45, citing a 0.5 standard deviation below its historical 5-year average book value. In contrast, CGS-CIMB maintained its "add" call, raising its target price to RM10, driven by expected improvements in loan loss provisioning and net interest margin.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The announcement of interest rate hike came as a surprise to the market as many expected Malaysia's central bank to maintain the historical low interest rate.
"We think we are on the right track," Zafrul told Bloomberg Television at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
Gig workers and low income groups in Malaysia are often neglected groups that are underserved by conventional banks.

site_title: Greenland bonds plunge after Chinese developer seeks extension
summary: Greenland Holdings, China's 11th-largest builder, is seeking investor approval to extend the repayment of a US$488 million dollar note due June 25. This move has triggered concerns over the firm's financial health, with its 6.75% dollar bond price falling 31.5 cents to 39.1 cents. S&P Global Ratings downgraded Greenland to B- and put the firm on watch for further cuts, citing uncertainty over its ability to dispose assets and repay offshore debt. The downgrade follows similar concerns from Moody's Investors Service, which also downgraded Greenland earlier this month.

site_title: Australia retail sales power ahead in sign of economic strength
summary: Australian retailers recorded a fourth consecutive month of sales gains in April, with sales advancing 0.9% to a fresh record A$33.9 billion. The data suggests households are weathering a spike in the cost of living, contrasting with consumer behavior during the pandemic. The strong economy-wide momentum and resilience among consumers highlight underlying economic strength, despite rising interest rates and a cooling property market. The Reserve Bank's recent interest rate hike and economists' expectations of further hikes raise questions over the sustainability of household spending.

images.alt_text: Rampant rises in Australian house prices will grind almost to a halt this year, a Reuters poll of property market analysts found.

site_title: Thai April exports miss forecast over Ukraine war, China lockdown
summary: Thai exports rose 9.9% in April from a year earlier, missing a forecast 14.6% rise, due to the impact of the Ukraine war and China's lockdown measures. Shipments to the US increased 13.6%, while exports to Russia dropped 77%. Thai food exports rose 2.2% and rice shipments jumped 44%. Despite this, the commerce ministry expects shipments to rise this year, benefiting from a weak baht and expected food export growth.

images.alt_text: From export bans to price controls, governments in Asia are taking a much more targeted approach than their Western counterparts in curbing global inflationary pressure, a strategy that appears to be working at least for now.
A poultry seller at Tekka Market at 11.45am on May 21, 2020.
THAILAND -- a major exporter of sugar, chickens and rice -- looks set to benefit as many of its Asian neighbours limit shipments of agricultural commodities to shelter consumers from surging prices.

site_title: North Korea tests rivers, air, garbage as anti-Covid efforts gather steam
summary: North Korea intensifies its fight against its first Covid-19 outbreak, testing rivers, lakes, air, and household wastewater and garbage for the coronavirus. The country reported a "stabilising" trend in the outbreak, with a relatively low death toll of 69, and a total of 3,270,850 fever patients among its 25 million population. Authorities are collecting samples from various sources, including people showing fever symptoms and drinks produced at water factories, and conducting daily disinfection efforts, despite concerns about underreported figures.

images.alt_text: People watch a TV broadcasting a news report on the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in North Korea, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, May 17, 2022.    REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji
North Korea said on Friday it was achieving "good results" in the fight against the country's first confirmed Covid-19 outbreak, as the number of people with fever symptoms surpassed 2 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps 3-session slide on Wall Street rally, posts weekly gain
summary: The Nikkei share average rose 0.66% to close at 26,781.68, ending 0.16% higher for the week, despite snapping three consecutive sessions of losses. The rally was driven by an overnight Wall Street rally, with investors selling shares near the 27,000 level to book profits. The shipping sector led gains, with Nippon Yusen jumping 6.4% after announcing a stock split, while companies related to inbound tourism also rose.

images.alt_text: epa09907807 Passersby are reflected in a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 25 April 2022. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 514.48 points, or 1.90 per cent, to close at 26,590.78.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

Asian markets climbed Friday following a strong performance on Wall Street, with Hong Kong leading the way as forecast-beating earnings reports by tech titans Alibaba and Baidu sent their shares soaring.
The Hang Seng Index surged 2.63 per cent, or 529.86 points, to 20,646.06.

site_title: JTC to link startups to corporates, including Sea and Grab
summary: The government agency JTC has launched an initiative to connect startups with corporates, including Sea and Grab, to facilitate sustainable industrial development. The 700 startups in JTC estates, specializing in advanced manufacturing, biomedical, and infocomm, will be linked with 8 pioneer members of the program. This move aims to unlock deep tech innovation and support the growth of startups in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The award, jointly organised by The Business Times and OCBC Bank, is held annually to celebrate and recognise emerging businesses with an enterprising mindset. It is now in its 15th year.

Slated to roll out to all users at the end of the week, Earn+ is the group’s second investment product and marks its latest foray into an increasingly competitive space for digital investment services.
Sea is stepping up on the fintech opportunity in e-commerce.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise 1% to end week flat; won hits 1-month high
summary: South Korean shares rose 1% on Friday, ending the week flat, as risk appetite improved with easing recession worries. The benchmark Kospi index closed 25.60 points higher at 2,638.05. The won hit a 1-month high, while the bond yield fell. Foreigners were net buyers of 189.3 billion won worth of shares. Tech stocks, including Samsung and Nvidia, surged on solid results, while the won was 0.95% higher for the week, its second straight weekly gain.

images.alt_text: epa08171648 A person wearing a protective mask works in front of monitors, displaying the KOSPI, at the KEB Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 28 January 2020. The benchmark South Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) plunged 69.41 points, or 3.09 percent, to close at 2,155.07. Reports blamed the decline on concerns over the spread of the coronavirus.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN
The benchmark Kospi ended down 4.77 points, or 0.18 per cent, at 2,612.45, reversing a nearly 1 per cent gain in early trade.

site_title: Norway oil and gas firms raise 2022 investment forecasts
summary: Norway's oil and gas companies have raised their investment forecasts for 2022 to 167.2 billion Norwegian crowns (S$24.1 billion), up from a previous forecast of 159.5 billion crowns. The increase is driven by higher estimates in field development, onshore activity, and exploration. Preliminary predictions for 2023 project investment of 130.6 billion crowns, down from a previous forecast of 131.4 billion crowns. The tax incentives, which are set to end this year, are expected to boost the economy and support the central bank's push for higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Energy security has become a top priority for importers as forecasts of tighter gas supplies and volatile prices in the next few years are keeping buyers on edge and impeding the push towards decarbonisation, energy executives said.

Oil prices climbed about 3 per cent to a 2-month high on Thursday on signs of tight supply ahead of US summer driving season, as the European Union (EU) wrangled with Hungary over plans to ban crude imports from Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St higher, tech leads Hong Kong rally
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, driven by strong performances on Wall Street and forecast-beating earnings reports from tech titans Alibaba and Baidu. Hong Kong's tech index jumped 4% as Alibaba and Baidu surged over 12% and 15%, respectively. The positive momentum came after Federal Reserve minutes suggested a possible pause in interest rate hikes if inflation shows signs of easing. Despite ongoing crises, investors remained optimistic, with other markets such as Shanghai, Tokyo, and Seoul also sharply higher.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed Thursday as minutes indicating a less hawkish Fed were offset by China's premier warning that the world's number 2 economy was in some ways worse off now than during the early days of the pandemic.

site_title: Singtel expects rebound in core business, after 4.9% rise in underlying H2 earnings
summary: Singtel reported a 4.9% year-on-year increase in second-half underlying net profit to S$941 million for the 6 months to Mar 31, 2022. The telco expects a rebound in its core business due to a recovery in international travel and easing competition in regional markets. Singtel's management plans to press on with an ongoing business transformation, driven by a travel recovery and improved regional market conditions.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Michelle Zhu
Both Singtel and the Mittal family are shareholders in Bharti Telecom, as well as own direct shares directly in Bharti Airtel.

First-quarter dividends in Asia Pacific, including
Japan and emerging Asia, rose 8.1 per cents to a total of
