$33.9bn, the fourth consecutive quarter of growth from this region, according to the report by Janus Henderson
VTLs are here, but roaming revenue is still stuck in the slow lane

site_title: Google in talks to join India's open e-commerce network ONDC: sources
summary: Google is in talks with the Indian government to integrate its shopping services with the country's open e-commerce network ONDC. This follows the government's efforts to reduce the dominance of US companies like Amazon in the Indian e-commerce market. ONDC aims to join 30 million sellers and 10 million merchants online, covering at least 100 cities and towns by August. Google's existing shopping business works as an aggregator of listings, without carrying out order fulfillment like delivery. The talks come after the government's success with its Unified Payments Interface initiative.

images.alt_text: Republican senators want to bar US app stores including Apple and Google from hosting apps that allow payments to be made with China's digital currency, amid fears the payment system could allow Beijing to spy on Americans.

After unprecedented revenue growth last year, digital platforms including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Snap and Twitter now face a sobering reality as pandemic-driven advertising trends dissipate, according to an analyst report on Thursday.
The search giant is positioning itself as a kind of anti-Amazon, a free marketplace for merchants and  Amazon rivals that’s designed to get consumers more comfortable shopping with Google.

site_title: China, Russia veto US push for more UN sanctions on North Korea
summary: China and Russia vetoed a US-led UN resolution to impose more sanctions on North Korea over its ballistic missile launches, publicly splitting the UN Security Council for the first time since 2006. The US-drafted resolution aimed to ban tobacco and oil exports and blacklist the Lazarus hacking group, but was rejected by China and Russia. The move comes after North Korea fired three missiles, including a large ICBM, following US President Joe Biden's trip to Asia, and amid concerns that Pyongyang is preparing to conduct a nuclear test.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past a television screen showing file footage of a North Korean missile test. North Korea test launched two ballistic missiles towards the sea off its east coast on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong seeks to revive global banking status with major summit
summary: Hong Kong's central bank plans to hold a major conference in November to draw global banking bosses, seeking to revive its global banking status. The move comes after two years of closed borders due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has starved the economy of tourist and business arrivals. This would be the first visit for most major bank CEOs in at least three years, aiming to welcome back international business and boost the territory's economy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong private home prices reversed a three-month decline in April, the latest official data showed on Friday, as the financial hub stabilised after Covid-related woes and homebuyer sentiment was boosted by waves of new development launches.

site_title: Japan Apr factory output seen posting first fall in 3 months on China lockdown
summary: Japan's factory output is expected to have fallen 0.2% in April for the first time in 3 months, due to strict Covid-19 lockdowns in Shanghai and other industrial centers in China. This decline is attributed to the impact on exports, particularly in the general and electrical machinery sectors. Meanwhile, April retail sales are forecast to be 2.6% higher than the previous year, marking the second consecutive month of annual growth. The data is set to be released on May 31.

images.alt_text: Core consumer prices in Tokyo, considered a leading indicator of Japanese price trends, rose 1.9 per cent in May from a year earlier, a pace that matched the previous month's 7-year peak in a sign recent fuel-driven inflationary pressures were broadening.

site_title: First Japan tourists face tests, chaperones and little free time
summary: For the first time in over 2 years, Japan welcomed its first tourists under a trial programme, with visitors subject to tight hygiene measures and monitoring. Upon arrival, tourists were given protective gear, tested, and required to install monitoring apps. The group, consisting of a travel industry professional and his companions, toured Ibaraki prefecture, experiencing a shrine, fish market, and suspension bridge. The trial aims to gauge Japan's preparedness for the limited border reopening next month, with tourists expressing satisfaction with the detailed prevention measures.

images.alt_text: Japan is set to allow in some package-tour tourists from overseas starting Jun 10.

site_title: Shanghai economy improves fitfully as end of Covid lockdown nears
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub, is gradually lifting its two-month Covid-19 lockdown, allowing more businesses to reopen and people to leave their homes. Beijing is also easing restrictions, but with a strict approach, including reduced workplace attendance and increased quarantines. The economic recovery is uneven, with businesses warning of slow sales and consumers cutting back on spending. Despite some improvements, China's industrial firms saw profits fall the fastest in two years in April, and car sales have slowed dramatically. The country's central bank has announced plans to promote more credit for smaller firms.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Containers are seen at the Yangshan Deep-Water Port in Shanghai, China October 19, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Evergrande discussing staggered payments, debt-to-equity swaps for US$19b offshore bonds: sources
summary: Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted developer, is considering repaying offshore public bondholders owed around $19 billion with cash instalments and equity in two of its Hong Kong-listed units. The company, which is in default on its $22.7 billion offshore debt, plans to unveil a preliminary debt restructuring proposal by the end of July. The proposal aims to repay creditors the principal and interest by turning them into new bonds to be repaid in instalments over 7-10 years.

images.alt_text: Chinese developers are now unable to refinance offshore after a series of defaults by other issuers in the troubled sector made new debt raising impossible.

Embattled property developer China Evergrande Group is selling the City Light Plaza project in the country's eastern marine hub of Ningbo for 1.35 billion yuan (S$275.1 million) to shore up its finances.
China is stepping up efforts to salvage the residential property market as consumer and business confidence has been battered by lockdowns.
Major developer Sunac China has made a local bond payment, shortly after it announced a dollar-note default, the latest example of cash first going to ailing builders’ domestic creditors.

site_title: High gas prices, energy security fears impede decarbonisation push
summary: High gas prices and energy security fears are hindering the push towards decarbonization. Europe is importing record volumes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) due to disrupted gas supplies from Russia, driving prices to all-time highs and retarding efforts to switch to gas from coal. Executives are calling for more financing and investments in the oil and gas sector to boost supplies and stabilize prices, with stabilizing gas prices considered the industry's top priority.

images.alt_text: OCBC will invest more than S$25 million in its operations in Singapore, Malaysia and Greater China in a bid to reduce its carbon footprint.
RINA has announced the approval in principle of Swedish designer FKAB Marine Design’s hydrogen powered medium range (MR) Tanker.

site_title: 2,500 prime BTO flats launched; 3 and 4-room units priced at S$369,000-S$737,000
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 4,583 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats across 5 projects in Singapore, including 1 each in Bukit Merah and Queenstown. The 3 and 4-room units are priced at S$369,000-S$737,000. The projects are part of the Prime Location Public Housing (PLH) model, which aims to keep new public housing affordable and accessible in prime locations, with stricter buying and selling conditions.

images.alt_text: Bukit Merah Ridge is bounded by Bukit Merah View, Henderson Road, Tiong Bahru Road and Lower Delta Road.
Ghim Moh Ascent is bounded by Ghim Moh Road, Ghim Moh Close and the Rail Corridor and located in the Health District @ Queenstown.

site_title: Can sustainable aviation fuel solve airlines’ ESG problem?
summary: Singapore is set to become the world's largest sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) producer by 2023, with a new refinery capable of producing 1 million tonnes of SAF per year. However, critics argue that the industry's growth is too slow, with only 200,000 tonnes produced annually, and that the cost is still too high. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) estimates that 65% of the reduction in emissions needed to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 could be contributed by SAF. However, the industry faces challenges in scaling up production and reducing costs. Governments and regulators are being urged to play a key role in facilitating the rollout of SAF by adopting regulatory standards and levelling the playing field for operators through carbon taxes and trading systems.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Singapore to have world's largest sustainable aviation fuel plant
Singapore joins hands with NZ to tackle 'a wicked problem' in aviation

HONG KONG'S Cathay Pacific Airways said on Wednesday (Apr 20) it would work with corporate customers to launch a major corporate sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) programme in Asia, as firms look to shrink their carbon footprint.
Airline chiefs want government aid to reduce carbon emissions
Singapore to conduct sustainable aviation fuel pilot at Changi Airport in Q3
Sustainable aviation fuel garners Asian support as key decarbonisation pillar
Singapore Airlines should disclose impact of sustainable fuel adoption
Neste to start Singapore sustainable aviation fuel plant by Q1 2023

site_title: Gloom engulfs UK services firms as costs and prices soar
summary: The UK services sector is experiencing widespread pessimism due to soaring prices and costs, with a survey by the Confederation of British Industry finding demand waning and profits under pressure. Despite firms increasing prices aggressively, many are scaling back investment plans. Economists warn that the economy risks recession unless significant government support is provided. The CBI calls for an extension of the Recovery Loan Scheme to help businesses and restore confidence. The sector accounts for 80% of UK economic output, with planned investment weakening and consumer services expected to contract over the summer.

site_title: Ford beats Tesla to the punch with first electric F-150 delivery
summary: Ford Motor has delivered the first electric F-150 Lightning to a customer, Nicholas Schmidt, in Standish, Michigan. Schmidt, a Tesla Model 3 owner, had previously reserved a Cybertruck but chose the F-150 Lightning, citing its suitability for his farming needs. This marks a significant milestone for Ford, as the F-150 is America's best-selling vehicle for 40 years, generating over $40 billion in revenue. The delivery signifies Ford's full electrification of its iconic pickup truck, a move seen as a major challenge to Tesla's dominance in the electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: The US automotive giant sold 7 million shares of Rivian stock at US$26.88 each on Friday, according to a filing, cutting its stake in the company to nearly 87 million shares.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS cuts Valuetronics target price to S$0.51 on weaker margin estimates
summary: DBS Group Research lowered its target price for Valuetronics to S$0.51 from S$0.55 due to weaker margin estimates, citing headwinds from supply chain disruptions and macroeconomic uncertainties. The brokerage maintained a "hold" call on the company, which posted a 40.5% drop in its net profit to HK$56.9 million for the second half. Analyst Ling Lee Keng expects headwinds to persist and weigh on Valuetronics' margins in FY2023, but notes a sound balance sheet and potential contributions from new customers.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Valuetronics said the severe shortages of certain key electronic components had impacted the company’s ability to meet orders in the full-year period.
Valuetronics implements HK$250m share buyback programme

site_title: ‘Baby Shark’ producer dismisses speculation of US$1b IPO
summary: Pinkfong, the company behind the popular "Baby Shark" YouTube sensation, has denied speculation about an initial public offering (IPO) valued at US$1 billion. Despite the Seoul Economic Daily's report that Pinkfong will submit a preliminary listing application to the Korea stock exchange next month, the company stated it has not made a decision on an IPO. Pinkfong will continue to review the timing for a potential listing, amid South Korea's cooling IPO market and recent cancellations of planned listings.

images.alt_text: Soft toys of the Baby Shark characters.Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.63% on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 20,646.06, following a strong performance on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.38% and 0.63% respectively. This rally comes amid positive sentiment globally, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Paypal begins cutting staff as its push to reduce costs ramps up: sources
summary: PayPal is cutting staff as part of its efforts to reduce costs and shore up profits after growth in spending on its platform stagnated in recent quarters. The company laid off dozens of staffers in Chicago, Omaha, and Chandler, Arizona, and plans to permanently lay off over 80 people in its headquarters in San Jose, California. PayPal's headcount has increased by 33% since pre-pandemic levels, and the company aims to save $260 million a year in employee-related costs through the restructuring.

images.alt_text: PayPal Holdings reduced guidance for full-year performance as volume growth on its platform continued to slow in the first quarter.

site_title: China's industrial profit falls sharply in April amid Covid curbs
summary: China's industrial profit fell 8.5% in April, the largest drop since March 2020, due to high raw material prices and Covid-19 curbs. Industrial output in Shanghai plummeted 61.5% and profits grew 3.5% year-on-year to 2.66 trillion yuan. Premier Li Keqiang acknowledged weak economic growth and vowed to ensure reasonable growth and lower unemployment. Analysts have downgraded full-year growth forecasts, citing the government's "zero-Covid" policy.

images.alt_text: China's economy is in some respects faring worse than in 2020 when the pandemic first emerged, Premier Li Keqiang said, urging efforts to reduce a soaring unemployment rate.
Chinese retail car sales data for May has added to a picture of a grinding economic recovery from severe anti-pandemic measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 5.45 points or 0.4% to 1,535.70. Volume was 367.7 million lots worth RM153.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 208 to 183, despite the initial lower opening.

site_title: US bill would bar Google, Apple from hosting apps that accept China's digital yuan
summary: US Republican senators Tom Cotton, Marco Rubio, and Mike Braun have introduced a bill that would bar Apple and Google from hosting apps that allow payments to China's digital yuan, citing national security concerns. The bill aims to prevent Beijing from spying on Americans through the payment system. The move comes after WeChat and Alipay, popular Chinese payment apps, began supporting the digital currency. The Chinese Embassy in Washington has called the legislation "state bullying", but bipartisan support for stopping national security threats remains.

images.alt_text: A 3D printed Google logo is placed on the Apple Macbook in this illustration taken April 12, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

After unprecedented revenue growth last year, digital platforms including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Snap and Twitter now face a sobering reality as pandemic-driven advertising trends dissipate, according to an analyst report on Thursday.

site_title: Putin ties grain exports to demand that sanctions on Russia go
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has proposed lifting sanctions on Russia in exchange for facilitating grain and fertilizer exports to address global food shortages and rising prices. In a phone call with Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi, Putin stated that disruptions to food supplies are exacerbated by US and allied sanctions. However, the US and its allies are unlikely to agree to remove the sanctions, and a senior diplomat said there would be no quick lifting of penalties on Russia. The situation remains unresolved, with Ukraine accusing Russia of preventing grain exports and Russia denying the allegations.

images.alt_text: Shipbrokers said smaller tankers which are suited to shuttle cargoes out of Kozmino efficiently are now in high demand.

site_title: Grow opportunities for countries to work together to reduce risk of hostilities: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for countries in the Asia-Pacific region to work together to reduce the risk of hostilities. He suggested re-examining defense strategies and spending while building mutually beneficial economic cooperation to form an open and inclusive regional architecture. Lee also highlighted the importance of Japan's role in regional affairs, urging it to consider its past and contribute to regional security cooperation. He cautioned against an arms race and emphasized the need for collective security frameworks, engagement, and trust-building arrangements to manage potential conflicts.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida attend the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) launch event at Izumi Garden Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, May 23. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst

site_title: Instacart to slow hiring to focus on profitability ahead of IPO
summary: Instacart plans to slow hiring to focus on profitability ahead of its initial public offering (IPO). The company, a decade-old grocery delivery startup, has nearly doubled its engineering teams but will slow hiring to prioritize growth over expansion. This move comes as Instacart faces decelerated growth and a potential recession, following a 40% valuation cut to $24 billion in March. The company confidentially filed for an IPO earlier this month, with a possible listing as soon as this year.

site_title: Alibaba shares surge as sales beats boost sentiment
summary: Chinese tech shares surged on Friday after Alibaba and Baidu reported sales growth beating expectations, easing investor concerns about the economic impact of Covid-19 lockdowns. Alibaba's shares jumped 13% and Baidu's shares rose 13%, with the Hong Kong Hang Seng Tech Index gaining 4.9% and the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index rising 7.6%. Analysts expect a potential bottom in growth for China tech companies in the second quarter, driven by easing Covid restrictions and government support.

images.alt_text: Ant Group saw profit inch up in the 3 months to December, despite setbacks from regulatory overhauls taming the country’s fintech industry.
Alibaba's profit fell 59 per cent in the latest fiscal year, joining a number of tech firms to report lacklustre results following strict Covid-19 restrictions and a sector crackdown.
The Hang Seng Index surged 2.63 per cent, or 529.86 points, to 20,646.06.

site_title: Oil rises to 2-month high on tight supplies, EU seeks Russian crude ban
summary: Oil prices surged 3% to a 2-month high on Thursday, reaching $117.40 a barrel for Brent futures and $114.09 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude, driven by tight supply ahead of the US summer driving season. The European Union is also wrangling over plans to ban Russian crude imports due to the invasion of Ukraine, with Hungary holding out against the proposal. The US dollar's weakening and equities' rise also contributed to the price increase.

images.alt_text: Shareholders of ExxonMobil Corp and Chevron Corp on Wednesday voted in favour of the energy transition strategies proposed by the two largest US oil producers.
Oil prices rose on Wednesday.

site_title: Metro H2 profit drops 68.4% to S$5.4m
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 68.4% drop in net profit for the second half of 2022 to S$5.4 million, driven by lower revenue, impairment losses, and lower joint venture profits. Revenue declined 1.5% to S$59.7 million, with the group's bottomline also impacted by an impairment loss of S$36.3 million. The board has proposed a final dividend of 2 cents per share and a special dividend of 1 cent per share.

images.alt_text: Unwanted apartments are weighing on China's economy - and, by extension, dragging down growth around the world.
Metro to press on with diversification strategy, cautiously optimistic on outlook

site_title: Evergrande to sell project in eastern China for 1.35b yuan
summary: China Evergrande Group is selling the City Light Plaza project in Ningbo, eastern China, for 1.35 billion yuan (S$275.1 million) to shore up its finances. The embattled property developer, saddled with over $300 billion in liabilities, is struggling to repay suppliers and complete projects. The sale, announced on May 26, will transfer the project to Zhejiang Zhejian Real Estate Group and Zhejiang Construction Engineering Group, with Evergrande receiving proceeds to settle unpaid construction fees and general working capital. The sale is expected to post a gain of about 175 million yuan.

site_title: Big tech ad revenue growth to taper as pandemic bubble pops: analyst
summary: Digital platforms, including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Snap, and Twitter, are expected to see a decline in ad revenue growth due to the end of pandemic-driven advertising trends. Research firm MoffettNathanson cut its 2025 revenue estimates by double-digit percentages for the four companies, citing a decrease in e-commerce and an increase in corporate expenses. The analyst report estimates online advertising in the US will grow by 12.5% annually through 2025, down from previous estimates. This marks a sobering reality for companies that saw unprecedented revenue growth last year.

images.alt_text: The search giant is positioning itself as a kind of anti-Amazon, a free marketplace for merchants and  Amazon rivals that’s designed to get consumers more comfortable shopping with Google.
Mark Zuckerberg said he plans to invest heavily in his company's metaverse ambitions and that will mean losing "significant" amounts of money on the project in the next 3 to 5 years.

site_title: Gold heads for small weekly rise as dollar weakens
summary: Gold prices were little changed on Friday, but on track for a second weekly gain as the US dollar retreated from 20-year highs. Spot gold held at US$1,848.59 per ounce, with US gold futures unchanged at US$1,846.70. The dollar index steadied after a drop, making bullion less expensive for buyers holding other currencies. The US Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy tightening plan and higher short-term interest rates raised the opportunity cost of holding bullion, contributing to the metal's appeal.

images.alt_text: A piece of 1kg gold bar at Le Freeport on October 16, 2020.

site_title: US home sellers cutting prices hit highest level since 2019
summary: US home sellers are cutting prices at the highest level since 2019, signaling a slowdown in the housing market. According to Redfin, nearly one in 5 sellers dropped prices during the 4-week period ending May 22. This trend is attributed to higher mortgage rates and economic uncertainty, raising concerns that the US housing boom may have reached its limit. The market's intensity is plateauing, with time on market and sales above listing price also showing signs of deceleration.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Singtel, IHH, The Hour Glass
summary: OCBC Bank was hit with an additional capital requirement of S$330 million following its deficiencies in responding to spoofed SMS phishing scams in December 2021. Meanwhile, Singtel reported a 10-fold increase in net profit to S$994.5 million for the second half of 2022, driven by exceptional items. IHH Healthcare saw a 31.3% increase in net profit to RM493.3 million, while The Hour Glass posted a 74.7% increase in net profit to S$92.1 million. Metro Holdings, however, saw a 68.4% fall in net profit due to lower revenue and impairment losses.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma to sell 10% stake in digital healthtech unit to Metro for S$6m
summary: Hyphens Pharma has agreed to sell a 10% stake in its digital healthtech unit DocMed Technology to Metro Holdings for S$6 million. As part of the deal, DocMed will acquire Pan-Malayan Pharmaceuticals, transferring it to a wholly-owned subsidiary. The transaction values DocMed at S$60 million post-money. The deal represents a Series A round of funding for DocMed, with Metro as the lead investor.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB initiates 'add' on Hyphens Pharma with S$0.36 target price
Hyphens Pharma inks exclusive licensing deal with Favorex to commercialise biosimilar in Singapore, Malaysia, Philippines
Hyphens Pharma to acquire Novem companies for S$16.3 million

site_title: Relevance and impact of climate change on businesses in Singapore
summary: Climate change is increasingly relevant to businesses in Singapore, with investors favoring sustainable eco-friendly companies. However, many public-listed companies in Singapore do not identify climate change as a material factor to their businesses, and few have reporting frameworks to disclose climate-related impacts. To address this, companies must establish systematic processes to identify, manage, and implement clear measures to transform their business operations. This includes conducting materiality analysis, scenario analyses, and documenting progress in achieving climate-related targets. By doing so, businesses can mitigate climate-related risks and enhance their resilience and long-term growth.

images.alt_text: renewable, energy, environment

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday, STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, May 27, 2022, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.6% to 3,228.41. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 24, with Sembcorp Marine and Rex International seeing significant gains. Singtel reported a 10-fold increase in net profit for the second half of 2021, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC rose due to improved trading. The rally followed a strong performance from Wall Street stocks, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices gaining over 1%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
An additional capital requirement of S$330 million was imposed on OCBC.

site_title: CD Projekt's first-quarter profit more than doubles
summary: CD Projekt's first-quarter net profit more than doubled to 68.9 million zlotys, driven by a 112% increase in sales of its flagship "Cyberpunk 2077" game after months of bug fixes. The company's revenue rose 9% to 216 million zlotys, with most coming from Cyberpunk. Selling costs dropped 2%, but publishing costs rose 87%. The company's balance of cash and deposits increased by 107 million zlotys.

images.alt_text: Sony said on Thursday that it plans to ramp up production of its PlayStation 5 console as supply chain snarls ease.

site_title: Ethereum founder Buterin blasts DeFi model in Terra critique
summary: Ethereum founder Vitalik Buterin criticized the DeFi model after the Terra blockchain's implosion, stating that no investment can achieve 20% annual returns. The TerraUSD and LUNA stablecoins' collapse led to a $60 billion loss in Terra coins and a bear market. Buterin welcomes increased scrutiny of DeFi mechanisms, emphasizing the importance of evaluating their safety under extreme conditions and warning of risks like technical glitches. He suggests exploring viable mechanisms for automated stablecoins and defines them as decentralized, price-index tracking systems without asset custodians.

images.alt_text: Vitalik ButerinPhotographer: Chet Strange/Bloomberg

site_title: Hundreds stranded after ransomware attack on Indian airline
summary: Hundreds of Indian air travelers were stranded on planes after SpiceJet canceled or delayed flights due to an "attempted ransomware attack". The airline said it had contained and rectified the situation, but some flights were canceled due to night curfews. Passengers expressed frustration over lack of communication, with some waiting for up to 5 hours. Flight operations have since returned to normal, but an investigation into the incident has not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: Ransomware: To pay or not to pay

site_title: Singtel H2 net profit rises to S$994.5m; proposes final dividend of S$0.048
summary: Singtel reported a net profit of S$994.5 million for the second half of 2022, more than 10 times higher than the same period last year. Despite lower operating revenue, the company's exceptional items turned positive, driven by a net gain from the sale of shares in Australia Tower Network. The company expects to benefit from the recovery in international travel and sees positive momentum in other associates' operating markets. A final dividend of 4.8 cents per share has been proposed, bringing the group's ordinary dividends for FY2022 to 9.3 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Annabeth Leow
Both Singtel and the Mittal family are shareholders in Bharti Telecom, as well as own direct shares directly in Bharti Airtel.
The interest rate discounts for the revolving credit facility are linked to Optus’ reduction of its absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 25 per cent by 2025.
The SLB will carry a US dollar fixed coupon rate of 4.56 per cent per annum and mature on Apr 27, 2027.
Singtel signs MOUs with Telkom on regional data centres, fixed broadband business

site_title: EY evaluating strategic options to improve audit quality
summary: Ernst & Young (EY) is evaluating options to improve audit quality, according to a memo from CEO Carmine Di Sibio. The firm, along with other Big Four accounting firms, has faced criticism for a lack of independence. Di Sibio denied reports of plans to split its audit and advisory operations, stating the process is in its early stages. EY spokesperson confirmed the firm routinely evaluates strategic options, but no decisions have been made. The move aims to address concerns about audit quality and independence.

images.alt_text: HONG KONG'S accountant body said it failed to reach an accord to prolong an 11-year mutual recognition agreement (MRA) with the US amid a dispute over local qualifications.

In December, the SEC mandated that Chinese companies, such as Alibaba, listed on US stock exchanges must disclose whether they are owned or controlled by a government entity, and provide evidence of their auditing inspections.

site_title: Twitter shareholder lawsuit accuses Musk of 'market manipulation'
summary: A Twitter shareholder lawsuit accuses Elon Musk of manipulating the company's stock price to gain leverage in his $44 billion buyout bid. The lawsuit claims Musk tweeted and made statements to create doubt about the deal, driving down the stock price by $8 billion in valuation. Musk's bid is now facing uncertainty, with Twitter shareholders seeking class-action status and damages. The lawsuit alleges Musk's actions were intended to get a cheaper price or back out of the deal without penalty, violating securities laws.

images.alt_text: The new structure could reduce the risk of the deal for both Musk and his lenders, particularly given the recent slide in Tesla’s stock price.

site_title: Securing a sustainable future
summary: DBS Bank emphasizes the importance of supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in achieving a sustainable future. The bank has committed to aligning its lending portfolio with net-zero emissions by 2050 and has made significant progress in sustainable financing, with S$39.4 billion in committed sustainable financing transactions to date. To translate climate pledges into action, DBS is also focusing on transition finance, supporting "brown" business activities like steel and cement production to become less polluting. The bank aims to bring everyone on board, including SMEs, to tackle climate and social challenges in unity.

images.alt_text: Together in partnership with the government, SBF and industry partners, SMEs can seize new green business opportunities while playing a part in Singapore’s net-zero transition.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher extending Wall Street rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, May 27, 2022, as investors took heart from Wall Street rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.29% to 26,948.51, while the Topix index gained 1.06% to 1,897.53. The positive start follows recent Wall Street gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Inflation in Japan's capital stays elevated as price pressures broaden
summary: Japan's capital, Tokyo, saw its core consumer prices rise 1.9% in May from a year earlier, matching the previous month's 7-year peak, indicating broadening fuel-driven inflationary pressures. This pace is in line with the central bank's 2% target and suggests price growth will hover around this level for much of the year, driven by rising raw material costs.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians wearing protective face masks, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, are seen at a shopping district in Osaka, Japan, in this photo taken by Kyodo April 7, 2021. Mandatory credit Kyodo/via REUTERS
Japan Nuclear Fuel's Rokkasho reprocessing plant in Rokkasho Village, Aomori Prefecture, Japan.

site_title: Sustainability matters for all businesses
summary: Singapore's global businesses must prioritize sustainability to mitigate climate risks and maintain long-term growth. The Singapore Green Plan 2030 aims to reduce carbon and waste, promote sustainable living, and transition to a green economy. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can leverage sustainability opportunities, but face challenges such as insufficient resources and expertise. Adopting sustainable practices makes economic sense in the long run, with benefits exceeding initial costs. Governments and organizations are supporting SMEs through various initiatives, including training programs, funding schemes, and collaboration opportunities.

images.alt_text: By integrating their sustainability ambitions into their digitalisation efforts, enterprises can make significant strides in the fight against climate change, says Tata Communications's Amitabh Sarkar.

site_title: Dell's sales top estimates on strong office pc growth
summary: Dell Technologies reported a 16% increase in quarterly revenue to $26.1 billion, beating analyst estimates, driven by strong demand for business PCs and networking services. Sales of commercial PCs rose 22% to $12 billion, while revenue from the Infrastructure Solutions Group increased 16%. Despite a decline in personal computer shipments across the industry, Dell's global shipments grew 6.1% in the quarter. The company attributed the growth to hybrid work and the return to offices, creating a need for new desktop machines.

images.alt_text: Lenovo Group's profit beat market estimates after the world's biggest personal computer maker widened its lead over longtime rival HP.

site_title: Banks are crucial in ‘greening’ entire value chains in transport and food sectors
summary: Banks play a crucial role in "greening" entire value chains in transport and food sectors, supporting companies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and transitioning to sustainable operations. Banks can help unlock capital for sustainable financing, enabling large companies to adopt sustainable solutions and positively impacting small and mid-sized firms and consumer products. The transport sector, particularly electric vehicle (EV) adoption, and food ecosystem require holistic approaches, with banks working with solution providers, innovators, and regulators to create sustainable value chains. By expanding sustainable finance coverage and stepping up partnerships, banks can drive synergy in sustainable value chains and help create a better world.

images.alt_text: Sales of electric cars accelerated last year but the availability of critical raw materials such as lithium risked slowing the sector's growth, a report warned Monday.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall to 5.1% in biggest drop since April 2020
summary: US mortgage rates dropped to 5.10% for a 30-year loan, the biggest decline since April 2020, according to Freddie Mac. This marks a slight reprieve for homebuyers from this year's surge in borrowing costs. However, rates remain above the 3.11% level at the end of last year, and the housing market continues to slow, with new home sales and existing home transactions falling. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat inflation are contributing to affordability concerns.

site_title: IMF says good progress made studying Sri Lanka economy situation
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has made "good progress" in analyzing Sri Lanka's economic situation and identifying policy priorities, but cautions that a loan would require adequate assurances on debt sustainability. Discussions with Sri Lanka focus on restoring fiscal sustainability, protecting vulnerable groups, and structural reforms to enhance growth. Sri Lanka seeks a bailout program, which would also pave the way for assistance from neighboring countries, including India, Japan, and China.

site_title: Making waves in sustainable travel
summary: Royal Caribbean Group, a leading cruise company, is making strides towards achieving its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) goals through innovative sustainability efforts. The company has reduced energy use among its 63 ships by 20% through hull configurations and heat waste recovery technology, and has implemented emission purification systems to remove 98% of sulfur dioxide emissions. Royal Caribbean aims to achieve net zero emissions by 2050 and has set targets to reduce carbon emissions, eliminate single-use plastics, and source sustainable seafood. The company has also partnered with the World Wildlife Fund to set ambitious sustainability targets.

site_title: Pound touches 3-week high, UK household support plan in place
summary: The British pound briefly reached a 3-week high on Thursday, May 26, due to the UK government's measures to alleviate the cost of living crisis, including a 25% windfall tax on oil and gas producers' profits and a £15 billion support package for households. The government's support is seen as supporting the economy in the short term, easing pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates. Sterling rebounded this week, with a 0.1% decrease at US$1.2567, as analysts noted the measures could ease pressure on the BOE.

site_title: Committed to cooling the Earth
summary: Mitsubishi Electric Asia, a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Electric Group, is committed to reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives. The company has integrated the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals into its management strategy and aims to achieve its sustainability goals by 2050. Mitsubishi Electric Asia offers energy-efficient air conditioning systems, reduces energy consumption in its operations, and promotes eco-friendly causes through partnerships and employee activities. The company has received awards for its sustainability efforts, including the BCA Green Mark Platinum Award and the Community In Bloom Silver Category Award.

site_title: US: Stocks rally for second straight day
summary: US stocks rallied for a second consecutive day, driven by strong results from retailers and investor bargain-hunting. Major indices posted rare back-to-back gains in 2022, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging towards fresh records. Additionally, moves by Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways to lift revenue forecasts boosted consumer sentiment. The momentum was also fueled by the strong performance of Singapore's stock market, which rose 0.4% on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished a choppy session higher as investors took an optimistic view of Federal Reserve minutes.

site_title: Alibaba full-year profit slumps nearly 60% on tech crackdown, Covid
summary: Alibaba's profit slumped 59% in the latest fiscal year due to strict Covid-19 restrictions and a sector crackdown. The Chinese e-commerce giant cited "macro challenges" impacting supply chains and consumer sentiment. For the January-March quarter, Alibaba reported a loss of 16.2 billion yuan, marking a fourth-straight quarterly decline. The company will not provide forward-looking financial guidance due to Covid risks.

site_title: Propertyguru’s Q1 FY2022 revenue rises as losses grow on business combination costs
summary: PropertyGuru's Q1 FY2022 revenue rose 42% to S$28.2 million, driven by momentum in its marketplaces, despite a 1183% increase in losses to S$120.3 million due to business combination costs. Revenue growth was seen in Malaysia (192% to S$5.4 million), Vietnam (18.6% to S$5.1 million), and Singapore (23.8% to S$15 million). Adjusted Ebitda turned positive to S$884,000, with the company reaffirming its full-year guidance of 44% year-on-year revenue growth and return to positive adjusted Ebitda.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
PropertyGuru closes at US$8.46, down 1.7% on its NYSE debut
PropertyGuru to begin trading on NYSE on Mar 18
PropertyGuru grows FY2021 revenue by 22.7% to S$100.7m

site_title:
Indonesia’s content creator platforms poised for sharp
growth
summary: Indonesia's content creator platforms are poised for sharp growth, driven by the country's large young population and increasing demand for online content. BintangGO and KaryaKarsa, two platforms that connect fans with influencers and content creators, have already seen significant success, with BintangGO having 10,000 influencers and KaryaKarsa having 99,000 registered creators. The platforms earn between 5-25% of the income earned from creators, and are expected to double in number over the next 5 years, driven by the growing demand for scriptwriters for local movies and TV shows.

images.alt_text: The fresh funds will be used for the launch of new products and services, technology development, hiring talent and strengthening the company’s financial programmes to create investment awareness in the country.

site_title: How sustainability can help companies to stay relevant and capture opportunities
summary: Sustainability is gaining momentum globally, driving demand for eco-friendly products and services. Companies can benefit from incorporating sustainability into their businesses, achieving cost savings, and attracting talent. Governments are also stepping up efforts to drive sustainability, with Singapore launching the Singapore Green Plan 2030. Several government initiatives aim to reduce packaging waste and increase solar deployment. Companies like Containers Printers, Pure Senses, and Barghest Building Performance have successfully implemented sustainability measures, resulting in energy savings and reduced carbon emissions. To succeed, enterprises must understand key sustainability concepts, develop comprehensive sustainability plans, and strengthen their knowledge and resources.

images.alt_text: ST20210519_202140020832 Yong Li Xuan/ glretail20/ Rent relief issues among retailers are cropping up again in the wake of Phase 2 (HA), as government support in the form of JSS is drying up soon, and revenues are again decimated by a drastic drop in traffic due to tighter safe distancing measures. Shops like Yankee Candle have voluntarily shut down one of their shops at Jem because of the jump in unlinked community cases there.
Japan's unemployment rate fell while factory output rose for the first time in four months in August - a sign the world's third-largest economy is on a path of gradual recovery.
KKR's co-heas of global impact Robert Antablin said that its impact fund typically looks to invest in small-cap businesses that already have a proven solution that is commercially successful.

site_title: US pending home sales dive to 2-year low in April
summary: US pending home sales dropped to a 2-year low in April, falling 3.9% to 99.3, as rising mortgage rates and higher prices deter demand for housing. This marks the sixth consecutive monthly decline and the lowest level since April 2020. Economists had forecast a 2% decline, but pending sales dropped 9.1% year-over-year. The increase in mortgage rates, averaging 5.25%, and steep home prices have raised costs by over 40%.

images.alt_text: US new home sales plunged 16.6 per cent in April, even as prices continued to climb, according to government data released on Tuesday (May 24).

site_title: Microsoft to slow hiring in Windows, Office, Teams groups
summary: Microsoft plans to slow hiring in its Windows, Office, and Teams groups due to global economic uncertainty, realigning staffing priorities as it approaches a new fiscal year. New hires must be approved by executive vice president Rajesh Jha and his leadership team. Despite the slowdown, the company will continue to hire overall and focus on making the right hires in the right places. This move follows similar steps by other big tech companies, including Nvidia and Meta Platforms, amid economic volatility.

site_title: Europe: Retailers lift stocks but growth worries persist
summary: European markets rose on Thursday, with the retail sector leading the charge, as Britain revealed new stimulus plans and the US Federal Reserve stuck to its monetary policy tightening script. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.8% higher, with retailers up 4.7% and luxury stocks also gaining. However, sentiment remained fragile due to lingering worries about slowing economic growth from central bank tightening. The European Central Bank is expected to begin a hiking cycle in July, adding to market volatility.

images.alt_text: EUROPEAN stock markets rose slightly at the open on Thursday (May 26) after Tokyo closed lower, as traders assess chances of a global recession in the wake of runaway inflation.
European shares rose on Wednesday, lifted by resource-linked stocks and banks.

site_title: Get on the sustainability agenda, or go out of business
summary: Singapore ranks behind other markets such as Australia, Taiwan, and Thailand in prioritizing sustainability, with only 20% of listed companies linking top executive remuneration to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors. The Economist Intelligence Unit gave Singapore a 'B' grade in its ESG country ratings, citing gaps in decarbonization, environmental stewardship, and labor conditions. Experts say the country needs to close these gaps and incorporate sustainability into its business plans to avoid losing revenue and opportunities.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

By integrating their sustainability ambitions into their digitalisation efforts, enterprises can make significant strides in the fight against climate change, says Tata Communications's Amitabh Sarkar.

Incorporating ESG metrics into executive remuneration is not a simple matter of merely selecting some measures and linking them to executive remuneration; ESG must be integrated into strategies, policies and practices of a company, says Prof Mak Yuen Teen
Buying shares of ExxonMobil in the secondary market does not benefit Exxon in any way. Subscribing to a new bond or a new share issuance, however, does benefit Exxon.

site_title: Biden to receive Korean boy band BTS at White House
summary: US President Joe Biden will receive K-pop group BTS at the White House on May 31 as part of events celebrating Asian-Americans and combating anti-Asian hate crimes. The move comes amid growing anti-Asian sentiment in the US during the pandemic. BTS, known for their message of hope and positivity, are seen as youth ambassadors who can promote Asian inclusion and representation. This marks the latest in Biden's efforts to engage with young people and promote social issues, following previous meetings with pop singer Olivia Rodrigo and the Jonas Brothers.

site_title: UK prosecutors charge actor Kevin Spacey with sex crimes
summary: UK prosecutors have charged actor Kevin Spacey with 4 counts of sexual assault against 3 men, including causing a person to engage in penetrative sexual activity without consent. The charges follow a review of evidence gathered by the Metropolitan Police in London, which investigated allegations of inappropriate conduct by Spacey at the Old Vic theatre between 1995 and 2013. Spacey, 62, has previously denied all accusations of misconduct. This marks the latest development in the ongoing case, which began in 2017 when the theatre received 20 allegations of misconduct.

images.alt_text: Kevin Spacey to pay US$31m after losing arbitration case with makers of House of Cards

site_title: Chipmaker Broadcom to buy VMware for US$61b
summary: Broadcom has agreed to purchase cloud computing firm VMware in a $61 billion deal, expanding the chipmaker's software offerings. The cash and stock deal will merge Broadcom's software assets into VMware's, providing customers with greater choice and flexibility in building and managing applications. Broadcom, led by CEO Hock Tan, has grown through acquisitions, with revenues of $27.5 billion in fiscal 2021. The deal is seen as a strategic move to boost Broadcom's software offerings and reduce dependence on semiconductor revenues amid concerns of a "chip cycle peaking."

site_title: US dollar edges back towards one-month low
summary: The US dollar edged back towards a 1-month low on May 26, as minutes from the Federal Reserve's May meeting showed few surprises, with most participants favouring additional 50 basis point rate hikes at the June and July meetings. The US dollar index fell 0.2% to 101.83, while the euro rose 0.35% to $1.0716. The Fed is likely to stay the course for now, but keep its options open for policy choices after July, allowing for a range of tightening options.

images.alt_text: The US dollar snapped a two-day losing streak on Wednesday as Treasury yields paused recent falls, its gain taking the edge off the euro as well as the kiwi dollar.

site_title: Medtronic posts downbeat results on supply chain issues, China restrictions
summary: Medtronic's quarterly revenue and profit missed market estimates due to supply-chain challenges and Covid-19 restrictions in China, particularly affecting its surgical instruments unit. Revenue fell 5% and sales of surgical instruments in China declined in the mid-teens. The company expects adjusted earnings for 2023 to be below analysts' estimates, citing near-term pressure from supply chain, inflation, and foreign exchange. Medtronic also announced plans to form a new, independent kidney care-focused medical device company.

images.alt_text: Global healthcare still attractive in 2022

site_title: Making supply chain central to sustainability plans
summary: Companies are under increasing pressure to prioritize supply chain sustainability as consumers, regulators, and investors demand greener growth. Governments are driving regulations, such as Singapore's carbon tax, to encourage sustainable business practices. To build a more sustainable supply chain, companies should focus on three key areas: understanding their entire value chain, ensuring sustainable sourcing, and improving supply chain traceability and visibility. Overcoming challenges, including leadership buy-in and knowledge gaps, is crucial for successful transformation. By putting supply chain sustainability central to their plans, organizations can reduce costs, increase productivity, and improve societal outcomes.

images.alt_text: FILE — Shipping containers stacked high on docks are sorted and unloaded onto trucks at the Port of Los Angeles in San Pedro, California, March 23, 2022. As the network that ferries goods around the world readjusts to pandemic supply chains, products may not be as cheap and easily available as before. (Coley Brown/The New York Times)

site_title: US jobless claims fall more than forecast in tight labour  market
summary: US jobless claims fell by 8,000 to 210,000 in the week ended May 21, exceeding forecast. This decline underscores a persistently tight labor market, with initial claims remaining at a historically low level. Continuing claims rose to 1.35 million. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes may slow hiring or lead to layoffs later this year. The drop in claims may assuage concerns of a cooling labor market, ahead of the government's May jobs report, which is forecast to show a drop in the unemployment rate.

images.alt_text: Applications for US state unemployment insurance have unexpectedly risen last week to the highest level since January.

site_title: WeWork appoints Andre Fernandez as CFO
summary: WeWork appoints Andre Fernandez as its new chief financial officer (CFO), replacing Benjamin Dunham. Fernandez, previously CFO at NCR, will assume the role on June 10. The company reported a 28% increase in revenue to $765 million, boosted by the hybrid-work model. WeWork reaffirmed its forecasts and tightened its revenue outlook for the current quarter to $800-$825 million. The appointment comes as companies opt for hybrid-work arrangements to be more cost-effective in a high-inflation environment.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open higher on earnings optimism
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by strong profit forecasts from companies like Macy's and data showing the US economy contracted in the first quarter, alleviating concerns about aggressive rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 127.89 points, or 0.40%, to 32,248.17, while the S&P 500 opened 5.87 points higher, or 0.15%, at 3,984.60.

site_title: Redesigning hair care for a sustainable future
summary: Lynn Tan, founder of THE POWDER SHAMPOO, has created a sustainable, plastic-free, vegan powder shampoo that foams and lathers when mixed with water. The product, launched in April 2022, helps save water and reduces carbon footprint by eliminating the need for single-use plastic packaging. Tan's goal is to create a ripple effect of change in the beauty industry, reducing plastic pollution and promoting eco-friendliness. The product incorporates essential oils, is vegan and animal cruelty-free, and is available in 100g refill packs to reduce waste.

site_title: Philippines' Marcos signals continuity ahead with new economic team
summary: Philippines President-elect Ferdinand Marcos has signaled continuity in economic policy by appointing familiar faces to his cabinet. He chose central bank chief Benjamin Diokno as finance minister and monetary board member Felipe Medalla as central bank governor. The appointments aim to tackle inflation and joblessness, with Marcos pledging to slash rice prices and maintain economic growth. Marcos inherits a strong economy with manageable debt and record-high foreign reserves, but faces a delicate balancing act to sustain economic recovery and control rising inflation.

images.alt_text: Marcos, who takes office on Jun 30, said he would resist challenges from China and stick to the 2016 ruling of an international arbitration court that made clear the Philippines’ economic entitlements.
THE Philippine Parliament on Wednesday (May 25) proclaimed Ferdinand Marcos as the country's 17th president, following his landslide victory in the May 9 polls.

site_title: Making a material difference to the environment
summary: BR Metals, a Singapore-based company, is expanding its precious metals recovery capabilities to include gold and silver recovery as part of its commitment to sustainability. The company aims to create a circular economy by recovering metals from scrap sources and reintroducing them into the supply chain. With a focus on reducing the environmental impact of mining activities, BR Metals has successfully applied for 5 patents and received ISO 14100 and 14001 certifications. The company's expansion is part of its goal to act in an ethical, transparent, and responsible way, and to build a company that operates sustainably and gives back to the environment and society.

site_title: Boustead FY22 earnings fall 73% on absence of one-off gain; proposes final dividend of 2.5 cents per share
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 73% drop in FY2022 earnings to S$30.6 million due to the absence of one-off gain from property sales. Revenue fell 8% to S$631.8 million, mainly impacted by inflationary pressures and geopolitical events. The company expects to be profitable for FY2023, with a proposed final dividend of 2.5 cents per share. Despite challenges, Boustead's geospatial division delivered steady results, and the company will step up efforts to address the challenges faced by its Healthcare division.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Boustead Singapore H1 profit dips 2%, revenue up as real estate business recovers
Boustead Singapore's geospatial business potential worth watching for investors

site_title: Southwest raises Q2 revenue forecast on travel demand
summary: Southwest Airlines raised its Q2 operating revenue forecast due to strong travel demand, putting US carriers on a path to recovery from pandemic lows. The airline reported strong load factors and an increase in bookings for summer travel. As a result, shares rose nearly 3% before the market opened. This upbeat outlook from Southwest follows a similar announcement from Delta Air Lines, which also lifted shares with its positive outlook on travel demand.

images.alt_text: Paris (with its landmark Eiffel Tower, above) is traditionally one of the most-visited cities in the world and, before Covid, tourism-related spending represented more than 7 per cent of France’s economy, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development noted.

site_title: Powering the transition to clean energy
summary: G8 Subsea, a Singapore-based renewable energy company, is accelerating the world's low-carbon transition by developing offshore wind and floating solar technologies. With a global strategy, the company has successfully completed projects in South Korea, Indonesia, and Malaysia, and has set up a joint venture in West Africa to construct a 65MW floating solar plant. G8's innovative solutions, including subsea cables and proprietary technologies, aim to overcome challenges in renewable energy development, particularly in urban areas. The company plans to go public on the NASDAQ exchange in 2023, further solidifying its position as a leading player in the renewable energy space.

images.alt_text: Gerald Tan (centre), founder and managing director of G8 with his staff.

site_title: Starting right, right from the start
summary: Royal Golden Eagle (RGE) Group, a Singapore-based conglomerate, is leveraging its position as a market leader in sustainable raw materials to create a low-carbon future. With over US$25 billion in assets and 60,000 employees, RGE produces renewable natural fibres, edible oils, and clean natural gas used in various consumer products. The company has set 2030 targets to achieve zero tolerance for deforestation, reduce emissions by 30-50%, and create a positive impact on biodiversity and conservation. RGE's sustainability initiatives include transitioning to renewable energy, investing in technology, and supporting sustainable fashion and conservation efforts.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The aerospace segment expanded 24.2% in the past day, driven by higher production of aircraft parts and maintenance, repair, and overhaul jobs from commercial airlines due to lifted border restrictions globally.

images.alt_text: Singapore's skyline on Apr 28, 2022.

site_title: Japan to start reopening to foreign tourists from Jun 10
summary: Japan is set to reopen to foreign tourists starting June 10, allowing package-tourists from overseas, after a 2-year ban as part of the country's virus control programme. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced the move, citing the importance of active exchanges between people for the economy and society. Preparations for international flights will begin at New Chitose airport in Hokkaido and Naha airport in Okinawa in June.

images.alt_text: Japan said on Tuesday it would start conducting “test tourism” in the form of limited package tours in May.

site_title: Jack Ma’s Ant ekes out profit rise as fintech overhaul advances
summary: Ant Group, a fintech company led by billionaire Jack Ma, reported a 1.3% increase in profit for its December quarter, reaching an estimated 22.05 billion yuan. The profit gain comes despite regulatory setbacks in China's fintech industry, which has led to a crackdown on tech giants. As part of the restructuring, Ant has increased its capital base to 35 billion yuan and built firewalls to separate its services. The company's assets under management have dropped 15% from a year earlier.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.59 points to 1,541.15, closing higher on Thursday. Volume was 2.894 billion lots worth RM1.972 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 557 to 406.

site_title: Applications open for Emerging Enterprise Award 2022, which returns for 15th year
summary: Applications are now open for the Emerging Enterprise Award 2022, a 15th-year recognition of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that have navigated challenging economic circumstances. The award, jointly organised by The Business Times and OCBC Bank, celebrates businesses with an enterprising mindset and innovative spirit. The theme "Breaking the Mould, Empowering the Bold" aims to recognise SMEs that have demonstrated business innovation, resilience, and excellence. Applications close on July 8, with 15 businesses to be shortlisted and announced in November, offering prizes including interest-free loans, business consultancy, and innovation vouchers.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

The Emerging Enterprise Award 2021 jointly presented by OCBC and The Business Times. G8 Subsea Pte Ltd, KoolLogix Pte Ltd & Nanosun Pte Ltd are the top three winners of Emerging Enterprise Awards 2021 (EE2021) (from left) : CK Cheong, CEO, KoolLogix; Gerald Tan, Managing Director, G8 Subsea and Darren Sun, Chairman, NanoSun.
G8 Subsea, KoolLogix and Nanosun win top accolades at Emerging Enterprise Awards

site_title: Back to snow: World Economic Forum reverts to January for 2023 gathering
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) will revert to its traditional January schedule for its 2023 annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, after moving to the spring in 2022 due to the pandemic. The event, scheduled for January 15-20, 2023, aims to bring together global leaders to discuss pressing issues despite public mistrust of the WEF, with a recent survey showing nearly 4 out of 10 respondents distrust the organization.

site_title: UK slaps 25% windfall tax on profits of oil and gas companies
summary: The UK government will impose a 25% windfall tax on oil and gas companies such as BP to fund at least £5 billion (S$8.7 billion) in support for Britons facing a cost-of-living crisis. The tax, described as "temporary" and "targeted," comes amid intense pressure to ease record living standards and follows a Labour Party proposal. The move is seen as a U-turn by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, who had previously opposed a special levy on energy firms. The tax aims to mitigate the impact of a record energy price cap rise to £2,800 in October.

images.alt_text: Britain wants to bolster London’s attractiveness as a global location for listings as it continues to trail New York in bringing tech companies to the market, and faces added competition from Amsterdam since Brexit.

BRITAIN set out plans to bolster airlines and airports roiled by the coronavirus pandemic, while emphasising that growth must be in line with steps to slash carbon emissions and promising a charter for traveller rights.

site_title: Hong Kong ends mutual accounting recognition accord with US
summary: Hong Kong's accountant body, the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants (HKICPA), failed to reach an accord with the US to prolong the 11-year mutual recognition agreement (MRA) due to a dispute over local qualifications. The agreement, which allows certified accountants to practice in each other's markets, will expire at the end of this year. The Hong Kong government had sought to waive the requirement for one year of local experience in favor of recognizing audit experience in the US, but the US International Qualifications Appraisal Board (IQAB) rejected this proposal.

site_title: Shanghai prepares to reopen, but soaring prices, longer-term supply-chain instability expected
summary: Shanghai is slowly reopening after a 2-month lockdown, but logistics providers expect soaring container prices that could last up to 8 weeks. Prices have skyrocketed by up to 5 times in the past 2 years, and a backlog of containers remains. The reopening coincides with peak season, and alternative port options like Ningbo are expected to ease congestion in 6-8 weeks. However, trucking demand is expected to spike, and regulations have hindered the pickup and delivery of cargo, making sourcing for drivers a challenge.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Daily container throughput - a measure of cargo handling activity - at Shanghai port has rebounded to 95.3 per cent of the normal level, Ministry of Transport official Li Huaqiang said Thursday (May 26), according to Chinese state media.

site_title: IHH Healthcare reports 31.3% rise in Q1 profit on growth in core operations, Covid-19 services rendered
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysian hospital group, reported a 31.3% increase in net profit for the first quarter ended March 31, to RM493.3 million (S$154.9 million), driven by growth from core operations and Covid-19 services. Revenue grew 5.5% to RM4.16 billion, while earnings per share rose to 5.36 sen. The company attributed the growth to recovery from local patient revenue and the ramp-up of operations at Gleneagles Hong Kong Hospital. However, the growth was dampened by the effects of the disposal of Continental Hospitals and the temporary closure of clinics in China.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
RHB believes that the stronger demand for treatments and digital developments may lift earnings of Asean healthcare players.

Back Row (L-R): Dr. Tan Aik Hau (RMA), Dr. Chan Kwok Wai, Adrian (RMA), Dr. Constance Lo (RMA), Dr. Chew Huck Chin (RMA), Dr. Kenneth Chan (RMA), Dr. Ng Choon Yong Alvin (TRP), Dr. Yip Hwee Seng (TRP), Dr Yang Tze Yi Steve (TRP), , Dr. John Law Lik Muk (TRP), Ms. Joelle Lee (Chief Operating Officer, OUELH)
