site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.27% on May 26, overshadowed by Premier Li Keqiang's warning on China's economy, despite minutes indicating a less hawkish Federal Reserve. The Hang Seng Index fell to 20,116.20, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.50% to 3,123.11.

site_title: Hwa Hong appoints IFA for privatisation offer despite SIAS advice to find an independent reviewer first
summary: Hwa Hong appointed Provenance Capital as its independent financial adviser (IFA) to assess a privatisation offer by Sanjuro United, despite receiving a notice from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) to first address a board compliance issue. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) (Sias) had advised the board to "expeditiously comply" with the notice before making the IFA appointment.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
pixgeneric/ generic picture of SGX Centre along Shenton Way ,  taken on 24 Feb 2022.

site_title: MAS slaps additional S$330m capital requirement on OCBC over its response to SMS scams
summary: MAS has imposed an additional S$330 million capital requirement on OCBC Bank due to its deficiencies in responding to a wave of spoofed SMS phishing scams in December 2021. The bank has strengthened its controls and implemented additional measures, but MAS will review the requirement when it is satisfied that deficiencies have been addressed. The additional capital requirement translates to a 0.21 percentage point impact on OCBC's capital ratios, with no impact on the bank's dividend policy.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Fake SMS scams: Do banks and telcos have a duty of care to customers?
Banks, customers to share scam losses; framework to seek views: Wong
Banks imposing extra security measures after recent SMS scams; OCBC will make 'full goodwill payouts'

site_title: Get ready for reverse currency wars
summary: The US dollar has surged 12% against the euro over the past year, approaching parity, and is expected to continue its upward trend, potentially leading to "reverse currency wars" where countries compete to strengthen their currencies to combat inflation. This trend could disproportionately affect emerging and developing economies with substantial dollar-denominated debts, exacerbating debt crises. The article suggests that the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate increases are attracting capital inflows, strengthening the dollar, and forcing up interest rates internationally.

images.alt_text: STERLING climbed to a 2-week high against a weaker US dollar on Thursday (May 19), winning a respite for now from the soaring inflation and murky growth outlook that has weighed on sentiment towards the British currency.

site_title: Apple to keep iPhone production flat as market grows tougher
summary: Apple plans to maintain iPhone production at around 220 million units in 2022, roughly the same as last year, amid a challenging market due to inflation, the war in Ukraine, and supply-chain issues. Despite forecasts of a 2% contraction in smartphone shipments, Apple expects resilient demand from its wealthier customer base and a strong software and services ecosystem. The company is preparing for an expected major iPhone update in the autumn, which may boost sales.

images.alt_text: APPLE has told its suppliers to speed up iPhone development after China's strict Covid-19 lockdowns hampered schedule for at least one of the new phones, Nikkei reported on Wednesday (May 25), citing multiple sources with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Chinese tech firms forced into 'blood listings' as capital dries up
summary: Chinese tech start-ups are listing shares publicly in China at lower valuations, known as "blood listings," amid a drying up of capital. Start-ups like CloudWalk Technology, which debuted in Shanghai with a 29% valuation cut, are taking this route. This move is a result of frothy tech markets and disruptions from COVID-19 restrictions, unlike other tech sector woes caused by rising interest rates. Venture capitalists may face losses from late funding rounds.

site_title: Incoming Philippines central bank governor sees no need to rush rate hikes
summary: Incoming Philippines central bank governor Felipe Medalla says there's no need to rush raising interest rates to combat inflation, which is mainly driven by higher import costs. The BSP has room to tighten monetary policy, but Medalla believes growth is already on solid footing. The central bank raised interest rates by 25 basis points for the first time in over 3 years in May. Medalla will start his term on July 1 and serve out the rest of the current governor's term, which ends in July 2023.

site_title: Baidu’s sales beat estimates as AI push offsets China slowdown
summary: Baidu has reported a surprise 1% increase in revenue to 28.4 billion yuan for the first quarter of 2022, driven by expansion in cloud computing and autonomous driving despite weak advertising sales in China. The company's net loss was 885 million yuan, exceeding analyst estimates. Baidu is shifting its focus from online marketing to hard-tech services, including AI technology, to offset the impact of China's weakening economy and Covid lockdowns on advertising spending. The company plans to launch a fully driverless ride-hailing platform in 2023 and raise $300 million in funding for its AI chip spin-off.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Men interact with a Baidu AI robot near the company logo at its headquarters in Beijing, China April 23, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Poignant artworks ponder history of Australia
summary: National Gallery Singapore has unveiled a major survey of Australia's First Peoples art, titled "Ever Present: First Peoples Art Of Australia." The exhibition, the largest to travel to Asia, features powerful and haunting artworks that commemorate the vitality and resilience of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, while also memorializing the losses incurred through European colonization. The show includes notable artworks such as "Seven Sisters."

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

hysydney20 - At the Cutaway, Australia design studio Cave Urban – comprising artists, architects and sculptors – has created a large bamboo installation that swirls and snakes across the ceiling like a winding river.

site_title: Taiwan raids Chinese firms in latest crackdown on chip engineer-poaching
summary: Taiwan authorities raided 10 Chinese companies suspected of poaching chip engineers and tech talent, in a crackdown to protect its chip supremacy. The raids, conducted by the island's Investigation Bureau, targeted integrated circuit design firms and electronics parts makers. Nearly 70 people have been summoned for questioning, and this is the latest in a campaign to counter illegal poaching by Chinese companies. Taiwan sees this as a threat to its chip expertise and national security, and has launched investigations into around 100 Chinese companies suspected of similar activities.

site_title: Les Amis launches Magnum Room
summary: Les Amis, a 3-Michelin-starred restaurant, has launched its Magnum Room, a themed private dining space showcasing over 100 magnum bottles from its extensive wine list. The room, designed by Kay Ngee Tan, features a dramatic "fresco" ceiling and hand-carved marble table. The space aims to offer a unique experience for guests, with the objective of keeping things interesting and enticed, according to director Sebastien Lepinoy. The Magnum Room is part of Les Amis' efforts to create new dining experiences, following the introduction of its Cheese & Caviar Room last year.

images.alt_text: Les Amis group appoints new CEO

site_title: A hit and a miss at SIFA’s opening weekend
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) 2022 kicked off with a hit, "Mepaan," a concert by the Singapore Chinese Orchestra and Tuyang Initiative, which featured traditional Dayak instruments and vocals. In contrast, "Ceremonial Enactments," a show with multiple artists, was a disappointment due to its lack of an overarching vision and repetitive performances. The festival continues until June 5, 2022.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

hysifa27 - Riduan Zalani's segment on Malay weddings in Ceremonial Enactments.

Credit: Crispian Chan/Tuckys Photography
Conditions for usage: Free with credit
put into BT EL

site_title: Eyewear unicorn Lenskart unit Neso Brands raises US$100m, appoints new CEO
summary: Neso Brands, a Singapore-based eyewear house owned by Indian direct-to-consumer unicorn Lenskart, has raised over US$100 million in funding. The startup aims to partner and invest in consumer eyewear brands globally, leveraging synergies across the Lenskart group and accelerating international expansion. Neso Brands has appointed Bjorn Bergstrom as its founding CEO, bringing experience from Swedish fashion brand NA-KD and venture capital investing. The funding will enable Neso Brands to scale the eyewear brands of the future through shared resources in technology, manufacturing, and distribution.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Disruption key to growth for Lenskart in Indonesia

Meta Platforms's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, on Wednesday teased a new smart glasses project with EssilorLuxottica, posting a photo of the eyewear company's chairman sporting a prototype of a neural interface wristband - designed for directing other devices.
Try on eyewear virtually with Lenskart; startup sees expansion in South-east Asia this year

site_title: Singapore stocks rebound following Wall Street advance; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 0.9% to 3,209.18 points, tracking Wall Street gains and bucking regional downward trends. Singtel led the gain, rising 3.4% after reports of potential talks with Bharti Airtel's chairman on a sale of a part of its Indian holding. All three local banks ended higher, while Mapletree Commercial Trust fell 1.1%. Improved risk sentiment on Wall Street, following the Federal Reserve's May policy meeting, may have provided some relief, according to market strategist Yeap Jun Rong.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Both Singtel and the Mittal family are shareholders in Bharti Telecom, as well as own direct shares directly in Bharti Airtel.

Asian markets were mixed Thursday as minutes indicating a less hawkish Fed were offset by China's premier warning that the world's number 2 economy was in some ways worse off now than during the early days of the pandemic.
Wall Street stocks finished a choppy session higher as investors took an optimistic view of Federal Reserve minutes.

site_title: Qantas cuts domestic capacity as fuel prices surge
summary: Qantas reduces domestic capacity by a few basis points due to surging fuel prices, lowering flying levels from 107% to 103% of pre-Covid-19 levels for July and August. The airline aims to "rebalance" capacity and airfares to cover the increased fuel costs, with no significant impact on customers expected.

site_title: More Premier League sides listed among Europe's most valuable clubs: report
summary: The Premier League now has 10 teams on a list of Europe's 32 most valuable clubs, according to a report by Football Benchmark. The report, released Thursday, found that the Premier League's growth was driven by broadcast revenues, with England's top flight leading the way with 10 clubs, including Manchester United, Liverpool, and Manchester City. LaLiga's Real Madrid remains Europe's most valuable club, valued at 3.18 billion euros, followed by Manchester United and Barcelona. The report also notes that clubs are recovering from the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SGX RegCo to extend suspension of entry into watch-list till June 2023
summary: SGX RegCo has extended the suspension of entry into the watch-list until June 2023, citing the ongoing economic challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic. The regulator had initially suspended entry in June 2020 to allow listed companies to focus on business operations during the pandemic. Companies will be reviewed for compliance in June and December, and those meeting the exit criteria can still be removed from the watch-list. The decision aims to allow issuers to recover from pandemic-related challenges and operate under normal business conditions.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Office workers walking past the SGX logo outside the SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on 17 January 2020.

site_title: British government to review of Drahi's BT stake
summary: The British government will review the national security implications of Patrick Drahi's 18% stake in BT Group, following his increase in shareholding. Business minister Kwasi Kwarteng is exercising his "call-in power" under the National Security and Investment Act 2021. BT Group has agreed to cooperate with the review. This move comes after a warning from Britain to intervene if necessary to protect the telecoms group's critical fibre network. Kwarteng has 30 working days to assess the situation.

site_title: UK unveils plan to boost aviation industry, passenger rights
summary: The UK government has unveiled a 10-point strategy to boost the aviation industry, focusing on sustainable growth, carbon emissions reduction, and improving passenger rights. The "Flightpath to the Future" plan aims to create jobs, upgrade skills, and promote decarbonisation technologies like electric planes and drones. The UK aims to achieve net zero emissions from aviation by 2050 and ensure benefits are shared across the country as part of a levelling-up agenda.

site_title: Universal Studios’ Minion Land to be first Singapore attraction powered by renewable energy
summary: Universal Studios Singapore's Minion Land is set to open in 2024 as the first attraction in the country powered by renewable energy, aiming for the Zero Energy Building certification. The zone will utilize smart energy systems and digital twin technology, and is part of Resorts World Sentosa's efforts to transform into a sustainable tourism destination. The attraction, themed around the Despicable Me characters, will feature immersive rides, shops, and restaurants, and is expected to contribute to tourism growth in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Genting Singapore H2 profit falls 49%; details of RWS expansion unveiled

site_title: Japan's Toshiba brings in M&A adviser and activists in board overhaul
summary: Toshiba has nominated Akihiro Watanabe as chairperson and Nabeel Bhanji, Eijiro Imai, and other activist shareholders as outside directors in a board overhaul. This move aims to intensify pressure to take the conglomerate private, following a long battle between Toshiba and its activist shareholders. The nominations come ahead of the annual shareholders' meeting on June 28, which could lead to a potential deal to go private. The overhaul also includes the nomination of Taro Shimada and Goro Yanase as CEO and COO, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher at open
summary: European stocks rose slightly at the open on May 26, driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. London's FTSE 100 index, Frankfurt's DAX index, and Paris' CAC 40 index all increased 0.1-0.3% as traders assessed the impact of runaway inflation on global recession fears. The rises came after Tokyo closed lower, and amid US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Azalea’s Astrea 7 PE bonds overall 3 times subscribed at over US$2b
summary: Azalea Asset Management, backed by Temasek, has seen its latest batch of Astrea 7 private equity bonds, Class A-1 and Class B, overall 3 times subscribed, with total subscription value exceeding US$2 billion. The retail offerings, including Class A-1 and Class B bonds, received 3.1 and 1.3 times the offer amount, respectively, with 92% of valid applicants receiving allocations. The strong interest in these bonds indicates growing popularity of investment-grade PE-backed bonds for diversifying portfolios and generating regular income.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The Astrea 7 Class A-1 bonds are denominated in Singapore dollars, while the Class B bonds are denominated in US dollars.

The Astrea 7 bonds will be backed by cash flows
from a US$1.9 billion portfolio of investments in 38 private equity funds
Private equity bonds gained traction as investors seek to diversify portfolios: Azalea

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS says US office S-Reits offer attractive yields, prefers KORE for stronger sub-markets
summary: DBS Group Research maintains a "buy" rating on all three US office Singapore-listed Reits, but prefers Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) due to its stronger sub-markets, higher growth profile, and lower gearing. DBS raised its target price on KORE to US$0.86, representing a 24.6% potential upside. The research team also lowered its target prices on Prime US Reit and Manulife US Reit, citing a delayed and slower pace of recovery in the US office market.

images.alt_text: Physical occupancy at US offices remains low.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as BOK raises rates; chipmakers drag
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.18% on May 26, with the Kospi index down 4.77 points at 2,612.45, amid a rate hike by the Bank of Korea to combat inflation. Technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix dropped 0.75% and 4.63%, respectively. The won weakened, while bond yields jumped, with the 10-year yield rising 6.5 basis points to 3.238%. The BOK forecast further aggressive interest rate hikes to control inflation, which reached 13-year highs.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 11.35 points, or 0.44 per cent, at 2,617.22.

site_title: Shanghai heading out of lockdown but China still lost in economic gloom
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub, is gradually easing Covid-19 curbs, allowing more residents to venture out and businesses to reopen. The city is set to officially emerge from its lockdown on June 1. However, a nationwide economic recovery is still uncertain, with Premier Li Keqiang stating that China's economic difficulties are even bigger than in 2020. Private-sector economists expect the country's GDP to contract in April-June from a year earlier. The central bank and finance ministry have announced measures to promote credit and subsidies to support the economy, which is still struggling due to lockdowns and Covid-19 outbreaks.

images.alt_text: Daily container throughput - a measure of cargo handling activity - at Shanghai port has rebounded to 95.3 per cent of the normal level, Ministry of Transport official Li Huaqiang said Thursday (May 26), according to Chinese state media.

site_title: JD Sports plunges after executive chairman steps down
summary: JD Sports plummeted 12% in London trading after executive chairman Peter Cowgill stepped down with immediate effect. This comes just a few months after the company was fined nearly £5 million by the UK's antitrust regulator for sharing commercially sensitive information. Helen Ashton, chair of the audit and risk committee, will become interim non-executive chair, while Kath Smith will take over as interim CEO. The move follows an ongoing review of JD Sports' internal governance and controls, and the company will begin searching for a permanent chair and CEO.

images.alt_text: First-quarter revenue to greater China fell 35 per cent, and Adidas has been starting to increase prices as higher costs for transport, shoes and garments erodes profitability.
Dubbed the "Mona Lisa of sneakers", this pair of Air Jordans is one of many vaunted sneakers on display at the exhibition.

site_title: UK regulator suggests simpler listing rule for London to attract more startups
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) proposes simplifying London's company listing rules to a single entry point, aiming to attract more startups and tech companies. Currently, companies must choose between standard and premium listing options, but the FCA suggests a single set of criteria for all listed companies, allowing them to opt-in to additional obligations. This move aims to boost London's attractiveness as a global listing location, following competition from New York and Amsterdam.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings has been examining an initial public offering of its Indonesian business to tap buoyant investor demand in the world's fourth-most populous country.
What Jamie Dimon and his team are trying to do is think like the big tech companies and exploit the same "winner takes all" principles that helped them dominate in their fields.

In December, the SEC mandated that Chinese companies, such as Alibaba, listed on US stock exchanges must disclose whether they are owned or controlled by a government entity, and provide evidence of their auditing inspections.

site_title: Philippines' Marcos vows to thwart interference from outside powers
summary: Philippines President-elect Ferdinand Marcos has vowed to prevent foreign interference in the country's governance, defending sovereignty and territorial claims in the South China Sea. He pledged to resist Chinese encroachment and uphold the 2016 international arbitration court ruling on economic entitlements. Marcos emphasized the importance of a sovereign nation's autonomy and will not compromise its sovereignty, even with China or other nations. He aims to establish an independent foreign policy and form alliances for regional stability.

images.alt_text: THE Philippines has revised its 2022 gross domestic product growth (GDP) target to 7.0 per cent-8.0 per cent from the previous range of 7.0 per cent-9.0 per cent to take into account external risks, the government said on Tuesday (May 24).

Customers dine in a restaurant in Batangas City, Philippines. The central bank governor Benjamin Diokno is optimistic that the country will post an even better performance following a solid rebound last year.

Philippine president-elect Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr., son of late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, speaks during a news conference at his headquarters in Mandaluyong City, Metro Manila, Philippines, May 23, 2022.

site_title: Bank of Singapore names ex-BlackRock exec as global head of alternative investments and managed solutions
summary: Bank of Singapore appoints Robert Reid as its new global head of alternative investments and managed solutions, effective May 30. Reid, a 30-year industry veteran, will oversee expansion of alternative investments offerings and lead growth of partners catering to diverse client needs. This appointment comes amid a heightened interest in alternative investments, with a 60% increase in flows towards these investments in 2021. Reid previously held senior leadership roles at BlackRock and global asset management firms.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
HSBC beefs up investments and wealth solutions team with Endowus, UBS hires
Bank of Singapore hires former UBS exec as global head of investment advisory solutions

site_title: Two and half cheers for Biden’s Asia forays
summary: US President Joe Biden has been praised for his successful response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, with a coalition of diplomatic and military partners halting the attack. However, his strategy should focus on sustainable foundations rather than a "defeat" of Russia. Biden's approach to China, including a warning to prevent invasion of Taiwan, is seen as a pragmatic move to maintain US presence in the Pacific. Nevertheless, his approach to the region must consider the strategic and economic interests of partners, as some countries, like India, have expressed concerns about the US's "One China" policy and potential military confrontation with China.

images.alt_text:
The Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity can be a valuable
platform for the US to exercise economic diplomacy in the region, and it
clearly signals the US’ continued commitment to engage with its partners in
Asia, and deepen ties across the Pacific, said Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

US President Joe Biden, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida attend the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) launch event at Izumi Garden Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, May 23, 2022. REUTERS

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as Fed minutes signal near-term rate hikes
summary: Australian shares ended 0.7% lower at 7,105.90, led by mining stocks after minutes from the Federal Reserve hinted at near-term US rate hikes. Technology stocks rose 1% despite the somber mood. Software maker Appen jumped 29.2% after a buyout approach, while Qantas Airways rose 1.1% after signaling changes to domestic capacity and fares. Gold and energy stocks fell, and the Reserve Bank of Australia may consider rate hikes next month, but is expected to be less hawkish than the US Federal Reserve or Reserve Bank of New Zealand.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei 225 index ended down 0.27 per cent or 72.96 points at 26,604.84.

Asian markets were mixed Thursday as minutes indicating a less hawkish Fed were offset by China's premier warning that the world's number 2 economy was in some ways worse off now than during the early days of the pandemic.

site_title: Shanghai port rebounds as lockdown loosens but backlog remains
summary: Shanghai port's daily container throughput has rebounded to 95.3% of normal levels after the city's Covid-19 lockdown, but a backlog of 260,000 containers remains due to disruptions. Despite this, cargo throughput at major Chinese ports increased 4.2% in May compared to April. However, trucking congestion persists due to driver and vehicle shortages, hindering deliveries to and from the port. The backlog is expected to cause shipping congestion well into the year, with a "bullwhip" effect across global supply chains.

site_title: 9 Marsiling HDB blocks to make way for Woodlands Checkpoint expansion
summary: The Woodlands Checkpoint in Singapore will undergo a major expansion, with 9 Housing Board blocks (Blocks 210-218 at Marsiling Crescent/Lane) being acquired to alleviate traffic congestion and meet a projected 40% increase in traffic volume by 2050. The expansion aims to reduce travel time by up to 4 times, incorporating automation and flexi-lanes, and will also allow for more efficient vehicle checks. Residents of the affected blocks will be offered compensation and the option to buy a new flat with a fresh 99-year lease. Construction is expected to begin in 2023 and be completed by 2027.

images.alt_text: Applications for the flats close on June 2, said National Development Minister Desmond Lee said on Wednesday (May 25).

site_title: Pasta worship at Forma
summary: A new Italian eatery, Forma, has opened in Joo Chiat, Singapore, offering authentic Italian fare. The restaurant features a variety of pasta dishes, including pappardelle e coda alla vaccinara, and other Italian specialties such as polpette di baccalà and deep-fried zucchini flower fritters. Forma is open for dinner only on Tuesdays to Saturdays from 6pm to 10:30pm. The eatery's focus is on solid Italian cuisine, rather than trendy or overhyped dishes, making it a unique addition to Singapore's dining scene.

images.alt_text: Interiors Forma
Forma Polpette di Baccalà.
Forma zucchini flower fritters.
Forma Tortellini in Brodo.
Pappardelle e Coda alla Vaccinara.
Forma Cannoli.

site_title: Lenovo profit beats estimates despite lockdown-sapped demand
summary: Lenovo's profit surpassed market estimates, jumping 58% to $412 million in the first quarter of the year, driven by a widening lead over rival HP. Sales reached $16.7 billion, beating the average expectation of $17.6 billion. Despite the strong results, Lenovo's Hong Kong shares fell slightly. The company's lead over HP has expanded, with Lenovo now holding the top spot in the global PC market.

images.alt_text: Staff were asked after the week-long May break to turn in foreign PCs for home-made alternatives that run on operating software developed domestically, people familiar with the plan said.

site_title: No slump for pump and dump cryptocurrency gangs
summary: Scammers continue to exploit the crypto-economy, using Telegram groups and Twitter to orchestrate "pump and dump" schemes. These scams, where traders artificially inflate a coin's value to make a quick profit, have been successful in recent weeks, with Enzyme's value rising from 30 cents to 47 cents before crashing. Experts warn that these schemes are often run by low-level scammers and are unsustainable, as they rely on a single buy order that quickly collapses once exhausted.

site_title: HSBC is said to consider an IPO of business in Indonesia
summary: HSBC Holdings is considering an initial public offering (IPO) of its Indonesian business, tapping buoyant investor demand in the world's fourth-most populous country. The plan is at an advanced stage and has yet to file a formal IPO application. Indonesia's economy is gathering pace, with predicted economic growth of 4.8 to 5.5 per cent this year, and HSBC's Indonesian business has booked a profit before tax of about US$129 million in 2021.

images.alt_text: Smarting from HSBC Holdings's move to scrap its dividend during the height of the pandemic, the bank's largely silent mass of retail shareholders in Hong Kong is warming up to the idea of a breakup.

site_title: Singapore factory output expands 6.2% in April, led by aerospace production
summary: Singapore's factory output expanded 6.2% in April, led by the transport engineering sector, which saw a 17.2% year-on-year increase. The aerospace segment also grew 24.2% due to higher production of aircraft parts and maintenance jobs. Industrial production excluding biomedical manufacturing grew 7.7% year-on-year. Despite economists expecting a slowdown in manufacturing growth, some analysts believe the sector will continue to perform well due to the relaxation of restrictions and international travel.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Private analysts were torn on the extent of the impact of a possible Chinese economic slowdown on Singapore’s manufacturing sector.
Headline readings had been slipping since the start of the year, though they remained expansionary.
Excluding the typically volatile biomedical manufacturing sector, industrial output for the same period grew 9.7 per cent year on year .

site_title: Brokers’ take: SAC upgrades UMS to ‘buy’ after strong Q1 showing
summary: SAC Capital has upgraded its call on UMS Holdings to "buy" from "hold", with a higher target price of S$1.55, after the precision engineering company exceeded Q1 FY2022 projections. Analyst Lim Shu Rong believes UMS can maintain its 51% gross margin due to stable supply chain dynamics, and the company's management is optimistic about a contract renewal. SAC has raised its FY2022 revenue and net profit estimates by 24% and 23%, respectively.

images.alt_text: UMS chief executive Andy Luong said that the  group has benefitted from timely diversification and acquisition of JEP.
UMS reports record earnings for FY2021, doubles dividend to 2 cents per share

site_title: Creating Maldivian memories
summary: The Conrad Maldives Rangali Island, a luxury resort in the Maldives, has recently completed its revamp with 50 new water villas featuring seamless indoor and outdoor spaces. The resort offers various experiences, including swimming with whale sharks and spotting manta rays, and features 12 restaurants, including the first underwater restaurant, Ithaa. The resort prioritizes sustainability, with a coral regeneration programme and a focus on locally sourced food. With over 150 resorts in the Maldives, the Conrad Maldives attracts repeat customers, thanks to its attentive staff and personalised experiences.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
sctravel26 - ConradMaldivesRangaliIsland 2022 4

site_title: Australia: Banks, tech push shares higher; Appen soars on buyout offer
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% to 7,161.00, driven by gains in banking and tech stocks, including a 30% surge in Appen after it received a $1.17 billion buyout offer from Telus International. The index also tracked global equities after US Federal Reserve meeting minutes suggested two more half-percentage-point rate hikes in coming months.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh Li remarks, Fed minutes
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as minutes from the Federal Reserve indicated a less hawkish stance, offset by China's premier warning that the country's economy is worse off now than during the pandemic. China's Li Keqiang warned of economic agony caused by lockdowns and strict containment measures, which have hammered growth and sent shockwaves globally. The mixed signals led to a 0.4% gain for Singapore's STI index, despite concerns about US-China trade tensions and the ongoing Fed's monetary policy.

site_title: Nvidia tumbles after lockdowns, Ukraine war hurt forecast
summary: Nvidia's stock tumbled in late trading after the company's sales forecast was impacted by China's Covid-19 lockdowns and the ongoing war in Ukraine. The company now expects revenue of $8.1 billion in the current quarter, below the analyst estimate of $8.44 billion. The outlook reflects ongoing supply-chain disruptions in China, making it challenging for Nvidia to capitalize on growing demand for chips.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of technology company Nvidia is seen at its headquarters in Santa Clara, California February 11, 2015.  REUTERS/Robert Galbraith/File Photo

site_title: Qualcomm CEO sees growth in high-end phones even if economy slows
summary: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon believes the company will continue to experience growth in high-end phones despite an economic slowdown. Amon attributes this growth to consumers' increasing desire for "better phones" with advanced capabilities, which may help stabilize the mobile market. Qualcomm's focus on premium and high-tier devices has led to a 40% to 75% market share in devices such as the Samsung Galaxy. The company also sees potential in augmented and virtual reality devices, with expanding partnerships with Meta Platforms and others.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm's robust earnings outlook and record quarterly revenue for the last quarter immediately pushed its shares up about 5 per cent in after-hours trading.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes lower
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index closed 0.27% lower at 26,604.84 on May 26, amid concerns over inflationary pressure due to the war in Ukraine. The broader Topix index rose 0.05%. Market declines followed subdued Chinese shares and were seen as a response to the ongoing US-China trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed Thursday as minutes indicating a less hawkish Fed were offset by China's premier warning that the world's number 2 economy was in some ways worse off now than during the early days of the pandemic.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO sees production rebound
summary: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess expects global production to recover this year due to improved semiconductor supplies and easing disruptions in Ukraine. The company plans to assemble its Scout brand electric trucks and SUVs in the US, with a decision expected this year. Volkswagen aims to spend 7 billion euros on US product line expansion, including an electric pickup truck. Diess is confident in securing enough batteries for electric vehicle production through 2025, but notes that rivals may face a battery supply crunch by 2024-2025.

images.alt_text: VOLKSWAGEN (VW) will pay £193 million (S$333.1 million) as part of an out-of-court settlement to around 91,000 British drivers over a diesel emissions scandal, litigation funder Therium and the German carmaker said on Wednesday (May 25).

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.31 points or 0.22% to 1,538.87 at 9:09 am on Thursday, with 174 gainers outnumbering 142 losers. Volume was 159.02 million lots worth RM68.05 million.

site_title: China car sales up 34% on April but still weaker than last year: industry
summary: China's retail car sales data for May showed a 34% increase from April but still 16% lower than last year due to ongoing COVID-19 restrictions. The China Passenger Car Association called for more government support, citing a grinding economic recovery. Automobile sales in the first quarter were 0.2% higher than last year, while sales of electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids have been the fastest-growing segment. Industry leaders, including Xpeng and Tesla, are accelerating deliveries and expanding production to keep the market growing despite broader economic challenges.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB cuts TDCX target price to US$18 on slower growth estimates
summary: CGS-CIMB has cut its target price on TDCX to US$18 from US$24 due to slower agent growth amid macro uncertainties. The research team lowered earnings per share estimates for FY2022, FY2023, and FY2024, citing delayed clients' project commitments. Despite this, CGS-CIMB maintains its "add" call on TDCX, citing structural trends in outsourcing. TDCX reported a 26.9% revenue growth in the first quarter, but shares fell 10.4% to US$12.15.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
TDCX founder and chief executive Laurent Junique.
TDCX expands into South Korea, appoints new VP of operations to helm office

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel up as much as 4.5% on rumoured Bharti Airtel stake sale
summary: Singtel's shares rose 4.5% on May 26 after reports emerged that the telco had initiated talks with Bharti Airtel chairman Sunil Mittal to potentially sell a small part of its holding in the Indian telco to the Mittal family. The stock reached an intra-day high of S$2.76 before closing 3.4% higher at S$2.73.

Reliefs for telco sector in India a boon for Airtel, says Singtel CFO

site_title: Rare ship-to-ship transfers keep oil moving from Russia to China
summary: Russian oil, specifically ESPO crude, is being transported to China through ship-to-ship transfers at sea. This rare logistical practice involves smaller tankers shuttling cargoes between Russia's Kozmino port and South Korea's Yeosu, where they are transferred to supertankers for the final leg to China. Chinese buyers are willing to take on this risk to ensure a steady supply of oil, as shipowners are increasingly shunning Russian oil due to financial sanctions. This unusual transfer process adds to costs and sailing time, but is becoming more common as buyers prioritize a steady supply of oil.

images.alt_text: Russia gave permission for natural gas supplies to Gazprom Marketing & Trading Singapore Ltd, part of Gazprom Germania, from Yamal LNG project for 90 days, a government decree showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Gold prices muted as Fed minutes fail to surprise
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Thursday, held back by rising Treasury yields, after minutes from the US Federal Reserve policy meet showed the central bank would likely maintain interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Spot gold held steady at $1,852.27 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.3%. The news was seen as a boost to gold prices after the Fed minutes suggested it would stick to hiking interest rates by 50 basis points in June and July.

images.alt_text: Gold prices hovered near a 2-week high on Wednesday, buoyed by a pullback in US Treasury yields and the dollar, with downbeat sentiment in riskier assets adding to safe-haven bullion's appeal.

site_title: Australia’s Westpac to sell one financial advisory business, merge unit’s funds with Mercer Super Trust
summary: Westpac Banking has agreed to sell its financial advisory business, Advance Asset Management, to Mercer Australia for an after-tax gain of A$225 million. The bank will also merge its BT unit's pension funds with Mercer Super Trust, creating a pension fund worth A$65 billion. The deals aim to simplify Westpac's operations and focus on its core banking business in Australia and New Zealand. The bank expects the deals to result in a gain over the remainder of this financial year and the next.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars eased back on Tuesday.
One of the world's most expensive property markets faces its biggest test in more than 30 years.

FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian looks at his phone as he walks past a logo for Australia's Westpac Banking Corp located outside a branch in central Sydney, Australia, November 5, 2018.   REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 26, 2022, following gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.14% to 26,714.74, while the Topix index increased 0.45% to 1,885.01. Investors sought fresh trading cues amidst global market fluctuations.

site_title: Apple hikes pay budget for US workers: WSJ
summary: Apple is increasing the compensation budget for its US employees amid inflationary pressures and unionization efforts. The starting pay for hourly workers will rise to $22 or higher, a 45% increase from 2018 levels. This change comes after some workers criticized the company's working conditions and amid a wave of labor activity at other major firms. The new pay will take effect in early July, with annual reviews being advanced by 3 months.

site_title: Russia poised to act against rouble rebound that's gone too far
summary: Russia is racing to slow its rouble's rally, which has surged 30% this year, as officials view the currency's appreciation as an economic threat. The government is poised to accelerate interest-rate cuts, potentially up to 700 basis points, to combat the gains, which have eroded exporter competitiveness and budget revenue. The decision comes amid a flood of energy earnings and a lack of imports, fuelling bets for a big cut.

site_title: China economy worse off in some ways than 2020, Premier Li says
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country's economy is worse off than in 2020, with significant economic indicators falling and difficulties exceeding those of the severe pandemic year. The economy's full-year growth is forecasted to be 4.5%, below the government's target of 5.5%. Li urged officials to ensure unemployment falls and the economy operates within a "reasonable range" in the second quarter, amid a soaring jobless rate of 6.1%. The premier's comments weighed on stocks, with the CSI 300 Index dropping 1% in early trading.

images.alt_text: CHINA has policy room to cope with challenges, as the downward pressure on China's economy increases, state media quoted Premier Li Keqiang as saying on Wednesday (May 18).

site_title: US securities regulators unveil proposal to fight ‘greenwashing’
summary: US securities regulators unveiled a proposed rule to tighten disclosure requirements for environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments, aiming to combat "greenwashing" and standardize transparency. The proposed rule would require funds to disclose how ESG factors are incorporated into investment processes and measure progress for impact funds. The SEC plans a 60-day public comment period, following opposition from Commissioner Hester Peirce, who argued that the rules do not adequately define ESG. The move comes as the US sustainable investment universe grows to $17.1 trillion.

site_title: Myanmar bans public sector's use of dollar for local payments
summary: Myanmar's military government has banned the public sector from using dollars for local payments, urging them to use the national currency, kyat, instead. The move aims to reduce the use of foreign currencies and stabilize exchange rates. The Central Bank of Myanmar sent a notification to ministries, provincial governments, and municipal bodies to report any circulation of the instructions among departments. The ban follows a previous mandate for foreign currency holders to exchange their dollars for kyat within one working day.

images.alt_text: A man counts Myanmar Kyat notes at Thirimingala Market in Yangon, Myanmar, on Monday, Oct. 12, 2015. Economic annual growth has averaged more than 7 percent since the 2010, helped by foreign funds that financed infrastructure and boosted low-cost manufacturing, alongside an increase in tourists.. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.50% on May 26, 2022, following a positive lead from Wall Street due to easing fears about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans. The Hang Seng Index increased to 20,272.22 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up.

site_title: Ellen DeGeneres ends pioneering talk show under cloud
summary: Ellen DeGeneres' 19-season talk show ended on Thursday amid allegations of a toxic workplace, contradicting its "be kind" mantra. The show, which was known for its feel-good format and celebrity guests, faced accusations of sexual harassment, bullying, and racism. Despite DeGeneres' denial of the allegations, three senior producers were fired, and she was accused of being less affable with employees in private. The show's departure marks a significant end to a pioneering career that began with her sitcom "Ellen" in 1997 and made her a gay icon.

images.alt_text: Film academy starts process to discipline Will Smith over Oscars slap

site_title: TTJ privatisation offer ‘unfair’
summary: A TTJ Holdings shareholder expresses concern over the company's privatization offer, stating it's "deeply unfair" to minority shareholders. The offer price of 23 cents per share is nearly 40% below the company's net asset value. If shareholders received the net asset value, it would be 60% higher than the current offer. The executive chairman's intention to acquire 90% of the company and then compulsorily acquire remaining shares is seen as undervaluing the company. The shareholder calls for a fair exit offer rather than enriching himself at the expense of minority shareholders.

site_title: Optimism dries up for UK services industry: CBI survey
summary: The UK services industry is experiencing a decline in confidence, with a CBI survey showing a decrease in business activity expectations and mixed news on inflation pressure. Consumer services firms reported stagnant growth and expected further decline, while business and professional services experienced growth but anticipate a halt. The survey aligns with a severe loss of momentum in the economy, raising concerns of recession. The CBI urges the government to support lower-income households and restore business confidence to stimulate investment.

site_title: HRnetGroup co-invests S$500,000 into Indonesia flexible staffing business
summary: HRnetGroup co-invested S$500,000 in Recruit First Indonesia's flexible staffing business, RFI, with new co-owner Kelvin Rimbum. The investment aims to provide further working capital. RFI manages the payroll for 2,000 people. This move follows HRnetGroup's previous joint venture with Rimbun Job Agency owners, bringing the company back to Jakarta after a 20-year hiatus. The co-ownership model has led to a 47% compound annual growth rate in net profits and a 41% return on investment.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Singapore retail rents and inflation moving in tandem may put retailers in a bind
summary: Singapore retailers may face increased costs due to rising rents and inflation. According to IREUS, some retailers, such as those selling recreational goods and furniture, may be hit harder by higher rents and inflation, while others, like food, toiletries, and computers, may be better able to weather the increase. A lead-lag relationship between rents and core inflation may explain the relatively weak correlation between the two, with landlords adjusting rents in response to inflation and stronger consumption demand. Retailers may need to bear the brunt of higher costs and diminishing profits if landlords are unwilling to share the burden.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Hawkers are already feeling the pinch of rising cooking oil prices. The price of oils and fats was up by 9.9 per cent in April, while hawker fare was up by 4.2 per cent.

Sibor and, in turn, mortgage rates are expected to rise further, IREUS noted. The strength of the private residential rental market will also soon be put to the test as more units are slated for completion.

If HDB flat owners who bought during the last peak in Q2 2013 had sold their flats in Q1 2022, they would have earned a return of 6.8 per cent. That did not outpace core inflation, which hit 11.6 per cent.

Shoppers outside stores at the Jewel Changi Airport mall in Singapore, on Sunday, Oct. 3, 2021. The relaxation of Covid-19 measures gives existing retailers, as well as new-to-market entrants greater confidence in their expansion plans.

site_title: Sony says it plans PS5 ramp up as shortages ease
summary: Sony plans to ramp up production of its PlayStation 5 console as supply chain snarls ease, aiming to close the gap versus its predecessor, the PS4, in year three. The company's gaming chief, Jim Ryan, stated that Sony will achieve production levels never seen before. The PS5, which initially faced shortages, is expected to surpass the PS4's installed base in year four. This move comes as the electronics industry recovers from pandemic-related disruptions.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday’s open, STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.9% at the open on Thursday, tracking gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,208.37, driven by gains from local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC, as well as Sembcorp Marine and Yangzijiang Financial Holding. In the US, Wall Street stocks finished higher after investors took an optimistic view of Federal Reserve minutes that reiterated plans to raise interest rates.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Wing Tai Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary has won the tender for Lakeside Apartments at S$273.9 million, representing a 14.1 per cent premium to the property’s S$240 million reserve price.

site_title: Russia pushed closer to brink of default after US payment licence expires
summary: The US failed to extend its license to pay Russia's bondholders, pushing the country closer to a historic debt default. The license, which expired on Wednesday, allowed Russia to make interest and maturity payments on its US sovereign debt. This move puts Russia's $40 billion of international bonds at risk of default, its first major external default in over a century. The US decision ramps up pressure on Russia following its invasion of Ukraine, with the US Treasury Department citing its decision as a response to Russia's actions.

images.alt_text: A SENIOR Russian central bank official said on Wednesday (May 25) that some banks would need additional capital and that the country's top 20 lenders would be assessed for their financial strength by the end of the month.

site_title: Wing Tai bags Lakeside Apartments for S$273.9 million, 14% above reserve price
summary: Wing Tai Holdings has acquired the collective sale of Lakeside Apartments in Singapore for S$273.9 million, a 14% premium to the reserve price of S$240 million. The site spans 12,465.4 sq m and will be redeveloped into an "iconic" residential development with over 300 units, subject to approvals. The acquisition is expected to have a minimal impact on Wing Tai's net asset value, with the company citing strong demand for the area due to its proximity to the Jurong Lake District.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Lakeside Apartments to go up for collective sale again at S$240m
Lakeside Apartments to go up for collective sale again at S$240m

Following the close of its public tender, The Beaumont went into a 10-week private treaty period which expired last week without any offers. The freehold residential development at Devonshire Road in the Orchard area was put up for sale at S$478 million.

site_title: Russia allows gas flows to Gazprom Marketing & Trading for 90 days
summary: Russia has granted permission for natural gas supplies to Gazprom Marketing & Trading Singapore Ltd, a part of Gazprom Germania, from the Yamal LNG project for 90 days. This move comes after the Kremlin stated that Russian sanctions on Gazprom's former German unit meant they could not receive gas supplies from Russia. The decision comes amid energy ties between Russia and Europe in crisis following Russia's "special military operation" in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The gas compressor station, a part of Polish section of the Yamal pipeline that links Russia with western Europe which is owned by a joint venture of Gazprom and PGNiG but it is operated by Poland's state-owned gas transmission company Gaz-System, is seen in Gabinek near Wloclawek, Poland May 23, 2022.REUTERS/Kacper Pempel

site_title: How China is seeking to revive a 16.3t yuan  property market
summary: China is implementing measures to revive its struggling residential property market, which has been battered by lockdowns and developer defaults. The government has urged banks to lend more, eased mortgage costs, and relaxed rules on owning multiple properties. Key steps include a lending push, a key interest rate cut, cheaper mortgages, and easier financing for property firms. These efforts aim to boost the housing market and counter weak loan demand, following a record 16.3 trillion yuan in annual new-home sales last year.

images.alt_text: CHINA will strive to achieve reasonable economic growth in the second quarter, state media quoted Premier Li Keqiang as saying on Wednesday (May 25).

site_title: New Zealand leader urges US to return to CPTPP trade pact
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern urged the US to return to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) if it wants to engage economically in the Indo-Pacific region. Despite the Biden administration's reluctance, Ardern emphasized the need for greater access to the US market, calling it the "gold standard." Ardern also highlighted the potential of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) to resolve non-traditional trade blockages, but expressed a commitment to advocating for market access.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand dollar climbed on Wednesday after the country’s central bank raised interest rates by half a point.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wing Tai, Valuetronics, HRnetGroup, Boustead Projects, Hwa Hong
summary: Wing Tai Holdings won a tender for Lakeside Apartments at S$273.9 million, a 14.1% premium to the reserve price, to redevelop the site into a residential development. Valuetronics Holdings posted a 40.5% drop in net profit due to a global components shortage. HRnetGroup co-invested in a flexible staffing business, while Boustead Projects reported a 91% fall in earnings. Nordic Group posted a 49% on-year increase in net profit, and Hwa Hong Corporation's board discussed views on a financial adviser appointment.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
HE Straits Times Index (STI) retreated further into the red on Wednesday (May 25).

site_title: Asia's war on inflation targets supply, not consumers
summary: Asian countries are employing targeted measures to curb inflation, focusing on supply rather than consumers. Export bans, price controls, and subsidies have helped shield the public from price rises and slowed the need for interest rate hikes. Governments have shifted cost burdens to their balance sheets, with Indonesia increasing energy subsidies by $24 billion and South Korea capping electricity bills. In contrast, Western governments have relied on monetary policy to combat inflation, leading to higher interest rates and price hikes.

images.alt_text: Clothing companies and gadget makers are among manufacturers across Asia seeing early signs of cooling demand from their global customers as soaring inflation takes hold.

site_title: 1982 Ventures closes inaugural seed fund at US$20m
summary: 1982 Ventures, a seed-stage fintech venture capital firm, has closed its debut fund at over $20 million, surpassing its target of $15 million. The fund has invested in 25 startups in South-east Asia, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, with notable portfolio companies including Brick, Wagely, and Bluesheets. The firm aims to make 10-15 new investments in its portfolio and has over $5 million in early commitments for its second fund. Co-founders Herston Powers and Scott Krivokopich, former executives of tryb Group, attribute the firm's success to the "most attractive sector for venture capital" being early-stage South-east Asian fintech.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

The fresh funds will be used for the launch of new products and services, technology development, hiring talent and strengthening the company’s financial programmes to create investment awareness in the country.

From left: Gautam Godhwani and Jayesh Parekh, managing partners of Good Startup. Since its launch in 2021, Good Startup has already invested in 21 alternative protein startups out of a target 35 companies globally, including Eat Just, Every Company, SuperMeat and TurtleTree.
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s housing boom to deflate as mortgage rates rise: poll
summary: Australia's housing market is expected to deflate as mortgage rates rise, with prices forecast to drop 8% in 2023, according to a Reuters poll of property market analysts. The cost-of-living crisis and high household debt levels contribute to this outlook, with prices predicted to fall 10-15% in 2024. The Australian central bank's recent interest rate hike has raised concerns about a potential housing market crash, with economists warning that a substantial decline in prices is needed to make housing more affordable.

site_title: South Korea delivers back-to-back interest rate hikes to combat inflation
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised interest rates for a second consecutive meeting, increasing the benchmark rate to 1.75%, the highest since mid-2019. This move aims to combat the country's 13-year high inflation rate. Governor Rhee Chang-yong and his monetary policy board voted to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, following over 100 cumulative basis points of hikes since August 2021. The rate hike is part of the bank's forceful tightening campaign to control inflation.

images.alt_text: From export bans to price controls, governments in Asia are taking a much more targeted approach than their Western counterparts in curbing global inflationary pressure, a strategy that appears to be working at least for now.

site_title: WTO chief urges countries not to block food exports
summary: WTO chief Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala urged countries not to block or restrict exports of basic foodstuffs, warning that export prohibitions could exacerbate global food market tensions and lead to price spikes. Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, India has capped sugar exports and several countries have imposed export restrictions or prohibitions on food, inputs, seeds, and fertiliser. Okonjo-Iweala emphasized the need for transparency and proportionate measures, and the WTO is monitoring such controls to deter member countries.

site_title: Zuckerberg's metaverse to lose 'significant' money in near term
summary: Mark Zuckerberg stated that his company's metaverse ambitions will result in significant losses in the next 3-5 years as he invests heavily in the project. He believes the metaverse will eventually generate revenue from a creator economy, where people build businesses selling virtual goods and services. In the meantime, the company is betting on revenue growth from its Reels short-form video services. Zuckerberg aims to make the hardware affordable for everyone and grow the digital economy.

site_title: Abbott apologises for US baby formula shortage
summary: Abbott, the manufacturer of baby formula, apologized to US families affected by the shortage, acknowledging the company "let you down." The shortage, caused by supply chain issues and a pandemic, worsened after a recall due to contamination concerns. Abbott claims there's no conclusive evidence linking their formula to infant illnesses and deaths. The FDA, which shut down the factory, criticized the company's unsanitary conditions and slow investigation process. The US government has flown in formula and invoked the Defence Production Act to prioritize baby formula manufacturers.

site_title: Malaysia's Finance Minister Zafrul says economy on track, has room to raise rates
summary: Malaysia's Finance Minister Zafrul Aziz says the country's economy is growing strongly due to rising commodity prices, with the central bank having room to raise interest rates to tackle accelerating inflation. The economy gained speed in the first quarter, with the central bank raising borrowing costs by 25 basis points to preemptively fight inflation. Zafrul notes that while interest rates are still accommodative, the country is on the right track and has the flexibility to adjust. The government is also taking steps to secure food supplies amid global tensions, including halting chicken exports and scrapping permit requirements for food imports.

images.alt_text: Zafrul Aziz during a Bloomberg Television interview at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on May 25.Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: How much for Buckingham Palace? £1.3b in heated UK market
summary: The value of Buckingham Palace has been estimated to be £1.3 billion, according to a study by McCarthy Stone, a significant increase from pre-pandemic estimates. The UK royal property portfolio, which includes castles and lodges, has also seen a significant increase in value, reaching £3.7 billion in 2022. The study highlights the UK's heated housing market, with the royal palaces not being private property but held in trust for future generations.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by banks, commodity stocks
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by resource-linked stocks and banks. The Stoxx 600 index reached a fresh one-month high, with banks rising 1.1%. Central banks are expected to raise interest rates, boosting banks and commodity stocks. Energy and material stocks also gained, while utilities rose 2.0% after a power company reported a 23% surge in annual profit. Despite market volatility, diversification of portfolios is seen as a way to navigate the tides.

site_title: Chinese developers still active but more cautious in Singapore, weaker yuan may be a boon
summary: Chinese developers remain active in Singapore's property market, albeit more cautiously, due to the weaker yuan. A 4.5% appreciation of the yuan against the Singapore dollar makes importing building materials from China cheaper. Despite concerns over Chinese developers' debt obligations, analysts note that many have sufficient capital in Singapore to sustain their business. Chinese developers are still participating in tenders, but their bids are less aggressive than before. The impact of the weaker yuan is seen as a positive factor for Chinese contractors, allowing them to keep construction costs low.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
China's property market woes are likely to worsen this year with prices remaining flat and sales and investment falling further, according to a Reuters poll.
money, banknotes, currency

site_title: Valuetronics H2 profit drops 40.5% to HK$56.9m
summary: Valuetronics reported a 40.5% drop in its second-half net profit to HK$56.9m, mainly due to severe shortages of electronic components impacting order fulfillment. Revenue declined 14.6% to HK$1 billion. The company's industrial and commercial electronics segment fell 17.5% due to a significant drop in sales from an auto customer. In contrast, the consumer electronics segment saw a 3.8% gain in revenue. The board recommended a final dividend of HK$0.10 per share, down from HK$0.16 per share last year.

images.alt_text: Even as Singapore continues to enjoy its status as a choice destination for quality events, the island state is working to enhance its overall attractiveness as a tourist destination, Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat said on Wednesday.

site_title: US hits Twitter with US$150m fine over privacy breach
summary: The US has fined Twitter $150 million for violating user privacy. Twitter agreed to the fine after allegations that the platform shared user information with advertisers, despite claiming it was for security purposes. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice accused Twitter of using phone numbers and email addresses to target users with ads. Twitter will implement new measures, including regular evaluation of its privacy program, to ensure user data is secure and protected.

site_title: Nvidia says video gaming market slowing; shares drop 7%
summary: Nvidia forecasts a 15% drop in gaming business revenue in the current quarter, citing a slowing market and supply-chain issues due to China's Covid-19 lockdowns. The company's shares fell 7% in extended trading, despite beating analyst estimates for first-quarter revenues and earnings. The decline is attributed to weaker demand for graphics chips and lower discretionary spending amid high inflation, with gaming revenue increasing 31% year-over-year but data centre revenue rising 83%. Nvidia's forecast for the second quarter is US$8.10 billion, plus or minus 2%.

images.alt_text: SPAIN'S government has approved a plan to spend 12.25 billion euros (S$18 billion) on the semiconductor and micro chip industry by 2027, Economy Minister Nadia Calvino said on Tuesday (May 24), including 9.3 billion euros to fund the building of plants.
Samsung Group will invest 450 trillion won (S$489.3 billion) in the next five years to accelerate growth in semiconductors, biopharmaceutical and other next-generation technologies.

site_title: Australia urged to quickly ditch coal to meet new climate goals
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has promised to end the "climate wars" by rapidly phasing out coal power plants and mines to meet the country's ambitious carbon emissions targets. Environmentalists say a phase-out of coal is crucial to meet the Labor government's new climate goals, with Greens and independents pushing for even more ambitious targets. However, the government's current emissions reduction target of 43% by 2030 is not in line with the Paris accord aim of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

site_title: Musk’s revised Twitter bid drops margin loan, requires more cash
summary: Elon Musk is revising his Twitter bid, dropping plans to use a margin loan tied to his Tesla stake and increasing the equity component to $33.5 billion. Musk will provide an additional $6.25 billion in equity financing, eliminating the margin loan. This change reduces the risk for both Musk and his lenders, particularly with Tesla's stock price having dropped 40% since Musk first announced his Twitter stake. Musk still needs to secure the full $33.5 billion equity component, seeking additional financing commitments from Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey and other investors.

images.alt_text: Twitter agreed to pay US$150 million to settle allegations the platform gave advertisers some user information that was supposed to be employed to strengthen account security.
Four year ago, Elon Musk first tweeted about a "roller skates & rock restaurant" that would double as a charging station for electric vehicles.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on Wednesday after Federal Reserve minutes
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday after Federal Reserve minutes, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbing 0.6%, the S&P 500 advancing 1.0%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.5%. Investors welcomed the Fed's plans to raise interest rates and offload bond holdings to combat inflation, with some analysts predicting an improvement in inflation by July or August. Individual companies such as Dick's Sporting Goods and Toll Brothers also saw gains after reporting better-than-expected quarterly profits.

site_title: Crying fowl: Poultry players scramble for fresh, frozen chicken supplies before Malaysia’s ban kicks in
summary: Malaysia's surprise ban on live chicken exports, set to kick in on June 1, is causing a scramble among poultry suppliers and food outlets in Singapore, who are pivoting to frozen chicken sources. Demand for cold storage facilities is expected to spike, with some facilities already receiving requests for 6 weeks' worth of frozen chicken. Suppliers are bracing themselves for a 90% decline in live chicken sales in Singapore and a potential increase in egg prices. Restaurants and food establishments are adjusting their menus and prices, while others are exploring alternative supply sources, such as imports from Thailand.

Malaysia will halt exports of 3.6 million chickens a month from Jun 1 and scrap the approved permit requirement for importing wheat until production and prices stabilize, Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob said.

site_title: SingLand gets URA provisional nod to redevelop Clifford Centre in Raffles Place
summary: Singapore Land Group has received the Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) provisional nod to redevelop Clifford Centre in Raffles Place into a 544,000 sq ft office and retail space, a 36% increase from the existing 401,000 sq ft. The redevelopment, expected to take 5 years, will capitalize on the office supply shortage in the CBD, according to CBRE's Michael Tay. The existing building has a 89% occupancy rate and current rents are 20% lower than nearby refurbished buildings.
