Tesla shares struggled Tuesday as the electric-vehicle maker's production woes in China refuse to go away, leading another analyst to slash his 12-month price target on the once high-flying stock.
The Nasdaq suffered another ugly round of selling on Tuesday.

site_title: Rising global food protectionism risks worsening inflation
summary: Global food protectionism is on the rise, with countries restricting exports to cope with high food prices, primarily caused by the war in Ukraine. This trend threatens to worsen inflation, particularly affecting the poorest countries, where lower-income households spend a large share of their income on food. The United Nations reports a 70% surge in world food prices since mid-2020, and more protectionism could push costs higher, further hurting consumer purchasing power and creating inflation headaches for central banks.

images.alt_text: India will restrict sugar exports as a precautionary measure to safeguard its own food supplies, another act of protectionism after banning wheat sales just over a week ago.

Malaysia will halt exports of 3.6 million chickens a month from Jun 1 and scrap the approved permit requirement for importing wheat until production and prices stabilize, Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob said.
The World Bank on Wednesday announced an additional US$12 billion in funding for projects to address the global food security crisis, bringing the total to US$30 billion.

site_title: Amazon delivery pressure hurting workers, labour group says
summary: Amazon delivery workers are experiencing injuries due to pressure to quickly deliver packages, according to a labour coalition. A report by the Strategic Organizing Center found nearly one in five delivery personnel were hurt on the job in 2021. The coalition attributes this to Amazon's high parcel delivery expectations and reliance on outside contractors, who face intense performance pressure. Amazon disputed the findings, stating the data is "cherry picked" and safety is a priority across its network.

site_title: Sneaker marketplace Novelship bags US$10 million in Series A funding
summary: Novelship, an online marketplace for limited-edition sneakers, streetwear, and collectibles, has secured US$10 million in Series A funding led by GSR Ventures and East Ventures. Founded in 2018, the platform curates and authenticates items from brands like Nike and Supreme, covering markets in Asia-Pacific and expanding into new regions. The funds will strengthen Novelship's leadership position and explore metaverse integration and brand partnerships. The startup has also seen over US$200,000 worth of sneakers sold in digital tokens since introducing cryptocurrency payment options.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Futu Singapore caps settlement fee of US stocks and ETF trades
summary: Futu Singapore has capped its settlement fee for US stocks and ETF trades at 1% of the transaction amount, effective May 23. The fee is lower than rival Tiger Brokers' 7% cap. Customers who are overcharged will be refunded within 2-3 business days. This move follows a similar announcement by Tiger Brokers and is in contrast to zero-commission trades offered by Syfe and TD Ameritrade Singapore.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York City, New York, U.S., October 2, 2020. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: OECD chief sees global digital tax deal pushed back to 2024
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has acknowledged that a global digital tax deal may be pushed back to 2024, contrary to initial plans to implement it in 2023. The deal, aimed at giving other countries a bigger share of tax on earnings of big US digital groups, is part of the biggest overhaul of cross-border tax rules in a generation. Despite progress from the Biden administration and the European Union, US approval is still stalled in Congress, with prospects uncertain ahead of the midterm elections.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OECD's incoming Secretary-General and former Australian Finance Minister Mathias Cormann delivers a speech at a handover ceremony during which he takes on the role of Secretary-General of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) from outgoing Secretary-General Angel Gurria at the OECD headquarters in Paris, France, June 1, 2021. Ian Langsdon/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
While the world economy faces headwinds, current growth forecasts offer a buffer against a potential global recession, the International Monetary Fund's No 2 official said Monday.
In the absence of global agreements, many countries have taken it upon themselves to devise their own rules and regulations that apply to cross-border digital trade in goods and services.

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners lift shares to near 3-week high
summary: Australian shares rose to a nearly three-week high on Wednesday, driven by gains in banking and mining stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 0.6% to 7,174.20 points, with major banks and mining companies like BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group rising between 0.6% and 1.8%. Despite a weak global market, the Australian financials sector added 1.2% and was on track for its best day in over a week, while energy stocks climbed 0.2% and gold stocks jumped 2.7%.

site_title: OCBC to invest over S$25m in decarbonisation efforts
summary: OCBC Bank is investing over S$25 million in Singapore, Malaysia, and Greater China to reduce its carbon footprint. The investments will deploy energy-efficient technology and solar energy systems, cutting around 10,000 tonnes of carbon emissions over the next 4 years. OCBC plans to retrofit buildings and data centers with energy-efficient technologies, install solar energy systems in 9 buildings by 2024, and convert its fleet to electric vehicles. The bank aims to achieve Green Mark certifications for its retail branches by 2030 and has committed to achieving carbon neutrality in operational emissions from 2022.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

OCBC works in partnership with EVCo – run by Strides Mobility, a business arm of SMRT Corporation, and DST Electric Vehicle Rental in Shenzhen – which offers EV leasing options for commercial businesses that can be structured towards actual vehicle ownership in the long term.
Singapore real estate companies and Reits raised some S$75 billion in green and sustainability-linked financing in 2021, up significantly from a modest S$300 million 2018.
Beyond Singapore, global organisations are also asking financial accounting standards boards to provide rules on topics like accounting for renewable-energy certificates and carbon-offset credits.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a retreat in US stocks due to concerns about growth after a profit warning from the owner of Snapchat. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.13% to 26,712.12, while the Topix index dropped 0.08% to 1,876.70. The profit warning from the tech sector shocked investors, leading to a decline in Asian markets.

site_title: Citigroup is in talks to buy Deutsche Bank Mexico for licence: sources
summary: Citigroup is in talks to buy Deutsche Bank's Mexican bank, aiming to set up a new local unit and exit retail operations in the country. The talks are in early stages and may not result in a deal, requiring regulatory approval. Deutsche Bank would retain its brokerage business in the country, and Citigroup plans to operate a locally licensed banking business through its institutional clients group and private banking franchise.

images.alt_text: Citigroup profit sinks 46% on loan loss provisions, dealmaking slump

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Logos Reit, Straco, Nordic, Japan Foods
summary: ESR-Logos Reit plans to divest its 3 Sanitarium Drive property in New South Wales, Australia, for A$55 million (S$53.4 million). Straco Corporation reported a net loss of S$3 million in its fiscal first quarter, attributed to negative revenue growth and Covid-19 measures. Nordic and Japan Foods are also mentioned as stocks to watch, but no specific developments are provided for these companies.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: India to limit sugar exports in risk to global food prices
summary: India will restrict sugar exports to 10 million tons for the marketing year, a precautionary measure to safeguard domestic supplies and control prices, following a ban on wheat exports earlier this month. The move, which will cap exports despite abundant domestic supplies, aims to maintain domestic availability and support global sugar markets. The decision is seen as an extreme case of precaution, given India's surplus of 16 million tons of sugar.

images.alt_text: Global buyers were banking on supplies from India, the world’s second-biggest wheat producer, after exports from the Black Sea region plunged following Russia’s Feb 24 invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: KKR closes US$1.1b inaugural pan-Asia credit fund
summary: KKR has closed its US$1.1 billion KKR Asia Credit Opportunities Fund, focused on performing privately originated credit investments in Asia-Pacific. The fund received support from over 100 investors, including public and corporate pensions, sovereign wealth funds, and private investment groups. KKR has invested over US$100 million in the fund and has closed 14 credit investments in the region, totaling US$2.4 billion. The fund will provide flexible and differentiated credit solutions to businesses in sectors such as environmental services, real estate, and healthcare.

images.alt_text: KKR eyes raising US$5b to invest in mid-size companies: sources
Toshiba, which had originally opposed a buyout, now plans to solicit proposals from potential investors in a drastic change in stance.
KKR is targeting US$4 billion for its third technology fund and plans to raise a small portion through Singapore-based private market platform ADDX.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit to divest Australia property at 18.5% premium in A$55m deal
summary: ESR-Logos Reit is divesting its Australian property, 3 Sanitarium Drive, for A$55 million, a 18.5% premium to its fair value of A$46.4 million. The buyer is the Australasian Conference Association. The divestment is part of the Reit's capital recycling efforts to focus on modern assets. Net proceeds will be used to repay borrowings and finance upcoming asset enhancements. The divestment is expected to have minimal impact on the Reit's net asset value and distribution per unit for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2022.

images.alt_text: The newly-styled ESR-Logos Reit began trading on May 5

site_title: China's Gen Z has the power to make or break western brands
summary: China's Gen Z, born since the mid-1990s, is redefining the country's consumer economy with its growing nationalism and exacting demands. The 270-million-strong cohort has the fastest spending growth, top buyers of cosmetics and tourism services, and is upending online shopping. Meeting their demands will require a massive shift in how Western companies operate in China, posing a significant challenge to market dominance. Local brands are capitalizing on this trend, with sales growing fourfold to 16 trillion yuan by 2035. Gen Z's growing pride in Chinese culture and preference for domestic brands is forcing Western firms to adapt to their unique tastes and values.

images.alt_text: Shanghai, China’s financial hub with more than 28 million people, remains in lockdown for almost 2 months, though more residents are recently allowed to go out to shop for groceries.

site_title: Battleground Georgia tests Trump’s US voter fraud ‘Big Lie’
summary: In the Georgia primary, Republican voters overwhelmingly rejected Donald Trump's "Big Lie" about the 2020 US election being stolen, with incumbent Governor Brian Kemp leading Trump-backed candidate David Perdue by 20+ points. Former Vice President Mike Pence endorsed Kemp, marking a high-profile clash with Trump. Kemp also leads in the secretary of state race, with Democratic opponent Jody Hice trailing behind. The results suggest a strong anti-Trump sentiment in the state, which could impact the 2024 elections.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open as investors cheer positive GDP, export data
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% at Wednesday's open, driven by positive GDP and export data, despite weaker US stock market performance. The Straits Times Index gained 11.89 points to 3,206.93, with Sembcorp Marine, Yangzijiang Financial Holding, and Thai Beverage leading the gains. Despite a mixed performance in banking stocks, the market was lifted by the upgrade of Singapore's 2022 key exports forecast and a stronger-than-expected Q1 GDP growth of 3.7%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
ESR-Logos Reit will divest 3 Sanitarium Drive, a freehold property comprising industrial buildings in New South Wales, Australia, for A$55 million (S$53.4 million).

site_title: Japan maintains economic assessment in May report
summary: Japan's economy showed signs of improvement, with the government maintaining its overall view unchanged in May's report. The economy is expected to recover on stronger consumption in the coming months. Imports from China declined 20.8% in April, while employment conditions and housing investment were raised. The government cited pandemic risks in China and the Ukraine crisis as downside risks. Analysts forecast a recovery, citing a 1.0% annualized dip in January-March due to COVID-19 cases and commodity price pressure.

site_title: Can Sea’s fintech ambition excite investors the way Free Fire did?
summary: Sea Ltd, a fintech-focused company, saw its shares rally 14% after reporting revenue that beat expectations for the first quarter, ending March, with a 64.4% surge to $2.9 billion. Despite a widening net loss to $445.1 million, investors appeared to be optimistic, similar to last year's reaction to Sea's financial results, which were met with higher valuations despite higher losses. This response suggests that investors may be willing to overlook Sea's financial struggles if its fintech ambitions can amplify its e-commerce business.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Sea owns game developer Garena and online shopping platform Shopee.
Sea faces prospect of depleting fuel for Shopee dream

site_title: Japan Foods records 46.4% rise in H2 profit to S$4.9m
summary: Japan Foods Holding reported a 46.4% increase in 2nd-half net profit to S$4.9 million, driven by a 2.9% rise in revenue from its halal restaurant brand Tokyo Shukudo. Gross profit grew 3.2% to S$28.4 million, while the group's gross profit margin increased to 85.1%. The company attributed higher other income to rental support payouts. Despite a 10.8% decline in FY2022 net profit, the group's share price rose 1.2% to S$0.42.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Japan Foods swings back to profitability in H2, proposes 1.75 S cents final dividend
Brokers' take: RHB upgrades Japan Foods to 'buy'; raises target price to S$0.50
Brokers' take: KGI upgrades Japan Foods to 'outperform' with higher S$0.65 target price

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: A US$40 billion crash in the cryptocurrency market occurred due to the downfall of Luna and TerraUSD, a case study of crypto hype and its consequences. Meanwhile, Temasek's Azalea launched Astrea 7 PE bonds with a fixed coupon of 4.125% and 6%. A Henderson 5-room HDB flat set a new record resale price of S$1.4 million. TSMC is reportedly eyeing a multibillion-dollar plant in Singapore. Highly leveraged homeowners in Singapore may face a double whammy from inflation and housing supply.

site_title: Australia housing industry at capacity as supply lines snarl: RBA
summary: Australia's housing industry faces a strong pipeline of new work but is delayed due to global supply disruptions and rising material costs, squeezing margins. According to Reserve Bank of Australia assistant governor Luci Ellis, one-fifth of businesses are struggling to source materials, and houses are now taking 9 months to complete instead of 6. The industry is reportedly at capacity, unable to work down its pipeline of detached homes.

images.alt_text: Anthony Albanese, leader of Australia's Labor Party is accompanied by his partner Jodie Haydon and son Nathan Albanese while he addresses his supporters after incumbent Prime Minister and Liberal Party leader Scott Morrison conceded defeat in the country's general election.

site_title: Petrobras shares fall after Bolsonaro fires its boss
summary: Petrobras shares fell over 4% on Tuesday after President Jair Bolsonaro fired its CEO, Jose Mauro Coelho, just 40 days into the job. The move was in response to rising fuel prices, which Petrobras sets but is tied to international market movements. Bolsonaro had previously fired the company's predecessors, and the dismissal raised concerns of government intervention in Petrobras' pricing decisions, which has been a point of contention ahead of the October elections.

site_title: Soros says ‘civilization may not survive’ Ukraine war
summary: US billionaire George Soros warned that "civilization may not survive" Russia's invasion of Ukraine, stating the war has "shaken Europe to its core." He praised US and European support for Ukraine but criticized Europe's excessive dependence on Russian fossil fuels. Soros believes Europe has a stronger position than it realizes and should defeat President Putin to preserve civilization. He also pointed out that Russia's gas storage facilities will be full in July, making it difficult for Russia to cut off gas supplies to Europe.

site_title: VCs bet on a carbon-credit startup co-founded by Adam Neumann
summary: Adam Neumann, co-founder and former CEO of WeWork, co-founded a carbon-credit startup called Flowcarbon, which raised $70 million in funding from venture capitalists. The startup sells carbon credits and uses blockchain technology to record transactions. Despite controversy surrounding Neumann, investors saw an opportunity for Flowcarbon, with backers including Andreessen Horowitz's crypto arm and Samsung Next. The company is run by a separate management team, with Neumann as an investor through his family office.

site_title: South Korean military says North Korea launched two ballistic missiles: Yonhap
summary: North Korea launched two ballistic missiles towards the sea off its east coast on May 25, 2022, just days after US President Joe Biden's visit to South Korea. The South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff described the missiles as "unspecified" type. The launches follow recent sanctions-busting weapons tests by Pyongyang, which had raised concerns of a potential nuclear test. Biden had warned Kim Jong Un that the US was "prepared for anything North Korea does." The incident marks the latest escalation in tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP up by 3.7% but external demand outlook is weaker now: MTI
summary: Singapore's economy expanded by 3.7% in the first quarter of 2022, driven by growth in manufacturing, finance, and services. However, the external demand outlook has weakened due to the ongoing Russian war in Ukraine and potential escalation of the conflict. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) has kept its full-year growth forecast between 3% and 5%, but acknowledges downside risks, including supply disruptions and prolonged economic slowdowns in China. The economy's growth is expected to be more subdued than earlier official estimates, with some analysts projecting full-year growth of 4.3-4.9%.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

SINGAPORE is upgrading its forecast its key exports in 2022 on the account of better-than-expected first-quarter performance and higher oil prices expected to support oil trade, Enterprise Singapore said in its quarterly trade review on Wednesday (May 25)
Shanghai, China’s financial hub with more than 28 million people, remains in lockdown for almost 2 months, though more residents are recently allowed to go out to shop for groceries.

Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in April eased for the fifth straight month to 6.4 per cent year on year, from 7.7 per cent the previous month according to data from Enterprise Singapore on Tuesday (May 17)

site_title: Gunman kills 21, including 18 children in Texas elementary school
summary: A gunman killed 21 people, including 18 children, at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, on Tuesday. The shooter, Salvador Ramos, 18, was killed by police, and three adults were also killed. Authorities say Ramos acted alone, with a motive not yet known. The shooting was one of the deadliest at a US school since the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre in 2012, fueling the debate on gun control. US President Joe Biden planned to address the nation about the tragedy.

site_title: Nordic Group wins S$19m in contracts; unit to buy Eratech for S$10m
summary: Nordic Group won S$19 million in contracts, including a S$9.1 million infrastructure project and S$5.7 million in marine contracts. The company's subsidiary Avitools Singapore will acquire precision-machining and turnkey-manufacturing services company Eratech for S$10 million, financed through internally generated funds and bank borrowings. The acquisition is expected to expand the group's product and service range and customer base.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Nordic Group's offer for Starburst closes with 94.3% valid acceptances
The old City Hall (left) and the Padang (right), with other historical buildings around, on 7 April 2021.
Nordic Group executive chairman Chang Yeh Hong.

site_title: Netflix releases new game titles
summary: Netflix has released three new mobile games, Dragon Up, Moonlighter, and Townsmen - A Kingdom Rebuilt, alongside a fourth title, Exploding Kittens - The Game, set to launch on May 31. This marks the streaming service's continued investment in interactive entertainment, with a total of 22 games in its catalogue. The games were developed by studios acquired by Netflix, including East Side Games, 11 Bit Studios, and HandyGames. The new releases are available through the Apple App Store and Google Play Stores.

site_title: Glencore to settle US, UK investigations for US$1.5b
summary: Glencore, a commodities trader, will pay US$1.5 billion to settle US and UK investigations into alleged wrongdoing, according to people familiar with the matter. The settlement will be announced later and is part of a February announcement that the company had set aside US$1.5 billion for potential settlement of probes. Glencore has faced investigations by the US Department of Justice, the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and the UK Serious Fraud Office, amid concerns over corruption and market manipulation.

images.alt_text: Glencore to pay out US$4b to investors after record profit

site_title: India's Andhra state in US$16b pacts involving Adani, GIC-backed Greenko
summary: Andhra Pradesh, a state in India, signed $16 billion renewable energy investment pacts with Adani Green Energy, GIC-backed Greenko, and Aurobindo Realty & Infrastructure during the World Economic Forum at Davos. The agreements will create 38,000 jobs and involve projects including solar, wind, and hydro power. The state aims to increase its renewable energy capacity to 33,000 megawatts by 2030, in line with India's goal to install 450 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2030.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp signs 12-year agreement to supply power to Indian state Andhra Pradesh

site_title: Hyundai to recall 281,000 North American vehicles over exploding part
summary: Hyundai Motor America is recalling 281,000 North American vehicles due to seat-belt pretensioners that could explode and project metal fragments, causing injuries. The recall affects 2019-2022 Accent, 2021-2023 Elantra, and 2021-2022 Elantra hybrid vehicles. Two injuries were reported in the US and one in Singapore. Dealers will secure seat-belt pretensioners with a cap. The recall expands on previous recalls and includes 239,000 US vehicles and 42,000 Canadian vehicles. Hyundai is still investigating other models.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor Group said on Friday it plans to invest about US$5.54 billion to build its first dedicated full electric vehicle and battery manufacturing facilities in the United States.

site_title: Singapore upgrades 2022 export forecasts on better-than-expected Q1 showing and higher oil prices
summary: Singapore is upgrading its 2022 export forecasts due to better-than-expected first-quarter performance and higher oil prices. The country now expects total merchandise trade to grow 8-10%, while non-oil domestic exports are expected to grow 3-5%. This is a revision from the previous forecast of 0-2%. Higher oil prices and robust global semiconductor demand are expected to support exports, particularly in the electronics trade.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Robo-adviser Endowus receives Hong Kong licences, aims to launch in 2022
summary: Singapore-based robo-adviser Endowus has received licenses from the Securities and Futures Commission of Hong Kong (SFC) to offer wealth management and advisory services in the territory. The company, which has over $1.5 billion in assets under management, plans to launch in Hong Kong in 2022. Endowus has appointed Steffanie Yuen as head of Hong Kong and is hiring other key staff. The move comes despite challenges in the Hong Kong market, but Endowus is not the only platform entering the territory, with fellow local robo-adviser Syfe also opening a Hong Kong branch.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Endowus首席执行官万振邦建议投资者多了解可投资的基金，选择一个较适合自己风险承担能力和投资目标的投资组合。 （受访者提供）

site_title: Samsung SDI, Stellantis invest US$2.5b in US battery plant
summary: Stellantis and Samsung SDI have invested $2.5 billion in a US battery plant in Kokomo, Indiana, with annual production of 23 gigawatt hours expected to increase to 33 gigawatt hours by 2025. The project will create 1,400 new jobs and is part of Stellantis' plan to develop 5 large battery factories across North America and Europe to produce 400 gigawatt hours of capacity by 2030. The company has pledged to sell 5 million battery-electric vehicles by the end of 2030 and make all European passenger car sales fully electric by then.

images.alt_text: The logo of German car manufacturer BMW is seen on the bonnet of a vehicle covered with water drops in Kiev March 27, 2012.   REUTERS/Str (UKRAINE  - Tags: TRANSPORT BUSINESS LOGO)
Stellantis will spend up to C$3.6 billion (S$3.9 billion) to boost production of electric vehicles at its Windsor and Brampton, Ontario plants with government investment, it said on Monday (May 2).

site_title: Sri Lanka's prime minister says will slash expenditure in new budget
summary: Sri Lanka's new Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe plans to present an interim budget within six weeks, slashing expenditure on infrastructure projects and redirecting funds to a two-year relief program for the crisis-hit nation. The move aims to cut costs and alleviate inflation, which could rise above 40% due to fuel subsidy cuts and increased money printing. A new finance minister will be appointed to lead negotiations with the International Monetary Fund for a loan package.

site_title: Oil steadies after choppy trade, US says export ban not ruled out
summary: Oil prices steadied on Tuesday after a choppy trade, with Brent crude rising 14 cents to $113.56 a barrel and US WTI crude falling 52 cents to $109.77 a barrel. The US Energy Secretary stated that President Biden had not ruled out using export restrictions to ease soaring domestic fuel prices. Tight supply concerns and worries over a recession offset concerns about China's Covid-19 curbs. A potential European Union ban on Russian oil imports is also expected to be agreed upon "within days."

site_title: US says ending Russia debt payment exemption
summary: The US will end an exemption allowing Russia to pay foreign debts with dollars held in Russia as of 0401 GMT on Wednesday, potentially pushing the country closer to default. The exemption, which was put in place to allow financial institutions to adjust, ends two days before Russia's next debt service payment is due. The US Treasury said the exemption was "time limited" and was meant to allow financial institutions to adjust. Russia faces 13 debt service deadlines in 2022, with the next payment due on May 27 for 100 million euros in interest.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as business growth data deepens slowdown worries
summary: European shares ended lower on Tuesday, falling 1.1% due to business expansion data showing a slowdown in the eurozone economy. The data, combined with a shortage of raw materials and inflationary pressures, raised concerns over global growth and the European Central Bank's monetary policy tightening. Major sectors declined, with luxury stocks and retailers leading the way, and the Stoxx 60 index is now down over 12% from its year-highs in January.

site_title: Asean growth expected to surpass China in 2022: analysts
summary: Asean's economies are expected to surpass China's in 2022, with the Asean-5 region projected to grow at 5.2% and the Philippines at 6.5%, according to Maybank analysts and the International Monetary Fund. In contrast, China's GDP growth is forecast at 4.5%. The Asean region's "living with Covid" strategy, allowing for more mobility and visitor arrivals, is seen as a key factor in its growth outlook. However, China's strict lockdowns and zero-Covid policy are expected to continue, posing a challenge to its economic growth.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
money, banknotes, currency
pudong, shanghai under lockdown
Asean poised for rebound, but growth fragile as Ukraine war adds to list of risks: OECD
A worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) rides a bicycle along a nearly-empty road in Shanghai on May 5, 2022.

China's development is positive for the region, but countries in the Asia-Pacific also want to maintain ties with other economies like Japan as well as the US and Europe, PM Lee said in an interview with Nikkei.

site_title: US new home sales drop 16.6% in April: govt
summary: US new home sales dropped 16.6% in April to an annual rate of 591,000, seasonally adjusted, according to government data. This is a 26.9% decline compared to April 2021. Despite a rise in borrowing costs, median home prices reached $450,600 in April, a 4.5% increase from the prior month. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are contributing to the cooling demand, with builders adding to the housing stock, but not enough to tilt the market in favor of buyers, according to economists.

site_title: Philippines narrows 2022 GDP growth target due to external risks
summary: The Philippines has revised its 2022 GDP growth target to 7.0-8.0% from 7.0-9.0% due to external risks, including the Russia-Ukraine conflict, China's slowdown, and monetary policy normalisation in the US. The government also lowered its budget deficit target to 7.6% of GDP from 7.7%. The GDP growth target remains at 6.0-7.0% for 2023 and 2024, while the budget deficit targets are set at 6.1% for 2023 and 5.1% for 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Vendors and customers wearing face masks for protection against the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) are seen inside a public market in Quezon City, Metro Manila, Philippines, February 5, 2021. REUTERS/Eloisa Lopez/File Photo

site_title: Tesla resumes plunge as fears of slow production weigh
summary: Tesla shares plummeted on Tuesday as production woes in China continued, leading analyst Jairam Nathan to slash his 12-month price target to $800 from $1,150. The electric-vehicle maker's production issues have weighed heavily on the stock, which has lost nearly half its market capitalization since touching a record high in November. The decline follows a recent 50% rise last year, with shares closing at $620.57 on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: TESLA plans to restore production at its Shanghai plant to the level at which it had operated before the city's Covid-19 lockdown by Tuesday (May 24), a day later than its most recent recovery plan, according to an internal memo seen by Reuters.
Tesla's Gigafactory in Shanghai.

site_title: Countries agree to overhaul WHO funding
summary: The World Health Organization's (WHO) member states agreed to overhaul the agency's funding model, giving it more money to spend on its own priorities. The change aims to strengthen the organization and make it more agile in responding to global health crises. The new funding system will give the WHO a more stable income stream and control over a larger portion of its funding, allowing it to implement its priorities more effectively and efficiently. The overhaul is a key plank of WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus' leadership, which includes increasing the organization's membership fees to 50% by the 2030-2031 budget cycle.

site_title: London's £19b Crossrail finally opens
summary: London's £19 billion Crossrail, now renamed the Elizabeth line, has finally opened to passengers after a 12-year construction process, 3.5 years late and £4 billion over budget. The new railway, expected to carry 200 million people annually, offers faster journeys from Heathrow to Essex and increases London's rail capacity by 10%. The line features 21 km of tunnel, connects Paddington to Canary Wharf and Abbey Wood, and will initially operate with 12 trains per hour in each direction, with services set to nearly double later this year.

images.alt_text: Momin Rashid and Sangita Bhunia, students who will perform at Queen's Platinum Jubilee Pageant, at the George Harris Academy in Birmingham earlier this month. ,

site_title: Blackstone-backed entity acquires Singapore-based One Animation
summary: Moonbug Entertainment, backed by Blackstone's private equity, has acquired Singapore-based media company and production studio One Animation. The acquisition will give One Animation a global footprint and access to Moonbug's talent, distribution network, and data insights. One Animation, founded in 2008, holds IP rights for popular children's content titles such as Rob The Robot and Oddbods, and has partnerships with Disney, Netflix, and Amazon. The deal marks a significant expansion for Moonbug, a digital kids' entertainment company, and is expected to accelerate One Animation's growth.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Adobe, with the aid of acquisitions, has expanded its marketing, analytics and e-commerce products, which Narayen is counting on to spur the company’s effort to reach US$20 billion in annual revenue.
Nordic Group executive chairman Chang Yeh Hong.

site_title: Tedros re-elected as head of World Health Organization
summary: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus was re-elected as Director General of the World Health Organization (WHO) for another 5 years, receiving a strong majority vote by secret ballot. He was the only candidate running, and his re-election was seen as a formality. The vote marked a significant period for the WHO, which has navigated the COVID-19 pandemic under his leadership.

images.alt_text: epa09972155 Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus (C) Director General of the World Health Organization (WHO) celebrates his reelection, during the 75th World Health Assembly at the European headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva, Switzerland, 24 May 2022.  EPA-EFE/SALVATORE DI NOLFI

site_title: Ralph Lauren expects margins to grow on resilient luxury demand
summary: Ralph Lauren forecasts improved full-year margins due to strong demand for luxury apparel in North America and Europe, despite inflation denting profits at major US retailers. The company expects revenue to increase in high single digits and gross margin to rise 30-50 basis points. Higher-income customers have remained unaffected by inflation, leading to increased spending on fashion. The brand also plans to raise prices to counter increased freight and product costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past Ralph Lauren Corp.'s flagship Polo store on Fifth Avenue in New York City, U.S., April 4, 2017.    REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD/File Photo

site_title: Chanel may limit purchases more in exclusivity drive
summary: Chanel may limit purchases of its high-end products, including the quilted Classic Flap handbag, to protect customers and curb bulk buying amid soaring demand. The company's chief financial officer, Philippe Blondiaux, said limits could be implemented on certain product ranges, not just the flap bag, in various countries. This move is part of Chanel's strategy to make its brand even more exclusive and counter the growing resale market for luxury goods. The company has already limited purchases in South Korea and may consider similar measures globally.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says it’s done all it can for the global oil market
summary: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Faisal bin Farhan, stated that the kingdom has done all it can to stabilize the global oil market, implying no plan to accelerate production increases. He said there is enough energy in the market, citing a refining crunch as a primary cause for soaring fuel prices. Oil prices have risen 70% in the past year, driven by demand rebounding from the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The kingdom's assessment is that oil supply is currently in balance, contradicting US pressure for faster production.

images.alt_text: A photograph shows petrol nozzles at a gas station in Montgiscard, southwestern France, on January 24, 2022, as oil prices are at their highest in France since 2014. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: Spain to spend 12.25 billion euros on microchip industry
summary: Spain's government has approved a 12.25 billion euro plan by 2027 to develop the country's microchip industry, including 9.3 billion euros for plant construction and 1.1 billion euros for research and development. The program aims to boost domestic semiconductor production capacity, create a 200 million Chip Fund for start-ups, and support strategic projects at the European level. The plan is directed towards the digital economy and responds to global chip shortages, with the goal of making Spain a relevant player in the technological field.

site_title: 'Stranger Things' returns with more supernatural horrors
summary: The Netflix sci-fi drama "Stranger Things" returns with the first part of its highly-anticipated season 4, promising more supernatural horrors in the fictional Indiana town of Hawkins. Set 6 months after season 3, the story follows Eleven, who moves to California with Joyce and her sons, while the rest of the gang faces a new threat in Hawkins. The season explores Eleven's struggles with her powers and social skills, amidst the gang's high school life and the emergence of a new threat from the Upside Down.

site_title: US bank profits dip as loan loss provisions jump in response to global uncertainty: FDIC
summary: US bank profits declined 6.5% to $59.7 billion in the first quarter of 2022, with larger firms increasing loan loss provisions due to economic and geopolitical uncertainty. This marks a reversal from recent history, where banks grew reserves during the pandemic. Loan balances grew 1% despite rising interest rates, while noncurrent loan balances fell 4.5% to 0.84%. The FDIC attributed the decline to inflationary pressures, rising interest rates, and geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: Arts cluster Gillman Barracks set for another transformation
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) plans to transform Gillman Barracks, a quiet arts cluster, into a bustling lifestyle hub with a broader mix of dining, leisure, and arts offerings. The SLA aims to spend S$2 million to improve the precinct's infrastructure, including a new children's playground, and is launching 5 tenders for F&B and lifestyle uses. The SLA seeks proposals that contribute to the precinct's vibrancy and show a commitment to sustainability, with tenders open for 8 weeks.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Timbre Group braves pandemic uncertainty with expansion

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends 2.4% lower as Wall Street selloff resumes
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.4% to 11,264.45, ending a brief upbeat session, due to weak earnings and economic data. The S&P 500 declined 0.8% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%. The decline was fueled by UBS Group and JPMorgan Chase cutting their China economic growth forecasts and data showing new US home sales plummeting in April. Analysts cited Snap's warning that key financial benchmarks would lag earlier estimates, citing a deteriorating macroeconomic environment.

site_title: Social media firms sink after bleak warning from Snapchat parent
summary: Snapchat parent Snap Inc's shares plummeted 40% after a profit warning, signaling tough times for the digital ad industry. The company expects to miss revenue and profit targets, leading to a sector-wide selloff affecting Meta Platforms, Pinterest, Twitter, and Alphabet. The warning highlights the impact of the Russia-Ukraine war, inflation, and rising interest rates on social media companies. Analysts predict expenses will outpace revenue growth, with pressure from TikTok and shifting ad budgets.

images.alt_text: Snap cut its revenue and profit forecasts below the low end of its previous guidance, sending shares plunging as much as 31 per cent and pushing other social media stocks down.

site_title: Oil rises as tight supply counters economy fears and China curbs
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Tuesday, recovering from earlier losses, as tight global supply and expected demand during the US summer driving season balanced concerns over a possible recession and China's Covid-19 curbs. Brent crude rose 0.2% to $113.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude added 0.1% to $110.40. Analysts attribute the price recovery to the expected pick-up in demand and EU's potential ban on Russian oil imports, which is expected to be agreed within days.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were little changed on Monday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CDL reported a 41% drop in Q1 home sales, a decline from the same period last year. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of enterprises driving innovation and growth. Meanwhile, Asia-Pacific dividends rose 8.1% year-on-year to $33.9 billion, while Singapore stocks extended losses, down 0.58%.

images.alt_text: Hawkers are already feeling the pinch of rising cooking oil prices. The price of oils and fats was up by 9.9 per cent in April, while hawker fare was up by 4.2 per cent.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on Snap shock, growth fears
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 162.63 points or 0.51% to 31,717.61, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropping. The decline was driven by weak forecasts from companies, including Snapchat owner Snap Inc, which added to concerns about an inflation-struck economy.

site_title: Bank of England tells banks to take climate action now or face profit hit
summary: The Bank of England has urged banks and insurers to take immediate action to manage climate risks, warning that failure to do so could result in a 10-15% hit to annual profits and higher capital requirements. The central bank's first comprehensive stress test found that climate risks will become a persistent drag on banks' and insurers' profitability if they don't manage them effectively. The test, which tested 19 banks and insurers, found that total losses of $417 billion could occur over three decades if no action is taken.

images.alt_text: A visitor inspects an energy-efficient LED panel's construction at the LED (Light-Emitting Diodes) exhibition in Taipei, Taiwan.

site_title: Straco posts S$3m net loss in Q1 on China’s Covid-19 measures, Singapore Flyer closure
summary: Straco Corporation posted a net loss of S$3 million in its Q1, mainly due to negative revenue growth from its attractions and business interruptions from Covid-19 measures. The group's operations in China experienced short periods of service suspension, while its Singapore Flyer attraction closed temporarily due to a technical issue. Despite the losses, Straco's financial position remains strong with S$165.7 million in net cash holdings. The company expects sentiments to improve as Covid-19 measures are gradually eased.

images.alt_text: Singapore will strive to keep its borders open and stay connected to the rest of world even if a new variant of Covid-19 emerges, Transport Minister S Iswaran said.

Proposed in October 2019, the partnership would see SIA and MAB sharing revenue on flights between Singapore and Malaysia, expanding their code-share routes, and participating in joint marketing activities to develop tourism.

site_title: Why Asia must adapt to keep its global supply chain crown
summary: Asia's position as the global supply chain crown is under threat due to the pandemic's impact on regional economic growth and supply chain links. The region's dependence on Southeast Asia has exposed vulnerabilities, and businesses are rethinking supply chains, with 67% of Asia-Pacific executives taking steps to change supply chains. To maintain its global trade network, Asia must adapt by embracing complexity, investing in digital technologies, and adopting agile collaboration to provide real-time line of sight and better supply forecasting. This will enable the region to unlock end-to-end visibility, resilience, and sustainability into its supply chain operations.

images.alt_text: pudong, shanghai under lockdown

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.23 points to 1,531.30. The index saw 3.598 billion lots traded worth RM2.093 billion, with 696 losers and 247 gainers.

site_title: SPD Bank marks 5th anniversary by giving back
summary: SPD Bank, the Singapore branch of Shanghai Pudong Development Bank, marked its fifth anniversary by participating in the OneMillionTrees greening movement, planting 50 trees in Pasir Ris Park as part of the National Parks Board's initiative. The bank aimed to contribute to the Singapore Green Plan 2030 and demonstrate its commitment to sustainable financing. This event was part of the bank's CSR efforts, which also included distributing essential items to needy families through a partnership with social enterprise Glyph.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
Hsieh Fu Hua (right), chairman of SBF Foundation showing Chee Hong Tat around, along with Fong Yong Kian (middle), chief executive of Tote Board

site_title: China regulators vow to keep property sector credit growth stable
summary: China's financial regulators pledged to maintain stable credit growth in the property sector, deferring mortgage payments for homebuyers affected by COVID-19 outbreaks. Household loans, including mortgages, contracted by $32.6 billion in April, indicating a deep freeze in the property market. The central bank plans to use various tools to boost credit and support economic growth, including increasing lending for small firms, home businesses, and consumers. This move aims to mitigate the economic impact of pandemic control measures and stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore has seen an influx of wealth from Greater China in recent years.
China's property market woes are likely to worsen this year with prices remaining flat and sales and investment falling further, according to a Reuters poll.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde boosts euro as US dollar nurses wounds
summary: The euro rose to a one-month high after European Central Bank (ECB) president Christine Lagarde said interest rates in the euro zone will likely be in positive territory by the end of the third quarter, boosting appetite for the single currency. The euro was up 0.2% at $1.0707, while the US dollar fell to a fresh one-month low. Lagarde's comments, combined with resilient business activity data, capped gains ahead of the release of minutes from the Federal Reserve's May policy meeting.

site_title: UBS hopes to boost wealth management profits through private markets, digital client engagements
summary: UBS aims to boost wealth management profits through digital client engagements and private market products amid global uncertainties. The bank's global wealth management segment reported a 7% year-over-year decline in profit due to weak sentiment, attributed to pressures in Chinese markets and the war in Ukraine. To counter this, UBS plans to provide digital reports and information to clients, and has moved them into alternative investments such as private credit and private equity to diversify their portfolios.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: MAS and Swiss government body to promote data connectivity for financial services
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Swiss State Secretariat for International Finance (SIF) have issued a joint statement to promote data connectivity for financial services, aiming to foster growth and development of the global economy. The two parties recognize the importance of regulatory and policy frameworks that facilitate cross-border data transmission, storage, and processing. They seek to enable data flows, protect customer data and privacy, and balance growth with cybersecurity and operational risks. The goal is to create an environment for innovative, efficient, and consumer-focused global financial markets.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, in Singapore, on Wednesday, Oct. 27, 2021. Singapore is seeking to cement itself as a key player for crytocurrency-related businesses as financial centers around the world grapple with approaches to handle one of the fastest growing areas of finance. Photographer: Wei Leng Tay/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on May 24 due to concerns over China's economy, despite a new stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.75%, and the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined. The losses extended from the previous day. Fears about the impact of China's zero-Covid policy on growth persisted, causing investors to sell shares.

site_title: Global dividends: a dependable source of return in uncertain times
summary: Investors are seeking dependable sources of return in uncertain times, and dividend-paying equities may be a promising option. Historically, companies that pay high dividends have performed better during periods of high inflation, with a focus on dividends helping to mitigate inflation. The current dividend environment is favorable, with companies paying out nearly $1.3 trillion in dividends in 2022 and expected to see a 10% earnings growth in 2022. Low payout ratios and high cash reserves on company balance sheets also support the dividend outlook, making dividend-paying equities a potentially attractive strategy.

site_title: US business activity slows in May, survey shows
summary: US business activity slowed moderately in May due to higher prices cooling demand for services and renewed supply constraints from Covid-19 lockdowns in China and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The S&P Global flash US Composite PMI Output Index fell to 53.8, the slowest in 4 months, attributed to elevated inflationary pressures and weaker demand growth.

site_title: Asian owners commit to ‘greener shipping’
summary: The Asian Shipowners' Association (ASA) reaffirmed its commitment to protecting the environment and ensuring seafarers' welfare. At its annual general meeting, ASA emphasized the importance of greener shipping and the need for stability and transparency in pricing policies. The association expressed concerns over the Suez Canal's toll and surcharge increases and new toll system proposals by the Panama Canal Authority. ASA also welcomed a Memorandum of Understanding between the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) and the Suez Canal Authority, which aims to increase information sharing and negotiations on toll pricing, environmental protection, and decarbonization.

images.alt_text: The tragic situation in Ukraine has caused widespread disruption in the Black Sea and elsewhere, exacerbating ongoing supply chain, port congestion, and crew crisis issues caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Takeover loophole disadvantages minority shareholders of TTJ Holdings
summary: A loophole in Singapore's corporate takeover rules allows a major shareholder to acquire a minority stake without securing 90% of the minority shares, allowing for compulsory acquisition and delisting. This was illustrated in the case of TTJ Holdings, where the executive chairman plans to buy out minority shareholders at 23 cents per share through a shell company, despite the company's audited net asset value being 37 cents per share. The Securities Industry Council needs to close this loophole to protect minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: The executive chairman of mainboard-listed T T J Holdings is looking to take the structural steel specialist private at an offer price of S$0.23 per share.

site_title: Malaysia rules out curbs on cooking oil exports, minister says
summary: Malaysia's Plantation Industries and Commodities Minister Zuraida Kamaruddin has ruled out curtailing cooking oil exports due to sufficient supplies to meet local demand. Instead, the nation will focus on targeting subsidies to benefit the most needy consumers, aiming to fill the gap in the edible oil market caused by the Ukraine war and Indonesia's export curbs on palm oil. Malaysia's palm oil production is forecast to rebound to 23-25 million tons in 2022.

site_title: Energy management and efficiency by far the biggest green sector out there: FTSE Russell
summary: The energy management and efficiency sector has significantly outperformed other green sectors, growing from almost $1 trillion to $3 trillion in market capitalization between 2016 and 2021. Cloud computing, in particular, drove 61% of the sector's growth, while renewable energy equipment experienced modest growth, driven by solar companies such as LONGi Green Energy Technology and Enphase Energy. The sector's green exposure outperformed the wider market and the oil and gas sector, with the FTSE Environmental Opportunities All Share Index outperforming the FTSE Global All Cap Index by 9.7% over the last 3 years.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
renewable, energy, environment
Australians voted in a new government that has vowed to end decades of inaction by one of the world's highest per capita emitters. Now the fight is about just how quickly to make up for lost time.
Samsung Group will invest 450 trillion won (S$489.3 billion) in the next five years to accelerate growth in semiconductors, biopharmaceutical and other next-generation technologies.

site_title: The recipe for the outperformance of Swiss businesses
summary: Switzerland's corporate success can be attributed to its unique blend of common sense, low taxes, and openness to the world. The country's federal model, direct democracy, and weak central government create a light regulatory environment, attracting multinationals and foreign talent. Switzerland's welcoming nature, with foreigners making up half of its top CEOs, has contributed to its business success. The country's 26 cantons and 2,000 municipalities also compete to offer attractive business conditions, with some cantons offering lower corporate tax rates. Despite challenges, Switzerland's reputation as a hub for businesses is likely to endure.

images.alt_text: Neutral, inscrutable Switzerland was, perhaps more than any other country, presumed to be the treasure house of the Putin kleptocracy.
Switzerland would be less prone to serious producer price inflation and its currency, regarded as a haven, should do well in times of global trouble.
The post-neoliberal world isn’t all bad or all good — it’s just different. And crucially, it’s more of a reflection of realities on the ground.

site_title: Lufthansa bids with MSC for Alitalia successor ITA Airways
summary: Lufthansa has made a joint bid with MSC Mediterranean Shipping Company to acquire a 20% stake in ITA Airways, the successor to failed carrier Alitalia. This sets up a possible two-horse race against a group backed by Air France KLM, led by US-based investment firm Certares Management. The Italian administration is looking to sell ITA to shore up its balance sheet and repay state aid. The bid comes after ITA's management aims to secure an equity partnership by mid-2022, marking a major success for Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Lufthansa ordered 10 more Boeing cargo jets, as the carrier looks to keep pace with booming global demand for air freight services.

site_title: Net zero is 'biggest challenge' for aviation: Etihad CEO
summary: Etihad Airways CEO Tony Douglas stated that achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 poses the "biggest challenge" for commercial aviation. This target, also set by the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and the United Arab Emirates, is considered extremely difficult due to the physics of powered flight. Douglas emphasized the need for the aerospace sector to enable the next generation to achieve this goal, which will determine the winners and losers in commercial aviation.

site_title: Vietnam EV maker VinFast to shift HQ to Singapore ahead of IPO, first exports
summary: Vietnam-based electric vehicle maker VinFast is shifting its headquarters to Singapore ahead of a public listing and its first exports to US and European markets. The company, a unit of conglomerate Vingroup JSC, will start building its first SUV, the VF8, next week and begin producing its own EV batteries in August. VinFast plans to build a US$4 billion US factory by summer-end and has filed for an IPO in the US through a Singapore-based holding company, with plans to list in 2023 if market conditions permit.

images.alt_text: VinFast could seek US government financing for expansion: Vingroup chairman
The chairman of Vietnam's Vingroup conglomerate said on Wednesday that an initial public offering (IPO) for the company's auto unit, VinFast, may be delayed until next year due to market uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losses, STI down 0.58%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.58% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,195.04. Most index constituents ended in the red, led by DFI Retail Group's 2.55% drop. Jardine Matheson was the top gainer, rising 1.58%. Other Asian markets also declined, while Jakarta's Composite Index rose 1.07%. Economists attribute the losses to concerns over China's growth, with the authorities announcing another package to help businesses cope with virus restrictions.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Asian stocks retreated Tuesday on concerns over the impact of China's Covid restrictions on the world's second-largest economy as investment banks slashed their forecasts.

site_title: G7 moves from macroeconomic mandate to geopolitics
summary: The G7 is shifting its focus from macroeconomic policies to geopolitics, reflecting the growing influence of the Ukraine conflict. The group is exploring a plan to use Russian assets to rebuild Ukraine, a concept similar to the Marshall Plan. The agenda also includes strengthening financial stability and addressing a looming global hunger crisis, with an estimated 47 million people facing acute hunger due to the war. The G7's role as a geopolitical lynchpin has been highlighted by its involvement in the sanctions against Russia and its stance on Ukraine's borders, potentially leading to Russia's permanent exclusion from the group.

images.alt_text: United Nations Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres speaks during a courtesy visit to Borno State Governor Babagana Zulum in Maiduguri, Nigeria, May 3, 2022.

site_title: Structured thinking essential in choosing markets to commercialise in, business leaders say
summary: Business leaders from Scale-up SG companies emphasized the importance of structured thinking in choosing markets for commercialization, especially in the Asean region. The discussion, part of Enterprise Singapore's Scale-up Ignite event, highlighted the need for a long-term vision and mid-term deliverables in expanding into new markets. Companies such as Castlery, HMI Group, and MiRXES shared their experiences of adopting structured thinking, including analyzing logistics, target customer mapping, and systemically opening new markets. The event also highlighted the success of Enterprise Singapore's Scale-up SG programme, which has helped companies scale rapidly and expand abroad.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
