site_title: Yangzijiang Financial proposes adoption of share buyback mandate
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding, a spin-off from Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, plans to adopt a share buyback mandate at its June 8 extraordinary general meeting. The proposed mandate allows the company to buy back up to 10% of its issued ordinary shares, with a maximum purchase price of 105% of the average closing market price. The move aims to increase shareholders' value and improve return on equity, with the objective of enhancing earnings per share and net tangible assets per share.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Vincent Toe, chief executive officer of Yangzijiang Financial Holding
Vincent Toe, chief executive of Yangzijiang Financial Holding.

site_title: US: Stocks rally amid hopes market has bottomed
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the S&P 500 gaining 1.9% to 3,973.75, following hints that the US may end some tariffs on China, potentially ending the year's bearish trend. US President Joe Biden mentioned considering removing punitive import duties. Technical factors also suggested stocks may have reached a short-term bottom, setting the stage for a rebound. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 2.0% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.6%.

site_title: UK luxury brands urge government to bring back tax-free shopping
summary: A group of 250 luxury UK brands, including Burberry and Harrods, is urging the government to reintroduce tax-free shopping for tourists to boost the economy. The move would generate an additional £1.2 billion in annual retail sales and attract 600,000 more visitors. The UK is the only European nation without this perk, and the luxury industry believes it's crucial for the country to regain its status as the world's top luxury destination.

images.alt_text: Dufry's 2021 turnover rises 53%, far behind pre-pandemic levels
Luxury salespeople need to develop new skills, to become more agile, less focused on the brand, and more focused on customers.

site_title: Metech disposes of wastewater management subsidiary
summary: Metech International, a Catalist-listed company, is disposing of its 60% stake in wastewater management subsidiary Blufu Water (Xinmin) for S$618,000 to focus on its lab-grown diamond business. The sale will increase Metech's net tangible asset per share and widen its loss per share, as the company has no plans to expand the wastewater business. The disposal is not expected to result in a gain or loss on the company's books.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on banks, growth stocks boost
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by gains in growth and bank stocks, after hovering near a grim market milestone at the end of last week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 133.99 points, or 0.43%, to 31,395.89, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 18.06 points, or 0.46%, at 3,919.42. The Nasdaq Composite gained 41.66 points, or 0.37%, to 11,396.28.

site_title: GameStop launches wallet for crytpocurrencies and NFTs
summary: GameStop has launched a digital asset wallet allowing users to store, send, and receive cryptocurrencies and NFTs across decentralized apps. The self-custodial Ethereum wallet enables users to control their assets without a third party. The wallet extension can be downloaded from Google's Chrome web store and will facilitate transactions on GameStop's NFT marketplace, set to launch in the second quarter. This move aligns with Chairman Ryan Cohen's strategy to shift towards digital sales and away from brick-and-mortar stores.

site_title: Taiwan fails in bid to join WHO assembly amid heat from China
summary: Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) assembly was rejected due to diplomatic pressure from China, which considers Taiwan one of its own provinces. The decision was made after a proposal by 13 WHO members to allow Taiwan to join as an observer was excluded from the agenda. Taiwan's foreign ministry expressed "deep regret and dissatisfaction" and argued that China's objections have hindered global health efforts, particularly in fighting the Covid-19 pandemic. The US and Britain showed support for Taiwan's inclusion, but the decision was ultimately made by the WHO assembly president.

images.alt_text: “We agreed with the One China policy, we signed on to it... but the idea that (Taiwan) can be taken by force is just not appropriate," Biden said.

China said in a statement that naval and air force assets carried out drills from Friday to Sunday to the east and southwest of Taiwan to “further test and improve the joint combat capability of multiple services and arms”.

site_title: FOREX: Euro soars after Lagarde points to rate hikes, dollar extends slide
summary: The euro surged 1.1% to US$1.0687 after European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde signaled potential interest rate hikes by September, while the dollar slid 0.8% to 102.15. The euro has risen 3.3% since hitting a multi-year low on May 13, amid a calmer mood in European markets and pressure on the dollar. Analysts attribute the dollar's slide to a temporary correction, but note that the macroeconomic backdrop still points to downside risks for the euro.

images.alt_text: epa09969288 (L-R) European Commissioner for Economy Paolo Gentiloni, President of the European Central Bank (ECB) Christine Lagarde and German Finance Minister Christian Lindner speak at the start of the Eurogroup Finance Ministers meeting in Brussels, Belgium, 23 May 2022.  EPA-EFE/OLIVIER HOSLET
FILE PHOTO: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says that any hikes beyond zero would be dependent on the 'inflation outlook'.

European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde hinted on Wednesday the Frankfurt-based institution could raise its interest rates from historic lows as soon as July as inflation in the eurozone soars.

site_title: New centres open to offer both Covid-19 testing and vaccination
summary: Singapore has opened five new centres offering both Covid-19 testing and vaccination services, marking the next phase of the country's Covid-19 operations. The centres, which will be progressively opened from May 24, will conduct antigen rapid tests and polymerase chain reaction tests, and offer two vaccines each. The move comes as the majority of the population is now vaccinated, with vaccination centres expected to close from the end of May. The centres aim to scale up operations in case of new Covid-19 variants and can administer up to 4,500 vaccinations a day and run over 2,000 tests daily.

site_title: Philippines economy will continue to see strong growth under new administration: central bank chief
summary: The Philippines' central bank chief, Benjamin Diokno, is optimistic that the country's economy will continue to see strong growth under the new administration. Following a solid rebound last year, Diokno predicts annual growth of 6-7% in the coming years, driven by robust infrastructure projects and improved business sentiment. The central bank will work with the incoming government to boost financial stability and promote long-term development goals, including climate-friendly growth and financial inclusion.

images.alt_text: An egg stall in the main tourist area of Cordova town in Cebu, the Philippines. The Philippine economy outperformed expectations in the first quarter and grew at one of the fastest paces in the region. But the incoming administration under Ferdinand Marcos Jr faces a slew of challenges, including the need to boost government revenue and pare down its mounting debt.

site_title: EU oil embargo ‘in days’ as Ukraine isolation drives Russia closer to China
summary: The European Union is set to agree an oil embargo on Russia "within days" as a response to its invasion of Ukraine, with Germany's Economy Minister Robert Habeck stating that a breakthrough is imminent. The embargo comes as Russia seeks to strengthen its economic ties with China, amid growing isolation from the West. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has called for increased sanctions against Russia to deter other countries from using "brute force." The move follows a series of economic and diplomatic measures, including US President Joe Biden's comments on defending Taiwan against Chinese aggression.

images.alt_text: epa09968632 Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky delivers an address via videolink during the opening plenary session of the 51st annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, 23 May 2022. The forum has been postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic and was rescheduled to early summer. The meeting brings together entrepreneurs, scientists, corporate and political leaders in Davos under the topic 'History at a Turning Point: Government Policies and Business Strategies' from 22 to 26 May 2022.  EPA-EFE/GIAN EHRENZELLER

site_title: Stock selloff to intensify as fresh 10% plunge looms, survey finds
summary: US stocks are expected to experience a fresh slump, with the S&P 500 likely to decline by at least 10% from its current level, according to a survey of 1,009 respondents. The survey also found that 4% of respondents believe the S&P 500 has found a bottom for the year, while 47% expect a 30% decline from its peak. The Fed's hawkish policies, supply chain chaos, and business cycle threats are undermining confidence in Corporate America's profit machine, with equity valuations continuing to sink.

images.alt_text: blur, chart, computer
Keep investing in tranches and do not panic. This only works if you are invested in broadly diversified securities with a long track record

site_title: T-Mobile launches 5G products to compete with Verizon, AT&T for business clients
summary: T-Mobile has launched a suite of 5G products to compete with Verizon and AT&T for business clients. The product suite, called 5G advanced network solutions, offers three levels of service, from a complete private 5G network to sharing space over a public network. The company aims to capture market share despite being outdone by its rivals in spectrum. T-Mobile has signed up customers, including an automaker, airline operator, and theme park, without disclosing their names.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA'S 4 largest telecommunications firms are seeking a majority stake in a state 5G agency, countering a proposal by the government to offer them minority ownership, according to a letter sent by the firms to the finance ministry.

Deutsche Telekom reported quarterly core profit and revenue above market estimates on Friday, boosted by its US unit, T-Mobile, along with growth in its European business, and lifted its full-year outlook.

site_title: After US$5 trillion rout, emerging markets seek turnaround signal
summary: Emerging markets are seeing a potential buying opportunity after a $5 trillion rout, with stocks and bonds nearing their average valuations and yields reaching historic highs. Despite concerns about China's economy and the Federal Reserve's tightening policies, investors are gradually warming up to the asset class, with some money managers reducing their bearishness and others looking for signs of a turnaround, such as peak inflation and a halt to the dollar's rally.

images.alt_text: Investors find refuge from market turmoil in South-east Asia

site_title: Investcorp targets US$400 million at Indian school infrastructure, warehousing
summary: Bahrain-based Investcorp plans to deploy $400 million over 4 years into Indian school infrastructure and a booming warehousing sector, driven by e-commerce growth. The firm's co-CEO, Rishi Kapoor, cited the Indian middle class's prioritization of education for their children as an attractive investment opportunity. This marks Investcorp's expansion into real estate in India, following its previous investments in companies such as FreshToHome and ASG Eye Hospitals, totaling $500 million.

site_title: Malaysia aims to regain palm oil market share in EU amid global shortage
summary: Malaysia aims to regain its market share in the EU palm oil market, driven by a global shortage of edible oils and EU rules to phase out palm oil-based biofuels by 2030. The move comes amid boycotts of palm oil due to environmental concerns and exploitation of migrant workers. Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, plans to leverage the shortage and "political tension in Europe" to increase its market share and offset losses from EU regulations.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is not expecting a big downward adjustment to crude palm oil prices following Indonesia’s latest policy announcements.
Malaysia is still reviewing the viability of a temporary cut of a crude palm oil export tax, the Commodities Ministry said on Friday, after Indonesia lifted an export ban that has rattled the market.
Palm oil, used in everything from margarine to frying fats and shampoo, comprises a third of the world’s vegetable oil market, with Indonesia accounting for about 60 per cent of supply.

INDONESIAN lawmakers on Thursday (May 19) requested that the government review an export ban on palm oil, as industry groups warned that one of the country's leading economic contributors could grind to a halt in coming weeks as storage nears full capacity.

site_title: China plans tax relief of over 140 billion yuan to lift economy
summary: China plans to provide over 140 billion yuan (S$28.9 billion) in tax relief to companies and consumers to offset the economic impact of coronavirus lockdowns. The measures include additional tax rebates, cuts on passenger car purchase taxes, and extended social-insurance contributions. The goal is to stabilize the economy, with no direct household support announced. The tax relief is part of a larger 2.5 trillion yuan package announced in March, and the funding mechanism is unclear.

site_title: OUE and OUE Lippo Healthcare form joint venture with medical specialist groups in Singapore
summary: OUE and OUE Lippo Healthcare have formed a joint venture called Echo Healthcare Services with three medical specialist groups, Respiratory Medical Associates (RMA), The Respiratory Practice (TRP), and Thoracic & Cardiovascular Surgery Specialists (TCSS), in Singapore. The joint venture will hold a 60% stake in each medical specialist group and will be backed by a S$31 million investment. The partners will retain their clinical independence, and the transaction is expected to close by the end of Q3 2022.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
OUE Lippo Healthcare trims H2 loss to S$2.5m, swings back to black for full year
OUE Lippo Healthcare divests 12 nursing homes in Japan for S$163.5m

site_title: Marcos Jr wants ‘trade, not aid’ from US, open to economic pact
summary: Philippine President-elect Ferdinand Marcos Jr has expressed a desire to boost trade ties with the US instead of relying on aid, stating "trade, not aid" as his approach. He plans to attract private investments and joint ventures from the US, while also joining the US-led Indo-Pacific economic framework to counter China's influence. Marcos aims to revitalize the Philippine economy by moving public spending to more investment-led expenditures and is open to discussing a visiting forces agreement with the US. He also plans to study the revival of a nuclear power plant built during his father's term.

images.alt_text: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas increased the benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, it said in a statement on Thursday (May 19), as forecast by 14 of 21 economists in a Bloomberg survey. The rest forecast no change.

PHILIPPINES president-elect Ferdinand Marcos Jr on Wednesday (May 18) said his country's relations with China will expand and shift to a higher gear under his administration, and Beijing had assured him of its support for his "independent foreign policy".

site_title: Facebook-owner Meta to share more political ad targeting data
summary: Meta Platforms will share more data on targeting choices made by advertisers running political and social-issue ads in its public ad database, starting in July. The company will include detailed targeting information for these individual ads in its "Facebook Open Research and Transparency" database. This expansion aims to provide transparency around targeted advertising on its platforms, particularly around elections. The data will be available to vetted researchers since August 2020, and will show information on ad targeting for social issue, electoral, or political ads.

site_title: Thailand aiming to keep inflation under 5% this year, PM says
summary: Thailand aims to keep inflation below 5% this year, Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha said, amid surging fuel prices and a fragile economic recovery. The country's inflation rate rose 4.65% in April, down from a 5.73% jump the previous month. The government will manage prices and implement measures such as price controls and subsidies to slow inflation. Despite breaching the central bank's target range, interest rates are not expected to be raised soon due to the slow recovery.

site_title: Biden says he’ll review Trump’s China tariffs, fuelling yuan rally
summary: US President Joe Biden announced he will review tariffs imposed by the Trump administration on Chinese imports, sparking a 0.7% rally in the offshore yuan. The tariffs, which were imposed in 2018, are considered a major point of contention in US-China relations. Biden's decision comes as businesses have called for the removal of the levies. The move is seen as a positive development for China's economy, which has been experiencing growth despite easing lockdowns in Shanghai.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on Friday said it was worth considering taking steps to lower US tariffs on Chinese goods given the “desirable effects” such a move could have on lowering US inflation, which has hit 40-year highs this year.
US reinstates tariff exemptions on some Chinese products
Biden's frozen trade policy

site_title: Beijing sees record new cases of outbreak, fuelling lockdown angst
summary: Beijing reported a record 99 new Covid-19 cases, the largest daily tally since the outbreak, prompting authorities to urge residents to continue working from home to curb the spread. The city's total cases are still low, but the spike is a concern for China's "Covid Zero" approach, which has become increasingly controversial. China's Covid cases have declined recently, but officials are under pressure to prevent a rebound, particularly in Beijing, where clusters and sporadic infections have been reported.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect the current downturn will be harder to shake off than the one seen in early 2020.
pudong, shanghai under lockdown

site_title: Capitaland Integrated Commercial Trust renews leases with Temasek subsidiaries
summary: Capitaland Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) has renewed leases with Temasek subsidiaries, including StarHub, Temasek Foundation, and Certis Cisco. StarHub's lease renewal at Plaza Singapura will boost occupancy and income, while Temasek Foundation's renewal at Atrium@Orchard will also improve occupancy. A new service agreement with Certis Cisco will align technological infrastructure across CICT properties, optimizing operations and productivity gains. The leases were benchmarked against market standards and reviewed by independent valuers.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Long-term growth seen for travel industry despite short-term headwinds: S Iswaran
summary: Transport Minister S Iswaran notes that despite short-term headwinds, the travel industry is expected to see long-term growth due to pent-up demand. The tourism industry has historically been resilient, with people continuing to travel despite economic challenges, opting for shorter flights or regional trips. In Singapore, passenger traffic at Changi Airport has surpassed 50% of pre-pandemic volumes, indicating stronger-than-expected growth momentum. However, Iswaran warns that manpower and resource constraints will be a challenge to overcome, and the government is taking steps to incorporate lessons from the pandemic into future plans.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Singapore's Minister for Transport and Minister-in-charge for Trade Relations S. Iswaran delivers his opening address at the Changi Aviation Summit in Singapore on May 17, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP) (Photo by ROSLAN RAHMAN/AFP via Getty Images)

site_title: Supplementary Budget? Economists look to more policy moves to mitigate Singapore  inflation
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 3.3% in April, driven by high food and energy prices, with economists warning that inflation could persist in the near term due to elevated commodity prices and global logistics disruptions. Some economists suggest that the government may need to introduce targeted fiscal measures to assist lower-income households and vulnerable individuals with the rising cost of living. Monetary policy may not be sufficient to contain inflationary pressures, and fiscal support could be a welcome development to deal with rising food and energy prices.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Central banks have been forced to tighten monetary policy as inflation has risen, which may negatively affect economic growth.

Vendors selling fish at a street market in the Tondo district of Manila. Sonal Varma, an economist at Nomura, said that “we are still far from a recession, higher unemployment rate and double-digit inflation” in the region.

site_title: Hyflux’s pre-emptive lawsuit against Olivia Lum is on hold
summary: Hyflux's pre-emptive lawsuit against founder Olivia Lum has been put on hold until September 27, 2022, due to the liquidators' ongoing investigations. The High Court granted a temporary stay after the plaintiffs requested more time to investigate and seek legal advice. The lawsuit against Lum and former auditor KPMG was filed in March, but neither party has been served.
