site_title: Daimler Truck to take 9% stake in Germany's Manz in battery push
summary: Daimler Truck is acquiring a 9% stake in German engineering firm Manz for 30.6 million euros, focusing on battery production. Manz will issue 774,408 new shares at 39.53 euros apiece. The deal aims to strengthen Daimler Truck's position as a technology leader in lithium-ion battery production.

images.alt_text: Daimler truck gains in debut after split from Mercedes
Daimler cuts stake in Chinese electric-car venture with BYD

site_title: MCT, MNACT unitholders approve merger to create third largest Reit in Singapore
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) have unanimously approved a merger to create Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), one of Asia's 10 largest Reits. The merged entity will have a theoretical market capitalisation of S$10.5 billion, ranking it among the top 3 Reits listed in Singapore. Unitholders from both trusts voted in favour of the merger, with over 90% support from MCT and 99% support from MNACT. The merger is expected to be completed in early August, with MNACT set to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange in mid-August.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Mapletree's support for MCT-MNACT merger may raise expectations of other Reit sponsors

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close  lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.59 points lower, or 0.43%, at 1,542.53 on Monday. The index saw 3.379 billion lots traded at RM1.88 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 546 to 355.

site_title: Thailand central bank signals it's in no hurry to raise rates
summary: Thailand's central bank, Bank of Thailand, is confident that inflation will return to its target of 1-3% next year, despite prices hovering around a 13-year high. Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput stated that inflation is concentrated in energy and food, but does not see demand-side inflationary pressures. The bank has not raised interest rates, unlike some Asian central banks, and instead aims to support the economy's recovery. The bank's decision is seen as a sign that it is not in a hurry to change monetary policy settings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core consumer prices rose 3.3% in April, driven by increases in food, electricity, and gas costs. Rising cooking oil prices, up 9.9% in April, are affecting hawkers. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for global measures to combat inflation, despite the risk of recession. Meanwhile, Singapore has seen an influx of wealth from Greater China, with a pair of Chinatown shophouses up for sale at S$53 million.

images.alt_text: Shanghai, China’s financial hub with more than 28 million people, remains in lockdown for almost 2 months, though more residents are recently allowed to go out to shop for groceries.

site_title: Tesla plans to ramp up to pre-lockdown output in Shanghai by Tuesday: memo
summary: Tesla plans to restore production at its Shanghai plant to pre-lockdown levels by Tuesday, May 24, exceeding its previous recovery plan. The factory will more than double its daily output to 2,600 electric vehicles, bringing weekly output to nearly 16,000 units. The move comes after a two-week delay, due to challenges including insufficient workers, shipping obstacles, and restricted supplies of parts. Tesla had previously planned to return to pre-lockdown levels on May 16 but delayed the target.

site_title: UK CEO pay rebounds, gap widens with workers, says   report
summary: UK chief executives' pay is on track to exceed median employee earnings by more than before the pandemic, with a ratio of 63:1 in the first quarter of this year, up from 34:1 a year ago. This reversal comes as profits and executive bonuses rebound, reversing a trend that began during the pandemic. The widening pay gap comes as many British households struggle with a soaring cost of living, with over a quarter having skipped meals recently to save money.

images.alt_text: A Singapore-bound bus crossing the Causeway on Apr 3, after the land border with Malaysia fully reopened.
Chief executives at 13 STI companies receive higher remuneration in 2021

site_title: US’ Indo-Pacific economic pact of strategic, economic significance to region: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong welcomes the US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF), calling it a valuable platform for the US to exercise economic diplomacy in the region. The framework focuses on four key pillars: digital economy, supply chain resilience, clean energy, and a fair financial system. Lee sees the IPEF as a positive agenda for economic cooperation, particularly in the digital and green economies, and encourages its openness and inclusiveness to foster greater economic engagement between the US and the region.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Central banks have been forced to tighten monetary policy as inflation has risen, which may negatively affect economic growth.

China's development is positive for the region, but countries in the Asia-Pacific also want to maintain ties with other economies like Japan as well as the US and Europe, PM Lee said in an interview with Nikkei.

site_title: Global capital flows to real estate hit new high in Q1 2022: JLL
summary: Global capital flows to real estate reached a new high in Q1 2022, with US$292 billion in investment volumes, a 47% year-over-year increase. This is the most active first quarter on record, driven by diminishing operational uncertainty, robust demand, and abundant liquidity. Private investors played a larger role, representing over 43% of volumes. However, markets face headwinds from elevated inflation, geopolitics, and tightening monetary policy, and a degree of caution is now needed.

images.alt_text: Singapore commercial real estate recorded the highest investment growth, up 134% year-on-year to finish the first quarter with $5.7 billion.

site_title: HDB launching some 4,500 BTO flats including 2 PLH projects in May
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) announced that 4,500 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats, including two Prime Location Public Housing (PLH) projects, will be made available in May. The two PLH projects in Bukit Merah and Queenstown will offer 1,660 and 860 units, respectively, comprising 3-room and 4-room flats. These flats come with stricter buying and selling conditions, including a 10-year minimum occupation period and a subsidy clawback at the first resale transaction.

images.alt_text:
atplh - The first BTO project under the Prime Location Public Housing (PLH) model will be launched in Rochor next month, with a total of 960 units of 3-room and 4-room flats up for grabs as well as 40 units of 2-room rental flats, announced Minister of National Development, Desmond Lee.

copyright given by HDB

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid mixed regional showing; STI down 0.83%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.83% to 3,213.65, amid a mixed regional market performance. The index trended downward throughout the day, with losers beating winners 270-233. Core consumer prices in Singapore rose, with core inflation in April at its highest level since 2012. Regional markets reacted differently, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.19%, Jakarta's Composite Index down 1.12%, and Kuala Lumpur's Composite Index down 0.43%.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Hawkers are already feeling the pinch of rising cooking oil prices. The price of oils and fats was up by 9.9 per cent in April, while hawker fare was up by 4.2 per cent.
Shares of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding advanced in early morning trade on Wednesday.

site_title: Travellers in Asia-Pacific see higher fares than other regions amid travel recovery: Mastercard
summary: Travelers in the Asia-Pacific region experience higher fares compared to other regions, with airfares in Singapore averaging 27% above pre-pandemic levels. The increased cost of travel is driven by higher operating costs and supply-side constraints. Despite this, Mastercard expects 430 million more passengers to fly in the Asia-Pacific region if flight booking trends continue. The region is expected to see a strong rebound in travel, with leisure and business flight bookings exceeding 2019 levels. However, high inflation may weigh on consumers' purchasing power, particularly for discretionary purchases like travel.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Singapore's Changi Airport Terminal 2, which has been closed since May 2020, will be progressively opened from next Sunday (May 29).
Singapore had planned for air passenger volume to recover to 50 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by this year.
Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Monday, May 23, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.19% to 20,470.06. The decline was attributed to falls in tech titans Alibaba and Tencent. The Shanghai Composite Index ended flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.56%.

site_title: Keeping faith despite the market downdraft
summary: The S&P 500 has fallen 18.36% since the beginning of 2022 due to inflation, supply chain disruptions, and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Central banks have raised interest rates to combat inflation, but this may tip the global economy into recession. Despite this, experts believe that the markets will remain resilient and grow over the long term. Investors are advised to stay invested in diversified portfolios, maintain financial prudence, and review their investment strategies to mitigate risk. The focus should be on survival and financial well-being in the event of a catastrophic global economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Vendors selling fish at a street market in the Tondo district of Manila. Sonal Varma, an economist at Nomura, said that “we are still far from a recession, higher unemployment rate and double-digit inflation” in the region.

site_title: Tencent billionaire airs rare frustration during China slowdown
summary: Tencent billionaire Pony Ma expressed frustration over China's weakening economy under Covid Zero measures in a rare public opinion piece. Ma criticized Chinese internet users for taking online service providers for granted, saying they would rather see businesses fail than conduct layoffs. The comments came as Tencent reported no growth in Q1 revenue, missing estimates, and amid a government crackdown on the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Tencent slid as much as 8.4 per cent in early Hong Kong trading.
Chinese gaming and social media giant Tencent Holdings reported virtually no growth in first-quarterly revenue, its worst ever such performance.

site_title: India's Modi, Softbank's Son discuss more investments after big tech bets
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi met with SoftBank Group founder Masayoshi Son to discuss more investments by the country's biggest tech backer. The meeting comes amid a cooling startup boom in India and global economic worries. SoftBank has injected over $14 billion into India's tech industry, including in payments app Paytm. The talks focused on future investments in technology, energy, finance, and research and development. Son stated that India is growing quickly and becoming the third-largest generator of startups worldwide, with Modi expressing support for the startup sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi attends a news conference during the German-Indian government consultations at the Chancellery in Berlin, Germany May 2, 2022. REUTERS/Michele Tantussi/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Equities advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the open on May 23, despite concerns over elevated inflation and its impact on the economic outlook. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.8%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 1.4% and 0.7%, respectively.

site_title: Indonesia tech firm GoTo seeks approval to issue 118.44 billion shares
summary: Indonesia's tech firm GoTo Group plans to issue 118.44 billion shares, worth around 10% of its total capital, through a private placement. The move aims to raise funds for working capital and its subsidiaries, including e-commerce unit Tokopedia. The shares will be priced at least 90% of the average closing price of GoTo's shares for 25 consecutive trading days prior to the application. The company debuted on April 11 after raising $1.1 billion in an initial public offering.

site_title: Stagflation risk rising, but growth in Asia is still the base case scenario
summary: Economists warn of rising stagflation risk globally, but Asia's growth is expected to remain positive due to rebounding domestic demand. Stagflation, characterized by high inflation and low growth, is considered a "highest in decades" risk. However, Asia's Asean region is expected to avoid a recession, despite double-digit inflation, and maintain economic growth. Experts attribute this to the region's resilience and rebounding domestic demand, making stagflation a "base case scenario" for the region.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

This photo taken on May 10, 2022 shows woman selling fish at a street market in the Tondo district of Manila. - For Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr, who won the presidency in a landslide victory on May 9, the coming weeks and months will bring high expectations from poor supporters already disillusioned with a string of post-dictatorship governments, which many believe failed to materially improve their lives. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)

site_title: Putin rules Russia like an asylum
summary: Vladimir Putin rules Russia through coercion, using a system of punitive psychiatry to retain control and suppress dissent. Since 1969, the KGB's punitive psychiatry was used to produce a "lobotomised mass" of citizens, and Putin has revived this system, detaining and punishing dissidents, and using propaganda to block independent information. Many Russians live in poverty, and the country's middle class is largely compliant, with few questioning Putin's rule. Putin's grip on power is tenuous, with 41% of respondents wanting him to leave office after 2024, but he plans to prolong his murderous war in Ukraine to outlast his opponents.

images.alt_text: Vladimir Putin said on Monday Sweden and Finland joining Nato would be no threat to Russia but warned the Western alliance that moving troops or weapons into the Nordic neighbours would provoke a “response.”

site_title: Climate won Australia’s election; wielding power will be harder
summary: Australia's Labor Party won the general election, with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese leading the party to victory. The election marked a significant shift, as the right-of-centre Liberal-National Coalition was ousted after nine years in power. Albanese's victory was seen as a response to voters' concerns, but it remains to be seen whether he can deliver on his promises and effectively wield power.

images.alt_text: Anthony Albanese, leader of Australia's Labor Party is accompanied by his partner Jodie Haydon and son Nathan Albanese while he addresses his supporters after incumbent Prime Minister and Liberal Party leader Scott Morrison conceded defeat in the country's general election.

site_title: Lagarde signals end to ECB negative interest rates by September
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde signals the end of negative interest rates by September, citing soaring inflation in the eurozone. The ECB will likely exit negative interest rates by the end of the third quarter, with a potential rate hike in July. The initial rate hike would be the ECB's first in over a decade, lifting rates from their current historically low levels. The decision will depend on the inflation outlook, with further increases considered if the forecasted rate of inflation stabilizes around the ECB's two-per cent target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde t in Brussels, Belgium February 6, 2020. REUTERS/Francois Lenoir/File Photo

site_title: Bitcoin recovers after longest run of weekly losses since 2011
summary: Bitcoin has recovered after its longest run of weekly losses since 2011, rising 1.7% to $30,425. The largest digital token had fallen for seven consecutive weeks following the collapse of the TerraUSD algorithmic stablecoin. Experts, such as Fundstrat's Mark Newton, believe the decline in the S&P 500 could trigger a buying opportunity for Bitcoin in the next couple of months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Souvenir tokens representing cryptocurrency Bitcoin plunge into water in this illustration taken May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The current crypto crash could be a new bullish signal for Bitcoin, and possibly Ethereum, as extreme volatility brings a sharper focus to the market.
The biggest paper loss has been to the fortune of Pete Bodharamik, who controls the parent company, broadband-network provider Jasmine International, founded by his father.

site_title: Biden says US would defend Taiwan militarily from invasion
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that the US would defend Taiwan militarily if Beijing invaded the self-ruled island, warning China is "flirting with danger." Biden emphasized that the US agreed with the One China policy but would not allow Taiwan to be taken by force. He linked the potential US response to lessons learned in Ukraine, stating that China should pay a price for attempting to take Taiwan by force. Biden signaled that an invasion is unlikely but depends on the world making clear that there will be consequences.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a joint news conference with US President Joe Biden after their bilateral meeting at Akasaka Palace in Tokyo, Japan, May 23, 2022.
Space is a key area of cooperation for Japan with the United States, its closest ally, amid heightened tensions with an increasingly assertive China, which itself aims to become a space power.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.98% to 27,001.52, and the Topix index climbing 0.92% to 1,894.57. Investors focused on growth stocks and steady US futures gains.

site_title: Suburban condos can continue to outperform prime ones
summary: Suburban condominiums in Singapore continue to outperform prime ones in terms of price growth, driven by factors such as better connectivity, amenities, and regulations. According to data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority, prices of private non-landed homes in the outside central region (OCR) rose by 14.7% in Q1 2022, while those in the core central region (CCR) rose by 3.4%. Regulations, including the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) and upcoming property tax hikes, also favor OCR. As suburban living continues to improve, it is expected to remain a more affordable option for homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
URA said future residents at all 3 sites will enjoy direct access via public transport to Woodlands Regional Centre, the Central Business District and various parts of Singapore.
Price growth of private homes slows in Q1 after cooling measures, even as levels hit new high

site_title: ECB splinters over powers to police banks’ net-zero transition
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is divided over its new power to oversee banks' net-zero transition plans, with some regulators skeptical that climate risks warrant new rules. The ECB will take on this role by 2025, but some national officials are concerned that it exceeds the central bank's mandate and could steer credit away from certain industries. The debate centers on whether the ECB should require banks to implement mitigating measures to address climate-related risks, with some arguing that it oversteps its mandate and others seeing it as necessary to ensure the financial system's safety and soundness.

images.alt_text: The ECB plans to force global investment banks to relocate senior staff and trading activity to the eurozone.

site_title: Pair of Chinatown shophouses up on the market with S$53m guide price
summary: A pair of freehold Chinatown shophouses in Singapore, located along Pagoda Street, has been put up for sale via public tender with a guide price of S$53 million. The 3-storey shophouses, rebuilt in 1995, offer a combined land area of approximately 2,493 sq ft and a total floor area of 8,220 sq ft. The property is zoned for commercial use, accessible to the Downtown Line and North-East Line MRT Station, and is just a 5-minute walk from the Central Business District. The sale is open to foreigners and companies, with no Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty or Seller’s Stamp Duty payable.

images.alt_text: Bukit Sembawang Estates' Liv @ MB sold more than 75 per cent of its 298 units on its launch weekend.

site_title: China bill yields slump as lenders ‘window dress’ loan books
summary: China's economic growth has slowed due to widespread lockdowns in Shanghai, making it challenging for banks to meet lending targets. To compensate, lenders have turned to buying low-risk short-term financial instruments, known as banker's acceptance bills, which has pushed yields near zero. This practice, known as "window dressing," allows banks to artificially inflate their lending volumes, distorting interest rates and undermining the effectiveness of China's monetary policy. As a result, commercial paper yields have slumped, and new lending in China has plummeted 80% from March.

images.alt_text: A barricade formed by shared bicycles at an entrance to a closed Bank of Nanjing branch during a lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai, China.
Starting in June, Shanghai will put areas of the city into high-, medium- or low-risk categories.

site_title: Downton Abbey 2 starts strong with US$16m as Doctor Strange rules again
summary: "Downton Abbey: A New Era" starts strong at the box office, earning US$16 million from 3,815 North American theatres in its domestic debut, marking an encouraging start for the sequel. The film, a sequel to the 2019 hit, follows the wealthy Crawley family as they uncover a mystery in the South of France. It ranks second at the box office behind Disney's "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness," which added US$31.6 million. The sequel's performance is a testament to the enduring popularity of the original series, with nearly half of ticket buyers being 55 and older.

images.alt_text: Cast member Benedict Cumberbatch attending the premiere of the film "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness" in Los Angeles on May 22.

site_title: Thai Q1 jobless rate drops to 1.53% as Covid-19 curbs eased
summary: Thailand's unemployment rate dropped to 1.53% in the first quarter, the lowest since the pandemic, following the easing of coronavirus restrictions and reopening to foreign tourists. The number of jobless workers decreased to 610,000, down from 1.64% in the previous quarter. This decrease is attributed to the country's economic recovery, with tourism and other sectors experiencing growth. The low unemployment rate indicates a strong labor market, which bodes well for Thailand's economic growth and stability.

site_title: Paris tourism rebounds as Europeans and Americans return
summary: Paris tourism is experiencing a rebound as European and American visitors return after two years of COVID-19 restrictions. The city is now the second-most sought-after destination worldwide, with booking aggregator Trivago stating that London is the top destination. Hotel room rates and occupancy have increased significantly, with average prices rising 17% from 2019 to 173 euros per night in April. This surge is attributed to the lifting of travel restrictions and the desire for international travel after the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Diners at the new Pizzeria L'Elementare, which serves up thin-crust pizzas and craft beers, in Rome on May 5.

site_title: UK housing market frenzy shows signs of slowing, Rightmove says
summary: UK housing market prices reached a new record for the fourth consecutive month, with asking prices increasing 2.1% in May, the highest since 2014. This marks a £55,551 jump since the pandemic, more than 10 times the previous two years' increases. The Bank of England's efforts to quell inflation are being tested, with interest rates raised at each of its past meetings, adding to a cost-of-living squeeze. Experts predict the market will moderate later this year due to increased supply and affordability concerns.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won gain as US weighs tariff cut on China imports
summary: South Korean shares rose to their highest close in nearly three weeks, with the benchmark Kospi increasing 8.09 points, or 0.31%, to 2,647.38. The won also gained, lifted by US President Joe Biden's comment that the US may cut tariffs on Chinese imports. Foreigners were net sellers of 28.9 billion won worth of shares, but the won reversed earlier losses on the possible tariff cuts.

images.alt_text: epa08171648 A person wearing a protective mask works in front of monitors, displaying the KOSPI, at the KEB Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 28 January 2020. The benchmark South Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) plunged 69.41 points, or 3.09 percent, to close at 2,155.07. Reports blamed the decline on concerns over the spread of the coronavirus.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN

site_title: Davos and the new era of deglobalisation
summary: The World Economic Forum in Davos is set to discuss deglobalisation, with many economists predicting doom due to decoupling between China and the US. However, experts argue that this new reality presents opportunities for growth and resilience, particularly in emerging markets and through decentralized technologies. Decoupling is not inevitable, and the shift towards local production and knowledge-intensive businesses could lead to new development models and industries. The post-neoliberal world is not all bad or all good, but rather different, and it's essential to question conventional economic wisdom and adapt to new realities.

images.alt_text: hands, world, map
Delegates at the WEF this year will be more likely to be packing sandals than ski boots as Davos hosts a warmer, springtime version of the flagship networking forum.

site_title: Broking firms should play a bigger role in preserving market integrity
summary: Brokerages play a crucial role in preserving market integrity, particularly in a disclosure-based market that relies on "caveat emptor." The 2013 penny stock crash, which wiped out S$8b in market value, highlights the need for tighter internal controls to prevent similar incidents. Brokers should utilize surveillance handbooks and the member surveillance dashboard to detect market misconduct, such as spoofing and wash trades. They should also tighten in-house compliance and lending rules, especially for high-risk stocks, and encourage research analysts to consider ESG factors in their recommendations.

images.alt_text: $8b penny stock crash trial. Quah Su-Ling (picture), along with John Soh Chee Wen, are accused of masterminding Singapore’s most serious case of stock market manipulation.
Quah Su-Ling (left) and John Soh Chee Wen are accused of masterminding Singapore’s most serious case of stock market manipulation.

site_title: US unveils Asia-Pacific trade framework, but questions remain
summary: US President Joe Biden unveiled the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) in Tokyo, with 13 countries including India and Japan signing up. The framework aims to integrate partners through agreed standards in digital economy, supply chains, clean energy, and anti-corruption measures, without negotiating tariffs. The US has pushed to rebuild strategic military and trade alliances weakened under former President Donald Trump, offering an alternative to China's growing presence in the Asia-Pacific. However, questions remain about the pact's effectiveness, with concerns over enforcement mechanisms and incentives for US participation.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks about the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity at the Izumi Garden Gallery in Tokyo on May 23, 2022. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

site_title: Britons party for the Queen - but not the monarchy
summary: Britons are celebrating Queen Elizabeth's 70 years on the throne with a Platinum Jubilee, featuring 10,000 performers, including students from diverse backgrounds. Despite her popularity, many people, particularly younger generations and ethnic minorities, express ambivalence or even skepticism about the monarchy. Research suggests that 58% of people believe the institution should continue, but 25% think it's time for Britain to become a republic. The event aims to showcase the country's diverse cultures and bring the nation together, but some attendees, including a Jamaican-born man, question the monarchy's relevance and legacy after the queen's passing.

images.alt_text: Elizabeth II marks Platinum Jubilee with 'Queen Camilla' announcement
Prince Harry, Meghan make first public appearance in Europe since royal exit

site_title: UK's cost-of-living gap between rich and poor hits record
summary: The UK's cost-of-living gap between the rich and poor has reached a record high, with the poorest tenth of households experiencing inflation of 10.2%, compared to 8.7% for the richest. This is the widest gap in at least 16 years, driven by soaring energy bills and higher food costs. The Resolution Foundation is calling for targeted support for low-and-middle-income households through the existing benefits system, including increased universal credit and state pension. The Chancellor is urged to prioritize support for these households to alleviate the pressure of rising costs.

images.alt_text: Shoppers pass a clothing store with sale items in the window on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Britain’s worst bout of inflation in 40 years is quickly becoming a crisis both for Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government and the Bank of England. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Beyond ‘isolationism’ and ‘internationalism’
summary: The US Senate has passed a $54 billion aid package to Ukraine, with bipartisan support, after a trip by Republican Senators to Ukraine expressing support for President Zelensky. However, 11 Republicans opposed the aid package, sparking concerns about rising isolationist tendencies in the GOP. Critics argue that opponents of US involvement in the Ukraine conflict are not necessarily isolationists or pro-Putin, but rather have differing views on US foreign policy priorities and the definition of national interests. The debate reflects a broader consensus on protecting US national interests through maintaining the balance of power in Europe and Asia.

images.alt_text: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner was quoted as saying there was also a discussion among Western powers about how Russia could be made to help pay for the massive, longer-term task of rebuilding Ukraine.

site_title: Indonesia set to resume palm oil exports but policy uncertainty persists
summary: Indonesia is set to resume palm oil exports on May 23 after a 3-week ban to control local cooking oil prices. The country aims to retain 10 million tonnes of cooking oil supplies at home through a Domestic Market Obligation (DMO) policy, which will regulate production and sales. Industry traders await details on the accompanying rules, and the move has led to a 1.67% rise in Malaysian palm oil futures. The average price of bulk cooking oil in Indonesia remains at 17,000 rupiah per litre, and some farmers have welcomed the end of the export ban, citing stabilized palm fruit prices.

images.alt_text: Palm oil, used in everything from margarine to frying fats and shampoo, comprises a third of the world’s vegetable oil market, with Indonesia accounting for about 60 per cent of supply.

site_title: Billionaire Richard Li’s FWD wins nod for Hong Kong IPO: source
summary: FWD Group, backed by billionaire Richard Li, has received approval for its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The company is seeking to raise approximately $1 billion in its Hong Kong offering, after previously filing for an IPO in the US that could have raised up to $3 billion. FWD will now decide on a launch date following a hearing with the Hong Kong bourse's listing committee.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,247.80 points on Monday, driven by gains from investment holding company HGH Holdings and Sembcorp Marine. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 31, with 93.2 million securities worth S$46.8 million changing hands. This follows a mixed US market, where stocks ended the week down but on uncertain note. European shares closed higher on Friday, boosted by defensive sectors, while Asian markets opened higher following the mixed US market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Notably, China's Loan Prime Rate cut exceeded market expectations.

site_title: BMW exploring energy investments to reduce dependence on natural gas
summary: BMW is exploring investments in solar, geothermal, and hydrogen energy to reduce its dependence on natural gas. The carmaker's production chief warned that an embargo on Russian gas would bring the industry to a standstill, highlighting the need for alternative energy sources. BMW plans to add solar panels to its plants and develop hydrogen transport plans, with a new plant in Hungary set to run entirely without fossil fuels. The company aims to rely on regenerative energy sources, including nuclear energy, to stabilize its production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BMW logo is seen during the 2016 New York International Auto Show in Manhattan, New York, March 24, 2016. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz/File Photo

site_title: Australian markets assume business as usual under new government
summary: Australia's Labor Party won the general election, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison conceding defeat. The market reaction was muted, with the outcome already priced in, and no significant change in economic course expected. The new government is expected to maintain a majority and avoid a hung Parliament. Economic forecasts remain unchanged, with no major implications for the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate decisions. The Australian dollar strengthened slightly, while the ASX 200 share index and debt markets showed little reaction to the election outcome.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Monday, lifted by mining stocks.

Newly sworn-in Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (left) shakes hands with Australian Governor-General David Hurley  during a swearing-in ceremony at Government House in Canberra, Australia, May 23, 2022.
RBA  projected its A$600-billion (S$584 billion) balance sheet would remain large for some years to come as bonds it bought under quantitative easing slowly mature.

site_title: Singapore core inflation hits 3.3% in April
summary: Singapore's core consumer prices rose to 3.3% in April, its highest level since early 2012, driven by increases in food, oils and fats, and electricity and gas prices. Private transport costs, excluding car prices, rose 18.3% in April, while accommodation costs increased 3.9%. Experts predict private transport and accommodation inflation will remain firm in the near term. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry expect core inflation to remain above historical average through the year.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Central banks have been forced to tighten monetary policy as inflation has risen, which may negatively affect economic growth.
The analyst consensus is for tougher central bank action in the second half of 2022.
First Resources and Golden Agri-Resources were among the potential winners named by CGS-CIMB.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, May 23, 2022, following a mixed close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng fell 0.52% to 20,608.65, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.12%. Investors are weighing concerns over inflation and economic growth.

site_title: With US help, Japan aims to go from player to power in space
summary: Japan is teaming up with the US to become a space power, following China's efforts to achieve the same goal. As part of NASA's Artemis program, Japan aims to send its first astronaut to the lunar surface by the late 2020s. Japan has an extensive space program, but currently relies on US and Russian help for human spaceflight. This cooperation is seen as a response to China's growing space ambitions and a way for Japan to increase its influence in the space industry.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks to reporters before departing the Osan Air Base in Pyeongtaek, South Korea on May 22, 2022.

site_title: Australia: Miners lift shares; new Labor PM Albanese sworn in
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, lifted by mining stocks, which touched a two-week high after iron ore prices surged. Labor Party leader Anthony Albanese was sworn in as the country's 31st prime minister, vowing to tackle climate change and rising living costs. Key mining stocks such as BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group rose 0.1-2.6%. Energy stocks also gained 0.3% due to strong oil prices, while technology stocks declined 0.2%.

site_title: In Tokyo, Biden endorses Japan’s plan to beef up its defences
summary: US President Joe Biden has endorsed Japan's plan to boost its defense capabilities, committing to work closely with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to counter China's growing influence in Asia. During a bilateral meeting, Biden expressed support for Japan's efforts to strengthen its defense and praised the US-Japan alliance as the cornerstone of peace and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific region. The two leaders also discussed China's "increasingly coercive behavior" and Japan's potential membership in the UN Security Council, with Biden expressing support for the latter.

site_title: Paytm payments bank expects central bank curbs to be lifted in 3 to 5 months
summary: Paytm Payments Bank expects the Reserve Bank of India to lift central bank curbs on it in 3-5 months, allowing it to take on new customers after a comprehensive audit of its IT systems. The bank is working with the RBI to address regulatory concerns, with CFO Madhur Deora stating the process will take 3-5 months. Paytm aims to achieve profitability by September 2023 and is seeing growth in high-margin businesses.

images.alt_text: Paytm aims to break even in under 2 years

site_title: Datapulse records 3 straight years of losses, at risk of joining SGX’s watch list
summary: Datapulse Technology reported its third consecutive year of pre-tax losses, based on audited full-year consolidated accounts. The company's average daily market capitalization of S$22.1 million over the last 6 months puts it at risk of being included in the SGX watch list, which requires 3 consecutive years of pre-tax losses and an average daily market capitalization below S$40 million.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS starts coverage on Civmec with ‘buy’, S$0.88 target
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Civmec with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.88, representing a 36% upside. The research house believes Civmec's strong economic outlook, orderbook, and diversified sectors such as infrastructure and defence will drive steady earnings growth. Civmec's robust orderbook of A$1.07 billion and its proximity to growing capex in the new economy sectors, including lithium and hydrogen energy projects, are seen as key drivers of growth.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Civmec reports 50.1% rise in H1 net profit; declares dividend
CONSTRUCTION and engineering group Civmec can likely ride on its strong orderbook as well as rising investments in the resources and energy sectors to post a positive growth outlook, Maybank said.
Brokers' take: UOBKH initiates Civmec at 'buy' with S$0.98 target price

site_title: Argentina reports first suspected case of monkeypox, no confirmed cases in Latin America yet
summary: Argentina's health ministry reported a suspected case of monkeypox in Buenos Aires, with the patient in good condition and isolated for testing. This marks the first suspected case in Argentina, with no confirmed cases in Latin America. The patient had recently traveled to Spain and the case is being monitored by the World Health Organization.

site_title: Grab launches investment product Earn+, brings financial services under new brand GrabFin
summary: Grab launches Earn+, its second investment product, under the GrabFin brand, offering users a 2-2.5% projected yield with no lock-in period. The service, available to all users by the end of the week, allows users to invest with a minimum of S$1 and withdraw funds at any time. A 0.59% annual fee applies, and the product is suitable for first-time investors with short-term goals. This marks Grab's latest foray into digital investment services, following the launch of AutoInvest in 2020.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The headquarters of Grab Holdings Ltd., in Singapore, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Grab Holdings Ltd., is expected to report results on May 19. Photographer: Bryan van der Beek/Bloomberg
Gig workers and low income groups in Malaysia are often neglected groups that are underserved by conventional banks.
Grab-Singtel is among 5 winners of Malaysia's digital bank licences.
Grab and Sea winning the Malaysia digital bank licence raises questions if attentions will be turned away from Singapore

A GrabFood delivery man walking past the company logo in the new Grab office at Marina One West Tower on May 28, 2018. Ride-hailing app Grab holds a media briefing to share about its plans and direction.##########ECSILICON##########KEVIN LIM
The headquarters of Grab Holdings Ltd., in Singapore, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Grab Holdings Ltd., is expected to report results on May 19. Photographer: Bryan van der Beek/Bloomberg

site_title: Creating sustainable enterprises with digital technology and greener supply chains
summary: Tata Communications' Amitabh Sarkar emphasizes the importance of integrating sustainability into digitalization efforts to combat climate change. 97% of business leaders worldwide acknowledge climate change's negative impact on their companies. Digital technology can significantly reduce carbon emissions, with Asia Pacific's emissions decreasing by 0.43 billion metric tons in 2020. Enterprises can create a greener supply chain by assessing suppliers' environmental compliance and sourcing low-carbon solutions. Digital technologies, such as IoT, AI, and machine learning, can monitor energy consumption and improve energy efficiency, enabling enterprises to reduce carbon emissions and create a more sustainable future.

images.alt_text: Controversies to do with unclear rules in the carbon market still occasionally make headlines.
At CGS-CIMB, the team of more than 70 writing analysts filter their research with an ESG lens.

site_title: New Hong Kong leader’s vow to fix housing crisis draws sceptics
summary: Hong Kong's new leader, John Lee, has vowed to address the city's housing crisis, but analysts remain skeptical. With soaring property prices and a lack of affordable housing, Lee faces a significant challenge in taming the market without alienating property developers. His plan to simplify the land and housing development process and increase public housing supply may not be enough to alleviate the crisis, and Beijing's influence on policy decisions may limit his ability to make meaningful changes. Experts predict that home prices will continue to rise, with some forecasting a 10% increase this year.

images.alt_text: HONG KONG'S unemployment rate surged to 5.4 per cent for the 3 months ended April as the city's Covid restrictions continued to weigh on businesses and keep people at home.

HONG KONG'S new listings volume plunged 90 per cent to a nine-year low this year, data showed, as China's sharp economic slowdown and its regulatory drive cast a long shadow over the city's prospects as a destination for initial public offerings (IPOs).

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as inflation fears weigh
summary: Asian stocks were mixed Monday due to inflation fears and concerns about low economic growth. The release of notes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting on Wednesday is expected to provide clues on further rate hikes by the US central bank. Wall Street ended the week flat, with the S&P 500 down about 19% from its January high. Investors await GDP data in Singapore and look to the US-EU trade talks for direction.

images.alt_text: Asian markets opened higher Friday, as bargain-hunters capitalised on the battering Wall Street took the day before after decades-high inflation sparked recession fears.

site_title: Global measures to tackle inflation may cause recession, but must be taken: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong says global measures to tackle inflation may lead to a recession, but action must be taken to prevent severe inflation. He notes that high inflation poses a significant threat to the world economy, and sustained growth has been driven by expansion of debt and loose monetary policy for the past 15 years. Loong emphasizes that the risks of recession must be weighed against the risks of severe inflation, and that decisive action is necessary to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Hawkers are already feeling the pinch of rising cooking oil prices. The price of oils and fats was up by 9.9 per cent in April, while hawker fare was up by 4.2 per cent.

site_title: Global elites return to Davos under Ukraine storm
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has resumed its annual Davos summit, taking place after a 2-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, amidst the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict. The summit, themed "History at a Turning Point," will focus on the economic and political fallout from the crisis, with Ukrainian leaders and experts attending to plead their case. The event will also address climate change, inflation, and economic recovery, with over 50 heads of state or government, business leaders, and academics in attendance.

images.alt_text: Delegates at the WEF this year will be more likely to be packing sandals than ski boots as Davos hosts a warmer, springtime version of the flagship networking forum.

site_title: Nio to be included in Hang Seng composite, tech indexes
summary: NIO, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, will be included in the Hang Seng Composite Index and Hang Seng Tech Index starting June 13. The move comes after the company's recent listing in Singapore by way of introduction. NIO's inclusion in these indexes will provide increased visibility and access to a broader market.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
FILE PHOTO: A NIO EP9 electric car is displayed at its store in Beijing, China August 20, 2020. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Gold hits over 1-week high as dollar dips
summary: Gold prices reached a one-week high on Monday, rising 0.3% to $1,850.39 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar. The dollar's decline, following its first weekly loss in nearly two months, made gold more attractive for overseas buyers. However, rising US Treasury yields capped gains, limiting demand for zero-yield gold. The move was seen as a positive sign for the metal, which tends to become less attractive when interest rates are raised.

images.alt_text: Gold prices on Friday hovered near a 1-week high scaled in the previous session, and were set for their first weekly gain since mid-April, as the US dollar receded from 2-decade highs, reviving demand for safe-haven bullion.

site_title: Singapore’s half-open nightclubs signal a sad, weird new normal
summary: Singapore's nightclub scene has reopened, with some venues offering limited services, while others have remained shut due to flouting "intermingling" rules. The country has lifted many pandemic restrictions, including mask mandates and group size limits, but some citizens remain cautious, with many still wearing masks outdoors. Authorities have appealed for firms to hire workers in pandemic-related roles, as the country seeks to reap economic benefits from its reopening. However, concerns about a potential new wave of cases and the risk of backtracking remain.

images.alt_text: The relaxation of Covid-19 measures gives existing retailers, as well as new-to-market entrants greater confidence in their expansion plans.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.24 points or 0.40% to 1,555.36 on Monday, driven by a higher trading volume of 511.19 million lots worth RM122.26 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 218 to 148, marking a positive start to the week.

site_title: Amazon aims to sublet, end warehouse leases as online sales cool: sources
summary: Amazon plans to sublet at least 10 million square feet of warehouse space, roughly equivalent to 12 of its largest fulfillment centers, as online sales cool. The company may end leases with landlords, including Prologis, and could vacate even more space. This move comes as Amazon seeks to trim costs associated with excess capacity, which was built up during the pandemic. The company has declined to confirm the amount or specific locations, but subleasing is a common real estate practice that allows companies to manage their portfolios.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com has held preliminary discussions with Metropolis, according to a source.

site_title: Oil climbs in tight market as US driving season looms
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by US fuel demand, tight supply, and a weaker US dollar. Brent crude futures increased 82 cents to $113.37 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose 69 cents to $110.97 a barrel. Analysts attribute the gains to solid demand ahead of the US peak driving season, despite concerns about soaring fuel prices potentially impacting demand. However, market gains are capped by ongoing lockdowns in China and the European Union's inability to agree on banning Russian oil.

images.alt_text: The PCK Schwedt oil refinery, operated by PCK Raffinerie GmbH which is controlled by Rosneft Oil Co., in Schwedt, Germany, on Monday, May 9, 2022. A plan to ban Russian oil imports by the end of the year threatens to choke off supplies to the facility in the small town of Schwedt, which would cripple Berlin and much of eastern Germany in the process. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: India's top crypto app CoinSwitch calls for regulatory 'peace, certainty'
summary: India's top crypto app CoinSwitch CEO Ashish Singhal called for regulatory clarity to resolve uncertainty and protect investors in the sector. Despite the central bank's opposition to a ban on cryptocurrencies, the government's decision to tax income from them has been seen as a sign of acceptance. Singhal expressed concerns over the lack of clear rules, stating that users are uncertain about the future of their holdings. He emphasized the need for regulation to boost the crypto sector and protect investors, highlighting the importance of establishing clear guidelines.

images.alt_text: Crypto payments frozen across India, hitting trading

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after mixed US close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 23, 2022, following a mixed US market. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.99% to 27,003.07, while the Topix index gained 0.84% to 1,893.22. Analysts expect the day's trade to remain within a narrow range.

site_title: Australia finally gets its decisive climate change election
summary: Australia's Labor Party, led by Anthony Albanese, has won the country's election, vowing to end decades of inaction on climate change. Albanese has pledged to reduce Australia's emissions by 43% by 2030 and reach net-zero by 2050, aiming to become a renewable energy superpower. However, climate activists and some lawmakers are demanding more ambitious targets, and tensions have emerged over the need for a comprehensive plan to transition away from fossil fuels. The new government will face pressure to balance its climate goals with the interests of the fossil fuel industry and its pro-coal mining base.

images.alt_text: Albanese and key ministers are expected to be sworn in on Monday (May 23), just in time to attend a summit with Japanese, Indian and US leaders.
Polls opened in Australia’s federal election on Saturday, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison fighting for another three-year term.

site_title: WHO expects more cases of monkeypox to emerge globally
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) expects more cases of monkeypox to emerge globally as it expands surveillance in non-endemic countries. As of May 21, 92 confirmed and 28 suspected cases have been reported from 12 countries, with human-to-human transmission occurring among symptomatic individuals in close physical contact. The virus is spread through close contact and can be contained through self-isolation and hygiene measures. WHO officials emphasize that vaccines are available, but the key to protection lies in avoiding close contact with others.

images.alt_text: The palms of a monkeypox case patient from Lodja, a city located within the Katako-Kombe Health Zone, are seen during a health investigation in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 1997.
First case of monkeypox detected in Texas resident

site_title: General Atlantic plans US$2b investment in India, South-east Asia
summary: Global private equity firm General Atlantic plans to invest $2 billion in India and South-east Asia over the next two years, after falling valuations made the region's startups more attractive. The firm, which has investments of over $4.5 billion in India, is in early-stage talks with 15 companies in sectors such as technology and financial services. Following a record $35 billion investment in 2021, General Atlantic is now ready to loosen its purse strings, with the head of its business in India and South-east Asia stating that "now is the best time to consolidate."

images.alt_text: Walmart's Indian payments unit PhonePe will buy WealthDesk for about US$50 million and OpenQ for nearly US$25 million, 2 sources directly aware of the matter said on Tuesday (May 17).

site_title: Australia’s new PM Albanese overcame car crash, party coup rumblings
summary: Australia's newly sworn-in Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, 59, overcame a near-fatal car crash and party coup rumors to lead his Labor Party to victory in the country's election, ending nearly a decade of conservative leadership. Albanese, who shed 18 kg and underwent a significant image makeover, credited his near-death experience for his renewed determination and ability to connect with voters. His party's shift in image and message helped them pull ahead in polls and secure a win.

site_title: New Zealand PM Ardern alters US trip details following Covid-19 recovery
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has altered her US trip details following her recovery from Covid-19. The trip, originally scheduled for May, will now take place in June, with a focus on trade and tourism. Ardern will meet senior US Senate members and UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, but a meeting with President Joe Biden may be canceled due to health protocols. The trip aims to strengthen New Zealand's relationship with the US, particularly in the Pacific region.

site_title: Airbus sees business jet sales boost despite war, China lockdown
summary: Airbus's corporate-jet division is optimistic about 2022 prospects despite the Russia-Ukraine conflict and Chinese coronavirus lockdowns. The division has seen 5 corporate-jet orders so far this year, including 4 for the A220 variant, with opportunities in the Middle East and US to complete more business. Global head of Airbus Corporate Jets Benoit Defforge cited the trend upwards in sales as a positive sign.

images.alt_text: Airbus is pushing ahead with ambitious plans to ramp up production of its bestselling A320 family of jets to 75 a month by 2025.

site_title: SpaceX aims to raise US$1.7b: media
summary: SpaceX is seeking to raise $1.7 billion in fresh funding, valuing the company at $127 billion. The funding, at $70 per share, is 25% above the stock's February price after a split. This comes as SpaceX continues to finance its Starship rocket and Starlink satellite internet network. Meanwhile, CEO Elon Musk is facing controversy, including a $250,000 payment to resolve a complaint of alleged sexual misconduct against him. Musk has denied the charge.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Halcyon Agri, TTJ Holdings, Datapulse Technology, Procurri
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Halcyon Agri reported an 18.9% revenue increase to US$617.3 million in Q1, driven by higher sales volume and prices. TTJ Holdings' executive chairman plans to privatize the company at S$0.23 per share, while Datapulse Technology recorded three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. Procurri Corporation received a mandatory cash offer from DeClout at S$0.425 per share. Trading halts were called for Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust and Mapletree Commercial Trust due to upcoming announcements. The Singapore stock market closed flat on Friday, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.

site_title: Australia swears in new Labor PM  Anthony Albanese ahead of Quad meeting
summary: Australia's Labor Party leader Anthony Albanese was sworn in as the country's new prime minister, vowing to tackle climate change and rising living costs. He will lead a minority government, as Labor is four seats short of a majority. Albanese will attend a Quad meeting in Tokyo alongside the prime ministers of Japan and India, and later meet with US President Joe Biden. This marks a significant change for the country after nearly a decade of rule by the conservative coalition.

site_title: Australia’s central bank balance sheet to shrink only slowly
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) projects its A$600-billion balance sheet will remain large for years due to bonds maturing slowly under quantitative easing. Only A$4 billion of bonds mature this year, with maturing amounts increasing to A$35-47 billion annually from 2023 to 2031. The RBA has no plans to sell bonds early, and excess cash created by the program will remain in banks' accounts, influencing the cash rate. The RBA maintains control over the cash rate as it withdraws monetary policy stimulus.

site_title: USDJPY meteoric rise stalls
summary: The USDJPY has stalled after a 14% year-to-date gain, with a pullback of 2.5% from its recent high. A head and shoulders pattern and double top formation indicate further weakness, and the weakening Relative Strength Index (RSI) suggests a bearish momentum. The potential downside target is 125.081, and traders should hold the head and shoulders neckline support-turned-resistance level to validate the short-term bearish outlook.

site_title: Apec meeting fails to issue statement after US-Russia walkout
summary: A gathering of trade ministers from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) group failed to issue a joint statement after the US and Russia walked out of the meeting in Bangkok. The US and Russia staged a tit-for-tat walkout during their presentations, citing disagreements over certain parts. Thailand, as the chair, authorized the country to make a statement on behalf of the group, but no joint communique was issued. A working group was established to facilitate better links between members, and Apec members agreed to move forward with transitioning the bloc into the Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: A map of the Eastern Economic Corridor in Thailand.

site_title: Bank of Singapore partners Community Foundation of Singapore to provide clients with philanthropy services
summary: Bank of Singapore has partnered with Community Foundation of Singapore (CFS) to provide philanthropic services to its high net worth clients. The partnership aims to help clients translate their interests and values into philanthropic strategies that align with local community needs. CFS will utilize its expertise and insights to develop strategic giving plans, while Bank of Singapore will leverage its network of ultra-high and high net worth individuals and wealthy families. The partnership comes as philanthropic activities among this demographic are on the rise, with 54% of global family offices increasing their philanthropic activity in 2021.

images.alt_text: Corporate giving in Singapore increases during pandemic: NVPC survey

site_title: Defi believers never say die, even after they see Terra's demise
summary: Hardcore believers in decentralized finance (DeFi) are standing by algorithmic stablecoins despite the collapse of TerraUSD (UST), citing their potential to move towards a world without intermediaries. Several new stablecoins, including USDD launched by Justin Sun on the Tron network, aim to maintain pegs using arbitrage mechanisms. While regulators express concerns about stablecoins as a source of risk, some investors remain optimistic, with USDD offering high returns and a plan to defend its peg. Despite Terra's failure, some predict that algorithmic stablecoins will exist within the next 5-7 years.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrencies steadied after the woes of the TerraUSD stablecoin triggered a flight from many popular digital tokens.

site_title: Bangkok votes for new governor for first time in a decade
summary: Bangkok held its first governor election in nearly a decade, with 30 candidates vying for the top job. Independent candidate Chadchart Sittipunt, a former transport minister, is leading the pack, promising to tackle traffic and pollution. The election is seen as a precursor to a national vote expected within a year. Polling centers opened across Bangkok, with over 4 million eligible voters casting their ballots. Results are expected late Sunday evening, with the outcome giving insight into the capital's willingness to support candidates from the royalist and military establishment that dominates Thai politics.

images.alt_text: Thailand's main economic forecasting agency lowered its growth estimate for this year, and raised its inflation expectations, due to the impacts on the global economy from Russia’s war in Ukraine and a slowdown in China.

THAILAND'S industries sentiment index dropped to a 5-month low in April, hit by higher production costs as Russia's invasion of Ukraine pushed up the price of energy and raw materials, an industries group said on Wednesday (May 18).
Thailand expects tourist arrivals to more than triple to about 1 million a month from October as the nation rolls back most of the pandemic-era travel curbs.

Thailand will allow bars and pubs to reopen in some regions, ending a more than a year-long shutdown, as the tourism-reliant nation targets more travelers to bolster an economic recovery amid an easing Covid outbreak.

site_title: China’s development is good for Asia, but countries want to maintain ties with Japan, US, Europe too: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that China's development is beneficial for the region, but countries in the Asia-Pacific want to maintain ties with other economies like Japan, the US, and Europe to avoid overdependence. Lee emphasized the importance of regional interdependence, saying that countries can prosper together and maintain peace and stability. He acknowledged China's growing influence and economic ties with the US, while also supporting the US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework. Lee expressed interest in digital economy cooperation, sustainable energy, and sustainable finance with Japan and other countries.

images.alt_text: This aerial picture shows the sun rising behind the skyline of Shanghai's Lujiazui Financial District of Pudong on November 13, 2018. (Photo by Johannes EISELE / AFP)

site_title: Fintech MatchMove to acquire Shopmatic on US$200m valuation
summary: MatchMove, a Singapore-based fintech company, is acquiring Shopmatic, a digital e-commerce services startup, in a share-swap deal valued at US$200 million. The acquisition will provide MatchMove with a large user base to deploy its financial services, including supply chain lending and vendor payments. Shopmatic's valuation has doubled rapidly following the deal, despite showing revenue growth of 122% in 2020. The combined entity aims to hit US$25 million in revenue this year and US$400 million by 2026, driven by the growth of embedded finance.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
What's US$100m? MatchMove deal points to opacity in fundraising
Fintech company MatchMove clarifies that 80% of US$100m funding will be in services; cash component comes with conditions

site_title: Bukit Sembawang’s Liv @ MB sells over 75% of units on launch weekend
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' condominium project Liv @ MB in Singapore sold over 75% of its 298 units on its launch weekend, with an average selling price of S$2,387 per square foot. Over 90% of buyers were Singaporean residents from the immediate neighborhood, located just a 3-minute walk from the future Katong Park MRT.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land has launched its 407-unit condominium Piccadilly Grand, with previews starting Saturday (Apr 23) and sales booking scheduled for 2 weeks later on May 7.

site_title: China’s new rich drawn to Singapore
summary: Singapore has seen an influx of wealth from Greater China in recent years, with newly minted millionaires and billionaires seeking diversification and exclusivity. The tightening of tax perk criteria for family offices has made Singapore more attractive, with the number of new family offices setting up shop increasing significantly. Industry watchers expect continued strong inflows, driven by Singapore's political, financial, and cultural stability, as well as its proximity to South-east Asia. The recent crop of HNWIs from Greater China tend to be younger with higher risk appetites, typically moving 10-20% of their portfolios to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Tycoons from around the region, along with their families, are reportedly flocking to Singapore, with interest in immigration rising during the Covid-19 pandemic.
MAS tightens criteria for family offices to qualify for tax incentives

site_title: Opportunities arising from Middle East’s Asian pivot
summary: The Middle East's Asian pivot is driving investments and trade between the two regions. Countries like Indonesia and Singapore have benefited from the shift, with Indonesia securing $32.7 billion in investment commitments from UAE businesses and Singapore emerging as a key destination for businesses looking to diversify into new sectors. Economic ties between the Middle East and ASEAN have strengthened, with bilateral partnerships and investments reaching $700 million in 2020. The region is expected to see significant growth in sectors such as refining and petrochemicals, infrastructure, renewable energy, retail, and digital infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: India mulls spending additional  2 trillion rupees to fight inflation
summary: India's government is considering spending an additional 2 trillion rupees in the 2022/23 fiscal year to combat high inflation, which has reached an 8-year high in April. This measure is double the revenue hit from tax cuts on petrol and diesel. The government estimates an additional 500 billion rupees needed for fertilizer subsidies and may borrow funds to fund these measures, potentially affecting its deficit target of 6.4% of GDP.

images.alt_text: SURGING inflation is forcing many poor Indians to rein in spending, threatening a slowdown for companies such as Godrej Appliances which saw bumper sales as recently as March and April after a brutal heatwave spiked demand for its cooling products.

site_title: ‘Making’ vs ‘milking’: strategies to beat the competition
summary: Business leaders face a choice between two innovation strategies: "making" and "milking". The making strategy involves enhancing value creation through products and services to meet customers' needs, while the milking strategy involves capturing the value already created by bargaining more effectively with customers. Research shows that the innovation strategy chosen not only impacts organizational performance but also has implications for competitive dynamics in the market. Addressing weaknesses rather than just building on strengths can be beneficial, and firms tend to imitate each other's strategy choices. The study highlights the importance of culture change in increasing risk tolerance and suggests a novel approach to generic strategies, focusing on the gap between willingness-to-pay and costs of a firm's offering.

images.alt_text: Luxury salespeople need to develop new skills, to become more agile, less focused on the brand, and more focused on customers.
Chief executive Khoo Boo Hor joined Tech Group Asia in May 2005, just ahead of its merger with Sunningdale Precision Industries,.

site_title: Companies expected to resume live engagement and voting at all AGMs, regardless of format
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has updated its expectations for companies holding annual general meetings (AGMs) for financial years ending June 30, 2022, or after. The regulator requires issuers to use real-time electronic voting and real-time electronic communication for virtual-only meetings, and to provide public responses to shareholder questions between 48 and 72 hours prior to the meeting. This aims to ensure shareholders can make informed decisions, even in virtual meetings.

images.alt_text: What issuers, shareholders should be aware of in respect of proxy votes for scheme of arrangement meetings
In Malaysia, Azeus said has spearheaded large creditor and annual meetings for state and federal societies.

site_title: Shanghai partly resumes public transport in patchy reopening
summary: Shanghai, China's largest city, has partially resumed public transport after nearly 2 months of lockdown, a gradual reopening amid slowing new infections. Four subway lines and some road transport services restarted on Sunday, requiring a negative Covid test and normal temperature for those using public transport. However, the central Jing'an district has returned to lockdown, with mass Covid tests and residents not allowed to leave their homes. Shanghai reported over 600 Covid cases, with Beijing continuing to enforce strict restrictions, including a ban on dining out and forced work-from-home measures.

images.alt_text: A barricade formed by shared bicycles at an entrance to a closed Bank of Nanjing branch during a lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai, China.

site_title: Malaysia sees sustained competitiveness even as Indonesia resumes palm oil exports
summary: Malaysia expects sustained competitiveness despite Indonesia's resumption of palm oil exports, which is expected to increase sales to India. Indonesia's policy of requiring 10 million tonnes of domestic stock to maintain exports may benefit Malaysia, which could become a dominant supplier to India. Prices of edible oils remain elevated due to supply disruptions, and Malaysia's commodities minister believes the country will not lose its competitive edge. The ministry is also exploring a proposal to temporarily cut an export tax on crude palm oil to boost Malaysia's market share.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is still reviewing the viability of a temporary cut of a crude palm oil export tax, the Commodities Ministry said on Friday, after Indonesia lifted an export ban that has rattled the market.
First Resources and Golden Agri-Resources were among the potential winners named by CGS-CIMB.
Palm oil, used in everything from margarine to frying fats and shampoo, comprises a third of the world’s vegetable oil market, with Indonesia accounting for about 60 per cent of supply.
INDONESIA will lift its palm oil export ban from Monday (May 23), following improvements in the domestic cooking oil supply situation, President Joko Widodo said on Thursday

site_title: Man City retain Premier League title with late comeback
summary: Manchester City secured their fourth Premier League title in five years with a dramatic comeback against Aston Villa. Trailing 2-0 at halftime, City scored three goals in the final 15 minutes, including a late winner from Rodri, to win 3-2. The victory denied Liverpool the title and ended their bid for an unprecedented quadruple. Manager Pep Guardiola hailed his team as legends, praising their "magnitude of achievement" against a rival he described as "the greatest in the world".

site_title: Biden arrives in Japan with no response on outreach to North Korea
summary: US President Joe Biden arrived in Japan on Sunday for the second leg of an Asia trip, meeting with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Emperor Naruhito. The trip comes as North Korea continues to ignore US outreach, with Biden expressing concern that the country may test a nuclear-capable missile or bomb. Despite this, Biden's administration remains prepared to respond, with National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan stating that North Korea has a choice: act or come to the table. The trip also includes a US-led multilateral trade initiative and a summit with leaders from Australia, India, and Japan.

site_title: Dollar catches a break after bruising week as investors turn risk averse
summary: The US dollar rose 0.3% against the euro on Friday, as investors became risk-averse due to concerns about the potential economic fallout from the US Federal Reserve's efforts to squash inflation. The dollar has been down 1.3% for the week, its worst weekly showing against the euro since early February. Other safe-haven currencies, such as the Swiss franc and Japanese yen, have rallied, while sterling is set for its biggest weekly gain since December 2020 against the dollar.

site_title: Building ESG metrics into executive remuneration
summary: A new report, "Integrating ESG Factors Into Executive Remuneration," highlights concerns about the subjectivity of ESG metrics and their possible abuse. The report, led by corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen, provides 10 key questions for boards and remuneration committees to consider when incorporating ESG factors into executive remuneration. The report found that only 16% of major listed companies in Asean explicitly disclosed incorporating ESG factors into executive remuneration, with Singapore having the highest percentage. The report emphasizes the need for transparency and integration of ESG metrics into company strategies and policies.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

His team plans to issue regular reports on different areas of ESG, such as on how climate risk affects various outcomes such as cost of capital, ESG issues in supply chains, implications of ESG for directors’ duties, and so on, says Prof Mak Yuen Teen.
Sustainability standards, financial reporting must be on equal footing
Asean Exchanges publishes table comparing sustainability reporting regimes

site_title: In Japan, Biden to launch economic plan for region sceptical on benefits
summary: US President Joe Biden arrived in Japan to launch the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF), a plan aimed at promoting economic engagement in the region, amid skepticism over its benefits. The IPEF, which will discuss supply-chain resilience, clean energy, and digital trade, is expected to start discussions rather than formal negotiations due to Japan's push for broader participation. Critics argue the plan lacks practical incentives, and the White House will need to offer more tangible benefits to keep countries on board.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol looks on as US President Joe Biden delivers remarks at the Samsung Electronics Pyeongtaek Campus in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, May 20, 2022.
U.S. President Joe Biden arrives to deliver remarks on expanding high-speed internet access, during a Rose Garden event at the White House in Washington, U.S., May 9, 2022. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque

site_title: Didi investors to vote on NY delisting after Beijing crackdown
summary: Didi Global, a Chinese ride-hailing giant, is expected to secure shareholder approval to delist from the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, marking the end of an 11-month ordeal that wiped out around US$60 billion of its market value. The company's biggest backers, including SoftBank Group and Tencent Holdings, are expected to vote in favor of the delisting, clearing the way for cooperation with regulators and paving the way for a potential Hong Kong share float. The move is seen as a comeuppance for the company, which was forced off China's app stores and initiated a cybersecurity probe after its US$4.4 billion IPO in June 2021.

images.alt_text: Didi is struggling to bring its business back to normal after angering Chinese regulators by pushing ahead with a US$4.4 billion listing in the United States despite being asked to put it on hold.
US lawmakers had last year called for an investigation into Didi’s controversial IPO - the biggest by a Chinese firm since Alibaba Group.

site_title: Assembling the ‘Avengers’: practicable ESG research for businesses
summary: The Sustainable Finance Institute Asia (SFIA) has launched a series of ESG research reports aimed at making academic research on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues more accessible to businesses, investors, and other stakeholders. The first report, "Integrating ESG Factors Into Executive Remuneration," provides guidance on how companies can link ESG factors to executive compensation. The team, led by Professor Mak Yuen Teen, aims to issue four reports per year, covering various areas of ESG, including climate risk, supply chains, and directors' duties.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Sustainability standards, financial reporting must be on equal footing
Asean Exchanges publishes table comparing sustainability reporting regimes

site_title: Cryptos are crashing, will NFTs be next?
summary: Cryptocurrency values are plummeting, with major cryptocurrencies experiencing a significant decline in value. The NFT market, which was previously driven by celebrity endorsements and speculation, is also showing signs of a downturn. The number of NFTs traded in the first quarter of this year dropped by nearly 50% compared to the previous quarter. Experts attribute the decline to a decrease in hype, fear of scams, and tightening of belts. The lack of regulation in the NFT market has also contributed to the issue, with many transactions being fake or fraudulent.

images.alt_text: Bored Ape Yacht Club #4418, one of a set of 10,000 non-fungible tokens (NFTs) representing cartoon apes, made by the U.S.-based company Yuga Labs is seen in this image created in the digital space, May 1, 2021.
