The Bored Ape Yacht Club NFT collection on the OpenSea marketplace.

site_title: Fresh off student housing deal, Wee Hur keen on more partnerships with institutional investors
summary: Wee Hur Holdings has sold a 9.9% stake in its Australian student accommodation property trust, Wee Hur PBSA Master Trust (WHPMT), to Reco Weather, a Singapore-based investment holding company linked to state investment firm GIC, for A$112.7 million ($113.3 million). The sale values the fund's properties at A$1.14 billion, with an equity value of A$551.1 million. The deal provides certainty for investors and has cemented Wee Hur's reputation among institutional investors, opening the door to future partnerships. The company plans to be more prudent in the near term, focusing on risk management and diversification to ensure its longevity.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Wee Hur's student housing property at 124 Waymouth Street in Adelaide.
Wee Hur rises 11% on partial stake sale in student housing fund to GIC-linked entity

site_title: How to TikTok your way to a prize at the Cannes Film Festival
summary: The Cannes Film Festival, now 75, partnered with TikTok to inject youth into the event, making it an official sponsor. A short film competition was held, with prizes awarded by a jury of film professionals, including TikTok star Khaby Lame. The top prize was shared by two winners, Japan's Mabuta Motoki and Slovenia's Matej Rimanic. However, the head of the jury briefly resigned after accusing TikTok of trying to influence the selections, citing the platform's attempt to cut off interviews with the winners.

images.alt_text: TikTok owner ByteDance's revenue growth slowed to 70% in 2021: sources

site_title: A house with ‘good bones’? ‘Original details’? It could be a complete wreck
summary: Real estate listings often use overly flattering language to attract buyers, but industry experts say this can be misleading. Descriptions like "good bones" or "loads of original details" can actually mean the house is a wreck in need of renovation. To effectively market a property, listing agents must strike a balance between highlighting its appeal and addressing practical concerns. The goal is to create an emotional connection with potential buyers, rather than simply listing facts.

images.alt_text: Since Blackstone launched its income-oriented real estate strategy in the US, investors globally including in Singapore have been increasing their allocation in such types of strategies, off from “a very low base”, said Herbert Suen.
US existing home sales dropped to the lowest level in nearly 2 years in April as house prices jumped to a record high.
The number of short-term rentals in New York City is outpacing the number of available apartments, putting a pinch on renters who are looking for space in a hot housing market.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain on defensives, but still down for the week
summary: European shares rose on Friday, driven by a boost from defensive sectors following China's central bank cutting its five-year loan prime rate by 15 basis points, boosting market sentiment. Despite the gain, the week ended down 0.5% for the main index. Travel and tourism, financial services, healthcare, and utilities led the gains, while retail and food stocks fell 2.2% and 5% respectively. The European Central Bank is expected to hike interest rates in July, with some economists forecasting a 50-bp rate hike.

site_title: Biden says first shipments of baby formula flying in from Europe this weekend
summary: President Joe Biden announced that the first shipments of infant formula from Europe, under "Operation Fly Formula," will arrive in the US this weekend. The shipments, carried by US military aircraft, will include up to 1.5 million bottles of safe formula, primarily from Nestlé Health Science Alfamino Infant and Alfamino Junior formulas. The recall by Abbott Laboratories in February led to a critical shortage, prompting Biden to invoke the Defense Production Act to increase supplies.

site_title: Bangkok picks independent as new governor as national vote looms
summary: Thailand's capital, Bangkok, has elected an independent, Chadchart Sittipunt, as its new governor in the first election in nearly a decade. Chadchart won with 52% of the vote and 60% of the ballots counted, receiving support from across the political spectrum for his policy-focused approach. His landslide win may embolden pro-democracy groups and opposition parties, which are pushing for the ouster of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha. Chadchart will face challenges in rebuilding Bangkok's pre-pandemic status as a tourism hub and tackling persistent pollution, including repairing the city's economy and addressing traffic and pollution issues.

images.alt_text: Independent candidate Chadchart Sittipunt (in white shirt) leaves after casting his vote in the governor elections in Bangkok on May 22, 2022.

site_title: Labor Party wins the government after long stretch of Conservative leadership
summary: Australia's Labor Party, led by Anthony Albanese, won the federal election, ending nine years of conservative government. Albanese secured at least 72 seats, surpassing the 76 needed to form a government, with alliances with independent and minor-party victors expected to give him a majority. Albanese campaigned on a promise of "renewal not revolution," and his victory marked the fourth time a Labor leader has won the government from the opposition since World War II. Prime Minister Scott Morrison conceded defeat, citing exhaustion with the incumbent rather than enthusiasm for the challenger.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison criss-crossed the country in a final day of campaigning, insisting he could still win Saturday's election despite polls pointing to a change of government or hung parliament.
Polls opened in Australia’s federal election on Saturday, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison fighting for another three-year term.

site_title: PM-elect vows to repair Australia's image overseas
summary: Australia's newly elected Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has vowed to repair the country's image overseas and address climate change, following a decade of conservative rule. Albanese, who won the election, promised a change in politics, saying it should be a "big moment for the country." He will attend a Tokyo summit with Japanese, Indian, and US leaders, the so-called Quad, and plans to introduce more ambitious emissions targets and create a federal anti-corruption watchdog. Albanese's election marks a shift away from the country's reputation as a climate laggard and a spoiler at international climate talks.

images.alt_text: Australian opposition leader Anthony Albanese speaks to supporters after winning the 2022 Federal Election, at the Federal Labor Reception held at Canterbury-Hurlstone Park RSL Club in Sydney, Australia. More than 17 million Australians have voted to elect the next federal government.

site_title: SBF Foundation signs MOU to enhance employability support for four vulnerable groups
summary: The SBF Foundation has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Singapore Human Resources Institute, NTUC's e2i, and Tote Board to provide holistic employability support for four vulnerable groups: rough sleepers, long-term unemployed parents, caregivers of at-risk children, and individuals with mental health conditions. The partnership aims to uplift 300 individuals annually through personalized aid and dedicated platforms, with a goal of raising S$1 million annually from the business community to fund the Employability Fund.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Positioning portfolios amid the energy transition
summary: A consensus is forming that investing in areas with proven technologies and innovative strategies is the best strategy to reach net zero emissions by 2050. This involves scaling up existing technologies that reduce fossil fuel-related emissions and pursuing solutions to challenging problems. Key areas of focus include clean tech, green hydrogen, and lower-carbon cement, with opportunities emerging in sectors such as power, automobiles, and renewable infrastructure. Investors must focus on active managers with specialized industry skills to benefit from the energy transition and engage with companies to encourage real-world movement toward lower greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text:

site_title: Changi Airport T2 to reopen in phases from May 29
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 2 will reopen in phases starting May 29, 2022, after being closed since May 2020 for upgrading works. The terminal will initially host peak-hour arrival flights, with some T3 departure flights also using T2 gates. The expanded terminal will feature automated immigration lanes and special assistance lanes, increasing capacity by 5 million to 28 million passenger movements per year. The reopening is part of Changi Airport's efforts to meet the expected increase in passenger traffic ahead of the June travel peak.

images.alt_text: Travellers look at information regarding their flights in the departure hall at Changi International Airport in Singapore on December 2, 2021. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Singapore will strive to keep its borders open and stay connected to the rest of world even if a new variant of Covid-19 emerges, Transport Minister S Iswaran said.
Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.

site_title: Industrial S-Reits report positive rental reversions
summary: Singapore's industrial S-Reits reported positive rental reversions in Q1 2022, despite a drop in overall occupancy rate to 89.8%. Prices and rentals rose by 2.1% and 1.0% respectively compared to the previous quarter. Notable performers include AIMS Apac Reit, Ascendas Reit, and Sabana Industrial Reit, which attributed their improved performance to contributions from recently acquired assets and higher rental recoveries. The Reits sector remains stable, with leasing demand boosted by e-commerce growth and business inventory stockpiling.

images.alt_text: Singapore focused office S-Reits remain poised to benefit as more employees return to the office.

site_title: Digital bank operators seek to unlock the value of Malaysia’s underserved market
summary: Digital banks in Malaysia aim to serve the country's underserved gig workers, small and medium enterprises, and micro enterprises. The 4 million gig workers and 1.15 million SMEs face difficulties in securing loans due to lack of data and proper accounting records. Digital banks can use alternative data points for credit scoring, offering faster and more affordable access to financial services. The Malaysian government is developing a robust digital economy, with digital banks expected to play a key role. Digital bank players, including Grab, Sea, and MoneyMatch, are working to create new products and services tailored to the underserved segments, with plans to launch within the next 12-24 months.

images.alt_text: GRAB likely has an advantage over its other digital bank competitors in Malaysia given its e-wallet share in the country, Maybank said on Sunday (May 1).
Grab-Singtel is among 5 winners of Malaysia's digital bank licences.

site_title: Malaysia sounds alarm over lowest SEA Games ranking in 40 years
summary: Malaysia's sports minister, Ahmad Faizal Azumu, expressed disappointment over the country's likely lowest ranking in the SEA Games in nearly 40 years, finishing sixth in the medals table. Despite reaching the target of 36 golds, Malaysia's performance has been underwhelming, with hosts Vietnam leading the way. The government's reduced sports spending and athlete numbers may have contributed to the poor performance, with the country's last hope resting in badminton. The disappointing result comes ahead of the Commonwealth Games in July-August and Asian Games later this year.

site_title: Russia stops Finland gas flows over payments dispute
summary: Russia's Gazprom halted gas exports to Finland on Saturday, citing a payment dispute over sanctions-imposed roubles. Finland refuses to pay in roubles, while Gazprom demanded the payment. This marks the latest escalation in an energy payments dispute with Western nations. Finland plans to manage without Russian gas by sourcing supplies from other countries, including Estonia's gas grid, and has chartered a storage and regasification vessel from US-based Excelerate Energy.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for May 20-26, 2022, shows the Capesize market reached new highs, with the Capesize 5TC rising $4,805 to $37,538. The Atlantic Basin saw increased fixing activity, with transatlantic lifting rates rising $8,900 to $32,150. Panamax rates remained flat, while Ultramax and Supramax markets showed a split, with positive sentiment in the Pacific region. Handysize rates were also mixed, with a split market in the Atlantic and improved demand in Asia. VLCC and Suezmax rates held steady, while Aframax rates declined due to the ongoing war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on April 5, 2022 shows a view of the Panama-flagged bulk carrier ship ATA-M moored at the Red Sea port of Hodeida in western Yemen. - A fragile two-month truce brokered by the United Nations in war-torn Yemen has given people just a glimmer of hope as they continue to struggle for survival. Many fear the latest ceasefire in the seven-year-old conflict, coinciding with the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, will only silence the guns temporarily. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Polls open in Australian election
summary: Polls opened in Australia's federal election, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison fighting for another three-year term against Anthony Albanese's Labor party. Long queues formed at polling stations, with Morrison accusing Albanese of "hubris" and promising to continue strong economic management. Labor is six points ahead in the final polls, but the outcome is uncertain, with over 17 million Australians registered to vote. More than seven million have already cast early or postal ballots. The election will decide who controls the House of Representatives, Senate, and the prime minister's Lodge.

images.alt_text: A billboard showing Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison adorns the side of the Trades Hall building in Melbourne on May 20, 2022, a day before Australia goes to the polls in a general election. (Photo by William WEST / AFP)

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group to invest US$5.5b to build electric vehicle, battery facilities in US
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to invest US$5.54 billion in its first dedicated electric vehicle and battery manufacturing facilities in the US. Groundbreaking is expected in early 2023, with commercial production starting in the first half of 2025. The facility in Georgia will have an annual capacity of 300,000 EV units, creating approximately 8,100 jobs. This investment is part of Hyundai's US$7.4 billion plan to foster future mobility through 2025, and coincides with US President Biden's visit to South Korea.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Hyundai Motor Company is pictured at the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 13, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: North Korean nuclear sabre rattling overshadows Biden’s South Korea trip
summary: US President Joe Biden's South Korea trip was overshadowed by North Korea's "sabre rattling" as the secretive dictatorship battles a raging Covid-19 outbreak. Despite this, Biden met with newly sworn-in South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol to discuss nuclear fears and establish a strong personal relationship. The US official stated that the US is ready for any eventuality, while South Korean intelligence warned of preparations for a potential nuclear test. Biden's trip aims to demonstrate unity and resolve with key allies in the region, with stops in Japan and a regional summit of the Quad.

site_title: ‘I had to go back’: Over 55, and not retired after all
summary: Millions of older Americans, aged 55-64, have returned to work since the COVID-19 pandemic, with nearly 64% of adults in this age group now employed, mirroring the February 2020 rate. This rapid rebound has surprised economists, who initially expected a wave of early retirements due to the pandemic. However, research suggests that the narrative of early retirements was overblown, with many older workers choosing to return to work due to financial necessity or a desire to preserve their mental health. The return of older workers has been concentrated among those in their late 50s and early 60s, who were still several years away from retirement when the pandemic began.

images.alt_text: Just as employers should be open to hiring people of different age groups, job-seekers in the older age group should also manage their expectations when it comes to salary adjustments and upskilling
For years, older Americans have been continuing to work for longer, as life expectancy rates rose and many were unwilling or unable to retire. That came to a halt with the health crisis.

site_title: In a time of market volatility, focus on what you can control
summary: Investors are navigating market volatility caused by rising inflation, interest rates, and geopolitical tensions. Despite market fluctuations, long-term investors are advised to focus on fundamental basics, including asset allocation, diversification, and minimizing costs through passive investing. A 1986 study found that 94% of an investor's returns come from asset allocation, with traditional asset allocation (60/40) and risk budgeting strategies being effective. Additionally, defensive assets like REITs and low-duration cash management solutions can provide stability during periods of high inflation. Staying the course and holding investments for a 20-year period can lead to historically positive returns.

What should we do when the market corrects?
S-Reits punching above their weight in the global arena

site_title: Keep calm and carry on
summary: Global stock markets continue to sell off amid rising interest rates, with US stocks down nearly 20% and Asian markets down around 18% year-to-date. Investors are advised not to panic and sell everything, but rather to focus on their long-term investment goals and manage risks. Timing the market is not effective, and investing through dollar cost averaging can help build portfolios. A diversified asset allocation, rather than picking individual stocks, is key to success. Investors should assess their own risk tolerance and consider seeking professional advice to construct a suitable portfolio.

images.alt_text: Japanese equities are relatively cheap, says the author. He also favours the Canadian dollar and Norwegian krone.

site_title: Shanghai looks to categorise parts of city low-risk for Covid
summary: Shanghai is introducing a risk categorization system starting in June, dividing the city into high-, medium-, and low-risk areas. Areas without reported positive cases or community infections for 14 days will be considered low-risk. Residents in high- and medium-risk areas will face restrictions, including daily PCR tests. The move aims to ease the city's 2-month-long lockdown, which has had a significant economic and social impact, and is part of China's efforts to end the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Parts of Shanghai's subway services have resumed.

site_title: Working in the metaverse: what virtual office life could look like
summary: Virtual reality is poised to revolutionize knowledge work, particularly in fields such as software engineering, law, and design. Younger professionals, part of Gen Z, have a competitive edge due to their intuitive grasp of digital technology and self-taught problem-solving skills. Their familiarity with massively multiplayer online games and ability to manage multiple digital identities will further enhance this edge. As the metaverse becomes more prevalent, companies must adapt to the changing workforce, valuing skills and mindset over device access and connectivity. This shift will redefine the nature of work in the virtual office.

images.alt_text: A participant at VR World in Manhattan on Monday, Nov. 1, 2021. NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future. (Jeenah Moon/The New York Times)##########mlcrypto13##########

site_title: UOL, Trans-China Automotive & Frencken chairmen raise stakes
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Institutions invested S$3.4 million in Singapore stocks over May 13-19, following S$145 million of net outflows in the previous five sessions. OCBC, Keppel Corporation, UOB, Singapore Exchange, and Singapore Telecommunications led the net institutional inflows. Seventeen primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, with a total consideration of S$67.4 million. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included UOL Group chairman Wee Cho Yaw increasing his stake, Trans-China Automotive Holdings CEO Francis Tjia acquiring shares, and Frencken Group chairman Gooi Soon Chai increasing his stake. Net institutional inflows and share buybacks reflect market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Overall, the net institutional inflows into Singapore stocks in the 2022 year to May 12 totalled S$307 million.

site_title: Monkeypox outbreak in Europe ‘largest ever’ in region as cases cross 100
summary: Europe has seen its largest-ever monkeypox outbreak, with over 100 cases reported across countries including the UK, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, France, the US, and Australia. The virus, typically spread through close contact, has rarely spread outside Africa, but scientists do not expect a pandemic. Most cases are among men who self-identify as gay, bisexual, or men who have sex with men. While health authorities are sequencing the virus to determine links, they believe the outbreak can be contained via contact tracing and effective vaccines, which are up to 85% effective against monkeypox.

site_title: Welcome to our be-careful-what-you-wish-for economy
summary: The US economy is experiencing a slowdown, with companies like Walmart announcing excess inventories and tech firms implementing hiring freezes and job cuts. This shift is a reversal of concerns six months ago, when economists urged a slowdown to deflate market bubbles. As investors worry about recession, homebuilders are slowing demand and the supply of existing homes is rising. The economic downturn is a stark contrast to the initial goal of slowing growth, leaving some to wonder if this is the "be-careful-what-you-wish-for" economy.

images.alt_text: EVIDENCE of red-hot inflation seeping into the American economy is sending a chill through investors after major US retailers reported people are cutting back on buying bigger-ticket items as they just try to get by.
US existing home sales dropped to the lowest level in nearly 2 years in April as house prices jumped to a record high.

site_title: India's Jet Airways allowed to fly again
summary: India's Jet Airways has been cleared by the country's aviation regulator to resume commercial flights. The airline had stopped operations in April 2019 due to financial issues, but has since completed a regulatory and compliance process. A resolution plan was approved by the National Company Law Tribunal, allowing Jet to resume operations with the grant of an air operator certificate.

site_title: Tokyo protests to Beijing over East China Sea construction
summary: Japan has lodged an official protest with China over suspected efforts to develop gas fields in the disputed East China Sea waters, where the two countries' exclusive economic zones overlap. Beijing was accused of unilaterally proceeding with development, despite a 2008 bilateral agreement to jointly develop undersea gas reserves. The agreement, however, was suspended in 2010. Japan urged China to resume negotiations and respect its maritime border. The incident adds to the ongoing tensions between the two nations, including disputes over the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands in the East China Sea.

site_title: Oil settles up as supply risks outweigh economic worries
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, with Brent futures increasing 0.5% to $112.55 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rising 0.9% to $113.23 a barrel. The gains were driven by a planned EU ban on Russian oil and easing of Covid-19 lockdowns in China, outweighing concerns about slowing economic growth. The energy market expects China's reopening to boost energy demand, and the EU is close to a deal on a Russian oil embargo.

site_title: Russia to halt gas flows to Finland on Saturday
summary: Russia's Gazprom will halt gas flows to Finland starting Saturday morning, after the country refused to pay in roubles. This move follows Russia's demand for payment in roubles due to sanctions over Ukraine's invasion. Finland will continue to supply gas from other sources, including the Balticconnector pipeline. The country has also chartered a vessel to import liquefied natural gas from the US to replace Russian supplies.

images.alt_text: The European Union said companies can keep buying could keep buying gas without breaching sanctions, as it softened its stance in a standoff with Moscow over energy supplies.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda vows to keep ultra-easy monetary policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has reaffirmed the central bank's ultra-easy monetary policy stance, citing slim chances of inflation accelerating beyond projections. Kuroda stated that Japan will remain an outlier among G7 nations in maintaining low interest rates, as the economy is expected to make a sustained recovery from the pandemic. This decision comes despite a G7 finance leaders' communique warning of the need to calibrate monetary policy with inflation at levels not seen for decades. The BOJ will continue to maintain its powerful monetary easing to support the economy.

site_title: US mystery hepatitis deaths rise to 6, cause still unknown
summary: The US has reported six deaths from a mysterious form of hepatitis, with 180 cases tied to the condition, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The leading hypothesis is adenovirus 41, but other factors, such as prior Covid-19 infection, are also being investigated. The CDC is cautious, stating it may take time to assess the evidence, and there is no link to coronavirus vaccines. Genetic sequencing has revealed multiple strains of adenovirus 41 in affected children, and theories include a cluster of cases due to Covid lockdowns or a lack of exposure to pathogens.

site_title: The future of luxury retail is hybrid
summary: Luxury retailers must adapt to a rapidly changing market by embracing a hybrid retail strategy. This involves using retail spaces to cater to diverse clientele, adopting a retail portfolio strategy to target tourists and non-traditional customers, and leveraging technology to create efficient and distinctive experiences. Key findings include the need for salespeople to be more agile and customer-focused, rather than solely brand-centric, and the importance of spatial, technological, and interactional hybridization in delivering a luxury experience.

images.alt_text: A closed store of French luxury brand Louis Vuitton is pictured during lockdown, amid the Covid-19 pandemic, in Shanghai, China, May 6, 2022.

site_title: Russia makes early debt payment dash in bid to swerve default
summary: Russia made early debt payments on two external bonds, totaling $71.25 million in US dollars and €26.5 million in euros, to avoid a looming sovereign default ahead of a US licence expiring on May 25. This move comes as the country faces the prospect of default due to Western sanctions and has been severed from the global financial system. Russia has made payments on 7 bonds since its invasion of Ukraine and has $40 billion of international bonds outstanding, with around half held by foreign investors.

site_title: Moody’s cuts Ukraine debt rating, outlook negative
summary: Moody's cut Ukraine's debt rating to Caa3, its second downgrade in three months, due to the risk of a protracted military conflict affecting the nation's debt sustainability. The ratings agency lowered the outlook to negative, citing the country's significant rise in government debt, which could impede access to official financing. Ukraine's economy is expected to contract by 35% this year, with President Volodymyr Zelensky stating the country needs $7 billion a month to keep its economy afloat. Moody's estimates Ukraine faces financing needs of around $50 billion this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy speaks during a news conference with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau (not pictured), as Russia's attack on Ukraine continues, in Kyiv, Ukraine May 8, 2022.  REUTERS/Valentyn Ogirenko/File Photo

site_title: Obi-Wan hides the Force in new ‘Star Wars’ TV series: Ewan McGregor
summary: Ewan McGregor stars in a new six-part 'Star Wars' TV series, 'Obi-Wan Kenobi', where he reprises his role as the Jedi master. McGregor, 51, says Obi-Wan has "given himself away" and can no longer use the Force, as he's being hunted by the Empire. The series is set 17 years after McGregor's character last appeared in 'Star Wars: The Revenge of the Sith'. McGregor reunited with Hayden Christensen, who reprises his role as Anakin Skywalker/Darth Vader, in a "crazy time warp" that felt like no time had passed. The series premieres on Disney+ on May 27.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 2.96% on Friday, May 20, 2022, driven by China's decision to lower a key benchmark rate. The Hang Seng Index increased to 20,717.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also closed higher, up 1.60% and 1.59% respectively.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) is seen at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China September 14, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: The future of work that respects, liberates and conforms to you
summary: The future of work is shifting towards an asynchronous state, where teams work remotely and independently, without being tied to traditional office hours or time zones. This model respects employees' autonomy, agency, and inclusivity by allowing them to work at their own pace and location. Asynchronous work can lead to higher efficiency and productivity, as employees can default to action without waiting for decision-makers. Companies like GitLab and Automattic have successfully implemented async workflows, showcasing its benefits. Strong leadership and intentional communication are key to making this model work, and it's not just for tech startups, but can be adapted by any organization to create a better work environment.

images.alt_text: Flexi-work leaves San Francisco trailing NYC in office comeback
Employers must consider flexi-work requests by 2024
Flexing a 4-day week to work the right way

site_title: Ezion Holdings to apply to delist from SGX
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based liftboat operator, plans to apply to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to its insolvent state and inability to repay debts. The company, which previously faced difficulties in procuring investment, went into liquidation in February. Its liquidators have concluded that its debts exceed its realizable assets, leading to the delisting application.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Indonesia's Garuda given debt restructuring extension
summary: Indonesia's flag carrier Garuda Indonesia has had its debt restructuring deadline extended for the third time by a month, from May 20 to June 20, according to a court-appointed curator. The airline started the process in December after a vendor petitioned over unpaid bills, seeking to cut its total liabilities from $9.8 billion to $3.7 billion. Garuda has been verifying claims worth $9.72 billion and disputing $885.5 million as of March 14. The airline has repeatedly requested more time to negotiate restructuring terms.

site_title: Big brands fret over China as middle-class spurns luxury
summary: China's zero-Covid policy has led to a decline in luxury sales, with 28-year-old marketing manager Chloe planning to save instead of spend, citing financial uncertainty. The country, which accounted for 21% of the world's personal luxury goods market in 2021, is expected to become the top market by 2025. Luxury brands, including LVMH and Burberry, have invested ahead of the curve, but executives warn of a potential "bumpy recovery" due to prolonged lockdowns and a more conservative consumer behavior.

images.alt_text: Virtually Versailles.

site_title: Shanghai issues return-to-office rule for bankers as virus eases
summary: Shanghai has issued rules for financial companies to resume operations as the city's Covid-19 outbreak eases. Employees returning to work must not exceed 40% of total staff and will be allowed to return in batches, with each batch not exceeding 20%. Financial institutions must resume work under closed-loop arrangements and adhere to epidemic prevention requirements. A total of 864 financial entities are allowed to resume on-site operations, with state banks and international companies among the first to resume. The rules aim to gradually unwind the city's lockdown that confined 25 million people.

site_title: US: Stocks end bruising week near ‘bear market’ territory
summary: US stocks ended a bruising week near "bear market" territory, with the S&P 500 finishing flat at 3,901.36 and down 3% for the week. The index is now 19% below its January high, meeting the criteria for a bear market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also saw minimal changes. Economic concerns, including inflation and interest rate hikes, have weighed on the market, with some companies experiencing significant losses, such as Ross Stores and Deere & Company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign hangs on a signpost in front of the New York Stock Exchange August 5, 2011. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo

site_title: The many paths to success in STEM
summary: Women have been instrumental in shaping the scientific landscape, with notable breakthroughs in vaccine development, gene editing, and pandemic research. However, despite the increasing profile and opportunities in STEM fields, women and girls continue to underrepresent themselves, with only 30% of researchers worldwide being women. A recent study found that girls' interest in STEM subjects decreases between the ages of 14 and 16, with parents and friends influencing their decisions. To inspire girls to pursue STEM careers, it's essential to provide female role models and mentors, and to showcase the diversity of pursuits within the STEM fields.

images.alt_text: Looking ahead, there will be a growing urgency to reduce dependence on bulk active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) and generic drugs sourced from offshore markets.

site_title: G-7 finance leaders reaffirm forex commitment in communique
summary: G-7 finance leaders reaffirmed their commitment to exchange rates, pledging to closely monitor markets amid recent volatility, particularly Japan's concern over the yen's sharp decline. The agreement, in place since 2017, emphasizes that markets should determine currency rates and excessive moves could harm growth. Japan seeks more flexibility to intervene in the currency market, while the dollar's rise pushes down the euro, adding inflationary pressure. The G-7 will continue to coordinate on currency moves to mitigate the impact of exchange-rate fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The US dollar edged higher on Wednesday, a day after posting its biggest single-day drop in more than two months after US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell struck a more hawkish tone as the central bank battles to rein in surging inflation.

site_title: Managing challenges in US equity and fixed income markets today
summary: US stocks and fixed income markets face challenges due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes and balance sheet reduction. Despite robust economic growth in 2021, the market has been volatile this year, with growth-oriented stocks declining more than the S&P 500. Inflation concerns have become a top priority, and investors are uncertain about the Fed's ability to engineer a soft landing. The US labor market remains resilient, but consumers face challenges maintaining purchasing power amid rising inflation and geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: The tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 underperformed major benchmarks. Data on Monday (May 16) showed New York state manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in May for the second time in three months, stoking concerns of slowing economic activity that may complicate the Fed’s policy path.

site_title: When the EPL came knocking, it was an opportunity StarHub could not pass up
summary: StarHub has secured a 6-year deal to broadcast the English Premier League (EPL) in Singapore, ending a 12-year streak by Singtel. The deal, worth an undisclosed amount, will see StarHub screen every EPL match live in HD quality across its TV, mobile, and broadband platforms. Johan Buse, StarHub's chief of the consumer business group, emphasized the company's commitment to delivering a different experience to fans, with features like OTT, party watch, and on-demand viewing. The pricing for the EPL package will be announced in June, with Buse stating that the company aims to make the product more affordable and accessible to the masses.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
StarHub clinches Premier League rights in 6-year deal

site_title: China quietly increases purchases of low-priced Russian oil
summary: China is quietly increasing its purchases of low-priced Russian oil, filling the vacuum left by Western buyers who have backed away from business with Russia after its invasion of Ukraine in February. China's seaborne Russian oil imports are expected to jump to a near-record 1.1 million barrels per day in May, up from 750,000 bpd in the first quarter. Unipec, a trading arm of Asia's top refiner Sinopec Corp, is leading the purchases, along with Zhenhua Oil and Livna Shipping, a Hong Kong-registered firm. The low price of Russian oil is a boon for China's refiners, who face shrinking margins in a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Oil has rallied this year following Russia’s invasion of its smaller neighbour, but the price of its own crude has tumbled as buyers step away to avoid damaging their reputation or being swept up in financial sanctions.

China's crude oil imports from top supplier Saudi Arabia soared 38 per cent in April from a year earlier, hitting the highest monthly volume since May 2020, according to Reuters' calculations based on official Chinese customs data.

site_title: TTJ Holdings’ chairman makes S$0.23 per share privatisation bid
summary: TTJ Holdings' chairman, Teo Hock Chwee, is making a S$0.23 per share voluntary conditional offer to privatize the structural steel specialist. The offer, made by investment holding company THC Venture, represents a 33.6% premium over the last traded price of S$0.169 per share. The offer is conditional on receiving over 90% of issued shares and does not intend to preserve the listing status. This move aims to provide shareholders with a premium over market price without brokerage costs, as the company's shares have low trading liquidity.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Building and construction stocks surge in anticipation of recovery
TTJ Holdings swings into the black with S$1.6m in H2

site_title: Japan to double limit on foreign arrivals from next month
summary: Japan will double its foreign arrival limit to 20,000 per day starting next month, allowing most countries to enter without COVID-19 tests or quarantine. This includes G7 countries and business travelers, students, and academics. However, tourists will only be allowed in limited trial package tours, with experience from these trials to be used in future decisions to further reopen the country.

site_title: US House Speaker Pelosi warns Britain: No trade deal unless you respect Northern Irish peace deal
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi warned Britain that a post-Brexit trade deal with the US is unlikely unless it respects the Northern Irish peace deal. Pelosi stated that the existing agreement is crucial to maintaining peace in Northern Ireland, which has been plagued by sectarian conflict since the 1998 Good Friday Accords. If Britain unilaterally scraps rules governing trade with Northern Ireland, the US Congress will not support a bilateral free trade agreement with the UK.

images.alt_text: Britain said on Tuesday it would take all necessary steps to protect peace in Northern Ireland as it urged the European Union to show new imagination in talks to resolve problems with post-Brexit trading rules.

Britain on Wednesday rejected European Union proposals to resolve a standoff over post-Brexit trade rules for Northern Ireland, saying it would not shy away from taking direct action in the latest escalation between the two sides.

site_title: Ex-Julius Baer banker boosts hiring to target Asia's ultra-rich
summary: Former Julius Baer banker Ali Jamal is expanding his wealth-management firm Azura's Asia operations, targeting the ultra-rich. Jamal, 40, has added over 20 professionals since 2021 and plans to make up 1/3 of its total headcount with the Singapore team within the next few years. Lawrence Lua, former DBS Group Holdings' global head of private bank, was hired as chairman of Azura's Singapore branch. Azura has opened offices in Dubai, London, Geneva, and Monaco, and currently has 40 employees globally. The firm aims to capitalize on Singapore's reputation as a global wealth hub.

site_title: Japan Inc to be required to disclose gender pay gaps: PM Kishida
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has pledged to require big firms to disclose wage gaps between men and women as part of his "new capitalism" agenda. The rule will apply to 17,650 firms with over 300 employees, aiming to address long-time gender-based inequalities. The move is part of Japan's efforts to balance economic and social concerns, following the country's chronic labor shortage and lagging pay equality, with women's earnings averaging 78% of men's. The new rules are expected to pressure companies to review traditional career development and promotion practices.

site_title: Seroja Investments eyes RTO with acquisition of Denway Development for up to US$2b
summary: Seroja Investments has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement with Nickel Global Group and Denway Development to acquire Denway in a reverse takeover (RTO) for up to US$2 billion. The deal will give Seroja a majority stake in two nickel ore mines in Indonesia, with a significant reserve of nickel ore. An extraordinary general meeting will be held to vote on the proposal. The acquisition aims to increase shareholder value and enhance investor interest in the shares.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
The commodity trading industry is dominated by a group of mostly private companies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.29 points to 1,549.12. The index saw 2.394 billion lots traded worth RM1.985 billion. In contrast, the broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 593 to 318.

site_title: Not-so-stable coins: Why currency pegs don’t always work
summary: TerraUSD, a stablecoin, lost its peg to the US dollar, destabilizing other stablecoins, including Tether, which briefly lost its peg. The failure of TerraUSD, an algorithmic stablecoin, highlights the difficulties of maintaining a peg, as it relies on computer code and sister tokens rather than significant collateral. The history of currency pegs, including Hong Kong's successful peg, shows that substantial reserves and a flexible economy are crucial for maintaining a peg. Stablecoins face significant risks, including insufficient reserves and an unregulated environment, making their pegs vulnerable to volatility.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Cryptocurrencies play almost no role in economic transactions other than speculation in crypto markets themselves.
The current crypto crash could be a new bullish signal for Bitcoin, and possibly Ethereum, as extreme volatility brings a sharper focus to the market.
Kwon’s rise was enabled by respected financiers who were willing to back highly speculative financial products.
Coming as perhaps the darkest moment in crypto’s history so far, Singaporean investors in TerraUSD or Luna had to endure losses ranging from a few hundred dollars to more than five-digit.

site_title: China's yuan snaps 6 weeks of losses, on course for best week in 17 years
summary: China's yuan surged to a two-week high against the US dollar on Friday, on track for its biggest weekly gain in 17 years, driven by broad US dollar weakness and strong capital inflows. The onshore yuan finished at 6.6740 per US dollar, up 0.55% from the previous close, with potential gains capped by company dividend payments and the ongoing COVID-19 lockdowns. If sustained, the weekly gain would be its best since 2005, when China revalued the currency.

site_title: Biden arrives in South Korea with first stop at Samsung
summary: US President Joe Biden arrived in South Korea on Friday, marking his first trip to Asia as president. He met with President Yoon Suk-yeol and toured a Samsung Electronics plant before a full day of events on Saturday. Biden aims to counter China's influence and build economic ties, but South Korea is expected to maintain a cautious tone on the topic. The two countries are set to join the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework, which will set standards on labor, the environment, and supply chains. Biden will also face the challenge of North Korea, where leader Kim Jong Un is poised to resume testing nuclear bombs.

images.alt_text: Joe Biden leaves on Thursday for his first trip as president to Asia convinced that the confrontation with Russia has reinvigorated US leadership.

site_title: UK flying taxi startup mulls ship-to-shore delivery in Singapore
summary: UK-based flying taxi startup Skyports is planning to launch ship-to-shore drone deliveries in Singapore over the next year. The company signed a deal with Jurong Port to explore the development of ship-to-shore infrastructure. Skyports aims to commercialize its service, which could bring faster delivery times, higher labor productivity, and reduced emissions. The market for drone package deliveries is expected to grow to over $15 billion by 2028. The service will initially focus on last-mile shipping and logistics operations, complementing boat deliveries for weight and package size limitations.

site_title: Finnish brewery launches Nato beer to mark membership application
summary: A small Finnish brewery, Olaf Brewing, has launched a new beer called Otan olutta to celebrate Finland's application to join the Nato military alliance. The lager, named after the French variation of Nato's initials, is a play on the Finnish phrase for "I'll have some beer." The brewery's CEO, Petteri Vanttinen, views the beer as a symbol of security and freedom, saying "we can have a beer now we've got this far in the process." The brewery's cans feature Nato's color scheme and logo, and the company is named after a medieval stone fortress in Finland.

images.alt_text: Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg attends a ceremony to mark Sweden's and Finland's application for membership.

Finland's ambassador to Nato Klaus Korhonen, Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg and Sweden's ambassador to Nato Axel Wernhoff at a ceremony to mark Sweden's and Finland's application for membership in Brussels, on May 18, 2022.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after two-day selloff
summary: Wall Street's main indexes rose on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 173.81 points, or 0.56%, to 31,426.94. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 up 26.97 points, or 0.69%, to 3,927.76, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 154.18 points, or 1.35%, to 11,542.67. The gains followed a two-day selloff amid concerns over inflation and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Halcyon Agri Q1 revenue up 18.9% on higher sales, average selling prices
summary: Halcyon Agri's Q1 revenue rose 18.9% to US$617.3 million, driven by higher sales volume and average selling prices. The company's Ebita increased 5.6% to US$15.1 million, while gross profit margins rose 20.8% to US$47 million. Sales volume grew 5.2% year-over-year to 306,733 tonnes. Despite an operating loss in its upstream business unit, the company expects improvement in the coming quarters and maintains a positive view on mid- to long-term supply and demand dynamics of natural rubber.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Halcyon Agri swings back into black with US$10.8m H2 profit
Halcyon Agri eyes return to profitability amid stronger rubber demand, prices
Halcyon Agri guides for post-tax profit for FY2021, reversing year-ago loss

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub remains in lockdown for almost 2 months, with more residents recently allowed to go out for groceries. The lockdown, which started in March, has had a significant impact on the city's economy and global supply chains. According to Morgan Stanley's chief China economist, the worst of supply chain disruptions in China appears to be over, but the road to recovery is likely to be slow and bumpy.

images.alt_text: Market sentiment should remain tentative over the next few weeks, analysts say.

site_title: BOE's Pill sees need for further interest rate rises
summary: UK central bank chief economist Huw Pill warns the Bank of England (BOE) will need to raise interest rates further to combat self-perpetuating price rises, amid a 40-year high inflation rate of 9.0%. Pill cites the risk of "inflationary psychology" becoming entrenched and urges caution in interpreting BOE forecasts, which do not capture potential future disruptions. The BOE has already raised interest rates four times since December, with expectations of a 2% rate by the end of the year.

site_title: UK retail sales jump unexpectedly in April
summary: UK retail sales volumes rose 1.4% month-on-month in April, reversing a 1.2% drop in March, but the outlook for consumer spending remains weak due to the cost-of-living crunch. Retail sales in the 3 months to April fell 0.3%, after a 0.7% drop in March. This data contrasts with economists' expectations of a 0.2% monthly fall in retail sales.

images.alt_text: Shoppers walk along a street in Covent Garden, London, UK, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Britain’s worst bout of inflation in 40 years is quickly becoming a crisis both for Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government and the Bank of England. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Food shortages add to Sri Lanka's woes
summary: Sri Lanka is facing a dire economic crisis, marked by a shortage of foreign exchange, fuel, and medicines, which has slowed economic activity. The country has struggled with crop yields due to a ban on chemical fertilizers, reversed by the government but with no substantial imports yet. The government has vowed to ensure adequate stocks for the next planting season. Inflation is expected to rise to 40% in the next couple of months, with food prices up 46.6% year-on-year. Protests against the government have increased, with students demanding the ouster of the president and prime minister.

images.alt_text: SRI LANKA fell into default for the first time in its history as the government struggles to halt an economic meltdown that prompted mass protests and a political crisis.

site_title: Terra trauma: Investors lick their wounds amid cryptocurrency implosion
summary: Singaporean investors suffered significant losses after the collapse of TerraUSD (UST) and its affiliated cryptocurrency Luna, with some losing up to 5-digit amounts. Young investors like Berkley Lee and Terence Ho, who initially invested in the cryptocurrencies, are now reevaluating their portfolios and adopting a more cautious approach. Experts warn that the crypto space is highly volatile and that investors should diversify their portfolios to minimize risk. The collapse of Terra has led to a broader market downturn, with Bitcoin falling below US$40,000, and investors are pulling out of volatile assets in anticipation of a bear market.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Smartphone with Terra logo is placed on displayed U.S. dollars in this illustration taken May 11, 2022. Illustration taken May 11, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid improving China sentiment; STI up 1.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.6% or 49.87 points to close at 3,240.58 on May 20, amid a regional rally. The move was attributed to China's 15 basis point cut in the 5-year Loan Prime Rate, exceeding market expectations. The STI's top performer was Jardine Matheson Holdings, while banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also saw gains.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Nio has a primary listing of American depositary shares on the New York Stock Exchange. It has listed in Singapore by way of introduction.

site_title: Nobel Foundation returns ancient gold ring to Greece
summary: The Nobel Foundation in Sweden returned an ancient Mycenaean gold ring to Greece, stolen from the island of Rhodes during World War II. The ring, marked with winged sphinxes, was found in 1927 and later purchased by Hungarian Nobel laureate Georg von Békésy. It was kept at the Stockholm Museum of Mediterranean and Near Eastern Antiquities before being returned to the Rhodes archaeological museum. The ring's identity was confirmed in 1975 by archaeologist Carl Gustaf Styrenius, and its return is seen as a significant step in recovering lost antiquities from World War II.

site_title: Huawei, Singapore Poly launch AI and cloud services course; to train 120 participants in next 2 years
summary: Huawei and Singapore Polytechnic have launched an industry certification-based course in artificial intelligence (AI) and cloud services, part of the SkillsFuture Career Transition Programme. The course, starting with a class of 15 in 2022, aims to train up to 120 participants in the next 2 years. Participants will be certified in 5 domains, including AI, cloud services, and Python programming, preparing them for various job roles offered by Huawei and its partners.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Chinese smartphone maker Honor Device is seeking to raise expansion capital ahead of an initial public offering (IPO) as early as this year.

site_title: Malaysia still reviewing proposed cut in palm oil export tax
summary: Malaysia is reviewing a proposed cut in its crude palm oil export tax, amid global market fluctuations following Indonesia's lift of an export ban. The tax cut, proposed at 4-6%, aims to boost Malaysia's share in the edible oil market. Global buyers are expected to source Malaysian palm oil, with prices likely to fall due to increased production. However, prices are expected to remain elevated until mid-2023 due to tight global supply and robust market demand, particularly from China.

images.alt_text: Palm oil, used in everything from margarine to frying fats and shampoo, comprises a third of the world’s vegetable oil market, with Indonesia accounting for about 60 per cent of supply.

site_title: Asia Green in Tampines up for sale at indicative price of S$470m
summary: Asia Green, a 2009-built Grade A office development in Tampines, Singapore, is up for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise at an indicative price of S$470 million (S$1,645 per square foot). The 99-year-leasehold property features 285,559 sq ft of net lettable area and 23 strata titles, with a focus on sustainable green building features. The sale presents investors with a rare opportunity to acquire a core Grade A suburban commercial asset with immediate income yield from high-profile tenants.

images.alt_text: Grand Building relaunched for collective sale at same guide price of S$195m
Two office floors of Springleaf Tower for sale at S$54.8m

site_title: Danone ramps up US baby formula shipments to address shortage
summary: Danone, the world's second-largest baby milk formula maker, has ramped up shipments of infant formula from Europe to address a shortage in the US, following a February recall by Abbott Laboratories. The company's Nutricia North America arm has more than tripled its ocean imports to North America between January and May, with over 90% of the shipments going to the US. This move has given Danone a significant share of the lucrative $4.8 billion US baby formula industry, with Reckitt Benckiser now accounting for over 50% of total baby formula supply in the country.

site_title: Nissan, Mitsubishi Motors unveil light EVs for Japan
summary: Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors unveiled their first jointly developed light electric vehicles (EVs) for Japan's market. The vehicles, priced around 1.78 million yen (S$21,557) and 1.85 million yen, respectively, aim to attract Japanese drivers to battery-powered cars. The move follows a five-year plan to invest $26 billion in EV development, including kei cars, which account for nearly 40% of cars on the road in Japan. The new EVs are expected to start selling this summer, with a range of 180 km.

site_title: BMW dealers ‘not expected to play nice’ here
summary: BMW Group Asia has appointed Eurokars Group as a second BMW dealer in Singapore, with Eurokars' dealership set to open on October 1. The move aims to foster competition in the luxury car retail market, with BMW Group Asia managing director Lars Nielsen stating that he believes there is potential to expand sales further over the next 6-7 years. Nielsen expects both dealerships to compete fiercely, saying "I don't want to make them play nice. Competition is supposed to take place in the market."

images.alt_text: A boxy BMW with a burbling voice has landed here, but it finds itself in hostile territory

site_title: Britain's Nationwide warns inflation surge could dent house prices
summary: Nationwide Building Society reported a nearly doubled annual profit of £1.6 billion, but warned of potential economic and housing market impacts from rising inflation. The UK's second-largest home loan provider attributed the profit to a strong economic recovery, but cautioned that the housing boom may not last, citing pressure on household budgets and a possible downward movement in house prices. The lender's CEO, Joe Garner, described the emerging inflation as a significant drag on the economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on bargain-hunting; post weekly gains
summary: Japanese shares ended 1.27% higher at 26,739.03, marking a 1.18% weekly gain, as investors sought beaten-down stocks amid hopes for corporate earnings growth. The gains came despite a decline on Wall Street due to inflation fears. Top performers included Fast Retailing, SoftBank Group, and Seiko Epson, while Tokyo Gas fell 2.75% and was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index headed up 0.9 per cent or 28.06 points to 3,218.77
Asian markets opened higher Friday, as bargain-hunters capitalised on the battering Wall Street took the day before after decades-high inflation sparked recession fears.
HONG KONG stocks opened higher on Friday despite Wall Street suffering a battering over recession fears.
The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index was up 7.09 points or 0.5 per cent to 1,556.50 as at 9.24 am.

site_title: Inflation crimps Indian firms as rural millions cut spending
summary: India's inflation is forcing poor Indians to cut spending, threatening a slowdown for companies like Godrej Appliances, which saw bumper sales in March and April due to a heatwave. The Ukraine crisis and global supply chain disruptions have driven up prices worldwide, affecting developing countries like India more severely. This is evident in a drop in demand for Godrej Appliances, with early signs of inflationary impact on discretionary spending.

site_title: China property loan growth lowest on record
summary: China's property loan growth slowed to its lowest pace in over a decade, at 6% in March, due to the real-estate market slump caused by developer defaults, virus lockdowns, and weak consumer confidence. Outstanding loans in the property sector reached 53.2 trillion yuan, with residents' mortgages increasing 8.9% and property development loans growing after three consecutive drops. The average interest rate on new mortgages declined to 5.42%, down 17 basis points from the start of the year.

site_title: Early-stage VC firm Antler to invest US$100m in South-east Asia startups by 2025
summary: Early-stage VC firm Antler has committed to investing US$100 million in South-east Asia startups by 2025, aiming to support over 300 new companies. Since its 2018 launch, Antler has invested US$25 million in over 127 startups, including Reebelo, Homebase, and Xanpool. Co-founder Jussi Salovaara stated that South-east Asia is a breeding ground for innovative startups, and Antler aims to give exceptional founders the necessary investment, support, and expertise to realise their visions. This new commitment is expected to fuel the expansion of more startups in the region.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: Amazon, Walmart's Flipkart in talks to buy stake in US$1.1b diagnostics chain: sources
summary: Amazon and Flipkart are in talks to buy a stake in Metropolis, a US$1.1 billion diagnostics chain operating in India and Africa, in a deal potentially worth over US$300 million. The company is seeking a strategic partner by selling a significant minority stake, and has signed non-disclosure agreements with several potential investors, including Amazon and Flipkart. Barclays has been advised on the deal.

images.alt_text: IOI Central Boulevard Towers will have about 1.26 million sq ft of offices and 30,000 sq ft of retail space.
Pang Sze Yunn, chief executive officer of healthtech startup, Neurowyzr
Completed in 1977, the development comprises 5 integrated purpose-built hospital buildings ranging from 2 to 5 storeys.

site_title: Gain insights on using ETFs to grow your portfolio at BT’s webinar
summary: The appetite for exchange-traded funds (ETFs) continues to grow, with global assets reaching over US$10 trillion. Singapore's ETF sector has also seen interest, with the largest stock ETF crossing the S$1 billion milestone in 2020. A webinar by The Business Times on May 26 will discuss the role of ETFs in portfolios and asset allocation, featuring a panel of market practitioners. The hour-long discussion will take place on Zoom and can be registered for at gevme.com/bt-roundtable-2022-growing-your-portfolio-with-etfs.

images.alt_text: Pandemic sparks digital brokerage boom; incumbents unfazed
Will young investors hang on when markets turn volatile?
The brokerage also said that it will contact clients affected by the settlement fee change to arrange for refunds.

site_title: Shanghai finds cases after five days of 'zero Covid' but end of lockdown on track
summary: Shanghai reported its first new COVID-19 cases outside quarantined areas in five days, triggering stricter curbs and mass testing in one district. The cases were found in a family of three who had visited several places, including a supermarket, before being re-tested and cleared. Despite the new cases, plans to end the city-wide lockdown on June 1 appear to be on track, with other officials announcing the reopening of suburban parks and metro lines. Shanghai's economic decline continues, with industrial output shrinking 61.5% in April, but daily container throughput at ports has almost recovered to last year's levels.

images.alt_text: A healthcare worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) collects a swab sample from a resident at a Covid-19 testing facility in Beijing, China, on Wednesday, May 18, 2022. Fresh outbreaks around key Chinese cities and the ongoing Covid-19 spread in Beijing are raising the specter of more disruptive pandemic curbs, even as Shanghai slowly emerges from its six-week lockdown. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Brokers’ take: Phillip raises BRC’s target price amid faster-than-expected construction recovery
summary: Phillip Securities Research has raised its target price for BRC Asia to S$2.26 from S$1.84, citing the company's faster-than-expected construction sector recovery. BRC Asia reported a 108% increase in net profit to S$39.8 million for the first half of 2022, driven by revenue growth of 61% year on year. The brokerage maintains a "buy" call on the counter, expecting a 34.5% upside from its current price. Despite concerns over supply chain disruptions and raw material price increases, Phillip Securities believes the construction sector's recovery remains on track.

images.alt_text: While small-cap stocks are set to have a good run, the Straits Times Index's returns could be stuck in the mid-to-low single digits, said RHB analyst Shekhar Jaiswal.

site_title: Zilingo fires CEO as clash over embattled startup escalates
summary: Zilingo has fired co-founder Ankiti Bose, citing "cause" after an independent investigation into complaints of financial irregularities. The move follows her suspension on March 31 and comes amid a deepening crisis at the Singapore-based startup. Bose disputes the allegations, claiming her termination was due to "insubordination." The investigation, led by Kroll, aims to review Zilingo's finances after auditors raised questions. Creditors have recalled loans, prompting the company to appoint a financial adviser.

images.alt_text: The board suspended its CEO and co-founder Ankiti Bose in March with the backing of major investors, pending a probe by an independent firm they hired.

Ankiti Bose, co-founder and chief executive officer of Zilingo Pte, poses for a photograph in Singapore, on Monday, Feb. 11, 2019. Zilingo said it raised $226 million from investors including Sequoia Capital and Temasek Holdings Pte. The latest financing valued the fashion platform at $970 million, according to people familiar with the matter, who asked not to be named because the information is private. That makes 27-year-old Bose among the youngest female chief executives to lead a startup of the size in Asia. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded on Friday, May 20, after a decline the previous day due to decades-high inflation sparking recession fears. London's FTSE 100 index rose 1.3% to 7,399.77 points, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices gained 1.0% and 0.5% respectively. The rebound was aided by news of recovering UK retail sales and was seen as a relief for investors.

site_title: UK regulator scrutinises Terra fallout as it weighs crypto rules
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is scrutinizing the fallout from the collapse of Terra, a stablecoin that lost over $40 billion in value. The regulator, led by executive director Sarah Pritchard, is considering new rules for cryptoassets and stablecoins, citing concerns over consumer protection and market stability. The FCA will work with the Treasury to develop and implement new regulations, which will include stablecoin issuance and custody services. The regulator's new powers will be announced in the upcoming Financial Services and Markets Bill.

images.alt_text: Kwon’s rise was enabled by respected financiers who were willing to back highly speculative financial products.
The implosion of the algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD and its sister Luna token sent shock waves through the cryptosphere, crashing prices and roiling the entire ecosystem behind the coins.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.09 points or 0.5% to 1,556.50. Volume reached 364.3 million lots worth RM175.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 321 to 147.

site_title: US growth seen outpacing China’s for the first time since 1976
summary: China's economic growth is predicted to undershoot the US for the first time since 1976, with a growth rate of 2% this year, compared to the US's 2.8% growth. China's strict Covid Zero policy and lockdowns are hindering the country's economic recovery. This reversal may have significant implications for China and the US, with potential political reverberations and implications for President Xi Jinping's third term as Communist Party chief. The US, on the other hand, is being propelled by strong hiring and consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Chinese banks cut a key interest rate for long-term loans by a record amount, a move that would reduce mortgage costs and may boost weak loan demand amid a property slump and Covid lockdowns.

site_title: Two industrial buildings at Ang Mo Kio, Bartley put on the market
summary: Two industrial buildings in Ang Mo Kio and Bartley have been put up for sale. The Ang Mo Kio building, with an indicative price of S$27 million, has redevelopment potential and sits on a 87,340 sq ft site zoned for heavier industrial use. The other building, located off Upper Paya Lebar Road, has an indicative price of S$71 million and can be redeveloped into a strata-titled development or corporate headquarters. Both properties are expected to close sales by June 30.

site_title: DeClout makes mandatory cash offer for Procurri after married deal raised its stakes past 30%
summary: Technology incubator DeClout has made a mandatory cash offer for IT solutions provider Procurri Corporation, purchasing 3.9 million shares through a married deal and triggering a need for a compliance offer. The offer price of S$0.425 per share is final, and DeClout will not increase the price further. DeClout intends to maintain Procurri's listing status and does not currently plan to exercise any rights of compulsory acquisition.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Procurri provides data centre maintenance, OEM recertified hardware, and IT lifecycle services.
Partial offer for Procurri lapses, both requisite thresholds unmet
DeClout says no plan for now to mount counter offer for Procurri
Third Procurri shareholder comes out against Novo Tellus' partial offer

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher, post biggest weekly gain in 2 months
summary: South Korea's Kospi index ended 1.81% higher on Friday, posting its biggest weekly gain in 2 months, driven by China's policy measures and a weaker dollar. The won jumped, snapping a 6-week losing streak, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Key performers included Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, with LG Energy Solution and LG Chem also experiencing significant gains. Foreigners were net buyers of 194 billion won worth of shares, and the currency strengthened by 1.27% against the dollar for the week.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 33.64 points, or 1.28 per cent, at 2,592.34, after 2 sessions of gains.

site_title: Thai agritech startup Freshket secures US$23.5m Series B round
summary: Thai agritech startup Freshket has secured US$23.5 million in Series B funding led by PTT Oil and Retail Business, with other investors including Openspace Ventures and Betagro Holding. The funds will be used to enhance supply chain technology, expand operations to new regions, and increase product offerings. Freshket aims to reduce food waste and improve farmers' income by sourcing 30% of its products directly from local farmers, with plans to expand to new areas and develop demand forecasting technology.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

From left: Oddle co-founder Alan Goh, founder and CEO Jonathan Lim, and co-founder Yong Xiang Pua.  The fresh funds will be used for product development and market expansion in Singapore, Malaysia, Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Financial infrastructure startup Xendit is set to face a tough challenge from global and local rivals, including from Stripe, which has ramped up efforts in Indonesia and the Philippines.

site_title: Tesla wants China staff to stay in factory bubble until mid-June: sources
summary: Tesla plans to keep its Shanghai factory staff in a closed loop system, including daily Covid-19 testing and on-site accommodations, until mid-June. The factory has been operating 12-hour shifts, 6 days a week, to restart production after a lockdown pause. Tesla is also considering a second shift and negotiating with Shanghai authorities for accommodation options. Despite easing lockdown restrictions, Shanghai remains restricted, with residents requiring special passes to leave their apartment blocks and many businesses still closed.

images.alt_text: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said on Thursday that "Tesla is on my mind 24/7," trying to soothe investor worries about him being distracted by a Twitter deal that has depressed stocks at the electric car company.

site_title: The worst of supply chain disruptions in China is over: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley's chief China economist, Robin Xing, says the worst of supply chain disruptions in China is over, but the road to recovery will be slow and bumpy. Xing predicts a quarter-on-quarter contraction in China's GDP growth in the second quarter, but a pickup in production activities from the third quarter. China is expected to exit its zero-Covid strategy by the end of the year, with a forecasted GDP growth of 4.2% for 2022, assuming no further extended lockdowns.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Morgan Stanley forecasts this year’s global economic growth to be less than half of 2021 due to risks from the Russia-Ukraine conflict and Covid-19 surge in China even as central banks tighten monetary policy to control record high inflation.
Chinese banks cut a key interest rate for long-term loans by a record amount, a move that would reduce mortgage costs and may boost weak loan demand amid a property slump and Covid lockdowns.

site_title: Gold set for first weekly gain in 5 as dollar rally eases
summary: Gold prices rose near a 1-week high, set for their first weekly gain since mid-April, as the US dollar receded from 2-decade highs. Spot gold hovered near $1,841.37 per ounce, while US gold futures edged 0.1% lower. A weaker dollar and falling US 10-year Treasury yields revived demand for safe-haven bullion, amid growth concerns and aggressive monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were flat on Thursday, as an elevated dollar weighed on greenback-priced bullion and countered support from lower Treasury yields, with the metal's outlook already dulled by an aggressive Federal Reserve stance on inflation.

site_title: Palm oil export ban lift to send global CPO, share prices in different directions: analysts
summary: Indonesia's palm oil export ban, implemented on April 28, will be lifted from May 23, sending global crude palm oil (CPO) prices in different directions. Analysts expect Indonesian plantation players to benefit, while those in Malaysia will lose out as they no longer have the advantage as the main supplier of palm oil. Global CPO prices are anticipated to fall, and the current gap between Malaysian and Indonesian CPO prices is expected to narrow, leading to a softening of global CPO prices.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Palm oil, used in everything from margarine to frying fats and shampoo, comprises a third of the world’s vegetable oil market, with Indonesia accounting for about 60 per cent of supply.
INDONESIA will lift its palm oil export ban from Monday (May 23), following improvements in the domestic cooking oil supply situation, President Joko Widodo said on Thursday

INDONESIAN lawmakers on Thursday (May 19) requested that the government review an export ban on palm oil, as industry groups warned that one of the country's leading economic contributors could grind to a halt in coming weeks as storage nears full capacity.

site_title: Thailand begins to reopen bars, nightclubs to woo back tourists
summary: Thailand has begun to reopen bars and nightclubs in some regions, ending a 1-year shutdown, as the country targets tourists to boost its economic recovery. The reopening allows pubs and bars in green and blue zones to serve patrons until midnight, starting from an unspecified date. The move aims to lure more foreign tourists during the June-September period, considered a low season for Thai tourism. Thailand expects tourist arrivals to more than triple to about 1 million a month from October as it rolls back border controls and scraps mandatory Covid testing for tourists.

images.alt_text: A worker waits for customers outside a bar on Khaosan Road in Bangkok in February.

site_title: China banks cut key rate by record to boost ailing economy
summary: Chinese banks cut the 5-year loan prime rate to 4.45% from 4.6%, a record low since 2019, to boost weak loan demand amid a property slump and Covid lockdowns. The move aims to reduce mortgage costs and stimulate economic activity. The 1-year loan prime rate remained unchanged at 3.7%. The cut is seen as a response to the PBOC's earlier reduction in mortgage rate floor and comes after loan demand weakened in April.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) in Beijing.
Chinese banks may cut their benchmark lending rates for a second time this year, giving consumers and businesses some relief as Covid lockdowns and outbreaks wreak havoc on the economy.

site_title: Crypto startup tries to claw its way back from Luna disaster
summary: Crypto startup Stader Labs, which was heavily reliant on the Luna coin, is trying to recover from the collapse of algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD and its sister Luna token. The company's total value locked on its protocol has dropped to $50 million from $750 million before the crash, resulting in a 40% hit on revenues. Stader is expanding into rival blockchains and has enough cash to weather the storm, with over $40 million in funding. The company's CEO is optimistic about the potential for decentralized stablecoins in the long run, but acknowledges the need for lessons to be learned from the Terra implosion.

images.alt_text: Tether, the world's largest stablecoin, said on Thursday it has boosted its holdings of US government debt while cutting exposure to riskier assets, the first look at its reserves since the token was rocked by the crypto sector's recent sell-off.

site_title: China's April Saudi oil imports soar 38% on yr, Russian oil up 4%
summary: China's crude oil imports from Saudi Arabia surged 38% in April to 8.93 million tonnes, the highest monthly volume since May 2020. Russian oil imports rose 4% to 6.55 million tonnes, while overall Chinese crude oil imports increased 7% for the first time in 3 months. Despite US sanctions, China continues to import oil from Iran, with nearly 2 million barrels expected in May. Chinese liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports from Russia rose 80% in April, but overall LNG imports fell 34.5% due to high global prices.

images.alt_text: Oil has rallied this year following Russia’s invasion of its smaller neighbour, but the price of its own crude has tumbled as buyers step away to avoid damaging their reputation or being swept up in financial sanctions.
