site_title: Zurich Insurance to exit Russian market, sell business to local team
summary: Zurich Insurance has agreed to sell its Russian business to local team members, becoming the latest company to exit the market due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The Swiss insurer will retain a 0.3% market share and sell its business for regulatory approval. The sale will allow the new company to operate independently under a different brand, while Zurich will no longer conduct business operations in Russia. The deal is part of a growing trend of companies quitting the Russian market, with Zurich's Russian business generating $34 million in gross written premiums in 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, May 20, 2022, despite falls on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.14% and the Topix index gained 0.03%. Bargain-hunting purchases offset risk-off sentiment among investors, leading to the positive trading session.

site_title: Top securities regulator fired amid Vietnam’s market probe
summary: Vietnam's finance ministry fired State Securities Commission chairman Tran Van Dung for "serious wrongdoings" amid an ongoing investigation into stock trading. The move follows the dismissal of Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange's General Director Le Hai Tra from the Communist Party two days prior. Deputy Finance Minister Nguyen Duc Chi will temporarily take charge of the commission.

images.alt_text: A man uses a mobile phone as a bull statue stands at the Hanoi Stock Exchange (HNX) in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Monday, Sept. 10, 2018. Vietnam has averaged economic growth of 6.3 percent between 2005 and 2017, multiplying its per capita income six-fold to $2,385 last year from $396 in 2000, according to data from General Statistics Office in Hanoi. Photographer: Maika Elan/Bloomberg
The chairman of Vietnam's Vingroup conglomerate said on Wednesday that an initial public offering (IPO) for the company's auto unit, VinFast, may be delayed until next year due to market uncertainty.

site_title: Cost of living in focus as Australia's election race hits final stretch
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison is running a tight election campaign, despite polls indicating a possible change of government or hung parliament. Morrison and Labor leader Anthony Albanese targeted key seats, focusing on the cost of living, with Morrison promising to manage the nation's finances and Albanese pledging to boost the minimum wage to keep pace with inflation. The election, set for Saturday, has seen a surge in pre-poll and postal votes, with over 6.5 million cast out of 17 million eligible voters.

images.alt_text: Australia posted its lowest jobless rate in 48 years on Thursday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Centurion, FLCT, Yeo Hiap Seng, PEC
summary: Centurion Corp announced plans to acquire a 103-bed student accommodation asset in Nottingham, UK, for £10.4 million (S$18 million). Shares fell 1.4% to S$0.35. Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) plans to acquire a freehold suburban property in Victoria, Australia, for A$60.25 million (S$58.4 million). Yeo Hiap Seng's CFO and CEO tendered their resignations. PEC won new contracts worth S$80 million. TTJ Holdings called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Bitcoin slump erodes fortunes of would-be miners in Thailand
summary: Thailand's Jasmine Technology Solution, a telecom-turned-crypto company, has seen a significant slump in value, with its market capitalization dropping to 260 billion baht (S$10.4 billion) after losing more than a third of its value in the past month. The company's 7 biggest individual shareholders, including Pete Bodharamik, have also seen their fortunes decline, with Bodharamik's stake dropping below US$1 billion. The company's Bitcoin mining plans have been met with regulatory scrutiny and concerns about the regulatory environment, leading to a halt in trading.

images.alt_text: The current crypto crash could be a new bullish signal for Bitcoin, and possibly Ethereum, as extreme volatility brings a sharper focus to the market.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% or 28.06 points to 3,218.77, driven by gains in banking stocks and heavy trading in counters like Jiutian Chemical, Golden Agri-Resources, and Sembcorp Marine. This follows a decline in US stocks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.8% and European stocks slumping 1.5%. The rally is seen as a response to concerns about a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Consumer brands told The Business Times that Shanghai shopping malls have asked them to prepare for reopening, but with few details on how and when this will happen.

site_title: Richemont profit and sales jump, discussions about YNAP continue
summary: Richemont, the luxury goods group behind Cartier, reported a 61% increase in net profit to €2.1 billion and a 44% jump in sales to €19.2 billion in the 12 months to March, driven by strong demand for its jewelry and watches. However, the company did not provide an update on its plans to relinquish control of YNAP, citing ongoing discussions with "Luxury New Retail" partners, which are expected to be concluded "in the near future".

images.alt_text: The relaxation of Covid-19 measures gives existing retailers, as well as new-to-market entrants greater confidence in their expansion plans.
Luxury salespeople need to develop new skills, to become more agile, less focused on the brand, and more focused on customers.
THE boom in demand for Rolex watches and a lack of sufficient supply is driving sales of other luxury timepieces, the head of retailer Watches of Switzerland Group said.

site_title: China in talks with Russia to buy oil for strategic reserves: sources
summary: China is in talks with Russia to buy discounted Russian oil to replenish its strategic crude stockpiles, amid rising oil prices and Europe's plans to ban Russian imports. The talks, conducted at a government level, aim to fill China's vast strategic reserves, which have dwindled due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The potential deal would provide China with cheap oil, as the US and UK have pledged to ban Russian oil imports, and Europe is discussing similar steps.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Oil and gas tanks are seen at an oil warehouse at a port in Zhuhai, China October 22, 2018. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.74% on Friday, May 20, 2022, to 20,470.95, despite US recession fears. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Nio shares surge over 20% in early trade in SGX mainboard debut
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, made its Singapore Exchange (SGX) debut, with its shares surging over 20% in early trade. The company expects its unique battery swapping technology to grow its market share globally. Nio's CEO William Li believes the technology will allow EV drivers to spend less time at charging stations and choose different battery capacities. The company plans to build battery swapping facilities in all new markets and has already begun hiring for a research and development centre in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Michelle Zhu
CHINESE electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio has received a conditional green light for its proposed secondary listing in Singapore.

Hong Kong hasn’t hosted any IPO larger than US$1 billion so far this year. Overall proceeds in the Asian financial hub have slumped, with the vast majority of newcomers plunging below the listing price after they debuted.
China EV maker Nio misses estimates amid supply pressures
Chinese EV maker Nio debuts in Hong Kong homecoming listing
Chinese EV maker Nio pursues secondary listings in Singapore, Hong Kong

site_title: World’s No. 1 chipmaker TSMC eyes multibillion-dollar  plant in Singapore
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker, is considering a multibillion-dollar plant in Singapore, according to the Wall Street Journal. The Singapore government may help fund the construction, with negotiations underway with the Economic Development Board. TSMC, a major Apple supplier, is evaluating the feasibility of production lines for 7-28 nanometre chips, which are widely used in smartphones and cars. The move comes after TSMC posted a record first-quarter net profit in April, beating estimates due to solid demand for chips and rising prices amid a global chip shortage.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
TSMC beats profit estimates as gadget demand boosts chip sales
TSMC, Samsung urge US to allow them into US$52b chip plan

site_title: EU apartments a new front in energy war with Russia
summary: The European Union is accelerating efforts to replace fossil fuel heating with heat pumps to meet its 55% greenhouse gas emission reduction target by 2030. Heat pumps, which extract warmth from air, liquids, or other sources, are seen as a key technology for securing energy independence from Russian natural gas. The EU imports 90% of its natural gas, 40% of which comes from Russia, and currently, heat pumps supply only 2.5% of the EU's heating and cooling demand. Retrofitting existing housing to run on heat pumps is complicated and expensive, but experts call for accelerated natural gas bans, more government incentives, and a carbon tax to spur adoption of the technology.

images.alt_text: European shares slipped on Wednesday led by technology stocks.

site_title: New Zealand economy will skirt recession in 2023, Treasury says
summary: New Zealand's economy is expected to narrowly avoid recession in 2023, according to the Treasury Department. Gross domestic product is forecast to grow just 0.1% in each of the second, third, and fourth quarters of 2023, and annual average growth will slump to 0.7% from 4.2% in the previous year. Rising mortgage rates and falling house prices are expected to cool the housing market and dampen consumer spending, while inflation pressures will continue to linger.

images.alt_text: The Chinese Premier called for greater “urgency” in rolling out measures to support the country’s virus-battered economy, state media reported on Wednesday, days after data highlighted the stark impact of Covid-19 restrictions.

President Joe Biden will launch a long-awaited economic initiative for increasing US involvement in Asia in the coming days during his trip to the region, according to one of the cabinet officials leading the initiative.

The Australian (pictured) and New Zealand dollars suffered a fresh setback on Monday (May 16) when stunningly weak economic data out of China stoked fears of a global recession, undermining risk assets and commodities.

site_title: Schroders to oppose Amazon, Meta, Alphabet over worker, digital rights
summary: Britain's largest asset manager, Schroders, plans to vote against 11 shareholder resolutions at Amazon, Meta, and Alphabet over workers' and digital rights. Schroders will oppose management on issues such as workers' pay and benefits at Amazon, while supporting improved digital rights at Meta and Alphabet. The move is seen as an escalation measure following talks with the companies, and reflects growing pressure from clients to ensure companies act responsibly on environmental, social, and governance issues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed Whatsapp logo is placed on the keyboard in this illustration taken April 12, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Musk says 'Tesla is on my mind 24/7' amid concerns about Twitter distraction
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk stated that "Tesla is on my mind 24/7" amid investor concerns about his distraction from the Twitter deal. Musk claimed to be spending less than 5% of his time on the Twitter acquisition, saying it's "not rocket science." Tesla shares have lost a third of their value since Musk disclosed his Twitter stake and sold $8.5 billion worth of Tesla stocks. Analysts and investors, including Daniel Ives and Leo KoGuan, expressed worries about Musk's distraction and the impact on the company's production and stock performance.

images.alt_text: The world's most famous electric-vehicle maker has lost its spot on the ESG version of the S&P 500 Index.

site_title: Outlook for Singapore retail rents favourable: analysts
summary: Analysts predict a favorable outlook for Singapore retail rents due to the relaxation of Covid-19 measures, sustained economic growth, and increasing consumer footfall. Retail rents are expected to grow 1.5 to 3.5% year on year in 2022, with prime floor space rents anticipated to reach pre-pandemic levels next year. This confidence in expansion plans is driven by the lifting of safe management measures and the return of tourism spending.

images.alt_text: Recovery may be in sight for Singapore retail property market

site_title: Japan inflation hits 7-year high
summary: Japan's core consumer prices jumped 2.1% year-on-year in April, the largest increase in 7 years, driven by soaring global commodity prices and a slump in the yen. This exceeds the Bank of Japan's 2.0% long-term inflation target and follows a 0.8% rise in March. Energy prices, excluding fresh food, also rose 0.8% in April, marking the first positive figure since July 2020. The Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, citing temporary and volatile price trends.

images.alt_text: The analyst consensus is for tougher central bank action in the second half of 2022.

site_title: Canada to ban Huawei/ZTE 5G equipment as China tensions ease
summary: Canada has announced plans to ban the use of Huawei Technologies and ZTE 5G equipment to protect national security, joining the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing network. Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne stated that providers with installed equipment must remove it by June 2024, with companies using 4G equipment required to remove it by the end of 2027. The decision follows diplomatic tensions with China, with the rest of the Five Eyes network having already banned the equipment.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS almost halves target price on Grab after revising valuation metrics
summary: DBS Group Research reduced its target price on Grab Holdings to US$2.93 from US$5.60, citing a 7.6% potential downside. The research team changed its valuation metrics to 2.8 times revenue, in line with peers Uber and DoorDash. Grab narrowed losses for Q1 FY2022 to US$435 million, with revenue growing 6% to US$228 million. DBS expects Grab's adjusted Ebitda losses to continue for at least 2 years. The research maintains a "hold" call on the stock.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

A GrabFood delivery man walking past the company logo in the new Grab office at Marina One West Tower on May 28, 2018. Ride-hailing app Grab holds a media briefing to share about its plans and direction.##########ECSILICON##########KEVIN LIM

site_title: IMF urges Asia to be mindful of spillover risks from tightening
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Asian economies to be mindful of spillover risks as major central banks withdraw unconventional easing policies faster than expected. Deputy managing director Kenji Okamura warned that the most vulnerable economies face a choice between supporting growth with more stimulus or stabilizing debt and inflation. With the COVID-19 pandemic and war in Ukraine affecting growth, Okamura called for calibrated policies and clear communication to mitigate the impact of tighter global financial conditions. He also cautioned that drifting inflation expectations could lead to more forceful tightening.

images.alt_text: In its latest forecast issued this month, the IMF said it expects Asia’s economy to expand 4.9 per cent this year, down 0.5 percentage points from its previous projection made in January.

site_title: Indonesian Stripe rival Xendit raises US$300m, eyes regional expansion
summary: Indonesian fintech startup Xendit has raised $300 million in funding, valuing the company at nearly $3 billion. The 8-year-old company aims to expand in Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam, targeting a booming internet market in the region. Xendit has processed $15 billion in payments in Indonesia and the Philippines over the past year, and has 3,000 enterprises in its client list. The company faces competition from global and local rivals, including Stripe, which has ramped up efforts in Indonesia and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: From left: Oddle co-founder Alan Goh, founder and CEO Jonathan Lim, and co-founder Yong Xiang Pua.  The fresh funds will be used for product development and market expansion in Singapore, Malaysia, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

site_title: North Korea claims 'good results' in Covid fight as fever cases top 2m
summary: North Korea reported "good results" in its fight against the country's first confirmed Covid-19 outbreak, with 263,370 new fever cases and 2 additional deaths, bringing the total fever caseload to 2.24 million.

images.alt_text: People watch a TV broadcasting a news report on the coronavirus disease (Covid-19) outbreak in North Korea, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, May 17, 2022.

site_title: Centurion to acquire freehold student accommodation in Nottingham
summary: Centurion Corp acquired a 103-bed freehold student accommodation asset in Nottingham, UK for £10.4 million (S$18 million). The building, The Orbital, will be rebranded and managed with two other PBSA assets in Nottingham. Centurion expects the acquisition to enlarge its UK PBSA portfolio to 2,910 beds. The company notes that Nottingham has a strong PBSA market with a projected shortfall of 2,000 beds and 5,000 beds by 2024/2025. The asset is expected to be accretive upon completion and enable management synergies in Nottingham and the UK.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Centurion's revenue from Singapore grew some 51 per cent year on year to S$30.6 million for the first quarter of 2022.
Centurion expects the move to enhance shareholder value as part of its efforts to rationalise its portfolio of assets.
Brokers' take: RHB expects Centurion's financials to improve, upgrades to 'buy'
Centurion gains on expanded worker accommodation portfolio; number of beds to fall in 2022

site_title: Europe: Shares lower as retailers, food and beverage stocks lead falls
summary: European shares declined 1.5% on Thursday, the second straight session, due to dismal US retailer results and surging inflation. European retailers fell nearly 2% and led the decline, with major stocks like Tesco, Nestle, and Unilever dropping 4.5-5.5%. The Stoxx 600 index is down 12% for the year, with investors fleeing to bonds amid concerns about stagflation and the Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: EUROPE'S main stock markets opened sharply lower on Thursday (May 19), after heavy losses in Asia and on Wall Street.

site_title: UK consumer morale hits lowest since records began in 1974: GfK
summary: UK consumer morale has reached an all-time low of -40 in May, according to a survey by market research firm GfK, surpassing previous readings that predicted a recession. The cost-of-living crisis has pushed confidence in the economic outlook to its joint lowest, with households facing the highest rates of inflation since the early 1980s. Economists warn that further government action may be necessary to address the crisis, which has left consumer confidence weaker than in previous recessions, including the 2008 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Lloyds on Wednesday announced plans to shut 28 branches, two months after revealing it would permanently close 60 other sites.

site_title: US launches US$3.5b programme to speed development of up carbon removal tech
summary: The US Energy Department has launched a $3.5 billion programme to fund four large-scale projects that can remove carbon dioxide from the air, aiming to meet the goal of achieving net-zero emissions by mid-century. The projects, part of the 2021 Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, will create four regional direct air capture hubs to spur the widespread deployment of carbon removal technology. This investment is seen as necessary to combat climate change, following a report by the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change that highlighted the need for carbon removal technologies.

images.alt_text: Climate models see the use of carbon capture technology growing to 10 times within the next decade to put the world on track to slow the rise in global temperatures.

site_title: US existing home sales fall for third straight month; house prices at record high
summary: US existing home sales dropped 2.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.61 million units in April, the lowest level since June 2020, amid a persistent lack of inventory. House prices reached a record high, leading to the third straight monthly sales decline. Sales rose in the Northeast and Midwest but fell in the South and West, with economists forecasting further declines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A "For Sale" sign is posted outside a residential home in the Queen Anne neighborhood near the Space Needle in Seattle, Washington, U.S. May 14, 2021.   REUTERS/Karen Ducey/File Photo
US MORTGAGE rates jumped again this week, extending a steep climb that is shutting some would-be homebuyers out of the market.

PERMITS for future US homebuilding tumbled to a 5-month low in April, suggesting the housing market was slowing as rising mortgage rates contribute to reduced affordability for entry-level and first-time buyers.

site_title: Qatar World Cup marks last dance for Messi and Ronaldo
summary: The 2022 Qatar World Cup marks the end of an era for football's two dominant players, Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo. The tournament, set to take place in 6 months, will bookend the era of these two pre-eminent players, who have been at the top of the sport for years. The 2018 tournament in Russia is seen as a turning point, as it marked the emergence of teenage Kylian Mbappe as a global superstar, helping France become world champions.

site_title: G7 pledges billions for Ukraine 'to get through this'
summary: The G7 has pledged $18.4 billion to Ukraine to help it pay its bills, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stating the group "stands behind Ukraine" and is committed to providing the necessary resources. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has also authorized $100 million in additional US arms and supplies. Meanwhile, Finland and Sweden are set to join NATO, despite Turkey's objections, and Ukraine has recaptured 23 settlements near Kharkiv in the past two weeks. The conflict remains unclear, with the fate of hundreds of Ukrainian defenders at the Mariupol steelworks still unknown.

images.alt_text: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner was quoted as saying there was also a discussion among Western powers about how Russia could be made to help pay for the massive, longer-term task of rebuilding Ukraine.

site_title: Ahead of Malaysia polls, analysts staying neutral on election-themed stocks
summary: Analysts in Malaysia are taking a neutral stance on election-themed stocks ahead of the upcoming general election, citing political uncertainties and depleted government coffers. The expected "neutral to moderately positive" impact on Malaysian equities is attributed to the Barisan Nasional coalition's expected victory, but the excitement is expected to be less pronounced due to the government's tight finances. Analysts recommend focusing on counters that can replenish the government's coffers, such as oil and gas, and crude palm oil.

images.alt_text: Malaysia PM warns against undermining king in call for election
Looking for election rally? Better to focus on Malaysia's economic rebound instead

site_title: Oil prices recoup losses on renewed supply worries, dollar weakness
summary: Oil prices rebounded on May 19, recouping earlier losses, due to concerns over Chinese officials' plan to ease COVID-19 restrictions in Shanghai, which could tighten global energy supply. Brent crude futures rose 92 cents to $110.03, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 32 cents to $109.91. The dollar's retreat from recent gains also contributed to the price increase, as investors await further developments on the Shanghai restrictions and their impact on oil demand.

images.alt_text: Oil fell 2.5 per cent on Wednesday.

site_title: WhatsApp to launch cloud-based tools, premium features for businesses
summary: WhatsApp is introducing free cloud-based API services to attract more businesses to its platform. Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the move, allowing any business or developer to access the service and build customized experiences. The new API will enable businesses to speed up their response time to customers and generate revenue for Meta. WhatsApp also plans to offer optional paid features as part of a premium service for small businesses, including features to manage chats across multiple devices and custom click-to-chat links.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Deutsche Bank's headquarters in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany.  German financial watchdog BaFin is following up on indications that senior Deutsche Bank executives have been relying on messaging tools like WhatsApp and private e-mail accounts to conduct business, which can violate banking rules.
WhatsApp tests new feature to organise groups for work, school

site_title: 135m euros Mercedes-Benz smashes Ferrari's classic car record
summary: Mercedes-Benz has broken Ferrari's record for the most expensive classic car sold at auction, with a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300 SLR Uhlenhaut Coupé selling for 135 million euros. The rare car, one of only two produced, was sold in a secret auction in Germany, surpassing the previous record of $48.4 million set by a 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO in 2018. The sale is seen as a significant boost to Mercedes-Benz's brand, with Chairman Ola Källenius stating it puts the brand "on a different planet" from competitor Ferrari.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz is honing its identity as a luxury company, cutting out entry-level models and releasing limited collectibles.

site_title: Top stablecoin Tether boosts US Treasuries holdings
summary: Tether, the world's largest stablecoin, has boosted its holdings of US government debt while cutting exposure to riskier assets, its first update on reserves since the recent crypto sector sell-off. This move aims to stabilize the token, which is widely used in cryptocurrency trading and typically backed by dollars, gold, and government debt. The decision follows the demise of the TerraUSD token, highlighting the importance of stablecoins in maintaining market stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with Tether logo is placed on displayed U.S. dollars in this illustration taken, May 12, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The current crypto crash could be a new bullish signal for Bitcoin, and possibly Ethereum, as extreme volatility brings a sharper focus to the market.

site_title: Henderson 5-room HDB flat sets new record resale price of S$1.4m
summary: A 5-room HDB flat in Block 96A, Henderson Road, Singapore, has sold for a record resale price of S$1.4 million, making it the priciest transaction in the HDB resale market. The 41st-floor unit, measuring 1,216 sq ft, is nearly new, having commenced its lease in 2019. This sale follows a 2.4% increase in resale prices for the 8th consecutive quarter, with demand for larger flats and million-dollar HDB flat transactions contributing to the price growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
HDB resale prices rise for 8th straight quarter, up 2.4% in Q1
The most expensive HDB flat resold was S$1,228,000 for a 5-room unit at Pinnacle@Duxton.

site_title: Indonesia to impose local sales rule when palm oil exports restart
summary: Indonesia's economy minister has announced that the country will impose a local sales requirement for palm oil when exports resume next week, aiming to control high domestic cooking oil prices. The move comes after the government lifted an export ban on April 28. Despite the ban lift, bulk cooking oil prices have not yet reached the government's target of 14,000 rupiah (S$1.32) per liter. This policy is part of Indonesia's efforts to shore up local supplies of cooking oil, which comprises a third of the world's vegetable oil market and accounts for 60% of global supply.

images.alt_text: People ride on a motorbike passed the trucks with palm oil fresh fruit bunches queue for unloading at a factory in West Aceh, Indonesia, May 17, 2022, in this photo taken by Antara Foto. Picture taken May 17, 2022. Antara Foto/Syifa Yulinnas/ via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. INDONESIA OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN INDONESIA.
INDONESIA will lift its palm oil export ban from Monday (May 23), following improvements in the domestic cooking oil supply situation, President Joko Widodo said on Thursday

INDONESIAN lawmakers on Thursday (May 19) requested that the government review an export ban on palm oil, as industry groups warned that one of the country's leading economic contributors could grind to a halt in coming weeks as storage nears full capacity.

INDONESIA'S trade minister on Wednesday (May 18) said he expected prices of cooking oil would stabilise after a programme to distribute subsidised supplies reaches 10,000 locations across the country.

site_title: Amazon said to be in advanced negotiations to lease space at IOI Central Boulevard Towers
summary: Amazon is reportedly in advanced negotiations to lease approximately 350,000 sq ft of office space at IOI Properties Group's IOI Central Boulevard Towers in Singapore. Meta is also considered a potential anchor tenant for the project, which is expected to receive its Temporary Occupation Permit in Q3 2023. The development will feature 1.26 million sq ft of offices and 30,000 sq ft of retail space. Industry watchers note that Amazon's lease would leave room for another anchor tenant, and the project's average rent target is estimated at S$12-14 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

krbrunch23 - The auditorium at the WeWork facility at 21 Collyer Quay opening in 2022.

Copyright: WeWork
Source:WeWork
Conditions: For SPH Editorial Use, must credit WeWork
KPMG relocating to Asia Square, ByteDance in talks at Capital Tower
CBD offices coming back to life

site_title: US: Stocks fall again after choppy session
summary: US stocks fell again on May 19, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.8% to 31,253.13, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declining 0.6% and 0.3%, respectively. Investors remained anxious over slowing growth and concerns about inflation, despite efforts to rebound from the prior session's rout. Earnings reports from major retailers showed pressured earnings due to higher costs, with individual companies such as Cisco Systems, Harley-Davidson, and Under Armour experiencing significant losses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York City, New York, U.S., October 2, 2020. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

WALL STREET'S main indexes opened lower on Thursday (May 19) after the S&P 500's biggest rout this year in the previous session, as investors fretted over the impact of surging inflation on the economy and corporate earnings.

site_title: Investors jolted as US retailers show inflation hitting consumers
summary: US retailers reported consumers cutting back on buying bigger-ticket items due to inflation, with major retailers such as Target and Walmart experiencing significant stock price drops. Investors are concerned about the impact of inflation on consumer spending and profit margins. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell pledged to raise interest rates to combat inflation. Retailers' earnings forecasts have been downgraded, with some predicting a mild recession in 2023. Consumer discretionary spending remains weak, with the S&P 500's consumer discretionary index down 30% year-to-date.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US drop to 5.25%, first decline this month
summary: US mortgage rates have dropped to 5.25% for the first time this month, according to Freddie Mac. This decline comes as the Federal Reserve works to control inflation, which has been the hottest in over 4 decades. Despite the decrease, mortgage rates have risen rapidly from 3.11% last year. The housing market is feeling the pressure, with 61% of home offers facing bidding wars in April, down from 67% in 2021.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Residential single family homes construction by KB Home are shown under construction in the community of Valley Center, California, U.S. June 3, 2021.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Charging along Malaysia’s North-South Highway
summary: Audi's e-tron models were driven from Kuala Lumpur to Singapore, showcasing the pleasure and pain of long-distance travel in electric cars. The powerful EVs demonstrated effortless acceleration and smooth handling on the highway, but long journeys require more planning, including finding charging stations and managing battery life. The e-tron GT and RS e-tron GT excelled in high-speed travel, while the e-tron S Sportback struggled with efficiency and range. Audi emphasizes the importance of efficient EVs and disciplined driving to overcome the limitations of long-distance EV travel.

images.alt_text: The car  has a fastback silhouette and smooth front end. with only a slender opening for cooling air to slip into the engine bay.

site_title: China’s reopening should be a boon to SGD and regional currencies, say analysts
summary: China's reopening is expected to boost the Singapore dollar (SGD) and regional currencies, according to analysts. The SGD has risen 4% against the Chinese yuan (CNY) in two months, with forecasts suggesting it will continue to strengthen, albeit at a slower pace. China's strict zero-Covid policy has led to increased capital outflows, putting downward pressure on the CNY. Analysts predict the USD-CNY will continue to rise, leading to a stronger SGD against the CNY, with forecasts of a 4.88 yuan to 1 SGD exchange rate by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

FILE PHOTO: A woman wearing a mask walks past the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, in Beijing, China, as the country is hit by an outbreak of the new coronavirus, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
Chinese banks may cut their benchmark lending rates for a second time this year, giving consumers and businesses some relief as Covid lockdowns and outbreaks wreak havoc on the economy.

site_title: Jobless claims in US climb to highest level since January
summary: US jobless claims rose to 218,000 in the week ended May 14, the highest level since January, according to Labor Department data. This increase was driven by higher filings in Kentucky and California. Meanwhile, continuing claims for state benefits dropped to 1.32 million, the lowest level since 1969. The unexpected rise in initial claims contradicts economists' median estimate of 200,000.

site_title: Sterling at 2-week high, wins respite from growth fears for now
summary: The British pound reached a 2-week high against the US dollar, climbing to US$1.25130, as a weaker US dollar provided respite from concerns over soaring inflation and a murky growth outlook. Sterling bounced back from a sharp fall on Wednesday, with analysts attributing the move to the broadly-weak US dollar. The pound was last up 1.1%.

site_title: Boeing's Starliner space capsule set for launch on key test flight to orbit
summary: Boeing's CST-100 Starliner spacecraft is set to launch on a second unpiloted test flight to the International Space Station, aiming to deliver a much-needed success after over 2 years of delays and costly setbacks. The capsule, carrying a research mannequin and cargo, is scheduled to launch from Cape Canaveral, Florida, and dock with the space station in about 24 hours. A successful mission will move the Starliner closer to providing NASA with a second reliable means of ferrying astronauts to and from the ISS, and could pave the way for its first crewed mission in the fall.

images.alt_text: Boeing's biggest airline customer in China has removed more than 100 of the US manufacturer's 737 Max jets from its fleet plans, citing uncertainty over deliveries.

site_title: Sushi show at Unkai
summary: Unkai Sushi, a new eatery in Orchard Rendezvous Hotel Singapore, offers a conventional Japanese dining experience with an extensive menu but average quality and prices. The restaurant's interior features a bold, KTV-bar aesthetic, while the sushi is described as hastily arranged, with unevenly sliced fish and a lack of flavor. Cooked dishes fare slightly better, but overall, Unkai Sushi sits in uncertain territory, neither cheap enough to be forgiving nor exceptional enough to warrant a special trip. The reviewer rates it 5.5 out of 10.

images.alt_text: White Marble takes the Mediterranean route
Wakuda's stunning main dining room

site_title: All Singapore Covid-19 cases in April were of the Omicron variant
summary: Singapore reported 4,578 new COVID-19 cases on May 19, down from 6,442 the previous day. All local and imported cases were infected with the Omicron variant, with 99% being the BA.2 strain and 1% the BA.1 strain. Two imported cases were infected with the BA.4 strain, marking the first community cases confirmed to be infected with the BA.4 and BA.5 variants. The number of hospitalizations stood at 302, with 2 deaths recorded.

images.alt_text: Singapore will strive to keep its borders open and stay connected to the rest of world even if a new variant of Covid-19 emerges, Transport Minister S Iswaran said.

site_title: Audi’s e-tron S Sportback is a heavyweight contender
summary: Audi's e-tron S Sportback is a high-performance electric vehicle that combines the features of a sport utility vehicle, coupe, and high-performance car. With three electric motors, it offers exceptional handling and power, making it suitable for aggressive driving. However, its weight and size result in less-than-brutal acceleration and a bumpy ride at high speeds. The car has a spacious interior, comfortable ride, and a generous cargo area. Despite its impressive features, the e-tron S Sportback comes with a hefty price tag and annual road tax of S$6,146, making it less accessible to some drivers.

images.alt_text: A car on the Jagged edge

site_title: McDonald's to sell Russia restaurants to local operator
summary: McDonald's is selling its Russia business to local operator Alexander Govor, ending its nearly 3-decade presence in the country. Govor's firm GiD will operate under a new brand, retaining employees for at least 2 years on equivalent terms. The deal, valued at up to $1.4 billion, comes after McDonald's closed its restaurants in Russia, including a Moscow location, amid the country's invasion of Ukraine. The sale provides Govor with assistance to set up operations, following a "long and difficult" negotiation process with the Russian government.

site_title: Biden welcomes Finland, Sweden to join Nato, as Turkey balks
summary: US President Joe Biden welcomed Sweden and Finland to join NATO, expressing strong support for their applications as "momentous" day. The move comes after Turkey expressed opposition, citing concerns over Sweden's support for Kurdish militants and Finland's arms ban. However, US officials believe Turkey's concerns can be addressed. Biden submitted paperwork to the US Congress for speedy approval once NATO approves the applications. All 30 NATO members must approve any new entrant, with Turkey's President Erdogan stating he will reject Sweden and Finland's membership.

site_title: Harley-Davidson to suspend most vehicle assembly due to parts issue
summary: Harley-Davidson has suspended vehicle assembly and shipments for 2 weeks, excluding LiveWire electric-vehicles, due to a parts issue related to a supplier. The decision was made after a regulatory compliance matter was discovered with a third-party supplier's component part. This suspension affects most vehicle production, excluding those from its electric division, and is in response to a supplier issue.

site_title: FLCT to acquire prime suburban office building in Victoria for A$60.25m
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) plans to acquire a fully-leased suburban office building in Victoria, Australia for A$60.25 million, boosting its exposure to the Australian market to 51.8% of its total portfolio value. The building, completed in 2016, has a total net lettable area of 7,297 sqm and is fully leased to nine tenants with a weighted average lease expiry of about five years. The acquisition is funded from divestment proceeds and is expected to enhance FLCT's quality tenant mix and portfolio metrics.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
FRASERS Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT)’s distribution per unit (DPU) rose by 1.3 per cent to S$0.0385 for its first half ended March 31, 2022, from S$0.038 a year ago.
Covid-19 had 'no material impact' on FLCT's portfolio despite challenges to retail segment

site_title: Qatar World Cup to feature female referees in first for tournament
summary: FIFA has announced that female referees will officiate matches at the 2022 Qatar World Cup, marking the first time women will be involved in the men's tournament. Three female referees and three assistant referees from various countries have been selected, including Stephanie Frappart from France, Salima Mukansanga from Rwanda, and Yoshimi Yamashita from Japan. The selection process was based on "quality first," with the chosen officials representing the highest level of refereeing worldwide, according to FIFA Referees Committee chairman Pierluigi Collina.

site_title: Major Credit Suisse shareholder calls for new CEO
summary: Artisan Partners, a top-10 shareholder of Credit Suisse, has called for a new CEO to replace Thomas Gottstein, citing his leadership's failure to turn around the bank after a series of scandals and losses. The bank's chairman, Axel Lehmann, has supported Gottstein, but Artisan Managing Director David Samra believes it's time to find a top-notch successor to execute the bank's strategy. Other major shareholders and investor advisers are also unhappy with Gottstein's tenure, but some, like Harris Associates, say the board should decide his future.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng’s CFO, Malaysia CEO resign
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a beverage manufacturer, announced the resignations of its CFO Chan Ying Jian and Malaysia, Indonesia, and Brunei CEO Jerson Go Uy. Chan will leave on August 10, while Go Uy will resign on July 31 to pursue other opportunities. Chan previously worked at BreadTalk and The Learning Lab, while Go Uy joined Yeo's two years ago. The company will provide more details on their replacements soon.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Indonesia to lift palm oil export ban from Monday, president says
summary: Indonesia will lift its palm oil export ban starting Monday, May 23, following improvements in the domestic cooking oil supply situation, according to President Joko Widodo. The ban, implemented on April 28, aimed to control domestic prices but has been eased as farmers protested the lack of demand for their palm fruits. The average price of bulk cooking oil has dropped to around 17,200-17,600 rupiah per liter, exceeding the domestic market's needs. The decision aims to support the welfare of 17 million palm oil industry workers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.50 points lower at 1,549.41 on Thursday, with 692 losers outnumbering 272 gainers. The index saw a volume of 2.690 billion lots worth RM2.231 billion.

images.alt_text: The Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur taken on 8 May 2018.

site_title: ECB to force UK-based investment banks to relocate staff, trading
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) plans to force UK-based investment banks to relocate senior staff and trading activity to the eurozone, citing concerns over risk management and governance. ECB supervisory chief Andrea Enria announced that the ECB will issue "binding decisions" to key investment firms, requiring them to appoint a head of trading desk within the euro area, establish a solid governance framework, and limit reliance on intragroup hedging. The move aims to protect depositors and prevent disruption to banking services, and is seen as a response to the industry's reluctance to relocate activities after Brexit.

images.alt_text: Is the ECB serving objectives other than those defined in its mandate?

site_title: Japan plans to issue 20t yen in ‘green transition’ bonds
summary: Japan plans to issue 20 trillion yen worth of "green transition" bonds to finance investment in achieving a carbon-neutral society by 2030. The move aims to reduce the country's reliance on fossil fuels, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The government will create a 10-year roadmap to promote green investment, including financial aid and infrastructure building. The bonds will help raise an estimated 20 trillion yen needed to achieve the goal, with the remaining amount coming from private investment.

images.alt_text: Japanese automakers Toyota Motor, Nissan Motor and Honda Motor are the least prepared for a zero-emissions vehicle transition compared with their global competitors, according to research released Wednesday from climate think tank InfluenceMap.

site_title: The boxy baby BMW is back
summary: BMW's new 218i Active Tourer, a boxy baby BMW, has returned with many of its predecessor's virtues, including an airy cabin and versatile boot space. However, its pricing has been pushed into adult territory due to a higher Category B certificate of entitlement (COE) cost of S$95,889. The Luxury edition starts at S$220,888, while the M Sport version retails for S$223,888. The car's handling isn't sharp, and its acceleration is only "eager," but it's a frugal option with a lower COE cost for a future 216i version, which may be a more appealing option for buyers.

images.alt_text: The Skoda Octavia RS is a thing worthy of admiration, offering just about everything a man could want in a modern petrol car.

site_title: India’s Go First plans IPO in July as air travel rebounds
summary: India's Go First, the country's No 2 airline, plans to raise 36 billion rupees (S$641.3 million) through an initial public offering in July as air travel rebounds from the pandemic. The airline aims to repay debt and dues to creditors using the IPO proceeds, which will be crucial for its financial stability. With air travel expected to exceed pre-pandemic levels of 415,000 daily fliers within a year, Go First's IPO is seen as a positive sign for the Indian aviation market. The airline's share sale comes as international flights resume and demand for air travel recovers.

images.alt_text: The logo of GoAir airline is pictured on an A320neo aircraft at the builder's headquarters of Airbus in Colomiers near Toulouse, France, November 15, 2019. REUTERS/Regis Duvignau

site_title: WHO authorises China's CanSinoBIO Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) authorized the use of China's CanSinoBIO Covid-19 vaccine, known as Convidecia, on May 19, 2022, making it the ninth jab to receive WHO green light. The vaccine has 64% efficacy against symptomatic disease and 92% efficacy against severe Covid-19. The WHO granted emergency use listing (EUL) to the vaccine, which has been rolled out in several countries, including China, Argentina, and Pakistan. This approval gives countries assurance that the vaccine has met international standards, paving the way for rapid distribution and equitable access to doses worldwide.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as growth fears mount
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 19, 2022, as investors fretted over the impact of surging inflation on the economy and corporate earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 227.45 points, or 0.72%, to 31,262.62, while the S&P 500 dropped 24.68 points, or 0.63%, to 3,899.00, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 53.75 points, or 0.47%, to 11,364.40. This marked the S&P 500's biggest rout this year.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz aims for more luxury in model line-up
summary: Mercedes-Benz aims to reposition itself as a luxury brand by cutting entry-level models and focusing on high-end vehicles. The company plans to reduce its entry-level segment to 4 models from 7 and simplify production processes. It will also invest 75% of its resources in top-end vehicles, such as C-Class and E-Class models, expecting a 60% rise in sales share to 17-18% by 2026. The company aims to reduce battery size and weight, and is exploring cobalt-free technologies to lower costs.

images.alt_text: The logo of German car manufacturer BMW is seen on the bonnet of a vehicle covered with water drops in Kiev March 27, 2012.   REUTERS/Str (UKRAINE  - Tags: TRANSPORT BUSINESS LOGO)

site_title: Malaysia exploring ‘new ideas’ for terminated high-speed rail project with Singapore: Vivian
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan announced that Malaysia is exploring "new ideas" for a potential high-speed rail project to link Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, following the project's termination in 2021. The two countries are waiting to receive proposals, with Balakrishnan expressing optimism about connectivity and collaboration opportunities. Meanwhile, air travel between Singapore and Malaysia has seen a 40% increase, and land border traffic is expected to rise, with plans for a ferry service and the Johor-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) making progress.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Singapore, Malaysia to work towards full resumption of air, land travel

Travelers with their baggage at Kuala Lumpur International Airport 2 (KLIA 2) in Sepang, Selangor, Malaysia, on Friday, April 1, 2022. Malaysia allows quarantine-free entry for fully vaccinated travelers from April 1, ending almost two years of stringent border controls introduced to contain the Covid-19 outbreak. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg##########malaysia##########

site_title: Grab narrows losses for Q1 FY2022, driven by mobility, food and grocery verticals
summary: Grab, a New York-listed company, narrowed its losses for the first quarter ended March 31, reporting a loss of $435 million from $666 million a year prior. Revenue grew 6% to $228 million, driven by growth in its food and grocery business segment and a rebound in the mobility segment. Despite a 22% drop in mobility segment revenue, losses narrowed to $82 million from $115 million the year before. Grab is optimistic about the economy's recovery and plans to expand into under-penetrated areas, with a focus on sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Grab and Sea winning the Malaysia digital bank licence raises questions if attentions will be turned away from Singapore
GRAB likely has an advantage over its other digital bank competitors in Malaysia given its e-wallet share in the country, Maybank said on Sunday (May 1).
Grab-Singtel is among 5 winners of Malaysia's digital bank licences.

site_title: PEC lands new contracts worth S$80m
summary: PEC Ltd has secured new contracts worth S$80 million for engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) and mechanical works across various projects in the energy and chemicals sectors. The contracts include S$50 million for EPC and commissioning services. CEO Robert Dompeling expressed cautious optimism about project works and maintenance prospects in the medium term, driven by the ongoing tightness in global energy supply. The contracts are not expected to significantly impact the group's earnings.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
KEPPEL Offshore & Marine (O&M), through its wholly-owned subsidiary Keppel Shipyard, has been awarded contracts from repeat customers worth around S$250 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks tumble, tracking US market sell-off; STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% to 3,190.71 on May 19, tracking a US market sell-off. The decline was attributed to a global risk-off mood and increased Covid-19 cases in China, dampening hopes for a quick easing of virus restrictions. The move follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors weighing the impact of trade activities in the region.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Sentiment should remain tentative over the next few weeks, analysts say.

site_title: EasyJet says bookings strong as it posts £545m first half loss
summary: EasyJet reported a first-half loss of £545m, in line with guidance, as demand remained strong with bookings consistently above pre-pandemic levels. The airline plans to fly 90% of its 2019 capacity in the third quarter and has sold ticket yields 15% above 2019. EasyJet has taken measures to strengthen operational resilience, including moving 1.5 million seats to best-performing markets. The carrier will not provide further financial guidance for the second half due to higher fuel costs and exchange rates.

site_title: A fiery  taste of Patagonian cooking
summary: Argentinian celebrity chef Francis Mallmann is bringing his famous open-fire cooking to The Fullerton Bay Hotel in Singapore for a 7-day pop-up. Mallmann, known for his appearance on Netflix's Chef's Table series, will cook over a massive open fire grill using techniques that date back 11,000 years to Patagonia. A dome will be built at the hotel's outdoor terrace to replicate the Patagonian cooking style, and the menu will feature dishes such as Andean potatoes and open-fire roasted premium aged beef. The 6-course dinner menu is priced at S$628 per person, with wine pairing options available.

images.alt_text: Interior of Restaurant Poise

site_title: Parkway Shenton partners Neurowyzr for digital brain health screening
summary: Neurowyzr, a healthtech startup, has partnered with Parkway Shenton, a medical group, to launch a digital brain health screening for patients. The Digital Brain Function Scan is a browser-based assessment that can be completed on any digital device, providing an accurate diagnosis (91-93% accuracy) and early detection of brain health problems. This partnership aims to promote brain health and prevent problems associated with cognitive decline, stroke, and dementia, with the potential to save time and costs compared to traditional cognitive tests.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Shaping the future of healthcare with digitalisation and innovation

site_title: Malaysia's biggest telcos seek majority stake in 5G agency: document
summary: Malaysia's four largest telecommunications firms - Celcom Axiata, DiGi Telecommunications, Maxis, and U Mobile - have expressed opposition to the government's plan to offer them minority stakes in the state 5G agency Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB). The firms want a majority stake and a review of the pricing model and network access plan, citing concerns over undermining competition and creating a nationalized monopoly. The government aims to finalize stake sales by end-June, but the dispute may lead to delays.

site_title: Credit ratings clients of Moody’s, S&P received better ESG scores, SMU study finds
summary: Researchers from the Singapore Management University found a positive correlation between environmental, social, and governance (ESG) scores given to companies by Moody's and S&P, and their status as paying clients of the ratings agencies. Companies with existing credit rating dealings with Moody's experienced a 1.287-point increase in ESG ratings, while those with existing credit rating dealings with S&P experienced a 1.997-point increase. The findings suggest score inflation and a need to manage conflicts of interest, with regulators and financial services companies advised to be aware of potential biases in ESG ratings.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Beyond Singapore, global organisations are also asking financial accounting standards boards to provide rules on topics like accounting for renewable-energy certificates and carbon-offset credits.
Most regions saw a slump in sustainable fund inflows in Q1, except for Canada and Asia ex-Japan.
Rain clouds over condominiums, commercial buildings, and hotels as viewed from the Sky Garden of CapitaSpring on Mar 2, 2022.
The value of ETFs traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in April fell to S$454 million, from S$663 million in March.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 2.54% on May 19, 2022, following major losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng index fell to 20,120.60, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.36%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 0.58%.

site_title: Xiaomi’s Q1 revenue falls 4.6% due to Covid, supply chain disruptions
summary: Xiaomi reported a 4.6% decline in Q1 revenue to 73.35 billion yuan, largely due to Covid-19 controls and lockdowns in China and economic headwinds abroad. This fell short of analysts' expectations of 74.3 billion yuan.

site_title: Germany's 10-year yield drops below 1% as growth fears in focus
summary: Germany's 10-year bond yield fell below 1% on May 19, as growth fears took center stage following a slump in US stocks. European shares declined, and the 2-year yield dropped 1 basis point to 0.36%, while the 2-year/10-year segment flattened another 5 basis points. Investors scaled back rate hike expectations from the European Central Bank, now anticipating around 107 basis points by year-end. Growth concerns also impacted corporate bonds, sending the Markit iTraxx Europe crossover index to its highest level since May 2020.

images.alt_text: The ECB plans to force global investment banks to relocate senior staff and trading activity to the eurozone.

site_title: Impact investing is not the same as ESG: KKR
summary: KKR's global impact fund, launched in 2018, invests in small-cap businesses with commercially successful, impact-driven solutions to global challenges. While the fund assesses environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, it is distinct from ESG investing, focusing on scaling solutions to major global issues. The fund has made 15 investments totaling over $1 billion in capital, with a focus on Asia-Pacific markets, particularly in Australia, India, and Singapore. KKR aims to achieve financial returns while meeting its impact objectives, without making trade-offs between the two.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
money, coin, investment
KKR & Co expects that borrowers paying attention to environmental and social concerns will outperform in the US corporate high-yield and leveraged loan markets.
Buying shares of ExxonMobil in the secondary market does not benefit Exxon in any way. Subscribing to a new bond or a new share issuance, however, does benefit Exxon.

A major investor-led initiative to get companies to take action over climate change has achieved little so far and must be clearer about how investors will pressure laggards, a report by NGO ShareAction said.

site_title: COE premiums for larger cars up in latest tender exercise
summary: COE premiums ended mixed at the latest tender exercise, with larger cars and motorcycles seeing a rise and smaller cars and commercial vehicles experiencing a fall. The COE premium for smaller cars with engines up to 1,600 cc decreased by 4.1% to S$68,001, while larger cars above 1,600 cc increased by 4.1% to S$95,889. Motorcycle COE premiums rose by a single dollar to S$9,490, and commercial vehicle COEs increased by 1.2% to S$51,501.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Asian markets plummeted on May 19, following a sharp decline on Wall Street, amid concerns over the US economy. Retailer Target Corp's earnings miss sparked worries, and analysts expect market sentiment to remain uncertain for the next few weeks, potentially extending into Q3.

images.alt_text: STMicroelectronics has set a global target to attain carbon neutrality by 2027.

site_title: Temasek’s Azalea launches Astrea 7 PE bonds with fixed coupon of 4.125% and 6%
summary: Temasek's Azalea has launched Astrea 7 private equity bonds with two fixed coupon rates: 4.125% for Class A-1 bonds denominated in Singapore dollars and 6% for Class B bonds denominated in US dollars. The public offer allows retail investors to apply for the Class B bonds, which come with a higher credit risk profile but also offer a higher interest rate. The bonds are backed by cashflows from a $1.9 billion portfolio of investments and have a maturity date of 10 years.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

The Astrea 7 bonds will be backed by cash flows
from a US$1.9 billion portfolio of investments in 38 private equity funds
Azalea launches its first sustainability fund, co-seeded with Singlife with Aviva
Outside equities: bonds and how to get exposure

site_title: Hong Kong's jobless rate surged to 5.4% during Covid wave
summary: Hong Kong's jobless rate surged to 5.4% for the 3 months ended April, the highest since June 2021, due to ongoing Covid restrictions weighing on businesses and keeping people at home. The underemployment rate rose to 3.8% from 3.1%. The elevated unemployment rate is one of several challenges for Hong Kong's economy, which is also facing rising interest rates and struggling exports.

site_title: Show and Shop
summary: Retailers in Singapore are shifting away from conventional supermarket layouts to create immersive shopping experiences. The Decorum Singapore, set to open, will feature a "farmers' market" atmosphere with on-site bakeries, cheese displays, and staff interactions. This approach aims to recreate the social and interactive experience found in European and Australian markets. The goal is to engage customers and create a memorable shopping experience, much like in traditional farmers' markets.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

scfeature19 - The Decorum Singapore

credit: The Decorum Singapore
float: EL
Raising the flag for Singapore brands

site_title: Indonesia MPs seek palm oil export ban review as industry warns on storage
summary: Indonesian lawmakers have requested a review of the export ban on palm oil, citing concerns that storage nears full capacity and the industry risks grinding to a halt. The ban, implemented in April, aims to control domestic cooking oil prices, but has led to a shortage of storage space and a halt in operations if not lifted by the end of the month. Industry groups warn that the ban could reduce government revenue by 6 trillion rupiah per month.

site_title: Singapore Airlines expected to be profitable in FY2023, analyst consensus shows
summary: Singapore Airlines is expected to return to profitability in FY2023, with analysts forecasting a net profit of S$160 million and earnings per share of 3.7 cents on a turnover of S$13.1 billion. The carrier's chief Goh Choon Phong cited operational profitability for the second half of FY2022 and robust freight shipments as contributing factors. Analysts also noted potential challenges, including higher fuel prices and staff expenses.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Two insurance agents charged over falsifying records, providing false information to MAS
summary: Two insurance agents, Eunice Yuen and Grace Tan, from Prudential Assurance Company Singapore, have been charged for obstructing justice by falsifying records and providing false information to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Yuen faces 6 charges, including wilfully causing false entries and providing misleading information, while Tan faces 2 charges for making false entries. Both agents could face fines not exceeding S$100,000 or imprisonment for up to 2 years if convicted.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Peter Tan Shou Yi and Prudential have reached settlement and would not proceed with their appeals.

site_title: Philippines hikes rate for first time since 2018 on price risks
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 2.25% for the first time since 2018 to combat the country's second-fastest inflation of 4.9%. The move aims to slow down price pressures fueled by the war in Europe and supply disruptions. Governor Benjamin Diokno termed the increase "timely" and will help arrest second-round effects, with the peso gaining 0.3% to $52.30 following the announcement.

site_title: Sydney Biennale: A rivus runs through it
summary: The 23rd Sydney Biennale, titled "rivus" (Latin for "stream"), explores the relationship between humans and water sources, including rivers, wetlands, and ancestral landscapes. The event features various international artists, including a large bamboo installation by Cave Urban, and lists rivers around the world as "participants." The biennale's gritty and raw approach contrasts with traditional art events, focusing on earthy and organic themes.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

At the Cutaway, Australia design studio Cave Urban – comprising artists, architects and sculptors – has created a large bamboo installation that swirls and snakes across the ceiling like a winding river.
In Venice, minimalist Singapore show speaks volumes

site_title: Europe: Markets sink at open in global selloff
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened sharply lower on May 19, following heavy losses in Asia and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.8%, Frankfurt's DAX lost 1.5%, and Paris's CAC 40 shed 1.4%. Analysts attributed the decline to concerns about an economic downturn and soaring inflation, as well as downcast earnings reports from retailers.

site_title: Food Services Industry Transformation Map launched at Restaurant Asia 2022
summary: Singapore launches the refreshed Food Services Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025, aiming to catalyze innovation and create new revenue streams for the industry. The ITM has four key thrusts: driving innovation, growing home-grown regional brands, grooming digital champions, and stepping up job transformation. The initiative seeks to help businesses adopt solutions to future-proof operations and adopt solutions to capture new growth opportunities. The launch coincides with the Restaurant Asia 2022 event, which attracted 8,000 visitors and 180 exhibitors from 15 countries.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Refreshed maritime sector road map to grow value-add by S$2 billion by 2025

site_title: Thailand to promote medical tourism in post-Covid era, PM says
summary: Thailand aims to promote medical tourism as it rolls back pandemic-era travel curbs, expecting tourist arrivals to more than triple to about 1 million a month from October. The country has a proven track record in handling the Covid-19 outbreak, and a new virus task force will consider reopening bars and nightlife venues. With new Covid cases declining, Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha vows to relax remaining restrictions to boost business and economic activities.

images.alt_text: THAILAND'S industries sentiment index dropped to a 5-month low in April, hit by higher production costs as Russia's invasion of Ukraine pushed up the price of energy and raw materials, an industries group said on Wednesday (May 18).

site_title: Free and easy travel with no restrictions
summary: Switzerland, Australia, and possibly other destinations have relaxed COVID-19 travel requirements, allowing travellers to visit without restrictions or tests. Switzerland no longer requires pre-entry COVID-19 tests, while Australia requires proof of full vaccinations and a digital passenger declaration form. Meanwhile, Singapore requires travellers to complete an SG Arrival Card up to 72 hours before departure.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Singapore had planned for air passenger volume to recover to 50 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps 4-day rally as inflation jitters return
summary: The Nikkei stock index in Tokyo closed 1.89% lower at 26,402.84, its biggest drop since May 9, after US stocks plummeted overnight due to inflation concerns. The US stock market's decline, led by Target's earnings report, dragged down Japanese shares. Despite this, the Nikkei remains relatively stable due to the weaker yen making Japanese shares appear cheaper.

images.alt_text: Asian markets posted big early losses on Thursday.
The Hang Seng Index dipped 2.71 percent, or 559.39 points, to 20,084.89.
Australia shares fell on Thursday, dragged by technology and mining stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong new listings volume sinks to 9-year low on China slowdown
summary: Hong Kong's new listings volume plummeted 90% to a 9-year low this year due to China's economic slowdown and regulatory drive. The city's ranking in global listing league tables dropped to 10th, and only $2.1 billion was raised via IPOs and secondary listings compared to $20.7 billion last year. Investment banks and the city's status as a global financial hub face challenges, but some analysts remain optimistic about the city's long-term prospects.

site_title: Asia's 2 richest men reap windfall from surging oil, coal
summary: Indian billionaires Gautam Adani and Mukesh Ambani are profiting from a surge in global commodity prices, including coal and crude oil, due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Adani's conglomerate is expanding a controversial coal mine in Australia, while Ambani's Reliance Industries is snapping up distressed crude-oil cargoes. Despite publicly promoting green energy investments, the two tycoons are reaping benefits from fossil fuels, with their wealth increasing by $26 billion and $8 billion respectively since the war started. Global coal demand is expected to rise to a record level in 2022 and stay there through 2024.

images.alt_text: Labourers stand after unloading cement bags from a freight train in India. Holcim has been selling non-core cement businesses and buying new construction companies to benefit from rising demand for energy efficient buildings.

Billionaire Mukesh Ambani abandoned a plan to buy a teetering Indian retailer amid protracted legal challenges from Amazon.com, potentially ending one episode of the broader clash between the 2 titans to control the country's billion-people-plus market.

site_title: Will Biden lift trade tariffs on China?
summary: US President Joe Biden is reassessing his trade policies with China amid rising inflation and changing socio-political realities. Despite progressive Democrats' calls for a protectionist approach, Biden seems to be keeping in place many of his predecessor's China trade policies, including the 25% tariffs on Chinese imports. The Office of the US Trade Representative is pushing for a "worker-centred" trade policy, but Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo advocate lifting tariffs to combat inflation. The decision could have significant political implications for Biden, particularly with the midterm elections approaching.

images.alt_text: President Biden has now an opportunity to upgrade his Asia policy by taking steps to promote and liberalise trade in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 1% lower on economic slowdown worries
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1% on Thursday, tracking a decline in US markets, amid concerns over a global economic slowdown and inflationary pressures. The benchmark Kospi closed 33.64 points lower at 2,592.34. Foreign investors sold 96.9 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won weakened and bond yields fell. The decline was partly attributed to weaker US retail earnings results and concerns over corporate earnings and recession due to inflation shocks.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 5.54 points, or 0.21 per cent, at 2,625.98, marking the highest close since May 6.

site_title: Tiger Brokers Singapore caps settlement fee of US stocks and ETF trades
summary: Tiger Brokers Singapore has capped the settlement fee for US stocks and ETF trades at 7% of the trade value, effective May 19. The move follows a report of a customer being charged $16,000 in fees after selling $5,000 worth of US-listed shares. The brokerage will contact affected clients to arrange for refunds. This change contrasts with rival brokerages like Syfe and TD Ameritrade Singapore, which do not charge settlement fees.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign is pictured outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York, October 28, 2013. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Marriott to double hotels in Latin America
summary: Marriott plans to double its hotels in Latin America within 3-4 years, following the region's recovery from the pandemic. Soaring commodity prices and multinational companies' push to shorten supply chains are driving growth. Despite risks such as high unemployment and poverty, Latin America is expected to experience post-pandemic growth, with the region's economy and infrastructure being discussed at the New Economy Gateway Latin America event in Panama City.

images.alt_text: Marriott wary of Delta impact after hit to Asia-Pac recovery

site_title: KPMG commits S$25m to pay raises, S$30m to lifelong learning programme
summary: KPMG in Singapore is investing S$25 million this financial year in pay adjustments and bonuses, including a 20% increase in starting pay for eligible entry-level professionals. The firm also plans to spend S$30 million over the next 5 years on a lifelong learning program to improve data and digital literacy, and to provide S$21,000 in tuition fees for each employee to pursue professional accreditations. The move aims to enhance employee skills and knowledge to tackle emerging challenges in ESG and digital transformation.

images.alt_text: If you work for a listco your family controls, does pay incentivise you the way it would for an outsider?

Businesses face big challenges right now, but giving customers less for their money is the opposite of customer love. Leaders can make the best of a tough situation by doubling down on innovation and transparency.
(FILES) In this

site_title: Saint Pierre ex-head chef poised to go solo
summary: Chef Steve Lancaster, formerly the head chef of 2-Michelin-starred Saint Pierre, has opened his own restaurant, Poise, in Singapore's CBD. Lancaster spent 3 years working under Emmanuel Stroobant before striking out on his own, drawing inspiration from European haute cuisine and Nordic culinary expression. Poise's menu features dishes such as lacto-fermented asparagus and live Australian marron, with prices starting from S$118++ for a 4-course lunch. Lancaster aims to deliver high standards of quality and consistency, with a focus on lean operations and minimizing waste.

images.alt_text: California Republic's interiors

site_title: Sri Lanka enters default, warns inflation may surge to 40%
summary: Sri Lanka has entered its first-ever default, as the government struggles to halt an economic meltdown prompting mass protests and a political crisis. The country failed to make coupon payments worth $78 million due on April 18, citing a need to restructure debt. Central bank governor Nandalal Weerasinghe warned that the nation is in pre-emptive default, with inflation potentially surging to 40%. The economic crisis has sparked widespread protests and a political crisis, as policymakers attempt to address the country's deepening economic woes.

site_title: Japan’s March core machinery orders rise 7.1% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 7.1% in March from the previous month, exceeding economists' expectations of a 3.7% increase. This represents a 7.6% year-over-year growth, indicating a strong lead in capital spending for the next six to nine months.

site_title: China's Premier Li urges 'decisive' action on growth policies
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged local governments to take decisive action to support growth in the coming weeks, citing "further intensified new downward pressure" on the economy. He emphasized the need for policies outlined in the government work report to be enacted by the end of June, and hinted at potential additional fiscal policy support in the second half of the year. This comes as China's economy faces challenges, including a 6.1% jobless rate and a 5.5% annual growth target, which may seem further out of reach due to the ongoing COVID-19 lockdowns and zero-tolerance policy.

images.alt_text: The Chinese Premier called for greater “urgency” in rolling out measures to support the country’s virus-battered economy, state media reported on Wednesday, days after data highlighted the stark impact of Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: EMA to seek more term LNG importers for Singapore
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore plans to appoint up to 2 additional liquefied natural gas (LNG) term importers to enhance competition and provide more options for gas buyers. This move will complement the current 4 term LNG importers, ensuring a reliable, secure, and competitive supply of LNG to Singapore. The EMA issued a Request for Proposal (RFP) to interested parties, which will be evaluated based on their ability to meet the required standards.

site_title: MAS estimates 9,400 new permanent roles for financial sector in 2022
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) estimates that over 9,400 permanent roles will be created in the financial sector in 2022, with the highest demand for software developers and engineers. New jobs in sustainable finance, including ESG transactions and advisory services, will also be available. This growth is part of a broader 7.2% annual growth in the financial sector, outpacing the overall economy. MAS is stepping up efforts to support local talent, particularly polytechnic graduates and mid-career professionals, with initiatives such as a new wealth management accelerator program.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
MAS should publish outcome of every investigation and enforcement action related to the listed-companies space

site_title: Reinventing corporate real estate by looking beyond office walls
summary: The corporate office sector is shifting towards innovative, sustainable designs that harmonize with the physical surroundings and community. As Singapore's Covid-19 situation stabilizes, demand for physical office spaces is expected to rise with employees returning to the office. Under-utilized office buildings can be converted into creative, cultural spaces, offering a fresh approach to corporate real estate. This trend is driven by the need for companies to re-evaluate their workspace and create a more positive, engaging environment for employees.

images.alt_text: architecture, buildings, city

site_title: Woodside shareholders approve BHP petroleum merger
summary: Woodside shareholders approved a merger with BHP's petroleum arm, creating a top 10 global independent oil and gas producer worth $40 billion. The deal, agreed last August, doubles Woodside's oil and gas production and gives BHP investors a 48% stake in the merged group. The merger advances BHP's decarbonization efforts, while Woodside's climate plan, which doesn't set targets for reducing customers' emissions, received 45% opposition from shareholders. The merged group will have assets in Australia, the US, Mexico, Senegal, and Trinidad.
