images.alt_text: BHP to exit fossil fuel business in sweeping overhaul

site_title: Canada's Brookfield buys Britain's HomeServe for £4.1b
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has agreed to buy British home repair services firm HomeServe for £4.1 billion (S$7 billion), expanding its exposure to UK residential infrastructure investments. The recommended cash deal, which adds to Brookfield's US$725 billion portfolio, sent HomeServe's shares more than 10% higher. HomeServe shareholders will receive 1,200 pence in cash for each share, representing a 71% premium to the stock price prior to disclosure of takeover talks.

site_title: Asia markets suffer sell-off as Wall Street wobbles; uncertainty could extend into Q3
summary: Asian markets declined on May 19, following a sharp drop on Wall Street due to concerns over the US economy. Retailer Target Corp missed earnings estimates, while rival Walmart cut its annual profit forecast. This led to the worst 1-day loss for the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average since June 2020. Market sentiment is expected to remain tentative over the next few weeks.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Singapore's STI headed down 1.4 per cent or 46.03 points to 3,179.32.
Australia shares fell on Thursday, dragged by technology and mining stocks.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB cuts CSE Global target price to S$0.54 on lower margins
summary: CGS-CIMB lowered its target price on CSE Global to S$0.54, citing lower margins due to supply chain disruptions and inflation in 2022. The research team cut earnings-per-share estimates by 10.9% in FY2022, 5.3% in FY2023, and 2.7% in FY2024, but maintained a "add" call on the counter due to strong order book visibility. CSE Global's Q1 revenue rose 5.8% to S$117.6 million, driven by infrastructure segment growth.

Lim Boon Kheng, CEO, CSE Global

site_title: Global bonds switch to rally mode as recession fears intensify
summary: Global bonds experienced a rally on May 19 as investors sought safe havens amid recession fears and a risk-asset rout. The 10-year Treasury yield fell 10 basis points to 2.88%, while Australian yields dropped 13 basis points to 3.33%. The S&P 500 slumped 4%, its worst day since June 2020. Investors added long-dated Treasuries to their portfolios as a hedge against economic slowdown, driven by the Federal Reserve's focus on taming inflation via rate hikes.

images.alt_text: HDB issued its inaugural green bond in March at 1.845 per cent. Earlier this year, Finance Minister Lawrence Wong also announced in his Budget 2022 speech that Singapore aims to issue up to S$35 billion of green bonds by 2030 to fund public sector green projects.
Chinese Premier Li Keqiang told local governments to "act decisively" on measures to support growth in the coming weeks in an effort to bring the economy back on track as soon as possible.

Gold prices were flat on Thursday, as an elevated dollar weighed on greenback-priced bullion and countered support from lower Treasury yields, with the metal's outlook already dulled by an aggressive Federal Reserve stance on inflation.

All in all, 64 per cent of Japanese companies want large-scale stimulus gone by March when the fiscal year ends and that number jumps to 84 per cent for April when BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda serves out his term.

site_title: China, US lead rise in global debt to record high US$305t: IIF
summary: Global debt reached a record high of $305 trillion in the first quarter, with China and the US leading the increase. China's debt rose $2.5 trillion and the US added $1.5 trillion, while the eurozone saw a decline for the third consecutive quarter. As central banks tighten monetary policy to curb inflation, debt vulnerabilities are expected to worsen, particularly for emerging market borrowers with limited investor diversification. The global debt-to-GDP ratio fell to 348%, but growth is expected to slow significantly this year, potentially reversing the downward trend in debt ratios.

images.alt_text: Willie Walsh, director general of the International Air Transport Association, argued that high inflation could be a help to the aviation industry which has taken on a lot of debts to stay afloat during the pandemic.

site_title: Carousell, L Catterton SPAC merger talks end amid rout: sources
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based online classifieds marketplace operator, has ended talks to go public through a merger with L Catterton Asia Acquisition Corp amid market volatility. The deal, which could have valued the combined entity at up to $1.5 billion, was stalled due to macroeconomic uncertainty and valuation concerns. Other investors, such as private investment in public equity (PIPE), were also deterred by the market rout. The decision marks the latest in a string of failed SPAC deals amid heightened market volatility and changing regulations.

images.alt_text: Quek Siu Rui, CEO and co-founder of Carousell (left) with Refash founder Aloysious Sng

site_title: Asia: Markets plunge after Wall Street battering
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday, following a Wall Street battering, with Hong Kong down 3% and Tokyo 2.5%. Retailers' earnings reports sparked concerns about consumer resilience and corporate profitability. Chinese tech giant Tencent fell 8% on weak first-quarter results. Despite Australia's lowest jobless rate in 48 years, other regional markets declined, with stocks in Sydney, Singapore, and Seoul down. The Dow and Nasdaq in the US also dove, with the Federal Reserve hinting at interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: BOE gold trades at rare discount in sign of central bank selling
summary: The Bank of England's gold reserves have been trading at a rare discount, indicating central banks may be selling some of their holdings. The BOE's vaults hold 5,676 tons of gold, and recent trades have seen the metal trading up to a dollar an ounce beneath benchmark London prices. This suggests central banks are shedding reserves to raise US dollars, which could slow gold buying in 2022 as financial institutions prioritize interest-bearing dollars ahead of monetary tightening.

images.alt_text: Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
Jon Cunliffe (above), deputy governor for the UK central bank, stepped up his call for authorities to regulate cryptoassets to ensure the market is stable and transparent.

site_title: Chinese banks may lower lending rates, giving relief to economy
summary: Chinese banks are expected to lower their benchmark lending rates for a second time this year, providing relief to the economy amid the ongoing Covid lockdowns and property market slump. The 1-year loan prime rate is likely to be reduced by 5-10 basis points from 3.7% on Friday, according to 11 economists surveyed by Bloomberg. A cut in loan rates would help reduce business costs and give consumers much-needed relief, with the sector struggling since last year due to severe strain on the property market.

images.alt_text: Chinese brokers including Citic Securities and CSC Financial last year made broad cuts to travel budgets for junior bankers and senior directors.

site_title: Tencent dives after warning tech crackdown won’t end quickly
summary: Tencent's stock slid 8.4% after executives warned that a Chinese tech crackdown won't end quickly, despite promises from Beijing to support the industry. The company reported its slowest revenue gain since 2004, with sales rising only 0.1% and net income sliding 51%. Tencent's gaming division barely expanded revenue, and online advertising sales plummeted 18% due to the pandemic and competition from ByteDance. Executives said it will take time for regulators to translate their support into real action, and the company may struggle to grow in the short term.

images.alt_text: The headquarters of Chinese internet giant Tencent in Shenzhen, China, taken on Sept 27, 2020.##########pic##########Elizabeth Law

site_title: Singapore wants to keep borders open even if Covid variant emerges
summary: Singapore aims to maintain open borders despite a potential emergence of a new Covid-19 variant, according to Transport Minister S Iswaran. The island city has learned from past experiences, adapting its response to Omicron and the delta outbreak. Iswaran emphasized the importance of assessing the situation and taking a calibrated response, citing the availability of various tools to manage the risk. This stance reflects Singapore's commitment to staying connected to the global community.

images.alt_text: Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.

People waiting in the observation zone at a vaccination centre in November 2021. The Ministry of Health surged vulnerable people to get boosters and be cautious in “settings with many potential contacts”.

Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in April eased for the fifth straight month to 6.4 per cent year on year, from 7.7 per cent the previous month according to data from Enterprise Singapore on Tuesday (May 17)
Singapore had planned for air passenger volume to recover to 50 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by this year.
Changi Airport Group (CAG) is looking to hire more than 6,600 workers, as it embarks on one of its biggest recruitment drives to take full advantage of a fierce rebound in air travel.

site_title: Major wine exhibition Vinexpo Asia to move to Singapore from Hong Kong in 2023
summary: The Vinexpo Asia wine exhibition will move from Hong Kong to Singapore in 2023, with its first event scheduled for May 23-25, 2023, at Marina Bay Sands. The decision to relocate was made due to the complexity of entering Hong Kong and the growth of the wine trade in Singapore. The event will be rebranded as Vinexpo Asia to serve the Asia-Pacific region, including Australia and China. The organizer expects around 7,000 visitors for the inaugural Singapore event, down from the average 15,000 attendees at previous Vinexpo shows in the region.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.
Marina Bay Sands' nightly light and water show Spectra

site_title: China’s zero-Covid policy dashes global hopes for quick economic return to normal
summary: China's strict zero-Covid policies have led to a sharp slowdown in its economy, casting doubt on its future global trade and investment contribution. Analysts expect the downturn to be harder to shake off than the 2020 slowdown, with China's average annual contribution to global growth projected at around 29% through 2027. China's economic policies have shifted towards home-grown solutions, rather than resuming its past model of greater engagement with the world, raising concerns about the country's long-term growth prospects.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sharply down at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.71% on May 19, 2022, following a Wall Street downturn the previous day. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 20,084.89, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.96% and the Shenzhen Composite Index decreased 0.91%. The decline was attributed to the global market's reaction to the previous day's trading.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower tracking US losses
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on May 19, 2022, following US losses, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropping 1.78% and the Topix index losing 1.79%. The decline was attributed to concerns over inflation and corporate profitability.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades Sarine Tech to ‘hold’, expects growing trade revenues to lift margins
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Sarine Technologies to "hold" from "fully valued" and raised its target price to S$0.50 from S$0.45, citing the company's normalized top and bottom lines. The share price corrected to near its previous target price after the normalization. This move comes as the research team expects growing trade revenues to lift margins.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sarine Technologies is looking towards e-Grading, which uses artificial intelligence to grade diamonds, as one of its growth drivers.
Israeli-based Sarine Tech reported revenue of US$15.6 million in the 3 months to Mar 31, 2022, down 9.9 per cent year on year.

site_title: Singapore shares tumble at Thursday’s open; STI down 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.4% to 3,179.32, with 157 losers outweighing 22 gainers. Banking stocks led the decline, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 1.7%, 1.8%, and 1.3%, respectively. The drop follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 3.6% and the S&P 500 dropped 4%. European stocks also slipped, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index falling 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines on Wednesday posted a deficit of S$962 million for the financial year ending Mar 31, 2022.

site_title: Australia: Shares track global equities lower; tech stocks slide
summary: Australia's shares fell 1.95% on Thursday, snapping a four-day winning streak, as technology and mining stocks declined. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped to 7,042.9, amid global concerns over inflation and its impact on corporate earnings. Key drops included technology stocks (3%), mining stocks (2%), and financials (1.9%). Gold stocks bucked the trend, rising 0.5% on firmer bullion prices. Global equities also fell, with Japan's Nikkei and US S&P 500 E-minis futures down 2.3% and 0.5%, respectively.

site_title: Highly leveraged homeowners may face double whammy from inflation, housing supply: IREUS
summary: Highly leveraged homeowners in Singapore may face a double whammy from inflation and housing supply, according to the Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (IREUS). Rising interest rates and mortgage rates, driven by global inflationary pressures, will put pressure on financially constrained homeowners. Meanwhile, the robust private residential rental market may soon be tested as more units are slated for completion, potentially leading to declining rents and a precarious position for homeowners reliant on rental income.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Private and HDB housing in the eastern part of Singapore on 5 May 2020.##########condos##########Kua Chee Siong

site_title: US to fly in baby formula on military contracted planes
summary: The US government will transport baby formula on commercial planes contracted by the military to ease the nationwide shortage, which was caused by a perfect storm of supply chain issues and a massive recall. The White House said the operation, dubbed "Operation Fly Formula," will speed up the importation and distribution of formula from manufacturing facilities abroad that meet FDA safety standards. President Joe Biden has also invoked the Defense Production Act to prioritize formula production and allocation. The airlift aims to bridge the gap until domestic production increases, with the shortage leaving many parents frantic and fearful for their infants' nutrition.

site_title: Russia to legalise cryptocurrency as means of payment 'sooner or later': minister
summary: Russia's Industry and Trade Minister Denis Manturov stated that the country will legalize cryptocurrencies as a means of payment "sooner or later." This comes after the government and central bank have been working to settle their differences over the issue. The central bank, led by Elvira Nabiullina, has proposed banning trading and mining of cryptocurrencies due to financial stability risks. Manturov suggested that regulations would be formulated by the central bank and then by the government, indicating a potential shift towards allowing cryptocurrencies in Russia.

images.alt_text: Jon Cunliffe (above), deputy governor for the UK central bank, stepped up his call for authorities to regulate cryptoassets to ensure the market is stable and transparent.

site_title: Nomura explores the metaverse in digital push to boost profit
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, is building a team to help firms tap into the metaverse, a digital push to boost profit. The team will utilize Nomura's investment banking knowledge to help companies raise money and navigate regulations in the virtual space. The firm may generate revenue by creating securities from digital assets, such as non-fungible tokens, and merging economic activity in the real world with metaverse creations. Details of Nomura's plans are still being worked out, but the goal is to capitalize on the metaverse's potential for growth.

images.alt_text: The trades, executed on the CME by crypto asset trading firm Cumberland DRW this week, were the Japanese investment bank’s first digital asset trades.

NOMURA Holdings posted a fourth straight quarter of profit as Japan's largest brokerage booked gains from a stake sale in one of its affiliated companies, offsetting further expenses for a legal case in the US.

site_title: SBI Holdings, NTUitive, Kyobo Life Insurance launch US$75m VC fund
summary: SBI Holdings, a Japanese financial services group, has launched a US$75 million venture capital (VC) fund with NTUitive and Kyobo Life Insurance. The fund will invest in pre-series A and Series A startups in South-east Asia and South Asia, with cheque sizes ranging from US$1 million to US$5 million. SBI Ven Capital, the venture capital arm of SBI Holdings, will manage the fund, while NTUitive and Kyobo Securities will have representatives on the investment committee, leveraging their reputation and local knowledge to create a strong ecosystem of digital companies.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The turmoil in the public markets are just a harbinger for what's to come in the private markets

site_title: Australia reports 48-year-low jobless rate before election
summary: Australia reported its lowest jobless rate in 48 years, with an unemployment rate of 3.85% in April, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The country created 92,400 full-time jobs, trimming the seasonally adjusted rate from 3.93% the previous month. However, many employers struggle to find staff, citing staff shortages. The news comes ahead of federal elections, where Prime Minister Scott Morrison faces a tight election race against the opposition Labor Party. The rising cost of living remains a priority for voters, with Labor leader Anthony Albanese advocating for a minimum wage increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 5.65 points lower, 0.36% down, at 1,549.26. Losers outnumbered gainers 467 to 59, with a total trading volume of 386.22 million lots worth RM156.19 million.

site_title: Gold flat as dollar strength counters weaker US bond yields
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,816.63 per ounce, as a stronger US dollar countered support from lower Treasury yields. The elevated dollar makes gold less attractive for foreign buyers, while US central bankers expect the Federal Reserve to slow down policy tightening after July. This dulled gold's outlook, which is sensitive to rising interest rates and bond yields. Other metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium, also fell.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged higher on Wednesday, as a weakening dollar countered pressure from stronger Treasury yields and an aggressive stance on inflation by the US Federal Reserve chief.

site_title: Hong Kong telco HKBN draws interest from KKR, PAG: sources
summary: Private equity firms KKR & CO and PAG are considering bids for Hong Kong telecommunications provider HKBN, according to sources. HKBN offers broadband services, enterprise telecom solutions, data centers, and Wifi connectivity. The company has attracted interest from Stonepeak and major shareholders TPG and MBK Partners. Deliberations are at an early stage, and there's no certainty the funds will proceed with formal bids, citing challenging financing markets and stock market volatility.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA telco Axiata Group and utilities operator YTL Power will unlikely see material contributions from the digital banking sector in the initial years, although their new digital bank licences should offer them another value creation avenue, Maybank said on Thursday (Apr 5).
NORWAY'S Telenor posted on Tuesday (May 3) weaker-than-expected first-quarter profits and said growth in earnings was expected to lag revenue development by a few quarters as costs rose.
Chua, who retired as Singtel group CEO in 2020, is currently a senior advisor at the Singapore telco.

site_title: SpaceX urged by US to ease blow to wildlife in Texas launch plan
summary: The US Fish and Wildlife Service has released a final opinion on SpaceX's planned expansion in Boca Chica, Texas, recommending mitigation measures to minimize the impact on local species. The measures include monitoring vegetation and birds, operating an employee shuttle, reducing vehicle traffic, and adjusting lights to minimize the impact on sea turtles. The recommendation comes as part of an environmental assessment by the Federal Aviation Administration, which has delayed its ruling on SpaceX's request for approval multiple times. SpaceX plans to conduct a test flight of Starship from Texas in June or July.

site_title: First Reit to divest Siloam Hospitals Surabaya for 430b rupiah
summary: First Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, will divest Siloam Hospitals Surabaya for 430 billion rupiah (S$40.9 million), marking a 143.2% premium over its original purchase price in 2006. The divestment will improve First Reit's weighted average property age to 15.7 years. An extraordinary general meeting will be convened to seek unit holder approval, with Stirling Coleman Capital Limited appointed as the independent financial adviser.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
First Reit prices S$100m of guaranteed bonds due 2027 at 3.25%

site_title: US puts full weight behind Sweden, Finland bids to join Nato
summary: The US has pledged full support for Sweden and Finland's bids to join NATO, with President Joe Biden welcoming the move and promising to work with Congress to ensure a swift process. Despite Turkey's objections, citing concerns over the two countries' ties to terrorist groups, US officials aim to address these issues to facilitate membership. Biden emphasized the US commitment to shared security and deterrence against Russian aggression, as Finland and Sweden prepare to meet with Turkish officials in Brussels to discuss their applications.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - LtoR, Finland's Ambassador to NATO Klaus Korhonen, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg and Sweden's Ambassador to NATO Axel Wernhoff pose during a ceremony to mark Sweden's and Finland's application for membership in Brussels, on May 18, 2022. - Finland and Sweden submitted their applications for NATO membership on May 18, 2022 and consultations were underway between the Allies to lift Turkey's opposition to the integration of the two Nordic countries into the Alliance. site_title: Hong Kong considers 'closed loop' for free China travel, report says
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive-elect John Lee plans to propose a "closed-loop" system for quarantine-free business travel between Hong Kong and mainland China, according to a report. The system, which has been used in mainland China to keep production running during lockdowns, would allow employees to live in hotels or dormitories, sealing them off from their families and the wider community. The proposal aims to facilitate business travel while Hong Kong continues to work towards a full re-opening with the mainland. Details on implementation and timing are not yet available.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, First Reit, Delfi, IPC Corp
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a deficit of S$962 million for the financial year ending Mar 31, 2022, despite revenue doubling. First Reit announced a property divestment, while Delfi posted Q1 earnings growth of 13.9%. IPC Corp disclosed three consecutive years of losses, potentially placing it on the watch list. Shares of SIA ended the day up 1.9%, while First Reit units rose 1.8%, and Delfi's counter increased 0.7%.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Crypto ETP-provider 21shares marks US debut with 2 launches
summary: 21Shares, a cryptocurrency exchange-traded products issuer, marks its US debut with the launch of two new index funds: the 21Shares Crypto Basket 10 Index Fund and the 21Shares Crypto Mid-Cap Index Fund. The funds track the largest and mid-cap coins, excluding Bitcoin and Ether, and will be rebalanced quarterly. CEO Hany Rashwan says the company is excited to bring its products to the US market, despite the turbulent crypto market, and plans to launch exchange-traded funds in the States in the future.

images.alt_text: The crypto world has been riveted by the rapid collapse of the TerraUSD stablecoin. But its implosion may bring about something just as noteworthy: the death of a major blockchain.

site_title: Hedge fund Melvin Capital tells investors it plans to shut down: letter
summary: Hedge fund manager Gabe Plotkin announced the shutdown of Melvin Capital, citing billions of dollars in losses. The fund had $7.8 billion in assets at the end of April, losing 23% since January. Plotkin plans to fully liquidate assets and return cash to investors, marking the end of one of Wall Street's best-performing investing records.

site_title: Tesla loses spot on S&P ESG index due to concerns over crashes, working conditions
summary: Tesla has lost its spot on the S&P ESG index due to concerns over crashes, working conditions, and the handling of an investigation into deaths and injuries linked to its driver-assistance systems. The company's score on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) standards has remained "fairly stable" but slipped behind improving global peers. The exclusion will lead to forced selling of Tesla's stock by funds benchmarked to the ESG index, and the decision has sparked debate over the importance of ESG standards.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc shipped 4,767 cars from its Shanghai plant to Slovenia on Wednesday, the first batch of exports since the factory reopened on April 19.

TESLA is recalling about 130,000 vehicles in the United States following an overheating issue that may cause the centre touchscreen display to malfunction, the country’s auto safety regulator said on Tuesday (May 10).

site_title: Investor group urged to step up climate action after falling short: report
summary: A report by ShareAction urges the climate action initiative Climate Action 100+ to step up its efforts, citing that the group has achieved little in its five-year phase. The report found that four in five investors lack clear objectives and escalation strategies, and fewer than one in five report on engagement progress. ShareAction recommends setting minimum transparency requirements, escalation expectations, and publishing statistics on engagement activities and outcomes. The initiative should also remove lead investors who fail to meet these requirements, and investors should be held accountable for their actions, particularly in monitoring progress and addressing greenwashing.

site_title: Delfi Q1 earnings up 13.9% on higher sales
summary: Delfi Ltd, a chocolate confectioner, reported an earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebita) of US$20.5 million in Q1, up 13.9% from the previous year. The growth was driven by higher sales and controlled operating costs. The company attributed the success to its focus on growing core strategic products and improved market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Delfi's FY2021 net profit grows 67.5% to US$29.3m
Delfi posts 20.8% rise in Q3 Ebitda to US$6.4m

site_title: Airbnbs outnumber New York City apartments in hot housing market
summary: The number of short-term rentals in New York City has surpassed the number of available apartments, exacerbating the city's hot housing market. According to third-party data tracker AirDNA, there are over 22,000 active short-term rentals, while rental inventory in Manhattan, Brooklyn, and a portion of Queens is around 7,500. This imbalance is driving up rents, with Manhattan's median rent surging to $3,870 in April. Critics argue that Airbnb's business model makes homes unaffordable, and the city has tightened restrictions on short-term rentals.

images.alt_text: Airbnb Inc projected second-quarter revenue above market estimates on Tuesday.

Employees who work in lower cost-of-living areas won’t see their compensation change, Airbnb chief executive officer Brian Chesky said in an email to staff, adding that the company would host regular in-person meet-ups and retreats.

site_title: Cisco plunges after China lockdowns, Ukraine wreck forecast
summary: Cisco Systems plummeted 19% in late trading after warning of a 1-5.5% sales decline in the current quarter, citing disruptions from Chinese lockdowns and the Ukraine war. The company slashed its annual forecast, citing supply chain issues, including a $300 million revenue loss due to power supply shortages in China. Cisco's earnings forecast fell short of Wall Street predictions, with analysts questioning whether customers are cutting spending budgets amid weak guidance.

images.alt_text: CISCO Systems on Wednesday (May 4) unveiled a technology that it says can predict issues on enterprise networks before they happen to help prevent problems and increase reliability.

site_title: Japan Inc turns against central bank's monetary stimulus: survey
summary: A survey of 500 Japanese companies found that 64% want the central bank to end large-scale monetary stimulus by March and 84% by April when BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's term ends. The weak yen has increased fuel and raw materials costs, lifting corporate and household spending costs. 24% of respondents want the central bank to abandon stimulus now, while 23% want it to end by the end of the first half. The survey marks a significant shift from previous support for the BOJ's monetary policy, with 58% wanting to scrap negative rates and 35% wanting interest rates hiked.

images.alt_text: Japanese automakers Toyota Motor, Nissan Motor and Honda Motor are the least prepared for a zero-emissions vehicle transition compared with their global competitors, according to research released Wednesday from climate think tank InfluenceMap.
Japan's economy fell for the first time in two quarters in the first three months of the year as Covid-19 curbs hit.

site_title: UK to guarantee access to cash as banks shut branches
summary: The UK government has announced a law to guarantee access to cash as banks continue to close branches. The Financial Conduct Authority will be granted new powers to ensure cash withdrawal and deposit facilities are available in communities. Approximately 5.4 million adults rely on cash for daily life, and vulnerable groups are particularly affected. The move comes after 5,000 UK bank branches have disappeared between 2015 and 2022, with Scotland being the worst-affected area. The law aims to protect access to cash as the country shifts towards a more digital world.

site_title: Dow ends ugly session 3.6% lower, Nasdaq slumps 4.7%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.6% to 31,490.07 and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 4.7% to 11,418.15. Target's disappointing earnings, which missed expectations, exacerbated worries about inflation and profit margins in a slowing economy. Consumer-oriented names such as Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola, and Walgreens Boots Alliance also fell sharply, with losses of 6.2%, 7.0%, and 8.4%, respectively. The market's decline is attributed to recession fears and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes.

site_title: Biden sells renewed US leadership in first Asia trip, but North Korea looms
summary: US President Joe Biden embarks on his first trip to Asia, touting renewed US leadership in the region, following a successful Western response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. He will meet with South Korean and Japanese leaders, as well as join a regional summit of the Quad group, while avoiding a traditional visit to North Korea due to its nuclear threat. The trip aims to demonstrate unity among Western and Asian partners against rising Chinese power, with officials acknowledging the unpredictable nature of North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Europe: Shares deepen fall on inflation worries
summary: European shares fell 1.1% on Wednesday, led by technology stocks, amid inflation worries and expectations of monetary policy tightening. The Stoxx 600 index has declined 11% year-to-date, outperforming the S&P 500 and MSCI's All Country index. Inflation in the UK rose to 9% in April, and the Euro zone's inflation remained steady at a record high 7.4%. The European Central Bank is expected to hike rates, echoing the US Federal Reserve's strategy.

site_title: Xi says China will 'open still wider' despite tight border controls
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the country will continue to open to the world, despite strict border controls, in a speech at a trade summit. This comes after Beijing doubled down on its zero-Covid policy, causing disruptions in foreign businesses and supply chains. Xi emphasized the need for a balance between pandemic response and economic development, and promised to foster an enabling business environment. Despite the challenges, Xi expressed confidence in China's resolve to open up to the world.

site_title: New York agency accuses Amazon of workforce discrimination
summary: New York state's Division of Human Rights accused Amazon of discriminating against pregnant workers and staff with disabilities by refusing to make reasonable accommodations. The agency cited two cases, including one where a pregnant worker was forced into indefinite unpaid leave after being denied an accommodation and another where a worker with a disability was denied a sleep schedule adjustment despite providing medical documentation. Amazon was accused of overriding accommodations consultants and failing to train managers on handling requests. The agency is seeking an administrative order and civil fines, and Amazon stated it was "surprised" by the accusation and cooperated with the investigation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Amazon logo is seen outside its JFK8 distribution center in Staten Island, New York, U.S. November 25, 2020.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid./File Photo

site_title: Burberry pins prospects to China's Covid recovery
summary: Burberry reports higher sales and profits for its 2022 financial year, citing China's Covid-19 recovery as a key factor. The luxury brand's biggest market, China, saw 13% drop in sales in its final quarter due to lockdowns and disrupted digital sales. Burberry's prospects depend on China's recovery, which accounted for 30% of the company's turnover last year.

site_title: US building permits dive in April; housing starts fall
summary: US building permits fell to a 5-month low in April, suggesting a slowing housing market due to rising mortgage rates and reduced affordability for entry-level and first-time buyers. Despite this, a record backlog of houses still to be constructed indicates a moderate moderation in homebuilding. The housing market is sensitive to interest rates, and supply-chain constraints continue to impact construction, resulting in rising backlogs of projects.

site_title: Foreign-born US workers reach pre-pandemic level: Census
summary: The US has reached 17.4% foreign-born workers, nearing pre-pandemic levels, with a 671,000 increase to 27.9 million. The unemployment rate for foreign-born workers fell to 5.6% in 2021, while the native-born labor force remained unchanged. Despite this, the US economy faces a worker shortage, fueling inflation and prompting Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell to express concern about a smaller economy. Labor force participation has not fully recovered, and the shortage continues to impact the US economy.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 13, 2022, a man wearing a face mask walks past a "Now Hiring" sign in front of a store in Arlington, Virginia. - US private businesses saw surprisingly weak hiring in April, a survey showed on May 4, 2022, amid low unemployment that's made their quest to find workers even more difficult. (Photo by OLIVIER DOULIERY / AFP)

site_title: US recession risk low but Europe 'vulnerable': Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the US is unlikely to fall into a recession as interest rates rise to combat soaring inflation. However, she warned Europe is "more vulnerable and exposed" due to its reliance on Russian energy imports and rising prices, which drove eurozone inflation to 7.5% in April. The US economy remains "a strong economy" according to Fed Chair Jerome Powell, despite concerns of a hard landing from interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said on Wednesday (May 18) that Covid-19 lockdowns in China appear to be impeding the flow of goods and hampering global supply chains and a broader slowdown in growth in the world's No 2 economy could have global spillover effects that warrant close attention.

site_title: Musk loses US$12b in a day as he tweets politics, slams ESG
summary: Elon Musk spent May 18 on Twitter, announcing his shift from Democrat to Republican, trashing ESG, and replying to users. This led to a $12.3 billion loss in his wealth, wiping out his daily gains. Musk has lost $49 billion since launching his Twitter bid, with his net worth dropping to $209.9 billion. He also tweeted that ESG is a "scam" and predicted "political attacks" would escalate, citing his change in party affiliation.

images.alt_text: The world's most famous electric-vehicle maker has lost its spot on the ESG version of the S&P 500 Index.
Twitter's directors voted earlier to unanimously recommend that shareholders approve Musk’s US$54.20-a-share offer.

site_title: Oil falls 2.5% as US refiners ramp up output, equities retreat
summary: Oil prices fell 2.5% on Wednesday as US refiners ramped up output, alleviating supply concerns. US West Texas Intermediate crude and Brent crude declined to $109.59 and $109.11 per barrel, respectively. Refineries increased production in response to tight product inventories and near-record exports, forcing diesel and petrol prices to record levels. The US crude inventory drawdown was unexpected, with 3.4 million barrels removed last week. Despite this, ongoing supply concerns and market volatility remain due to economic growth and inflation concerns, as well as reports on Venezuela sanctions and a potential Russian oil embargo.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the ExxonMobil Baton Rouge Refinery in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, U.S., May 15, 2021. Picture taken May 15, 2021.  REUTERS/Kathleen Flynn/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices steady on China demand recovery expectations, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices remained stable on Wednesday, with Brent crude up 2 cents to $111.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate climbing 29 cents to $112.69 a barrel. Supply concerns and expectations of China's demand recovery due to easing Covid-19 restrictions eased losses from the previous session. The easing of restrictions, including the resumption of work for 864 Shanghai financial institutions, boosted expectations for demand recovery.

images.alt_text: After hitting seven-week highs,  oil prices slumped 2 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: IPC Corp flags 3 years of losses, at risk of joining SGX’s watch-list
summary: IPC Corp, a property company, reported a total loss of S$8.85 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2021, narrowing from S$28.43 million the previous year. The company faces the risk of being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list due to three consecutive years of losses and a low market capitalization of S$12.25 million over the last six months. IPC's sales declined 23% year-on-year to S$4.17 million. The counter closed unchanged at 13.5 Singapore cents on May 18.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
pixgeneric/ generic picture of SGX Centre along Shenton Way ,  taken on 24 Feb 2022.

site_title: Malaysian stocks losing appeal as economic recovery plays amid soaring valuations
summary: Malaysia's stocks are losing appeal as the country's economic recovery gains momentum, with soaring valuations. The central bank raised its Overnight Policy Rate by 25 basis points to 2% in May, surprising market expectations. The move was driven by inflationary pressures, including imported inflation, and strong domestic demand. Analysts predict further rate hikes, potentially denting market sentiment and growth. Despite concerns, the market has been relatively calm, with investors drawn to the country's safe-haven status and its role as a net oil exporter.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The announcement of interest rate hike came as a surprise to the market as many expected Malaysia's central bank to maintain the historical low interest rate.

Malaysia's central bank governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said the economic improvement also reflects the recovery in the job market, with unemployment rate declined to 4.1 per cent in first quarter this year.
The weakening ringgit has impacted many Malaysian businesses but some are benefited from it.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as growth stocks rally wanes
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones falling 185.92 points or 0.57% to 32,468.67, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropping. A rally in growth shares faded, and downbeat results from Target Corp added to concerns over surging inflation. The decline was attributed to concerns over inflation and the impact of US trade policies on global markets.

site_title: MBS to hold first public fan event in 2 years with Top Gun multimedia showcase
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) is hosting a Top Gun-themed light, water, and pyrotechnic showcase on May 21, marking its first public fan event in over 2 years. The event, in partnership with United International Pictures, will feature a multimedia spectacle on the resort's 3 hotel towers, ArtScience Museum, and Sands SkyPark. The show starts at 8pm and is free and open to the public, with a second run at 9:30pm. This event follows the upcoming release of Top Gun: Maverick in Singapore on May 25.

site_title: China lockdowns impeding supply chain recovery, slowdown risks spillovers, Yellen says
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that China's Covid-19 lockdowns are hindering global supply chains and potentially slowing the world's No 2 economy, which could have global spillover effects. The lockdowns appear to be impeding the flow of goods and services, exacerbating existing supply chain difficulties and boosting prices. Yellen expressed concern over the developments in China, which compound existing supply-chain pressures.

site_title: World in no better place to fight pandemics than before Covid, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization's Independent Panel for Pandemic Preparedness and Response stated that the world is no better prepared for a new pandemic than it was before COVID-19, despite some progress in funding. The panel's report highlighted a lack of progress on international health regulations, citing the same tools and system used in 2019, which were insufficient to respond to a pandemic. The panel called for a high-level meeting at the UN General Assembly and independent health threats council to galvanize action and urged the WHO to establish a pandemic treaty.

images.alt_text: Developing vaccines and finding new treatments are among the items on Gates' list of things to accomplish.

site_title: Subscription-based printing, instant ink deliveries for home businesses and workers
summary: HP Inc has introduced a subscription-based printing service called Instant Ink, which provides affordable ink replacements for home businesses and telecommuting employees. The service, available in Singapore, detects low ink levels and automatically requests replacements, reducing waste and carbon footprint. Instant Ink also offers recycling services, collecting used cartridges and reusing them to make new ones. The service is priced from S$1.90 for 10 pages to S$36.90 for 700 pages a month, with customers able to choose from different price bands.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
DBS will launch 5 platform partnerships to help SMEs in their digital and supply chain capabilities.
Consumer brands told The Business Times that Shanghai shopping malls have asked them to prepare for reopening, but with few details on how and when this will happen.

site_title: Hatten Land subsidiary donates virtual land in metaverse to raise funds for BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: Hatten Land's subsidiary, Hatten Edge, donated 2 hectares of virtual land in the metaverse to the Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) to raise funds. The donation marked the 17th anniversary of the fund, which supports financially disadvantaged children and youth in the arts. Donors who contribute S$100 will receive a virtual tree in the metaverse, allowing them to 'plant' it and dedicate it to beneficiaries. The donation aims to empower the next generation of artists and support their development.

images.alt_text: Art competition in support of BT Budding Artists Fund
Digital artworks by BT Budding Artists Fund youths on show at Tekka Place

site_title: US men's and women's teams strike equal pay deal, US Soccer says
summary: The US Soccer Federation has reached collective bargaining agreements with its men's and women's teams, achieving equal pay for players and creating a mechanism for sharing prize money, including from the World Cup. The agreements, which run through 2028, make US Soccer the first Federation in the world to equalize FIFA World Cup prize money. The deals also improve player health and safety, data privacy, and commercial revenue sharing. US Soccer President Cindy Parlow Cone described the agreements as a "truly historic moment" that could change the game globally.

site_title: India’s biggest IPO comes to market at the wrong time, KPMG says
summary: India's largest IPO, valued at $2.7 billion, was met with market volatility and a plunge in its stock price, falling 7.8% on its debut. The Life Insurance Corporation of India's dominant market share of over 70% in the insurance sector makes its business resilient, according to KPMG. Despite this, the IPO came at a "wrong point in time," according to KPMG India's senior partner Srinivas Balasubramanian, who expects increased acquisitions activity in India's technology services sector.

images.alt_text: State-run insurer Life Insurance Corporation of India dropped early in its Mumbai trading debut after a record initial public offering that priced at the top of the range and was oversubscribed nearly 3 times.

site_title: India, world's biggest buyer of Russian arms, looks to diversify suppliers
summary: India, the world's largest buyer of Russian arms, is diversifying its suppliers amid the ongoing war in Ukraine and sanctions against Russia. The country aims to produce half of its defense equipment domestically and source alternative suppliers from domestic firms and eastern European nations. India has identified $324 million worth of defense equipment for domestic firms to produce this year, including ejection pods for Sukhoi fighter jets and propellers for Antonov transport aircraft. The move aims to provide certainty and stability in its supply chain mechanism.

images.alt_text: India accidentally fires missile into Pakistan: defence ministry

site_title: Tencent posts no growth in Q1 revenue, misses estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings reported its worst-ever quarterly revenue growth, with a 0.2% increase in revenue from the same period last year, missing analyst estimates. The company's profit halved, its largest decline since going public in 2004, due to a decline in advertising sales and regulatory crackdowns. Tencent's domestic game revenue dropped 1%, while its international game revenue rose 4%. The company's market value has more than halved from its peak of $930 billion in 2021.

images.alt_text: Now Tencent Holdings and  Alibaba Group Holding are struggling to keep up with even the most staid utilities as China's crackdown on Internet giants takes its toll.

site_title: China has policy room to cope with challenges, Premier Li says
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country has policy room to cope with economic challenges, citing stable prices and available policy space. The downward pressure on the economy has increased, with weakened economic indicators, including consumption and factory output. The government will take decisive action to adjust policies and support private enterprises, digital companies, and domestic stock listings. Li aims to quickly return the economy to a normal track, despite China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Indonesia hopes new programme will help lower cooking oil prices
summary: Indonesia's trade minister expects cooking oil prices to stabilize after a subsidized supply distribution program reaches 10,000 locations across the country. The program, launched by the trade ministry and state food company ID Food, allows low-income households to buy up to 2 liters of cooking oil daily at 14,000 rupiah (S$1.3) per liter. The program aims to address soaring cooking oil costs, which have remained high despite Indonesia's halt on crude palm oil exports in April. Prices are expected to stabilize as the program expands to more locations.

site_title: Global Rolex shortage spreads to Cartier and Tudor
summary: A global Rolex shortage is driving sales of other luxury timepieces, according to Watches of Switzerland Group's CEO Hugh Brian Duffy. The retailer saw a "modest" increase in sales of high-demand Swiss brands like Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet, but sales of other brands such as Cartier, Omega, Tag Heuer, Tudor, and Breitling more than doubled. The shortage is attributed to a boom in demand for Rolex watches, which is outpacing supply, leading to increased sales of other luxury timepieces.

images.alt_text: Signage for Rolex SA atop a building in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on on Friday, May 6, 2022. Concerns about inflation are also stoking demand for some luxury timepieces because they can be seen as a store of value and a guard against currency fluctuations. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: China calls for urgent boost to virus-hit economy
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang urged greater urgency in rolling out economic support measures amid a virus-battered economy. The country's economic slump is due to prolonged Covid-19 restrictions, which have constricted supply chains and stalled manufacturing. Li called for support for tech companies to list domestically and abroad, a day after Communist Party leaders doubled down on support for the tech sector. China's economic growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers to meet the country's 5.5% full-year growth target.

images.alt_text: Roads lie almost empty during Shanghai's long lockdown.

site_title: Gucci, Adidas's leaky US$1,644 parasol faces backlash in China
summary: Gucci and Adidas faced backlash in China for selling a $2,285 parasol that doesn't block rain, despite marketing it as an umbrella. The product, priced at 11,100 yuan, was designed for sun shade and fashion purposes. The move sparked criticism on social media, with some calling it "not intended for the common folk." The incident highlights the growing scrutiny of luxury brands in China, amid a broader backlash on excess and nationalism. The brands' representatives declined to comment.

site_title: A new way to shop
summary: Retailers are revamping the shopping experience to draw customers out of their homes. Gourmet store Little Farms is offering an immersive experience, including free samples, meal preparation, and interactive displays. Other unique concepts include show-and-tell kitchen showrooms, jewelry stores with gemstone histories, and clothing stores in apartment settings. As online shopping continues to rise, these innovative approaches aim to recreate the joys of physical shopping, encouraging customers to rediscover the benefits of in-store experiences.

site_title: Recovery in passenger traffic at Changi Airport to pick up, volume nears 50% of pre-pandemic level
summary: Singapore's passenger traffic at Changi Airport is expected to continue its recovery, nearing 50% of pre-pandemic levels. The airport's passenger traffic now averages above 40% and is expected to gain momentum with the June holidays and summer travel period. The government will reassess its target after the expected wave of travelers in June, but aims to reach 50% by the end of 2022. Challenges include bringing back the airport workforce and gearing up operational systems, with aviation authorities pledging to speed up recovery, promote sustainability, and adopt new technologies.

site_title: The case against bad profits via shrinkflation
summary: Inflation is driving businesses to adopt "shrinkflation," where companies offer less for the same price, instead of cutting costs. However, this approach can harm customer relationships. To overcome inflationary pressures, leaders can focus on innovation and transparency, such as by using gamification, offering tiered pricing, and being clear about price increases. Companies like Bowtie, a virtual medical insurance company, and Grab, a mobility app, have successfully implemented these strategies, demonstrating that it's possible to keep customers satisfied while managing costs.

images.alt_text: EUROPE'S main stock markets wavered at the open on Wednesday (May 18), with London sliding on news that UK inflation has spiked to a 40-year peak.

site_title: Even after the long-awaited reopening, Shanghai will never be the same
summary: Shanghai's lockdown has dragged on for seven weeks, eroding trust among residents and businesses. Despite a June 1 timeline to restore "normal production and life," the city's reopening has been met with skepticism due to past broken promises and inconsistencies between official statements and everyday realities. The drawn-out lockdown has cost global trade and supply chains $28b, and may reduce China's GDP by 4% this year. Shanghai's experience will shape China's zero-Covid strategy and its position as a business hub, raising questions about whether reopening will bring normalcy or lead to an exodus.

images.alt_text: SHANGHAI achieved its long-awaited milestone of three consecutive days with no new Covid-19 cases outside quarantine zones on Tuesday but most residents will have to put up with confinement for a while longer before resuming more normal life.
Consumer brands told The Business Times that Shanghai shopping malls have asked them to prepare for reopening, but with few details on how and when this will happen.

site_title: Suburbs vs downtown: Toronto’s mixed housing market may signal coming trend
summary: Toronto's median home price has declined 8.9% in the last 2 months due to back-to-back Bank of Canada rate hikes, but the city's core has seen a 5.2% increase in median price from February to April. This trend may signal a potential correction in Canada's housing market, with smaller cities where prices surged the most being at greater risk of steep declines. The suburbs, where prices fell by 15% in 2 months, have seen a significant decrease in demand, while the core remains resilient, driven by remote workers returning to offices.

images.alt_text: Toronto home prices dip as new listings close the gap with sales

site_title: Michelangelo ink drawing fetches 23 million euros in Paris sale
summary: A Michelangelo ink drawing, 'A nude man (after Masaccio) and 2 figures behind him', sold for 23 million euros at an auction in Paris on May 18, 2022. The work, dated to the late 15th century, was one of the few Michelangelo pieces in private hands and had been designated a French national treasure, but was removed from the list after 30 months. Recognized as a genuine Michelangelo work in 2019, it was sold without restriction after its designation was lifted.

images.alt_text: A Christie's employee installs the drawing "A nude young man (after Masaccio) surrounded by two figures" by Michelangelo Buonarroti (1475-1564) before its auction at Christie's auction house in Paris, France, April 5, 2022.  REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes

site_title: China's anti-graft watchdog investigating former central bank official Sun
summary: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection is investigating Sun Guofeng, former head of the People's Bank of China's monetary policy department, for suspected serious violations of discipline and laws. Sun was removed from his position this month, and the investigation details have not been disclosed. This probe marks the latest in China's anti-graft efforts, which have targeted high-ranking officials in various sectors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, up 6.31 points to 1,554.91. The index saw 3.740 billion lots worth RM2.255 billion in volume, with losers outnumbering gainers 464 to 460.

site_title: Dollar up after biggest drop in 2 months as Fed's Powell reaffirms hawkish outlook
summary: The US dollar rose after its largest single-day drop in over two months, following Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's hawkish stance on inflation. Powell pledged to raise interest rates as high as needed, including above neutral levels, to curb inflation. The neutral rate is expected to be around 3.5% by mid-2023.

images.alt_text: The dollar eased for a third straight day on Tuesday as a jump in sentiment across global markets encouraged investors to reinvest in riskier currencies and trim bets on the safe haven greenback which hit a two-decade high last week.

site_title: SIA still in the red for FY2022, but narrows loss to S$962m
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net loss of S$962 million for FY2022, its third annual loss. However, forward sales for the next 3 months are approaching pre-pandemic levels. The airline's group revenue more than doubled to S$2.5 billion in Q4 FY2022, but it failed to sustain profitability in the fourth quarter. This marks a significant improvement from the S$210 million loss in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
SIA’s shares rose as much as 3.2 per cent or S$0.17 to S$5.50 as at 10.26 am on Wednesday.
Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong recounted how the airline group's operating numbers plunged when the pandemic began.
PASSENGER traffic of Singapore Airlines (SIA) will likely recover faster than anticipated, as reopening in the Asia Pacific region continues to pick up momentum, said DBS Group Research.
SIA first signed as the title sponsor in 2014 for 4 years, and subsequently extended it in 2018 and 2020 for 2 years respectively.
Singapore Airlines' senior vice-president of sales and marketing, Leslie Thng, will take over as Scoot’
Launch of SIA Engineering Company's LEAN Academy in 2021 to improve productivity as the company hunkered down for the pandemic to pass. (file photo)

PASSENGER volume at Singapore’s Changi Airport has more than doubled to reach close to 40 per cent of pre-Covid levels in end-April, up from about 18 per cent in March, said Transport Minister S Iswaran.
Singapore Airlines appears to be taking off fast in post-pandemic reopening. (file photo)
Singapore Airlines is gradually restoring basic pay for pilots, after cuts that were in effect since October 2020.
Flight bookings show pent-up demand, bodes well for Singapore's air traffic target

site_title: Singapore stocks buoyed by potential China reopening; STI up 0.7 per cent
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,225.35, driven by positive news from China, including supportive comments on tech companies and plans for 864 financial institutions to resume operations. The index was led by gains from Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, while City Development and ST Engineering fell. The strong US overnight rally also contributed to the regional markets' increase.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
SIA’s shares rose as much as 3.2 per cent or S$0.17 to S$5.50 as at 10.26 am on Wednesday.
Shares of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding advanced in early morning trade on Wednesday.

site_title: Changi Airport starts major recruitment drive to fill 6,600 job vacancies
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) is launching a major recruitment drive to fill over 6,600 job vacancies, including frontline passenger service positions, innovation and technology roles, and airport emergency service and cyber security officers. The recruitment drive aims to take advantage of a fierce rebound in air travel, with Changi expected to recover more than half of its pre-Covid-19 passenger volume in 2022. The hiring process will take place at an on-site careers fair and will focus on competitive salaries, good incentives, and better career prospects.

images.alt_text: Passengers departing from Bintan Ferry Terminal. Indonesia overtook India as the biggest source of arrivals to Singapore in April 2022.

site_title: ABN Amro shares fall as money-laundering provision boosts costs
summary: ABN Amro beat first-quarter earnings expectations with a net profit of 295 million euros, but shares dropped 10% due to higher-than-expected costs, including a 50 million euro anti-money laundering provision. The bank's cost target for 2024 remains at 4.7 billion euros, despite CEO Robert Swaak expressing concerns about the "smooth glide path." Analysts also expressed disappointment over the lack of a share buyback scheme, citing higher-than-expected costs.

site_title: Philippines' Marcos wants China ties to 'shift to higher gear' under his presidency
summary: Philippines president-elect Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has expressed his intention to shift the country's relations with China to a higher gear under his administration, citing Beijing's support for his independent foreign policy. Marcos held phone talks with China President Xi Jinping, agreeing to hold more comprehensive discussions of issues. The Philippines and China have had a rocky relationship over Beijing's territorial claims and actions in the South China Sea, but Marcos aims to expand their relationship in areas such as culture, education, and health.

site_title: Aviva leaves door open to return more capital
summary: Aviva, a British insurer, reported a 5% increase in general insurance sales in the first quarter, with its Solvency II ratio at 198%, exceeding the 180% threshold. CEO Amanda Blanc stated that excess capital will be returned to shareholders over time, potentially giving more cash back to investors. This follows a previous commitment to return £4.75 billion to investors. Aviva's shares rose 0.64% despite activist investor Cevian Capital's pressure to return more money to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Aviva, which has major businesses in Britain, Canada and Ireland, also said in March it would boost its dividend this year and next.

site_title: Sri Lanka can’t find cash to pay even one ship for petrol
summary: Sri Lanka is struggling to pay for a fuel shipment, with the nation on the verge of default. Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera announced that the country has no dollars to pay for the shipment and is working to obtain dollars in the open market. The nation's fuel requirement for June is estimated at $530 million, with current supplies of petrol prioritized for essential services. Sri Lanka's economic crisis has led to shortages of food, cooking gas, and inflation soaring 30% in Asia's fastest inflation rate.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s situation is unique in the way all debt crises are - the particulars here involve an unpopular government run by an all-powerful family, the unresolved aftermath of a 30-year civil war and violent street protests.

site_title: Genting tycoon seeks Singapore comeback with new cruise line
summary: Malaysian billionaire Lim Kok Thay is launching Resorts World Cruises in Singapore with one ship, Genting Dream, set to operate cruises to nowhere starting in June. This comes months after his Hong Kong-based cruise empire, Genting Hong Kong, imploded. Despite the collapse, Lim's new venture is expected to focus on Asia, with routes to Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia planned for September. The company's success will depend on travel demand rebounding in the region amid easing of travel curbs and economic reopenings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: STMicroelectronics sets a global carbon neutrality target by 2027. SP Group clinched a US$370 million deal to build a district cooling system at STMicroelectronics' manufacturing site. Singapore businesses prepare for Shanghai's planned lifting of Covid-19 curbs in June. Kensington Park condo launched a collective sale tender with a guide price of S$1.28 billion. WeWork's enterprise demand drives growth in Singapore.

images.alt_text: WHILE investors debate whether China is still investible, global financial institutions including DBS and OCBC in Singapore are expanding operations in the mainland, shrugging off the geopolitical tensions as short-term bumps for a lucrative future.

site_title: Japan set to allow foreign Toshiba bids if they comply with security rules
summary: Japan will allow foreign investors to bid on industrial giant Toshiba if they comply with security rules governing sensitive infrastructure and technology. Economic security minister Takayuki Kobayashi stated that foreign investors will be subject to Japanese laws and regulations. Toshiba, which includes nuclear energy, military radar, and semiconductors, has received interest from US private equity firms like Bain and Blackstone. Japan aims to attract overseas investment to grow its economy, but also increases oversight of sensitive technologies amid growing tensions with China. Foreign investors must comply with security rules to pursue Toshiba bid.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly higher on May 18, 2022, with the Hang Seng index rising 0.20% to 20,644.28. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.25%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.08%. This follows a rally on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) is seen at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China September 14, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: LTA awards contracts for final Jurong Region Line station, provision of power supply system
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded two contracts for the Jurong Region Line (JRL) worth a total of S$386 million. A S$148 million civil contract was awarded to Hwa Seng Builder for the construction of JW5 station and its associated viaducts, set to start in the third quarter of this year and complete by 2029. A second contract, valued at about S$238 million, was awarded to a consortium consisting of Siemens Mobility and Concord Corporation for the provision of the JRL power supply system, with construction set to begin in 2025.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
LTA awards S$363m civil contract for Cross Island Line Phase 1
LTA awards S$526m civil contract for Bright Hill interchange on Cross Island Line Phase 1

site_title: Central Japan water leak affects plants near Toyota hub
summary: A major water leak in central Japan on May 18 disrupted supply to over 130 businesses near Toyota Motor's production center. The leak, occurring at the Meiji Irrigation Works, affected major auto firms and power companies, with Toyota using well water to cope with the shutdown. Authorities aim to resume water supplies by the end of Wednesday, and the cause of the leak is still under investigation.

site_title: Enterprise demand drives WeWork growth in Singapore
summary: WeWork's flagship property in Singapore, 21 Collyer Quay, will start operations in July 2022. Enterprise demand drives 46% of physical memberships in South-east Asia, with larger corporations showing no signs of slowing. WeWork's revenue forecasts for Q2, Q3, and Q4 2022 are 97%, 70%, and 100% committed, respectively, according to General Manager Balder Tol. This growth is attributed to the increasing interest and enquiries from larger corporations in the region.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: China relaxes some Covid test rules for US, other travellers
summary: China has relaxed some COVID-19 test requirements for travelers from the US and other countries, removing pre-departure tests for some inbound travelers and shortening the quarantine period. The changes, effective May 20, aim to cope with the Omicron variant. The adjustments apply to travelers from Dallas, New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Seattle, who will no longer need RT-PCR tests or antibody tests before flying. The move is part of China's efforts to fine-tune its stringent measures in response to the characteristics of coronavirus variants.

site_title: Microsoft announces changes after cloud computing complaints
summary: Microsoft is revising its licensing terms and allowing cloud service providers to better compete in Europe after being fined 1.6 billion euros by EU antitrust regulators. The company's president, Brad Smith, announced the changes in response to complaints from cloud service providers, including NextCloud and OVHcloud, who alleged Microsoft's cloud practices were unfair. The revised terms include offering Windows as a complete desktop operating system, providing longer-term price protection, and revising licensing terms to give European cloud providers more options.

site_title: Global Switch's Chinese owners said to kick off US$10b sale
summary: Global Switch Holdings, a US$10 billion data centre company owned by Chinese steelmaker Jiangsu Shagang Group and Avic Trust, is set to start a formal sale process amid interest from firms like Blackstone, KKR, and DigitalBridge Group. A potential sale could value the business at £8 billion (S$13.7 billion) or more. Discussions are ongoing, with no certainty on the outcome, as Global Switch's management and Shagang Group discuss details including valuation. This sale follows strong takeover interest in data centre companies due to their stable returns and growth expectations.

site_title: Fiscal capture at the ECB
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) actions to support debt-distressed member states may be undermining its price-stability mandate. Since 2021, inflation in the UK, US, and eurozone has exceeded their 2% targets, potentially due to fiscal dominance or "fiscal capture." The ECB has engaged in aggressive low-interest-rate and asset-purchase policies to support governments' expansionary fiscal policies, despite knowing they may run counter to its mandate. This could have detrimental effects on the ECB's objectives and the stability of the eurozone economy.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde hinted on Wednesday the Frankfurt-based institution could raise its interest rates from historic lows as soon as July as inflation in the eurozone soars.

site_title: China in talks with automakers on EV subsidy extension: sources
summary: China is in talks with automakers to extend subsidies for electric vehicles (EVs) set to expire in 2022, aiming to boost a slowing market. The move comes as the country's economy slows and auto sales decline due to COVID-19 lockdowns. The subsidy extension, if approved, would roll back a planned purchase tax increase for qualified EVs and could include an extension of the subsidy scheme, which has been credited with creating the world's largest EV market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The interior of a Toyota bZ4X concept electric vehicle (EV) is seen during its world premiere on a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Aircraft leasing faces shake-up as risks cloud recovery
summary: Global aircraft leasing is facing a shake-up after SMBC Aviation Capital's US$6.7 billion deal to buy Goshawk Aviation, making it the second-largest player globally. The move comes as the industry reports a stronger-than-expected US-led recovery, but it's increasingly overshadowed by inflation, rising borrowing costs, and the Ukraine conflict. SMBC's acquisition leapfrogs Dublin-based rival Avolon, putting it in second place behind AerCap.

images.alt_text: Steven Udvar-Hazy, chairman of Air Lease Corp, said that every leasing company or bank that has lent money or assets to Russia is going to build in a cushion for every future transaction. "We will all pay a price for that."

site_title: Aviva targets on track as Q1 general insurance sales rise 5%
summary: Aviva, a British insurance company, reported a 5% increase in general insurance sales in the first quarter, reaching a record £2.1 billion. The company also boosted its dividend payout by £4.75 billion, following a series of disposals. Despite external net outflows of £200 million from its fund management unit, Aviva remains on track to meet its financial targets.

site_title: F&B tech startup Oddle bags US$5m in bridge round led by Altara Ventures
summary: Oddle, a F&B technology startup, has secured US$5 million in a pre-Series B bridge round led by Altara Ventures. The funds will be used for product development and market expansion in Singapore, Malaysia, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Oddle, founded in 2014, has expanded its solutions to include reservation systems, QR ordering systems, and payment terminal solutions, aiming to bring its full suite of solutions to these markets.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: Decline of office set to define City of London’s future
summary: UK finance workers are increasingly viewing the office as their main place of work, with 85% no longer considering it their main workplace. A YouGov survey found that only 14% of finance executives view the office as their main workplace, while 42% prefer working from home and 44% prefer a hybrid arrangement. Despite efforts to persuade bankers to return to pre-pandemic norms, many firms are adopting hybrid working models, with some, like JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, allowing staff to work from home or take unlimited vacation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view is seen of the London skyline from Canary Wharf in London, Britain, October 19, 2016. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo
As visitors reappear and commuters return to the office, local cabbies are emerging from the doldrums less pessimistic about a future against fast-growing rivals like Uber Technologies.

site_title: Thai industrial confidence at 5-month low as costs rise
summary: Thailand's industries sentiment index dropped to a 5-month low in April, reaching 86.2, due to higher production costs caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which increased the price of energy and raw materials. The Federation of Thai Industries attributed the decline to global trade and growth disruptions.

site_title: Singapore to lose most from China slump, Natixis says
summary: Singapore is set to be the hardest hit from China's economic slowdown due to prolonged coronavirus lockdowns, according to Natixis. The slowdown is expected to shave off 1.5 percentage points from China's GDP growth this year, cutting its annual estimate to 4.2% from 5.2%. This will have a knock-on effect on Singapore, which is indirectly vulnerable to Chinese demand due to its role as a trade centre and commodity hub in Asia. India, on the other hand, is expected to benefit from the weakened global commodity prices and improved terms of trade.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in April eased for the fifth straight month to 6.4 per cent year on year, from 7.7 per cent the previous month according to data from Enterprise Singapore on Tuesday (May 17)

site_title: Air France-KLM agrees to cargo deal with French shipping firm CMA CGM
summary: Air France-KLM has agreed to a cargo deal with CMA CGM, a French shipping firm, as part of a 10-year partnership. CMA CGM will take up to 9% of Air France-KLM in exchange for investing in the airline's air cargo division. The partnership aims to generate significant revenue synergies and invest in the air freight market, driven by growing demand for flying goods amid supply chain disruptions. The deal is subject to anti-trust approval and marks a significant move by CMA CGM to diversify its logistics business.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Lufthansa ordered 10 more Boeing cargo jets, as the carrier looks to keep pace with booming global demand for air freight services.

site_title: China, US are racing to make billions from mining the moon's minerals
summary: The US and China are racing to mine the moon's minerals, with the US pushing for a non-legally binding set of principles, known as the Artemis Accords, to govern space activity. The US has blocked China from joining the International Space Station, prompting Beijing to build its own. China and Russia oppose the accords, instead promoting an alternative project, the International Lunar Research Station. The lack of cooperation between the US and China risks an arms race and clashes over extracting resources, with China seeking to establish itself as the "Nasa of the future."

images.alt_text: Singapore signs international pact for space exploration
EU lays out US$6.8b satellite communication plan in space race

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB cuts Jumbo target price to S$0.30 on bumpy recovery journey
summary: Jumbo Group's recovery journey is expected to be bumpy due to ongoing uncertainties in China, according to CGS-CIMB. The brokerage firm cut its target price to S$0.30 from S$0.31 and maintained a "hold" call on the stock, citing slower recovery in Singapore amid the Omicron variant. The company reported a net loss of S$4.5 million for the first half of FY2022, with revenue from Singapore recovering and China growing due to new outlet openings.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Consumer brands told The Business Times that Shanghai shopping malls have asked them to prepare for reopening, but with few details on how and when this will happen.

Occupying a standalone building within a commercial zone, the latest outlet has 2 levels with an overall floor space of 8,081 sq ft, 7 VIP rooms and a total seating capacity of 166, the group noted in a press statement on Wednesday (May 11).
Jumbo opens 2 more Kok Kee Wanton Noodle stalls as safe-management measures ease

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group plans to invest 21t won in South Korea EV business
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to invest 21 trillion won (S$23 billion) through 2030 to expand its electric vehicle (EV) business in South Korea. The company aims to annually produce 1.44 million units of EVs in South Korea by 2030, accounting for 45% of global EV production capacity of 3.23 million units in 2030.
