Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and Standard Chartered also plan to increase their presence in China, with Goldman Sachs relocating a senior executive to Shanghai and JPMorgan aiming to expand its licenses and onshore presence.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Partners and managing directors at Goldman Sachs can take time off when needed “without a fixed vacation day entitlement”.
A worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) rides a bicycle along a nearly-empty road in Shanghai on May 5, 2022.

site_title: Russia tests the West’s resolve
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has significantly impacted the global system, revitalizing the Western alliance and prompting a unified response. The US and NATO have provided military assistance to Ukraine, contributing to its success in defending its capital and pushing back Russian troops. Economic sanctions have also inflicted significant pain on Russia. The invasion has strengthened NATO, with Finland and Sweden edging closer to joining the alliance, as the West seeks to address the most serious threat to international order since the end of the Cold War.

images.alt_text: “President Putin wants Ukraine defeated, Nato down, North America and Europe divided,” Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said. “But Ukraine stands, Nato is stronger than ever, Europe and North America are solidly united.”

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 3.27% to 20,602.52, driven by hopes of Shanghai's gradual reopening after weeks of Covid lockdowns. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.65%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.73%. The rally follows a broader Asian market surge.

site_title: Singapore new private home sales flat in April, likely to climb in coming months
summary: Singapore's new private home sales remained flat in April, with 653 units sold, unchanged from the previous month. However, analysts expect sales to pick up in the coming months, driven by new projects such as Piccadilly Grand and Liv @ MB. Despite the cooling measures, new home sales have stabilized, with buyers motivated by locking in mortgage rates and pent-up demand. The market is expected to continue to be buoyant, with new sales volumes potentially reaching 8,000 to 9,000 units for the year.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Purchases of non-landed private homes by foreign buyers picked up in April with 93 transactions, up from 51 units in March.
Facade of one block of a condominium in Singapore.
Price cuts at Perfect Ten condo in Bukit Timah raise eyebrows
Price gap narrows between RCR and CCR homes in March
New home sales up in March, expected to stay buoyant in coming months

site_title: Shanghai hits prized 'zero Covid' status but lockdown lingers
summary: Shanghai, China's commercial hub, has achieved "zero Covid" status after three consecutive days with no new cases outside quarantine zones, but residents will still face confinement for several more weeks. The city plans to resume outdoor activities in stages, with most restrictions on movement remaining in place until May 21. By June, the lockdown is expected to be lifted, but residents will still be required to get tested frequently. China's "zero Covid" policy has had a significant impact on the country's economy, with retail sales and industrial output plummeting in April.

images.alt_text: PRECISION components specialist CDW Holding said it has resumed production at one of its Shanghai factories, since it temporarily halted operations amid a citywide lockdown to curb the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, driven by gains in Tokyo and easing UK unemployment. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 rose 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: CDW partially resumes Shanghai production; says lockdown may hit FY2022 performance
summary: CDW Holding, a precision components specialist, has partially resumed production at one of its Shanghai factories after temporarily halting operations due to the citywide lockdown to curb Covid-19. The SHCD factory resumed production on May 9 with governmental approval, and applications have been made to increase the worker quota for the SHTP factory. The production halt may impact CDW's FY2022 performance, and shares are trading flat.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
CDW unit to buy back shares of biotech unit from controlling shareholder's son
CDW guides for consolidated operating profit in FY2021 on strong H2 turnaround
CDW wins contract from Razer-backed Loupedeck, reports recovery in 2021

site_title: Singapore visitor arrivals take off, with April’s 294,300 figure highest since pandemic
summary: Singapore's international arrivals reached 294,300 in April, the highest figure since the pandemic, with a month-on-month increase for the third straight month. Indonesia surpassed India as the largest source of arrivals, with 58,270 visitors, while Australia and Malaysia also saw significant increases. Despite China's limited travel, regional tourism is expected to generate more visitor flows, with the Singapore Tourism Board aiming to position itself as a standalone destination. Experts note a modest recovery in the tourism sector, with travel expected to increase gradually in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Travellers look at information regarding their flights in the departure hall at Changi International Airport in Singapore on December 2, 2021. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

Labour economist Walter Theseira stressed that Singapore’s broader economic status and reputation as an investment destination could be hurt, if the travel and hospitality sector is unable to meet the surge in demand.
The restrained outlook comes as several major source markets remain effectively shut, one economist told The Business Times.
Singapore hotel industry takings could be near-normal by year-end

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on commodities boost, RBA minutes hint at June hike
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% to 7,112.5, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks due to strong commodity prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) minutes hinted at a possible interest rate hike in June, while data on wages and employment will influence future rate hikes. Technology stocks fell, with Block and Xero down 3.3% and 1.6%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Australian stocks inched higher on Tuesday.

site_title: Nasal sprays - the next-gen vaccines to combat Covid
summary: Scientists are working on a nasal spray vaccine to combat COVID-19, which could prevent infections altogether and slow the virus's spread. Unlike current vaccines injected into arm muscles, nasal sprays target the virus at its entry point in the nose, providing sterilizing immunity. Animal studies have shown promising results, and a single vaccine for a broad range of coronaviruses is also in development. While challenges remain, a nasal spray vaccine could offer a game-changing solution to prevent severe disease, long-term symptoms, and future variants, potentially leading to a new generation of vaccines.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust posts DPU of 2.57 Singapore cents for H2 FY2022, up 0.8%
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 0.8% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.57 Singapore cents for the 6 months ended March 31, 2022, driven by higher connections revenue. Revenue for the period was 1.4% higher at S$189.68 million, with profit attributable to unitholders rising 2.3% to S$51.18 million. The company expects to maintain distributions and continues to expand its network and invest in new infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore’s export growth in coming months likely to be dragged down by China’s slowdown: economists
summary: Singapore's export growth is expected to slow in the coming months due to China's economic slowdown, according to economists. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in April grew 6.4% year-on-year, down from 7.7% in March, marking the fifth consecutive month of easing growth. Shipments of electronic products showed resilience with a 12.8% year-on-year growth, while non-electronic exports slowed to 4.6%. Global headwinds are expected to dampen external demand, despite Asean's reopening offering a silver lining.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Authors of the quarterly BT-SUSS Business Climate survey are expecting Q2 gross domestic product (GDP) to come in at 5.1-6.1 per cent - a figure that several economists said is higher than they had predicted.
Headline readings had been slipping since the start of the year, though they remained expansionary.
Excluding the typically volatile biomedical manufacturing sector, industrial output for the same period grew 9.7 per cent year on year .

site_title: Manning the defences: the case for active management and diversification
summary: The global economy is being impacted by multiple shocks, including tighter monetary policy, an energy crisis, and a clouded Chinese economy, leading to a shrinking global liquidity and potential economic slowdown. Investors face challenges in asset allocation, but the author suggests an active management approach, focusing on granular asset classes and themes such as companies with pricing power, real estate vehicles, and diversification into currencies and commodities. The author also emphasizes the importance of diversification, particularly in fixed income, and highlights the potential for private equity to deliver high returns despite market challenges.

images.alt_text: Ascott Residence Trust has been one of the key beneficiaries of Singapore's reopening.
The value of ETFs traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in April fell to S$454 million, from S$663 million in March.

site_title: Cannes Film Festival kicks into full swing for 75th anniversary
summary: The Cannes Film Festival is set to kick off its 75th anniversary edition with a lineup of big Hollywood names, including Tom Cruise, Baz Luhrmann, and Tom Hanks. The festival, which resumes its traditional calendar after two years of pandemic disruptions, will feature a diverse range of films, including Asia's strong showing and several Ukrainian entries. Despite banning official Russian delegations, the festival will still screen films by exiled Russian director Kirill Serebrennikov. The event aims to bring back the excitement of cinema, with festival director Thierry Fremaux calling it "one of the best Cannes line-ups in years."

images.alt_text: Top Gun: Maverick earned a 96 per cent positive rating from 76 reviews collected on the Rotten Tomatoes website.

site_title: Germany’s great pacifism debate
summary: Chancellor Olaf Scholz faces intense debate in Germany over the country's stance in the Russia-Ukraine war, sparked by philosopher Jürgen Habermas' commentary. Public figures have signed hundreds of open letters, with some advocating for more forceful engagement and others pushing for a settlement that would spare Europe from conflict. As a pacifist nation, Germany is uncomfortable with the assumptions and red lines involved, with Germans sharply divided on the decision to deliver heavy weapons to Ukraine and the effectiveness of current sanctions. The debate has brought long-ignored issues of national and European security to the forefront.

images.alt_text: German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock says she expects the European Union to impose sanctions on Russian oil within days.

site_title: Reinventing the conveyancing process with blockchain
summary: Singapore is exploring the use of blockchain technology to modernize the real estate industry, with the potential to facilitate faster, easier, and more secure property transfers. Asset tokenization, which involves digitalizing ownership rights and breaking them into fractions, could lower the barrier to entry for property ownership, particularly for lower-income households. However, concerns include regulatory burdens, jurisdictional issues, and safeguarding ownership. To implement blockchain-based real estate transfers, Singapore's land title regulator must recognize title transfers on the blockchain, and integration with relevant agencies, as well as digitization of conveyancing documents, is required.

images.alt_text: Speakers at a panel at the 4th Annual Security Token Summit agreed that private markets are generally illiquid, but blockchain technology could increase efficiency and reach.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump nearly 1% as chipmakers rally
summary: South Korean stocks jumped nearly 1% on Tuesday, led by technology giant Samsung Electronics and chipmaker SK Hynix, as global markets gained confidence from China's plan to ease strict Covid-19 lockdowns. The Kospi index ended at 2,620.44, its highest close since May 6, while the Korean won strengthened for a third straight session. Despite weak economic data, recession worries around the Chinese economy have dwindled due to planned lockdown easing.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi rose 54.16 points or 2.12 per cent to close at 2,604.24. For the week, it declined 1.5 per cent.

site_title: Temasek hikes stake in e-commerce companies Amazon, Pinduoduo
summary: Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings increased its stake in e-commerce companies Amazon.com and Pinduoduo by more than 15% through a securities filing. This follows previous investments in 2017 and 2020, respectively. Temasek has also made significant investments in the US tech sector and has sold shares in Intel and Draftkings. The firm cut its stakes in Airbnb and Lumen Technologies, while adding Nvidia, S&P Global, and 1Life Healthcare to its portfolio.

site_title: UK cost-of-living squeeze intensifies with drop in real wages
summary: The UK's cost-of-living squeeze intensified in March, with wages falling 1.9% behind inflation, the largest decline since 2013. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose 4.2% in the first quarter, but were largely offset by surging prices. With inflation expected to exceed 10% by year-end and tax hikes, consumers face a significant decline in real disposable income, raising concerns about recession and interest rate hikes. The labor market remains tight, with unemployment at 3.7%, but economists expect jobless rates to rise at year-end.

images.alt_text: Tens of thousands of UK civil servants are set to lose their jobs under new cost-cutting measures planned by the government, senior minister Jacob Rees-Mogg said on Friday (May 13).

site_title: Los Angeles County property market soars by record US$100b
summary: Los Angeles County is projected to see a record $100 billion increase in property values this year, resulting in $18 billion in property tax revenue. The 6% annual increase is attributed to low-interest rates, inflation, and high demand, boosting home values to new highs. The median price of an LA home is now $1 million, up 14% from last year, exacerbating the county's affordability crisis, with nearly 60,000 homeless residents.

site_title: Lentor Hill Estate land parcels launched for sale, could draw bids in S$1,000-S$1,100 psf ppr range
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched three 99-year leasehold residential sites in the Upper Thomson area under the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme for the first half of 2022. The sites, Lentor Central, Lentor Gardens, and Lentor Hills Road (Parcel B), are expected to yield 735 and 530 housing units, respectively. Bids are expected to range from S$1,000 to S$1,100 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), with two sites coming under the confirmed list and one on the reserve list.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Latest GLS tenders see firm land prices
Developers show restraint in latest GLS tender, despite shrinking unsold inventory
Dunman Road mega site up for tender, bids could hit S$1.3b

site_title: Japan announces limited ‘test tourism’ from May as step to full re-opening
summary: Japan will start conducting "test tourism" in the form of limited package tours in May, with tourists from the US, Australia, Thailand, and Singapore allowed to participate. The tours will be strictly planned and accompanied by tour conductors, with the goal of verifying compliance and emergency responses for infection prevention. The move aims to gather information prior to a full re-opening of Japan's borders to tourism, which was closed in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: India's Byju's eyes Chegg or 2U as it weighs US acquisition: sources
summary: Byju's, an Indian online education startup, is in talks to acquire either Chegg or 2U, a US-based education company, with a potential deal value of around $2 billion. Byju's has already lined up $1 billion in debt commitments to finance the acquisition. The talks come as Byju's seeks to expand its business through acquisitions and capitalize on the global market rout. Byju's has a valuation of $22 billion, making it one of the world's most valuable startups.

images.alt_text: Asean to play increasingly beneficial role for Indian enterprises seeking new opportunities

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 8.50 points to 1,552.91. Volume was 476.20 million lots worth RM195.26 million, with 226 gainers outnumbering 190 losers.

site_title: Indonesia posts largest ever trade surplus thanks to export boom
summary: Indonesia reported its largest-ever trade surplus of $7.56 billion in April, driven by a record high in exports and slower-than-expected imports. Exports rose 47.76% to $27.32 billion, while imports grew 21.97% to $19.76 billion. The country's export boom is attributed to commodities like thermal coal, palm oil, and nickel, with mining and oil and gas products driving growth. The government's export ban on crude palm oil and derivatives may impact the trade balance in May.

images.alt_text: Several factors have acted to shelter Asian consumers’ wallets,  such as the more structured post-pandemic reopening of Asian economies.
A seaside restaurant on Nusa Lembongan, an island located southeast of Bali, in Indonesia.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei gains for third day on China optimism; subdued earnings weigh
summary: The Nikkei stock average in Japan rose for a third consecutive day, gaining 0.42% to 26,659.75, driven by optimism over China's lifting of Covid-19 lockdowns and a rally in energy shares. Shanghai achieved three consecutive days without new cases outside quarantine zones, boosting sentiment. Energy shares led gains, jumping 3.62% after crude oil rose overnight. However, some disappointing financial results, such as those from Uniqlo and Dentsu Group, weighed on the market.

images.alt_text: epa09937374 A passerby wearing a face mask is reflected in a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 10 May 2022. Tokyo stocks dropped by more than 2 per cent in the morning trading session following overnight plunge in Wall Street and concerns on China’s economy.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday.

site_title: Uber launches robot food delivery in California
summary: Uber launched pilot food delivery services using autonomous vehicles in two California cities, Santa Monica and West Hollywood. The services are available to Uber Eats users and can be opted out. The autonomous car pilot is in collaboration with Motional, while sidewalk robots are provided by Serve Robotics. The vehicles are actively monitored by human operators, and the technology will be scaled up over time. Uber is also launching a map of electric vehicle charging stations in its driver app in the US this summer, aiming to promote drivers switching to battery-powered vehicles by 2030.

images.alt_text: UBER TECHNOLOGIES will scale back hiring and reduce expenditure on its marketing and incentive activities, CNBC reported on Monday (May 9), citing a letter from chief executive officer Dara Khosrowshahi.

site_title: Digital wealth manager Syfe makes push into Hong Kong
summary: Syfe, a Singapore-based digital wealth manager, is expanding into Hong Kong with its advisory and wealth management services. The platform has secured a licence from the Securities and Futures Commission in Hong Kong and will offer nine investment portfolios, including four core and one thematic portfolio. Syfe's founder, Dhruv Arora, believes the focus on passive investments will endure in the Hong Kong market, which has seen family offices and financial institutions leaving the city for Singapore. Syfe aims to accelerate hiring in Hong Kong and plans to bring its brokerage platform to the territory within the next six to 12 months.

site_title: China offers property-buying perks to families with 3 kids
summary: China is offering property-buying perks to families with 3 kids, allowing households with 3 children to buy 1 more residence and giving them precedence in purchasing new homes. The policy, implemented in Hangzhou, aims to boost birth rates and revive the housing market. This move follows a nationwide trend of smaller cities rolling out similar policies, and is part of the Chinese government's efforts to support "real" housing demand for multi-children families, while maintaining its stance that "houses are for living in, not for speculation".

images.alt_text: In January-April, China property sales by value fell 29.5 per cent year on year, compared with the 22.7 per cent decline in the first 3 months.
China has allowed a further cut in mortgage loan interest rates for some home buyers, in another push to prop up its property market.

site_title: Amid crypto crash, some market players argue for less regulation but more clarity
summary: US Congressman Tom Emmer argues that over-regulation of cryptocurrencies is counterproductive and instead advocates for "more clarity and certainty" to allow financial innovations to thrive. Emmer believes that innovation should be encouraged, not punished, and that governments should focus on creating rules that provide certainty, rather than trying to protect people from taking risks. Market players, such as Tim Draper, also support this view, suggesting that regulation should allow individuals to take a chance and innovate, rather than stifling the industry's growth.

Deus Finance's DEI token has lost its 1-to-1 peg to the dollar, becoming the latest failure of an algorithmic stablecoin during a period of crypto market stress.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.29% to 20,206.81, despite a downbeat US market due to weak Chinese economic data. The Shanghai Composite Index opened down 0.09%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index sank 0.41%. The Hang Seng Index's gain was the highest among major exchanges, with investors seemingly brushing off concerns about the US-China trade tensions.

site_title: EU gives companies green light to keep Russian gas flowing
summary: The European Union has given companies the green light to continue buying Russian gas without breaching sanctions, softening its stance in a standoff over energy supplies. The EU's revised guidelines state that companies should make a clear statement that they consider their obligations fulfilled once they pay in euros or dollars. This move allows companies to continue making payments in euros or dollars, as long as they intend to fulfill their existing contractual obligations. The decision eases tensions between the EU and Russia over energy supplies.

images.alt_text: 3D-printed natural gas pipes are placed on displayed EU and Russian flags in this illustration.

site_title: Trump's social media app may raise up to US$50m before deal closes
summary: Former US President Donald Trump's social media venture, Truth Media & Technology Group (TMTG), may raise up to $50 million through convertible notes before merging with Digital World Acquisition, a blank-check acquisition firm, for $1.25 billion. The deal is under investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the funds are inaccessible to Trump's company until cleared. TMTG had an operating loss of $4.3 million in 2021 and had previously raised $38.2 million through convertible promissory notes.

site_title: Del Monte’s US subsidiary raises US$600m for refinancing purposes
summary: Del Monte Pacific's US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods Inc, raised $600 million through a 7-year term loan B facility to refinance senior secured notes. The facility has a floating interest rate of 0.5% plus 4.25% per annum and is expected to result in $20-30 million of annual pre-tax interest savings. The move reflects creditors' confidence in Del Monte Foods' sustained profitability, following a recent upgrade in credit rating and improved operating performance.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades SIA to ‘buy’ on faster-than-expected recovery
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Singapore Airlines' (SIA) rating to "buy" from "hold" due to a faster-than-expected recovery in passenger traffic in the Asia-Pacific region. SIA's passenger volumes are expected to reach 70% of pre-pandemic levels by the end of FY2023 and 96% by the end of FY2024. The airline's relatively promising recovery trajectory and lower financial leverage make it a stronger competitor in the region. DBS also expects SIA to outperform peers in inter-region travel and maintain elevated passenger yields.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

Willie Walsh, director general of the International Air Transport Association, argued that high inflation could be a help to the aviation industry which has taken on a lot of debts to stay afloat during the pandemic.

Proposed in October 2019, the partnership would see SIA and MAB sharing revenue on flights between Singapore and Malaysia, expanding their code-share routes, and participating in joint marketing activities to develop tourism.

Singapore Airlines is gradually restoring basic pay for pilots, after cuts that were in effect since October 2020.

site_title: Hwa Hong substantial shareholders make S$0.37 per share cash offer to privatise company
summary: Substantial shareholders of Hwa Hong Corporation have made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.37 per share to take the company private, representing a 29.8% premium over its net asset value. The offeror, Sanjuro United, aims to acquire 100% control of the company and does not intend to preserve its listing status. The offer provides a viable exit alternative for shareholders and addresses the company's internal control issues, which led to a notice of compliance from the Singapore Exchange Regulation.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: From just in time to act in time - how proactive business intelligence can fix the supply chain
summary: Supply chain departments have access to large amounts of data, but it's not currently guiding decisions. The ongoing challenges in the supply chain, including computer chip shortages and workforce availability, are having a significant impact on the world's economy. Despite years of issues, chief supply chain officers and teams should not remain inactive. Proactive business intelligence can help fix supply chain problems, allowing for more efficient decision-making and mitigating the effects of disruptions. Implementing AI-driven solutions can help supply chain professionals make data-driven decisions and stay ahead of emerging challenges.

site_title: IReit secures 6-year lease extension at Bonn Campus; sets up US$1b debt issuance programme
summary: IReit Global secured a 6-year lease extension at Bonn Campus in Germany, with a weighted average lease expiry of 7.1 years. The revised lease with Deutsche Telekom's real estate leasing unit will expire in April 2029 and generates 7.3 million euros in annual rental income. The extension boosts the Reit portfolio's weighted average lease expiry to 4.6 years. IReit also established a US$1 billion debt issuance programme on May 13, with DBS and OCBC as joint arrangers and dealers.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Concor Park in Germany. For the first quarter of 2022, IReit's portfolio occupancy was unchanged from the prior quarter, at 95.7 per cent.

site_title: Australia’s central bank says further rate increases likely
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) considered a 40 basis point interest rate hike but decided to move by 25 basis points to 0.35% in its May meeting. The decision aims to return to "normal operating procedures" and allows for a review of interest rates within a short period. This move reflects the bank's concerns over inflation, with further rate increases likely to address the issue.

site_title: Blockchain has potential to solve private market problems of efficiency and liquidity: panel
summary: Blockchain technology could increase efficiency and reach of private markets, addressing key issues of liquidity and efficiency. Experts say integrating blockchain technology can improve access to private markets, allowing alternative asset classes to reach retail investors worldwide. Companies like ADDX are already employing blockchain technology to simplify investment processes and increase efficiency. While some argue that liquidity should not be a primary focus, others believe it's crucial for market growth, with some predicting private market exchanges could surpass public exchanges in transaction volume by 2040.

site_title: Insurer LIC slumps in debut after record US$2.7b India IPO
summary: LIC, India's state-run insurer, slumped 9.4% in its debut after a record US$2.7 billion IPO that was oversubscribed nearly 3 times. The shares initially dropped to 860 rupees, but recovered about half of the losses. The IPO was priced at the top of the range and attracted buyers including sovereign funds and millions of small-time Indian investors. Despite the weak debut, the offering remains a significant milestone for the 65-year-old insurer, which is synonymous with insurance in India.

images.alt_text: Life Insurance Corporation of India shares have been priced at 949 rupees each, the state-run firm said in a prospectus filed Friday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts downgrade First Resources, lower Q2 expectations
summary: Brokerages CGS-CIMB and UOB Kay Hian have downgraded their calls on First Resources, lowering Q2 earnings expectations due to Indonesia's complete ban on palm oil exports since April. Analysts expect weaker quarter-on-quarter earnings, with lower sales volumes and higher operating costs. Despite this, UOBKH has raised its target price to S$2.30, citing higher CPO ASP assumptions. The downgrade comes as the stock has appreciated 38% in the year to date, with further downside risk to earnings projections if the export ban lasts.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

INDONESIA palm oil producer First Resources posted a net profit of US$73.6 million for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, jumping by 738.5 per cent from the US$8.8 million it recorded a year earlier.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,193.97 at the open on Tuesday, driven by gains in Sembcorp Marine and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust. The STI saw 78.5 million securities change hands worth S$109.4 million. In contrast, Asian markets, including Tokyo's Nikkei 225 and European stocks, closed lower due to ongoing concerns over inflation and interest rates. US stocks also declined, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index shedding 0.4% and 1.2%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The improving Covid-19 situation in Thailand drove sales growth in all of Thai Beverage's business segments.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts stay positive on Silverlake Axis on steady contract win momentum
summary: Analysts maintained a positive outlook on Silverlake Axis, expecting steady contract win momentum into Q4 2022. The company posted a core net profit of RM40.1 million (S$12.7 million) in its third quarter, up 3% on year but down 33% on quarter. CGS-CIMB maintained its "add" call on the counter, lowering its target price to S$0.40 from S$0.41. This follows a steady contract win momentum for the company.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrency is set to change many of the biggest industries in the world, including the banking, insurance, commerce and finance sectors.

site_title: A crypto first? What happens when a blockchain like Terra dies
summary: The Terra blockchain, a major platform supporting decentralized applications, has collapsed due to the rapid decline of its main cryptocurrency, Luna, and the related TerraUSD stablecoin. The collapse has led to a loss of economic incentives for various parties to support the chain, resulting in a significant decline in activity and a potential death of the ecosystem. With Luna's value near zero, efforts to revive the chain are unlikely to succeed, and the demise of a crypto ecosystem of the size and depth of Terra would mark a milestone in the history of blockchain technology.

site_title: Gold steady as dollar retreat offsets firmer Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,825.66 per ounce on Tuesday, supported by a pullback in the dollar, which makes gold more attractive for buyers holding other currencies. However, a recovery in US Treasury yields limited demand for non-interest-bearing gold. The dollar index fell for a second straight session, while benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields climbed. Silver remained flat, platinum edged up 0.1%, and palladium fell 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.3 per cent at US$1,815.69 per ounce, as of 12.57 am GMT on Monday.

site_title: Musk sees US as 'probably' in recession lasting up to 18 months
summary: Elon Musk stated that the US economy is "probably" in a recession lasting up to 18 months, contradicting economists and data. He cautioned companies to monitor costs and cash flows, suggesting that recessions can be beneficial for correcting misallocated capital. Musk also expressed concerns about inflation, attributing it to excessive money printing by governments, and criticized the Biden administration for not addressing key issues like immigration policy.

images.alt_text: STERLING fell to a fresh 2-year low against the US dollar on Thursday (May 12)  after a slew of data pointed to a weakening British economy.

site_title: Property stamp duty collection jumps 73% to S$6.8b; corporate, personal tax payments rise above pre-Covid levels
summary: Stamp duty collections in Singapore rose 73.6% to S$6.76 billion in FY21, driven by a hot property market. This surpasses pre-Covid levels and is 61.1% higher than FY19. The total number of properties transacted in FY21 reached 63,914, a 19.9% increase from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Property stamp duty collection jumps to S$3.2b; corporate, income taxes race past pre-Covid levels

site_title: Thailand lowers 2022 GDP outlook on Ukraine war, China slowdown
summary: Thailand's main economic forecasting agency lowered its growth estimate for 2022 to 2.5-3.5% due to the impacts of the Ukraine war and China's slowdown. The National Economic and Social Development Council (NESDC) also raised its inflation expectations to 4.2-5.2%. This contrasts with a better-than-expected performance in the first quarter, with GDP expanding 2.2% from a year ago. The baht strengthened against the dollar following the GDP data.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians outside Siam Paragon in Bangkok last month. A commerce ministry official said headline inflation is likely to exceed 5 per cent in the coming months following the end of a cap on diesel prices.

"Our export sector is strong, but tourism recovery will be gradual," Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith told an online business seminar, noting Thailand received about 700,000 visitors in the first 4 months of 2022.

Thailand’s central bank says the movement of the baht has had limited impact on inflation and the economy, after the currency reached its weakest level for 5 years against the US dollar on Thursday (May 12).

site_title: US$922m divorce sale makes Macklowe art collection most valuable ever
summary: The US$922.2 million sale of the Macklowe art collection, once the most valuable marital property, concluded at Sotheby's New York on May 16, 2022, with the final tranche of artworks selling for US$246.1 million. The collection, comprising 65 artworks, surpassed the previous record for the most valuable art collection sold at auction, with the most expensive lot being a Mark Rothko painting valued at US$41.5 million. The sale came after a bitter 2018 divorce between Harry and Linda Macklowe, with the couple disputing the value of the collection, which ultimately sold through a court-ordered auction.

images.alt_text: A journalist takes photos during a press preview March 21, 2022 in New York as Christie's announces "Shot Sage Blue Marilyn" by Andy Warhol will lead its Marquee Week of sales in May. site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after US falls
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on May 17, 2022, following a decline in US stocks due to weak Chinese economic data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.16% to 26,504.22, while the Topix index edged down 0.04%. The move was largely influenced by the US market's performance, which finished mostly down.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports growth eases to 6.4% in April
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 6.4% year-over-year in April, slightly easing from the previous month's 7.7% growth. This marks the 17th consecutive month of expansion for NODX, with both electronics and non-electronics exports seeing growth. Shipments to Singapore's top 10 markets rose as a whole, meeting economists' expectations of a 6.5% growth.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The trengthening of the Singapore dollar is not expected to have a significant negative impact on Singapore’s exports, said Alvin Tan.

site_title: US: Stocks pressured by weak China data, recession worries
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, pressured by weak Chinese economic data and recession worries. China's retail sales and factory output slumped in April, reflecting the impact of Covid-19 restrictions. Former Federal Reserve Chair Ben Bernanke warned of "stagflation" and criticized the Fed's response to inflation. The Dow Jones gained 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes fell 0.4% and 1.2% respectively.

site_title: Intel shareholders reject compensation packages for top executives
summary: Intel Corp shareholders rejected compensation packages for top executives, including CEO Pat Gelsinger, who could have received up to $178.6 million. The non-binding vote saw 1.78 billion votes cast against executive compensation, while 921.2 million votes were in favor. The company acknowledged investors' concerns and committed to engaging with them, stating there's more work to be done. Gelsinger's compensation was 1,700 times that of a typical employee in 2021, amid weak demand in Intel's largest market and supply-chain uncertainty.

site_title: US warns firms over incognito North Koreans seeking tech jobs
summary: The US government has warned that North Koreans are hiding their identities to secure contract jobs in the global technology sector, posing major security risks. North Korean IT workers pose as nationals of other countries, including China and the US, to avoid sanctions. They use intermediaries to complete contracts, and may steal customer account information to verify their identities. The practice poses risks of intellectual property theft, data breaches, and reputational harm, and is a concern for both US and UN authorities.

site_title: Singapore to restart work on Changi Airport T5 construction
summary: Singapore is restarting work on Changi Airport's Terminal 5 (T5) construction, expected to be ready by mid-2030s. The move reflects confidence in the aviation industry's recovery from the pandemic, with passenger traffic at Changi Airport recovering to above 40% of pre-Covid levels in May. The terminal's design has been revised to be more modular and flexible, with enhanced resilience and sustainability. This comes after a 2-year hiatus, during which the design was reviewed and updated to meet post-pandemic travel needs.

site_title: Another stablecoin loses peg as algorithm fails to keep pace
summary: DEUS Finance's DEI token has lost its 1-to-1 peg to the dollar, trading at 70 cents after an algorithmic failure. This is the latest failure of an algorithmic stablecoin amid crypto market stress. Unlike TerraUSD's collapse, DEI's drop hasn't triggered a broader market contagion, with Bitcoin falling less than 4% and popular DeFi tokens down similar amounts. Deus Finance's team is working to restore the peg, and the token's market value is around $63.5 million.

images.alt_text: cryptocurrency, concept, blockchain

site_title: Regional consumer prices held down by government subsidies, stable rice prices
summary: Asian consumer prices remain relatively stable due to government subsidies and restrained demand, with headline inflation rates at 5.7% in Thailand, 5.4% in Singapore, 4.1% in South Korea, and 4.0% in the Philippines, according to economists. This is lower than global inflation rates. However, economists warn that spending rebounds and commodity price increases could lead to inflationary pressures in the region.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
The analyst consensus is for tougher central bank action in the second half of 2022.

site_title: Putin warns Finland, Sweden over Nato as Ukraine braces for eastern assault
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin warned Finland and Sweden that joining NATO would not be a threat to Russia, but would provoke a response if troops or weapons were moved into the Nordic neighbors. Sweden's Prime Minister confirmed her country's intention to apply for NATO membership, while Finland also announced its bid. Turkish President Erdogan has expressed opposition to the applications, citing concerns over terrorism. The move is not a done deal, with NATO membership requiring unanimous approval from all 30 member nations.

site_title: Do Kwon proposes creating another blockchain from Terra's ashes
summary: Do Kwon, co-founder of Terraform Labs, proposed reviving the troubled Terra blockchain by creating a new network from its ashes, eliminating the failed TerraUSD stablecoin. The new network would use the existing blockchain code and distribute new tokens to former supporters, including app developers and those holding TerraUSD. This is Kwon's second proposal to revive the network, which has been met with skepticism from long-time crypto experts, including Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao, who believes forks do not create value.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on miners, energy boost; Brambles sinks
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.3% to 7,113.0, driven by mining and energy companies, but Brambles fell 6.8% after a European private-equity firm ended talks on a potential A$20 billion takeover offer. Iron ore prices pushed miners up 1.2%, while energy stocks rose 1.6% due to strong oil prices. Technology stocks slipped 1.3% and financials advanced 0.5% with the "Big Four" banks rising 0.1%.

site_title: More people flying premium class now that they can travel again, says IATA chief
summary: IATA director-general Willie Walsh says more people are flying in premium cabins for leisure trips despite rising airfares due to surging oil prices. This helps offset slower business travel recovery. Consumers have saved during the pandemic and are now prepared to spend on comfortable seats. However, a quick recovery is crucial for global aviation, which was hit hard by the pandemic. China's tightening Covid-related restrictions and the war in Ukraine are adding challenges, forcing airlines to raise ticket prices.

images.alt_text: Airlines cling to hopes for 2024 travel recovery, even with war
IATA director-general Willie Walsh says  the near-term outlook remains positive even as the aviation industry faces new headwinds, such as high oil prices, inflation and workforce shortages.

site_title: Hacker shows off a way to unlock Tesla models, start cars
summary: A cybersecurity researcher, Sultan Qasim Khan, has demonstrated a way to hack into Tesla models, allowing thieves to unlock and start cars using the carmaker's keyless entry system. The hack, which relies on the Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) protocol, can be conducted with a custom software and hardware costing around $100. Khan has disclosed the potential for the attack to Tesla and notes that the issue can be fixed by altering the carmaker's hardware and keyless entry system.

images.alt_text: TESLA is recalling about 130,000 vehicles in the United States following an overheating issue that may cause the centre touchscreen display to malfunction, the country’s auto safety regulator said on Tuesday (May 10).

site_title: Tencent, Alibaba look like utilities after US$1t drubbing
summary: China's tech giants, Tencent Holdings and Alibaba Group Holding, are struggling to keep up with utilities as a result of the country's crackdown on internet giants. The companies' revenue growth is expected to be record lows, with Tencent's revenue projected at 4.3% and Alibaba's at 7.1% in the March quarter. This marks a significant shift from the companies' past growth story, which relied on unconstrained growth. The crackdown has led to a decrease in online advertising sales, with a 15% decline forecast, and a ban on minors tipping on livestream platforms.

images.alt_text: Tencent stock soars after China ends 8-month gaming freeze

CHINESE authorities in the city of Hangzhou, home base to Alibaba Group Holding and Ant Group, have imposed “compulsory curbs” on an individual surnamed Ma, state broadcaster CCTV reported Tuesday (May 3).

site_title: Boeing’s top Chinese customer removes 737 Max from fleet plans
summary: China Southern Airlines has removed over 100 Boeing 737 Max jets from its fleet plans due to uncertainty over deliveries. The airline cited concerns over deliveries through 2024, down from a previous forecast of 181. China Southern had previously planned to take delivery of 78 aircraft in total over the period, but the move is a reversal of its earlier expansion plans. The decision comes amid uncertainty surrounding the Max's return to service in China, where the jet was grounded in 2019 following fatal crashes.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 20, 2020 the Boeing logo is pictured at its Renton Factory, where the Boeing 737 MAX airliners are built, in Renton, Washginton. - Boeing has removed orders for 141 jets from its backlog, mostly due to sanctions placed on Russia in the aftermath of the Ukraine invasion, officials from the plane manufacturer said on April 12, 2022. (Photo by Jason Redmond / AFP)

site_title: Take-Two tops earnings estimates, but gives tepid forecast
summary: Take-Two Interactive Software reported fourth-quarter earnings that topped analysts' estimates, driven by games like NBA 2K22. However, the company's forecast for the coming year suggests an industrywide slump will impact sales, with revenue and earnings projected to be below analyst estimates. The video-game industry is facing challenges from hardware shortages, inflation, and reduced consumer spending. Take-Two's shares rose 4.3% in late trading after the earnings report.

images.alt_text: Take-Two to buy 'Farmville' creator Zynga for US$12.7b

site_title: Europe: Shares flat after weak China data, miners limit fall
summary: European shares closed flat on Monday as weak China data fueled recession fears, despite a 1.5% gain in miners. The Stoxx 600 index closed flat after its first weekly gain in five, while Germany's benchmark index fell 0.4% and French stocks dropped 0.2%. Analysts warn that global economic problems, including China's economic contraction, will impact the European economy and lead to monetary policy tightening, which could hinder economic growth.

site_title: Musk says Twitter deal at lower price is 'not out of the question'
summary: Elon Musk expressed openness to renegotiating his $44 billion Twitter takeover deal, citing concerns over the accuracy of Twitter's publicly disclosed data on spam and fake accounts. Musk estimated that fake users make up at least 20% of all Twitter accounts, and questioned the company's methodology for determining the number of bots. Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal disputed Musk's claims, stating that the company manually checks thousands of accounts quarterly and cannot conduct the process externally due to user privacy concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk's Twitter profile is seen on a smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Chinese immigrant attacked US church over ‘hatred of Taiwan’: probe
summary: A 68-year-old Chinese immigrant, David Chou, attacked a US church in Laguna Woods, killing one person and injuring five others in a "methodical" attempt to inflict carnage. Chou, who worked as a security guard in Las Vegas, was motivated by "politically motivated hate" due to tensions between China and Taiwan. A parishioner, Dr. John Cheng, tackled Chou, allowing others to hogtie him until police arrived, but was fatally shot in the process. The attack comes just 24 hours after a gunman killed ten people in Buffalo, being investigated as a racist attack.

site_title: Major US baby formula producer agrees with regulators on restarting production
summary: A major US baby formula producer, Abbott, has reached an agreement with regulators to restart production at its Michigan plant, which was shut down due to a recall. The agreement outlines steps for restarting production, with the company expecting it to take six to eight weeks before product is available on shelves. The recall was initiated after the death of two babies, and the nationwide shortage has led to an average out-of-stock rate of 43% for baby formula. The FDA and Justice Department have filed complaints, but the agreement aims to increase the supply of baby formula for families.

images.alt_text: A woman shops for baby formula at Target in Annapolis, Maryland, on May 16, 2022, as a nationwide shortage of baby formula continues due to supply chain crunches tied to the coronavirus pandemic that have already strained the country’s formula stock, an issue that was further exacerbated by a major product recall in February. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Oil prices rise on China demand optimism, petrol strength
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday due to optimism over China's demand recovery, with Brent crude increasing 1.2% to $112.89 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate rising less than 0.1% to $112.71 a barrel. China aims to reopen Shanghai from June 1, and 15 of its 16 districts have eliminated cases outside quarantine areas. Despite 46 cities under lockdown, signals suggest demand will return, supporting higher prices. US petrol futures set an all-time high amid supply concerns.

site_title: Biden announces new plan to ease housing shortage, lower costs
summary: US President Joe Biden's White House unveiled a plan to improve housing supply and affordability, aiming to provide access to credit for homebuilders and buyers, especially low-income families, and assistance to renters. The plan also seeks to ease supply constraints for building materials and construction workers, and encourage state and local authorities to ease zoning restrictions. The goal is to close the housing supply shortfall in five years, addressing rising housing costs that have burdened families of all incomes, particularly low- and moderate-income families and communities of color.

site_title: US: Stocks drop amid growth concerns
summary: US stocks declined amid concerns of slowing economic activity and potential Federal Reserve policy changes. The S&P 500 traded off session lows, while the Nasdaq 100 underperformed major benchmarks. New York state manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in May, stoking worries about inflation and rate hikes. Goldman Sachs' Lloyd Blankfein warned of a "very, very high risk" of a US recession, citing price pressures and rising borrowing costs.

site_title: Rising inflation may aid debt-heavy aviation industry: IATA chief
summary: IATA chief Willie Walsh suggests that rising inflation could aid the debt-heavy aviation industry by reducing the real cost of debt. He argues that high inflation, which is a concern globally, could be seen as a positive factor due to its effect on debt. This comes as the industry has taken on significant debt to stay afloat during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Ardern said addressing climate change can bring down the cost of living – a key political theme as the country grapples with the fastest inflation in more than 30 years.
SIA first signed as the title sponsor in 2014 for 4 years, and subsequently extended it in 2018 and 2020 for 2 years respectively.
Russia's biggest airline, Aeroflot, said on Friday it had bought 8 Airbus A330 aircraft from foreign leasing companies “as part of the fulfilment of contractual obligations”.
Emirates, which only operates international services, reported a 91 per cent jump in revenue to US$16.1 billion for the year ended Mar 31 as passenger numbers tripled to 19.6 million.
Singapore Airlines' senior vice-president of sales and marketing, Leslie Thng, will take over as Scoot’

Labour economist Walter Theseira stressed that Singapore’s broader economic status and reputation as an investment destination could be hurt, if the travel and hospitality sector is unable to meet the surge in demand.

Emirates is relatively late to the market with a premium economy offering that's long been popular at many other major carriers. It finally resolved before Covid-19 hit to add the new class, a decision that's looking fortuitous after the pandemic upended travel patterns, hurting demand for long-haul business trips but boosting premium-leisure bookings.

Proposed in October 2019, the partnership would see SIA and MAB sharing revenue on flights between Singapore and Malaysia, expanding their code-share routes, and participating in joint marketing activities to develop tourism.

site_title: As Bali reopens, the pandemic forces a rethink for smaller businesses
summary: Bali has reopened to tourists after a two-year pandemic-induced shutdown, but the island's small businesses still face significant challenges. Local Indonesians make up the majority of visitors, with a few foreign tourists also present. The tourism industry, which previously contributed 60% to Bali's gross regional product, has been severely impacted, with many small entrepreneurs shutting down or diversifying into seaweed farming and fishing. The Bali government is now promoting eco-tourism alternatives, including tours of seaweed cultivation, to balance the economy and support small businesses.

images.alt_text: Indonesia sees sharp rise in foreign visitors in Jan-Feb
As Malaysia reopens to the world, airlines see healthy pick-up in flight bookings

site_title: Lockheed Martin wins US$309m Javelin missile contract from US army
summary: Lockheed Martin has been awarded a US$309 million contract by the US army for its Javelin missiles, which have been used in Ukraine to combat Russian tanks. The contracts include over 1,300 Javelin missiles funded from the Ukraine Supplemental Appropriations Act and orders for international customers. The company plans to increase its missile production rate beyond 2,100 per year. The US has already sent over 5,500 Javelin systems to Ukraine, highlighting the ongoing demand for the anti-tank weapon.

images.alt_text: “In terms of Russia’s war aims, Russia has already failed and Ukraine has already succeeded,” Blinken told a news briefing in Poland.
Lockheed quarterly profit falls 5.7% on supply chain snags

site_title: Doctor Strange 2 rules again at US box office as Firestarter flames out
summary: Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness remains the top movie at the US box office, collecting $61 million in its second weekend. The film's ticket sales declined 67% from its opening weekend, similar to recent Marvel movies. In contrast, the new Firestarter remake grossed just $3.8 million from 2,412 screens, despite being available on Peacock simultaneously. The film received negative reviews and poor word-of-mouth, contributing to its disappointing box office performance.

images.alt_text: Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness starring (from left) Xochitl Gomez, Benedict Wong and Benedict Cumberbatch

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, ComfortDelGro, SBS, IReit Global, Sunpower, Hatten Land
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported financial updates on May 17, 2022. Thai Beverage's net profit rose 20% to S$285.6 million, driven by improved sales in Thailand. ComfortDelGro's revenue increased 3.9% to S$895.9 million, with rail ridership reaching 65-70% of pre-pandemic levels. SBS Transit posted a profit after tax of S$15.5 million, down 33.5% due to higher operating costs. IReit Global secured a 6-year lease extension and established a US$1 billion debt issuance program. Sunpower Group's net profit fell 51.8% to S$8.4 million, despite revenue growth. Hatten Land's Q3 net losses narrowed to S$10.3 million.

images.alt_text: The founding members of SGListCos, an association for Singapore Exchange-listed companies, include large, mid and small-caps as well as professional services firms.

site_title: Startups could suffer deep cuts soon as investors re-rate and re-price
summary: Investors in private markets are re-evaluating startup valuations, leading to potential deep cuts in funding for mid-to-late stage companies. The market correction, driven by turmoil in global stocks and cryptocurrencies, is expected to impact pre-IPO and post-IPO startups. Investors are becoming more cautious, focusing on portfolio company survival and less on new investments, resulting in tougher fundraising conditions for growth stage startups. Flat or down rounds are expected, with bridge rounds and convertible notes becoming more common, and some investors are already writing down their portfolio valuations.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Singapore drove exit values for private equity in 2021 with Grab's SPAC mergee
Do Kwon
SoftBank Group-backed Light is struggling to raise funds after the world's largest tech investor balked at putting more money into the startup.

site_title: Princeton joins school bond wave with US$600m for expansion
summary: Princeton University plans to issue $600 million in debt to finance its expansion, including new dorms and a new campus in New Jersey. The school will sell half of the debt through the New Jersey Educational Facilities Authority and the remaining half through the university's trustees. The bonds are expected to fetch a great price due to Princeton's sterling credit rating and relatively slow week of tax-exempt issuance. The proceeds will fund the expansion, which aims to accommodate 500 new undergraduate students over four years.

images.alt_text: The Fed might have to send the US economy into a substantial recession with significantly higher-than-expected interest rates to return inflation to its target over the medium run.

site_title: German foreign minister predicts oil sanctions deal within days
summary: German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock predicts the European Union will impose sanctions on Russian oil within days. The move comes as Russia's President Vladimir Putin warned of a response to Sweden and Finland's potential NATO membership. EU members are also discussing new guidance on paying for Russian gas without breaching sanctions, which could keep European gas prices lower. Meanwhile, Ukraine hopes to be accepted as an official EU candidate for membership, with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba warning of the consequences if the EU refuses to advance Ukraine's candidacy.

images.alt_text: A monitoring instrument seen on the gas distribution pipeline in Beregdaroc, Hungary, one of several points where Russian gas crosses into the European Union.
Drivers stay in line outside a petrol station as they try to buy fuel, amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, in Kyiv, Ukraine, May 11, 2022.

site_title: Fund flows out of passive ETF strategies may signal changing investor preferences
summary: Active managers may gain traction as passive ETFs experience a decline in value, with the Singapore Exchange's ETF trading value falling to S$454 million in April from S$663 million in March. This shift could be attributed to extreme market volatility, driven by stagflation and rising interest rates, prompting investors to seek more adaptable actively managed funds. According to Stephen Dover, chief market strategist, "We may be at a tipping point" as investors face a rapidly changing climate, potentially favoring actively managed funds over passive strategies.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
INDIVIDUAL US investors are turning bearish and staying away from buying the dip this week, data showed, a sharp reversal from the frenzied trading during the peak of the pandemic.
High inflation is biting into people’s incomes and forcing them to make tougher choices about what they can afford.

site_title: Dollar firm at 2-decade highs as Aussie, yuan sink
summary: The US dollar reached a 20-year high, while the Australian dollar and Chinese yuan declined. Weak Chinese economic data, including sharply falling retail and factory activity, contributed to the decline. European Central Bank policymaker Francois Villeroy de Galhau's comments on the euro's weakness also weighed on sentiment. Analysts expect the euro to fall to parity with the dollar in the coming year, citing weaker growth and higher inflation. The offshore Chinese yuan held near a 2020 low, and Bitcoin fell over 5% to around $29,500.

images.alt_text: The US dollar saw some fresh demand in London trading after Germany reported that industrial orders in March suffered their biggest monthly drop since last October.

site_title: Asia’s insurance sector gets a pandemic push
summary: Asia's insurance sector experienced a pandemic-driven push for life and health protection, with insurers rebounding from 2020 lows. The region's emerging markets hold vast potential for insurers, with some companies introducing simpler, more affordable policies and digital solutions. Key players like Great Eastern, AIA, and Prudential Singapore saw earnings rebound in 2021, with Great Eastern's net profit increasing 16% and AIA's new business value rising 18%. The industry is expected to continue adapting to changing customer expectations, with a focus on targeted health management, holistic wellness, and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: In Rome, new food and old sites beckon
summary: Rome is experiencing a resurgence in tourism as crowds return to the city's historic center, with many iconic sites and new attractions opening their doors. The city's food scene has also seen a boost, with new restaurants and pizzerias serving up everything from thin-crust pizzas to gourmet delis. The Italian government has lifted many COVID-19 regulations, and free admission to state museums and archaeological sites is now available on the first Sunday of each month. Summer festivals, including the La Città della Pizza and Vinoforum wine and spirits gala, are set to take place in the coming months, featuring local and international artists and performers.

site_title: Asian inflation could hit highs seen elsewhere; central banks to step up in H2 2022: analysts
summary: Asian inflation is expected to rise to similar levels as other markets this year due to surging commodity prices, prompting firmer central bank action. Analysts predict inflation rates in emerging markets will exceed those in the West, with some forecasting 6-7% inflation in countries like India and Thailand. Central banks are expected to tighten monetary policies, with some countries, such as Thailand and Indonesia, raising rates only as a last resort to protect demand and economic growth. However, others, like the Monetary Authority of Singapore, have already raised rates, and the US Federal Reserve's aggressive action is prompting capital outflows from countries like Japan.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Several factors have acted to shelter Asian consumers’ wallets,  such as the more structured post-pandemic reopening of Asian economies.

Chinese investors monitor stock prices at a brokerage house in Beijing, Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Asian shares rose Friday as worries receded the United States and Iran might be stepping closer to the edge of war, and U.S. indexes hit records. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)

Consumer prices picked up at the fastest pace in 3 years in the Philippines and moderated only slightly in Thailand in April, complicating central bankers' efforts to keep post-Covid recoveries on track.

site_title: Three suggestions for the new SGListCos association
summary: The SGListCos association, formed by 20 Singapore Exchange-listed companies, aims to support SGX-listed companies through thought leadership and advocacy, the environmental, social and corporate governance (ESG) ecosystem, and corporate access and investor relations. The association's pro-tem chairman, Chew Sutat, has identified areas for focus, including pushing for higher standards of behavior, expanding the ESG network, and experimenting with new ways to engage with investors. The association's goals are still being decided, but it may help uplift valuations, raise the profile of SGX, and push regulators to take more progressive positions.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng

Responding to queries from SGX, Amara has since come out to say that it does not consider the issue - which relates to an immediate family member of one of Amara's executive directors - as an unresolved matter as it is still under discussion.

Enabling class action lawsuits could create alternative recourse for Singapore investors
Voting before getting answers: the farcical way shareholders' meetings are conducted now

site_title: Sri Lanka’s national carrier to be privatised
summary: Sri Lanka's national carrier, Sri Lankan Airlines, will be privatized as the country struggles with a severe economic crisis, including a fuel shortage and impending foreign debt default. The government, led by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, is working to ease shortages of essential items and present a new "relief" budget. The country has only one day's stock of petrol and is seeking dollars to pay for imported oil. A nationwide strike is planned by trade unions on May 18, while a curfew will be reimposed from 11 pm Monday to 5 am Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Ranil Wickremesinghe was sworn in late on Thursday to navigate his country through the worst downturn in its history as an independent nation, with months of shortages and blackouts inflaming public anger.

site_title: Hard disk parts maker Broadway appears cheap, but faces risks from legal dispute
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a hard disk parts maker, has seen its shares gain despite a scuppered deal. The company reported 17.7% revenue growth and 8.2% net profit growth in FY2021. However, it faces risks from a legal dispute with two Chinese companies over a terminated sale of its HDD business. The dispute could deplete the company's cash pile, which was S$16.4 million as of Dec 31, 2021. Broadway's shares are down 19.1% from their high due to the arbitration risk, which may already be reflected in the stock price.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Three charged with insider trading of Broadway Industrial shares

site_title: TerraUSD backer says it will compensate some users; bitcoin back below US$30,000
summary: TerraUSD's affiliate, the Luna Foundation Guard (LFG), announced it will compensate some users who lost out due to the stablecoin's collapse, using its remaining assets. Bitcoin fell 5% to around $29,700, losing around a-fifth of its value this month, amid concerns over high inflation and interest rates. The collapse of TerraUSD has drawn attention to stablecoins and their potential to disrupt the international financial system if not regulated and made interoperable. Regulators, including the Bank of France and the US Federal Reserve, have expressed concerns over the vulnerability of stablecoins to investor runs.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon
cryptocurrency, concept, blockchain
Last week’s undoing of the TerraUSD algorithmic stablecoin and its sister token Luna has ramifications for all of crypto.

site_title: China stocks decline as economic data disappoints
summary: China's stocks declined 0.8% on Monday, erasing early gains, as disappointing economic data outweighed government efforts to boost the property sector. Industrial output and retail sales contracted more than estimated in April, and the central bank left interest rates unchanged. Despite a mortgage rate cut, optimism was short-lived, with a fund manager stating it would have a limited impact on the sector and economic growth. The smaller ChiNext Index fell 1.1% and the Hang Seng Index remained little changed, as China's Covid-zero strategy and phased reopening of shops in Shanghai failed to boost markets.

images.alt_text: HONG KONG stocks ended the day higher after the Hang Seng index rose 2.7 per cent to 19,898.77.

site_title: SEA Games: Schooling wins 5th straight gold in 100m butterfly
summary: Singapore's Joseph Schooling wins his 5th consecutive gold in the 100m butterfly event at the SEA Games in Hanoi, touching the wall in 52.22 seconds. Schooling, who failed to retain his title at the Olympic Games last year, edged out compatriot Quah Zheng Wen and Thailand's Navaphat Wongcharoen. Singaporean swimmer Gan Ching Hwee also won gold in the women's 200m freestyle, while debutant Letitia Sim claimed her first gold in the women's 50m breaststroke with a time of 31.43 seconds.

images.alt_text: The SEA Games are centred on Hanoi with action also taking place in 11 nearby northern provinces.
In this file photo taken on Aug 22, 2018 Singapore's Joseph Schooling competes in the final of the men’s 100m butterfly swimming event during the 2018 Asian Games in Jakarta.

site_title: ecoWise reports S$7.11m loss in audited FY2021 results, almost twice unaudited figure
summary: ecoWise, an environmental-solutions provider, reported a total comprehensive loss of S$7.11 million in FY2021 audited results, nearly twice the unaudited figure of S$3.81 million. The company attributed the variance to potential legal claims, impairments, and accrual of professional fees. Its independent auditor issued a disclaimer of opinion due to service agreements and related-party transactions. The group plans to stabilize operations, monetize non-core assets, and explore funding opportunities.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

The strife-hit group reported S$160,000 in net profit for the period in its audited financial statements, as opposed to the S$1.7 million profit reported in the unaudited financial statements issued on Jun 14, 2021.

ecoWise EGM requisitioned by 8 shareholders to proceed on Apr 14

site_title: Deutsche Bank gets WhatsApp information request from regulator
summary: Deutsche Bank has received a WhatsApp information request from German financial watchdog BaFin, seeking clarification on how staff use private messaging tools for business purposes. The request follows indications that senior executives, including management board members, used WhatsApp and private e-mail accounts to conduct business, potentially violating banking rules. This comes amid industry-wide scrutiny from US regulators, who have fined several major banks for failing to comply with record-keeping requirements. Deutsche Bank has launched an internal investigation and implemented technical solutions to improve oversight of communications through private channels.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's net profit attributable to shareholders came in at 1.06 billion euros (S$1.55 billion), better than analyst expectations of around 950 million euros.

site_title: Ant Group completes China tech sector’s first ESG-linked loan deal
summary: Ant Group has completed the first ESG-linked loan deal in China's tech sector, a sustainability-linked revolving credit line with French bank BNP Paribas. The deal is tied to targets on using renewable energy and donating to environmental projects, with interest rates adjusted annually based on performance. This marks the first-ever sustainability-linked loan in China's technology sector, and follows a growth trend in sustainability-linked loans in Asia, which reached $52.6 billion last year.

images.alt_text: According to a McKinsey report, more than one-quarter of assets under management globally are now being invested based on how ESG factors affect a company’s performance and market value.
Singapore real estate companies and Reits raised some S$75 billion in green and sustainability-linked financing in 2021, up significantly from a modest S$300 million 2018.

site_title: Beijing students protest against Covid controls
summary: Hundreds of students at Peking University in Beijing protested against strict COVID-19 curbs on campus, with students chanting and heckling university officials. The restrictions, which include daily testing and lockdowns, have sparked frustration and anger among students. The protest, which was quickly censored on China's Weibo platform, was described by one student as having "totally destroyed everyone's normal lives." The university has agreed to make it easier for students to travel and provide grocery deliveries, but authorities are expected to "react swiftly and strongly" to put an end to future protests.

images.alt_text: A closed Li-Ning store in  a shopping mall in Beijing, which has imposed curbs on people's movement to fend off a fresh wave of Covid-19 infections.
The latest cases show the difficulty in finishing off the highly transmissible Omicron variant.

site_title: Lithium sector needs US$42b as pivot from China adds to costs
summary: The global lithium industry requires US$42 billion of investment by 2030 to meet forecast demand of 2.4 million tons per year, four times higher than 2022 production. Attempts to build supply chains outside of China are subject to much higher costs, with prices having surged over 400% in China over the past year. To meet demand, the sector will need US$7 billion of investment each year until 2028, with the US and Canada earmarking billions in grants to accelerate production of key battery metals, including lithium.

images.alt_text: CATL, the world's largest electric vehicle (EV) battery manufacturer, reported a 23.6 per cent drop in the first quarter profit on Friday (Apr 29), its first fall in 2 years, as it battles soaring raw material costs and a resurgence of Covid-19 in China.

DATA shows there is enough nickel and lithium to produce up to 14 million electric vehicles (EVs) globally in 2023, so Europe should secure more raw materials to shift away from oil faster, campaign group Transport and Environment (T&E) said on Tuesday (May 3).

site_title: Timely for Singapore groups to capture property opportunities in China
summary: China's real estate sector is struggling due to debt-laden developers, liquidity problems, and lockdowns affecting home buyer confidence. New home sales in 23 major cities fell 33% in May compared to the previous year, and combined sales of top 100 developers have halved in the first four months of 2022. Despite this, some Singapore-listed companies, such as CapitaLand Development and Keppel Land, remain positive on China's property market, citing opportunities for counter-cyclical investments and the potential for growth in tier-one cities. These companies see potential for select Singapore property groups to grow in China despite the challenges.

The Cloud Atlas residential property, developed by Shimao Group Holdings Ltd., in Shanghai, China, on Saturday, Jan. 8, 2022. site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up
summary: Hong Kong stocks edged up 0.3% to 19,950.21 on Monday, with the China Enterprises Index also gaining 0.3%. Mainland developers listed in Hong Kong surged 3.4%, led by Country Garden's 10% jump, while tech giant Alibaba rose 3% and e-commerce behemoth Meituan fell 2.5%.

site_title: Wheat soars in risk to food inflation as India restricts exports
summary: India's decision to restrict wheat exports has led to a surge in global prices, with benchmark futures in Chicago rising 5.9% to a record-high of $12.475 a bushel. This move has exacerbated global food inflation, threatening to drive up prices of staples like bread and noodles. The Russia-Ukraine war and bad weather have already crippled Ukraine's exports and threatened output among major producers, making India's restrictions a significant contributor to the global supply shortage.

images.alt_text: A farmer on tractor prepares his wheat fields for the next crop in the Ludhiana district of Punjab, India, on Monday, May 2, 2022. A blistering heat wave has scorched what fields in India, reducing yields in the second-biggest grower and damping expectations for exports that the world is relying on to alleviate a global shortage. Photographer: T. Narayan/Bloomberg
Fuel shortages are bad, but it's food shortages that cause deeper social unrest.

site_title: McDonald’s to exit Russian market altogether
summary: McDonald's is exiting the Russian market after 30 years, following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. The company plans to sell its entire portfolio of restaurants to a local buyer and will "de-arch" the outlets, removing the McDonald's name and branding. McDonald's expects to record a non-cash charge of $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion. The company will continue to pay local staff while it seeks a buyer, with approximately 62,000 employees currently working in its Russian restaurants.

images.alt_text: McDonald's, Pepsi, others should consider pausing Russia operations: NY pension fund
McDonald's, a rare holdout in Russia, has been mum on its plans

site_title: It’s a good time to think about stagflation havens
summary: Global economic uncertainty amid China's contraction and recession risk has led to a shift in market sentiment. The Federal Reserve's ability to control inflation and interest rates is under scrutiny, with three central scenarios emerging: soft landing, recession, and stagflation. Investors are positioning for the "recession" scenario, making it cheaper to hedge against stagflation. Opportunities include inflation-linked bonds, the Swiss franc, Australian and Canadian dollars, and value stocks, while betting against the Bank of Japan's yield curve control may also be a viable strategy.

images.alt_text: EXPECTATIONS for Singapore's monetary policy or growth trajectory were largely unshaken by Wednesday's (May 4) rate hike in the United States, and a recession looks unlikely for now -- though some economists still see a risk of a slowdown, independent of the Fed's decision.
