site_title: Defending champ Mickelson withdraws from PGA Championship
summary: Phil Mickelson, the 51-year-old American golfer, withdrew from the PGA Championship due to controversy surrounding his comments supporting the Saudi-backed LIV Golf series. Mickelson won the PGA Championship last year, becoming the oldest major winner in golf history. He has not played since January. The PGA of America expressed disappointment but wished him well, looking forward to his return to golf.

site_title: Macau mulls casino tax cut as gaming revenue plummets
summary: Macau is considering revising its casino bill, including a potential 5% tax cut on gaming revenue, in an effort to boost the struggling gaming industry amid China's Covid lockdowns. The city currently taxes casino operators around 40% of revenue, which is believed to be relying too heavily on mainland China. Other proposed changes include allowing satellite casinos to operate and relaxing regulations on junkets. The proposed bill is expected to be passed by the end of June, paving the way for new casino licenses and potentially easing the industry's financial struggles.

images.alt_text: Macau government extends casino licences to December
Macau gaming revenue rebounds on CNY tourist boost
Macau casino stock rally points to risky bet on China ending Covid-zero

site_title: Formula One: SIA to continue as Singapore Grand Prix's title sponsor for 3 more years
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has secured a 3-year extension as the title sponsor of the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix, starting from this year's race on October 2. The deal marks the carrier's continued support for tourism and sports, complementing its global network expansion and bolstering Singapore's recovery as a key international air hub. The event will also feature the use of renewable energy and sustainable materials, reflecting the alignment between partners and Formula One in reducing environmental impact.

images.alt_text: Formula 1's race to net-zero

Formula One F1 - Miami Grand Prix - Miami International Autodrome, Miami, Florida, U.S. - May 8, 2022 Red Bull's Max Verstappen celebrates on the podium after winning the Miami Grand Prix with the trophy and Dan Marino.

site_title: Social media sites face worldwide upheaval, Supreme Court told
summary: The US Supreme Court has been told that social media sites, including Twitter and Facebook, will be compelled to allow the dissemination of Russian propaganda and hate speech unless a Texas law blocking such content is blocked. The Texas law, HB20, was put on hold by a federal appeals court, but tech groups representing the companies claim the law would result in massive changes to global websites, costing billions of dollars. The groups argue the law would lead to boycotts from advertisers, citing past losses due to extremist content.

images.alt_text: All content on the WeChat account of Hong Hao, who is head of research at Bocom International Holdings, has been blocked since late Saturday.

site_title: ‘If economists are so smart, why ain’t they rich?’
summary: Economists often face skepticism about their financial success, with some wondering why they're not rich despite their intelligence. Five possible explanations have been proposed: economists may not aspire to wealth, they may be too skilled and end up in low-paying academia; some economists may be less intelligent in areas outside their specialty; the "efficient market hypothesis" discourages them from trying to beat the market; and many economists are indeed wrong about their ability to beat the market, as evidenced by the failure of hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management.

images.alt_text: How can this university charge nothing for tuition?

site_title: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern tests positive for Covid
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has tested positive for Covid-19 with moderate symptoms, forcing her to miss the country's Emissions Reduction Plan and Budget events. Ardern had been symptomatic since Friday and returned a positive result on Saturday. She will isolate until May 21 and undertake remote duties. Deputy Prime Minister Grant Robertson will address media in her place.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Trade and Export Growth Minister Damien O'Connor met with Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong on April 19, 2022.

site_title: London cabbies bask in ‘renaissance’ of riders in race with Uber
summary: London's taxi drivers are experiencing a "renaissance" as ridership increases, with 452 new licenses issued in the first quarter, five times the increase a year earlier. The surge in ridership is attributed to visitors and commuters returning to the office, with many opting for traditional black cabs over ride-hailing apps like Uber. The number of electric taxis on the road is also expected to rise, with 37% of black cabs now powered by electricity, and plans to reach 85% by 2025. Despite long-term challenges, drivers are welcoming the rebound in business and tourism, which has boosted their earnings and confidence in the industry.

images.alt_text: Singapore's taxi fleet shrank by almost a fifth during the past two years, government data show.
Heathrow hiring as traffic hits highest since start of Covid

site_title: Oil jumps 4% as US gasoline prices hit record high
summary: Oil prices rose 4% on Friday, May 13, driven by US gasoline prices hitting a record high and concerns about potential EU sanctions on Russian oil. Brent futures rose to $111.55 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $110.49. Gasoline futures surged to an all-time high, boosting the gasoline crack spread to its highest since April 2020. Analysts warn that a possible EU ban on Russian oil could tighten supplies, while fears of a resurgent Covid-19 pandemic could cut global demand.

images.alt_text: Drivers stay in line outside a petrol station as they try to buy fuel, amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, in Kyiv, Ukraine, May 11, 2022.

site_title: Aeroflot buys 8 stranded Airbuses from foreign leasing firms
summary: Aeroflot, Russia's largest airline, has purchased 8 Airbus A330 aircraft from foreign leasing firms as part of contractual obligations. The move comes as over 400 aircraft leased from Western firms worth nearly $10 billion remain stranded in Russia due to Western sanctions. The purchase aims to maintain good relations with lessors by utilizing an EU exemption for aircraft financial leases, which allow for the transfer of aircraft to Russia's registry to ensure airworthiness certificates remain valid. This move may also help recover lost value through insurance claims.

images.alt_text: Airbus is pushing ahead with ambitious plans to ramp up production of its bestselling A320 family of jets to 75 a month by 2025.

site_title: EQT to buy Redwood Capital in bet on US apartment properties
summary: EQT, a European private equity firm, agreed to buy Redwood Capital Group, a Chicago-based owner of 30 US apartment communities, in a bid to expand its multifamily offerings. The acquisition is part of a growing trend of property investors betting on continued rent growth. Redwood Capital has over $1.7 billion in assets under management, and the deal is expected to close in the third quarter. This move comes as soaring US home prices and rising mortgage rates force many people to remain renters, fueling demand for apartment living.

site_title: JPMorgan builds global bet on wealth of the ultra-rich
summary: JPMorgan Chase is expanding its global private-banking operations, aiming for double-digit percentage growth in headcount over the next 5 years. The firm has hired over a dozen private-banking executives from rivals, including Credit Suisse, Citigroup, and UBS, to target the ultra-rich in international markets. CEO Pablo Garnica Alvarez-Alonso plans to push deeper into European markets, including a digital retail bank in the UK, and a commercial-banking expansion. Despite recent global stock-market losses, JPMorgan's private-banking division has reported 10% annual growth, with assets under management rising 13% to $1.9 trillion.

images.alt_text: Tycoons from around the region, along with their families, are reportedly flocking to Singapore, with interest in immigration rising during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Coinbase Global founder Brian Armstrong (above) had a personal fortune of US$13.7 billion as recently as November and about US$8 billion at the end of March.

site_title: Goldman agrees to settle suit over 1MDB for US$79.5m
summary: Goldman Sachs agreed to a $79.5 million settlement with shareholders who blamed lax oversight for its involvement in the 1MDB bribery scandal. The settlement will be paid by insurers for Goldman's former CEO and current CEO, along with 10 other executives. The funds will be used for compliance activities, including anti-corruption measures. The 1MDB scandal has already cost Goldman over $5 billion globally, including $2.9 billion paid to US regulators. Neither Goldman nor the executives admitted to any blame in the settlement, which must be approved by the court.

images.alt_text: Ex-Goldman banker convicted of bribery, money laundering conspiracy charges in 1MDB case
Ex-Goldman banker jury asks for wife's testimony in 1MDB case

site_title: Europe: Stocks mark positive end to volatile week
summary: European stocks rose 2.1% on Friday, marking the first close in 5 weeks, as bargain hunting took over amid concerns about inflation, interest rate hikes, and the ongoing war in Ukraine. The Stoxx 600 index snapped its 4-week losing streak. Travel and leisure, banks, and personal household stocks led gains. Despite worries about economic uncertainty, some stocks like Deutsche Telekom and Norwegian Air rose, while others like Vestas and Casino jumped after news of potential acquisitions.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index climbed 0.8 per cent to 7,292.81 points.

site_title: Saudi Energy Minister says record fuel costs driven by refining crunch
summary: Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman attributes record fuel costs to a refining crunch, not crude shortages, citing the closure of refineries in Europe and the US as a major factor. This view aligns with his October warning, and the Opec+ coalition has stuck to modest supply increases despite high fuel prices and inflationary pressures. The US Senate Judiciary Committee has approved legislation to subject Opec to antitrust laws, but Riyadh and its allies maintain that the market isn't facing a crude barrel deficit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pump jacks operate at sunset in an oil field in Midland, Texas U.S. August 22, 2018. REUTERS/Nick Oxford/File Photo

site_title: A recession won’t be as scary as it sounds
summary: The US economy may enter a mild recession after the Federal Reserve pulls back inflation, but it will be a short-lived and anaemic growth period. The Fed's efforts to lower inflation may not be enough to control it, leading to a bumpy-but-not-crash landing. Inflation could remain above the 2% target, and the Fed may need to consider increasing rates beyond neutral, potentially leading to rising unemployment and a recession. However, a mild recession may be preferable to a severe one, as it could avoid the worst effects of over-leveraged firms and households.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the May Day Rally 2022.
Asian markets were back in negative territory on Wednesday.

site_title: US import prices unchanged as petroleum costs drop
summary: US import prices remained unchanged in April, following a 2.9% surge in March, as declining petroleum costs offset gains in food and other products. The 12-month import price increase slowed to 12.0% from 13.0% in March. This suggests inflation may have peaked, but it will remain elevated. The Federal Reserve's rate hike and bond trimming also indicate that annual inflation rates are expected to continue edging lower, though likely above the 2% target.

images.alt_text: Prices of goods climbed 1.3 per cent in April, including gains in categories such as motor vehicles and diesel fuel,

site_title: Russian inflation spikes to 20-year record on war, sanctions
summary: Russian inflation has reached a 20-year record of 17.8% in April, exceeding analyst estimates. The core rate, excluding volatile components, was 20.4%, due to international sanctions and supply chain disruptions. The Bank of Russia expects price growth to be 18-23% in December. Economists predict the peak in annual terms may be around 20% in the summer, with risks from producer prices and shortages. The central bank has begun to ease credit conditions as the economy faces a potential contraction.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with Artyom Zhoga, father of commander of the Sparta Battalion pro-Russian military unit Vladimir Zhoga who was killed in a conflict in Ukraine, following the parade on Victory Day, which marks the 77th anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany in World War Two, in Moscow, Russia May 9, 2022. site_title: Crypto exchanges are delisting Terra tokens after meltdown
summary: The largest cryptocurrency exchanges, including OKX, FTX, Binance, and Huobi, are suspending or delisting Terra tokens after the blockchain's collapse. The Terra blockchain halted its network for a second time, resulting in "no deposits or withdrawals possible to or from any exchange." The delisting comes after TerraUSD, the dollar stablecoin, lost its peg and UST trading plummeted 83.7% in the past 24 hours. The collapse of the Terra blockchain and its tokens has sent shockwaves through the crypto world.

images.alt_text: cryptocurrency, concept, blockchain

site_title: Sunac pays local bondholders after dollar default
summary: Major developer Sunac China has made a local bond payment, shortly after announcing a dollar-note default. The payment, worth 400 million yuan (S$82 million), is part of an 18-month extension plan agreed to by note holders. This move comes as the real estate sector faces stress, with global investors receiving less favorable treatment compared to domestic creditors. Sunac China has US$7.7 billion in outstanding dollar bonds and the equivalent of US$3.1 billion in local notes, and has warned of ongoing liquidity issues.

images.alt_text: DEVELOPER Sunac China missed the deadline for coupon payments on a US$742 million offshore bond and said on Thursday (May 12) it does not expect to make payments coming due on other bonds, adding to a wave of defaults in China's debt-laden property sector.
Chinese developers are now unable to refinance offshore after a series of defaults by other issuers in the troubled sector made new debt raising impossible.

site_title: Zilingo debtholders recall loan, company appoints financial adviser
summary: Zilingo's debtholders have recalled their entire loan, prompting the Singapore-based company to appoint a financial adviser. This decision comes after the company's failure to fulfill prior obligations under the loan agreement. The board, which had previously suspended CEO and co-founder Ankiti Bose in March, is now assessing options. The move is a result of the lenders' backing a probe by an independent firm. Zilingo's board statement said the lenders made the decision to accelerate the repayment of the entire loan due to the company's failure to meet its obligations.

images.alt_text: Ankiti Bose, co-founder and chief executive officer of Zilingo Pte, poses for a photograph in Singapore, on Monday, Feb. 11, 2019. Zilingo said it raised $226 million from investors including Sequoia Capital and Temasek Holdings Pte. The latest financing valued the fashion platform at $970 million, according to people familiar with the matter, who asked not to be named because the information is private. That makes 27-year-old Bose among the youngest female chief executives to lead a startup of the size in Asia. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: How novelty and narratives drive the stock market
summary: A new study by Nicholas Mangee explores how novelty and narratives drive the stock market, extending narrative economics developed by Nobel Prize-winner Robert Shiller. Mangee measures the impact of news narratives on equity behavior using text-based indices capturing uncertainty and ambiguity in unscheduled news. His research focuses on novelty information embedded in textual news narratives, highlighting the role of narratives as the currency of uncertainty in the stock market.

images.alt_text: Index fund industry: Behind one of the greatest financial revolutions of the last 50 years

site_title: What happens in crypto may not stay in crypto this time around
summary: The cryptocurrency market is experiencing a significant decline, with the bitcoin price dropping to around US$27,000, down from its peak above US$68,000 in 2021. The decline is attributed to cracks in stablecoins, which are designed to maintain a stable value relative to a fiat currency. The collapse of TerraUSD and concerns over Tether's reserves have raised questions about the stability of the crypto market. This decline may have implications for traditional markets, including stocks and bonds, as investors seek safer havens. The situation is being closely watched by investors and regulators, who are concerned about the potential impact on the global financial system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign is pictured outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York, October 28, 2013. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Lotte buys a US Bristol-Myers plant for US$160m
summary: Lotte Corp, South Korea's fifth-largest conglomerate, is buying a US Bristol-Myers Squibb pharmaceutical manufacturing facility for $160 million. The deal, expected to close by mid-2022, aims to diversify Lotte's operations and bolster its healthcare sector presence. The acquisition marks Lotte's push into growing its healthcare and biologics operations, following its country peers Samsung Biologics and SK Bioscience. The deal underscores Lotte's investment commitment of $2 billion over the next decade in the healthcare sector.

images.alt_text: Messaging app helps take off blinders at top-down South Korean chaebol culture

site_title: Philippine presidential runner-up Robredo vows to 'fight lies'
summary: Philippine presidential runner-up Leni Robredo vowed to "fight lies" as she accepted the election results showing Ferdinand Marcos Jr. won by a landslide. Robredo, who lost to Marcos Jr. in Monday's election, urged supporters to accept the results despite initial concerns and allegations of electoral fraud. Her legal team is investigating these claims, but Robredo emphasized the "biggest foe" in the election was misinformation, and she will focus her energy on combating this.

images.alt_text: The United States is seeking early engagement with the newly elected administration of Ferdinand Marcos Jr in the Philippines, although historical considerations mean there will probably be some initial challenges.

site_title: US tells South-east Asian leaders it will be in region for 'generations'
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris told South-east Asian leaders that the US will remain in the region for "generations," emphasizing the need to maintain freedom of the seas and defend international rules and norms. Harris made the comments during a summit of the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), where the US pledged $150 million to improve infrastructure, security, and pandemic preparedness in the region. The US aims to counter China's growing assertiveness in the Indo-Pacific, with Harris not mentioning China by name.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Vice President Kamala Harris speaks at the White House in Washington, Feb. 2, 2022. site_title: What it means to lead in a multipolar world
summary: Leaders in a multipolar world must create a brave space for dialogue to relate and lead effectively. The shift from a unipolar to a multipolar world has led to a reevaluation of traditional Western narratives and leadership models. This change has implications for governance and the way we think about leadership, as power dynamics are now more complex and diverse. To thrive in this reality, leaders must be adaptable and open to new perspectives, and are no longer limited by a single dominant ideology.

site_title: Auditor KPMG fined £14.4m over Carillion collapse
summary: KPMG has agreed to pay a £14.4m fine for providing false information to regulators prior to the collapse of construction group Carillion in 2018. The fine was agreed with Britain's Financial Reporting Council regulator after a complaint alleged that certain employees provided "false and misleading information" in 2 Carillion audits, including for 2016. KPMG UK chief executive Jon Holt apologized for the misconduct, stating it was "unjustifiable and wrong." The penalty is part of a larger regulatory overhaul of the UK's audit sector, which is seeking to curb the dominance of the Big Four accounting firms.

images.alt_text: The government said it would propose draft legislation to rebuild trust in audit, company reporting and corporate governance by increasing choice in a market dominated by EY, KPMG, PwC and Deloitte, known as the “Big Four”.

site_title: Covid-19 infection growth rate inches down to 1.49
summary: The Covid-19 weekly infection growth rate in Singapore has decreased to 1.48, marginally lower than the previous day. The rate refers to the ratio of community cases for the past week over those of the week before, with a rate above 1 indicating an increase in new weekly cases. Despite this, the number of new cases increased to 4,291, with 266 hospitalised cases and one death reported. This marks the second consecutive day of decrease in the growth rate.

images.alt_text: On Thursday (May 12), Singapore recorded 3,645 new cases, compared to 3,890 cases on Wednesday.

site_title: Balancing industries of the past and the future
summary: Indonesia's new three-tier green taxonomy, launched in January 2022, aims to unlock green private capital to meet the country's Paris Agreement commitments. The taxonomy applies a traffic light system: green for environmentally protective activities, yellow for those not significantly harming the environment, and red for harmful activities. However, the yellow tier's meaning is subjective and may lead to investments in high-emission, future-stranded assets. This raises concerns about the taxonomy's usefulness and potential impact on Indonesia's credit standing and climate-related risks. The system's lack of comparable emissions criteria and differing classification compared to global peers further limits its usefulness.

images.alt_text: An Asian shade of green

site_title: Spinning offers much more than a bike ride to nowhere
summary: Over 1,500 participants signed up for 12 spin sessions at the Singapore Sports Hub as part of OCBC Cycle's Spin Ride category. The event, led by instructors from Cru Cycle, featured a mix of women and men of various ages and fitness levels. Despite the author's initial struggles with the intensity of the workout, many participants reported enjoying the fun and intense yet easy-on-the-knees experience. The event aimed to promote cycling and fitness, showcasing the benefits of spinning as a workout.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US consumer sentiment falls to lowest in more than a decade
summary: US consumer sentiment fell to 59.1 in early May, the lowest since 2011, due to persistent concerns over inflation. The University of Michigan's sentiment index dropped 5.1 points from April, with a gauge of current conditions reaching 63.6, the lowest in 13 years. Consumers expect prices to rise 5.4% over the next year and 3% over the next five to 10 years. Nearly half of respondents don't expect their incomes to keep pace with inflation, and Americans' view of their current financial situation is at its lowest reading since 2013.

images.alt_text: US import prices were unexpectedly flat in April as a decline  in the cost of petroleum offset gains in food and other products, a further sign that inflation has probably peaked, though it will remain elevated.

site_title: ThaiBev Q2 net profit up 20 per cent as Covid-19 situation improves
summary: Thai Beverage's Q2 net profit rose 20% to 7.1 billion baht, driven by improved sales in its beer, non-alcoholic, and food businesses. Revenue increased 11% to 65.8 billion baht, while earnings per share rose 17%. The company attributed the growth to the relaxation of pandemic controls and the reopening of the economy. However, its spirits business saw a 3% decrease in net profit due to higher raw material costs and price increases.

Janice Lim
ThaiBev to revive unit's US$2b Singapore IPO, sources say

SHARES of Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) rose on Thursday (May 5) morning after the beer and liquor giant said it was resuming the proposed spin-off and listing of its brewery unit BeerCo on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Freehold boutique project Baywind Residences to launch with prices starting under S$2 million
summary: Baywind Residences, a 5-storey freehold boutique development in Singapore, is set to launch showflat previews on May 14 with guide prices starting under S$2 million. Developed by Baywind Properties, the 24-unit development offers 3-bedroom flats from 969 sq ft to 1,066 sq ft, and 4-bedroom units from 1,270 sq ft to 1,313 sq ft. The project joins a pipeline of launches in District 15, including Liv@MB and Atlassia, amid evolving urban living trends.

images.alt_text: City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land has launched its 407-unit condominium Piccadilly Grand, with previews starting Saturday (Apr 23) and sales booking scheduled for 2 weeks later on May 7.

site_title: Pakistan parched and pummelled by blistering heatwave
summary: Pakistan is experiencing a severe heatwave, with temperatures reaching nearly 50 degrees Celsius in some areas. The heatwave, which has been ongoing since late April, is consistent with climate change and has led to acute water shortages and a threat to health. The country's irrigation system is under strain, with the Indus river shrinking by 65% due to a lack of rains and snow. The heatwave has also triggered glacial lake outburst floods, including a recent incident that swept away a highway bridge in the Gilgit-Baltistan region.

images.alt_text: Extreme heat caused by urbanisation, global warming threatening cities: study

site_title: Reinventing Paris
summary: Paris's "Réinventer Paris" initiative, launched by former Deputy Mayor Jean-Louis Missika, is finally bearing fruit. Five years after its launch, several projects initially selected are now underway, including the transformation of the Préfecture de Paris into a mixed-use complex. The project, which aims to reinvent the city through open calls for ideas and proposals, has inspired other urban-planning programs globally, including the "Reinventing Cities" competition launched by the C40 Cities network. Missika's approach, which facilitates interaction between designers and citizens, is seen as a key factor in fast-tracking urban innovation, with the initiative now reaching an international stage.

images.alt_text: Although it is 2 years away, the Paris 2024 Olympic Games organising committee says it is well on its way to putting in place the pieces for the summer event that it hopes will draw millions of visitors.

site_title: Shanghai appears to be near lockdown’s end
summary: Shanghai's six-week lockdown appears to be nearing its end, with officials aiming to stop community spread of the virus by May 20. The city's goal is based on a three-day stretch of zero infections outside of quarantine areas, a key milestone in containing an outbreak. However, China's zero-tolerance Covid strategy is facing criticism and backlash, with President Xi Jinping's government vowing to maintain stricter restrictions despite growing concerns about their impact on the economy and public health.

images.alt_text: Workers deliver items of food to residents at a neighbourhood under lockdown in Shanghai, on May 7.
The latest cases show the difficulty in finishing off the highly transmissible Omicron variant.

site_title: Sweden sets out benefits of Nato as membership bid looms
summary: Sweden is considering joining the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (Nato) as its foreign minister, Ann Linde, said the move would boost national security and stabilize the Nordic and Baltic regions. Following Finland's decision to seek Nato membership, Sweden is expected to apply for entry as early as Monday. Nato membership would include Sweden in security guarantees and raise the threshold for military conflicts, according to a report by the Swedish government. An application would require approval from all Nato countries and Sweden's Parliament, amid potential Russian opposition.

images.alt_text: Despite Russian warnings, Finland and Sweden draw closer to Nato

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher, Twitter slumps as Musk puts deal on hold
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 233.56 points, or 0.74%, to 31,963.86. This comes after a bumpy week marked by concerns over tighter monetary policy and slowing economic growth. In contrast, Twitter slumped after Elon Musk put his deal for the social media company on hold. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 gaining 33.82 points, or 0.86%, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 185.01 points, or 1.63%.

site_title: Disconnect to reconnect
summary: The article discusses the need to disconnect from an overstimulated world to engage better. The author shares their personal experience with floatation therapy, a practice where participants float in a saltwater pod for an hour to relax. The author notes that their busy lifestyle, marked by constant notifications and social media use, has impaired their ability to focus and engage with others. They attribute this to the hyper-connected lifestyle, which can lead to multitasking, distraction, and decreased cognitive and emotional engagement. To counter this, the author has started limiting their social media use and reinstating quiet time, such as running without a phone and journaling.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies, weekly losing streak continues
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, ending a week of wild market fluctuations, as inflation signs hinted at peaking and relief outweighed concerns about the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones rose 1.47%, the S&P 500 gained 2.39%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 3.82%. Despite the gains, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq posted their sixth consecutive weekly loss, the longest losing streak since 2012 and 2011, respectively.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 233.56 points, or 0.74per cent, at the open to 31,963.86.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q1 revenue up 3.9%; Singapore public transport ridership ‘slowly improving’
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported a 3.9% increase in revenue to S$895.9 million for the first quarter of 2022. Taxi revenue fell 11.2% year-over-year to S$106.3 million. Public transportation services accounted for 79.5% of total revenue, up from 77.9% in the previous year. The company's profit after taxation and minority interests rose 30.4% for the quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day higher, with the Hang Seng index rising 2.7% to 19,898.77. The blue-chip CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.8% and 1% respectively. Despite a 0.5% decline for the week, investors remained optimistic amid market trends.

site_title: Japan's Mizuho, SMFG book combined US$1.3b Russia provisions
summary: Japan's Mizuho Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG) have set aside a combined $1.3 billion to cover potential losses from their exposure to Russia, following a trend of other global banks making similar provisions. Mizuho added $752 million to its reserves in the January-March quarter, while SMFG took $582.16 million in provisions. The move comes as both banks forecast flat net profits for the current financial year, despite a drop in credit-related costs.

images.alt_text: A man cleans a window at a branch of Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation in Tokyo, in this file picture taken January 29, 2013. Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp is in advanced talks to buy a $1.3 billion stake in BTPN, an Indonesian lender backed by TPG Capital, people familiar with the matter told Reuters, lifting BTPN's shares 9 percent on April 29, 2013.     REUTERS/Shohei Miyano/Files (JAPAN - Tags: BUSINESS LOGO)

site_title: No Signboard and units’ moratorium requests to be heard in court on May 26
summary: The Singapore High Court will hear moratorium requests from No Signboard Holdings and two of its subsidiaries on May 26. The embattled restaurant operator and its subsidiaries applied for a 6-month moratorium to restructure liabilities under Section 64 of the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act. No Signboard is seeking to exclude OCBC, a creditor of S$3 million under a temporary bridging loan facility, from the terms of the moratorium order.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
No Signboard has flagged going concern issues amid operating challenges such as the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the food and beverage business.

Renewable biomass project developer and operator Gazelle Ventures has entered into a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) to invest up to S$5 million in Catalyst-listed restaurant operator No Signboard Holdings.
No Signboard closes its Esplanade outlet just as Singapore reopens
No Signboard unit to pursue creditors' voluntary liquidation

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.61 points to 1,544.41. The market saw a significant increase in volume, with 3.166 billion lots traded worth RM2.507 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 658 to 318, indicating a positive trend.

site_title: Singapore stocks snap losing streak on Friday as Fed hike fears ebb; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% on Friday, snapping a seven-day losing streak, as investors' fears over US inflation policies eased following Jerome Powell's comments. The rally was attributed to a technical rebound rather than a structural change in sentiment. Top performers included City Developments Limited and Sembcorp Marine, while Singtel declined 2.1%. Asian markets also rebounded, with key indices in Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, and Malaysia gaining ground.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Singapore’s STI headed up 1.4 per cent or 45.42 points to 3,210.60
Asian stocks collapsed on inflation fears following the release of US consumer price index (CPI) data.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysia's Q1 GDP jumped 5%, beating projections, due to improved demand. The central bank governor attributed the improvement to the recovery in the job market, with an unemployment rate of 4.1%, down from 4.3% in the fourth quarter of 2021. Meanwhile, Li Ka-shing's family office is expanding into Singapore with 10 staff members, and investors are cautiously optimistic about the market after a brief losing streak.

images.alt_text: Other than reviewing manpower policy, the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has also made suggestions on upgrading talent and fostering cross-sector teamwork to improve manpower allocation.

site_title: UK set to axe 1 in 5 civil servants
summary: The UK government plans to cut 91,000 jobs, approximately 20% of the civil service, to save around £3.5 billion per year, amid a struggle to balance the books and tackle spiralling inflation. The move is part of cost-cutting measures aimed at reducing the cost of government and the cost of living. The civil service has expanded in recent years, and the government is trying to "get back to normal" after the pandemic and Brexit.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the open on Friday, driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.8%, while Frankfurt's DAX index climbed 0.6% and Paris's CAC 40 advanced 0.7%. The rebound follows a volatile week for financial markets, with traders assessing the impact of high inflation on the economy.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades Riverstone to ‘hold’, citing lack of near-term catalysts
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Riverstone Holdings to "hold" from "buy" with a lower target price of S$0.82, citing a lack of near-term catalysts. Analyst Ling Lee Keng expects margin pressures due to higher raw material and labor costs, but remains positive on the stock in the medium- to long-term due to its market leader position in the high-end cleanroom space.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Average selling prices of healthcare gloves have come off historic highs seen in Q1 2021, Riverstone Holdings noted in its bourse filing on May 10.
Among glove makers, Riverstone has most attractive margins
Riverstone acquires 7.4 ha of industrial land in Perak, Malaysia for RM17.6m

site_title: Nightmare on Crypto Street: Investors share their pain as TerraUSD stablecoin crashes
summary: TerraUSD, a stablecoin pegged to the US dollar, has crashed, causing investors to lose millions. The collapse, which occurred mid-week, sent shockwaves through the decentralized finance (DeFi) industry, prompting major exchanges to halt trading. Investors who invested in Terra's sister token Luna, which was burnt to create UST, have also lost significant amounts. Experts warn that the collapse serves as a warning that cryptocurrencies can crash as fast as they emerge, and investors will be more cautious in selecting their holdings.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Cryptocurrencies steadied after the woes of the TerraUSD stablecoin triggered a flight from many popular digital tokens.
UST was designed to work with its sister token Luna to maintain a one-to-one peg with the dollar.
Do Kwon

site_title: Russian shipping traffic remains strong as sanctions take time to bite
summary: Russian shipping traffic remains strong despite global sanctions, with volumes of crude and oil products shipped out of Russian ports reaching 25 million metric tons in April, up from 24 million metric tons in the previous four months. Companies are racing to fulfill contracts before sanctions take full effect, and the European Union's planned ban on Russian oil is yet to be implemented. Despite Western governments' efforts to restrict trade with Russia, data shows that shipments into Russia have declined only 23% in March and April compared to the same period last year, with some products like semiconductors and airplane parts experiencing significant drops.

images.alt_text: THE European Commission has proposed changes to its planned embargo on Russian oil in a bid to win over reluctant states, 3 EU sources told Reuters on Friday (May 6).

site_title: An imperial treasure
summary: The Skoda Octavia RS, named after Roman Emperor Octavian's sister Octavia, is a highly-regarded car offering a balance of performance, features, and practicality. Powered by a 245-hp turbocharged engine, it boasts a roomy body, excellent road manners, and modern equipment. The RS model elevates the Octavia's capabilities, making it a strong contender in the market. With features like massage chairs, semi-autonomous driving, and a solid cabin, the Octavia RS is a great value at S$207,900, rivaling more expensive options like the BMW 2 Series.

images.alt_text: The JCW Clubman busts the 100km/h mark in only 4.9 seconds.

site_title: UAE President Sheikh Khalifa has died: official media
summary: UAE President Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al-Nahyan, 73, died on Friday after battling illness for several years, according to official state media. The Ministry of Presidential Affairs announced 40 days of mourning and suspended work in the public and private sector for the first three days. The news was confirmed by the official WAM news agency, which also expressed condolences to the UAE and Islamic world on the passing of the long-serving leader.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: President of the United Arab Emirates Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan is seen at Khalifa Port during the official inauguration of the container terminal in Abu Dhabi, December 12, 2012. site_title: Tighter monetary policy right response to inflation: UK minister
summary: UK Minister Jacob Rees-Mogg suggests a tighter monetary policy and constrained fiscal policy to control inflation and ease the cost-of-living crisis. He rejects the idea of an emergency budget, instead advocating for long-term measures combined with immediate support for those affected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The City of London financial district is seen as people walk over Millennium Bridge in London, Britain, February 16, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s history on his sleeves
summary: Retail consultant Cary Cheng has amassed a large collection of vintage wear, which he believes can reveal the history of a nation through its people's clothing. Cheng, who once ran a revolving showroom showcasing emerging fashion designers, has sourced vintage pieces from private collectors, vendors, and even museums. He defines vintage as pieces 40 years old or older, and hopes to raise awareness about the beauty of vintage wear, which can be less damaging to the environment if restyled or repurposed.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Freedom on two wheels

site_title: SBS Transit Q1 profit down 33% to S$15.5 million on increased operating costs
summary: SBS Transit reported a profit after tax of S$15.5 million for Q1 2022, down 33.5% from S$23.3 million in the previous year. Revenue increased 8.5% to S$344 million, but operating costs rose 11.2% to S$324.7 million due to higher staff costs and electricity costs. The group expects rail ridership and commercial services revenue to improve as Covid-19 restrictions are relaxed.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
SBS Transit appoints new CEOs for core bus, rail businesses

site_title: Hong Kong cuts GDP growth forecast as risks mount with Covid
summary: Hong Kong revised its economic growth forecast for 2022 to 1-2% due to pandemic restrictions and higher interest rates. The city's GDP growth is expected to contract in the first quarter at 4% and then recover in the second and third quarters, with a projected growth of 2.3% and 4.1% respectively. Economists have downgraded their forecasts due to weak consumer spending, lack of tourism, and a separate outbreak in mainland China. The city faces additional pressure from higher US interest rates and a weakening local currency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Two International Finance Centre (IFC), HSBC headquarters and Bank of China in Hong Kong, China July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
While Hong Kong’s US$466 billion foreign-reserves stockpile and plentiful interbank liquidity suggest little chance of an imminent crisis, signs of financial stress are building.

site_title: Surge in industrial property supply could slow price and rental growth: Colliers
summary: Colliers estimates 25.9 million sq ft of new industrial space will be completed in 2022, with net absorption projected to grow 16.4 million sq ft. This surge in supply could slow price and rental growth in the sector, as occupiers may wait for more options. Most industrial supply pipeline projects are coming online this year, including Perennial Business City and Soilbuild Group's Solaris @ Tai Seng. This could lead to a slowdown in price and rental growth, after 6 consecutive quarters of increases.

images.alt_text: Industrial space prices rose 2.1 per cent on the quarter and 5.6 per cent on the year in Q1, while rents added 1 per cent quarter on quarter and 2.4 per cent year on year.
Tampines industrial site on reserve list triggered for tender: JTC

site_title: LIC prices IPO at top end of indicated range
summary: The Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC) priced its shares at 949 rupees each, raising 205.6 billion rupees (S$3.7 billion) in its largest-ever initial public offering. The IPO, dubbed India's "Aramco moment," was oversubscribed by nearly three times, with strong demand from local investors and foreign funds stepping in on the last day. The offering marks India's biggest IPO and the world's fourth-largest this year, with the government expecting to bridge a widening budget deficit with the funds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: LIC (Life Insurance Corporation of India) logo is seen on smartphone in front of displayed rising stock graph in this illustration taken, February 15, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

India’s largest initial public offering, which is expected to fetch 210 billion rupees (S$3.8 billion), sold 67  per cent of the issue on day one, after attracting anchor investors including sovereign funds from Norway and Singapore.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher; post third weekly drop on concerns over economy
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index rose 2.12% to close at 2,604.24, despite posting its third weekly decline due to concerns over policy tightening and economic growth. The index declined 1.5% for the week. Foreign investors bought 60.5 billion won worth of shares, and technology giants Samsung and SK Hynix rose 2.47% and 3.21%, respectively. The won strengthened to 1,284.2 per dollar, and the Kospi has fallen 12.54% this year.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index ended up 2.64 per cent or 678.93 points at 26,427.65.
Asian equities were mostly up on Friday following a tumultuous trading period on Wall Street.

site_title: Bitcoin eyes record losing streak as ‘stablecoin’ collapse crushes crypto
summary: Cryptocurrencies, particularly Bitcoin, are experiencing a record losing streak as the collapse of TerraUSD, a stablecoin, sends shockwaves through markets. Bitcoin is pinned below $30,000, with a potential record seventh consecutive weekly loss. The collapse of TerraUSD has led to a broad selling of risky investments, fueled by worries about high inflation and rising interest rates. Experts warn that the market remains fragile, with sentiment particularly fragile, and predict further declines unless a rebound in weekend trade occurs.

site_title: Musk puts on hold US$44b deal for Twitter, shares slump
summary: Elon Musk temporarily put his $44-billion deal for Twitter on hold due to pending details supporting the claim that spam and fake accounts represent less than 5% of users. This move led to a 17.7% drop in Twitter shares to $37.10, their lowest level since Musk's stake was disclosed. Musk cited his priority of removing "spam bots" from the platform, which had been a key aspect of his deal. The deal's implied probability of closing fell below 50% for the first time, indicating uncertainty over the deal's outcome.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk's Twitter profile is seen on a smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Stocks up as investors calm over potential Fed moves
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, following a Wall Street rebound after investors calmed over potential Federal Reserve moves. The Fed announced its largest rate hike since 2000 and signaled similar increases, sparking market volatility. Despite stagflation and recession fears, Fed Reserve chief Jerome Powell expressed confidence in the economy's strength. Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore, opened higher, while oil prices remained above US$107 a barrel.

site_title: Toshiba says 10 potential investors signed confidentiality pacts
summary: Toshiba has signed confidentiality agreements with 10 potential investors and sponsors as it solicits proposals on privatization and strategic alternatives. The deadline for non-binding proposals is May 30, with JPMorgan Chase & Co and Mizuho Financial Group assisting in the evaluation. The move comes after shareholders rejected a plan to split the company in two. Private equity firms such as Blackstone, KKR & Co, CVC Capital Partners, and Bain Capital are reportedly considering joint bids for the conglomerate.

images.alt_text: Toshiba, which had originally opposed a buyout, now plans to solicit proposals from potential investors in a drastic change in stance.
Toshiba's talk of privatisation leaves some analysts with doubts

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 8.64 points or 0.56% to 1,547.44. The index saw 258 gains and 116 losses, with a total trading volume of 180.03 million lots worth RM111.91 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, rising 1.45% to 19,660.66, following a rocky week of trading fueled by inflation and US monetary tightening concerns. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 0.54% and 0.55%, respectively.

site_title: Chinese developers' debt woes worsen as sales, yuan weaken
summary: Chinese developers are facing worsening debt woes due to a decline in sales and a weakening yuan. Zhongliang Holdings, a Shanghai-based company, is struggling to refinance offshore and has asked bondholders to delay maturity by exchanging bonds for new issuance. The company's sales have plummeted 55% in the first four months of 2022, and a weaker yuan has made offshore debt maturities more expensive. The situation is worsened by repeated lockdowns in Chinese cities, affecting the property market and developers' ability to repay debt.

images.alt_text: DEVELOPER Sunac China missed the deadline for coupon payments on a US$742 million offshore bond and said on Thursday (May 12) it does not expect to make payments coming due on other bonds, adding to a wave of defaults in China's debt-laden property sector.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom results beat estimates on subscriber gains, lifts outlook
summary: Deutsche Telekom reported quarterly core profit and revenue above market estimates, driven by strong subscriber gains in its US unit T-Mobile and European business growth. The company lifted its full-year outlook, now expecting adjusted Ebitda of more than 36.6 billion euros, up from previous guidance of 36.5 billion euros. T-Mobile added 1.3 million customers in the latest quarter, lifting its subscriber base to 109.5 million customers, with a stake in the US company now at 48.4%.

images.alt_text: epa09916411 Exterior view on the Deutsche Bank headquarters during a raid in Frankfurt Main, Germany, 29 April 2022. Prosecutors said that financial authorities and federal police searched the German lender's headquarters following self-reported suspicious transactions.  EPA-EFE/CONSTANTIN ZINN

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after mixed US close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, following a mixed close on Wall Street, as investors remain concerned about growth due to stubborn inflation and rising interest rates. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.67% and the Topix index edged up 0.40%.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Kimly to ‘hold’, expects lower heartland footfall amid return to office
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded Kimly Group to "hold" from "add" due to expected lower footfall as workers return to office in Singapore, impacting the coffeeshop operator's growth prospects. The brokerage lowered its target price to S$0.41 and estimates a potential upside of 6.5% from Kimly's share price. The company's first-half net profit declined 14.7% year-over-year to S$18.5 million, despite a 27.9% increase in revenue.

images.alt_text: Kimluy declared an unchanged interim dividend amount of 0.56 Singapore cent, which will be paid on or around Jul 15, 2022.

site_title: Gold faces fourth weekly loss as burgeoning dollar saps appeal
summary: Gold prices held steady near a three-month low on Friday, as the strong US dollar continued to reduce demand for the metal. Spot gold remained flat at $1,823.25 per ounce, and US gold futures edged down 0.1% to $1,823.00. Analysts predict the metal could suffer its fourth consecutive weekly loss, with potential support levels at $1,780.00 per ounce.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Genting Singapore expected to recover in quarters to come
summary: DBS has reiterated its "buy" call on Genting Singapore with an unchanged price target of S$1.00, citing the integrated resort operator's strong performance and resilience of domestic gaming demand. Analysts expect the company to recover gradually over the next few quarters, driven by the reopening of borders and a surge in tourist arrivals. However, some analysts, such as Maybank's Yin Shao Yang, remain cautious due to the potential impact of Thailand's plans to legalize integrated resources and higher utilities expenses.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Genting Singapore's revenue grew 13% in the first quarter. Construction works on Minion Land and the Singapore Oceanarium (above) are scheduled to start in Q2 2022.
RHB raises targets on Genting, sees potential upside in dividends
Tourism-dependent stocks to benefit from Malaysia reopening: UOBKH

site_title: Shein’s breakneck growth slows, testing US$100 billion valuation
summary: Shein, the Chinese fast-fashion giant, is seeing its sales growth slow to around 60% in 2021, down from an eye-popping 250% in 2020. Despite reaching annual revenue of at least $16 billion, the company's valuation of $100 billion is under pressure. Expansion in the first half of the year slowed down in the second half, with the trend continuing into 2022. Shein faces challenges including the threat of US legislation eroding its cost advantage and disruptions to its supply chain due to rolling Covid lockdowns in China.

images.alt_text: Shein's US$100b valuation would top H&M and Zara combined

site_title: Malaysia’s Q1 GDP jumps 5%, faster than projected due to improved demand
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded by 5% in the first quarter of 2022, exceeding forecasts of 3.3-4.8% growth. The central bank attributed the growth to improved domestic demand, with unemployment rates declining to 4.1% and economic activities returning to normal after easing of Covid-19 measures. Experts predict sustainable growth momentum for the rest of 2022, with some forecasting GDP growth of 5.5% for the year. The central bank maintained its 2022 economic growth forecast at 5.3-6.3%.

images.alt_text: An employee at a Change Alley money changer counts a wad of Malaysian Ringgit banknotes on 14 November 2016. The Malaysian ringgit touched a 10-month low of 4.34 to the US dollar.##########pjringgit##########MARK CHEONG

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei sees best day since late-March, led by SoftBank gains
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index surged 2.64% to 26,427.65, its largest gain in over a month and a half, driven by a rebound from a 2-month low. SoftBank Group led the gains. The broader Topix index rose 1.91% but fell 2.7% for the week. This follows a 2.1% decline in the previous session.

images.alt_text: Asian equities were mostly up on Friday following a tumultuous trading period on Wall Street.
Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, after a rocky week of trading.

site_title: Fears of financial crisis loom with mega-tech stocks deep in bear territory
summary: The pandemic stock market bubble has burst, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite experiencing significant losses. Mega-tech stocks like Apple, Amazon, and Meta Platforms are now in bear-market territory, with losses of 18% and 29% respectively. The speculative unwind has triggered fears of a global financial crisis, with some experts warning that Bitcoin's price could drop to $10,000, potentially causing a wider crisis. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and concerns over inflation have contributed to the market's decline, with regulators warning about the risks of stablecoins and cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Tech-linked shares slumped, leading the market lower on Wednesday as Wall Street  stocks suffered another bruising round of losses.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Golden Agri-Resources to ‘hold’ on Indonesia palm oil export ban
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded its call on Golden Agri-Resources to 'hold' due to potential profit margin hits from Indonesia's palm oil export ban, which could lead to higher logistic and storage costs. The research team cut its target price to S$0.30 from S$0.335. Despite strong Q1 net profit, second-quarter earnings may weaken due to the export ban, which could also lead to a 60% jump in fertiliser costs.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Indonesia's "unpredictable" palm oil export policies may help Malaysia emerge as the dominant supplier to India, the world's top buyer of the edible oil.

Markets had shown relief when Indonesia’s chief economic minister said on Tuesday the ban would only cover refined, bleached and deodorized (RBD) palm olein, but a day later authorities announced other products would be included.
SHARES of plam oil counters fell on Monday (Apr 25) after Indonesia announced it would ban the export of palm oil from Apr 28.

site_title: Emirates airline cuts annual loss to US$1.1b as travel rebounds
summary: Emirates airline reported an annual loss of US$1.1 billion, a significant improvement from the US$5.5 billion loss in the previous year. Revenue jumped 91% to US$16.1 billion, driven by a 91% increase in passenger numbers to 19.6 million. The airline filled 58.6% of seats flown, up from 44.3% a year earlier. Emirates forecasts a return to profitability this financial year, while its parent company, the Emirates Group, also expects to return to profitability.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines' senior vice-president of sales and marketing, Leslie Thng, will take over as Scoot’

Emirates is relatively late to the market with a premium economy offering that's long been popular at many other major carriers. It finally resolved before Covid-19 hit to add the new class, a decision that's looking fortuitous after the pandemic upended travel patterns, hurting demand for long-haul business trips but boosting premium-leisure bookings.

site_title: ST Engineering expects commercial aerospace’s full recovery before 2024 as Asian borders reopen
summary: ST Engineering's commercial aerospace segment is expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels before 2024, driven by the reopening of Asian borders and air travel resuming. The company reported a Q1 revenue of S$2 billion, matching FY2020 levels, with maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) demand increasing and strong passenger-to-freighter (PTF) conversion demand. Component and engine MRO capacity utilization rates are now at 80%, while airframe utilization is "very, very full." The company expects a good recovery in the second half, with the final piece being the reopening of Asian borders.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Tay Peck Gek
ST Engineering’s order book stood at S$21.3 billion as at end-March.
The gradual easing of border controls in Singapore has boosted sentiment for the stock in recent months, with share price up close to 20 per cent year to date.
