site_title: Nomura offers its first Bitcoin derivatives, just as crypto markets tumble
summary: Nomura has begun offering Bitcoin over-the-counter derivatives to clients, marking its first digital asset trades. The move comes as crypto markets have tumbled, with Bitcoin hitting a 16-month low of around $25,400. The trades were executed on the CME by crypto asset trading firm Cumberland DRW. Nomura's head of markets, Asia ex-Japan, Rig Karkhanis, stated that working with institutional-grade counterparties will allow the bank to scale into the increasing demand from clients. This is part of a broader trend by traditional financial institutions to offer crypto-related services to meet demand from institutional investors.

site_title: Li Ka-shing’s family office joins Singapore expansion wave
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's private investment firm Horizons Ventures is opening a Singapore office to find new deals and support portfolio companies expanding in Asia. The office, which will be staffed by around 10 people, aims to capitalize on Singapore's low taxes, relative safety, and expedited pathway for permanent residency. This move follows a trend of high-profile investment outlets and family offices setting up presence in Singapore, driven by the city-state's regional hub status and favorable business environment.

images.alt_text: MAS tightens criteria for family offices to qualify for tax incentives
Good move by MAS to mandate family offices to invest more in Singapore

site_title: Allied Tech receives 2 letters calling for EGM to remove CEO, chairman as directors
summary: Allied Tech, a precision engineering company, has received two letters from existing shareholders calling for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove its CEO and chairman, as well as appoint three new directors. The shareholders, Lin Tah Hwa and Kenneth Low, also propose removing any new directors appointed between May 9 and the proposed EGMs. The proposed new directors are Lim Chee San, Davy J Goh, and Choo Weng Wah. This move comes after a special audit report found failure on the part of the independent directors in safeguarding the company's interest and potential undisclosed transactions.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Allied Tech misappropriation case: auditors find lawyer Jeffrey Ong's account 'plausible'
Shareholder approval was needed for Allied Tech's China subsidiaries' disposal: SGX RegCo

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit 2-year trough as China casts long shadow
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hit a 2-year trough due to China's downgrade of growth forecasts and the yuan's decline. The Aussie dropped 1.2% overnight, losing 2.8% for the week, and risks further decline to US$0.6777. China's drastic Covid-19 response has hammered industrial commodity prices, while JPMorgan's China growth forecast downgrade and the Reserve Bank of Australia's expected rate hike add to the pain. The yuan's decline has encouraged investors to sell the Aussie as a liquid proxy, with the Aussie losing 10% on the US dollar in 6 weeks.

images.alt_text: Australian shares climbed more than 1 per cent on Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound but set for fourth weekly drop
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% on Friday, but were set for their fourth consecutive weekly drop due to concerns over high inflation, rising interest rates, and energy supply fears in Europe. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 7,018.50, with energy stocks gaining 1.9% but facing a fourth straight weekly loss. Global markets, including Japan's Nikkei and US S&P 500 futures, also rose, but investors remained cautious amid economic slowdown worries.

site_title: ST Engineering’s Q1 revenue up 13% to S$2b; declares S$0.04 per share dividend
summary: ST Engineering reported a 13% year-on-year increase in Q1 revenue to S$2 billion, returning to pre-Covid levels. Its order book stood at S$21.3 billion as of end-March. The company approved a Q1 interim dividend of S$0.04 per share, set to be paid out on June 7, 2022. This growth is attributed to improvements in revenue across all business segments.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
ST Engineering says TransCore acquisition complies with US rules
The company’s acquisition of TransCore was completed last month after regulatory approvals had been sought, including clearance from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS).
ST Engineering H2 profit increases 3.8%; to up dividend payout frequency to 4 times
ST Engineering secures over S$1.8b in new contracts for Q3

site_title: Movie critics gush over Tom Cruise's return in 'Top Gun' sequel
summary: Tom Cruise's 36-year wait for a 'Top Gun' sequel is over, with critics praising the film's 96% positive rating from 76 reviews. The movie, 'Top Gun: Maverick', follows Cruise reprising his role as Pete Mitchell, training young fighter pilots for a mission. Critics praise the film's thrilling flight scenes, emotional story, and Cruise's strong performance, calling it a "textbook example" of a well-made sequel. With projected $100 million ticket sales, the film is expected to be one of the biggest box office hits of the summer.

images.alt_text: FROM a "Star Wars" X-Wing spacecraft model to a "Thor" hammer, a treasure trove of entertainment memorabilia from much-loved movies is going up for auction in Hollywood next month.

"The Kashmir Files" has been praised by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his right-wing Hindu nationalist followers, and has proved a box office hit, but critics say it is loose with facts and fans anti-Muslim sentiment.
Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness starring (from left) Xochitl Gomez, Benedict Wong and Benedict Cumberbatch

site_title: US says has no current plans to share Covid-19 vaccines with North Korea
summary: The US has no current plans to share COVID-19 vaccines with North Korea, according to a White House spokesperson. The country has repeatedly refused vaccine donations from the Covax project, and the US will instead support international efforts to provide humanitarian aid to vulnerable North Koreans. North Korea's reported COVID-19 outbreak highlights the potential for a major crisis in a country with limited medical resources and closed borders.

site_title: Sri Lanka's new PM struggles to form unity government
summary: Sri Lanka's new Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe faces challenges in forming a unity government as opposition leader Harsha de Silva rejected an offer to head the finance ministry, instead vowing to push for the government's resignation. Wickremesinghe's administration is struggling to address the country's worst economic downturn in its history, with months of shortages and blackouts fueling public anger. Wickremesinghe has called for international assistance and warned that the situation could worsen in the coming months.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 02, 2020 United National Party (UNP) party leader Ranil Wickremesinghe waves to supporters during the party's final campaign rally ahead of the upcoming parliamentary elections in Colombo. - Beleaguered President Gotabaya Rajapaksa was set to name Wickremesinghe as the new prime minister on May 12, 2022, to try to steer Sri Lanka out of its dire economic crisis after days of violence, officials said. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Twitter executives exit, hirings halt as Musk buy looms
summary: Twitter has paused most hiring and two senior executives, Kayvon Beykpour and Bruce Falck, are set to leave the company, amid Elon Musk's looming $44-billion acquisition. Musk's takeover is expected to close later in 2022, with him stepping in as Twitter's boss. The move has raised concerns among activists that Musk would "open the floodgates of hate" with his plans to lift the ban on Donald Trump, who has stated he would not return to Twitter.

site_title: Singapore shares jump at Friday’s open; STI up 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.4% or 45.42 points to 3,210.60 at the open on Friday, May 13. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The STI was driven by gains from Singapore Telecommunications, with 5.1 million shares changing hands. The market saw 129 gainers versus 48 losers, with S$160.4 million worth of securities traded.

images.alt_text: ST Enginerring reported revenue of S$2 billion for the first quarter ended March 2022, up 13 per cent year on year and returning to pre-Covid levels.

site_title: First Resources Q1 profit jumps over 700% to US$73.6m on higher selling prices
summary: Indonesian palm oil producer First Resources reported a net profit of US$73.6 million for its first quarter, jumping 738.5% from the previous year, driven by higher selling prices. Sales increased 54.1% to US$303.5 million, despite lower sales volumes and yields. The company attributed the growth to stronger average selling prices, but faced challenges from Indonesian government policies and supply disruptions, including a temporary export ban on palm oil.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Indonesia's "unpredictable" palm oil export policies may help Malaysia emerge as the dominant supplier to India, the world's top buyer of the edible oil.

Markets had shown relief when Indonesia’s chief economic minister said on Tuesday the ban would only cover refined, bleached and deodorized (RBD) palm olein, but a day later authorities announced other products would be included.
SHARES of plam oil counters fell on Monday (Apr 25) after Indonesia announced it would ban the export of palm oil from Apr 28.

site_title: North Korea reports first Covid-19 death after 350,000 sickened with fever
summary: North Korea has reported its first Covid-19 death, with at least six people dying from fever symptoms, according to state media. Over 350,000 people have shown symptoms, with 187,800 currently in isolation. The Omicron variant was confirmed in one case. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited the anti-virus command center, criticizing the country's epidemic prevention system. The outbreak highlights the country's lack of medical resources and potential for a major crisis, threatening its food situation.

site_title: US Senate confirms Powell for second term as Fed chief in bipartisan vote
summary: The US Senate confirmed Jerome Powell for a second 4-year term as Federal Reserve chief in a bipartisan vote of 80-19, with most opposition coming from Republicans. The confirmation comes as the Fed faces the highest inflation in 40 years and is expected to proceed with sharp interest rate hikes to combat it. Powell's handling of the crisis triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic and recession during his first term was also seen as a factor in his confirmation.

images.alt_text: Prices of goods climbed 1.3 per cent in April, including gains in categories such as motor vehicles and diesel fuel,
FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign is pictured outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York, October 28, 2013. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo
The central bank has faced criticism that it is behind the curve in responding to the hottest inflation in 40 years.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Genting, First Resources, OUE C-Reit, SingPost
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

ST Engineering reported a 13% year-on-year revenue increase to S$2 billion for the first quarter, returning to pre-Covid levels. Genting Singapore saw a 17% increase in net profit to S$40.4 million, while First Resources posted a 738.5% jump in net profit to US$73.6 million. In contrast, OUE C-Reit and SingPost reported declines in net property income and net profit, respectively. Other companies, such as Geo Energy and EC World Reit, reported growth in their respective net profits. The stock market ended Thursday up 0.4% on the STI, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon

site_title: Scientists successfully grow plants in soil from the Moon
summary: Scientists successfully grew plants in lunar soil brought back by astronauts in the Apollo program, a breakthrough that could enable longer and farther space missions by providing a sustainable food source. Researchers used lunar soil collected from the Apollo 11, 12, and 17 missions to grow arabidopsis thaliana, a relative of mustard greens, which showed similar growth patterns to those grown in hostile environments. The study, published in Communications Biology, highlights the potential for lunar agriculture and paves the way for NASA's long-term human exploration goals.

images.alt_text: THE scientists who gave the world a first glimpse of a black hole may be about to repeat their achievement - this time much closer to home.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit distributable income rises 7.9% in Q1 2022
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 7.9% increase in distributable income to US$8.1 million in Q1 2022, driven by a 20% year-over-year rise in gross revenue to US$16.2 million. Occupancy levels at its grocery and necessity properties improved to 96.4%, the highest since its IPO in 2020. The company attributed the growth to cycle-agnostic tenants adopting omnichannel strategies, leading to stronger online sales.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
United Hampshire US Reit lowers sale consideration for self-storage assets
United Hampshire US Reit again extends due-diligence period for divestment
United Hampshire US Reit to acquire grocery-anchored assets for US$78.3m; proposes private placement to raise US$30m

site_title: Singapore welcomes US's proposed Indo-Pacific economic plan, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore welcomes the US's proposed Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF), a non-traditional economic plan that will focus on clean energy, supply chains, anti-corruption, and fair trade. The plan aims to be inclusive and provide tangible benefits to encourage wider participation from Asean member states. Singapore encourages Asean participation and hopes for direct US engagement with Asean member states. The IPEF is expected to be unveiled around President Joe Biden's visit to Japan and South Korea later this month.

images.alt_text: Singapore commercial real estate recorded the highest investment growth, up 134% year-on-year to finish the first quarter with $5.7 billion.
Pedestrians walk in front of the Bank of Japan head office building in Tokyo. Financial leaders from Japan, China and South Korea urged caution against heightening risks.

The United States is seeking early engagement with the newly elected administration of Ferdinand Marcos Jr in the Philippines, although historical considerations mean there will probably be some initial challenges.

site_title: Weak economic data sends sterling to new lows against US dollar
summary: The British pound fell to a fresh 2-year low against the US dollar after weak economic data, including a 0.1% decline in March GDP and the weakest rate of permanent job additions in over a year. The Bank of England may need to raise interest rates further to control inflation, but its previous rate hikes are affecting the economy. The pound's decline follows the US dollar's 2-decade high, which is expected to keep the Federal Reserve on track to tighten policy aggressively.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rose to fresh 2-decade highs on Thursday (May 12) as concerns that tighter monetary policies to tame surging inflation will hurt the global economy dampened risk sentiment and drove investors into safe-haven currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong becomes world’s must-watch market as easy money ends
summary: Hong Kong's economy is facing financial stress as investors withdraw funds, leading to a decline in the city's stock market and property prices. The city's foreign-reserves stockpile and interbank liquidity suggest little chance of an imminent crisis, but signs of financial stress are building. The city intervened to prop up its pegged currency for the first time since 2019, and its wealth fund lost $7 billion in the first quarter. Economists predict that interest rates will rise, making it less profitable to hold Hong Kong dollars, and the property market may be vulnerable to a downturn.

images.alt_text: Capital outflows fuelled by rising interest rates in the US sent the Hong Kong dollar to the weak end of its permitted 7.75-to-7.85 per greenback trading range late Wednesday (May 11).
An empty area for passengers heading to quarantine in the arrival hall at Hong Kong International Airport.

site_title: S Korea's Yoon pledges US$300 million to global Covid response initiative
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol pledged an additional US$300 million to the global Covid-19 response initiative, Access to Covid-19 Tools Accelerator (ACT-A), bringing the country's total donations to US$510 million. The pledge aims to support poorer countries in accessing Covid-19 tests, treatments, and vaccines. Yoon made the announcement at a virtual global Covid-19 summit, marking his first attendance at a multilateral conference as president. The ACT-A programme seeks a US$23.4 billion budget, but has received just US$814 million in pledges so far.

site_title: US: Dow falls again amid worries over Russia, inflation
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell for the sixth consecutive session, closing 0.3% below Wednesday's close, amid concerns over the Ukraine war, inflation, and interest rates. Wholesale prices showed a 11% increase from last year in April, but eased from the prior month. Analysts expressed alarm over Russia's response to Finland's NATO bid, citing potential consequences. Individual companies saw mixed results, with Disney declining 0.9% and Rivian Automotive jumping 18% despite a hefty loss.

site_title: SingPost expects higher parcel revenue with resumption of longer-haul flights
summary: SingPost reported a 34% growth in revenue for the second half year ended March 31, 2022, driven by a 90.3% increase in e-commerce revenue to S$619 million. The company's net profit rose 188.1% to S$48.1 million, primarily due to e-commerce growth. The post and parcel segment declined 15% to S$296.8 million, while the property segment fell 8.2% to S$55.1 million. The company expects higher parcel revenue with the resumption of longer-haul flights.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Vivienne Tay
新邮政中心（Singpost Centre）、新加坡邮政中心（Singapore Post Centre）外观。

site_title: Powell says Federal Reserve will fix inflation, calls price stability 'bedrock' of economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that controlling inflation is the "bedrock" of the economy and that the central bank will implement higher interest rates to curb inflation, which is at its highest level since the 1970s. Powell acknowledged that the process of reducing inflation will cause "pain" but emphasized that failure to address it would be more painful for the economy. The Fed plans to raise interest rates by half a percentage point at each of its next two policy meetings, and Powell believes the US can avoid a serious downturn.

site_title: Higher foreign worker quotas in tourism, aviation only on case-by-case basis
summary: Singapore has introduced a case-by-case basis for foreign worker quotas in the tourism and aviation sectors, aiming to support businesses struggling with staff crunches. Labour economist Walter Theseira warned that failure to meet surge in demand could harm the country's economic status and reputation. The Ministry of Manpower assesses companies on local employment commitment and transformation progress before granting additional foreign worker allowances, which vary across companies. This targeted support is part of the government's efforts to mitigate the impact of the travel and hospitality sector.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
ST20211018_202189826985 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix hotel guests at the front desk of the MArina Bay Sands hotel lobby on 18 Oct 2021.

site_title: US will share Covid-19 vaccine technology, Biden tells global summit
summary: US President Joe Biden announced at the second global Covid-19 summit that the US will share Covid-19 vaccine technologies through the World Health Organization. The US will also contribute an additional $200 million to a global health fund for future pandemic preparedness, bringing its total contribution to $450 million. Biden emphasized the need for continued global efforts to end the pandemic and prepare for future health threats, calling on world leaders to contribute to the global response.

site_title: India inflation surges to 8-year high in fresh RBI challenge
summary: India's headline inflation surged to 7.79% in April, the fastest since 2014, challenging the central bank's efforts to contain prices and sustain economic recovery. For the seventh month in a row, inflation has exceeded the Reserve Bank of India's 2-6% target range, prompting a surprise rate hike last week. The RBI is expected to raise interest rates further in June, potentially by 75-100 basis points, as inflation is likely to remain above 6% until September, according to analysts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as rate hike worries seep back in
summary: European stocks declined 0.8% on Thursday, reversing mid-week gains, amid worries about rising interest rates and inflation. The Stoxx 600 index slid 6.7% in May, despite strong first-quarter earnings. Disruptions in Russian gas supplies to Europe and concerns about economic slowdowns in China and recession fears contributed to the decline. Analysts expect Stoxx 600 companies to grow 42.4% in profit this year, up from 20.8% previously.

site_title: G-7 seeks to shield world's poorest from Ukraine war fallout
summary: The G-7 industrialized nations will discuss ways to shield the world's poorest from the effects of the Ukraine war at talks starting in Germany. Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock emphasized the need to support Ukraine while helping the poorest people worldwide, citing a looming global food crisis exacerbated by the war and climate change. The crisis, caused by cut-off ports and congested land routes, threatens to deprive African countries and the Middle East of essential food supplies. The G-7 aims to address this issue through support for Ukraine and assistance to the poorest nations.

site_title: Recent uptick in Covid-19 cases not a new wave, no adjustments to measures needed: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore recorded 3,645 new Covid-19 cases on May 12, compared to 3,890 cases the previous day. Minister of Health Ong Ye Kung stated that this uptick is not a new wave and no adjustments to current safe management measures are needed, citing strong immunity from vaccinations and past recoveries.

site_title: Online shopping may plateau in short term; growth to lag physical retail sales
summary: Singapore's online shopping growth may plateau in the short term due to reopening borders and easing measures, potentially limiting its share of retail sales. Online retail, which peaked at 25% in May 2020, now accounts for 10-15% of sales. Analysts attribute this to consumers' "somewhat cemented" online shopping habits, while others point to supply chain disruptions, inflation, and uneven recovery. Despite this, e-commerce players remain bullish about their prospects, with Lazada and Amazon reporting year-on-year sales growth. Certain product categories, such as tech gadgets and electronics, are expected to continue performing well online.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Shoppers outside stores at the Jewel Changi Airport mall in Singapore, on Sunday, Oct. 3, 2021. Singapore Trade Minister Gan Kim Yong said the government is committed to reopening the country gradually after reimposing domestic curbs such as making work-from-home the default and cutting the number of diners to deal with a surge in cases. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg##########knallianz##########

site_title: Biden welcomes South-east Asian leaders with energy, security pledges
summary: US President Joe Biden welcomed South-east Asian leaders to Washington, promising support for clean energy and maritime security amid rising tensions with China. The Biden administration pledged $150 million in new initiatives, including $60 million for maritime security and $40 million for clean energy. The US also plans to unveil a broader package, the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework, when Biden travels to Tokyo and Seoul next week. The visit aims to show the US remains committed to the region despite focus on Ukraine.

site_title: Geo Energy raises interim dividend to S$0.02 a share; Q1 profit jumps 42%
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a 42% growth in its net profit from operations to US$40.5 million for Q1 2022, driven by higher operating profit and lower finance costs. Revenue grew 33% to US$152 million, with an average selling price of US$62.34 per tonne, up from US$38.83 a year ago. The company adjusted its delivery plan due to Indonesia's temporary coal export ban, but remains on track to achieve 5-6 million tonnes of coal sales for the first half of the year.

Indonesia's ban on coal exports likely to have 'serious repercussions' on already challenging market: observers
Indonesia coal export ban lifted for 3 Geo Energy mines
Geo Energy H2 net profit rises to US$129.8m on stronger coal prices, proposes final dividend of S$0.05

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 17.13 points lower to 1,538.80 on Thursday, with 874 losers outweighing 209 gainers. Volume reached 3.613 billion lots worth RM2.506 billion.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Daly backs half-percentage-point rate hikes at next meetings
summary: US Federal Reserve President Mary Daly backs proposed half-percentage-point interest rate hikes at upcoming meetings, citing the need to tighten financial conditions and bring inflation under control. Daly supports the Fed's plan to deliver at least two more rate hikes, following a recent 50-basis-point increase. Her comments align with Fed Chair Jerome Powell's blueprint, which aims to curb supercharged demand and bring supply and demand into better balance.

site_title: Oil settles mixed amid Beijing lockdown fears, tight supplies
summary: Oil prices settled mixed on Thursday, with Brent crude falling 6 cents to $107.45 a barrel and WTI crude rising 42 cents to $106.13 a barrel. Supply concerns and geopolitical tensions in Europe, including a pending EU ban on Russian oil, outweighed economic fears and inflation concerns. Prolonged lockdowns in China and a reduced forecast for world oil demand by the International Energy Agency (IEA) also impacted the market.

site_title: Putin says large Russian grain harvest to support higher exports
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin announced that the country is expected to harvest a record 130 million tonnes of grain in 2022, including 87 million tonnes of wheat, due to a potentially record harvest. This increase in wheat exports could help meet rising global demand, particularly if Ukraine's exports remain low and Kyiv does not regain access to its Black Sea ports.

site_title: Keong Saik conservation market buzzing with deals
summary: A Singaporean property investor, Lim Chin Huat, has purchased three adjoining freehold shophouses at the corner of Kreta Ayer and Keong Saik roads for S$44 million. The 3-storey shophouses have a total built-up area of about 11,613 sq ft. This deal comes after Lim recently sold two other shophouses for handsome price gains, and he has also acquired the 45-room Hotel Soloha in Teck Lim Road for S$53.38 million. The shophouse market has been active this year, with 70 deals worth S$632.8 million, compared to 78 deals worth S$526.8 million in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Shophouse market rounds off banner year - 217 transactions worth S$1.53b so far
Price gains tempt some buyers to flip shophouses
Hotel Clover in Jalan Sultan sold for S$74.8m to HK's Weave Living
Row of 3 shophouses along Kreta Ayer Road up for sale with S$49m guide price

site_title: STMicro sets bullish mid-term targets, shares jump
summary: STMicroelectronics sets a mid-term sales target of over $20 billion by 2027, representing a 30% increase from this year's expectations. The company aims to achieve this growth driven by the digitalization of the economy, with soaring demand for chips and sensors in smartphones, cars, and connected devices. CEO Jean-Marc Chery expects silicon carbide chip sales to reach $1 billion in 2023, ahead of schedule. The stock jumped 3% following the announcement, as investors welcomed the prospect of prolonged growth and a potential operating margin of over 30% by 2027.

site_title: SPH to delist from SGX on May 13 following Cuscaden takeover, scheme payment complete
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is set to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on May 13 after being acquired by investment vehicle Cuscaden. The payment of the Cuscaden scheme consideration has been completed, which includes cash and SPH Reit units. Cuscaden has arranged for odd lots trades of SPH Reit Units from May 12 to June 23, covering brokerage fees. This marks the end of SPH's presence on the SGX.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
A view of SPH REIT's Paragon retail mall at Orchard Road.
SPH Reit, which owns the Paragon retail mall at Orchard Road, last traded at S$0.975.

site_title: Chinese Covid testing firm probed after reports of false results
summary: A COVID-19 testing firm in Shanghai, Zhongke Runda, is under investigation by city officials after reports of false-positive results that led to harsh state quarantine for residents. The company's parent, Shanghai Runda Medical Technology, acknowledged the issue in a stock filing, stating an investigation is underway. Residents who received false-positive test results reported being sent to crowded quarantine facilities with poor conditions, sparking fears of a lockdown in Beijing. The incident raises concerns about the accuracy of China's mass testing policies.

site_title: Volkswagen to build 800,000 fully-electric cars this year
summary: Volkswagen plans to produce 800,000 fully-electric cars worldwide this year and 1.3 million in 2023, aiming to make half its global output all-electric by 2030. Despite challenging production conditions, the company expects to meet European emissions targets this year. Its sales chief, Hildegard Wortmann, also expressed optimism about electric car sales rising despite total deliveries falling. Additionally, Volkswagen's CEO, Herbert Diess, considers the timing ideal for an initial public offering (IPO) of Porsche, planned for the fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on rate hike worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 12, led by growth stocks, due to concerns about aggressive interest rate hikes potentially tipping the economy into recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.42%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.79%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.45%. Investors worry that high inflation and rate hikes could lead to a recession, despite recent records set by the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 11, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: US mortgage rates rise to 5.3%, highest level since July 2009
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 5.3%, the highest level since July 2009, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the second consecutive week of increases, shutting out some would-be homebuyers from the market. The rate climb follows a recent surge in 10-year Treasuries, driven by rising US consumer prices and the Federal Reserve's efforts to contain inflation.

site_title: Ranil Wickremesinghe: Sri Lanka's new, and old, PM
summary: Ranil Wickremesinghe, Sri Lanka's 73-year-old prime minister, was sworn in for the sixth time on May 12, replacing Mahinda Rajapaksa who resigned after his supporters attacked anti-government demonstrators. Wickremesinghe's return to office comes as the country faces a crippling economic crisis, with a $51 billion foreign debt and no money to import essential goods. He has warned of high inflation and hyperinflation, and will need to navigate complex bailout negotiations with the International Monetary Fund and foreign creditors.

images.alt_text: “I took on this responsibility with expectations that political stability will be established,” Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said at a briefing in Colombo on Wednesday. “It’s been more than a month with no progress. I do not wish to continue in this post if political stability is not achieved.”
The mooted new premier, Ranil Wickremesinghe (in this 2020 file photo), has already served in the office 5 times.

site_title: F&N to switch to sustainable packaging produced by its subsidiary
summary: F&N, a drinks manufacturer, plans to switch its packaging to sustainable alternatives produced by its indirect subsidiary, Print Lab. The Green Lab, a new eco-friendly manufacturing facility, will produce plastic bag substitutes made from cassava roots, recyclable paper bags, and compostable food packaging. The facility, launched in Singapore, aims to produce up to 250 million Kraft paper bags and 25-50 million cassava bags annually. F&N plans to switch to recyclable materials for more than 90% of its packaging, citing consumer preference and cost-effectiveness of made-in-Singapore packaging.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Beverage revenue from external sales was up by 15.3 per cent to S$288.5 million for the period, which buoyed the profitability in this segment, especially as beer profits more than doubled.
F&N Q1 net profit down 10.9% to S$40.2m
F&N announces CEO appointment and other leadership changes

site_title: Biggest stablecoin loses US dollar peg as crypto anxiety spreads
summary: Tether, the largest stablecoin, briefly dropped to its lowest level since December 2020 due to the collapse of TerraUSD, causing crypto anxiety to spread. The price slipped to 94.55 US cents before recovering to 98 US cents. Despite this, Tether's chief technology officer assured investors that they can continue to redeem tokens at a 1-to-1 value to the US dollar. The drop highlights the overall risk-off mood in crypto markets, with more than US$200 billion wiped from the market in 24 hours.

site_title: EC World Reit’s Q1 DPU down 9.7% despite rise in property income
summary: EC World Reit's Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) declined 9.7% to 1.383 Singapore cents, despite a 7.4% increase in net property income to S$29.7 million and a 4.4% rise in gross revenue to S$32.2 million. The decline was mainly due to withholding tax expenses and provision for pre-termination compensation. Distributions are expected to be made on June 29, with the Reit aiming to distribute at least 90% of its distributable amount.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
EC World Reit able to refinance loans, continue as going concern, says manager

site_title: JLR owner Tata Motors posts smaller March-quarter loss as demand improves
summary: Tata Motors, owner of Jaguar Land Rover, reported a smaller loss for the fourth quarter due to improving demand for its vehicles and cost management. The company benefited from rising demand despite rising raw material and shipping costs. Tata Motors has hiked prices at least four times in fiscal year 2022. The improved financial performance suggests a recovery from the pandemic's impact on the automotive industry.

site_title: So-cal so-so at California Republic
summary: California Republic, a Southern Californian Italian eatery in Singapore, boasts a stylish interior but falls short on substance. The menu features a small selection of Italian dishes, including baked stuffed clams, grilled oysters, and smoked bucatini, with some standout options like the smoked bucatini in pork ragu. However, the service is well-meaning but not polished, and the concept feels arbitrary and unconvincing. The restaurant's attempt to recreate a SoCal state of mind is admirable, but it ultimately feels like a shallow imitation. Rating: 6/10.

images.alt_text: California dream needs a shot of reality at Rosemead

site_title: SIA’s Leslie Thng named Scoot new CEO, Campbell Wilson quits to helm Air India
summary: Singapore Airlines named Leslie Thng, its senior vice-president of sales and marketing, as the new CEO of Scoot, replacing Campbell Wilson who resigned to join Air India on June 15. Wilson's last day at Scoot is on the same day Thng will take over as Scoot's chief executive on June 16.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

Proposed in October 2019, the partnership would see SIA and MAB sharing revenue on flights between Singapore and Malaysia, expanding their code-share routes, and participating in joint marketing activities to develop tourism.

Scoot to offer S$200 VTL flights to Australia
Singapore Airlines is gradually restoring basic pay for pilots, after cuts that were in effect since October 2020.
Singapore Airlines should disclose impact of sustainable fuel adoption

site_title: US producer prices rise more than forecast in sign of persistent inflation
summary: US producer prices rose 1.3% in April, exceeding forecasts and indicating persistent inflation. The producer price index (PPI) increased 11% from last year and 0.5% from the prior month. Core PPI, excluding volatile food and energy components, rose 0.4% monthly and 8.8% year-over-year. The Federal Reserve is likely to maintain aggressive rate hikes due to elevated consumer inflation.

images.alt_text: There were a record 11.5 million job openings on the last day of March.

site_title: Sustainable bond issuance likely flat in 2022 amid headwinds: Moody’s ESG Solutions
summary: Moody's ESG Solutions expects sustainable bond issuance to be flat in 2022 due to market headwinds, with a revised forecast of around $1 trillion in issuance, down from the original estimate of $1.35 trillion. Despite this, the team anticipates growth to resume in the second half of 2022, driven by issuers' need to meet ESG-related key performance indicators and a growing focus on environmental and social objectives. Long-term growth drivers remain strong, driven by climate mitigation and adaptation financing, regulatory attention, and decarbonization efforts.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
About 20 per cent of the top 50 listed companies by market capitalisation in Singapore disclose the linkage of ESG performance to the remuneration of their top executives.

Chinese companies have long turned to Hong Kong for foreign-currency borrowings. This now includes a corner of the green-debt market that's helping to stanch the city's overall slowdown in corporate lending.
Most regions saw a slump in sustainable fund inflows in Q1, except for Canada and Asia ex-Japan.

site_title: Chainalysis bags US$170m in Series F funds led by GIC
summary: Chainalysis, a blockchain data platform, has raised $170 million in its Series F funding round led by Singapore's GIC, doubling its valuation to $8.6 billion. The funding will be used to invest in product innovation and scale global operations. Chainalysis has seen a 75% expansion in customer count, with 700 employees, including recent executive-level hires. The company is looking to deepen its relationship with GIC to expand its business in the Asia-Pacific region, citing its unique position in the crypto space due to its stable business model and increasing demand for trust and safety.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Crypto money laundering rises 30% in 2021, says Chainalysis
Dapper, Chainalysis partner to better monitor platform activity

site_title: ECB rates likely positive by early next year: official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to raise interest rates back above zero by early 2023 to combat record euro-area inflation, according to Governing Council member Gabriel Makhlouf. This move would be a first rate hike in over a decade, following the end of net bond-buying "next month or in July." Makhlouf emphasized the need for data-dependent policy decisions and flexibility, as the ECB calibrates its policies to combat inflation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has made suggestions to improve manpower allocation by upgrading talent and fostering cross-sector teamwork. The SBF also calls for a more nuanced approach in classifying business activities in the services sector to allow for finer-grained treatment in foreign manpower policy. Meanwhile, Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 2% dip in new business premiums, and the city-state faces a taxi shortage as pandemic restrictions are lifted.

images.alt_text: Olivia Lum Ooi Lin could be asked to make compensation if the plaintiffs in the pre-emptive lawsuit proceed with the claims.

site_title: TerraUSD stablecoins collapse, MAS reiterates crypto warning
summary: TerraUSD, a stablecoin pegged to the US dollar, has lost over 70% of its value in days, sparking concerns over the stability of other stablecoins, including Tether, USD Coin, and Binance Coin. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reiterated its warning on the risks of trading in cryptocurrencies, citing their volatility and lack of economic fundamentals. The collapse has led to a review of regulatory approaches towards stablecoins and has raised concerns about the ability of these stablecoins to cover investor withdrawals. The Singapore-based Luna Foundation Guard is seeking to raise $1.5 billion to shore up the UST token.

site_title: UK consumer spending rebounded last week, ONS says
summary: UK consumer spending on credit and debit cards rebounded last week after a dip around the Easter holidays, according to the Office for National Statistics. This rebound is attributed to growing restaurant reservations. The card spending figures are not adjusted for seasonality or inflation.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise; monthly producer price gains slow
summary: US jobless claims rose to 203,000, the highest since February, as initial claims increased 1,000 from the previous week. Despite this, labor market conditions remain strong with a record 11.5 million job openings in March and 428,000 payrolls added in April. The Federal Reserve's rate hike aims to balance demand and supply, while producer price index (PPI) gains slowed to 0.5% in April, down from 1.6% in March.

site_title: Consumer, construction and O&G stocks among RHB’s top picks amid gradual economic recovery
summary: RHB Bank has identified consumer spending, construction, and oil and gas (O&G) sectors as top picks for 2022, amid a gradual economic recovery. Analysts expect small-cap stocks to outperform the Straits Times Index, driven by factors such as rising interest from institutional investors and strong retail participation. Consumer stocks, including companies like G.H.Y. Culture & Media and Hotel Grand Central, are expected to benefit from vaccination and travel resumption.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Ascott Residence Trust has been one of the key beneficiaries of Singapore's reopening.
The Chinese cities which Singapore imports most of its food supplies from are not currently classified as high-risk ones, Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling said in Parliament.

site_title: North Korea fires 3 ballistic missiles ahead of Biden visit
summary: North Korea fired three short-range ballistic missiles near Pyongyang towards its east coast ahead of US President Joe Biden's visit to the region next week. This is the third launch this month and follows a lockdown ordered by leader Kim Jong Un after the country's first reported case of Covid-19. The launch was detected by Japan's defense ministry and is seen as a test of South Korea's new President Yoon Suk Yeol's tough line with North Korea.

images.alt_text: Yoon, 61, will face 2 major problems as he takes office: a belligerent North Korea testing new weapons and inflation threatening to undermine an economic recovery from 2 years of Covid-19 gloom.

site_title: Proposed tax cut not likely to boost Malaysia’s palm oil exports by much: analysts
summary: Malaysia plans to reduce its export tax on palm oil to 4-6% and slow the implementation of its biodiesel mandate to boost exports amid the global edible oil shortage. However, analysts say these measures will not significantly impact the country's palm oil industry unless the government resolves the sector's labor shortages, which have caused losses of up to RM20 billion in revenue. Industry players emphasize the need to increase production and bring in more foreign workers to meet global demand.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA'S commodities ministry has proposed cutting the export tax on palm oil by as much as half to help fill a global edible oil shortage and grow the market share of the world's second-largest palm oil producer.
Indonesia's "unpredictable" palm oil export policies may help Malaysia emerge as the dominant supplier to India, the world's top buyer of the edible oil.

site_title: US retail investors turn bearish and elusive in latest selloff
summary: US retail investors have turned bearish and sold $1.9 billion worth of shares in the last two days, marking the largest 2-day outflow in 14 months. This reverses their role as net buyers of equities last week, when they notched the highest level ever recorded on May 5. Rising borrowing costs, high inflation, and slowing growth have intensified market volatility. Retail investors now account for only 12% of total share volume, down from 20% at the peak in January 2021.

site_title: Crypto crash: What happened to Luna and UST?
summary: Terra's algorithmic stablecoin experiment, TerraUSD (UST), collapsed in May 2022, leaving investors with significant losses. Designed to maintain a one-to-one peg with the dollar alongside its sister token Luna, UST was supposed to work by selling Luna when its value rose and buying it back when it fell. However, the experiment failed, resulting in a loss of nearly $40 billion in investor funds. The exact reasons behind the collapse remain unclear, sparking speculation and potential investigations.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit net property income slumps 21.5% in Q1
summary: OUE Commercial Reit's net property income fell 21.5% to S$48 million in Q1 due to the deconsolidation of OUE Bayfront's performance. Revenue dropped 20.3% to S$59.5 million, and the amount available for distribution shrank 15.8% to S$31.2 million. Committed occupancy in the commercial segment decreased 0.3 percentage points to 91.2%, while office occupancy in Singapore eased 0.4 percentage points to 90.8%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on May 12, 2022, following Wall Street falls due to concerns over inflation and US monetary tightening. The Hang Seng Index dropped 2.24% to 19,380.34, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.12% to 3,054.99.

site_title: IPhone maker Hon Hai’s profit beats estimates
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer and Apple's biggest assembly partner, posted earnings ahead of estimates with net income of NT$29.5 billion and revenue of NT$1.41 trillion for the quarter till March. Despite component shortages and strict pandemic controls across China, Hon Hai managed to keep production running by employing closed-loop production sites. The company expects revenue to remain little changed this quarter and anticipates strong growth in cloud and networking products, with a focus on electric vehicles, aiming for 5% market share in 2025.

images.alt_text: iPhone assembler Hon Hai says component shortages are easing

site_title: Genting Singapore Q1 earnings grow 17%, expects leisure travel recovery to moderate
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 17% increase in net profit to S$40.4 million for the first quarter, driven by a 13% revenue growth to S$314.5 million. Despite encouraging footfall to Resorts World Sentosa, the leisure travel recovery is expected to moderate due to limited flight schedules and travel restrictions. The company is investing in new visitor offerings, including Minion Land and the Singapore Oceanarium, and renovation works to strengthen its position as a business-leisure destination.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Brokers' take: RHB raises targets on Genting, sees potential upside in dividends

Genting's Asean-listed gaming stocks 'set for winning streak' and higher dividend yields: UOBKH
Genting Singapore H2 profit falls 49%; details of RWS expansion unveiled

site_title: An experimental home office
summary: Interior designer Kelvin Teo has converted a 1,900 sq ft terrace house in Macpherson, Singapore, into a unique home office for his design firm, Space Sense Studio. The space, which shares the house with a few colleagues, features a contemporary design with natural light, glass doors, and a glass roof. The ground floor serves as a showcase of design ideas, with a dining area, kitchen, and bathroom that demonstrate the concept of blending functionality with aesthetics. The second floor houses the firm's office and a loft area that can be used as a weekend home, making it an ideal space for clients to see design concepts in action.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Room to experiment

site_title: Singapore stocks dive on US inflation worries; STI tumbles 1.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.9% on Thursday, closing at 3,165.18, due to Asian markets' decline on US inflation fears. The US consumer price index (CPI) data showed a 0.2% monthly dip but a 8.3% year-over-year rise, raising concerns about inflation. Asian markets, including Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Japan's Nikkei 225, also fell. The STI is currently retesting a downward trendline, with potential further downside to 3,100.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
US consumer prices slow in April; inflation still high

site_title: BOE’s Ramsden says inflation risks mean more rate hikes needed
summary: The Bank of England's deputy governor, Dave Ramsden, warns that inflation risks mean more interest rate hikes are needed to control surging prices. Inflation is expected to top 10% later this year, and the economy is on track to shrink due to double-digit inflation. The BOE has already raised interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis, and Ramsden says further hikes are necessary to mitigate the economic impact. The jobs market could prove stronger than anticipated, fueling more persistent price gains.

images.alt_text: Britain is on course to enter a technical recession in the second half of this year and faces a big hit to living standards from surging prices, an economic think-tank said on Wednesday.

site_title: From the land of bold reds: 10 superb Spanish whites
summary: Eric Asimov, a wine expert, highlights the often-overlooked world of Spanish white wines. Despite Spain's association with red wines, Asimov discovered a range of unusual and captivating white wines across the country. He recommends 10 bottles from various regions, including Rías Baixas, Priorat, Galicia, and the Canary Islands. The wines are made from unique grape varieties such as albariño, palomino, and treixadura, and are characterized by their minerality, complexity, and aging potential. Asimov praises the combination of traditional winemaking techniques and modern approaches, resulting in distinctive wines that showcase Spain's diverse wine culture.

images.alt_text: New wines from old Spanish vines

site_title: 20% growth in Asia-Pacific real estate investment growth in Q1: JLL
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investment growth increased by 20% in Q1, driven by significant gains in Singapore, where commercial real estate saw a 134% year-on-year growth to US$5.7 billion in investments. This surge was largely attributed to large transactions in office and retail spaces.

images.alt_text: Purchases of non-landed private homes by foreign buyers picked up in April with 93 transactions, up from 51 units in March.

site_title: Telkom Indonesia-owned MDI Ventures, Bio Farma launch biotech, healthcare fund
summary: MDI Ventures, a venture capital firm owned by Telkom Indonesia, and Bio Farma, an Indonesian state-owned pharmaceutical company, have launched the Bio-Health Fund, a US$20 million early and growth-stage investment fund for biotechnology and healthcare startups. Bio Farma will act as a limited partner, leveraging its capabilities as a pharmaceutical manufacturer and healthcare provider in Indonesia. The fund aims to form a national health ecosystem, with the ultimate goal of innovating life science products and healthtech solutions applicable to the Indonesian market.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: US marks 1 million Covid deaths, early epicentre New York seeks to move on
summary: The US has reached 1 million Covid-19 deaths, according to the White House. President Joe Biden acknowledged the "unrelenting" pain of those who lost loved ones during the pandemic, calling for continued vigilance and funding for testing, vaccines, and treatments. Cities like New York, which was the epicentre of the virus, are trying to move on from the pandemic, with life largely returning to normal. However, concerns remain about another surge, particularly among unvaccinated and lower-income populations, and the US is seeing an uptick in daily virus cases due to the new Omicron subvariant.

site_title: Chinese developer Sunac misses bond repayment, expects to miss more
summary: Chinese property developer Sunac China missed a US$742 million offshore bond payment and does not expect to make payments on other bonds, adding to a wave of defaults in the country's debt-laden property sector. The company is considering a restructuring of its offshore debt and exploring strategic investments. Sunac's missed payment comes as the sector faces pressure from Covid-related lockdowns, a weakening yuan, and increased liquidity issues. The company's shares have been suspended pending the release of its financial statements, and analysts warn that more developers may miss their upcoming obligations or need to do bond exchanges.

site_title: Managing the data that comes with healthcare innovation
summary: Healthcare data management is crucial in Southeast Asia, where population growth rates are rising and demand for healthcare services is increasing. Cybersecurity breaches have become a significant concern, with 45.67 million patient records exposed in the US in 2021. Implementing verifiable credentials, which are tamper-proof and secure, can help automate workflows and ensure patient data privacy. Over 900 health clinics and labs in Southeast Asia are already using digital platforms to verify and exchange health data, leading to cost savings and improved efficiency.

images.alt_text: Cyberthreats will only grow in prominence and threat actors will become more emboldened.

site_title: Moody’s changes outlook on ART, FHT to stable; affirms Baa3 ratings
summary: Moody's has changed its outlook on Ascott Residence Trust (ART) and Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) to "stable" from "negative", affirming their Baa3 ratings. The agency expects both trusts to benefit from the resumption of leisure and business travel as movement restrictions ease. ART's credit metrics are expected to improve due to its financially prudent investments in longer-stay accommodation, while FHT's credit metrics are expected to improve in the next 18 months due to a recovery in operating performance and asset divestment. The outlook change reflects an improvement in liquidity and asset diversification for both trusts.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
HOSPITALITY trust Ascott Residence Trust (ART) said its portfolio revenue per available unit (RevPAU) rose 22 per cent on year to S$67 for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, from S$55 a year ago.

site_title: Europe: Stocks tumble at open
summary: European stocks plummeted at the start of trading on May 12, 2022, due to high inflation concerns. London's FTSE 100 index fell 1.9%, while Frankfurt's DAX index dropped 2.2% and Paris' CAC 40 retreated 2.4%. The declines followed sharp overnight falls in Asia and on Wall Street.

site_title: Good inflation news from the bond market
summary: The US bond market expects inflation to average 2.5% between 5-10 years from now, which is the rate needed to equalize returns on inflation-indexed and non-indexed US Treasury securities. This rate is higher than the Fed's 2% target and may require significantly higher interest rates to return inflation to its target. However, the Fed's current policy has enabled a rapid recovery from the pandemic-induced recession, and some experts argue that the expected higher inflation is a small price to pay for the economic transformation it brings.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 4.29 points, or 0.17 per cent, to 2,592.27, after falling as much as 0.67 per cent.

site_title: UK estate agents see inflation calming housing market frenzy
summary: UK estate agents expect the cost of living crisis and Bank of England rate increases to calm the housing market frenzy. Despite a shortage of homes for sale, forward-looking indicators softened, with agents predicting sales to fall and prices to rise less strongly than anticipated. Mortgage lenders have raised interest rates, adding to household budget pressure. The housing market is expected to lose momentum, but limited supply and steady demand growth are expected to drive house prices, with modest declines predicted over the coming year.

images.alt_text: Previously published figures from mortgage lender Nationwide showed the annual rate of house price increase slowed to 12.1 per cent in March from an 18-year high of 14.3 per cent in March.
Britain is facing a unique inflation shock with price pressures coming from every angle, according to former Bank of England rate-setter Kristin Forbes (above).

site_title: Cryptocurrencies drop anew as TerraUSD’s woes cloud outlook
summary: Cryptocurrencies experienced a decline as the collapse of TerraUSD's stablecoin triggered a flight from popular digital tokens. Bitcoin fell 6.1% to below $27,000, while Ether slid 12%. The collapse of TerraUSD has impacted the crypto market, with investors questioning the stability of money-market funds. Elevated US inflation and interest-rate hikes also contribute to the market's fragility. Despite some investors advising patience, the crypto sector is nursing heavy losses for the week, with the overall market sentiment remaining fragile.

images.alt_text: UST was designed to work with its sister token Luna to maintain a one-to-one peg with the dollar.

site_title: Ford makes U-turn, shelves plans for EV exports from India
summary: Ford Motor has dropped plans to manufacture electric vehicles in India for exports, reversing a decision made in February. The US car maker had received approval for the Indian government's $3.5-billion production-linked incentive scheme for clean-fuel vehicles. Ford's two factories in India, which stopped production last year, will now be explored for alternative options. The company cited a "careful review" for the decision, which was made after initially committing to EV manufacturing in the country.

site_title: Thai central bank plans to further relax forex rules
summary: Thailand's central bank plans to further relax foreign exchange rules, aiming to help companies efficiently hedge and manage risks. The measures, set to take effect on Friday, will simplify overseas transactions and improve risk management. The bank's governor, Alisara Mahasandana, stated that the baht's recent weakness against the US dollar, its weakest level in 5 years, has had limited impact on inflation and the economy. The relaxation of FX rules is part of a broader plan to ease regulations over the next few years.

images.alt_text: "Our export sector is strong, but tourism recovery will be gradual," Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith told an online business seminar, noting Thailand received about 700,000 visitors in the first 4 months of 2022.

site_title: China scrutiny stymies JD.com fintech unit's US$2b Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: JD.com's fintech unit, JD Technology, has delayed a potential US$2 billion Hong Kong IPO due to regulatory hurdles. The company applied to the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) in late January but has yet to secure approval. The main concern is JD Tech's consumer finance business, which has raised scrutiny from Chinese regulators amid fears of rising defaults and deteriorating asset quality. The delay poses a challenge to JD.com's newly appointed CEO, Lei Xu, and worsens Hong Kong's poor IPO performance this year.

images.alt_text: US regulators added more than 80 companies, including JD.com, to an expanding list of firms that face possible expulsion from American exchanges because of Beijing’s refusal to allow access to the businesses’ financial audits.
Hong Kong's IPO drought shown in worst quarter of pandemic era

Hong Kong hasn’t hosted any IPO larger than US$1 billion so far this year. Overall proceeds in the Asian financial hub have slumped, with the vast majority of newcomers plunging below the listing price after they debuted.

site_title: UK economy unexpectedly shrinks in March as recession risks loom
summary: The UK economy unexpectedly contracted by 0.1% in March, marking a weak end to the first quarter of 2022, as supply-chain problems led to a slump in car sales. GDP grew 0.8% in the first quarter, below expectations, and consumer spending faces its biggest squeeze in decades. The Bank of England forecasts inflation will exceed 10% in the final quarter of the year, raising recession risks. The government is under pressure to provide support to households amid soaring energy bills.

images.alt_text: UK estate agents are preparing for the cost of living crisis and Bank of England rate increases to take some of the heat out of the housing market, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyor (RICS).

Fierce competition for workers pushed UK salaries higher in April, according to a survey that will put pressure on the Bank of England to continue tightening monetary policy in its battle to tame inflation.

site_title: Crisis-hit Sri Lanka set for new PM, unity government
summary: Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa is set to name a new premier, Ranil Wickremesinghe, to replace his brother who was banned from leaving the country due to violent protests over the country's economic crisis. Wickremesinghe, who has previously served as prime minister five times, may face challenges in passing legislation through parliament. The move comes as President Rajapaksa continues to resist calls for his resignation amidst the country's worst economic downturn since independence.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 02, 2020 United National Party (UNP) party leader Ranil Wickremesinghe waves to supporters during the party's final campaign rally ahead of the upcoming parliamentary elections in Colombo. - Beleaguered President Gotabaya Rajapaksa was set to name Wickremesinghe as the new prime minister on May 12, 2022, to try to steer Sri Lanka out of its dire economic crisis after days of violence, officials said. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on May 12, 2022, following Wall Street's decline due to concerns over US monetary policy tightening. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.77% to 25,748.72, while the Topix index dropped 1.19% to 1,829.18.

site_title: Black hole scientists set to reveal 'groundbreaking' Milky Way discovery
summary: Scientists behind the Event Horizon Telescope are set to reveal "groundbreaking" results about the Milky Way on May 12, 2022. They may unveil an image of the supermassive black hole Sagittarius A*, located 26,000 light years from Earth, which is 4 million times the mass of the sun. This would be a major breakthrough, following the 2019 capture of the first black hole image, 55 million light years away. The discovery could provide insights into the galaxy's composition, with estimates suggesting up to a billion black holes in the Milky Way.

site_title: Online pharmacy secures Pakistan's biggest health care funding
summary: Pakistan's MedznMore, a healthcare startup, raised over $11.5 million in the country's largest funding round, securing its largest funding round by a healthcare startup. The pre-Series A round was led by Integra Partners, Sturgeon Capital, and Nunc Gestion. The company plans to expand services and hire more tech talent, aiming to enter 7-8 new cities by the end of the year. Founded in 2020, MedznMore aims to provide Pakistanis with easy access to genuine drugs in a market notorious for spurious medicines.

site_title: Nissan swings to Q4 profit, beats estimates
summary: Nissan reported a 56 billion yen (S$605.9 million) operating profit for the fourth quarter, beating analyst estimates. The Japanese automaker's cost cuts and a weak yen helped mitigate the impact of rising material costs and supply chain disruptions. Nissan expects operating profit to rise to 250 billion yen this fiscal year, below analyst estimates. The company faces challenges from rising material costs, supply chain disruptions, and the crisis in Ukraine, which it believes will make the market environment more severe this year.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor rolls out its first mass-produced battery electric car in Japan on Thursday for lease only, a strategy the automaker says will help ease driver concerns about battery life and resale value but has raised analysts' eyebrows.

Nissan Motor probably turned profitable in the recently ended fiscal year and investors will be looking for hints as to whether that momentum will carry forward as the Japanese automaker faces new risks from rising material prices to a potential slow-down in demand for cars.

Renault, whose sales fell for the third straight year in 2021, is in the middle of turnaround plan aimed at boosting profit margins and splitting its electric vehicle and combustion engine businesses.

site_title: SBF calls for more nuanced approach in foreign manpower for services, seeks more source countries
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has proposed a more nuanced approach to classifying business activities in the services sector to improve manpower allocation. The proposed "key actions" include revising the classification of business activities, expanding the list of non-traditional source countries for work permit holders, and recalibrating the dependency ratio ceiling (DRC) policy. SBF also suggests upgrading talent and fostering cross-sector teamwork to address manpower challenges in lifestyle services, environmental services, and estate and facility management industries. The federation aims to work with industry partners, trade associations, and government agencies to implement these changes.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
There were 2 job vacancies for every unemployed person in December last year.
Hotel staff, including a cleaner and a bellman walk past at the Marina Bay Sands Hotel.

site_title: SoftBank posts 1.7t yen FY net loss
summary: SoftBank Group reported a net loss of 1.7 trillion yen ($18.3 billion) for the year ended in March, compared to a record 4.99 trillion yen profit a year earlier. The tech investor faces a sliding tech portfolio, with portfolio companies such as Coupang, Didi Global, and Grab tumbling during the January-March quarter. This slump is casting a shadow on SoftBank's strategy of heavy concentration in high-growth stocks, which is increasingly out of favor with investors as interest rates rise.

images.alt_text: Above: The East Ventures team. Managing partner Roderick Purwana said rising digital adoption in Indonesia has pushed for many sector advances.

The logo of SoftBank Group Corp at a conference in Tokyo.

site_title: Shanghai hunts down Covid cases; Beijing curbs taxi services
summary: Shanghai authorities are combing the city for its last Covid-19 cases in a final push to eradicate the virus by the end of the month, following significant progress in recent days. The city reported just 2 new cases, both in districts that had achieved "zero Covid" status, highlighting the difficulty in finishing off the highly transmissible Omicron variant. Meanwhile, Beijing has curbed taxi services and banned dine-in services to keep a lid on its smaller outbreak, as China's "zero Covid" policy continues to cause significant economic damage and disruption.

images.alt_text: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said on Tuesday China’s zero-tolerance strategy is not sustainable and that it was time for a change in approach.
China is eyeing new incremental policies to prop up growth and will take steps when necessary, a senior official of China’s Communist Party said on Thursday.

site_title: Subaru to spend 250b yen on battery capacity, add EV line
summary: Subaru plans to invest 250 billion yen (US$1.9 billion) in electric-vehicle battery capacity over 5 years, aiming for 40% of new global car sales to be electric by 2030. The company will also add an EV production line at its main factory in Gunma prefecture, Japan, starting in 2027. This investment follows other Japanese automakers' efforts to catch up with global peers, with Honda and Toyota also investing in cleaner cars and electric vehicle components. Subaru's shares jumped 9.6% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Toyota, Subaru, Mazda stick to bets on greener combustion fuels

site_title: Toyota rolls out first battery electric car in cautious debut as rivals go full-throttle
summary: Toyota has launched its first mass-produced battery electric car, the bZ4X SUV, in Japan for lease only, aiming to ease driver concerns about battery life and resale value. The lease deal, which includes insurance, repair costs, and a battery warranty, costs around $39,000 for 4 years. Analysts have raised eyebrows, citing the strategy as potentially limiting purchasing options and risking market share. Despite this, Toyota plans to lease 5,000 bZ4X SUVs in the current financial year and sell the cars in other markets later this year.

images.alt_text: Toyota on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter profit slumped by a third, as a sliding yen and solid demand failed to offset the impact of production disruptions.
TOYOTA Motor said on Tuesday (May 10) it would suspend operations on 14 lines at 8 domestic factories for up to 6 days in May due to the Covid lockdown in China.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies stabilise after plunging on Terra, DeFi exodus
summary: Cryptocurrencies stabilized after plummeting following the collapse of the TerraUSD stablecoin, with Bitcoin rising to around $29,000. Tokens like Avalanche and Solana posted double-digit percentage gains. The TerraUSD stablecoin remains below its intended peg, while its affiliated token Luna struggles. Investors are concerned about the impact on liquidity protocols and the overall crypto sector, which is nursing heavy losses for the week.

images.alt_text: BITCOIN fell below US$30,000 and touched its lowest level since June, while the TerraUSD stablecoin continued its downward spiral.
Coinbase Global founder Brian Armstrong (above) had a personal fortune of US$13.7 billion as recently as November and about US$8 billion at the end of March.

site_title: Credit Suisse to name new co-heads of Asia financing group: sources
summary: Credit Suisse will name Tim Tu and Aaron Oh as co-heads of its Asia-Pacific financing group, aiming to shore up one of the bank's most profitable businesses in the region. The move comes after a series of global scandals and billions of dollars in losses, departures of senior executives, and a global restructuring of its senior ranks. The division, which originates and structures financing for entrepreneurs and corporate clients, will be bolstered through a venture between investment banking, capital markets, and private banking units in Asia.

images.alt_text: CREDIT SUISSE froze 10.4 billion Swiss francs (S$14.7 billion) of wealthy clients' assets in the first quarter under sanctions imposed in connection with Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the bank's financial report showed on Thursday (May 5).
Credit Suisse's first-quarter net loss came in at 273 million Swiss francs (S$385.3 million) and the report cited net litigation provisions of 703 million francs.

A sign on the roof of the Credit Suisse Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022.
