site_title: Hong Kong intervenes to defend its dollar for first time since 2019
summary: Hong Kong's central bank intervened to defend its currency for the first time since 2019, buying HK$1.6 billion to prop up the Hong Kong dollar, which had fallen to the weak end of its trading band. The move comes as capital outflows fueled by rising US interest rates and pandemic restrictions in Hong Kong continue to pressure the currency. The intervention is expected to drain liquidity from the financial system, driving up borrowing costs, and raises concerns about the impact on Hong Kong's property market, which Goldman Sachs predicts may slump 20% by 2025.

images.alt_text: An empty area for passengers heading to quarantine in the arrival hall at Hong Kong International Airport.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won drop over 1% after US CPI data
summary: South Korea's Kospi index fell 1.63% to 2,550.08, its lowest close since November 2020, amid a broader decline in Asian markets. The US inflation data showed consumer price growth slowed in April, but core prices accelerated, disappointing investors on potential policy tightening. The won dropped 1.03% to 1,288.6 per dollar, its lowest close since July 2009. Foreigners were net sellers of 279.3 billion won worth of shares, and tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 1.22% and 1.36% respectively.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 4.29 points, or 0.17 per cent, to 2,592.27, after falling as much as 0.67 per cent.

site_title: New Zealand says Canada isn’t fulfilling CPTPP dairy obligations
summary: New Zealand has initiated dispute settlement proceedings against Canada over dairy tariffs under the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). Canada's implementation of dairy tariff rate quotas is inconsistent with its obligations, resulting in a loss of NZ$68 million for New Zealand's dairy exporters over the first two years. New Zealand's Trade Minister Damien O'Connor expressed disappointment, stating that Canada's actions will hinder the country's exporters from benefiting from the agreement. The two countries have 7 days to respond to the request for consultations.

site_title: Japan, China, South Korea finance leaders urge caution amid Ukraine crisis
summary: Financial leaders from Japan, China, and South Korea have urged caution amid the Ukraine crisis, warning of heightened risks from monetary policy normalization, inflation, and supply chain disruptions. They pledged to maintain financial market stability and fiscal sustainability through support measures. The joint statement follows an annual meeting of the leaders, who will also discuss ASEAN issues later.

site_title: The World Wide Web's creator wants metaverse VR
summary: Tim Berners-Lee, creator of the World Wide Web, expects virtual reality (VR) and the metaverse to play a significant role in future interactions with the web. He supports decentralized data storage systems, like Solid, which allows individuals to own and control their data. Berners-Lee also opposes large tech companies controlling users' personal data, as he believes it's essential for functional democracy. His company, Inrupt, is developing a decentralized data-storage system, and he has sold his original web source code as an NFT, demonstrating his commitment to Web3 principles.

images.alt_text: VR will not define the future of the metaverse.

site_title: Russia ‘most direct threat to world order’: EU’s von der Leyen
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Charles Michel have warned that Russia poses the "most direct threat" to world order due to its invasion of Ukraine and pact with China. The EU is urging China to play a more constructive role on the international stage. Von der Leyen also emphasized the need for secure supply chains, particularly in the wake of the pandemic and war, and called for increased cooperation with Japan on infrastructure investment and security.

images.alt_text: epa09936078 European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen speaks during a press conference after the closing event of the Conference on the Future of Europe at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, 09 May 2022.  EPA-EFE/RONALD WITTEK

site_title: Singapore facing taxi shortage as pandemic restrictions lifted
summary: Singapore's taxi fleet has shrunk by almost a fifth over the past two years, with the number of licensed drivers declining by over 6,500. The city-state's private-hire and taxi companies are struggling to meet surging passenger demand as pandemic restrictions are lifted, resulting in longer waiting times and surging fares. To address the shortage, companies like ComfortDelGro are offering incentives to attract more drivers, amid a broader labor shortage across Asia and rising oil prices.

site_title: Singapore life insurance sales slide 2% to S$1.21b in Q1
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 2% dip in weighted new business premiums to S$1.21 billion in Q1 2022, down from S$1.23 billion in the year-ago period. Sales of annual-premium products dropped 20% to S$555.1 million, while single-premium products grew 21% to S$655.4 million. Online policy purchases rose 142% to 214,372, contributing S$27 million in weighted premiums. The industry paid out S$2.29 billion in claims, with most being for matured policies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Equities tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.35% at the open on May 12, 2022, following Wall Street's drop due to renewed inflation fears. The Hang Seng Index fell 267.68 points to 19,566.89. Mainland China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also dropped, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.45% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropping 0.64%. The losses were attributed to rising inflation concerns.

site_title: China's Didi awaits completion of regulator's review to return to normal
summary: China's ride-hailing giant Didi Global will resume normal operations after authorities complete a cybersecurity review, following its US$4.4 billion listing in the US despite being asked to put it on hold. The company's angering regulators with its initial listing days after going public in June, leading to a cybersecurity review and the removal of its mobile apps from Chinese app stores. The review is expected to be completed before Didi can return to normal operations.

images.alt_text: Shares of Rivian Automotive sank 21 per cent as some early stakeholders got their first chance to unload shares on Monday.

Drivers, who power Uber’s business - as well as the business of other gig economy companies like Lyft, DoorDash and Instacart -have said that high gas prices in recent months, stemming in part from the Russian invasion of Ukraine, have made it more difficult to make a living driving for Uber.
US lawmakers had last year called for an investigation into Didi’s controversial IPO - the biggest by a Chinese firm since Alibaba Group.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.51 points or 0.10% to 1,554.41. Losers outpaced gainers 205 to 117, with a total trading volume of 147.77 million lots worth RM73.20 million.

site_title: Sinarmas Land to purchase London office asset for £195m
summary: Sinarmas Land, a subsidiary of Sinarmas Land, has agreed to purchase a freehold prime commercial building in London, 32-50 Strand, for £195 million (S$334 million). The 139,000 sq ft property benefits from excellent connectivity next to the Charing Cross station and is close to Trafalgar Square. The acquisition is part of Sinarmas Land's expansion plans into international markets.

site_title: Gold gains as dollar, Treasury yields weaken after US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,855.11 per ounce after US consumer price data suggested inflation may have peaked in April, easing concerns of aggressive Fed rate hikes. A weaker dollar and lower Treasury yields also boosted gold, making it more attractive for overseas buyers. The consumer price index rose 0.3% last month, the smallest gain since August, and benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields fell.

images.alt_text: Gold, generally a sound hedge against uncertain times, has seen a steep sell off

site_title: ecoWise reports variances in H1 FY2021 results, to expand scope of internal audit
summary: ecoWise Holdings, an environmental solutions provider, has reported material variances between its audited and unaudited financial statements for the first half-year period ending Apr 30, 2021. The audited financial statements show a net profit of S$160,000, compared to S$1.7 million in the unaudited statements. The audited statements have factored in potential legal claims, fines, and taxes, resulting in lower other gains and higher administrative expenses. The group's independent auditor has issued a disclaimer of opinion due to service agreements and the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Tennis: Osaka breaks from IMG to start own sports agency
summary: Naomi Osaka is launching her own sports agency, Evolve, after breaking away from IMG. The agency, led by longtime agent Stuart Duguid, aims to focus on big-picture brand building for transcendent athletes. Osaka, a four-time Grand Slam winner, emerged as a leading advocate for athlete mental health and wellbeing. She began discussing the venture with Duguid at the Tokyo Olympics last year and plans to represent athletes with the potential to transcend their sports. Osaka's agency will operate as a boutique and bespoke agency, prioritizing athlete-driven decision-making over commission-based models.

Rafael Nadal enjoyed a winning return after a 6-week injury break, opening his Madrid campaign with a 6-1, 7-6(7/4) success over Serbia's Miomir Kecmanovic on Wednesday.

site_title: VC firm East Ventures closes US$550m fund for startups targeting Indonesia
summary: East Ventures, a VC firm, has closed a US$550 million fund focused on startups in Indonesia, the fastest-growing digital economy in South-east Asia. The fund will allocate US$150 million to early-stage deals and US$400 million to growth-stage deals. Existing investors, including Softbank-backed Z Holdings, supported the fund with a 120% re-up rate. East Ventures has previously invested in Indonesian unicorns like Traveloka and Tokopedia, which merged to form GoTo. The fund's closing is expected to further elevate the tech ecosystem in Indonesia, creating investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: Manulife profit lags estimates as Asia lockdowns hurt sale
summary: Manulife Financial reported a 5.8% decline in core earnings in Asia due to the impact of Covid-19 lockdowns, missing analysts' estimates. The company's CEO, Roy Gori, attributed the decline to low customer sentiment, but noted that case counts are decreasing and restrictions are lifting, indicating a potential recovery. Manulife's other businesses, including Canada and global wealth management, saw stronger performances. The company's net income attributed to shareholders more than tripled to C$2.97 billion, or C$1.50 a share.

images.alt_text: Insurer American International Group reported a nearly 17 per cent rise in quarterly profit on Tuesday that topped market estimates, as strong underwriting gains and lower catastrophe losses cushioned a drop in investment income.

site_title: Sasseur Reit’s Q1 DPU rises 3.6% to a record high; CEO optimistic about debt refinancing prospects
summary: Sasseur Reit's Q1 DPU rose 3.6% to a record high of 1.822 Singapore cents, driven by a 4.7% increase in distributable income to S$24.7 million. CEO Cecilia Tan is optimistic about debt refinancing prospects, aiming to increase offshore debt to reduce onshore loan costs. The refinancing exercise, expected to complete by end of 2022, will stagger debt maturity and amount, with Tan seeking "some level of savings" to secure higher DPU.

Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Palm oil producer Bumitama Agri’s Q1 profit surges to 873b rupiah on higher output, margins
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 521% surge in Q1 profit to 873 billion rupiah, driven by higher output and margins. Revenue grew 69% to 3.9 trillion rupiah, with crude palm oil and palm kernel sales surging 66% and 84% respectively. Business margins reached 37.8% and 22.4%, the highest in multi-years, with gross profit jumping 196%. The company expects continued production normalisation and elevated palm oil prices to support its prospects for the year ahead.

site_title: 5E Resources ends Catalist debut at S$0.265; 1.9% above IPO price
summary: 5E Resources, a scheduled waste management company, ended its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.265, 1.9% above its IPO price of S$0.26, giving it a market capitalization of S$41.3 million. The company posted a net profit of RM8 million (S$2.6 million) for the year ended Dec 31, 2020. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to acquire a storage facility and invest in new facilities to enhance production efficiency. The company received strong interest, with 3.5 times subscription for offer shares and 3 million shares allotted to substantial subscribers.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The company currently operates 3 waste treatment plants in Johor

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% or 22.17 points to 3,203.9, following overnight losses on Wall Street. The decline was driven by losses in banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC. In contrast, European stocks rose 1.7% on strong earnings and a surge in economically sensitive sectors. Asian stocks also fell, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index down 1.34% amid concerns over inflation.

images.alt_text: The real estate investment manager on Thursday posted a 16 per cent growth on year in revenue to S$598 million for its first quarter amid a healthy growth in fee-related earnings from its fund and lodging management businesses.

site_title: China to roll out new policies when necessary to support economy: senior party official
summary: China plans to implement new incremental policies to support its economy, according to a senior Communist Party official. The policies will focus on propelling growth and will be implemented as needed. Existing policies will be implemented in the first half of the year, with the central bank increasing financial support for the real economy. The move aims to address the economic impact of Covid-19 outbreaks and potential slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Hong Kong's refusal to open border is crushing city's businesses
summary: Hong Kong's prolonged refusal to open its border to mainland China is severely impacting the city's economy, with businesses facing potential ruin and residents emigrating in search of safer opportunities. The city's economy contracted 4% in the first quarter, and retail sales plummeted 12% in February and March. Small and medium businesses, which employ 45% of the workforce, are struggling to survive under the current restrictions. The city's unemployment rate rose to 5%, and residents are waiting for the new leader, John Lee, to ease restrictions and revive the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Two International Finance Centre (IFC), HSBC headquarters and Bank of China in Hong Kong, China July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust posts 0.8% rise in Q1 DPU to S$0.0131
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust posted a 0.8% rise in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0131, in line with its pro-rated forecasts. Gross revenue was down 0.8% to S$16.8 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 1.4% to S$13.3 million. The Reit's overall portfolio occupancy improved to 98.6% as of March 31, with all properties except one at full occupancy.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Bitcoin ETFs arrive in Australia just as the crypto market tanks
summary: Australia's inaugural cryptocurrency exchange-traded funds (ETFs) began trading on May 12, despite a crypto market meltdown. The ETFS 21Shares Bitcoin ETF, ETFS 21Shares Ethereum ETF, and Cosmos Purpose Bitcoin Access ETF debuted on Cboe Global Markets's local exchange. The funds invest directly in virtual coins, and their launch comes as Bitcoin has plummeted 38% this year and Ether has shed 44%. The crypto sector is also affected by the collapse of TerraUSD stablecoin and global monetary tightening.

images.alt_text: Australians may have to wait a little longer for the debut of the nation's first financial products offering direct expose to cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Shop and work: UK's Tesco gives up supermarket space for office area
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, has partnered with office rental firm IWG to convert excess supermarket space into office areas. A trial will start in mid-May at a Tesco store in south London, featuring 12 desks, 30 co-working spaces, and a meeting room. The service will be available for £93-£216 per month, with customer feedback assessed before a potential nationwide rollout. The partnership aims to capitalize on post-Covid-19 demand for hybrid working, with IWG planning to add 1,000 new locations globally this year.

images.alt_text: McColl's Retail Group, a large UK convenience store chain, has collapsed into insolvency and suspended the trading of its shares after refinancing talks failed, putting as many as 16,000 jobs at risk.
Tesco tests cashierless store

site_title: Tokyo: Shares drop on inflation fears, Wall Street falls
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.34% in early trade on Thursday, mirroring overnight drops on Wall Street due to inflation concerns. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 350.51 points to 25,863.13, while the Topix index fell 0.79% to 1,836.56. The decline was attributed to investors' worries about rising inflation, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit Q1 distributable income up 7.1% to 23.3m euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) reported a 7.1% increase in distributable income to 23.3 million euros for the first quarter ended March 31, 2022, from 21.7 million euros in the year-ago period. Gross revenue rose 8.5% to 52.6 million euros, while net property income climbed 5.4% to 32.5 million euros. The Reit maintained a portfolio occupancy of 94.8% and secured 53 leases for 37,622 square meters, with a positive rent reversion of 4.2%.

Lovosice is located approximately 65 km north-west of Prague, the capital of the Czech Republic, and

site_title: UK salaries rise as firms face growing candidate shortages
summary: UK salaries rose in April due to fierce competition for workers, with candidate shortages driving near-record growth in starting salaries for new staff. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) and KPMG reported that starting-salary inflation held close to a record high, despite the Bank of England's efforts to tighten monetary policy to combat inflation. The scarcity was driven by low unemployment, fewer foreign workers, and pandemic-related job hesitancy. Wages still trail inflation, leaving Britons facing a challenging period for living standards.

images.alt_text: Morning commuters cross London Bridge in the City of London.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Frasers Property, Golden Agri-Resources, Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Key companies posting updates include CapitaLand Investment, Frasers Property, Golden Agri-Resources, and Cromwell E-Reit, with notable earnings and revenue growth. CapitaLand Investment reported a 16% year-on-year growth in revenue to S$598 million, while Frasers Property saw a 42.7% drop in net profit to S$158 million. Golden Agri-Resources achieved record Q1 performance with a 32% year-on-year increase in revenue, and Cromwell E-Reit posted a 7.1% rise in distributable income to S$34.1 million.

site_title: Indian startups show more maturity about employee share options than South-east Asian ones: report
summary: A report by Saison Capital found that Indian startups are more employee-friendly with employee share options (ESOPs) compared to South-east Asian ones. About half of Indian startup founders understand ESOPs, while only a third of those in South-east Asia do. Indian startups also give employees more time to exercise options (over 12 months) and retain more options when employees leave (6% vs. 20% of South-east Asian startups).

site_title: Facebook-owner Meta tells hardware staffers to prepare for cutbacks
summary: Meta Platforms Inc, the owner of Facebook, is preparing cutbacks in its Reality Labs division, which focuses on hardware products and the metaverse. The division may have to postpone or cancel some projects due to financial constraints, but Meta is not planning layoffs. The company has already reduced hiring and lowered its 2022 expenses forecast. Reality Labs has invested heavily in the metaverse, but has also lost billions of dollars in the past year. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg aims to generate income growth from legacy apps to fund Reality Labs investments, but this is not expected to happen in 2022.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide as US inflation data fuels slowdown woes
summary: Australian shares declined 0.8% on Thursday, mirroring global market trends, following US inflation data that showed higher-than-expected core inflation and fuelled concerns about aggressive interest rate hikes and an economic slowdown. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with financial stocks suffering their sixth consecutive loss, while technology stocks plummeted 7.4% to their lowest in two years. Energy stocks rose 0.6% on rising crude prices, despite uncertainty in global oil markets.

site_title: Crypto billionaires' vast fortunes are destroyed in weeks
summary: Crypto billionaires have seen their fortunes decline sharply in recent weeks, with Coinbase founder Brian Armstrong's personal fortune shrinking from $13.7 billion to $2.2 billion. Other notable billionaires, including Michael Novogratz and Changpeng Zhao, have also seen significant losses. The decline in digital currencies, including Bitcoin and Ether, has led to a sharp downturn in the market value of crypto exchanges, with trading volumes at Coinbase falling steadily since the start of the year.

site_title: VC firm Good Startup hits US$34m in final close of alternative protein fund
summary: Singapore-based VC firm Good Startup has closed its US$34 million final round for Good Protein Fund I, focusing on alternative protein startups using biotechnology to solve food challenges. Since its launch in 2021, Good Startup has invested in 21 startups out of a target 35 companies globally, including Eat Just, Every Company, SuperMeat, and TurtleTree. The fund will support portfolio companies in operational areas such as intellectual property protection and hiring, enabling the VC firm to scale its work and facilitate deeper ecosystem connections.

site_title: UK faces unique inflation shock, former BOE official says
summary: The UK is facing a unique inflation shock with price pressures coming from all 6 key sources, according to former Bank of England rate-setter Kristin Forbes. This is unlike other major economies, with inflation potentially reaching 10% in the UK. Forbes attributes the UK's inflation to its history of higher inflation, weaker sterling, and higher medium- and long-term expectations. She would support aggressive policy, including a 50 basis point rate increase, to avoid a recession, and notes that the BOE may need to cut rates back if it overshoots.

site_title: Warren Buffett is right about crypto: Investment decisions shouldn’t turn on FOMO
summary: Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger, co-chairmen of Berkshire Hathaway, have criticized cryptocurrencies, saying investment decisions shouldn't be driven by fear of missing out (FOMO). Buffett stated that he wouldn't invest in all the bitcoin in the world for $25, citing that it doesn't produce anything. Munger called bitcoin "stupid, evil" and said it makes the US look foolish in comparison to China, where crypto is banned. Buffett advises investors to only invest in what they understand, rather than following FOMO, and warns that the ease of investing in crypto without knowledge could lead to a similar bubble to the dot-com era.

site_title: ERA, Huttons, PropNex, Savills to own Real Estate Analytics shares with SoReal deal
summary: Real Estate Analytics has acquired Singapore property technology firm SoReal Prop in a cash-and-equity deal. Leading property agencies ERA, Huttons, and PropNex, as well as real estate service company Savills, will become minority shareholders in Real Estate Analytics. SoReal Prop provides applications with real-time transaction data and analytical tools to property agents in Singapore, and the acquisition aims to form a strong partnership with the largest real estate brokers in Singapore. The deal value and details were not disclosed.

site_title: Oil jumps as Russia gas flow to Europe falls, EU Russian oil ban looms
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 5% on Wednesday after Russian gas flows to Europe fell by a quarter, with Brent crude rising 4.4% to $106.96 a barrel. The European Union is working on a Russian oil embargo, which would further tighten the market and shift trade flows. The move comes as supply concerns persist due to inadequate investment, and the EU's delay in a vote on the embargo has added to market volatility.

images.alt_text: US petrol prices reached a record high on Tuesday, as President Joe Biden said fighting inflation is his top domestic priority.

site_title: Biden administration sees early 'challenges' dealing with new Philippine government
summary: The US is seeking early engagement with the new Philippine government led by Ferdinand Marcos Jr, despite historical challenges due to his family's past authoritarian rule. US Coordinator for the Indo-Pacific Kurt Campbell expressed a desire to get off to a good start and continue a close partnership in security and trade. Marcos's victory complicates US efforts to counter China's influence in the region, particularly in the South China Sea. The US hopes to maintain strategic relations and continue cooperation with the Philippines, despite initial challenges.

site_title: Stablecoin rescue plan gets cold shoulder from big investors
summary: Big-name investors are rejecting a rescue plan for TerraUSD (UST), a closely-watched algorithmic stablecoin that broke its dollar peg. Talks stalled after firms such as Alameda Research, Celsius, and Galaxy Digital Holdings were approached with private discussions. Only Nexo declined to join the effort, while others like Jump Crypto and Jane Street declined to comment. The Luna Foundation Guard, backed by Terraform Labs, is struggling to raise $1.5 billion to shore up the token, with UST trading at around 67 US cents as of late-afternoon in New York.

site_title: Frasers Property H1 profit down 42.6% to S$158.2m due to previous one-off gain
summary: Frasers Property posted a 42.6% decline in attributable profit to S$158.2 million for its second half ended Mar 31, 2021, from S$275.8 million a year ago, due to a one-off gain in the previous period. The company will focus on growing its industrial and logistics sectors, as well as commercial and business park assets. Frasers has utilized S$500 million of its allocated S$700 million for I&L and business park assets. The company also reported higher contributions from its hospitality business in the half-year period, with earnings per share down 60.2% to 3.31 Singapore cents.

site_title: Will crypto market collapse bottom out?
summary: Cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, have experienced significant market turbulence, with Bitcoin briefly falling below $30,000, its lowest level in nearly a year. Financial advisers urge investors not to panic, citing the potential for rebalancing portfolios and identifying coins with long-term value. Billionaire Mark Cuban likened the current situation to the dot-com bubble, while experts argue that a bubble burst may not be inevitable. Investors are advised to focus on tailoring their portfolios with a long-term strategy, allocating 5-10% of their portfolio to crypto, and prioritizing fully collateralized stablecoins.

images.alt_text: Investment decisions shouldn’t turn on FOMO – the fear of missing out.
Complex issues around the proper valuation of cryptocurrencies are common in many crypto arbitrations, given their volatility.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources posts higher Q1 profit on 32% revenue growth
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported record Q1 profit of US$188 million, up nearly fivefold from last year, driven by a 32% year-on-year increase in revenue to US$2.7 billion. Crude palm oil prices rose 49% compared to the same quarter last year, while plantation output fell 18% to 668,000 metric tonnes. The company expects limited global oilseed production growth and a single-digit pace for palm oil production this year. Golden Agri-Resources fully supports Indonesia's temporary export ban to tackle food inflation and maintain domestic supply.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Golden Agri-Resources H2 profit up 71.2% to US$323m
Golden Agri swings into the black with US$115m profit for Q3
Golden Agri-Resources H2 profit up 71.2% to US$323m
SHARES of plam oil counters fell on Monday (Apr 25) after Indonesia announced it would ban the export of palm oil from Apr 28.

site_title: Russia slaps sanctions on over 30 EU, US and Singapore energy firms
summary: Russia has imposed sanctions on over 30 EU, US, and Singapore energy companies in retaliation for Western penalties over Ukraine. The list includes 31 companies, mostly subsidiaries of Gazprom, with a ban on transactions and entry into Russian ports of vessels linked to the affected companies. The sanctions affect Poland's EuRoPol GAZ S.A., which owns the Polish part of the Yamal-Europe gas pipeline. This move comes as part of an unprecedented scale and speed of Western sanctions against Moscow, which have ranged from asset freezes to export bans and financial sanctions.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment Q1 revenue up 16% to S$598m on growth in fund, lodging management units
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) reported a 16% year-on-year growth in revenue to S$598 million in Q1 2022, driven by a 28% rise in fee-related earnings from its fund and lodging management businesses. The company's lodging business saw a 34% increase in revenue per available unit, while its capital management business recycled S$1.6 billion in capital year-to-date. CLI expects to remain resilient despite global uncertainties and is focusing on sustainability, with a review of its 2030 Sustainability Master Plan underway.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The CapitaLand logo on the facade of Funan Centre.
CapitaLand Investment to issue S$400m worth of notes due 2027 at 3.33%
CICT and Coref to acquire Grade-A office building on Robinson Road for S$1.3b
CLI, Frasers Hospitality don't see big hit to Shenzhen businesses from temporary lockdown

site_title: The Pitch by Garage: How ShopBack bagged 30 million users in 8 years (Ep 2)
summary: ShopBack, a cashback start-up, has become the market leader in South-east Asia and Australia in 8 years, dominating 13 markets with over 1,500 retail partners. The company's success is attributed to its customer-centric approach, focusing on building a delightful shopping experience and aligning interests with partners. ShopBack's ability to adapt and expand into new verticals, such as financial services, has enabled it to surpass competitors and achieve long-term sustainability. The company's co-founder and CEO, Joel Leong, emphasizes the importance of striking a balance between short-term and long-term growth to create an efficient economy and environment for customers.

images.alt_text: The Pitch by Garage: What is the secret to Hepmil's Success? (Ep 1)

site_title: Victims of Florida condo collapse reach US$997m settlement
summary: Survivors and families of victims of the 2021 Champlain Towers South condo collapse in Miami have reached a settlement of at least $997 million. The settlement resolves a class action lawsuit against multiple defendants, including developers of an adjacent building, who were accused of contributing to the collapse through vibrations from construction work. The settlement compensates the owners of condos and the families of the 98 deceased residents, with an additional $100 million to be recovered for the victims.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine H1 profit rises 82% to S$10.8m as operations improve
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a 82% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$10.8 million for the first half of 2022, driven by operational improvements and higher gross profit margins. Revenue rose 30.9% to S$27.6 million, with the shipyard segment contributing 46% of the increase. The company expects its ship chartering business to benefit from higher oil prices and stable fleet utilisation. Gross profit margins expanded to 29.6% from 23.8% in the previous year, with a 63% surge in gross profit to S$8.2 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Marco Polo Marine's focus on renewables is paying off even as oil prices recover
Marco Polo Marine in tie-up to co-develop delivery drones for offshore wind farms
Marco Polo Marine ventures into green ship recycling, awarded ship recycling permit in Indonesia

site_title: Procurri reviewing non-binding indications of interest for its assets
summary: Procurri Corporation is reviewing non-binding indications of interest from third parties to purchase its assets. The IT solutions provider reported a 9.7% increase in its shares price following the announcement. The company emphasized that these expressions of interest are subject to due diligence and other conditions, and no assurance is given that a transaction will materialize. There is no guarantee that a definitive or binding agreement will be entered into.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: US backs new South Korea leader on North
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration supports South Korea's new conservative leader, President Yoon Suk-yeol, in his outreach to North Korea. Yoon called on North Korea to give up nuclear weapons in exchange for economic aid. The US is ready to engage in diplomacy with North Korea, despite recent provocative military steps. This marks a shift from Yoon's predecessor, Moon Jae-in, who pursued engagement with Pyongyang. The US has not seen a response to its outreach, but remains prepared for any kind of dialogue.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s new president Yoon Suk Yeol said on Wednesday the security situation on the Korean peninsula was “tense”, citing talk of the North’s possible nuclear test.

site_title: Disney profit slips but streaming TV subscribers jump
summary: Disney reported a 48% decline in profit to $470 million in the recently ended quarter, despite its television streaming service and parks experiencing strong growth. The Disney+ streaming service gained 7.9 million subscribers, reaching 205 million total, surpassing analyst expectations. Park attendance rebounded from pandemic lows, while the company continues to release films in theaters. CEO Bob Chapek attributed the strong results to the company's "league of its own" performance, citing the growth of its streaming services and parks.

site_title: UK house price gauge highest since mid-2021, slower rises ahead: RICS
summary: UK house prices rose at the fastest rate since June 2021, with demand outpacing supply, but surveyors trimmed their expectations for future price rises due to inflation pressures. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported a 80-point difference between rising and falling prices, the highest since June 2021. The annual rate of house price increase slowed to 12.1% in March, down from 14.3% in March. Despite this, many richer households still have significant savings, and a majority of surveyors expect house prices to rise over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Condominium rents have reached new heights in April after it rose 2.3 per cent during the month.
One of the world's most expensive property markets faces its biggest test in more than 30 years.

site_title: No further action from police on S$10,000 drawn from Kitchen Culture account
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has found insufficient evidence to prove a criminal offence in relation to S$10,000 withdrawn from Kitchen Culture's bank account in 2020. Two employees informed the company they were not the recorded recipients of the cash cheques. The CAD will take no further action on the matter after a review into the matter raised in a police report lodged by the company last December.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Kitchen Culture's AGM to review a turbulent FY2021
Kitchen Culture lodges report with CAD on payroll irregularities; board responds to SGX
Landlord to oppose Kitchen Culture unit's judicial management application
Auditor issues disclaimer of opinion for Kitchen Culture's FY2021 report
Kitchen Culture unit sues ex-CEO and two others over payroll irregularities

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends down 3.2% as stocks slump after inflation data
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 3.2% to 11,364.24, as tech-linked shares led the market lower. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.0% and the S&P 500 fell 1.7% after the latest US consumer price report showed inflation remained elevated. Despite a slight slowdown in annual inflation, the month-over-month increase exceeded expectations, fueling concerns of further Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

site_title: Google shows early preview of augmented reality glasses
summary: Google has showcased a prototype of augmented reality (AR) glasses at its I/O developer conference, aiming to create a product for the general public after failing with its internet-connected glasses a decade ago. The AR glasses, which use Google Translate, are designed to be built for the real world and won't detract from it, according to CEO Sundar Pichai. The company has a "long way to go" before releasing the glasses, which will rival Meta Platforms and Apple's similar products.

site_title: Oil up more than 5%, as Russia-EU energy quarrel intensifies
summary: Oil prices surged over 5% on Wednesday due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the subsequent energy quarrel with the EU, with Brent crude reaching $107.51 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude climbing to $105.71 a barrel. Russian gas flows to Europe fell by a quarter after Ukraine halted use of a major transit route, raising concerns of further disruptions. The EU is still debating an embargo on Russian oil, which could further tighten the market and shift trade flows, analysts warn.

site_title: Baby formula shortage sends US parents into panic
summary: The US is experiencing a severe shortage of baby formula, with nearly 43% of the usual supply out of stock, exacerbated by a mass recall of Abbott's formula and supply chain problems. Parents are struggling to find alternative formulas, with many resorting to online sellers at tripled prices, and some even importing from other countries. The shortage has caused distress and panic, with some hospitals and pediatricians unable to provide formula samples. The FDA and Abbott are working to increase supply, but the crisis has been politicized, with lawmakers accusing the Biden administration of not doing enough to address the issue.

site_title: Biden seeks to keep China in focus by welcoming Asean leaders
summary: US President Joe Biden is hosting a 2-day summit with the 10-nation Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) in Washington, aiming to maintain focus on the Indo-Pacific and China despite the Ukraine crisis. The summit, starting with a White House dinner on May 12, is expected to result in a comprehensive strategic partnership and new initiatives, including partnerships in public health and climate change. Analysts, however, expect little dramatic progress, with economic engagement being a key area of frustration for Asean countries.

site_title: Rivian reaffirms 25,000 EV target despite supply chain pain
summary: Rivian Automotive reaffirmed its goal to deliver 25,000 battery-electric vehicles this year, despite ongoing supply chain issues that have hampered production. The company has built around 5,000 vehicles since production started in September, with 2,553 units delivered in the first quarter. Rivian's stock surged 14% in after-hours trading before paring some gains, closing down 9.6% to $20.60.

images.alt_text: Shares of Rivian Automotive sank 21 per cent as some early stakeholders got their first chance to unload shares on Monday.

site_title: Hungary says its backing of EU's Russia oil ban hinges on hundreds of millions of US dollars
summary: Hungary is backing the EU's proposed Russia oil ban, but only if the EU offers a solution to replace Russian oil in the Hungarian economy, estimated to be in the hundreds of millions of US dollars. Hungary's MOL group, which profits from cheap Russian oil, wants exemptions from the embargo and financial compensation for refinery upgrades. The EU needs unanimous support for the ban, and Hungary's opposition is a major hurdle. The EU Commission is hosting a discussion on regional cooperation on oil infrastructure to find a solution.

site_title: Singapore job ads, Malaysian candidates surge as borders reopen
summary: Singapore's job market has seen a surge in job postings and Malaysian job applicants after the border reopening with Malaysia on April 1, 2022. Overall job postings rose 15% year-over-year, with Malaysian applicants more than doubling. Key sectors experiencing growth include human resource, education, F&B, retail, and merchandise. However, the foreign manpower supply is expected to take time to return to pre-Covid levels, and official quotas may limit the influx of Malaysian workers.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
No Covid test for land travel between Singapore and Malaysia from Apr 1

site_title: Citi looks for new manager in Delta One unit: sources
summary: Citigroup is searching for a new senior manager within its Delta One operations, a trading unit that sells financial products to sophisticated investors. The move comes after the departure of Ali Omari, who was EMEA Head of Delta One Forwards and Sectors. The job vacancy, posted on LinkedIn, targets investors such as pension funds, hedge funds, and blue-chip corporate clients. The search for a new Head of Forward Trading follows Omari's departure, with the position based at Citigroup's European headquarters in London.

images.alt_text: Citigroup to sell Philippines consumer assets to Union Bank

site_title: Google joins Amazon in mulling a bid for coveted cricket event
summary: Google, the parent company of Alphabet, has expressed interest in bidding for the broadcast rights of the Indian Premier League (IPL), joining other media giants such as Amazon, Disney, and Reliance Industries. The IPL, India's top cricket league, is valued at around $7 billion and attracts 600 million viewers annually. The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) will auction the broadcast and live streaming rights for 2023-2027 starting June 12, with Google's bid potentially giving it access to hundreds of millions of eyeballs and boosting advertisement revenue.

images.alt_text: Alphabet sank on Tuesday after the internet giant reported that earnings in the recently ended quarter missed market expectations, with profit down from a year earlier.

site_title: US seeks to boost investment to Asean countries: US official
summary: The US is seeking to increase investment in Asean countries, according to US Indo-Pacific coordinator Kurt Campbell. This comes ahead of President Joe Biden's summit with South-east Asian leaders, where they will discuss issues like China, Myanmar, and the war in Ukraine. The US aims to strengthen its presence in the region, despite other pressing global challenges.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Kurt Campbell attends a China Development Forum in Beijing, China March 23, 2019. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: IReit keeping eye on Europe uncertainties; Q1 portfolio occupancy flat at 95.7%
summary: IReit Global's portfolio occupancy remained flat at 95.7% for the first quarter of 2022, despite economic and geopolitical uncertainty in Europe due to the war between Ukraine and Russia, rising interest rates, and inflation. The company is closely assessing the situation and maintaining vigilance, while exploring options to extend leases and pursuing investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
IReit Global acquires Grade A office building in Barcelona for 27.2m euros
IReit Global bags new tenant for office space in Germany property
IReit Global H2 DPU rises 7.9 per cent to 1.50 euro cents
S-Reits hedge against rising interest rates

site_title: Amara appoints 3 new independent directors, makes changes to committees
summary: Amara Holdings has appointed three new independent directors, Bill Chua Teck Huat, Ginney Lim May Ling, and George Seow Ewe Keong, following the departure of two previous IDs. The appointments, effective May 11, come after the group's annual general meeting (AGM) where Tan Tiong Cheng's re-election as ID failed to pass. The new appointees will serve on various committees, including the remuneration committee and audit committee. The appointments come amid controversy surrounding Amara's transparency in disclosing directors' remuneration.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Following the AGM, a bourse notification of Tan’s cessation as a director indicated that there were unresolved differences in opinion on material matters between him and the board.
Property developer and hotelier Amara Holdings responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX-ST) on Thursday (Apr 28).

Responding to queries from SGX, Amara has since come out to say that it does not consider the issue - which relates to an immediate family member of one of Amara's executive directors - as an unresolved matter as it is still under discussion.

site_title: Australia's housing market faces its biggest test in 30 years
summary: Australia's housing market faces its largest test in 30 years, with interest-rate increases expected to lead to falling home prices and slowing building activity. The Reserve Bank's tightening cycle, the first in 11.5 years, has shaken consumer confidence, particularly among those with high debt loads. A recent auction in Sydney's Darlington suburb saw a 2-bedroom home yield no bidders, highlighting the market's downturn. Economists expect the sector to absorb the sharpest interest-rate increases since 1989, posing a significant challenge to the country's A$10 trillion residential real estate sector.

images.alt_text: The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment released on Wednesday sank 5.6 per cent in May from April, when it fell 0.9 per cent.

site_title: Google making smartwatch in ‘ambient’ computing push
summary: Google is developing a smartwatch called Pixel Watch as part of its "ambient computing" vision to provide services anywhere at any time. The watch will integrate health features from Fitbit, released in a US$2.1 billion deal last year. A Pixel Watch will be released late this year, along with a new premium Pixel 7 smartphone, and will be available in two versions: one syncing with Android-powered smartphones and one with its own wireless internet connectivity.

images.alt_text: This image courtesy of Google, shows a smart watch as part of the company's Pixel line. - Google on May 11, 2022, said it is strapping a smartwatch onto its Pixel hardware line as part of an "ambient computing" vision to make its services available anywhere at any time. The Alphabet owned internet titan used its annual developers conference as a stage to showcase a Pixel line expanding to include a smartwatch and tablet as well as upgraded earbuds and a more affordable version of its flagship smartphone. site_title: Moderna CFO lasts one day on job after probe at former company
summary: Moderna's CFO, Jorge Gomez, left the company after just one day following an internal investigation at his former employer, Dentsply Sirona. The probe involves allegations of using incentives to sell products to distributors and actions to achieve executive compensation targets. Gomez, who was hired by Moderna in April, cited his passion for sustainability, but shares fell 2.5% before markets opened. Moderna will continue to search for a new CFO, with David Meline serving temporarily. The incident occurred after Dentsply disclosed its internal investigation through a regulatory filing.

site_title: Weekly Covid-19 infection rate rises to 1.76 in Singapore, 3,890 new cases
summary: Singapore reported 3,890 new Covid-19 cases on May 11, with a weekly infection growth rate of 1.76. This is up from 1.49 on Tuesday and more than twice last week's rate of 0.7. The number of hospitalised cases was 246, with 26 requiring oxygen support, and two deaths were reported. The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore stands at 1,228,914, with 1,358 deaths.

site_title: Q&M Dental posts 7% rise in Q1 revenue, declares S$0.004 per share dividend
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 7% increase in Q1 revenue to S$46.8 million, despite a 31% decline in net profit to S$6.5 million. The company declared a S$0.004 per share dividend, lower than the S$0.01 per share paid in Q1 2021. Excluding other gains, net profit after tax increased by 26% to S$6.5 million.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Q&M Dental's Q4 earnings fall 47% on higher costs, expenses
Aoxin Q&M Dental Group has appointed Ng Sook Hwa as its non-executive and non-independent director.
RESTAURANT operator No Signboard Holdings has terminated its conditional sale and purchase agreement to sell a 29 per cent stake in the company to Q&M Dental chief executive Ng Siau Chin.

site_title: VW to challenge Rivian, Ford with electric Scout SUV
summary: Volkswagen plans to expand its electric vehicle (EV) range in the US with a fully electric pick-up and sports utility vehicle under the Scout brand. The carmaker will invest around 100 million euros, potentially seeking external funding to expand production capabilities. VW's supervisory board will discuss the topic at a meeting later on Wednesday. This move aims to challenge Rivian and Ford, both of which offer electric SUVs in the US market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as inflation data stokes rate hike concerns
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Wednesday as consumer prices rose more than expected in April, fueling concerns about aggressive monetary policy tightening. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 37.50 points, or 0.12%, to 32,123.24, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. The decline was attributed to rising inflation and rate hike concerns, which may impact the market's momentum.

site_title: Bitcoin tumbles to 11-month low while TerraUSD extends declines
summary: Bitcoin plummeted to an 11-month low of $29,085, falling over 6% on May 11, as the TerraUSD stablecoin continued its downward spiral. The US consumer price index data showed inflation will persist at elevated levels, leading to aggressive interest-rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Other cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin Cash and Dash, also fell. Analysts attribute the decline to macro headwinds and the collapse of the TerraUSD stablecoin, which has eroded confidence in the crypto market.

site_title: Welcome back to Tokyo - soon
summary: Tokyo is set to reopen to package tours as early as this month, offering millions a taste of Japan after two years of closure. Currently, only business travelers and students can enter the country. The city has undergone changes, with a renewed focus on its culture, cuisine, and original state. As Japan reopens, tourists can expect a more authentic experience, allowing them to appreciate the city's serene atmosphere and captivating attractions.

site_title: Top EU official backs multi-trillion plan to rebuild Ukraine
summary: European Union President Werner Hoyer has backed a multi-trillion-euro plan to rebuild Ukraine, pledging the EU's lending arm to support a global rescue effort. The plan, dubbed the "Marshall" plan, aims to help Ukraine recover from the devastating war with Russia, with estimated costs ranging from $528 billion to $633 billion. Hoyer emphasized the need for international guarantees and support from Western banks to entice investors and facilitate Ukraine's access to global borrowing markets. The EU is preparing to tackle the economic impact of the war, using the European Investment Bank's clout to fund infrastructure projects.

images.alt_text: Drones are part of a multifaceted, multimillion dollar crowdfunding campaign that is producing millions of dollars in donations, as well as a bounty of smaller weapons and other military equipment for the Ukrainian military.

site_title: Jumbo opens third outlet in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: Jumbo Group, a seafood restaurant operator, has opened its third franchised outlet in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The new outlet, occupying a standalone building, has 2 levels, 7 VIP rooms, and a seating capacity of 166. This marks the group's second outlet in the city, following its first opening in 2017. Jumbo's CEO, Ang Kiam Meng, attributed the success to the resilience of its franchise partner and the strength of the Jumbo Seafood brand in the region. The company plans to expand its presence in Vietnam with existing and new partners.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்

site_title: US dollar clings to 20-year high
summary: The US dollar remains close to a 2-decade high, holding at 103.59 due to investors waiting for US inflation data to assess the Federal Reserve's potential monetary policy tightening. The dollar is within reach of 104.19, its strongest since December 2002. Despite expectations of softened inflation to 8.1% in April, the dollar's strength persists, indicating investors' caution on rising prices.

site_title: Kimly H1 profit falls 14.7% to S$18.5m,  0.56-cent interim dividend declared
summary: Kimly, a coffee shop operator, reported a net profit of S$18.5 million for the first six months of 2022, down 14.7% from S$20.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 27.9% to S$156.9 million, driven by growth in its food retail division. Despite this, the group's cost of sales rose 32.4% due to higher utilities charges and employee benefits. Kimly declared an unchanged interim dividend of 0.56 Singapore cents, payable on July 15, 2022.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Kimly shuffles board, management following resignation of directors charged under SFA

site_title: US consumer prices slow in April; inflation still high
summary: US consumer prices slowed to a 0.3% gain in April, the smallest increase since August, as gasoline prices eased off record highs. Despite this, inflation is likely to remain high and the Federal Reserve's rate hikes may continue to cool demand. The CPI rose 8.3% in the 12 months through April, with core CPI increasing 6.2%. The slowdown is temporary, with gasoline prices rising again, driven by Russia's war in Ukraine and global supply chain issues.

images.alt_text: The US has a demonstrated record of defanging right-wing demagogues, debunking left-wing ideologues, promoting racial justice, reversing crime waves, revitalising the political centre and reinvigorating the American ideal.

site_title: DigitalBridge to buy data centre owner Switch for US$8.38b
summary: DigitalBridge to acquire data centre owner Switch for $8.38 billion, valuing each share at $34.25. The deal, expected to close in the second half of 2022, follows a trend of consolidation in the data centre industry driven by the digital shift and strong growth outlook. This marks the latest deal in a sector where companies like CyrusOne and QTS Realty Trust have also gone private.

images.alt_text: The proposed merger comes as software companies see surging demand from businesses embracing the digitalisation that accelerated during Covid-19.

site_title: Food Empire’s net profit rises 34.4% despite challenges in Russia, Ukraine
summary: Food Empire's net profit rose 34.4% to US$9.2 million for Q1 2022, driven by higher average selling prices and lower advertising expenses. Revenue increased 7.6% to US$82.6 million, despite challenges in Russia and Ukraine markets due to ongoing conflict. The group expects higher costs due to record freight rates and raw material prices, but maintains a positive outlook for its other markets, including Vietnam, Malaysia, and India.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
富旺朝控股（Food Empire）执行主席陈远昭。Tan Wang Cheow
Food Empire not facing any going concern issues from Russia-Ukraine conflict
Food Empire's auditors highlight impact of Russia-Ukraine crisis on company
Steps taken to mitigate situation in affected markets Russia and Ukraine: Food Empire

site_title: Sri Lanka central bank chief threatens to quit amid tumult
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank chief, Nandalal Weerasinghe, threatened to quit amid the country's worsening economic crisis, citing a lack of political stability. Weerasinghe imposed capital controls and warned that the central bank may print more money if revenue growth fails, exacerbating inflation. The IMF expressed concerns about the violence and technical discussions to resume once a new government is formed. Weerasinghe's resignation could slow IMF talks and hinder debt restructuring efforts. The country faces a dire shortage of dollars and needs a finance minister to implement essential steps.

images.alt_text: “This is the time for all Sri Lankans to join hands as one, to overcome the economic, social and political challenges,” President Gotabaya Rajapaksa said on Twitter.

site_title: Malaysia's Kimanis crude output falls on technical issues: sources
summary: Malaysia's Kimanis crude oil production has dropped due to technical issues at the Gumusut-Kakap and Malikai deepwater fields, which produce the country's key export crude grade. The issues occurred unexpectedly, just before a scheduled maintenance at the Sabah Oil and Gas Terminal, forcing operator Shell to reduce output further. The fields have a combined output of 170,000 barrels per day at peak, and some cargoes scheduled to load in May may have to be deferred.

site_title: Foreign buyers return to property market in April, after Q1 pullback
summary: Foreign buyers of non-landed private homes in Singapore saw a rebound in April, with 93 transactions, up from 51 units in March, as quarantine-free travel resumed. Despite a 30% Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD), buyers from Malaysia, India, the US, and Indonesia increased, with China maintaining its lead. Analysts expect a gradual increase in foreign demand as the market recovers, with a potential share of 6% of total sales by the end of the year, driven by a flight to safety amid global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Price growth of private homes slows in Q1 after cooling measures, even as levels hit new high
Going forward, Huttons expects the opening up of borders to boost the luxury market in the coming quarters.
CONDOMINIUM resale prices in Singapore are up for the 21st straight month to rise 0.7 per cent in April, as compared to prices in March.

site_title: China to use various policy tools to support employment
summary: China will use various policy tools to support employment and stabilize the economy, prioritizing employment amid a near 2-year high jobless rate of 5.8% in March. The government will exempt interest payments on student loans, allocate 50 billion yuan in renewable energy subsidies, and expand infrastructure investments through real estate investment trusts. The China Securities Regulatory Commission will launch a special corporate financing scheme to support private firms with good prospects and competitive technology. The government aims to ensure price stability, grain output, and goods supplies.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang warned of a "complicated and grave" employment situation as the country imposes sweeping lockdowns to contain Covid outbreaks.

site_title: UK rejects EU proposals to resolve Northern Ireland trade dispute
summary: The UK has rejected EU proposals to resolve a standoff over post-Brexit trade rules for Northern Ireland, saying it will not shy away from taking direct action to protect the region's peace and stability. The EU had offered to ease customs checks, but the UK's Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said it failed to address the core problem. The UK may now legislate to ditch checks on goods and disregard EU rules, prompting concerns across Europe and in Washington about a potential trade war.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

Britain said on Tuesday it would take all necessary steps to protect peace in Northern Ireland as it urged the European Union to show new imagination in talks to resolve problems with post-Brexit trading rules.

site_title: As Marcos Jr claims victory in Philippine polls, uncertainty remains over direction country will take
summary: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. claimed victory in the Philippine presidential election, securing over 56% of valid votes. Despite initial optimism, uncertainty remains about the direction the country will take under his leadership. Critics express concerns over the potential return to authoritarian rule and the lack of a concrete policy blueprint. The election has had a significant impact on the country's stock market, with a 3.14% decline on the day after the vote. Marcos Jr. has stated he wants to be judged by his actions, not his late father's legacy, and faces significant domestic challenges, including high public debt and unemployment rates.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
“I will go riding on a motorcycle and roam around...and I’ll search for drug peddlers, shoot them and kill them,” he said.

site_title: Crypto startup Moralis raises US$40m in fresh funding
summary: Moralis, a blockchain platform provider, has raised US$40 million in Series A funding despite slumping crypto prices. The company, valued at US$215 million, aims to make building on blockchain more accessible to non-technical users. Investors include Coinbase Ventures, EQT Ventures, and Fabric Ventures. Moralis plans to utilize the funding to help build out Web3, a decentralized internet vision. Despite investor concerns over the crypto market, Moralis CEO Ivan Liljeqvist believes Web3 can democratize the internet, reducing reliance on intermediaries.

site_title: S$500,000 raised for Breast Cancer Foundation
summary: The Breast Cancer Foundation (BCF) held its 8th annual Pink Charity Golf tournament, raising S$500,000, including a matching grant from Tote Board. The event, which took place at the Tanah Merah Country Club, also officially opened the first Breast Cancer Centre (BCC) in Sin Ming Avenue. Men's Champion James Lye and Women's Champion Stephanie Bradshaw were among the golf enthusiasts who participated in the tournament to support breast cancer awareness. The BCF aims to promote its mission of being a leader in breast-cancer support in Singapore through the BCC's communal space and activities.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: No quiet retirement for Philippines' Duterte when Marcos takes over presidency
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte's quiet retirement appears unlikely as he hands over to successor Ferdinand Marcos Jr. Despite efforts to put him on trial for thousands of killings in his "war on drugs," Marcos is unlikely to risk burning crucial bridges by allowing the International Criminal Court to investigate. Duterte, 77, will lose his legal immunity once he retires, but has vowed to continue his anti-drug efforts as a private citizen, sparking concerns from human rights groups and critics.

images.alt_text: The son of the disgraced late Philippines dictator Ferdinand Marcos vowed on Tuesday to work for all people after his stunning election victory, and told the world to judge him by his presidency, not his family’s past.

site_title: EU drafts US$205b plan to wean itself off Russian fuels
summary: The European Union is drafting a $205 billion plan to end its dependency on Russian fossil fuels by 2027, bolstering renewables and energy savings goals. The EU will raise its clean energy target to 45% by 2030 and boost its energy-efficiency goal, aiming to save 80 billion euros on gas, 12 billion euros on oil, and 1.7 billion euros on coal imports annually. The plan includes a target of 10 million tons of domestic renewable hydrogen production and 10 million tons of renewable hydrogen imports by 2030, and will outline contingency plans in case Russia cuts off gas.

site_title: Can we still be optimistic about America?
summary: The US faces widespread pessimism, driven by various forms of pessimism including progressive, conservative, Afropessimism, and middle-class pessimism. The country is experiencing alarming rates of overdose deaths, murders, carjackings, and mental health decline, as well as economic inequality. Despite these challenges, the author remains optimistic, citing the US's demonstrated record of addressing its problems through defanging demagogues, promoting racial justice, and revitalizing the political center. The author notes that while authoritarian regimes like China and Russia are brittle, the US has the power to bend and adapt, ultimately growing stronger through its flaws.

images.alt_text: US Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts has ordered a probe into the leak of the draft opinion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.35 points to 1,555.93 on Wednesday, driven by a higher volume of 2.402 billion lots worth RM1.908 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 443 to 440. This marks the second consecutive day of gains for the Malaysian stock market.

site_title: Malaysia central bank’s surprise rate hike will dampen market sentiment: economists
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, raised its overnight policy rate by 25 basis points to 2% in a surprise move, citing inflationary pressure. The decision, made at its third monetary policy meeting of the year, is expected to dampen market sentiment and slow down the pace of economic recovery. Economists predict that the higher interest rate will make borrowing more expensive for corporate and consumer borrowers, potentially hindering investment and business expansion plans.

images.alt_text: Market observers expect Bank Negara to maintain the benchmark interest rate to support Malaysia's economic growth.

site_title: Woman fined S$100,000 for false trading of Aspial Corp, Far East Orchard shares
summary: Tan Su Lan, a woman, was fined S$100,000 by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for false trading in Aspial Corp and Far East Orchard shares in 2016. She purchased shares near trading sessions, artificially raising closing prices, which impacted her pledged collateral. Tan admitted liability and paid the civil penalty, acknowledging that her reckless trading behavior distorted market prices and affected the fair functioning of Singapore's capital markets.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The traders had executed orders from their client, Indonesian tycoon Kris Wiluan, to purchase shares of now-collapsed oil services firm KS Energy, to create a false or misleading appearance for the counter’s share price.
Aspial's proposed privatisation of World Class Global unit gets shareholders' nod
FEO “is gearing up to recapture pent-up travel demands” as international borders reopen, said chief executive Alan Tang.

site_title: China calls WHO chief 'irresponsible' for saying zero-Covid strategy 'not sustainable'
summary: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus described China's zero-Covid strategy as "not sustainable" and called for a change in approach. China responded, labeling his comments as "irresponsible" and criticizing the WHO for being too close to the country. The zero-Covid policy has placed hundreds of millions under movement restrictions, causing economic damage and widespread frustration. China's leaders have threatened action against critics, while residents express resentment through social media, citing difficulties sourcing food, poor healthcare access, and unsanitary quarantine conditions.

images.alt_text: Workers deliver items of food to residents at a neighbourhood under lockdown in Shanghai, on May 7.

site_title: Japan's Takeda forecasts rebound despite full-year profit drop
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical reported a 9.5% drop in 12-month operating profit to 461 billion yen, despite forecasting a rebound for the current year to 520 billion yen. The company's operating profit for the previous year was 509.27 billion yen. The forecast comes after the company began domestic production of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Novavax. Takeda has been under pressure to reduce debt and build its pipeline after the loss of patent protection for certain drugs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on May 11, 2022, as investors awaited US inflation data. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.97%, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.75%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.27%. These gains came ahead of key US inflation data, with investors taking a cautious stance.

site_title: Morgan Stanley warns 2022 global economic growth to be less than half of 2021
summary: Morgan Stanley forecasts global economic growth to be less than half of 2021, at 2.9%, due to risks from the Russia-Ukraine conflict and Covid-19 surge in China, as central banks tighten monetary policy to control record high inflation. The brokerage expects a global deceleration driven by waning fiscal stimulus, tightening monetary policy, and supply chain frictions, with only Japan and India expected to experience minimal slowing.

images.alt_text: The Chinese market’s “potential final leg is likely to be bumpy” due to Covid-induced lockdowns and a gloomier global outlook, Morgan Stanley strategists led by Laura Wang wrote in a note.

site_title: Prime US Reit Q1 net property income up 10.4% to US$25.4m, as leasing activity more than doubles
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 10.4% increase in net property income to US$25.4 million for Q1 2022, driven by leasing activity that more than doubled, with renewals making up the majority. The real estate investment trust (Reit) added 171,747 sq ft of leases at a positive rental reversion of 3.4%. Gross revenue rose 13.6% to US$40.8 million.

images.alt_text: Venga (எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்)
Prime US Reit posts 0.9% rise in H2 DPU to US$0.0345

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Olivia Lum Ooi Lin may face legal action as the Hyflux group, which she co-founded, has lodged a pre-emptive lawsuit against her. The group and its liquidators claim she may be liable for compensation if the plaintiffs proceed with their claims.

Jubilee Bridge with the Central Business District (CBD) skyline shot from outside Esplanade on February 18, 2022.

site_title: International arbitration shaping cryptocurrency landscape
summary: International arbitration is increasingly shaping the cryptocurrency landscape due to disputes over valuation, ownership, and transactions. The volatility of cryptocurrencies and cross-border nature of disputes make it challenging to resolve disputes. Emergency arbitration mechanisms, such as the Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC), are gaining recognition for preserving the status quo pending a final award. The international enforceability of arbitration awards is also becoming more prominent, with over 150 countries recognizing the New York Convention. Effective cross-border strategies and prevention of disputes are key to resolving crypto disputes, with international arbitration cases helping to shape the dynamic crypto landscape.

images.alt_text: English law - another great trade for Singapore and the UK
Bored Ape Yacht Club #4418, one of a set of 10,000 NFTs representing cartoon apes, made by the US-based company Yuga Labs.

site_title: Lagarde suggests ECB rate hike could come as soon as July
summary: European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde hinted at raising interest rates as soon as July to combat soaring inflation in the eurozone, which reached 7.5% in April, its highest level in history. The ECB may end its stimulus bond-buying scheme in the third quarter and raise rates "only a few weeks" later. This would be the ECB's first interest rate hike in over a decade, following the lead of the US Federal Reserve and other major central banks.

images.alt_text: Finland's central bank chief Olli Rehn said on Monday the ECB would have to raise its key interest rate as soon as July, as the bloc battles soaring inflation.

site_title: Morgan Stanley cuts India growth forecasts on inflation, global slowdown
summary: Morgan Stanley lowered India's economic growth forecasts for fiscal 2023 and 2024, citing a global slowdown, surging oil prices, and weak domestic demand. The revised estimates predict 7.6% GDP growth for 2023 and 6.7% for 2024, 30 basis points lower than previous estimates. Higher inflation, tighter financial conditions, and weaker consumer demand are expected to impact the economy, with inflation and the current account deficit likely to worsen due to broad-based price pressures and record-high commodity prices.

site_title: Japan's economy to suffer Q1 slump on lower consumption
summary: Japan's economy likely contracted in Q1 due to lingering Covid-19 fallout, with a Reuters poll showing a 1.8% annualized decline in GDP. Private consumption fell 0.5% due to the Omicron outbreak and weak exports contributed to a 0.3% drop in external demand. Despite a moderate recovery expected in Q2, the outlook remains clouded by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and slowing global growth.

images.alt_text: Shirakawasuji street in Kyoto during Golden Week holidays. With the lifting of internal virus restrictions domestic tourists are starting to travel around again.

site_title: China’s commodities consumption to slow, no longer ‘big bulls’, says analyst Mistry
summary: China's commodities consumption is expected to slow due to an economic slowdown and the country's pursuit of a zero-Covid policy, according to analyst Dorab Mistry. This shift in demand has led to a decline in prices for commodities such as palm oil, with Mistry forecasting a drop to RM4,000 a tonne by September. Despite this, Mistry maintains his forecast for Malaysia's palm oil production and Indonesia's production increase. The analyst also expects interest rates to rise and production to pick up once the Indonesian ban on palm oil exports is relaxed and the Ukraine conflict is resolved.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's "unpredictable" palm oil export policies may help Malaysia emerge as the dominant supplier to India, the world's top buyer of the edible oil.

site_title: Zoom urged by rights groups to rule out 'creepy' AI emotion tech
summary: Human rights groups have urged video-conferencing company Zoom to scrap research on integrating emotion recognition tools into its products, citing concerns over privacy infringement and perpetuation of discrimination. Over 25 rights groups, including the ACLU, have sent a joint letter to Zoom CEO Eric Yuan, stating the technology is inaccurate and threatens basic rights. The tools, which use AI to scan facial movements and speech, could be used to draw conclusions about people's mood, sparking fears of misuse. Zoom has not yet responded to the letter.

site_title: Vicom posts 3% uptick in Q1 profit, notes ‘considerable’ inflationary pressures
summary: Vicom, a mainboard-listed vehicle inspection company, reported a 3% increase in Q1 profit after tax and minority interest to S$6.3 million, driven by higher operating profit and a 8.1% rise in revenue to S$26 million. The company attributed the growth to a recovery in the Singapore economy, particularly in its non-vehicle testing business. Vicom maintained a healthy cash balance of S$78.9 million, supporting its business growth and opportunities.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

The trade-related cluster, which led the recovery in 2021, is likely to see its contribution to GDP ease this year as it expands more slowly amid a weaker external environment, said MAS.
Instead, the recovery in the domestic-oriented and travel-related sectors is expected to gather pace now that Singapore has removed most of its Covid-19 restrictions.
Vicom FY2021 net profit up 1.2% to S$24.8 million
This was the first tender  exercise to include the new 110kw power categorisation for EVs, which was announced in March.
