site_title: South Korea’s Yoon says security situation tense amid talk of North Korea’s possible nuclear test
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol described the security situation on the Korean peninsula as "tense" due to possible North Korea nuclear tests. He urged officials to remain vigilant to respond effectively. Yoon also stated that the economy is facing a difficult situation, with price growth being the biggest problem.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip on Wednesday in mixed Asia trading; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% or 8.12 points to close at 3,226.07 points on Wednesday, extending its losing streak. Trading was mixed across Asia, with China's Inflation data showing benign inflation, driving gains in Mainland China stocks. Meanwhile, Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng rose 0.2% and 1%, respectively, while South Korea's Kospi dipped 0.2%. DFI Retail Group was the top performer on the STI, rising 2.7%, while Mapletree Commercial Trust fell 2.2%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Most key Asian markets also closed lower.

site_title: Row of Geylang Road shophouses up for sale with S$50m reserve price
summary: A row of 7 shophouses on Geylang Road in Singapore is up for sale with a reserve price of S$50 million. The freehold site spans 10,520 square feet and is zoned for commercial use, allowing foreigners to acquire the property without additional buyer stamp duty. The shophouses have a total built-up floor area of 18,072 sq ft and offer a "stable rental income stream" with permitted trade uses. The expression of interest exercise closes on June 18, 2022, presenting a potential redevelopment opportunity with steady rental income.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The Chinatown shophouses (left) are located along 20 Trengganu Street, while the freehold site (right) is located at 118 Killiney Road.

site_title: 4 floors at 20 Cecil St on the market at S$75.9m
summary: A portfolio of 22 strata units across four levels at 20 Cecil Street in Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$75.9 million, translating to approximately S$3,100 per square foot. The office building, known as PLUS, has direct access from Raffles Place MRT station and is zoned for "Commercial" use. The sale comes after the government restricted strata subdivision of commercial properties in central areas, making prime strata office spaces increasingly scarce.

images.alt_text: The 7 shophouses each have 2 floors and sit on a freehold site spanning 10,520 square feet zoned for commercial use.

site_title: Thai economic recovery hampered by lagging tourism: finance minister
summary: Thailand's economic recovery is being hindered by a gradual tourism recovery, according to Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith. The country received about 700,000 visitors in the first 4 months of 2022, and the Tourism Authority of Thailand is targeting 5-15 million arrivals this year. Exports grew 15% in the first 3 months of 2022, supporting the economy. The government aims to maintain fiscal and financial stability while supporting the recovery, with an inflation forecast of 3.5-5.5% and an export growth outlook of 3-5.5% for the year.

site_title: Timeline of Hyflux: From market listing to liquidation
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, was placed under judicial management in November 2020 after failing to secure a white knight despite a debt moratorium for nearly two years. The company's financial difficulties stemmed from its energy business venture, Tuaspring desalination plant, which incurred losses due to low electricity prices. Hyflux filed for bankruptcy protection in May 2018 and received an automatic 30-day moratorium. The company's founder, Olivia Lum, was charged with disclosure-related offenses, and several former directors were also charged. Hyflux was subsequently wound up in July 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises ahead of US inflation data
summary: The Nikkei share average rose 0.18% to close at 26,213.64, driven by investors seeking stocks with positive outlooks ahead of US inflation data. Despite gains, concerns over US consumer prices and Toyota's profit decline limited gains. Other notable movers included Sony Group's 2.1% rise and Nintendo's 3.25% gain. The broader Topix fell 0.60% due to Toyota's decline.

images.alt_text: The Chinese market’s “potential final leg is likely to be bumpy” due to Covid-induced lockdowns and a gloomier global outlook, Morgan Stanley strategists led by Laura Wang wrote in a note.
Asian stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, following a volatile day on Wall Street.

site_title: Panasonic keeps profit outlook flat amid price rises, shortages
summary: Panasonic expects flat operating profit growth this business year due to component shortages and rising material costs. The company forecasts 360 billion yen in operating profit, 5.9% lower than forecasted 382.7 billion yen. Component shortages, exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic and strict lockdowns in China, pose a risk to earnings. Panasonic also faces rising materials costs, particularly for metals used in electric vehicle production, and plans to mitigate these costs through "price revisions" and "rationalisation".

site_title: Thomson View set for en bloc relaunch at unchanged S$950m guide price
summary: Thomson View Condominium is set for an en bloc relaunch at an unchanged S$950 million guide price, following its initial unsuccessful launch in 2021 due to market cooling measures. The 200-unit condominium, completed in 1987, is located in District 20 with nearby amenities and schools. A pre-application feasibility study has been submitted to the Land Transport Authority, pending approval. The relaunch is expected to generate significant interest among prospective home buyers, with the tender closing on June 8, 2022.

images.alt_text: Thomson View up for collective sale again with S$950m reserve price

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend recovery at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on May 11, extending a recovery from sharp losses at the beginning of the week. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.6% to 7,283.74 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices rose 0.3% and 1.2% respectively. The recovery is attributed to gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Taiwan central bank flags 'timely' tightening of monetary policy
summary: Taiwan's central bank announced it will tighten monetary policy in a timely manner, considering inflation outlook, domestic Covid-19 outbreak, and major economies' moves. This comes after the central bank raised its benchmark interest rate in March, citing concerns about inflation driven by supply chain disruptions from the Ukraine war. Taiwan's inflation remains mild, but the central bank will adjust monetary policy accordingly, taking into account domestic inflation and industry impact. The next rate setting meeting is scheduled for June 16.

site_title: BlackRock’s star trader goes short as hedge fund loss mounts
summary: BlackRock's star trader, Alister Hibbert, has turned bearish amid the hedge fund's worst-ever losses, with its Strategic Equity Hedge Fund declining 13% in 2022. This marks a shift in global markets as soaring inflation forces interest rate hikes, leading to a selloff in growth stocks. Hibbert's reversal to a net short position is a significant move, contrasting his previous 35% net long position at the end of last year.

images.alt_text: BlackRock said on Tuesday it expected to support fewer shareholder resolutions on issues such as climate change in the current season of annual general meetings, as many proposals were too prescriptive.
The Middle East’s thriving domestic markets and vibrant IPO scene, which has sidestepped a global slowdown in listings, is bringing a growing cohort of international funds to local exchanges.
BlackRock is now recommending a neutral stance on Chinese stocks and bonds as the response to the pandemic takes a growing toll.

site_title: Google paying more than 300 EU publishers for news, more to come
summary: Google has signed deals to pay more than 300 European publishers, including Der Spiegel and Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, for their news content. The agreements follow landmark EU copyright rules requiring online platforms to pay for using their work. A new tool will be launched to make offers to thousands more publishers, starting in Germany and Hungary, and rolling out to other EU countries. This move aims to address criticism from news publishers who have urged governments to ensure online platforms pay fair remuneration for their content.

images.alt_text: Dating apps maker Match Group sued Alphabet's Google on Monday, calling the action a "last resort" to prevent Tinder and its other apps from being booted off the Play store for refusing to share up to 30 per cent of their sales.

site_title: Allianz sets aside another 1.9 billion euros over fund debacle
summary: Allianz, a German insurance company, has set aside an additional 1.9 billion euros to cover potential losses from US regulatory investigations into a multibillion-dollar trading debacle at its funds arm. This provision reduces the company's first-quarter net profit to 600 million euros, lower than the 1.9 billion euros analysts had expected. The move comes on top of 3.7 billion euros set aside in February for litigation and US regulatory investigations.

images.alt_text: Allianz hedge fund implosion results in 3.7b euro charge

The Felicity Ace, transporting Porsche, Audi, Lamborghini and other VW Group cars, sank off the coast of Portugal’s Azores after being battered by waves and leaning 45 degrees to its starboard side, the ship’s operator said at the time.

site_title: Ukraine diverts some Russian gas flows, claims battlefield gains
summary: Ukraine has diverted some Russian gas flows, citing the presence of occupying forces, while reporting battlefield gains against invading Russian forces. This move could signal a shift in the war's momentum, as Ukraine recaptured four settlements north of Kharkiv and pushed Russian forces out of the city. Ukrainian troops have held out against assaults in the eastern Donbas region, and President Volodymyr Zelenskiy urged caution against excessive emotions. Meanwhile, Russia continues to bombard Ukrainian cities and targets, with US intelligence suggesting a long conflict and potential Russian victory in Donbas may not end the war.

images.alt_text: 3D-printed natural gas pipes are placed on displayed EU and Russian flags in this illustration.

site_title: Artists of colour and women soar at Christie’s contemporary sale
summary: Christie's contemporary sale saw artists of color and women achieve strong prices, defying the traditional dominance of established artists. Works by Black artists like Amoako Boafo and Reggie Burrows Hodges sold for over their estimates, with Boafo's "Yellow Dress" selling for $819,000 and Hodges' "Intersection of Color: Experience" selling for $706,000. Women artists, including Shara Hughes and Ewa Juszkiewicz, also fared well, with Hughes' landscape selling for $2.9 million and Juszkiewicz's portrait selling for $1.6 million. The sale highlighted the growing demand for artists of color and the increasing recognition of their contributions to the art canon.

images.alt_text: On Monday night, a 58 year-old silkscreen by Andy Warhol sold at Christie's for a record US$195 million.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post longest losing streak in 9 months, bond yields drop
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on May 11, logging their longest losing streak in 9 months, with the Kospi index falling 0.17% to 2,592.27. The benchmark bond yield dropped amid expectations of limited bond issuance to finance the country's extra budget. Despite Chinese stocks rising, investors remain cautious ahead of US inflation data due later in the day. The won ended little changed, and foreign investors sold 288 billion won worth of shares.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 14.25 points, or 0.55 per cent, at 2,596.56, after dropping as much as 2.21 per cent.

site_title: Sea prepares move into Indonesia’s insurance sector: FT
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based tech company, is preparing to enter Indonesia's insurance sector through an acquisition of Asuransi Mega Pratama. This move follows Sea's recent digital bank licence acquisitions in Malaysia and Singapore. Sea's business partner, Andy Indigo, holds a 50% stake in its Indonesian digital payments arm, and has co-invested in Indonesian bank Bank Kesejahteraan Ekonomi. The acquisition aims to expand Sea's presence in the region and compete with rivals in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Sri Lanka's president warns of racial tension amid economic crisis
summary: Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has warned of racial tension amid the country's economic crisis, urging citizens to reject attempts to foment disharmony. Clashes have broken out in many areas, resulting in eight deaths, despite the resignation of his brother as prime minister and a curfew. The president's warning comes as the country faces a devastating economic crisis, with reserves of only $50 million, leading to shortages of food, fuel, and medicine. Analysts say the president can be impeached if he refuses to step down, but the opposition lacks the necessary majority in parliament.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators showed no sign they would back down, even after scores were injured when government supporters were bussed into Colombo on Monday, and attacked protesters with sticks and clubs.

site_title: Increasing monetary policy flexibility with a retail CBDC
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has launched "Project Orchid," a pilot for a retail Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) despite initial concerns about competition from foreign digital currencies. A retail CBDC could provide greater monetary policy independence, allowing the MAS to set interest rates and influence consumer behavior. This is crucial in Singapore's small and open economy, where the central bank struggles to balance inflation and exchange rate stability. The interest-bearing feature of a retail CBDC would also enable the MAS to use it as a second monetary policy tool to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: How central banks are moving into e-money

site_title: Myanmar junta charges central bank ex-deputy governor with corruption
summary: The Myanmar junta has charged Bo Bo Nge, a former central bank deputy governor close to ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi, with corruption. The charge stems from alleged tax evasion and "causing losses" to the government, totaling around $1.4 million. Nge was detained after the coup and faces a maximum 15-year jail term if convicted. The prosecution is the latest in a series of charges against Su Kyi's associates, with the Anti-Corruption Commission also pursuing several charges against her.

images.alt_text: ENEOS is the latest energy giant to retreat from the South-east Asian country, whose military has waged a widespread crackdown on dissent since it ousted and detained civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi last year.

MALAYSIA'S state energy firm Petronas on Friday (Apr 29) said it has withdrawn from Blocks M12, M13 and M14 located in the Yetagun gas field off Myanmar, the latest exit by a major energy company since last year's military coup.

site_title: A Zero Trust approach to cyber defence for banks
summary: Banks and financial institutions must adopt a "never trust, always verify" approach to security in response to evolving threats, according to CyberArk's 2022 Identity Security Threat Landscape report. The Singapore Parliament has passed a bill making financial institutions liable for cyberattacks, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore has amended its technology risk management guide to require financial institutions to implement a zero-trust mindset and secure privileged accounts. This includes adopting zero-trust principles, privileged access management, and multi-factor authentication to prevent lateral spread of attacks and protect sensitive data.

images.alt_text: Cyberthreats will only grow in prominence and threat actors will become more emboldened.

site_title: Toyota Q4 operating profit skids 33%, misses estimate
summary: Toyota reported a 33% slump in fourth-quarter operating profit to 463.8 billion yen, missing estimates. The yen's depreciation and solid demand failed to offset production disruptions caused by a global chip shortage and China's Covid-19 restrictions. Toyota forecast a 20% decline in operating profit to 2.4 trillion yen for the new fiscal year, below expectations. The company cut its global production target and suspended operations at 14 domestic factories due to the lockdown in China, impacting suppliers. Rising raw material costs and supply chain disruptions continue to pressure profitability.

site_title: UK carbon capture startup raises US$150m to scale tech
summary: A UK-based startup, Carbon Clean Solutions, has raised $150 million to scale its carbon capture technology, which can capture up to 97% of CO2 from industrial sites. The company, backed by Chevron, Saudi Arabian Oil, and Samsung Group, aims to deploy its technology globally to slow global temperature rise. With a decade of development, the startup plans to lower CO2 costs to $30 per ton, aiming to capture 30,000 tons of CO2 annually in partnership with Chevron.

images.alt_text: A view shows an area near the pond remaining of Lake Sawa, due to climate change-induced drought, in Samawa city, Iraq May 1, 2022.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars get respite, but charts stay bleak
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced a brief respite from selling pressure on Wednesday, with the Aussie at US$0.6957 and the kiwi at US$0.6305, ahead of US inflation data. However, the chart outlook remains bleak, with analysts expecting core prices to ease to 6.0% and potential rate hikes by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Aussie's decline is linked to weak global growth, rising stagflation risks, and Chinese lockdowns, with some analysts predicting a potential drop to US$0.6760.

site_title: Indonesia's flip-flops give Malaysia edge in top palm oil market India
summary: Malaysia is poised to become the dominant supplier of palm oil to India, the world's top buyer, due to Indonesia's unpredictable export policies. Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producer, has implemented a ban on exports, which has pushed Indian consumers to increase their dependence on Malaysia. To capitalize on the situation, Malaysia has cut palm oil export taxes by up to half, potentially reducing Indonesia's share of palm oil exports to India from 75% to 35%.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA'S commodities ministry has proposed cutting the export tax on palm oil by as much as half to help fill a global edible oil shortage and grow the market share of the world's second-largest palm oil producer.

site_title: SE Asia Islamic banking market set to see strong growth in next 3 years: S&P Global
summary: The Islamic banking market in Southeast Asia is expected to post a compound annual growth rate of 8% over the next three years, driven by favorable policy environments in Malaysia and Indonesia, which hold 96% of the region's Islamic banking assets. Malaysian Islamic banks are forecast to grow at 6-8% and account for 45% of commercial banking loan books by 2026, while Indonesian Islamic banks are expected to post 12-14% credit growth. The sector may face challenges when current loan reliefs are lifted, particularly in Malaysia, but is also expected to integrate environmental, social, and corporate governance considerations.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Islamic finance deals have the best start ever with oil up 40%
The future is bright for Islamic banking in Asean

site_title: Renewable energy to grow to new record in 2022: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a new record for renewable power capacity in 2022, driven by solar energy, which will account for 60% of growth. A record 295 gigawatts of new renewable capacity was added in 2021, and 320 gigawatts are expected to be installed this year. However, the IEA warns that renewable power's global growth may lose momentum in 2023 if current policies are not strengthened, with solar energy growth offset by a 40% drop in hydropower expansion.

images.alt_text: Solar power panels
A new solar farm at Tuas industrial estate can power about 4,700 4-room Housing Board flats a year.

site_title: Global coordination needed to help rebuild Ukraine
summary: Ukraine's reconstruction after the Russia-Ukraine war is likely to require hundreds of billions of dollars, with international coordination crucial to efficient funding. The international community has pledged significant aid, including €2bn from the European Investment Bank, $3bn from the World Bank, and $1.4bn from the International Monetary Fund. However, Ukraine estimates it will need $5bn per month, and the country faces harsh economic realities. Reparations from Russia could be a potential source of funds, but this is a contentious issue. The international community must navigate issues of conditionality and debt sustainability in providing aid to Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Financial aid for Ukraine critical to keep services working
EU officials mull using sanctioned Russians' assets for Ukraine

site_title: The Place Holdings to buy stakes in Beijing LED sky screen operations for S$47m
summary: The Place Holdings has proposed buying a 51% stake in two companies involved in the operations of an LED sky screen in Beijing, China, for around S$47 million. The company aims to expand its integrated media-related business and develop new commercial opportunities, including metaverse connections and digital economy propositions. The acquisition is expected to increase earnings per share, with post-acquisition earnings per share projected at 0.21 Singapore cent. The deal is part of The Place Holdings' plan to push the boundaries of digital media and accelerate Singapore's digitisation roadmap.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The Place Holdings says it is in talks on projects and opportunities to explain share price spike
The Place Holdings to jointly develop a residential-commercial project in Tanah Merah
The Place Holdings appoints new chief strategy officer

site_title: Vietnam's Vinfast IPO may be delayed to 2023 on market uncertainty
summary: Vietnam's VinFast auto unit's initial public offering (IPO) may be delayed to 2023 due to market uncertainty, according to the company's chairman, Pham Nhat Vuong. The IPO was initially set for the fourth quarter of 2022, but Vuong stated that VinFast is prioritizing spending on the business and aims to sell 750,000 cars in 2026, with 150,000 cars to be produced in North Carolina. The company is also seeking financing from the US government to support its expansion.

images.alt_text: Viet carmaker VinFast's planned US IPO more than just a lofty aspiration

site_title: Asia, emerging market stocks in bear market’s late stage: Morgan Stanley
summary: Asia and emerging market stocks are entering the late stages of a bear market, but a turnaround is unlikely due to earnings and valuations. Morgan Stanley maintains a neutral view, citing risks and potential downside. The Chinese market is expected to experience a "bumpy" final leg due to Covid-induced lockdowns and a gloomier global outlook. The firm prefers Japan and countries that export commodities or benefit from higher interest rates.

site_title: Flex sharpens medical device focus in Singapore, looks to 5G for future of manufacturing
summary: Manufacturer Flex plans to grow its employee count at its Singapore Kallang site by 10% by end-2022, up from 700 employees. The site is focusing on medical devices, including point-of-care testing, surgical devices, and medical wearables, driven by the rising demand for at-home care with an ageing population. Flex aims to capitalize on regional trends and leverage 5G technology to enhance its manufacturing capabilities.

images.alt_text: PHOTO: Tackling crippling supply chain challenges would require businesses to shift away from existing models that relied on lean inventories and just-in-time delivery.

site_title: Asia: Stocks open mixed as investors fret over oil prices
summary: Asian stocks opened mixed on Wednesday following a volatile day on Wall Street, amid concerns over surging inflation and oil prices. The region's equities have been on a rollercoaster ride due to inflationary pressures, Russia's war in Ukraine, and China's Covid-19 lockdowns affecting the global supply chain. Despite a temporary dip in oil prices, investors remain cautious, with many preparing for a recession.

site_title: Game over: EA, Fifa part ways after decades-long partnership
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) is ending its nearly 3-decade partnership with FIFA after the soccer governing body rejected an 8-year exclusivity deal. EA will pull the plug on its successful FIFA video-game franchise, which has generated billions of dollars in sales. FIFA will instead launch new football video games developed by third-party studios and publishers. EA will continue to develop a rebranded version of the game, EA Sports FC, with licensing deals for top clubs and leagues.

images.alt_text: Electronic Arts reported revenue for the current quarter that missed analysts' estimates, as the video game publisher continues to feel the effects of an industry-wide downturn and the flop of last fall's Battlefield game.
Fifa launches its own football streaming platform

site_title: EA revenue forecast misses estimates following Battlefield flop
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) reported revenue for the current quarter that missed analysts' estimates, falling short of $1.45 billion. The company attributed the shortfall to industry-wide downturns and the poor reception of its recent game, Battlefield 2042. Despite this, EA expressed confidence in its future growth, citing innovation and engagement in its live services. The company also announced the end of its Fifa licensing agreement and plans to release new titles, including Madden NFL and Star Wars games.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with the Electronic Arts logo is seen in front of a displayed "Battlefield 2042" logo in this illustration taken September 16, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Electronic Arts is parting ways with world soccer governing body Fifa after a near 3-decade partnership and pulling the plug on one of the world's most successful video-game franchises that has raked in billions of dollars in sales.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly down
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly down, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.62% to 19,511.80. The decline follows losses on Wall Street amid fears of economic risks from surging inflation. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.32% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.61%.

site_title: In Kyiv, boxing gyms offer chance to ease war stress
summary: Boxing gyms in Kyiv, Ukraine, offer a stress-relieving outlet for amateur boxers amidst the ongoing war. The All Stars Boxing Club provides a space for boxers to release pent-up emotions through intense workouts, combining hip-hop music with heavy bag punching. Participants, including a 38-year-old employee of the International Red Cross, report that boxing helps alleviate stress and emotional tension, allowing them to "blow off steam" during a time of restricted movement and curfews.

images.alt_text: Amateur boxers train at the All Stars Boxing Club in the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv on May 10, 2022. - The sound of hip hop mixes with the dull thuds of fists walloping heavy bags, as a group of boxers unleash combinations and burn off weeks of pent up stress in the Ukrainian capital. (Photo by Sergei SUPINSKY / AFP)

Local resident and social worker Oksana Khvostenko, 47, stands near her house, which was heavily damaged during Ukraine-Russia conflict in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine April 29, 2022. REUTERS/Alexander Ermochenko

site_title: Less than 20% of Asia’s listed food buyers recognise animal protein sourcing risks: study
summary: A study by Asia Research and Engagement found that less than 20% of Asia's listed food buyers recognize animal protein sourcing risks. Despite 70% providing food safety management disclosure and 62% acknowledging responsible sourcing as a business issue, only 16% have a responsible sourcing policy in place. This indicates that Asian food companies are lagging behind global players in addressing animal protein sourcing risks, with many failing to acknowledge the issue exists.

images.alt_text: From lab to table: Breaking the cost barrier
Temasek co-led a US$400 million funding round in Upside Foods, a producer of lab-grown meat.

site_title: Tesla ships 4,767 cars from Shanghai plant; first export since reopen
summary: Tesla shipped 4,767 cars from its Shanghai plant to Slovenia on May 11, 2022, marking the first export since the factory reopened on April 19. The shipment was part of the company's efforts to resume exports after China's zero-Covid-19 policies disrupted production and logistics in April. This move indicates Tesla's efforts to normalize its production and export operations in the region.

site_title: Gold may be losing its Midas touch
summary: Gold prices have seen a steep sell-off amid global market disarray, contradicting its traditional role as a safe-haven asset. In early 2022, gold surged 8% year-on-year, driven by the Russia-Ukraine conflict and inflation, with physical demand jumping 34% and surpassing a five-year average. However, gold's recent price drop has hit riskier assets, including equities, and appears to be losing its "Midas touch." This sell-off may be due to the current uncertain market conditions, which are typically associated with increased demand for gold.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged down on Monday as elevated US Treasury yields and a firm dollar pressured demand for greenback-priced bullion.

The dollar index pulled further away from 20-year highs on Wednesday, having already priced the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates by a half-point later in the day and by some 250 basis points (bps) by year-end.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents hit new peaks in April, with reopening likely to keep market tight
summary: Residential property rentals in Singapore reached new highs in April, with condominium rents rising 2.3% and HDB flat rents increasing 1.9%. This marks the 16th consecutive month of rent growth for condos and the 22nd consecutive month for HDB flats. The reopening of Singapore's borders is expected to keep the market tight, with some tenants booking units without viewing them and prices potentially rising 6-9% in 2022. Districts such as Kranji and Woodlands saw significant growth, while others like Alexandra and Harbourfront experienced declines.

images.alt_text: CONDOMINIUM resale prices in Singapore are up for the 21st straight month to rise 0.7 per cent in April, as compared to prices in March.
HDB rents hit new high in March; condo rents up 2.9%: SRX, 99.co
Parents should exercise care when buying homes in trust for minors.
PropNex said it is well on its way to attaining its goal of having 12,000 salespersons by end-2022.

site_title: Crypto assets shed US$800 billion in market value in a month
summary: Crypto assets lost nearly US$800 billion in market value over the past month, reaching a low of US$1.4 trillion, due to diminishing appetite for risk assets as easy monetary policy ends. Bitcoin, which makes up 40% of the crypto market, hit a 10-month low before rebounding to US$31,450. Digital asset prices slumped, mirroring a decline in equities, as investors fear aggressive interest rate hikes and decades-high inflation. The total crypto market value is now at US$2.2 trillion, down from its all-time peak of US$2.9 trillion.

images.alt_text: Bored Ape Yacht Club #4418, one of a set of 10,000 NFTs representing cartoon apes, made by the US-based company Yuga Labs.

site_title: Investors jumping into Web3 find the rules are not so simple
summary: Investors in South-east Asia are flocking to Web3, a decentralized version of the internet, with many smartest people in the region discussing the space. Funding is pouring in, with unicorn Axie Infinity emerging from Vietnam. However, investors are finding that traditional investing rules don't apply, with token-investing and quicker exits becoming common. Law firms and venture capital firms are adapting to the new landscape, with partnership agreements allowing for token investments and smaller cheque sizes to reflect the risk. Despite challenges, investors are drawn to Web3's potential for growth and the next platform shift.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
5 Questions with Coinhako's Liu Yusho
DeFi startup Treehouse clinches US$18m in seed round

site_title: As property market cools, New Zealand's recent home buyers tighten belts
summary: New Zealand's recent home buyers are tightening their belts as the country's cooling property market affects their household wealth. After paying a deposit of NZ$875,000 for a home, buyers like Aarti and Gaurav Kathuria are facing declining property values, rising mortgage rates, and increasing living costs. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has raised interest rates to combat the "unsustainable" housing market, and economists predict a 10% fall in house prices this year, which could reduce consumer spending and make it harder for recent homebuyers to repay their loans.

images.alt_text: Condominium rents have reached new heights in April after it rose 2.3 per cent during the month.

site_title: Hot stock: Yoma Strategic sees heavy trading ahead of H1 results release
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' shares surged 7% or S$0.01 to a near 2-week high of S$0.153 ahead of its May 12 interim financial results release. The company's shares traded heavily with 24.7 million shares changing hands by 10:40 am. This follows the recent acquisition of a 50% stake in MM Cars Myanmar from Mitsubishi Corporation. The group is confident in the strength of the Mitsubishi brand and business potential in Myanmar.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: China inflation exceeds forecasts as lockdowns roil supplies
summary: China's inflation exceeded forecasts in April, with producer prices rising 8% and consumer prices accelerating to 2.1%. The lockdown in Shanghai, which accounts for a fifth of China's port volume, threatens to exacerbate global supply chain pressures and inflation concerns. Economists attribute the higher-than-expected inflation to virus outbreaks, higher global commodity prices, and panic buying. Despite this, policymakers are not concerned, as the issue is seen as "benign" for the year, with room for policy action constrained by overseas economic policies and a stable yuan exchange rate.

images.alt_text: People queue to get a swab test for the Covid-19 coronavirus at a swab collection site in Beijing on May 10, 2022.

site_title: South Korea’s April unemployment rate stays at historical low for third month
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate remained at a historical low of 2.7% for the third consecutive month in April, according to government data. The country added 865,000 jobs over the past year, extending a 14th straight month of job gains. This is the lowest unemployment rate since data collection began in 1999.

site_title: Australia: Shares dragged by mining, gold firms; US inflation in focus
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 7,018.80 on Wednesday, marking a fourth consecutive decline, due to caution around US inflation data and potential interest-rate hikes. Mining and gold stocks led the declines, with Newcrest Mining and BHP Group falling 2.4% and 1.2% respectively. Bullion prices also dropped as the dollar strengthened, while healthcare stocks rose 1% as the only gainers on the benchmark.

site_title: China risks 1.6m deaths in virus 'tsunami' if Covid Zero is abandoned
summary: China risks a "tsunami" of coronavirus infections, resulting in 1.6 million deaths, if it abandons its Covid Zero policy and allows the highly-infectious Omicron variant to spread. Researchers at Fudan University found the level of immunity induced by China's March vaccination campaign would be insufficient to prevent an Omicron wave. Without restrictions, the spread of Omicron could lead to 112.2 million symptomatic cases, 5.1 million hospital admissions, and 1.6 million deaths. The World Health Organisation's director-general has called for China to rethink its zero-tolerance strategy, citing the unsustainable nature of the approach.

images.alt_text: People queue to get a swab test for the Covid-19 coronavirus at a swab collection site in Beijing on May 10, 2022.

site_title: Investree to acquire 18.4% stake in Indonesia’s Amar Bank
summary: Investree Singapore will acquire an 18.4% stake in Indonesian digital bank PT Bank Amar Indonesia (Amar Bank) from Tolaram Group for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition aims to expand access to financial services for micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in Indonesia. Amar Bank will benefit from Investree's expertise in the local MSME financing space, allowing it to introduce new and enhanced product offerings. The partnership is expected to accelerate Amar Bank's product diversification efforts and tackle the historically underserved MSME segment in Indonesia's economy.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
FinAccel spends US$200m for Indonesia digital banking push

site_title: BlackRock to back fewer shareholder resolutions in this AGM season
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to support fewer shareholder resolutions on climate change and other issues at upcoming annual general meetings, citing proposals that are too prescriptive. Despite this, the firm maintains its stance on managing climate risk and continues to engage with companies on their efforts to transition to a low-carbon economy. BlackRock's decision reflects the growing complexity of climate-related proposals and the need for more nuanced approaches to addressing these issues.

images.alt_text: AIG says BlackRock will manage up to US$150b of its assets

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% to 3,229.32 at Wednesday's open, following a mixed close on Wall Street. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.3%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.0%. Banking stocks in Singapore experienced a mixed open, with DBS down 1.2%, UOB down 0.2%, and OCBC up 0.4%.

images.alt_text: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore  on Tuesday granted conditional approval of the proposed partnership between SIA and Malaysia Airlines.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.26 points or 0.15% to 1,556.84, with 219.31 million lots traded worth RM82.60 million. Losers outperformed gainers 202 to 129.

site_title: US oil settles below US$100 a barrel on economic worries, strong dollar
summary: US crude oil prices settled below $100 a barrel on Tuesday, dropping 3.2% to $99.76 a barrel, amid concerns over economic worries, a strong dollar, and coronavirus lockdowns in China. A strong dollar made crude more expensive for buyers using other currencies, while recession risks and monetary policy tightening weighed on demand. The European Union has delayed acting on a proposal to ban Russian oil imports, which could further impact oil prices.

site_title: Softbank-backed car-sharing startup Getaround nears SPAC merger: sources
summary: Getaround, a car-sharing marketplace, has agreed to go public through a merger with InterPrivate II Acquisition, a special purpose acquisition company, valued at approximately $1.2 billion. Softbank-backed Getaround will be led by CEO Sam Zaid and trade on the New York Stock Exchange with the 'GETR' ticker. Existing investors, including SoftBank Vision Fund and actor Ashton Kutcher, will remain owners of the combined entity.

images.alt_text: Airbnb Inc projected second-quarter revenue above market estimates on Tuesday.

site_title: Blue-chip NFT collections hit harder than Bitcoin in crypto rout
summary: Blue-chip NFT collections, such as Bored Ape Yacht Club, are experiencing a sharp decline in value, with BAYC's average sales price plummeting 29% in the last 7 days. This decline is more pronounced than the 17% drop in Bitcoin and 15% drop in Ether over the same period. The trend is attributed to the broader market's downturn and illiquidity in NFT markets, with some analysts suggesting that NFT-backed loans may be contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: Bored Ape Yacht Club #4418, one of a set of 10,000 non-fungible tokens (NFTs) representing cartoon apes, made by the U.S.-based company Yuga Labs is seen in this image created in the digital space, May 1, 2021. site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Ultra-high net worth families are rushing to invest in Singapore under its enhanced GIP scheme. An assistant professor at SMU has left the university after allegations of faked claims surfaced during an investigation. A luxury hotel in the Central Business District, SO/ Singapore, is being sold for S$240 million. The Golden Mile Complex, a conservation landmark, has been sold to a consortium for S$700 million. Meanwhile, Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Riverstone, UMS, PropNex, Centurion
summary: Singapore Airlines shares fell 1.7% after the Competition and Consumer Commission granted conditional approval of its partnership with Malaysia Airlines. Riverstone Holdings posted a 20% drop in Q1 net profit, while UMS Holdings rose 26% year-over-year. PropNex saw a 6.1% decline in net profit, and Centurion Corporation's revenue rose 47% in the first quarter.

site_title: BlackRock to Vanguard, global funds rush to Middle East IPO boom
summary: Global funds, including BlackRock and Vanguard, are flocking to the Middle East's thriving domestic markets and vibrant IPO scene, sidestepping a global slowdown in listings. The region's energy-rich Persian Gulf has supported a flurry of listings, with Dubai Electricity & Water Authority's IPO raising $6.1 billion last month. Despite some concerns about corporate governance standards and economic outlook, international investors are increasingly drawn to the region's growing cohort of local exchanges, with HSBC noting a steady increase in international investor interest over the past 9 months.

images.alt_text: Following Binance CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao’s lead, many are flocking to the UAE, which he has called the “Wall Street of crypto”.
Souq Waqif, a traditional market in Qatar, during the Ramadan fasting month in 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday after mixed US close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.60% and 0.54% on the Nikkei 225 and Topix indexes, respectively. Investors await Toyota's earnings report. Meanwhile, US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices edged higher. In other news, Airalo raised $220 million in funding, and Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Gold prices slip to 3-month low ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices dropped to a 3-month low, reaching US$1,832.06 per ounce, as investors awaited US inflation data and a strong dollar. The elevated dollar makes gold less attractive, while analysts expect a sharp pullback in monthly growth, cooling to 0.2% in April. This could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy stance.

images.alt_text: A piece of 1kg gold bar at Le Freeport on October 16, 2020.

site_title: Harley spinoff LiveWire debuts US$15,000 electric motorcycle
summary: Harley-Davidson's electric motorcycle division, LiveWire, has introduced a US$15,000 model, the Del Mar Launch Edition, which is half the price of the company's first product. The bike features a modular electric platform, developed to reduce costs. LiveWire plans to sell the Del Mar in the US and Europe in spring 2023, with further cheaper models to be developed for global markets using a Taiwanese manufacturing partner. The company has also announced a merger with AEA-Bridges Impact, expected to close in the first half of 2022.

site_title: Apple to pull the plug on iPod after 20 years
summary: Apple is discontinuing the iPod, a device that revolutionized portable music, after over 20 years. The iPod Touch, the only remaining version, will be available until supplies last. Launched in 2001, the iPod initially gained popularity before being eclipsed by smartphones and online music streaming. Apple stopped reporting iPod sales in 2015, and the device's discontinuation marks the end of an era in the company's history.

site_title: How will Bongbong Marcos and Sara Duterte rule Philippines?
summary: Ferdinand Marcos Jr, the newly elected President of the Philippines, has given few specifics on his governance plans. Ahead of his election, he attended a private dinner with Governor Gwen Garcia, a powerful figure in Cebu, where he met his future running mate Sara Duterte. The dinner may have provided insight into his priorities, but the Marcos clan, who control key positions in Cebu, have a history of opposition to the family. Marcos Jr's lack of specifics on his governance plans has raised concerns about his leadership style.

images.alt_text: The son of the disgraced late Philippines dictator Ferdinand Marcos vowed on Tuesday to work for all people after his stunning election victory, and told the world to judge him by his presidency, not his family’s past.

site_title: Petrol prices hit new record in US
summary: US petrol prices reached a record high of $4.37 per gallon on Tuesday, surpassing the previous record of $4.33 set in March 2022. The average price is up 46% from last year, driven by the global rise in crude oil prices following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. President Joe Biden assured Americans that his administration is working to bring down prices without slowing economic activity, but options for relief are limited. Gas prices are expected to rise another 10 cents per gallon in the coming days.

site_title: Roblox misses revenue estimates on slowing post-pandemic growth
summary: Roblox, a video game platform for preteens and teenagers, reported bookings that declined 3% to $631.2 million in the first quarter, missing analyst estimates. Daily active users reached a record 54.1 million, but engagement hours grew at a slower rate than during the pandemic. The company cited a comparison to early 2021, when users were subject to COVID lockdowns, as a factor in the decline. Roblox plans to expand initiatives to generate revenue, including through advertising, and aims to grow its younger user base.

images.alt_text: Roblox founder's pay jumps to US$233m on long-term stock awards

site_title: Coinbase sinks after warning the slide in volume to worsen
summary: Coinbase Global shares plummeted 14% after the company reported first-quarter revenue that fell short of estimates, with $1.17 billion in revenue versus $1.48 billion expected. Monthly transacting users declined to 9.2 million, below estimates of 9.5 million. The exchange warned that trading volume in the current quarter will be lower than in the first quarter, amid a bear market and macro headwinds. Despite this, Coinbase's outlook for 2022 remains largely unchanged, with a focus on managing full-year adjusted Ebitda losses to $500 million.

images.alt_text: Coinbase Global's new marketplace for non-fungible tokens is now officially open to all - and it's getting off to a very slow start.

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment dives as rates, inflation rise
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment index dropped 5.6% in May, reaching a 21-month low, due to rising inflation and interest rates. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index fell 20.1% from May last year, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. The Reserve Bank of Australia raised interest rates, and inflation reached 5% for the first time since 2007, contributing to the decline. This gloomy mood may impact Prime Minister Scott Morrison ahead of the election on May 21, and retailers may face challenges with consumers being less likely to buy major household items.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars sank to two-year lows on Tuesday.

Australia's business conditions strengthened further in April, while labor costs and output prices remained elevated, a combination that suggests further interest rate increases ahead to rein in inflation.

site_title: Temasek subsidiary Fullerton Fund Management to list private equity fund on ADDX’s digital platform
summary: Temasek's Fullerton Fund Management has partnered with digital exchange ADDX to list its private equity fund of funds, the Fullerton Optimised Alpha Fund, on the platform. The fund aims for 8-12% annual returns over 7 years and will be available to accredited investors with a minimum investment of $10,000. The fund will invest in 6-8 private equity and credit funds, with a focus on thematic sectors and ESG factors. This partnership aims to make private equity more accessible to individual investors, with ADDX CEO Choo Oi Yee noting that private equity has outperformed public equity over long-term timeframes.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Real estate tokenisation - what does it mean for investors?
KKR is targeting US$4 billion for its third technology fund and plans to raise a small portion through Singapore-based private market platform ADDX.
ADDX chief executive Choo Oi Yee estimates that at any given point, there could be trillions of dollars stuck in a system that is not being used productively.
Exchanges looking to private arena as capital markets evolve

site_title: WHO says China's zero-Covid strategy unsustainable
summary: The World Health Organization's (WHO) chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, has stated that China's zero-Covid strategy is unsustainable, citing the behavior of the virus and its impact on society. The WHO has previously discussed this issue with Chinese experts, indicating that a shift in approach is necessary. WHO emergencies director Michael Ryan emphasized the need to balance control measures with individual and human rights, and Maria Van Kerkhove noted that it's impossible to stop all transmission of the virus worldwide, but rather to drive it down.

site_title: Japan missing out on 4.8t yen tourist windfall from weak yen
summary: Japan's economy is missing out on a 4.8 trillion yen (S$53 billion) tourism windfall due to the country's weak yen and strict border measures. Despite the yen's 2-decade low, foreign tourists have yet to return, depriving Japan of a significant influx of visitors. The government is considering relaxing border restrictions, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida hinting at reopening the border for group tours as early as June. Analysts expect it will take a year or more to normalize border restrictions, and the economy's recovery is still lagging behind its G-7 counterparts.

images.alt_text: Japan’s household spending fell in March for the first time in three months, though the 2.3% drop was smaller than expected, as consumers remained cautious despite some easing of Covid-19 curbs.
The Bank of Japan has no plan to allow long-term interest rates to move more widely around its 0 per cent target to stem sharp falls in the yen.

site_title: Hoteliers look to H2 with frisson amid deluge of wedding and event bookings
summary: Singapore's hospitality sector is experiencing a rebound as hotels see a surge in demand for venue bookings following the easing of Covid-19 restrictions. Venue bookings at some hotels have more than doubled, with some hotels experiencing a 50% increase in ballroom and function room bookings since restrictions were lifted. Industry experts predict a bottleneck in the third quarter due to expected ramping up of event bookings.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Hotel staff, including a cleaner and a bellman walk past at the Marina Bay Sands Hotel.

PASSENGER volume at Singapore’s Changi Airport has more than doubled to reach close to 40 per cent of pre-Covid levels in end-April, up from about 18 per cent in March, said Transport Minister S Iswaran.
Flight bookings show pent-up demand, bodes well for Singapore's air traffic target

site_title: US gun deaths soared in 2020 amid pandemic: CDC
summary: The US saw a significant increase in gun deaths in 2020, with 19,350 firearm homicides and 24,245 gun suicides, a 35% and 1.5% rise, respectively. The CDC attributes this to the pandemic's effects, poverty, and systemic inequities. The firearm homicide rate reached 6.1 per 100,000 inhabitants, the highest in over 25 years, with disproportionately high rates among men, teenagers, and young adults in African-American and Native American communities. Experts recommend a comprehensive approach to reduce inequity, including addressing economic factors, improving environment, and enhancing violence prevention programs.

site_title: US celebrity chef Batali acquitted of sexual assault
summary: Celebrity chef Mario Batali has been acquitted of indecent assault and battery charges in a Boston bar incident in 2017. The 61-year-old chef was accused of forcibly kissing and grabbing Natali Tene, but the judge found him not guilty, citing the accuser's "significant credibility issues." Batali waived his right to a jury trial and did not take the stand. The verdict was met with disappointment from the district attorney, who said he was "disappointed" with the outcome.

site_title: Ukraine pushes Russian troops back in counter-offensive near Kharkiv
summary: Ukraine has launched a successful counter-offensive against Russian forces near Kharkiv, recapturing several villages north and northeast of the city. This push could signal a shift in the war's momentum, jeopardizing Russia's main advance and potentially forcing Moscow to defend its own supply lines. Ukrainian forces are now within striking distance of the rear supply lines sustaining the main Russian attack force further south, according to military analysts. The counterattack could also thwart Russia's plans to announce a major victory on Victory Day.

images.alt_text: Drones are part of a multifaceted, multimillion dollar crowdfunding campaign that is producing millions of dollars in donations, as well as a bounty of smaller weapons and other military equipment for the Ukrainian military.

site_title: Nissan investors seek momentum from likely swing back to profit
summary: Nissan Motor is expected to report its first profit in three years, with analysts estimating an annual operating profit of around 223 billion yen (S$2.4 billion) for the fiscal year ended March. The company's efforts to restructure operations and increase quality sales have recently gained momentum due to a weakened yen. However, Nissan faces new challenges, including rising material prices and potential demand slowdowns, and investors will be watching for updates on its profit outlook and potential resumption of dividend payments.

images.alt_text: Nissan first killed off the Datsun brand in 1981, but it was revived in 2013 by then-CEO Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: UK to enter recession this year: think-tank NIESR
summary: The UK is forecast to enter a technical recession in the second half of this year, with gross domestic product expected to fall by 0.2% in the third quarter and 0.4% in the last three months of the year. The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) attributed the downturn to surging prices, particularly inflation, which is expected to peak at 8.3%. To mitigate the impact on living standards, NIESR recommends increasing the main welfare benefit for the unemployed and low-paid by £25 a week and giving a £250 grant to the poorest 40% of households.

images.alt_text: Customers outside a coffee shop in the town centre in Burnley, U.K., on Wednesday, April 27, 2022. The Bank of England issued the most gloomy outlook of any major central bank this year, warning Britain to brace for double-digit inflation and a prolonged period of stagnation or even recession. Photographer: Anthony Devlin/Bloomberg

site_title: Marcos tells world to judge him by actions, not family's past
summary: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son of the late Philippines dictator Ferdinand Marcos, won an outright majority in the country's presidential election, becoming the first candidate to achieve this in recent history. Marcos vowed to work for all people and judge him by his presidency, not his family's past. With 98% of ballots counted, he has 31 million votes, double that of his nearest rival. Marcos's victory has sparked concerns about his presidency, with many questioning his ability to unite the nation given the bitter feelings about his family's vast influence and wealth.

images.alt_text: Ferdinand Marcos Jr, whose dictator father and namesake plundered and brutalised the Philippines for decades, on Tuesday won a historic election victory.

site_title: PE firm CVC Capital pushes back stock market debut plans: sources
summary: EU's largest private equity firm CVC Capital Partners has pushed back its stock market listing plans, initially set for this autumn or early 2023. The firm will float just 10% of its business and may value it at over $29.3 billion. CVC had planned to list on Amsterdam's Euronext exchange, instead of London, with Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley working as advisers. The company has not made a final decision on the IPO.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Overview of Amsterdam's stock exchange interior as Prosus begins trading on the Euronext stock exchange in Amsterdam, Netherlands, September 11, 2019. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw/File Photo

site_title: Elon Musk says he would lift Twitter ban on Trump
summary: Elon Musk has stated that as owner of Twitter, he would lift the ban on Donald Trump, citing that the ban "alienated a large part of the country." Musk believes that permanent bans undermine trust in Twitter and should be reserved for accounts that are spam, scams, or run by software "bots." This move has triggered fears among activists that Musk would "open the floodgates of hate" and has sparked concerns about the impact on Twitter's revenue and reputation.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo illustration, the Twitter account of US President Donald Trump is displayed on a mobile phone on August 10, 2020, in Arlington, Virginia. - Elon Musk on Tuesday said that as owner of Twitter he would lift the ban on Donald Trump, contending that kicking the former US president off the platform "alienated a large part of the country." (Photo by Olivier DOULIERY / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Stocks stage comeback from two-month lows
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Tuesday, rebounding from two-month lows, as bargain hunters bought beaten-down shares amid concerns over a global economic slowdown. The Stoxx 600 index has shed 6.7% in May due to lockdowns, the Ukraine war, and interest rate hike worries. Analysts say the rebound is not enough to be hopeful, with the European Central Bank expected to normalize monetary policy quickly to tame inflation.

site_title: Netflix tells employees ads may appear by end of 2022: NYT
summary: Netflix may introduce its lower-priced ad-supported subscription plan by the end of 2022, earlier than initially planned, according to a report by the New York Times. The move comes as the company faces lagging subscriber growth and deeper losses, prompted by increased competition and password sharing. The company is also planning to crack down on password sharing around the same time. This shift in strategy aims to attract new subscribers and offset the impact of rising competition.

site_title: WHO studies whether Covid-19 has role in child hepatitis mystery
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is investigating 348 probable cases of hepatitis of unknown origin in children, with 109 cases in the US and five reported deaths. The leading hypotheses remain those involving adenovirus, with a possible link to Covid-19 infection also being considered. Testing has shown that around 70% of cases tested positive for adenovirus, and 18% for Covid-19. The WHO is focusing on serological testing to determine previous exposure and infections with Covid, and is awaiting results from a case-control study in Britain to refine its hypotheses.

site_title: Yellen says striking down abortion rights would hurt US economy
summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that limiting women's access to abortion would have "very damaging effects" on the US economy, citing research that would increase poverty levels and hurt future earnings of children. The draft of a potential Supreme Court ruling to overturn Roe v Wade was confirmed, allowing states to make their own laws and restrictions. Yellen's remarks sparked a response from Republican Senator Tim Scott, who disagreed with framing the issue in economic terms, but Yellen argued she was discussing economic realities for women and children.

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile day mixed ahead of inflation data
summary: US stocks ended a volatile day mixed, with the Dow falling 0.3% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.0%. Investors await the release of the April consumer price report, which is expected to show a modest monthly increase. Tech shares rallied amid talk of market overselling, with Pfizer and Biohaven Pharmaceutical rising after a merger announcement. The Dow fell for a fourth consecutive session ahead of the inflation report.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after three-day slump
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 258.4 points, or 0.80%, to 32,504.09. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, with the S&P 500 rising 43.9 points, or 1.10%, and the Nasdaq rising 277.1 points, or 2.38%. Investors bought into beaten-down banks and megacap growth stocks after a three-day sell-off due to concerns over monetary tightening and slowing economic growth.

site_title: PropNex Q1 net profit dips 6.1% on higher staff costs
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a 6.1% dip in net profit to S$13.9 million in Q1 2022, driven by higher staff costs and lower commission income from project marketing services. Revenue grew 9.5% to S$241.6 million. The company expects the private residential market to remain fairly resilient, with prices potentially growing 3-5% in 2022, and projects HDB resale prices to rise 6-8%. Despite a slow start in 2022, PropNex is on track to reach its goal of 12,000 salespersons by end-2022.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: SIA, Malaysia Airlines pact gets conditional approval from competition watchdog
summary: Singapore Airlines and Malaysia Airlines have received conditional approval from the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore for their proposed commercial cooperation. The partnership, announced in 2019, involves sharing revenue on flights between Singapore and Malaysia, expanding codeshare routes, and participating in joint marketing activities. The agreement is conditional on a review when a series of indicators signal a sustained recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The review will assess the competition impact and benefits of the joint business arrangement.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
There is renewed hope that national carrier Malaysia Airlines is poised to see its long flagging fortunes finally lifted as air travel bursts back to life
Malaysia Airlines parent MAG turns the corner in FY21 with positive Ebitda of RM433m

FILE PHOTO: Travellers arrive at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) under Malaysia-Singapore Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) programme, after travel between the two countries was halted due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, in Sepang, Malaysia November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Lai Seng Sin/File Photo

SIA customers will be able to connect on United’s flights out of Los Angeles to 10 new US codeshare destinations, namely Austin, Baltimore, Boise, Cleveland, Denver, Honolulu, Las Vegas, Phoenix, Reno and Sacramento.
S$500m in aviation support for Singapore Changi Airport

site_title: Manufacturers continue to worry about parts, more lockdowns in China
summary: China's ongoing Covid-19 lockdowns are causing significant disruptions to manufacturing, with companies like Griffin Group International unable to receive essential parts due to logistics issues. China's official Purchasing Managers' Index showed a manufacturing activity slump, and export growth fell to a 2-year low. The lockdowns are also affecting businesses, with 92% of companies polled saying they've been impacted by China's Covid-19 policy and rising costs. The situation may worsen with Covid case counts climbing in Beijing, raising the possibility of additional lockdowns, and could lead to companies considering shifting investments out of China.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
A worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) rides a bicycle along a nearly-empty road in Shanghai on May 5, 2022.
European businesses in China are increasingly looking to shift their investments to other markets due to the country’s strict Covid-19 containment measures and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: As new investment comes in, Thailand’s Eastern Economic Corridor shows flickers of life
summary: Thailand's Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) is showing signs of life with new investment pouring in, aiming to bring in 2.2 trillion baht (S$88.5 billion) in investments over the next 5 years. The EEC, covering 3 eastern provinces, focuses on S-curve industries like artificial intelligence and aerospace, with foreign investment from countries like Singapore and China. The government hopes to develop the region into a leading Asean economic zone, with a focus on promoting 12 new industries and upgrading research and development capabilities.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on October 27, 2021 airport staff chat at the new entry lanes at Suvarnabhumi International Airport as they rehearse reopening procedures to welcome the first group of vaccinated tourists without quarantine on November 1, in Bangkok. - Tens of thousands of travellers were expected to touch down in Bangkok and the holiday island of Phuket on November 1, 2021 as Thailand reboots its tourism industry after 18 months of Covid curbs. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Pfizer to buy migraine drugmaker Biohaven in US$11.6b deal
summary: Pfizer agreed to buy migraine drugmaker Biohaven Pharmaceutical Holding Company for approximately $11.6 billion in cash. The deal will grant Pfizer access to Biohaven's approved migraine drug Rimegepant, a CGRP inhibitor. Pfizer aims to bolster its portfolio ahead of patent losses for some cancer drugs. Biohaven shareholders will receive 0.5 shares of a new publicly traded company retaining non-CGRP treatments.

images.alt_text: Pfizer takeover makes dent in a US$32b stock-market slump

site_title: UK says it will take all necessary steps to protect Northern Ireland peace
summary: The UK has stated it will take all necessary steps to protect the peace in Northern Ireland, amid a stalemate over the Northern Ireland Protocol, a post-Brexit trading rule. The protocol, which created a customs border in the sea between Northern Ireland and the UK, has sparked tensions between the UK and EU. The UK is seeking a full overhaul of the agreement, while the EU is looking for changes within the existing deal. The situation has raised concerns about a potential flare-up in political tensions, threatening a 1998 peace deal.

images.alt_text: Brexit talks are stuck with little hope of progress before May

site_title: Singapore Covid-19 cases spike to 4,831, more than double previous day's figure
summary: Singapore reported 4,831 new COVID-19 cases on May 10, more than double the 2,271 cases on the previous day. The infection ratio rose to 1.49, exceeding 1 for the first time, indicating an increase in new cases. There were 263 hospitalized cases, 6 in intensive care, and 4 deaths. Total cases in Singapore stand at 1,225,024, with 1,356 deaths.

site_title: E-Log’s tepid debut may leave unitholders wondering if being bigger is better
summary: Singapore-listed ESR-Logos Reit (E-Log), the flagship asset securitisation platform of ESR Cayman, began trading on May 5 after merging with Ara Logos Logistics Trust (A-Log). The merger created a significantly larger Reit, but its market value has yet to reflect the increased size. Unitholders of ESR-Reit and A-Log may be wondering when the benefits of increased size and trading liquidity will kick in, as the merger has not yet delivered a higher market value. Regulators have emphasized the importance of treating unitholders fairly in mergers, with some sponsors beginning to adopt more transparent and equitable practices.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Reit managers, sponsors should get in front of evolving investor attitudes on mergers
ALog Trust units could bounce this week, but revised merger deal is still less than compelling for its unitholders

site_title: 'Star Wars' model, Elvis suit among movie items headed for auction
summary: A treasure trove of entertainment memorabilia, including a "Star Wars" X-Wing model, Elvis Presley's suit, and Thor's hammer, is up for auction in Hollywood next month. Over 1,800 items from more than 600 film and TV titles are being offered, with estimated values ranging from $20,000 to $1 million. The auction is expected to raise over $9 million, with leading items including a rare "Star Wars" X-Wing model and collectibles from popular franchises like "Thor" and "Top Gun."

site_title: Fighting rages in Ukraine’s east as US warns of long war
summary: Fighting intensifies in Ukraine's east as Russia continues its invasion. US Director of National Intelligence Avril Haines warns that Russian President Vladimir Putin is prepared for a long war. Ukraine's eastern region sees ongoing clashes, including a deadly Russian air strike in Bilogorivka, while Odessa experiences overnight missile strikes. Civilians struggle to survive amidst constantly shifting front lines, with water and food supplies dwindling. Germany's shift in stance on supporting Ukraine and imposing an oil embargo is seen as a positive development, but the conflict remains uncertain with Putin's plans unclear.

site_title: Tesla recalls 130,000 vehicles in US on touchscreen display malfunction
summary: Tesla is recalling 130,000 vehicles in the US due to a touchscreen display malfunction that may cause the centre screen to overheat. The issue may lead to a malfunction of the vehicle's systems. The recall affects certain model year vehicles and is being conducted by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). Tesla will notify affected owners and provide a software update to resolve the issue.

site_title: Centurion Q1 revenue grows 47% on new capacity,  business streams
summary: Centurion Corp's revenue rose 47% to S$45.1 million in Q1 2022, driven by new capacity and business streams in its purpose-built workers' accommodation and student accommodation segments. Revenue from Singapore grew 51% to S$30.6 million, while Malaysia saw a 3% increase to S$3.4 million. The UK saw a 56% boost in revenue to S$8.6 million due to a recovery in occupancy levels for the current academic year.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Centurion gains on expanded worker accommodation portfolio; number of beds to fall in 2022
Centurion posts higher full-year net profit, proposes S$0.005 final dividend
Centurion expects the move to enhance shareholder value as part of its efforts to rationalise its portfolio of assets.

site_title: Intel launches new AI chips, challenging Nvidia's market
summary: Intel launched its new AI chip, Gaudi2, focusing on artificial intelligence computing, aiming to challenge Nvidia's dominance in the market. Gaudi2 is twice as fast as its predecessor and manufactured at 7-nanometre technology. Intel also introduced Greco, a chip for inferencing work. The AI chip market is expected to grow 25% annually for the next 5 years, reaching $50 billion. Intel plans to invest in software, expanding its team and acquiring companies to lead the market.

site_title: Toyota to slash production plan, suspend some domestic operation due to Covid lockdown in China
summary: Toyota Motor has suspended operations on 14 lines at 8 domestic factories for up to 6 days in May due to the Covid lockdown in China, affecting about 40,000 vehicle outputs. The partial suspension will last between May 16 and May 21, expanding the number of affected lines and factories to 20 and 12, respectively.

site_title: Commodity currencies bounce back but sentiment remains fragile
summary: Commodity currencies, including the Norwegian krone and Australian dollar, recovered against the US dollar on Tuesday after hitting their lowest levels in nearly two years. European and Chinese stock markets rebounded, with signs of bargain hunting in both markets. However, sentiment remains fragile, keeping the safe-haven dollar near a 20-year high. The euro and sterling remained flat, while the dollar index edged 0.1% lower. Oil prices also fell, hurt by fears of recession and an economic slowdown in China.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars sank to two-year lows on Tuesday.

site_title: Heathrow airport eyes fresh loss despite recovery
summary: Heathrow airport expects another loss-making year in 2022 due to high inflation, renewed Covid travel restrictions, and the Ukraine war. Despite handling 5 million passengers in April, the airport anticipates a loss, with travel demand reaching 65% of pre-Covid levels. The airport's CEO attributes the challenges to uncertainty from ongoing conflicts, fuel costs, and travel restrictions, and has announced plans to recruit 12,000 staff to meet passenger demand.

site_title: Riverstone’s Q1 net profit drops 79.2% as demand for healthcare gloves normalises
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a 79.2% drop in Q1 net profit to RM108.7 million, due to normalized demand for healthcare gloves after the pandemic. Average selling prices of healthcare gloves have decreased from historic highs seen in Q1 2021. Revenue fell to RM402.3 million, and gross profit dropped to RM154.5 million. The company plans to expand production capacity by 1.5 billion pieces through 7 production lines, increasing annual output to 12 billion pieces of gloves.

images.alt_text: Venga (எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்)
Malaysia’s minimum wage for Malaysia workers is reviewed every 2 years. It was last raised in Feb 2020 to RM1,200, up from RM1,100 before.
Among glove makers, Riverstone has most attractive margins

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.4 points to 1,554.58 on Tuesday, driven by higher volume of 2.753 billion lots worth RM2.258 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 640 to 331. The index closed higher despite global market trends, with stocks in other regions also experiencing gains.

site_title: Keeping succession planning simple and sustainable
summary: Wealthy families face complex succession planning due to international taxes, geopolitical, and economic volatility. A trust structure, coupled with insurance solutions, offers a flexible and simple financial tool to adapt to changing circumstances while protecting and growing assets sustainably. Trusts reduce the risk of individual creditors and matrimonial claims, and can consolidate family businesses, avoid probate, and provide liquidity through insurance policies. Integrating insurance into a trust can provide lifetime and post-lifetime liquidity, mitigate inheritance taxes, and support long-term philanthropic partnerships.

images.alt_text: Tycoons from around the region, along with their families, are reportedly flocking to Singapore, with interest in immigration rising during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Cyberattack knocks out Russian video platform Rutube
summary: Russia's Rutube video platform remained offline for a second day after a massive cyberattack, which the platform described as its "biggest cyberattack in history." The attack occurred hours before the platform was set to stream Russia's Victory Day parade in Moscow. The company attributed the hack to hackers targeting sites of Russian institutions, which have faced constant cyberattacks since Russia launched its "special military operation" in Ukraine. The hack's purpose was reportedly to prevent Rutube from showing the parade and holiday fireworks.

site_title: UK government sets out priorities in Queen's speech
summary: The UK government has outlined its priorities in a speech by Prince Charles on behalf of Queen Elizabeth, aimed at winning back traditional supporters in southern England. The plans include 38 bills, including one to simplify EU regulations, overhaul human rights legislation, and introduce tougher laws on protests and derelict buildings. The government also seeks to make it easier to deport foreign offenders and increase penalties for those disrupting national infrastructure. The moves aim to boost the economy and reduce bureaucratic rules.

images.alt_text: Asked why welfare benefits would not rise in line with inflation, Johnson said the government had to be wary of driving up inflation even further.

site_title: Is holding stocks for the long run worth your time?
summary: Investing in the stock market for the long term can be rewarding, with returns often exceeding 8% annually over 70 years, as seen in the S&P 500 index. However, the average investor holds stocks for less than 5.5 months, which can lead to losses due to the odds being heavily stacked against them. Research suggests that only a small minority of stocks account for the majority of long-term returns, and patience is key to maximizing gains. By allowing winners to run and avoiding short-term volatility, investors can tap into the potential upside of the stock market, with some studies showing that the top performers can account for 75-91% of a portfolio's gains over time.

images.alt_text: Conxicoeur sees pockets of opportunity but investors need to be selective
http://www.gunaymutlu.com/iStock/financial-images-360.jpg

site_title: IBM unsure how long it will keep Russia-based staff on payroll, CEO says
summary: IBM's CEO, Arvind Krishna, expressed uncertainty about how long the company can pay its Russian-based employees due to escalating sanctions. IBM, which had over 1,000 workers in Russia, ceased all business in the country in March. Sanctions have limited the number of banks foreign firms can use to pay employees in Russia, and Krishna said the company's ability to keep workers on the payroll "may go away." For IBM to resume normal operations in Russia, significant changes, including an end to violence and reparations, would be necessary.

site_title: Deal-making frenzy comes to London's West End
