Container ships flood singapore as global scheduling left in tatters. (Pasir Panjang)##########pic##########陈斌勤

site_title: Singapore records 2,423 new Covid-19 cases on Sunday; infection rate above 1 for first time since Apr 23
summary: Singapore reported 2,423 new COVID-19 cases on Sunday, with a weekly infection growth rate of 1.01, the first time above 1 since April 23. This marks a surge from Saturday's 3,162 cases and Sunday's 1,732 cases the previous week. 2,269 locally transmitted cases were reported, with 154 imported cases. There were 240 hospitalised cases, including 6 in intensive care. Two deaths were also reported, bringing the total to 1,352.

images.alt_text: There were 3,201 new locally transmitted cases.

site_title: Wilmar leads buyback tally; YZJFH directors acquire shares
summary: Wilmar International led the buyback tally among primary-listed stocks in Singapore, with 5.4 million shares purchased at an average price of S$4.41 per share. The total net institutional inflows into Singapore stocks from April 29 to May 5 reached S$452 million, while the Straits Times Index (STI) generated an 8.4% total return. Meanwhile, Yangzijiang Financial Holdings directors acquired shares in the company, with multiple directors buying shares on the open market.

images.alt_text: Overall, the total net institutional inflows into Singapore stocks in the 2022 year to Apr 28  have totalled S$418 million, while the STI generated an 8.0 per cent total return.

site_title: Staff crunch hobbles Singapore hotels’ bid to cash in on  tourism, dining rebound
summary: Singapore hotels face a severe manpower crunch, with 160 member hotels reporting a "critical shortage" in operational departments, particularly housekeeping. Despite a 20-30% increase in starting pay, many positions remain unfilled. To maintain service standards, hotels are restricting occupancy and shutting restaurants on certain days. The shortage is attributed to the pandemic's impact on the industry's labor pool, with local talent switching to other sectors and 25% of foreign workforce returning home. Digital transformation is seen as a long-term solution, but technological gaps persist.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

PASSENGER volume at Singapore’s Changi Airport has more than doubled to reach close to 40 per cent of pre-Covid levels in end-April, up from about 18 per cent in March, said Transport Minister S Iswaran.
There were 2 job vacancies for every unemployed person in December last year.

site_title: Metis, formerly Manhattan Resources, reiterates future in renewables
summary: Metis, formerly Manhattan Resources, is repositioning itself as a renewable energy company in Asia and Australia. The company is constructing 26MW of rooftop solar facilities and has sufficient expertise and resources to evaluate investments in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Bangladesh. Metis has acquired Athena Energy Holdings, which has a presence in key renewable energy markets across Asia and Australia. The company aims to provide sustainable power to commercial and industrial users and utility customers, and has recently changed its name to Metis Energy.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Manhattan Resources to acquire renewable energy company Athena Energy
Manhatten Resources has appointed Tan Tong Hai, former CEO of StarHub, as its non-executive, non-independent director.

site_title: Following the Compass for a stronger workforce
summary: Singapore is introducing a new points-based framework, the "Compass," to assess Employment Pass applications, making it harder for employers to hire foreigners. The new framework considers individual skills, salary, qualifications, and firm strategic economic priorities, diversity, and support for local employment. The minimum qualifying salary for Employment Passes will increase to S$5,000 per month, with experienced PMETs needing to be paid at least double the minimum qualifying salary. The changes aim to strengthen the local workforce and address concerns about depressed salaries due to cheaper foreign labor.

images.alt_text: New EP framework provides clarity - now firms have to act on this knowledge
Strong enforcement measures will guard against new EP system fraud
Singapore's global hub ambitions: A Compass to guide the workforce

site_title: Dollar index slips from 20-year high, Fed rate path in focus
summary: The dollar index slipped from a 20-year high on Friday, falling to 103.64 after investors reassessed the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans and considered if inflation was nearing a peak. The dollar index hit 104.07 overnight, its highest since December 2002, amid safe-haven demand following a sharp stock sell-off. The Fed's hawkishness and potential risk of recession weighed on the dollar, while the euro gained ground after relatively hawkish comments from European Central Bank officials.

images.alt_text: The dollar index pulled further away from 20-year highs on Wednesday, having already priced the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates by a half-point later in the day and by some 250 basis points (bps) by year-end.

site_title: John Soh’s recalcitrance calls for tough stance
summary: Singapore's law enforcement agencies have successfully prosecuted John Soh and Quah Su-Ling for masterminding the 2013 penny stock crash, which resulted in billions of dollars in losses for investors. Soh and Quah used an extensive infrastructure of nominee accounts to manipulate the shares of Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital, and LionGold Corp, and were found guilty on various charges. The case highlights the need for vigilant and vigorous law enforcement agencies to prevent similar market manipulation operations. The authorities have also vowed to comprehensively dismantle Soh's network of enablers and take action against those who cooperated or enabled his activities.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
$8b penny stock crash trial. Quah Su-Ling (picture), along with John Soh Chee Wen, are accused of masterminding Singapore’s most serious case of stock market manipulation.

site_title: Infrastructure projects in Indonesia could feel the impact of slower China growth
summary: Indonesia's infrastructure projects may be impacted by a slowdown in China's economy, with potential losses in investment from Chinese companies. However, a more significant threat to Indonesia's infrastructure sector is the export ban on palm oil, which could cut export revenue by $2.5 to $3 billion per month. This could make the rupiah more vulnerable to currency fluctuations. Despite a potential slowdown in Chinese investment, Indonesia's GDP growth is expected to be less affected, as total FDI has been stagnant in recent years.

images.alt_text: Markets had shown relief when Indonesia’s chief economic minister said on Tuesday the ban would only cover refined, bleached and deodorized (RBD) palm olein, but a day later authorities announced other products would be included.
Workers load palm oil fresh fruit bunches to be transported from the collector site to CPO factories in Pekanbaru, Riau province, Indonesia, April 27, 2022.
Indonesia central bank trims GDP outlook, keeps rates on hold

site_title: Canada's Commissioner of Competition plans to oppose Rogers, Shaw US$16b merger
summary: Canada's Commissioner of Competition plans to oppose Rogers' proposed $20 billion merger with Shaw Communications, citing concerns over the impact on Canada's competitive wireless market. Rogers has agreed to divest Shaw's wireless business, Freedom Mobile, to address these concerns. The companies remain committed to the merger, with Rogers seeking a partner to join a bid for Freedom Mobile. The move follows regulatory risks and investors' concerns about the deal.

images.alt_text: Rogers said last year it would buy Shaw for about C$20 billion (S$21.5 billion) in a deal that would create Canada’s second-largest cellular and cable operator.

site_title: UK assets suffer after BOE’s gloomy prognosis on recession
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has issued a gloomy prognosis on recession, citing a 10% inflation rate and job losses, which has led to a decline in UK assets. The pound has slid to its weakest since June 2020, and currency traders are betting on further losses. The BOE's outlook has turned the market's view more negative, with strategists expecting stocks focused on the domestic economy to underperform and corporate debt risk to surge. Investors will look to the latest UK GDP figures for signs of further weakness, making it difficult for policymakers to navigate the juncture.

images.alt_text: THE Bank of England (BOE) raised interest rates to their highest since 2009 at 1 per cent on Thursday (May 5) to counter inflation now heading above 10 per cent, even as it sent a warning that Britain risks falling into recession.

site_title: Every business could use a ‘Granfluencer’
summary: Older workers, particularly those in their late 60s and 70s, are an underutilized resource for companies struggling to find staff. Despite life expectancy rates increasing and many unwilling or unable to retire, the pandemic halted this trend. Companies like Unilever and Walmart are now embracing older workers, offering flexible work arrangements, and providing benefits to attract them. AARP's Employer Pledge program has seen a surge in sign-ups, and some retailers, such as B&Q, are actively promoting apprenticeships for older employees.

images.alt_text: Just as employers should be open to hiring people of different age groups, job-seekers in the older age group should also manage their expectations when it comes to salary adjustments and upskilling

site_title: Blooming shame: Pandemic, Ukraine war hurts Thai orchid industry
summary: Thailand's orchid industry is struggling due to the pandemic, Ukraine war, and changing weather patterns. The pandemic has seen one in five farms shut, with workers facing reduced sales and increased costs due to rising fertilizers and pesticides prices. The war in Ukraine has disrupted transportation and supply chains, further impacting the industry. As a result, many growers are facing financial difficulties, with some having to let go of staff or reduce their selling prices. The industry's future is uncertain, with changing weather patterns and reduced local demand also posing long-term challenges.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians outside Siam Paragon in Bangkok last month. A commerce ministry official said headline inflation is likely to exceed 5 per cent in the coming months following the end of a cap on diesel prices.

site_title: Sri Lanka in talks for US$100m emergency funding from AIIB
summary: Sri Lanka is in talks with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) for a US$100 million emergency funding package. The country's finance ministry announced the request, seeking additional forex liquidity support for state banks. This move comes amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis, which has been exacerbated by a severe currency shortage and high inflation.

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde says stagflation is not the base case
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde stated that stagflation, a combination of slow economic growth and high inflation, is not the most likely economic outcome for the euro area. Lagarde said the current situation cannot be compared to the 1970s and that ECB officials will keep all options open as they consider normalizing monetary policy, with some predicting a first interest-rate increase in July.

site_title: UK property firms Capco, Shaftesbury in talks on reported  £3.5b merger
summary: UK real estate firms Capco and Shaftesbury are in advanced talks on a £3.5 billion merger, which would bring iconic London destinations like Covent Garden and Soho under one umbrella. Shaftesbury would own 53% and Capco the remainder, with a valuation of £3.5 billion. The merged businesses would be a real estate investment trust focused on London's West End, with a portfolio of 2.9 million sq ft. The deal is supported by Norway's sovereign wealth fund and comes as London recovers from pandemic lows.

site_title: Shanghai tightens lockdown to hit zero-Covid goal by late May
summary: Shanghai is tightening its Covid-19 lockdown in a push to eliminate infections outside quarantined areas by late May. The city, with 25 million residents, is accelerating efforts to transfer close contacts of positive cases to central quarantines centers. Movement curbs will likely remain until the end of May due to fears of a rebound, despite falling case numbers. The lockdown, already strict, aims to hit China's zero-Covid goal.

images.alt_text: Shanghai is also building thousands of permanent PCR testing stations, in line with other cities.
Two-and-a-half years since the coronavirus first emerged in Wuhan, China is the last major economy still closed off to the world, despite its relatively low death toll.

site_title: Do NFTs have any value at all?
summary: A leading NFT project, Bored Ape Yacht Club, has seen its floor price reach a new high at $400,000, defying broader market trends. The author questions whether NFTs have value, citing the concept of scarcity, but also acknowledges that NFTs provide real value through authenticity. The author cites the example of digital artist Beeple's NFT "Everydays: The First 5000 Days," which sold for $69 million, highlighting the value of unique digital art and the importance of authenticity. NFTs are also used as identity markers and status symbols in the digital world, similar to luxury collectibles in the physical world.

The metaverse land boom: economy of the future or a bubble?
NFTs: Finding the diamonds among the duds
The way of the DAO could be the future of work
Moving from play-to-earn to play-to-own
'I have seen the future, and it works.' But is it Web3?

site_title: Colombo calm after Sri Lanka declares state of emergency
summary: Sri Lanka declared a state of emergency on Friday amid ongoing anti-government protests over food, fuel, and medicine shortages. Police fired tear gas at dozens of demonstrators outside parliament, and streets in Colombo remained calm on Saturday. The emergency regulations are expected to give the president greater powers to deploy the military and detain people without charge. The decision was made to address the "public emergency situation" and maintain public security and essential services.

images.alt_text: Sri  Lanka’s fractious opposition showed rare unity on Sunday (May 1), joining together to demand embattled President Gotabaya Rajapaksa resign over the country’s worst-ever economic crisis.
Sri Lanka’s President Gotabaya Rajapaksa is willing to drop his brother as prime minister, according to a top leader, as a fresh surge in inflation threatens to renew calls for the family to resign.
INDIA, the world's second-biggest tea producer, will likely fail to take advantage of an export gap in the global market sparked by Sri Lanka's economic crisis, according to a top grower.

site_title: With voluntary carbon markets, it’s still buyer beware
summary: Companies are navigating the fragmented and opaque voluntary carbon marketplace with unclear rules and high risks. Despite net-zero pledges, companies are unsure of how to use carbon credits to justify their claims, and the market lacks transparency and liquidity. Prices are not standardized, and the lack of a widely accepted framework for credit quality has added confusion. To address these issues, some companies, such as Climate Impact X, are prioritizing community building and education on responsible use of carbon credits, while others, like MVGX, are developing proprietary technologies to track credits across borders and avoid double-counting.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Asia's booming carbon market - the road to net-zero or a minefield of risks?
'Now or never' to cut emissions and save the planet: UN
Exxon sees carbon capture market at US$4t by 2050
PHOTO: A carbon tax will likely lower Singapore’s greenhouse gas emissions, but its deployment warrants scrutiny and a careful weighing of costs and benefits.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida arranging to join Shangri-La Dialogue security summit: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is arranging to attend the Shangri-La Dialogue security summit in Singapore on June 10-12 to discuss Japan's defense buildup and promote international cooperation in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and China's maritime assertiveness. This will be Kishida's first appearance at the summit since 2014, when Shinzo Abe last attended.

site_title: Fed’s Barkin declines to take 75-basis-point hike off table
summary: US Federal Reserve officials, including Richmond Fed President Thomas Barkin, expressed determination to curb inflation, with Barkin stating that nothing is off the table, including a 75-basis-point interest rate hike. This comes amid criticism that the Fed is behind the curve in responding to the hottest inflation in 40 years.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve to move interest rates up 'steadily': Barkin

site_title: This is not your grandfather’s MBA
summary: Business schools are shifting their focus from solely training managers to address deeper philosophical questions about capitalism, including its means and ends. After decades of emphasizing financial markets and shareholder returns, schools are incorporating initiatives and programs that prioritize social impact, sustainability, and environmental concerns. However, critics argue that this is not enough, and that business schools should provide a more holistic education that encourages students to wrestle with giant, ambiguous questions about ultimate values and hierarchies of power. Experts suggest that the current curriculum is too focused on specialized skills and quantitative methods, and that a more interdisciplinary approach is needed to prepare managers for the complexities of the modern business world.

images.alt_text:
mlmba8 - Not your grandfather's MBA




source/copyright: NYT

site_title: Paris Olympics plan has Eiffel Tower volleyball, Seine swimming
summary: The Paris 2024 Olympic Games are well underway, with the organizing committee aiming to draw millions of visitors to the event. The games will feature unique sports such as beach volleyball at the Eiffel Tower, fencing at the Grand Palais, and equestrian competitions at Versailles Palace. The budget, 3.9 billion euros, is split equally among the International Olympic Committee, private companies, and ticket sales. The opening ceremony will be the largest in history, with a 6-kilometer procession along the Seine river, and will be largely ticket-free to attract a diverse crowd.

images.alt_text: Olympic ideals are on thin ice
Stakes 'never been higher' in fight against global warming: UN official
China faces Olympic-sized sporting challenge
EU hesitates over possible Olympic boycott in China

site_title: More ageing CBD buildings get new lease of life; pick-up helps support pandemic rents
summary: Singapore's redevelopment of ageing CBD buildings has gained momentum, supporting rents and injecting buzz into precincts. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has received 12 outline applications under the CBD Incentive Scheme, with 8 having been given in-principle approval, and 4 under the Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) Scheme. Analysts predict the redevelopment will contribute to upward pressure on rents, with CBD Grade A office rents expected to more than double this year. The projects will also introduce more live-in residents, boosting footfall and transforming the CBD into vibrant mixed-use neighbourhoods.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
International Plaza fails to get URA's nod for CBD Incentive Scheme
New projects on AXA Tower, PIL Building sites set to yield more office space
The death of offices may have been greatly exaggerated

site_title: Beijing kicks off fresh round of Covid tests as Shanghai postpones crucial exams
summary: China's capital Beijing has started a fresh round of mass Covid-19 testing, shutting more bus routes and metro stations, as it seeks to avoid the fate of Shanghai, where millions are locked down. Shanghai has postponed the university entrance exam, and authorities warn against complacency to stick to China's zero-Covid goal. The city is also building thousands of permanent PCR testing stations. Meanwhile, China's zero-Covid stance is inflicting a greater economic cost than in 2020, with car sales dropping 48% in April.

images.alt_text: Businesses ordered closed include karaoke bars, internet cafes, museums and art galleries, said Yang Beibei, deputy director of Chaoyang district.
A worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) rides a bicycle along a nearly-empty road in Shanghai on May 5, 2022.
China will roll out more support measures to help small firms and stabilise employment, including the introduction of policies to support the platform economy.

site_title: Argentine inflation seen surging to over 65% this year: central bank poll
summary: Argentina's inflation rate is expected to reach 65.1% this year, according to a central bank poll, a jump of 6 percentage points from the previous projection. Analysts also predict the average currency exchange rate will reach 155 Argentine pesos per US dollar by December, and 226 pesos by the end of 2023. The surge in inflation is attributed to the effects of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Brazil, Guayana agree to widen energy cooperation
summary: Brazil and Guyana agreed to expand energy cooperation during a visit by Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro to Georgetown, signing infrastructure and legal deals. The partnership aims to boost oil production, with Guyana emerging as a low-cost oil production country. The country is set to auction offshore oil blocks at the end of the year, with Petrobras, a Brazilian oil giant, expected to play a significant role in the cooperation.

images.alt_text: India’s government ordered coal-fired power plants that run on imported fuel to operate at full capacity to address an escalating energy crisis that’s threatening economic growth.
Oil prices edged up on Thursday on supply worries after the EU laid out plans for new sanctions against Russia including an embargo on crude.
A BP Pulse EV charging point outside BP’s headquarters in Milton Keynes, UK.

site_title: Xi warms up China's economy, but coronavirus narrows options
summary: China's economy is still struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic, with lockdowns and virus controls hindering growth. Despite President Xi Jinping's efforts to revive the economy with state backing for tech, infrastructure, and jobs, analysts warn that growth will continue to wilt until Beijing drops its rigid virus controls. The country's full-year growth target of 5.5% may be shaved off, with forecasters anticipating a 1% decrease. China's communist leadership has insisted on sticking to its zero-Covid strategy, citing "persistence is victory."

images.alt_text: Shanghai is also building thousands of permanent PCR testing stations, in line with other cities.

site_title: Toyota to invest 48b rupees to make electric vehicle parts in India
summary: Toyota plans to invest 48 billion rupees (S$864 million) to produce electric vehicle components in India, aiming to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The investment will be split between Toyota Kirloskar Motor (41 billion rupees) and Toyota Industries Engine India (7 billion rupees). This move is part of Toyota's efforts to align its green targets with India's ambitions of becoming a manufacturing hub for electric vehicles. The investment is expected to create around 3,500 new jobs, with Indian carmakers forecast to generate $20 billion in revenue from electric vehicles by 2026.

site_title: Taiwan says hopes world would sanction China if it invades
summary: Taiwan's foreign minister Joseph Wu said the island hopes the world would sanction China if it invades, echoing Western-led sanctions on Russia for its war on Ukraine. Taiwan has joined in sanctions on Russia and Belarus, with Wu stating it would stand with the international community in condemning aggression. The move is symbolic, given Taiwan's minimal trade with Belarus or Russia, but aims to show solidarity with Ukraine. If China invades, Taiwan hopes the international community will support and sanction it, similar to the response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: An Aframax vessel
China sends warplanes near Taiwan after US lawmaker's visit
China spurs Taiwan anger with criminal liability threat for independence supporters

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer worst week in 2 months; tech, retail fall
summary: European shares suffered their worst week in two months, with tech and retail stocks declining 2.4% and 2% respectively. The decline was driven by concerns over inflation, interest rate hikes, and economic growth. Retailers, such as Adidas, were hit by weak earnings reports and renewed lockdowns in China. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates later this year, exacerbating fears of a recession.

images.alt_text: European stocks fell for the second straight session on Thursday.

site_title: Rogers asks Quebecor to join bid for Shaw's Freedom Mobile: media
summary: Rogers Communications has asked Quebecor to join its bid for Shaw Communications' broadcasting services in a deal that would create Canada's second-largest cellular and cable operator. The acquisition, valued at C$20 billion, was previously approved by the Canadian telecommunications regulator for Shaw's Freedom Mobile. Quebecor's involvement comes two months after Globalive offered $2.9 billion for Freedom Mobile, and regulators are still reviewing Rogers' plans to buy the rest of Shaw's businesses.

images.alt_text: A view of the skyline in Toronto, Canada. It is dominated by the 553m-tall CN Tower, a communications and observation tower which offers fantastic views of the city.

site_title: Microsoft has US$1.3b at stake as US tests combat goggles
summary: Microsoft's HaloLens augmented-reality goggles are undergoing a month-long test by the Pentagon's testing office to determine their readiness for full production and deployment with the US Army. The $1.3 billion project aims to develop a "heads-up display" for US ground forces, featuring night vision and other features. The test will assess the goggles' effectiveness in a simulated combat environment and could lead to a positive "Rapid Fielding Report," freeing up $1.3 billion in spending.

images.alt_text: From robots to the metaverse: How Intuitive Surgical is changing the face of medical surgery
Microsoft reported quarterly sales and earnings that topped analysts' projections, fueled by robust growth in cloud-services demand.

site_title: Coinhako receives MAS licence to offer crypto payment services
summary: Coinhako, a Singapore-based cryptocurrency exchange, has received a major payment institution (MPI) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), allowing it to offer digital payment token (DPT) services. The platform, which has over 400,000 registered users, has grown its staff count to over 200 employees. Coinhako's co-founder and CEO Yusho Liu said the licence will enable the company to further its mission as Asia's gateway to the crypto-economy. The move follows a temporary exemption granted last year.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: China-backed John Lee new Hong Kong leader in uncontested vote
summary: China-backed John Lee has been formally confirmed as Hong Kong's next leader after an uncontested election, solidifying direct Chinese control over the financial hub. Lee, 64, won 1,416 votes, exceeding the required majority, and will start his five-year term as Chief Executive on July 1. His top priorities are expected to be recovery from the pandemic and addressing the city's housing shortage. The election marked the city's first without a contest in over two decades, following China's reforms and the Communist Party's endorsement of Lee.

images.alt_text: The HKMA’s base rate was increased to 1.25 per cent from 0.75 per cent, it said in a statement on its website Thursday (May 5).

Lee faces no competition but will inherit a city convulsed by huge democracy protests, an ongoing crackdown on political freedoms and more than 2 years of pandemic curbs that have left residents and businesses internationally isolated.

site_title: Inflation hits Mother’s Day with flower prices up 14% since 2020
summary: Flower prices have increased by 14% since the early days of the pandemic, according to the Labor Department. This rise in prices is attributed to various factors, including supply-chain issues and transportation difficulties. Flower shop owners, such as Marie Noe, have raised their prices by 24% in the past three years to cover costs. Despite high prices, demand remains strong, and some shops, like Mayesh, are innovating new designs to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Book cover: How To Cook Everything Singaporean by Denise Fletcher
In embattled Ukraine, spring flowers take on patriotic hues

site_title: Beijing district shuts gyms, movie theaters to halt Covid spread
summary: Beijing's Chaoyang district has ordered gyms, movie theaters, and other non-essential businesses to close to prevent the spread of Covid-19, following President Xi Jinping's reaffirmation of China's "Covid Zero" policy. The district, home to international companies, has also implemented mass testing and lockdowns. China reported 45 new Covid cases in Beijing and 4,620 local infections nationwide, with 13 deaths. The city of Shanghai has postponed college entrance examinations due to infection risk.

site_title: 'Like family': Japan's virtual YouTubers make millions from fans
summary: Japan's virtual YouTubers, known as VTubers, have transformed a niche subculture into a thriving industry, with top accounts earning over $1 million annually. Fans interact with their favorite animated idols, often paying hundreds of dollars for highlighted comments, and some devote significant time and resources to their virtual relationships. A Japanese court recently ruled in favor of a VTuber actor who argued that online slander against her character amounted to an attack on her, highlighting the blurred line between virtual and real identities.

Riot Games launches royalty-free album for streamers

site_title: China tensions dominate Australia-Solomons diplomats’ meeting
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Marise Payne expressed "deep concerns" over the Solomon Islands' security agreement with China, citing lack of transparency, during a face-to-face diplomatic meeting in Brisbane. The agreement has raised fears of a Chinese naval base in the region, prompting Australia's and US's public objections. Australia remains the Solomon Islands' security partner of choice, but the meeting highlighted deteriorating relations between Australia and China, with Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison considering the agreement a "red line".

images.alt_text: Behind in the polls, Scott Morrison’s Liberal government had pointed to its stances on China as a reason to support his party, and claimed without evidence that Beijing was backing the Labor opposition.

site_title: North Korea may have fired ballistic missile, Japan says
summary: North Korea may have fired a ballistic missile, according to Japan's Coast Guard. South Korea separately reported that North Korea launched an unidentified projectile off its east coast. The previous day, North Korea fired a ballistic missile that flew 780 kilometers into space before falling into the sea. The exact details of the new incident are unclear, but the reports suggest North Korea's continued missile activity.

images.alt_text: People watch a television screen showing a news broadcast with file footage of a North Korean missile test, at a railway station in Seoul on May 4, 2022. - North Korea fired a ballistic missile on May 4, South Korea's military said, just a week after leader Kim Jong Un vowed to boost Pyongyang's nuclear arsenal at the "fastest possible speed". (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Fed hawks Waller, Bullard push back on 'behind the curve' view
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers Christopher Waller and James Bullard pushed back on the notion that the central bank has missed the boat on fighting high inflation, citing a tightening of financial conditions that began before interest rate hikes in March. They argued that forward guidance on rate hikes started in September 2021, which may have been viewed as appropriate policy by some based on the labor market's health. This contradicts the "behind the curve" view that the Fed should have acted earlier to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The central bank has faced criticism that it is behind the curve in responding to the hottest inflation in 40 years.
The Fed's task under current conditions is extraordinarily difficult. The most it can do is avoid making the problem worse with unforced policy errors.
There are signs that high labour costs are starting to hurt small businesses, especially those in the leisure and hospitality industry.

site_title: Crypto bridge heists swiping US$1b spur race for alternatives
summary: Hackers have stolen over US$1 billion from crypto bridges like Wormhole and Ronin, prompting a rush for secure alternatives. Crypto exchanges FTX and Coinbase Global are developing bridge-like services on various blockchains, allowing users to swap digital tokens across networks. Additionally, app developers are moving onto new blockchains, making bridges unnecessary for certain transactions, and increasing competition in the market.

site_title: Musk aims to increase Twitter's revenue to US$26.4b by 2028: NYT
summary: Elon Musk aims to increase Twitter's annual revenue to $26.4 billion by 2028, down from 90% advertising revenue to 45% in 2028, generating $12 billion in ad revenue and $10 billion in subscription revenue. The company also expects to bring in $15 million from a payments business in 2023, growing to $1.3 billion by 2028. Musk is expected to become Twitter's temporary CEO after closing the takeover, according to a person familiar with the matter.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, who is buying Twitter for US$44 billion, has tweeted that the platform should not have ads so it can have more control over its content moderation policies.
Elon Musk said on Tuesday Twitter will always be free for casual users but may charge a slight fee for commercial and government users.
Activist groups called on Twitter advertisers on Tuesday to boycott the service if it opens the gates to abusive and misinformative posts with Elon Must as its owner.

site_title: Tesla sues engineer over ‘Dojo’ supercomputer technology theft
summary: Tesla sued a former engineer, Alexander Yatskov, for allegedly stealing confidential information on its supercomputer technology, Project Dojo. Yatskov, hired as a thermal engineer in January, was accused of transferring the information to his own computer. Tesla claims he also provided a "dummy" laptop for inspection to cover up the theft. The lawsuit seeks to protect Tesla's in-house supercomputer technology, used to process massive amounts of data, including video from Tesla cars, and create autonomous driving software.

images.alt_text: TESLA is aiming to increase its Shanghai plant's daily output to 2,600 cars from May 16, an internal memo seen by Reuters said, as it seeks to return production to levels before the city locked down to control the spread of Covid-19.
Tesla vehicles are displayed during the opening day of the Tesla 'Gigafactory' in Gruenheide near Berlin, Germany, 22 March 2022.
Elon Musk and Cathie Wood (above) criticised passive investing in a Twitter thread, weighing in on a controversial and unresolved debate.

Elon Musk likened Apple and its App Store to the equivalent of a "30 per cent tax on the Internet" and said the fee is "10 times higher than it should be", in a series of tweets responding to an article about the European Union's latest antitrust complaint against the tech giant.

site_title: Deciphering common symptoms
summary: Common symptoms such as memory decline, morning headaches, and chest pain can be indicative of various health issues. Frequent morning headaches may be caused by obstructive sleep apnea, while memory impairment can be linked to lack of oxygen during sleep, general anesthesia, or heavy alcohol consumption. Chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion can be related to heart artery disease, but risk assessment scoring systems are not always accurate. A CTCA (Computed Tomography Coronary Angiogram) can virtually rule out heart attack in individuals with normal heart arteries, and its use is recommended as a first-line investigation for suspected heart disease.

images.alt_text: Listen to your heart: Separating myth from fact

site_title: Ideology returns to war and peace
summary: The second Cold War has begun, marked by a resumption of ideological rivalry between the US and Russia. The conflict in Ukraine is a manifestation of this rivalry, with Russia's determination to prevent NATO expansion into its territory. Ideology plays a crucial role in international relations, with leaders judging threats based on the domestic legitimacy of their states. The US and Russia are on opposite sides of a zero-sum game, where one side's gain is the other's loss. The conflict has the potential to alienate countries that are against aggression but not willing to follow the Western narrative of democracy as the only legitimate basis for international relations.

images.alt_text: Yellen urges China to help stop Russia's war in Ukraine, or lose standing in the world

site_title: Chinese web users get creative to dodge Covid censorship
summary: Chinese web users are using creative methods to dodge censorship and voice discontent over Covid measures, despite China's tight grip on the internet. Censors have deleted popular hashtags and quotes from the national anthem, while users have hijacked other hashtags and referenced dystopian novels to make tongue-in-cheek comments. Despite the risks, people in Shanghai have become more willing to post critical views, with some even receiving calls from police to delete posts. The government's hardline approach on zero-Covid is unlikely to change, with President Xi Jinping personally invested in the policy.

images.alt_text: In one example, censors deleted a popular hashtag on the Weibo social media platform quoting the first line of China’s national anthem: “Arise, those who refuse to be slaves.”

site_title: US offers reward for hackers behind Costa Rica attack
summary: The US State Department has offered up to $10 million for information leading to the identification or location of the leaders of the Russian-linked Conti hacking group, responsible for a recent attack on government institutions in Costa Rica. The reward is part of a larger effort to combat cybercrime and protect potential victims worldwide. Conti has been linked to over 1,000 victims and $150 million in payouts, making it the costliest strain of ransomware ever documented. The US commitment to combating cybercrime demonstrates its dedication to protecting its citizens and global partners from exploitation by cybercriminals.

images.alt_text: A handful of hacker groups aligned with the Russian government have carried out hundreds of cyberattacks against Ukraine since Moscow invaded, Microsoft said in a report on Wednesday.

site_title: Biden announces US$150m more weapons for Ukraine
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a new $150 million weapons package for Ukraine, bringing the total US aid to $3.8 billion since Russia's invasion in February. The package includes 25,000 artillery rounds, counter-artillery radars, and electronic jamming equipment. Biden warned that funding was close to running out and urged Congress to authorize an additional $33 billion package, which would include $20 billion in military assistance, to support Ukraine for the next five months.

images.alt_text: President Biden has now an opportunity to upgrade his Asia policy by taking steps to promote and liberalise trade in the region.

The superyacht Amadea reportedly owned by a Russian oligarch; US President Joe Biden announced a proposal to ratchet up economic pressure on Russia, with enhanced seizure and forfeiture procedures allowing oligarchs’ seized assets to be “sold off” to “remedy the harm Russia caused and to help build Ukraine”.
Putin and Zelenskiy have accepted invitations from Indonesia, the current chair of the Group of 20 (G20), for a big ticket summit in November.

site_title: US: Tech shares lead stocks lower after solid jobs data
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, led by tech shares, despite a solid jobs report that showed a 428,000 job gain in April with a 3.6% unemployment rate. The jobs data failed to boost markets as investors worry about slowing growth and higher interest rates. Energy stocks were the only sector to rise, driven by higher oil prices. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, but concerns about tariffs and interest rates kept markets cautious.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 224.09 points or 0.68 per cent at the open to 32,773.88.

site_title: Dairy Farm International changes name to DFI Retail Group Holdings
summary: Dairy Farm International has changed its name to DFI Retail Group Holdings, effective May 5. The company will maintain its primary listing on the London Stock Exchange and secondary listings in Bermuda and Singapore. The name change does not affect shareholders, and existing share certificates remain valid. The company's shares closed at US$2.74 on Friday, down 2.1% due to the announcement.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Inflation and the investment outlook
summary: High inflation is biting into people's incomes, forcing them to make tougher choices about what they can afford. Rising interest rates have replaced official money printing, and companies that have historically grown strongly may struggle as demand for discretionary items drops. The US is set to catch up with several rate rises, while the euro area lags behind in its efforts to curb inflation. Central banks face a delicate balance between cooling inflation and avoiding recession, with the war in Ukraine and supply chain disruptions exacerbating the issue.

images.alt_text: The Fed needs to regain control of the policy narrative if it is to have any chance to land the economy softly.

site_title: Pro-Marcos accounts dominate online misinformation in Philippine polls
summary: In the Philippines, pro-Marcos accounts dominate online misinformation in the lead-up to the presidential election, with fake and misleading posts on social media platforms such as Facebook, TikTok, and YouTube. The accounts, which have millions of followers, have spread false information about Marcos Jr's opponent, Leni Robredo, and her campaign. Analysis by AFP's Fact Check team shows that Marcos Jr has been the beneficiary of misinformation portraying his family in a favorable light since 2021. The top super-spreader accounts of election-related misinformation are all pro-Marcos, with some receiving tens of thousands of interactions per week.

site_title: Markets are weaker than US economy, Bridgewater’s Prince says
summary: US stocks and bonds declined amid concerns over inflation and the Federal Reserve's rate-hiking policy, with the S&P 500 Index falling for its fifth-straight week. The US economy, however, continues to perform well, with consumer inflation rising to 8.5% in March. Experts, including Bridgewater's Bob Prince, advise diversifying portfolios with commodities, inflation-indexed bonds, and cash, rather than growth stocks. Prince states that financial markets are "much weaker than the economy," a reversal of previous trends.

images.alt_text: Of the 11 sectors in the S&P 500, 10 closed with losses Friday, with only energy stocks rising as oil prices climbed.
Christopher Waller and James Bullard were among the first Fed policy makers last year to call for a rapid removal of easy monetary policy and a quicker start to raising interest rates.
US job growth increased more than expected in April, underscoring the economy's strong fundamentals despite a contraction in gross domestic product in the first quarter.

site_title: Economists see Japan's inflation hitting at least 2.1% in April
summary: Japan's key inflation gauge is expected to exceed 2% in April, with consumer prices excluding fresh food likely rising by at least 2.1% due to stronger-than-expected price growth in Tokyo. This could make it harder for the Bank of Japan to justify its stimulus policies. Economists warn that prolonged inflation could lead to policy adjustments, and a weaker yen could push inflation to 3%. The Bank of Japan's Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has expressed no intention of tightening policy, but pressure may build on him to act before his term ends next April.

site_title: The Godfather who was born to live a life of football
summary: Antonio Conte, Tottenham Hotspur manager known as "The Godfather," opens up about his passion for football. A 52-year-old former Italy international player, Conte has delivered accolades in the Beautiful Game, including 13 seasons at Juventus and 17 years as a manager with 9 different clubs. He credits his drive to his love for football, saying it's his biggest passion in life. Conte has turned Tottenham around, leading the team to a 3-1 win over Leicester City, their 100th Premier League game under his management, and remains in contention for a top 4 place.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Left to right: Dejan Kulusevski, Eric Dier, Harry Winks, Lucas Moura. Tottenham Hotspur players will wear jerseys with 'AIA Better Lives Fund' emblazoned on the front to raise funds for disadvantaged children during their EPL match on Sunday (May 1).

site_title: Bill Gates explains "How to prevent the next pandemic"
summary: Bill Gates' new book "How to Prevent the Next Pandemic" proposes a global "fire brigade" of 3,000 experts to respond to outbreaks, as well as improving vaccine manufacturing and distribution, and developing heat-tolerant vaccines. Gates suggests creating a permanent standby team, GERM, to boost the world's anti-pandemic infrastructure and run drills. He also proposes designing protocols for rapid mass-testing of potential treatments and developing universal vaccines against entire classes of viruses, such as influenza. The idea aims to prevent pandemics by combining human and technological efforts.

images.alt_text: Sanofi's vaccine production facility to strengthen Singapore's future pandemic readiness

site_title: AGV Group responds to SGX queries on police reports filed
summary: AGV Group's judicial managers responded to Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) queries on police reports filed against the company's subsidiaries for alleged mismanagement and wrongdoing. The reports concern irregular selling prices and customs offenses in Malaysia. The judicial managers stated they are translating the police reports into English and are unable to assess the impact due to unverified allegations. The "certain persons" involved remain part of the group and hold key management positions.

site_title: China's outstanding property loans up 6% y/y at end-Q1
summary: China's outstanding property loans rose 6% year-over-year to 53.22 trillion yuan at the end of Q1, with new loans totaling 1.05 trillion yuan. Individual mortgages increased 8.9% to 38.84 trillion yuan, while property development loans decreased 0.4% to 12.56 trillion yuan. Authorities have eased financing controls to boost the economy. The interest rate for new individual mortgages fell to 5.42% in March.

site_title: No Signboard gets lawyer's letter from private investor over scrapped loan deal
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a seafood-restaurant operator, has received a lawyer's letter from private investor Bryan Lim over the termination of a scrapped loan deal. The company's board stated that it will work towards an amicable resolution, maintaining its unchanged position. The incident comes as the company has flagged going concern issues due to operating challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic on the food and beverage business.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
RESTAURANT operator No Signboard Holdings has terminated its conditional sale and purchase agreement to sell a 29 per cent stake in the company to Q&M Dental chief executive Ng Siau Chin.
Deal with Q&M Dental CEO 'key part' of trading resumption proposal: No Signboard

Renewable biomass project developer and operator Gazelle Ventures has entered into a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) to invest up to S$5 million in Catalyst-listed restaurant operator No Signboard Holdings.

site_title: New Covid-19 cases in Singapore fall to 3,420 after a spike the day before
summary: Singapore reported 3,420 new Covid-19 cases on May 6, down from 4,733 the previous day, with 3,201 locally transmitted cases and 219 imported cases. Hospitalized cases numbered 244, with 5 in intensive care and 24 requiring oxygen support. Two deaths were reported, bringing the total to 1,346 deaths and 1,212,337 cases. The weekly infection growth rate stood at 0.88, up from 0.82 the day before.

site_title: US job growth solid in April; unemployment rate holds steady at 3.6%
summary: US job growth increased more than expected in April, with nonfarm payrolls rising by 428,000 jobs, beating economists' forecasts of 391,000 jobs. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.6%. This strong job growth underscores the economy's fundamentals despite a contraction in gross domestic product in the first quarter.

site_title: The sustainable rise of sustainable investing
summary: Sustainable investing is gaining momentum globally, with over a quarter of assets under management now invested based on ESG factors. A recent HSBC survey found that 80% of investors in Singapore rate sustainable and environmental issues as very important. Banks are supporting this trend by lending expertise to businesses transitioning to low-carbon emissions and creating ESG-centric products. However, accountability and the lack of common standards are concerns, with ASEAN governments working to unify work and create standards. To tap into the full potential of financial markets, governments, regulators, and the public must continue to support ESG solutions, making investments that lower emissions crucial for a better world.

images.alt_text: To invest with impact, we need to invest in the planet

site_title: Don't expect the Fed to work miracles
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its policy interest rate by half a percentage point, accelerating its asset reduction plan to combat inflation at 5.2% on the Fed's preferred measure. The move is seen as necessary but acknowledges the difficulty in achieving non-inflationary growth due to the economy's strong recovery and global supply chain disruptions. The Fed aims to strike a balance, avoiding policy errors, and emphasizes that it will adjust its approach as circumstances require. However, it faces the challenge of communicating its intentions clearly, particularly regarding its target interest rate, which remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by half a percentage point on May 4 and announced that it would soon shrink its portfolio of bond holdings.

site_title: Rethinking the ethics of AI - and ours
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is emerging as a critical issue, with significant implications for society, businesses, and democracies. The potential risks of AI, including safety and discrimination concerns, are being tracked and studied by organizations like the OECD and Partnership in AI. To ensure AI is ethical, academics are proposing a new field of study, "Computational Ethics," which aims to develop tools and processes for making decisions in AI systems. This field draws lessons from history, including the development of computational neuroscience, and seeks to better understand human moral behavior and build ethical AI systems.

images.alt_text: The dark side of using AI to design drugs

site_title: Shell in talks to sell Russia fuel stations as part of exit plan
summary: Shell is in talks to sell its 370 fuel stations in Russia as part of its exit plan from the country following the invasion of Ukraine. The company's retail network, Shell Neft, is being considered for sale, with Russia's Lukoil PJSC reportedly the most likely buyer. Shell's main investments in Russia include a partnership with Gazprom in the Sakhalin-2 liquefied natural gas project and financing the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline. The company has taken a $3.89 billion impairment charge related to its planned exit from Russia.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang starts previews for Liv @ MB; units priced from S$1.08m to S$3.63m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates has opened previews for its 99-year-leasehold project Liv @ MB in Singapore, with indicative prices ranging from S$1.08 million for a 1-bedroom unit to S$3.63 million for a 4-bedroom deluxe unit. The project features 298 units across four blocks, with prices starting from S$2,190 psf for 1-bedroom units. Other new launches in the east include boutique development Atlassia and Baywind Residences, which are expected to draw strong interest from buyers.

images.alt_text: CDL, MCL launch this weekend to kick off batch of upcoming projects

site_title: Crypto’s promises keep crashing
summary: Cryptocurrency and non-fungible tokens (NFTs) have been plagued by "colossal crypto grifts" and "broken-casino" speculation, with the Bored Apes Yacht Club being a prime example. The digital art collection has become a hot commodity, with some NFTs selling for millions of dollars. However, the process has been marred by technical issues, hacking, and phishing scams, with thousands of people paying high transaction fees and losing money. Experts say the technology is not ready for widespread use and that the promised decentralization and freedom from tech giants have not materialized.

site_title: Why age should not be a barrier
summary: A common perception among workers in Singapore is that those in their late 40s will reach career stagnation. However, experts argue that age is not a barrier to employment and that skills, not age, should make the difference when hiring. A Randstad survey found that 58% of respondents believe they will reach career stagnation at 48 years old, but employers should consider the wealth of experience that older workers bring. As Singapore raises the retirement age to 68, job-seekers in the older age group should manage their expectations and focus on upskilling, with many companies now prioritizing skills-based hiring.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

After decades of emphasis on financial markets and shareholder returns, business schools are trying to take on deeper philosophical problems — including, maybe, tentative questions about the means and ends of capitalism itself.

site_title: UK retailer McColl’s collapses after financing talks fail
summary: UK retailer McColl's has collapsed into insolvency after refinancing talks with banks and wholesale supplier Wm Morrison Supermarkets failed, putting 16,000 jobs at risk. The company, which operates over 1,200 convenience stores, has appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers as administrator and expects a sale to a third-party purchaser to take place soon. The billionaire Issa brothers, behind EG Group, have expressed interest in purchasing the business, which could potentially keep stores open and employees employed.

images.alt_text: eBay became the latest e-commerce retailer to give a gloomy revenue forecast as growth slows in the sector after two years of rapid expansion during the pandemic.

site_title: Pump prices in Singapore rise, 92-octane fuel prices reach new highs amid renewed talks of Russian oil ban
summary: Petrol prices in Singapore have surged, with 92-octane fuel reaching new highs of up to S$3.10 a litre and diesel breaching the S$3 mark. The price increases are attributed to fears of a potential Russian oil ban, which could crimp global supply and drive up prices. Meanwhile, 95- and 98-octane fuels have seen modest increases, with the cheapest options available at S$2.41 and S$2.79 per litre, respectively. The European Union's discussion of a partial ban on Russian oil has contributed to the price hike.

images.alt_text: Cutting fuel duties would 'effectively amount to subsidy on private transport': Lawrence Wong

site_title: Golden Mile Complex sold to Far East, Perennial, Sino Land for S$700m
summary: The Golden Mile Complex in Beach Road, a conservation landmark, has been sold to a consortium of Far East Organization, Perennial Holdings, and Sino Land for S$700 million. The sale comes after two en bloc tenders at a reserve price of S$800 million, with the consortium making a lower offer via private-treaty negotiations. The offer has secured consent from over 80% of owners in both strata areas and share values.

site_title: China vows stronger supervision to stabilise coal prices
summary: China's state planner has vowed to deploy stronger forces to stabilise coal prices and punish price gouging, following new price caps set by the National Development and Reform Commission. The price caps, effective from May 1, aim to balance coal miners' and power generators' profits amid record high coal prices. The move is part of China's efforts to address power shortages and stabilise energy costs. The NDRC will step in and call for a legal investigation if coal prices exceed reference ranges, and has set price guidance for ex-pit coal in major mining regions.

images.alt_text: A tanker in front of a fuel depot of Aral at the Ruhr Oel petroleum refineries of BP Gelsenkirchen GmbH in Gelsenkirchen, western Germany in March.  (PHOTO:  Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)

site_title: PBOC to launch relending facility to aid transport, logistics
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced a 100 billion yuan (S$20.7 billion) relending facility to support the transport, logistics, and storage sectors, which have been severely impacted by Covid-19. The facility aims to provide liquidity to these sectors, stimulate market drivers, and boost the real economy. The PBOC plans to better combine its policy instruments and optimize its structural policy system to achieve stable growth. This move is seen as a response to the ongoing challenges faced by China's logistics and transportation industries.

images.alt_text: CHINA'S central bank on Wednesday (May 4)  pledged monetary policy support to ensure ample liquidity, help businesses badly hit by the latest Covid-19 outbreak in the country and support a recovery in consumption.

site_title: BOE's Pill says UK must accept income hit from high inflation
summary: The Bank of England's chief economist, Huw Pill, warned that the UK is unlikely to recover lost income due to high inflation, stating that a "real income squeeze" is taking place. The BOE has forecast inflation to surpass 10% this year, leading to a sharp economic slowdown and possible recession. Pill noted that monetary policy cannot cushion people from rising energy and goods prices, and that some individuals and businesses may need to accept the reality of reduced income. The BOE has raised interest rates to 1.0% to combat inflation.

site_title: UK police to probe Labour leader over possible lockdown breach
summary: UK police will investigate opposition leader Keir Starmer over potential Covid-19 lockdown rule breaches in 2021, following significant new information. Starmer had previously called for Prime Minister Boris Johnson and finance minister Rishi Sunak to resign after they received fines for party celebrations. New footage showed Starmer drinking indoors with colleagues in April 2021, prompting an investigation by Durham police. The Labour Party says they are "happy to answer any questions" and remain confident no rules were broken.

images.alt_text: Johnson, Sunak fined for breaking Covid lockdown rules

site_title: Grand Venture Technology posts 8.9% rise in Q1 2022 after-tax profit
summary: Grand Venture Technology posted a 8.9% rise in Q1 2022 after-tax profit to S$3.6 million, up from S$3.3 million last year. Revenue grew 41% to S$32.5 million, driven by increased demand for semiconductor chips and growth across all business segments. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) rose 19.5% to S$7.8 million. The company expects challenges from higher input costs but plans to pass on cost increases to customers.
