site_title: 'The Rock', a record-setting white diamond, goes up for auction
summary: A record-setting 228.31 carat white diamond, 'The Rock', is set to auction off in Geneva, Switzerland, with an estimated price of up to US$30 million. The pear-shaped stone, mined in South Africa, is one of the rarest gems ever sold at auction and boasts a perfectly symmetrical form. The sale, by Christie's, also features a 205.07 carat yellow diamond called 'The Red Cross Diamond', with proceeds going to the International Committee of the Red Cross to support clean water for conflict-affected areas.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as jobs data adds to rate hike worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones falling 224.09 points or 0.68% to 32,773.88, amid concerns over larger interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve to control inflation. Stronger-than-expected jobs data fueled these worries. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 opening 18.70 points or 0.45% lower at 4,128.17 and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 70.86 points or 0.58% to 12,246.83.

site_title: Far East Orchard back in the black with Q1 net profit of S$2.6m
summary: Far East Orchard (FEOR) reported a net profit of S$2.6 million in Q1 2022, up from a loss of S$0.7 million in the same period last year, driven by the recognition of a sale and unrealised foreign exchange gains. Revenue grew 7.6% to S$29.7 million. The company remains confident in its student accommodation business and hospitality segment, with international borders reopening expected to recapture pent-up travel demands.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Far East Orchard's full-year net profit rises to S$28.1m on fair-value gains
Time for change: Arthur Kiong, CEO, Far East Hospitality

site_title: China's to cut volume of soybeans in next week's sale from state reserves
summary: China will sell 314,000 tonnes of imported soybeans from its state reserves on May 13, a lower volume than previous auctions. This may be due to low demand from crushers, indicating poor appetite for the beans. The move aims to alleviate tight supply in the domestic market, with imported soybean arrivals expected to pick up from March. The reduced volume is part of Beijing's efforts to manage the market and ease supply constraints.

site_title: Under Armour profit view hit by higher costs, China lockdowns
summary: Under Armour reported lower-than-expected full-year profit due to higher transportation costs and the impact of renewed Covid-19 curbs in China. The company forecast an adjusted profit between 63 cents and 68 cents per share for fiscal year 2023, below analysts' average estimate. Quarterly sales fell 10% in premarket trading, with a 14% decline in revenue from the Asia-Pacific region overshadowing a 4% growth in North America. The company also reported net revenue of $1.30 billion in the quarter, missing expectations.

site_title: British pound could fall to as low as S$1.65 amid inflation, recession concerns, say analysts
summary: The British pound is expected to fall to as low as S$1.65 this year due to inflation and recession concerns in the UK. The Bank of England's 25 basis point interest rate hike to 1% has weighed on the pound, with some analysts predicting a decline to 1.655. The UK's inflation rate could rise to 10% and economic growth is expected to be squeezed, with household spending taking a hit as prices outpace wage growth.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Asian equities tumbled on Friday following a rout on Wall Street.

site_title: Larsen’s software units agree to merge in stock-swap deal
summary: Mindtree and Larsen & Toubro Infotech, two software units controlled by a Mumbai-based engineering conglomerate, have agreed to merge in a stock-swap deal. Shareholders of Mindtree will receive 73 L&T Infotech shares for every 100 shares held. The proposed merger aims to help the companies compete with global digital giants as software companies see surging demand from businesses embracing digitalisation. The deal is the latest in a series of mergers and acquisitions in the software sector, driven by accelerated digitalisation during the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: epa09914551 Attendees to the Regional Forum of the Council of Ministers of Health of Central America and the Dominican Republic (Comisca) follow the conference with their computers, in Panama City, Panama, 28 April 2022. The Council intends to discuss mental health policies and actions in order to create a 'political document' that improves its approach under the slogan 'Joining Forces for Mental Health'.  EPA-EFE/Bienvenido Velasco

site_title: Fraser and Neave H1 profits down by 20.8% to S$65.3 million as higher costs bite
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) reported a 20.8% decline in net profit to S$65.3 million for the first half-year of 2022, driven by rising material and energy costs. Beverage revenue rose 2.2% to S$1.01 billion, with beer profits more than doubling, while the dairies segment fell 20.6% due to unfavorable foreign currency translation and shipping disruptions. The printing and publishing segment recorded a wider operating loss of S$11.6 million. Despite this, F&N remains optimistic about exports and the halal packaged food segment, with plans to enter the upstream dairy business through an investment in Ladang Permai Damai.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

Bottles of Fraser & Neave Ltd. (F&N) carbonated soft drinks are displayed for sale on a shelf in a supermarket in Singapore, on Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2013. Fraser & Neave, controlled by Thailand’s richest man Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, climbed the most in five weeks on plans to spin off its property business through a Singapore listing at the end of the year. Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg
ThaiBev to revive unit's US$2b Singapore IPO, sources say

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 18.64 points to 1,564.34. The index saw 3.109 billion lots traded worth RM2.438 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 768 to 274, indicating a bearish trend in the market.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse names Yiu, Buckley co-COOs as Tai retires
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) has appointed Wilfred Yiu and John Buckley as co-chief operating officers, replacing Calvin Tai, who retires after 24 years. The appointment is effective June 1. Tai, who joined in 1998, oversaw the exchange's transformation from a members-exchange to a quasi-public organisation with nearly 6% government ownership. HKEX reported a 31% drop in profit in the first quarter, amid a decline in initial public offerings and stock trading. CEO Nicolas Aguzin has vowed to build the exchange on its existing bonds with China and expand its international footprint.

site_title: Citi speeds push to add 700 private bankers with Europe outposts
summary: Citigroup is expanding its private banking operations, opening two new offices in Paris and Frankfurt, and hiring 700 private bankers in the coming years. The move aims to deepen the bank's presence in catering to ultra-wealthy clients, doubling its private banking workforce. The private bank, which operates in 52 cities across 20 countries, has seen a 6% increase in revenue to $4 billion in 2021. The expansion is part of Citigroup's strategy to improve returns, following the combination of its private banking and wealth management divisions last year.

site_title: Hwa Hong served notice of compliance to appoint independent reviewer to review company’s board nomination process
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a notice of compliance to Hwa Hong Corporation, requiring the company to appoint an independent reviewer to review its board nomination process following the resignation of former independent and non-executive director Mak Lye Mun. The review will assess internal controls, processes, and practices, as well as the selection and appointment of potential directors. The company must also disclose any connections or relationships between potential candidates and directors/shareholders.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Property company Hwa Hong Corporation responded to queries raised by the Singapore Exchange on the resignation of Mak Lye Mun as its independent and non-executive director.

site_title: First Reit posts 1.5% rise in Q1 2022 DPU to 0.66 Singapore cents
summary: First Reit reported a 1.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.66 Singapore cents for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022. Rental and other income grew 32% to S$25.5 million, while net property and other income rose 34.9% to S$25.2 million. The increases were driven by the 1-month maiden contribution from the acquisition of 12 Japan nursing homes and accounting treatment for leases.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: China’s oil giant says it’s not seeking discounted Russian fuel
summary: China's state-owned oil giant PetroChina is not seeking discounted Russian fuel, according to company executives. The company is purchasing fuel from Russia through existing contracts and is settling transactions in US dollars or euros despite international sanctions. This contrasts with other countries, such as India, which is offering to buy Russian oil at discounted prices due to financing hurdles. PetroChina's decision suggests the company is committed to its existing contracts and is not affected by the global sanctions.

site_title: EU tweaks Russia oil sanctions plan in bid to win over reluctant states: sources
summary: The European Union has proposed changes to its planned embargo on Russian oil to win over reluctant states, including Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic. The tweaked proposal gives these countries more time to adapt, allowing them to buy Russian oil from pipelines until the end of 2024. The EU also extends the transition period for banning EU shipping services from transporting Russian oil from three months to one. This move aims to address concerns from countries like Greece and Cyprus about the impact on their shipping companies.

site_title: Deciphering common symptoms
summary: Common symptoms such as decreased memory, morning headaches, chest pain, and shortness of breath can be indicative of various health issues. Understanding the potential causes of these symptoms, including obstructive sleep apnea, post-anesthesia memory impairment, and heart disease, can aid in early detection and prevention of adverse health outcomes. Diagnostic tools like Computed Tomography Coronary Angiogram (CTCA) can help rule out heart disease and predict the likelihood of a heart attack, with normal CTCA results indicating a low risk of heart attack in the next two years.

images.alt_text: Better ways to take care of your ticker in 2022

site_title: Tesla targets pre-lockdown output in Shanghai by mid-May
summary: Tesla aims to increase its Shanghai plant's daily output to 2,600 cars starting May 16, as it seeks to return production to pre-lockdown levels. The move comes after the plant reopened on April 19 following a 22-day closure due to the Covid-19 lockdown. Tesla plans to add more shifts to achieve this goal, which would bring weekly output to 16,900 vehicles. The move is seen as a step towards recovering production levels at the plant before Shanghai lockdown curbs were enacted in late March.

site_title: India asks coal plants to run flat out to ease power crisis
summary: India's government ordered coal-fired power plants that run on imported fuel to operate at full capacity to address an escalating energy crisis threatening economic growth. The move comes as power demand surges amid a blistering summer, with production of coal failing to keep pace. The order, valid until October 31, aims to ease the power crisis and boost generation from curbed plants. However, the long-term goal is to end the use of imported coal for power plants, with plans to revive production from abandoned mines and prepare for the impact of the monsoon season.

images.alt_text: The move is contrary to a long-standing national objective to buy less coal from abroad but widely seen as a temporary measure to address shortfalls amid rising power demand caused by soaring temperatures and a pickup in industrial activity.

site_title: Boris Johnson’s Conservatives suffer early losses in local elections, key tests to come
summary: Boris Johnson's Conservatives suffered early losses in English local elections, with 53 council seats lost to the Labour Party and Liberal Democrats. The results, held amidst a cost-of-living crisis and Johnson's COVID-19 lockdown fine, are seen as a rebuff to the party. The opposition Labour Party gained 1 seat and the Liberal Democrats 27 seats. The full tally will be released later on Friday, offering a key snapshot of public opinion since Johnson's 2019 general election victory.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with big loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.81% on Friday, mirroring a global sell-off driven by rising interest rates, inflation, and concerns over China's Covid lockdowns. The Hang Seng Index fell to 20,001.96, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses were attributed to traders' worries over China's economic outlook and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: New, outgoing Q&M Dental CFOs join Aoxin Q&M board
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group has appointed Ng Sook Hwa and Vitters Sim Yu Xiong as non-executive and non-independent directors, respectively. Ng will also take over as CFO from May 7, succeeding Sim. The appointments come as Wan Sin Nee, the current financial controller, resigns to focus on family commitments, with Loo Keat Choon taking over her roles. The company's shares closed flat on the announcement. Ng is the sister of Q&M Dental Group's CEO Ng Chin Siau.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: UK construction sector suffers April slowdown on higher costs: S&P/CIPS
summary: The UK construction sector experienced its slowest month since January in April, with a S&P/CIPS construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 58.2, down from 59.1 in March. Rising costs and higher interest rates to finance new projects led to a slowdown in growth. House-building expanded at its weakest pace since September 2021, while order books were strong but demand growth slowed. The Bank of England raised its benchmark interest rate to 1.0% to combat inflation expected to top 10% later this year.

site_title: Assistant professor leaves SMU after allegations of faked claims surface
summary: Assistant professor Margaret Zhu of finance at Singapore Management University (SMU) has left the university after an investigation into allegations of faked academic claims. Zhu had listed 2 conditional acceptances to top journals, but emails revealed neither acceptance existed. SMU's spokesperson stated that Zhu's academic claims were not accurate, and the university will review its vetting procedures to prevent similar incidents. Zhu had previously worked at City University of Hong Kong and Chinese University of Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
How can this university charge nothing for tuition?

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Investors should be aware that zero-commission trades on US-listed stocks may not be entirely free due to various fees charged by brokerages. Singapore has received 20 proposals for low-carbon electricity imports from four South-east Asian nations. Office lunches may not be more expensive as workers face lower demand due to loosened Covid-19 curbs. The Golden Mile Complex was sold to a consortium for S$700 million, while SIA Engineering saw a strong recovery in April but requires more activities to break even operationally. Singapore stocks fell 1.6% due to global headwinds.

images.alt_text: The most expensive HDB flat resold was S$1,228,000 for a 5-room unit at Pinnacle@Duxton.

site_title: Singapore stocks tumble 1.6% as global headwinds dent sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.55% to 3,291.89, closing at 51.68 points, as global headwinds dented sentiment. The market was affected by concerns over a slowing China, the Russia-Ukraine war, inflation shock, and rising interest rates. Major Asian equity gauges posted steep losses, except for Japan, which finished 0.7% higher. The downturn was attributed to an overnight sell-off on Wall Street and worries about a potential recession in Europe.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Asian equities tumbled on Friday following a rout on Wall Street.

THE Bank of England (BOE) raised interest rates to their highest since 2009 at 1 per cent on Thursday (May 5) to counter inflation now heading above 10 per cent, even as it sent a warning that Britain risks falling into recession.

site_title: UK annual house price rise eases to 10.8%: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 1.1% in April, down from 1.5% in March, and were 10.8% higher than a year earlier, just below the peak of 11.2% in February. Despite a 30-year high in consumer price inflation, prices have shown little sign of slowing, with the Bank of England forecasting inflation to exceed 10% by the end of 2022. Halifax managing director Russell Galley warned that the rate of house price growth will likely slow by the end of the year due to rising interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: The average mortgage rate for a 30-year loan jumped to 5.27 per cent from 5.10 per cent last week.

site_title: Workers at Apple China plant clash with guards over lockdowns
summary: Hundreds of workers at a technology factory in China clashed with authorities and flooded past isolation barriers after weeks under lockdown, a breakdown in the Communist Party's efforts to contain Covid-19 infections. The Shanghai factory, owned by Quanta Computer, has been operating under tight restrictions since April. Workers, worried about further tightening due to positive Covid cases on the campus, rushed through barriers and tangled with guards in protective gear. The government is taking a central role in managing the plant's operations.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets close higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.69% to 27,003.56, while the Topix index gained 0.93%. The gains were driven by bargain-hunting, but investors remained cautious ahead of US jobs data. The benchmark indices closed higher on Friday, May 6, 2022.

site_title: SIA Engineering sees strong recovery, but requires  substantially more activities to be operationally profitable
summary: SIA Engineering Company reported a strong recovery in April, handling flights at 45% of pre-pandemic levels. However, the company requires a substantial increase in activities to achieve operational profitability. SIA Engineering's chief financial officer, Ng Lay Pheng, stated that the company needs to reach more than 50% of pre-pandemic levels of flights to break even. This indicates that the company is still in the process of recovering from the pandemic and will need to continue growing to achieve profitability.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Tay Peck Gek
Homes earmarked for Donald Trump's golf resort in northeastern Scotland are already attracting interest from property buyers, even before plans to construct them have been approved.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump as inflation woes hint at more rate hikes
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 2.2% to 7205.6, marking its worst day since February 24, as shares plummeted amid renewed fears of a faster rate-hike cycle. The Reserve Bank of Australia raised inflation forecasts, warning core inflation could hit 4.6% by December, sparking concerns about growth. Interest rate-sensitive stocks, including Xero and ASX-listed Block, slumped 4.5% and 1.7%, respectively, with the financial sector delivering its worst week since late February.

images.alt_text: EUROPE'S stock markets fell at the open on Friday (May 6) in a global selloff rooted in worries over rising interest rates and surging inflation.
The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield dropped slightly.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.69 per cent or 185.03 points to end at 27,003.56.

site_title: Bankers quit jobs for shot at riches in UAE's 'Wall Street of Crypto'
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao's call to the UAE as the "Wall Street of crypto" has attracted many to the country, including bankers and executives from big tech companies. A recent event in Dubai saw crypto executives mingle with Emirati royals and Wall Street bankers, with some considering career pivots to capitalize on the UAE's growing crypto scene. The UAE's favorable business environment and regulatory framework are drawing investors and entrepreneurs, with many hoping to replicate Zhao's rapid ascent to wealth.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin - the largest cryptocurrency - has dropped 21 per cent so far this year because of the risk-off mood sparked by the Russia-Ukraine conflict and a more hawkish outlook for Federal Reserve policy tightening.
GUCCI will accept payments in cryptocurrencies in the US starting this month, as the luxury industry takes tentative steps into the digital-asset universe.
Coinbase Global's new marketplace for non-fungible tokens is now officially open to all - and it's getting off to a very slow start.

Binance Holdings, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange by trading volume, has secured regulatory approval from the French government, boosting its operational plans across the European continent.

site_title: New operation to evacuate Mariupol civilians has begun, says Ukraine
summary: Ukraine has begun a new operation to evacuate civilians trapped in the heavily bombed Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol, after bloody fighting with Russian forces thwarted previous attempts. The plant, a strategic southern port, is the last part of the city still in the hands of holdout Ukrainian fighters, with an estimated 200 civilians remaining trapped underground. The operation comes amid ongoing fighting and allegations of war crimes by Russia, which has denied targeting civilians.

images.alt_text: Local resident Oksana Khvostenko, 47, stands near her house, which was heavily damaged during Ukraine-Russia conflict in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine, April 29, 2022.

site_title: China orders government, state firms to dump foreign PCs: sources
summary: China has ordered central government agencies and state-backed corporations to replace foreign-branded personal computers with domestic alternatives within 2 years. This move, part of Beijing's decade-long campaign to replace imported technology, is expected to affect at least 50 million PCs and directly impact sales by HP and Dell Technologies. The replacement effort reflects growing concerns around information security and a confidence in homegrown hardware, with local developers such as Lenovo and Kingsoft making rapid strides in office software.

images.alt_text: A worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) rides a bicycle along a nearly-empty road in Shanghai on May 5, 2022.

site_title: Office lunches may not prove much costlier as low demand caps CBD food prices
summary: Office workers in Singapore's central business district (CBD) may not face higher lunch costs as the office crowd returns amid loosened Covid-19 curbs. Despite low demand, CBD F&B outlets have maintained steady prices, while heartland outlets have seen increased demand and prices. Some office workers report spending more on food when returning to the office, while others save money by using food delivery services. Economists attribute this to geographical differences in demand, with CBD outlets facing limited demand and heartland outlets benefiting from daily demand for all meals.

images.alt_text: Food preparation at Amici Events and Catering.
Indonesia clarified the embargo would include all exports of the oilseed and not only products intended for edible oils, as indicated a day earlier.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts expect CICT will be key beneficiary of Singapore reopening
summary: Analysts expect CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) to benefit from Singapore's reopening, driven by office and retail sector recoveries. DBS Group Research raised its target price to S$2.70, citing a 6% 2-year compound annual growth rate, while Maybank expects easing negative retail reversions and office sector tailwinds. However, Jefferies lowered its target price to S$2.27 due to higher utility costs and frictional vacancies. The Reit posted a 0.5% on-year rise in first quarter net property income, with growth in retail, integrated development, and office earnings.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
CICT says Mr Tan Boon Khai will provide diversity to its board’s competencies and skills.
'Turning point' for S-Reits with Singapore office assets?
Singapore office S-Reits poised to benefit from positive rental momentum

site_title: Temasek's Azalea launches Astrea 7 PE-backed bonds; interest rates to be decided
summary: AZALEA Asset Management, an indirect subsidiary of Temasek Holdings, is launching the Astrea 7 bonds backed by 38 private equity funds with a US$755 million issuance. The bonds will have three classes, with Class A-1 and Class B available to retail investors, and will have a mandatory call after 5 years and maturity of 10 years. The issue will open for applications on May 19 and close on May 25, with trading starting on May 30.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Private equity bonds gained traction as investors seek to diversify portfolios: Azalea

site_title: Singapore draws 20 proposals on low-carbon electricity imports from region
summary: Singapore received 20 proposals to import low-carbon electricity from Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, and Thailand, with plans to import 1.2 gigawatts by 2027 and up to 4 gigawatts by 2035. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) will evaluate the proposals and announce the outcome in the final quarter of this year. The move aims to decarbonize Singapore's power sector and achieve net-zero emissions by mid-century. The country is also developing regional power grids and cross-border electricity trading to ensure energy security and support the growth of renewable energy.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Singapore is on a timer to decarbonise power sector
Singapore's net zero emissions target by 2050 for power sector 'realistic': report

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 8.20 points or 0.52% to 1,574.78. Volume was 106.62 million lots worth RM58.30 million. Losers outpaced gainers 336 to 40.

site_title: COE premiums close mixed; smaller cars and EVs up to 110kw at S$70,901
summary: COE premiums rose 3.2% to S$70,901 for smaller cars and EVs up to 110kw, while premiums for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp and EVs above 110kw increased by 2.3% to S$92,090. This was the first tender exercise to include the new 110kw power categorization for EVs, announced in March. The increase in premiums marks a shift towards higher emissions and larger vehicles.

images.alt_text: With some mass market EVs coming into Category A, some are expecting premiums to rise in the group when bidding closes on May 6 but other factors could also come into play.

site_title: Russian oligarch's yacht seized in Fiji on US request
summary: US authorities have seized a $325 million yacht, the Amadea, owned by Russian oligarch Suleiman Kerimov, in Fiji on a US warrant. The 348-foot yacht was seized due to alleged ties to corruption and violating sanctions imposed on Russian oligarchs. The US Justice Department has requested the vessel be held for violating sanctions and for alleged ties to corruption. The yacht's intended destination was believed to be Vladivostok or other Russian waters, and it is expected to be moved to the US within days.

images.alt_text: The superyacht Amadea reportedly owned by a Russian oligarch; US President Joe Biden announced a proposal to ratchet up economic pressure on Russia, with enhanced seizure and forfeiture procedures allowing oligarchs’ seized assets to be “sold off” to “remedy the harm Russia caused and to help build Ukraine”.

site_title: Asian Games 2022 in China postponed: Organisers
summary: The 19th Asian Games, originally scheduled for September 10-25, 2022, in Hangzhou, China, have been postponed indefinitely due to China's resurgence of Covid-19 cases. The postponement comes as the host city, Hangzhou, is near Shanghai, which is under a weeks-long lockdown. Organisers had planned to hold the events under a virus control plan, similar to the Beijing Winter Olympics, but no new dates have been announced.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on October 18, 2021, shows the Gongshu Canal Sport Park Gymnasium in the city of Hangzhou, in Zhejiang province. - The 2022 Asian Games in China is facing the "possibility" of being postponed, a senior official told AFP on April 21, 2022, after a rumour that it would be moved to next year. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall as Wall Street slides; benchmark bond yield drops
summary: South Korean stocks fell for a fourth consecutive session, their longest losing streak since January, amid US market turbulence. The benchmark Kospi dropped 33.06 points or 1.23% to 2,644.51, as investors worried about a potential 75-basis-point interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield dropped slightly, with foreigners selling 477.8 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi has fallen 11.19% so far this year, and the won has lost 6.6% against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 2.89 points, or 0.11 per cent, at 2,677.57, after rising as much as 0.58 per cent in early trade.

site_title: British Airways-owner IAG says business travel recovering
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, reported a strong recovery in business travel in the first quarter, driven by easing travel restrictions. The company expects to be profitable from the second quarter onwards and for the full year. Demand is recovering strongly, with no noticeable impact from the war in Ukraine, and capacity is expected to increase to 90% by the fourth quarter. Despite a first-quarter operating loss of 731 million euros, IAG is focusing on improving operations and customer experience.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Airways aircraft are parked at Heathrow Airport in west London February 5, 2010.  REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: ING misses Q1 profit estimates as Russia provisions hit earnings
summary: ING, the largest Dutch bank, reported a worse-than-expected Q1 net income of €429 million ($625.7 million) due to a surge in provisions for bad loans related to its exposure in Russia and Ukraine. The bank had forecast €679 million and had €1.01 billion in the year-ago period. €987 million was added to loan loss provisions, with €834 million attributed to Russia-related exposure. The bank has earmarked €2.5 billion in capital to cover expected losses.

images.alt_text: Dutch court scraps record US$50b payout to Yukos shareholders

site_title: Adidas cuts profitability target as sales in China slump
summary: Adidas cuts its profitability targets for this year, citing a 35% slump in first-quarter revenue in greater China due to lockdowns. The company also lowered its gross margin target to 50.7% and reduced its operating margin forecast. Supply bottlenecks in Vietnam and geopolitical challenges are eroding sales, with a fifth of the business underperforming. Foreign brands are struggling to maintain market share in China, where lockdowns and preferential treatment for local companies are affecting consumer behavior. Sales growth and profit are expected to be at the lower end of forecasts.

images.alt_text: Dubbed the "Mona Lisa of sneakers", this pair of Air Jordans is one of many vaunted sneakers on display at the exhibition.
Uniqlo owner's results seen as bellwether for China shutdown impact
Retail is here to stay, virtually and physically

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise CDLHT target price on hospitality and travel rebound
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research, OCBC Investment Research, Maybank Securities, and RHB have raised their target prices on CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) due to the rebound in tourism, with potential upside ranging from 10.7 to 18.3%. The companies cited improving revenue per available room (RevPAR) and a 25% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) in distribution per unit (DPU) as key drivers. CDLHT's stapled securities are trading at a slight premium to book value, with a 4.5% yield.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of the properties under CDL Hospitality Trusts.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.44% at the start of trade on May 6, 2022, following a Wall Street rout fueled by rising interest rates and inflation concerns. The Hang Seng Index dropped 506.34 points to 20,287.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.84% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.42%. The decline was attributed to global market volatility and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open in global rout
summary: Europe's stock markets plummeted on Friday, May 6, 2022, in a global selloff driven by concerns over rising interest rates and surging inflation. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX fell 0.8%, and Paris's CAC 40 lost 1.2%. The decline follows the Bank of England's interest rate hike and signals of US Federal Reserve monetary tightening. Global markets have been battered by a series of crises, including inflation, interest rates, China's slowdown, and the Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the entrance of the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain. Aug 23, 2018. REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Lendlease Reit amid recovering retail sector, high portfolio occupancy
summary: Analysts remain positive on Lendlease Reit due to its high portfolio occupancy and recovering retail sector. The Reit's portfolio occupancy remained high at 99.9% in Q3, and tenant sales at 313@somerset mall have recovered close to pre-pandemic levels. Analysts CGS-CIMB and Citi have raised their distribution per unit (DPU) estimates and maintained "add" calls on the counter, citing annual rental escalations and redevelopment plans. The Reit's share price has the potential for a 30.4% upside, according to CGS-CIMB's revised target price.

images.alt_text: Tenant sales year-to-date for Lendlease Reit's 313@somerset mall have also recovered close to FY2020 levels.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia drastically raises inflation forecasts, flags more rate hikes
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) drastically revised its inflation forecasts, predicting core inflation could reach 4.6% by December, exceeding its 2-3% target band. The central bank also raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 0.35%, signaling a lengthy tightening cycle, and forecasted a 3.6% unemployment rate and 3.7% annual wage growth by mid-2024. Markets expect further interest rate hikes, with some predicting a peak rate of 2.75% by Christmas.

site_title: BT kickstarts new subscriber-only events with Mark to Market 'Live'
summary: BT launches Mark to Market 'Live', a new series of subscriber-only events, featuring a fireside chat with OCBC Bank's group CEO Helen Wong on June 10. The inaugural event will discuss how OCBC plans to grow in an uncertain world and navigate modern-day banking risks. Slots are limited and registration closes on June 7. New subscribers will be automatically registered upon signing up for a subscription package, offering exclusive benefits and perks to loyal readers.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The F&B industry is expected to see a boost in activity from both locals and tourists, as domestic and border restrictions eased significantly in end-March, OCBC noted.

site_title: New Sembcorp solar farm can power 4,700 4-room HDB flats
summary: A new solar farm in Tuas industrial estate, developed by Sembcorp Solar Singapore, can power approximately 4,700 4-room Housing Board flats annually, reducing carbon dioxide emissions by around 9,000 tonnes per year. The 17.6 megawatt-peak solar farm features an integrated rainwater harvesting system, capable of treating 170,000 cubic meters of rainwater annually. This is part of Singapore's efforts to achieve its solar deployment targets and transition to a greener energy mix.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens lower after US falls
summary: The Nikkei index opened lower on Friday, falling 0.13% to 26,784.29, amid renewed anxiety over rising US interest rates. US stocks plummeted, leading to a decline in Tokyo's key Nikkei 225 index. In contrast, the broader Topix index rose 0.21%. The decline in US stocks was attributed to concerns over rising interest rates.

site_title: Keppel O&M bags FPSO integration contracts totalling around S$250m
summary: Keppel O&M has bagged contracts worth around S$250 million from repeat customers for the integration of 2 floating production storage and offloading vessels (FPSOs). The contracts include a newbuild FPSO integration with BW Offshore and FPSO integration with Single Buoy Moorings (SBM) and a joint-venture between SBM and McDermott. Keppel Shipyard expects to begin work in the second half of 2022 and deliver the FPSOs in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

pixkeppel - Keppel provides solutions for sustainable urbanisation. The picture depicts staff at the Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant inspecting the filtration membranes used in the water treatment process.
'More time and deliberation' needed in potential combination of Keppel O&M, Sembmarine
Keppel Corp reports higher Q1 profit as 3 out of 4 key segments fare better

site_title: Gold faces third weekly decline as dollar, Treasury yields firm
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,869.26 per ounce, marking its third weekly decline, due to a robust dollar and rising US Treasury yields. Investors await the US jobs report to assess its impact on monetary policy, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. The dollar remains near a 20-year high against a basket of currencies.

images.alt_text: Australian shares fell 2 per cent on Friday to hit a seven-week trough.
Oil prices edged up on Thursday on supply worries after the EU laid out plans for new sanctions against Russia including an embargo on crude.

site_title: China EV maker Nio wins nod for secondary listing on SGX
summary: China's electric vehicle maker Nio has received a conditional green light for its proposed secondary listing on Singapore's mainboard, the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company, which is seen as a competitor to Tesla, plans to list its Class A ordinary shares by way of introduction on the SGX, with the shares being fully fungible with its American depositary shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE). Nio's application for a listing on the SGX was reviewed as of February 18, and the company has previously listed in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
China EV maker Nio misses estimates amid supply pressures
Surging costs, price-conscious buyers add to Chinese EV makers' woes
Nio's Hong Kong listing faces delay into next year
Chinese EV maker Nio pursues secondary listings in Singapore, Hong Kong

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble on Wall street rout, pound slumps
summary: Asian equities tumbled on Friday following a Wall Street rout fueled by rising interest rates and surging inflation. The Nasdaq lost 5% and the Dow and S&P 500 fell over 3%. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, and Manila also declined, while Tokyo ended slightly higher. The pound slumped after the Bank of England warned of annual inflation topping 10% and the economy contracting later this year. The sell-off was attributed to concerns over monetary policy tightening by the US central bank and ongoing economic challenges in China.

site_title: Abramovich denies calling in loan for Chelsea to be sold
summary: Roman Abramovich has denied reports that he is seeking a £1.5 billion loan to repay for the sale of Chelsea FC, which is under threat due to a looming licence expiration. Abramovich claims the sanctions preventing him from writing off the debt are the reason, and all proceeds from the sale will go to charity. The club's sale is expected to fetch a world record price of around £2.5 billion, with American bank Raine handling the process and Todd Boehly's bid receiving preferred bidder status.

images.alt_text: nil

site_title: Australia: Shares skid 2% in broad-based selling on slowdown worries
summary: Australian shares fell 2% on Friday, hitting a seven-week low, as investors dumped equities due to concerns about aggressive central bank policies and slowing economic growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 7,215.5, with technology stocks leading the losses after the Nasdaq dropped 5% overnight. Financials, gold stocks, and miners also declined, with major players such as Macquarie Group, Newcrest Mining, and BHP falling 2-5%. The decline marked the benchmark's worst week since October 2020.

site_title: Macquarie's profit jumps 56% as commodities trading unit thrives
summary: Macquarie Group's annual profit jumped 56% due to a 50% increase in its Commodities and Global Markets unit's profit, driven by volatility in natural gas and oil prices. The company's capital business also saw a significant jump in earnings. A final dividend of A$3.50 per share was declared, up from the previous year. The profit attributable for the year ended March 31 rose to A$4.71 billion, exceeding a Visible Alpha consensus of A$4.45 billion.

site_title: China’s zero-Covid stance is inflicting a greater economic cost than 2020
summary: China's zero-Covid policy is inflicting a greater economic cost than in 2020, according to economists. The Omicron variant's high infectiousness is making zero-Covid more costly and difficult. China's lockdowns and mobility restrictions affect 44 cities with 25.3% of the population and 38.4% of the GDP. Economists have lowered growth forecasts to below Beijing's target of 5.5% and investors are re-evaluating exposures to the country. Nomura expects China to adhere to the restrictive zero-Covid strategy until the summer, with some adjustments after the ruling party's 20th Party Congress conference in October.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

A worker in personal protective equipment (PPE) rides a bicycle along a nearly-empty road during a lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, May 5, 2022. Shanghais Covid-19 cases fell slightly, while new infections in Beijing held steady, suggesting the capitals extreme steps to contain an outbreak are working so far. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday’s open; STI down 1.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.5% or 49.41 points to 3,294.16 on Friday, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street. Banking stocks led the decline, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 1.6%, 1.6%, and 3.5% respectively. The losses follow a broad-based sell-off on US stocks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunging 3.1% and the S&P 500 sliding 3.6%.

images.alt_text: The maintenance arm of Singapore Airlines on Thursday posted a net profit of S$42.6 million for the 6 months ended Mar 31, as earnings rebound on a writeback of associates’ tax provisions.

site_title: From lockdown to wedlock: Shanghai couple defy Covid-19 woes to marry
summary: A Shanghai couple, Matthew Mitchener and Janelle Nuyts, defied Covid-19 lockdowns and bureaucracy to get married in a car park after a ceremony officiated via Zoom from the US. The couple, who were expecting a baby, initially planned an online wedding but changed their mind after seeing Janelle in a wedding dress. The intimate ceremony took place in a car park after a ban on foreign marriages in China and a restriction on gatherings were lifted. The couple celebrated with a small reception, surrounded by socially distanced friends and neighbours.

site_title: US banking regulators propose update to fair lending rules
summary: US banking regulators have proposed an update to fair lending rules for banks, aiming to modernize the rules to reflect the rise of online banking and clarify requirements for the industry. The update to the 1977 Community Reinvestment Act would expand access to credit for poorer communities, create a consistent metrics-based approach to grading banks, and address complaints about the rules being opaque and subjective. The proposal, jointly made by the Federal Reserve, FDIC, and OCC, seeks public feedback to finalize the update.

site_title: How well do Singapore homes really hedge against inflation?
summary: Singaporean homes can serve as an inflation hedge in the long term, but investors should be aware of potential short-term fluctuations. According to an Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (IREUS) analysis, HDB flat owners who bought during the last peak in Q2 2013 would have earned a 6.8% return if they sold in Q1 2022, which did not outpace core inflation of 11.6%. However, properties purchased at historic highs may not necessarily hedge well against inflation, and buyers should consider holding power to wait out market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

The trade-related cluster, which led the recovery in 2021, is likely to see its contribution to GDP ease this year as it expands more slowly amid a weaker external environment, said MAS.
Instead, the recovery in the domestic-oriented and travel-related sectors is expected to gather pace now that Singapore has removed most of its Covid-19 restrictions.
The latest print came less than a fortnight after the Monetary Authority of Singapore raised its inflation forecasts and tightened monetary policy settings.
Buying Singapore property after cooling measures: Fomo or wait and see?
Do rising rents make Singapore homes ripe for investment?
Are buyers overpaying for freehold properties?

site_title: Yuan hits 1-1/2-year low as zero-Covid policy rattles investors
summary: The yuan hit a 1-1/2-year low against the US dollar on Friday, weakening to 6.6332 per dollar, as Beijing's pledge to double down on its zero-Covid policy rattled investors. Despite stronger-than-expected central bank guidance, the yuan's decline was driven by broad dollar strength and concerns over the impact of lockdowns and mobility restrictions on the economy. Analysts expect the yuan to trade in a range of 6.6 to 6.8 by end-June, with some predicting further losses if the exchange rate loses its two-way volatility.

site_title: Zero-commission trades do not mean free trades in many cases
summary: A Singaporean investor, Kong Weng Hong, recently sold US$5,000 worth of US-listed shares through online brokerage Tiger Brokers, only to find a deficit of US$11,000 due to a US$0.003-per-share settlement fee with no maximum cap. This fee was introduced in January and was not clearly disclosed in Tiger Brokers' fee schedule change notice. The incident highlights the need for investors to carefully review the terms and conditions of brokerages offering zero-commission trades, as fees can be hidden or not clearly disclosed.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Wall Street stocks suffered bruising losses on Thursday in a broad-based sell-off.

site_title: Boeing to move its headquarters to Washington area
summary: Boeing to relocate its headquarters from Chicago to Arlington, Virginia, citing strategic proximity to government decision-makers and access to world-class engineering talent. The move aims to enhance digital innovation and will involve establishing a "research and technology" hub. Boeing will maintain a significant presence in the Chicago area, but the Virginia location will house its corporate headquarters, defence, space, and security business.

site_title: Chinese, Russian central banks to discuss use of national payment systems
summary: China's envoy to Moscow announced plans for discussions between the Chinese and Russian central banks on promoting their national payment systems, Mir and China UnionPay, in both countries. The move aims to facilitate trade between the two nations, with China aiming to increase trade to $200 billion by 2024. The talks also aim to ensure the sustainable development of national trade, with no intention of replacing US dollar and euro settlements in bilateral trade.

site_title: Tokyo consumer prices rise at fastest pace in 7 years
summary: Tokyo's core consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.9% in April from a year earlier, the fastest annual pace in 7 years, driven by food costs and dissipating cellphone fee cuts. The overall CPI, including fresh food, increased 2.5% in April, the fastest growth since October 2014. Economists predict price rises will accelerate to the central bank's 2% target in coming months. The Bank of Japan's monetary policy remains unchanged despite the inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Border easing would be welcomed by Japan’s tourism industry,
Kishida set out his plan to grow Japan's economy by attracting private-sector investment and redistributing wealth.

site_title: Xbox makes ‘Fortnite’ game free to play on iPhones
summary: Xbox has announced that Fortnite will be made free to play on mobile devices powered by Apple or Android software through its cloud gaming service. The move comes after Fortnite was removed from the App Store due to a dispute over payment systems. The game will be available on iPhones, iPads, Android phones or tablets, and Windows computers through web browsers. This partnership with Epic Games is part of Xbox's efforts to expand its cloud gaming service and bring more free-to-play titles to players.

site_title: Europe: Stocks’ relief rally fades, growth concerns rise
summary: European stocks fell 0.7% on Thursday, marking the second straight session of losses, despite earlier gains after the Federal Reserve's less hawkish comments. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index is down over 10% for the year, driven by concerns over growth, interest rates, China's Covid-19 lockdowns, and inflation. The rally in European stocks faded as US stocks opened lower, with the US economy's growth and the European Central Bank's potential interest rate hikes weighing on markets.

site_title: Siemens unveils hydrogen-powered train
summary: Siemens has unveiled its first hydrogen-powered train, the Mireo Plus H, in partnership with Deutsche Bahn. The train, set to be operational by 2024, will run on electricity produced by a hydrogen fuel cell, reducing carbon emissions to zero. The train is part of Germany's plan to electrify 75% of its rail network by 2030, and is expected to save up to 45,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide over its 30-year lifetime.

site_title: Boustead Projects to beef up real estate presence in Vietnam through joint venture with local firm
summary: Boustead Projects has entered a strategic collaboration with Khai Toan Joint Stock Company to acquire, develop, and own a portfolio of logistics and industrial properties in Vietnam. BP Vietnam Development will own 60% of KTG & Boustead Joint Stock Company, which holds properties worth US$84.2 million. The collaboration is expected to strengthen Boustead Projects' presence in Vietnam and align with its real estate strategy.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Boustead Projects back in the black on resumption of E&C projects
Boustead Projects signs option agreement to acquire 49% interest in holding company

site_title: US tech titans look to ditch passwords
summary: US tech giants Apple, Google, and Microsoft are working together to replace passwords with more secure methods, such as fingerprint or face recognition, to access accounts and devices. The companies support a common standard, backed by the FIDO Alliance and the World Wide Web Consortium, which will enable websites and device makers to build password-less options. This shift aims to eliminate passwords, which are considered a major security flaw, and will simplify sign-ins across devices and platforms.

site_title: Dorsey-led Block's profit disappoints as bitcoin boost fades
summary: Block, a fintech firm led by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, missed market estimates for first-quarter profit due to a decline in bitcoin revenue. The company's bitcoin revenue halved to $1.73 billion, hit by a drop in cryptocurrency prices. Block's overall revenue fell 22% to $3.96 billion, and the company earned an adjusted profit of 18 cents per share, short of analyst estimates. Despite this, shares of Block were 10% higher in extended trading. The company closed its $29 billion purchase of Afterpay, creating a transactions giant competing with banks and tech firms.

images.alt_text: Tesla to partner with Block to mine Bitcoin at Texas site
Coinbase Global's new marketplace for non-fungible tokens is now officially open to all - and it's getting off to a very slow start.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit in 'exclusive due diligence' to acquire Sydney office property
summary: AIMS APAC Reit is conducting exclusive due diligence to acquire Avaya House, an office property in Macquarie Park, Sydney, Australia. The acquisition is not binding, and there's no certainty the Reit will acquire the property. The manager clarified this in a Singapore Exchange announcement after "certain media reports" sparked interest in the proposed deal. The Reit's counter closed 0.7% higher at S$1.41 on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Oil edges up on supply jitters as EU plans Russian oil ban
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% to $110.90 a barrel, driven by supply worries after the EU proposed a ban on Russian oil imports, with Brent futures reaching their highest settle since April 18. The EU sanctions proposal includes phasing out imports of Russian refined products by the end of 2022 and a ban on all shipping and insurance services for transporting Russian oil. Despite a strong dollar and drop in global stock markets, oil prices remained high due to concerns over potential sanctions and their impact on global supply.

site_title: DoorDash lifts 2022 core growth target after revenue jumps 35%
summary: DoorDash has raised its 2022 full-year growth target after reporting a 35% jump in quarterly revenue, exceeding analyst expectations. The company now estimates gross order value of $49 billion to $51 billion, up from its prior range of $48 billion to $50 billion. DoorDash's market share in the US food delivery sector improved to 57% in March, while the company expanded its delivery network for groceries and international business. Despite a wider loss per share, the surge in revenue and growth target lifts shares 9% and alleviates concerns about labor woes.

site_title: Board diversity through renewal, succession and mentorship
summary: Singapore listed companies are required to adopt a board diversity policy starting January 2022, addressing gender, skill, and experience diversity. Despite progress, corporate boards remain dominated by men, with women occupying just 12.7% of board seats. To address this, companies can implement board renewal through term limits, intentional succession planning, and mentorship programs. These strategies can help build a diverse and effective board, essential for navigating today's complex business environment.

site_title: FLCT raises H1 DPU by 1.3% to S$0.0385 on contributions from FY2021 acquisitions
summary: FRASERS Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a 1.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0385 for its first half ended March 31, 2022, driven by contributions from FY2021 acquisitions and an early surrender fee. Gross revenue rose 1.7% to S$235.7 million, mainly due to full income contribution from its acquisitions and the early surrender fee.
