site_title: Legendary Morozov art collection back in Russia after hit show in Paris
summary: Russia's Morozov art collection, featuring works by Van Gogh, Cezanne, and Monet, has been safely returned after a successful show in Paris, drawing a near-record 1.25 million visitors. The collection, built by brothers Mikhail and Ivan Morozov in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, was initially extended due to its popularity. However, two paintings were held back due to Western sanctions against Russia. The artworks have been delivered to Russian state museums and will go on show at Moscow's Pushkin Museum this summer.

site_title: Axington's independent auditor puts disclaimer of opinion on FY2021 statements
summary: Independent auditor Foo Kon Tan LLP has included a disclaimer of opinion on Axington's FY2021 financial statements due to uncertainty over opening balances and carry-forward effects. The auditor is still reviewing unpaid placement shares. Axington's board expects the issues to be resolved by FY2022 and will provide updates. The company will also hold annual and extraordinary general meetings to vote on share capital reduction and new listing requirements.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Axington ex-director Marjory Loh declared bankrupt
Auditor issues disclaimer on finances of Loh cousins' Axington
Axington's planned RTO of Chinese tech company was dead on arrival

site_title: Karine Jean-Pierre named first Black White House press secretary
summary: US President Joe Biden announced the appointment of Karine Jean-Pierre as the first Black and openly gay White House press secretary, succeeding Jen Psaki. Jean-Pierre, who has served as deputy press secretary since 2021, will be the first person of color to hold the position. Biden praised Jean-Pierre's experience, talent, and integrity, and expressed his hope that she will "make people proud." The appointment is seen as a step towards increasing diversity in the administration, with Biden pledging to name officials who reflect the diversity of America.

images.alt_text: epa09929397 Incoming White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre responds to questions from members of the news media after White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki announced  Jean-Pierre would replace her when Psaki steps down from the position, in the James Brady Press Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 05 May 2022. When Psaki leaves the position next week, Karine Jean-Pierre will become the first black woman to be press secretary.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS

site_title: How to choose the perfect Porsche
summary: Porsche has introduced a GTS version of every model, offering a balance of value, performance, and style. The GTS label, born in racing, provides a shortcut to the best features of each car, including unique styling elements and performance upgrades. The GTS treatment is applied to both gasoline-powered and electric models, such as the 911 and Taycan, with the goal of creating a well-rounded driving experience. The label is expected to continue even as Porsche shifts towards electric power, representing the brand's most well-rounded form.

images.alt_text: With some mass market EVs coming into Category A, some are expecting premiums to rise in the group when bidding closes on May 6 but other factors could also come into play.

site_title: Evidence mounts for need to study Pfizer’s Paxlovid for long Covid-19: researchers
summary: US researchers say evidence mounts for studying Pfizer's Paxlovid for long Covid-19, citing reports of patients who experienced symptom relief after taking the treatment. The oral antiviral is currently only authorised for high-risk people early after onset of Covid-19 symptoms. Three new case studies detail patients who improved after taking Paxlovid, but also highlight that the treatment may not prevent long Covid-19 in all cases. Researchers are calling for clinical trials to test Paxlovid's effectiveness for the debilitating condition, which affects 30% of people infected by the coronavirus.

images.alt_text: Dr. Cesira Nencioni, Director of infectious diseases at Misericordia hospital, holds coronavirus disease (COVID-19) treatment pill Paxlovid, in Grosseto, Italy, February 8, 2022. REUTERS/Jennifer Lorenzini

site_title: China’s top leaders reiterate support for Covid Zero, roll out more measures to stabilise jobs
summary: China's top leaders reaffirmed support for its Covid Zero strategy despite economic strain from lockdowns. The nation will accelerate measures to tackle regional outbreaks and introduce policies to support small firms and employment. The government will also provide financial assistance, including tax cuts and VAT rebates, to help stabilize jobs.

images.alt_text: China will roll out more support measures to help small firms and stabilise employment, including the introduction of policies to support the platform economy.

site_title: US mortgage rates jump to 5.27%, highest since 2009
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 5.27%, the highest level since 2009, according to Freddie Mac. The rate increase, following a half-point hike by the Federal Reserve, is expected to reduce homebuying and ease competition for listings. Tight inventory and pent-up demand from the past couple of years may limit a crash in home sales. Experts predict decelerating house price growth in the coming months, while housing affordability and inflationary pressures pose challenges for potential buyers.

site_title: Slight rise in corruption-related reports last year, most cases probed came from private sector
summary: Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) reported a slight rise in graft-related reports last year, with 249 cases, a 4% increase from 2020. About 33% of the reports, or 83, were registered for investigation. The majority of cases (74) came from the private sector, with a 98% conviction rate. One notable case involved an assistant engineer accepting bribes, resulting in a 11-month jail sentence. The CPIB said the corruption situation remains under control, with Singapore ranking fourth in the Corruption Perception Index.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FLCT, SIA Engineering, AEM, Aims Apac Reit, Oceanus
summary: Singapore stocks rebounded on Thursday, with key players posting earnings beats. SIA Engineering Co (SIAEC) reported a net profit of S$42.6 million for the 6 months ended Mar 31, driven by a writeback of associates' tax provisions. AEM Holdings also posted a tripled profit to S$40.8 million, while Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT) saw a 1.3% rise in distribution per unit to S$0.0385. Shares of Oceanus Group's subsidiary, Oceanus Media Global, closed flat after setting up a S$5 million futurealistic studio.

site_title: Thai inflation slows in April, but pace seen quickening
summary: Thai inflation slowed in April to 4.65% from a year earlier, below forecasts, driven by higher energy and food prices. However, the end of a diesel price cap is expected to push headline inflation above 5% in the coming months. Despite this, the government maintains its forecast of 4-5% inflation this year, while the central bank is unlikely to raise rates soon due to its priority on supporting growth. Core inflation, which strips out volatile energy and food prices, remained stable at 2.0%.

images.alt_text: Thailand's retail inflation is poised to accelerate from a 13-year high with the government lifting a freeze on some retail fuel prices, boosting the odds for the central bank to pivot away from its pandemic-era monetary policy accommodation.

site_title: ECB sees sequence of moves to lift rates into positive territory: Lane
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing for a sequence of rate hikes to lift its benchmark rate into positive territory, but the exact date is less important than the path of policy normalization. ECB chief economist Philip Lane said the bank's inflation target of 2% is not consistent with a deposit rate of -0.5%, and that normalization will be more than a single move. Lane also noted that wage growth remains muted, suggesting inflation may settle at the 2% target, rather than overshooting it.

site_title: Disney's US$500m roller coaster underscores deep ties to Florida
summary: Disney's $500 million Guardians of the Galaxy: Cosmic Rewind roller coaster is set to open at Epcot in Walt Disney World Resort, Florida, on May 27. The ride features a 360-degree cockpit and a reverse launch, and is part of a multiyear refresh of the park. The investment underscores Disney's importance to the state's tourism industry, with the company's Florida resorts employing 70,000 people and generating significant revenue. The attraction is the latest stage in Epcot's remodelling, which aims to boost its appeal to families with younger kids.

site_title: Kellogg raises sales forecast as price increase counters strike impact
summary: Kellogg raised its 2022 sales forecast to 4% from 3% due to price increases offsetting the impact of supply shortages from a US workers' strike and the war in Ukraine. The company's cereal sales in North America fell 10.3% in the first quarter, but analysts say the forecast boost is a relief to investors, who had concerns about Kellogg's profit guidance. The company expects demand for some cereals to slow due to surging global inflation, and warned of potential cereal shortages in the first half of the year.

site_title: US: Dow ends ugly session 3.1% lower while Nasdaq plunges 5%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.1% to 32,997.97, its worst day since June 2020. The S&P 500 slid 3.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 5.0%. The losses were sparked by concerns over shifting monetary policy and rising economic risks from inflation. Major tech companies, including Amazon, Tesla, and Facebook, fell heavily, while Booking rose 3.3% on a positive outlook for the summer travel season.

site_title: Chipmaker MaxLinear to buy Taiwan's Silicon Motion for about US$4b
summary: Chipmaker MaxLinear agreed to buy Taiwan-based Silicon Motion Technology for approximately $4 billion in a cash-and-stock deal, creating one of the largest fabless semiconductor suppliers in the world. The combined entity will have over $2 billion in combined revenue annually and a total available market opportunity of $15 billion. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2023, with MaxLinear's shareholders owning about 86% of the combined company.

site_title: Shopify sinks after earnings miss and US$2.1b Deliverr deal
summary: Shopify reported adjusted earnings of 20 US cents per share, missing analyst calls for 64 US cents. Revenue rose 22% to US$1.2 billion, but fell short of US$1.25 billion expectations. The company announced a US$2.1 billion deal for startup Deliverr, its largest acquisition. Shopify's shares plummeted 15% to US$413 in premarket trading. The disappointing earnings report led to a significant drop in the company's stock price.

images.alt_text: Shopify is in talks to buy technology startup Deliverr, according to people familiar with the matter, a move that would help the Canadian e-commerce company expand in fulfillment services.
AMAZON.COM said it will let merchants sell products they list with the e-commerce giant directly from their own websites, as part of a move to blunt the momentum of fast-growing competitor Shopify.

site_title: RBI may extend rate hikes on worries over inflation-target breach
summary: The Reserve Bank of India may extend interest rate hikes due to concerns that inflation could exceed its 2-6% target in the next 6 months. A 40-basis-point rate hike was implemented in an out-of-cycle move, with a possible 75-basis-point hike in the June meeting considered unlikely. India's retail inflation rose to a 17-month high of 6.95% in March, exceeding the RBI's mandate. The RBI aims to stabilize growth in the medium term while being mindful of its short-term impact.

images.alt_text: THE Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) monetary policy committee (MPC) raised the key lending rate by 40 basis points on Wednesday (May 4), citing persistent inflationary pressures in the economy, governor Shaktikanta Das announced.

site_title: 4,733 new Covid-19 cases reported in Singapore, up from 1,638 cases on May 4
summary: Singapore reported a surge in new Covid-19 cases, with 4,733 cases reported on May 5, surpassing the 1,638 cases on May 4. This increase is higher than the usual spike on Tuesdays, which typically see more cases after the weekend. The Ministry of Health attributed the rise to ongoing community transmission.

images.alt_text: The vaccine, which got interim authorisation from the Health Sciences Authority in February, is approved for both primary series and booster doses under the national vaccination programme.

site_title: AEM Q1 net profit more than triples to S$40.8m on the back of record quarterly revenue
summary: AEM Holdings reported a net profit of S$40.8 million for its first quarter, more than tripling from the previous year, driven by record quarterly revenue of S$261.9 million. The increase in revenue was mainly due to strong uptake of new-generation equipment and tools, as well as the consolidation of its subsidiary CEI. Earnings per share rose 172.9% year-on-year, and the group raised its revenue guidance for the full year to between S$700 million and S$750 million.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Japan premier pledges to relax border controls by next month
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has pledged to relax the country's virus-related border controls by next month, aiming to boost consumer spending and combat an economic slowdown. The move is expected to welcome Japan's tourism industry, which has been impacted by the pandemic. By June, Japan's borders will be as accessible as those of other G-7 countries, according to Kishida, who credits the border controls for helping Japan weather the pandemic relatively well.

images.alt_text: Kishida set out his plan to grow Japan's economy by attracting private-sector investment and redistributing wealth.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls at open as Big Tech stocks weigh
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Thursday, May 5, as megacap growth stocks weighed down the market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 206.89 points, or 0.61%, to 33,854.17, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, down 0.69% and 1.37%, respectively. This comes a day after the Federal Reserve's less aggressive tone sparked a rally.

site_title: 'Japan is a buy,' PM Kishida tells City of London
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida told the City of London to "buy" Japan, outlining a plan to grow the country's economy by attracting private-sector investment and redistributing wealth. Kishida's speech came as Japan's economy is expected to slow due to rising energy and living costs, with the yen trading at 2-decade lows to the US dollar. The plan aims to spur economic growth and address the country's economic challenges, following a shift to an upgraded version of capitalism.

images.alt_text: JAPAN'S Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said on Thursday (May 5) that it would use nuclear reactors to help reduce its own and other countries' dependence on Russian energy.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase; lay-offs creep up in April
summary: US weekly jobless claims increased 19,000 to 200,000 in the week ended April 30, exceeding economists' forecasts. This rise in claims is consistent with tightening labour market conditions and further wage gains. The labour market imbalance is forcing employers to increase wages, contributing to soaring inflation. The Federal Reserve raised its policy interest rate by half a percentage point, citing "extremely tight" labour market and high inflation. Job cuts announced by US-based companies increased 14% to 24,286 in April, with the leisure and hospitality industry leading the rise in lay-offs.

images.alt_text: US services industry growth unexpectedly slowed in April, with employment contracting for the second time this year, while a measure of input prices raced to a record high.

site_title: US productivity drops on weaker output as labour costs jump
summary: US productivity dropped by 7.5% in the first quarter, the largest decline since 1947, as the economy shrank. Labour costs surged, highlighting an extremely tight job market. This drop contrasts with the 6.3% gain in the fourth quarter and a 5.3% projected decline. The pandemic's impact on productivity growth rates has made the figures more volatile, and it may take several years to determine if underlying productivity trends have shifted.

images.alt_text: There are signs that high labour costs are starting to hurt small businesses, especially those in the leisure and hospitality industry.

site_title: Elon Musk secures US$7.1b in new financing for Twitter
summary: Elon Musk has secured approximately $7.1 billion in new financing commitments for his proposed $44 billion takeover of Twitter. The funding includes contributions from billionaire Larry Ellison, a Saudi prince, and Sequoia Capital. This new funding reduces the risk for Musk and his lenders, allowing him to reduce the size of a loan against his Tesla shares by half. The deal is seen as more stable, with Twitter's stock price narrowing to its lowest gap with Musk's offered price since April 26.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk and Cathie Wood (above) criticised passive investing in a Twitter thread, weighing in on a controversial and unresolved debate.

site_title: Driving Ferrari’s weird but wonderful 296 GTB
summary: The Ferrari 296 GTB is a plug-in electric hybrid vehicle marking the company's evolution towards a more environmentally friendly sportscar. With a 2.992cc V6 engine and 167 horsepower electric motor, the car produces 830 horsepower and can accelerate from 0-100km/h in 2.9 seconds. Its unique design features a digital cockpit, haptic panel start system, and advanced braking technology. Although it lacks a traditional V8 engine, the 296 GTB delivers a surprisingly relaxing driving experience, making it a game-changer in the sportscar market.

images.alt_text: There is now a GTS version of every Porsche model out there.

site_title: Carro’s Indonesia bank play could spell big returns
summary: Carro, a used car marketplace, is investing in Indonesian banks to gain a foothold in the country's lucrative used car market. The company's move is part of its strategy to expand its car financing business, with the aim of boosting sales and inventory turnover. Carro's co-investment in Indonesian banks, such as Funding Societies, aims to provide financing services to its customers, allowing the company to reap higher margins. The Indonesian market is estimated to be worth $20 billion, and Carro's entry could help it tap into this growing market, potentially increasing its sales and market share.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Funding Societies is coinvesting with Carro into Indonesian bank, Bank Index to further their fintech ambitions
What's turbocharging Carro and Carsome's funding fever?
Carro bags another US$15.6m in ongoing Series C round

site_title: SIA Engineering Co H2 earnings rebound on one-time tax writeback, wage support
summary: SIA Engineering Co's second-half earnings rebounded on a one-time tax writeback, with net profit surging to $42.6 million for the 6 months ending March 31, 2022. The company's full-year net profit reversed a loss of $11.2 million, driven by revenue growth of 37.5% and associate and joint venture contributions. However, operating losses persisted, mainly due to rising costs and declining government wage support, with the board warning of risks to its business outlook despite early signs of recovery.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
SIAEC leverages Covid-19 downtime to improve efficiency, retrain workers
Singapore, Malaysia aviation sectors near recovery to pre-Covid levels: UOBKH
SIA Engineering posts S$33.2m net profit in Q3, lifted by one-time write back

site_title: Euro's post Fed glow fades on bleak German industrial orders
summary: The euro lost ground against the US dollar after Germany reported its largest monthly drop in industrial orders since last October, signaling growing economic headwinds from the war in Ukraine. The US dollar rebounded in London trading after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 50 basis points. The European Central Bank is expected to follow suit with an interest rate hike as early as July, raising concerns about choking economic growth.

site_title: Smart-casual Japanese dining in Wakuda's luxe surroundings
summary: Tetsuya Wakuda has opened a new restaurant, Wakuda, in the lobby of Marina Bay Sands, offering smart-casual Japanese dining in a stunning, luxe setting. The menu features a range of dishes, from affordable options like fried shishito peppers to luxe fare like S$550 omakase. Head chefs Sufian Zain and Suzuki Masaya have been deployed from the flagship Waku Ghin. The restaurant's unique cocktail creations and beautiful surroundings make it a standout dining experience. With a large menu and high-quality ingredients, Wakuda has the potential to be a winner, but maintaining high standards in a larger restaurant may pose challenges. Rating: 7.5.

images.alt_text: Poisson - a  seafood restaurant with nautical-inspired interiors
A new chapter for Tetsuya Wakuda

site_title: State-owned Central Bank of India to close 13% of its branches: sources, document
summary: The Central Bank of India, a state-owned commercial bank, plans to shut 13% of its branches, approximately 600, by the end of March 2023, to improve its financial health and escape the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) prompt corrective action (PCA) list. This move is part of the bank's strategy to reduce loss-making assets and streamline operations. The bank has struggled to recover from nearly 5 years of close scrutiny by the RBI, and the closure of branches will be followed by the sale of non-core assets.

site_title: MPA traces origin of contaminated bunker fuel, calls for stricter quality tests
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has traced the origin of contaminated bunker fuel sold in Singapore's maritime hub to a tanker loaded in the United Arab Emirates. The contaminated fuel, containing high chlorinated organic compounds (COC), was sold to Glencore and PetroChina, which are licensed bunker suppliers. The MPA has called for stricter quality tests and will include COC on its list of chemicals to be tested. The incident has raised concerns about bunker quality assurance in the industry, with the MPA and Singapore Shipping Association working to strengthen measures.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
200 ships receive contaminated bunker fuel from Glencore, PetroChina: MPA
MPA investigating cause of major bunker fuel contamination at Singapore port

site_title: Gucci to start accepting crypto payments in some US stores
summary: Gucci, the luxury fashion brand, will begin accepting cryptocurrency payments in select US stores starting May 2022, marking a tentative step into the digital-asset universe. Initially, 10 cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ethereum, will be accepted in stores in New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Atlanta, and Las Vegas, with plans to expand to all North American stores this summer.

site_title: Russia fallout hits US$7b for European banks pulling back
summary: European banks are facing a significant hit of around $7 billion due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with the potential for further losses as defaults spread. The economic impact is already being felt globally, with commodity prices spiking and supply chains disrupted. Banks are re-evaluating their presence in Russia, with some considering exiting the country altogether. To mitigate the risks, lenders are increasing their loan loss reserves and provisioning, with UniCredit and Raiffeisen Bank International among those setting aside more funds. The uncertainty surrounding the economic damage is prompting regulators and chief risk officers to discuss strategies.

images.alt_text: FRENCH lender Societe Generale beat first-quarter earnings expectations on Thursday (May 5) but booked higher provisions for loans turning bad as the economic impact of the war in Ukraine hits its customers.

CREDIT SUISSE froze 10.4 billion Swiss francs (S$14.7 billion) of wealthy clients' assets in the first quarter under sanctions imposed in connection with Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the bank's financial report showed on Thursday (May 5).

site_title: SocGen boosts first-quarter income but costs of Ukraine war rise
summary: Societe Generale, a French lender, reported a 3.4% increase in first-quarter net income to 842 million euros, beating expectations, despite higher provisions for bad loans due to the economic impact of the war in Ukraine. Revenue rose 16.6% driven by domestic retail arm prosperity and trading improvements. The bank now expects this year's cost of risk to reach 30-35 basis points, higher than its previous forecast, and has already written off 3.1 billion euros from its Russian operations.

site_title: Almost 3 times as many died as a result of Covid than officially reported: WHO
summary: A new World Health Organization (WHO) report reveals that almost 3 times as many people have died as a result of Covid-19 as the official data show, with 14.9 million excess deaths associated with the pandemic by the end of 2021. The official count of deaths directly attributable to Covid-19 is around 5.4 million. The report also suggests that 4.7 million people died in India, mainly during a surge in May and June 2021, but the Indian government disputes these figures.

site_title: Credit Suisse froze US$10.6b worth of sanctioned assets in Q1
summary: Credit Suisse froze US$10.6 billion worth of sanctioned assets in the first quarter, primarily from wealthy clients' accounts, due to sanctions imposed on Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The bank's wealth management division reclassified CHF 10.4 billion (S$14.7 billion) of assets under management to assets under custody. This move reflects the bank's compliance with sanctions regulations.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse's first-quarter net loss came in at 273 million Swiss francs (S$385.3 million) and the report cited net litigation provisions of 703 million francs.

site_title: Beijing will roll out more support measures to stabilise jobs
summary: China will introduce additional support measures to stabilize employment and aid small firms, including policies for the platform economy. The measures come as the country's economy slows due to COVID-19 cases and lockdowns, with a near 2-year high jobless rate of 5.8% in March. The government will provide financial help, including tax cuts, loan repayment extensions, and VAT credit rebates, to support small firms and the foreign trade sector. The goal is to stabilize employment and keep the economy growing.

site_title: Singapore 'unlikely' to have recession after Fed hike but near-term risks remain, say economists
summary: Singapore's economy is unlikely to experience a recession despite the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, according to economists. A slowdown is still possible, but independent of the Fed's decision. Interest rates in Singapore are expected to rise, but likely to a smaller extent, following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's recent rate hikes to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
A woman jogs past as the city skyline is reflected in a puddle leftover from earlier rain in Singapore on February 8, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

Chinese investors monitor stock prices at a brokerage house in Beijing, Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Asian shares rose Friday as worries receded the United States and Iran might be stepping closer to the edge of war, and U.S. indexes hit records. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)

site_title: Japan to use nuclear to cut dependence on Russian energy: PM Kishida
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to utilize nuclear reactors to reduce dependence on Russian energy, amid rising energy prices and upcoming elections. Japan has been reliant on Russian gas since shutting down nuclear reactors following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Kishida aims to diversify energy sources, promoting renewables and nuclear power, and has set a goal to raise $1.6 trillion in investment by 2030 to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.

site_title: Joan Road Good-Class Bungalow on market with S$48m guide price
summary: A 29,483 sq ft site on Joan Road in District 11 is on the market with an indicative price of S$48 million, or approximately S$1,628 per square foot. The site has a 53-metre frontage and depth of 55 metres, allowing for potential subdivision into two GCBs. Located near the Caldecott Hill GCB Area, the property is expected to draw strong interest from ultra-high-net-worth families due to its prime location and limited availability of prime landed homes.

images.alt_text: Good Class Bungalow market poised to remain buoyant
House along Olive Road being sold for S$50.2 million

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 17.45 points lower at 1,582.98 on Thursday, with 628 losers outpacing 380 gainers. The index saw 2.682 billion lots traded worth RM2.379 billion.

site_title: Britain's Barratt upbeat on housing demand, urges rethink on safety levy
summary: Britain's largest housebuilder Barratt Developments expressed confidence in housing demand, but urged the government to rethink its plan to expand a tax on companies to fund removal of flammable roof coverings from buildings. Barratt believes the tax is unjust and disproportionate, and wants it to apply to all stakeholders rather than just a small section of builders. The company has already set aside £350-400m for safety measures, and its shares have dropped 29% this year due to uncertainty over the cladding levy.

images.alt_text: Owners of problem flats give cautious welcome to UK cladding move
UK gives housebuilders US$5b bill to remove cladding

site_title: NYSE owner ICE profit rises on high trading volume
summary: NYSE owner Intercontinental Exchange reported a 2% increase in first-quarter profit to $657 million, driven by higher trading volumes in asset classes amid market volatility due to interest hikes and the Ukraine war. The exchange's revenue rose 6% to $1.9 billion, with gains in fixed income and data services. The company also announced a $16 billion acquisition of Black Knight. Net income per share edged past analysts' mean estimate, and the company's earnings followed strong performances by rivals CBOE Global Markets and CME Group.

images.alt_text: US: Wall Street surges in growth stocks rally; earnings season opens

site_title: Hwa Hong responds to SGX queries on resignation of independent non-exec director
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation responded to Singapore Exchange queries on the resignation of independent non-executive director Mak Lye Mun, citing a disagreement over the selection and appointment process of new directors. The company maintains a "ready" pool of potential candidates and conducts the selection process through board contacts and external recruitment companies. Following Mak's resignation, the company appointed Ong Eng Loke as non-independent executive director and acting group managing director, and Ong Mui Eng tendered his resignation as non-independent executive director, effective July 31.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
CICT says Mr Tan Boon Khai will provide diversity to its board’s competencies and skills.

site_title: Thai stock investor mood at 3-month low over Ukraine war, Fed
summary: Thai investor confidence in the stock market has reached a 3-month low due to concerns over the Ukraine war and the Federal Reserve's tightening policy. A recent survey by Fetco showed the investor confidence index dropped to 95.42, falling 19% from the previous month. Foreign investors are also bearish, with a decline in confidence. The finance ministry's plan to collect a financial transaction tax is seen as a contributing factor to the decline in investor confidence.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HDB resale prices continued their upward trend in April, with the most expensive flat resold for S$1,228,000. Retail sales in Singapore rose 8.7% in March, reversing February's decline. Consumer prices in the Philippines and Thailand picked up at the fastest pace in 3 years, complicating central bankers' efforts to control inflation. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) fell 0.17% on Thursday, after a post-FOMC rally.

site_title: Bank of England raises rates to 1% despite looming recession risk
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates to 1% for the first time since 2009 to combat inflation, now above 10%, despite warning of a recession risk. The decision was made by 9 rate-setters, with 6 voting in favor and 3 opposing a more significant increase. Economists had forecast a more dovish outcome. The move aims to curb inflation but may exacerbate the economic slowdown, which the Bank of England warns could lead to recession.

site_title: China's Covid controls makes EU firms consider shifting investments:  chamber
summary: European businesses in China are shifting investments due to strict Covid-19 containment measures and supply chain disruptions. A member survey by the European Chamber of Commerce in China found nearly a quarter of respondents are considering moving investments out of China, more than double the number at the start of the year. 60% of respondents lowered revenue forecasts, citing lockdown measures and supply chain disruptions, with 92% negatively impacted by port closures and rising sea freight costs.

images.alt_text: The lacklustre closing came on the back of a slew of data showing a sharp contraction in the world’s No 2 economy.

site_title: SGX reprimands AGV Group’s former executive director for breach of Catalist rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Albert Ang, former executive director of AGV Group, for breaching Catalist rules by failing to disclose his involvement in an investigation conducted by the Commercial Affairs Department. Ang was involved in an investigation for alleged false trading and market rigging transactions, but did not inform the company of the order in a timely manner, leading to inaccurate disclosures. As a result, Ang has been charged with a breach of Catalist Rule 703(1)(a) and will resign from director positions for 2 years.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Police reports have been filed against individuals from AGV's subsidiaries.
AGV Group unit receives RM1.6m letter of demand from RHB Bank
AGV Group independent directors urge company to 'consider facts holistically' after EGM requisitioned to remove them

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.17% as rally loses steam on post-FOMC relief
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.17% to 3,343.57 on Thursday, May 5, after a rally lost steam following the US Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) policy statement, which ruled out a 75 basis point rate hike. The FOMC also hiked rates by 50 basis points and will start reducing its balance sheet in June. Despite gains in other Asian markets, losses in key index leaders DBS, Jardine Cycle & Carriage, and UOB led the decline.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The Straits Times Index headed up 0.6 per cent or 19.91 points to 3,369.18 as at 9.02 am.

Chinese investors monitor stock prices at a brokerage house in Beijing, Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Asian shares rose Friday as worries receded the United States and Iran might be stepping closer to the edge of war, and U.S. indexes hit records. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)

site_title: Keong Hong warns of expected H1 net loss, blames virus-related business conditions
summary: Keong Hong Holdings, a construction player, is warning of an expected net loss for the 6 months to Mar 31, 2022, citing labour shortages and rising business costs due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company attributed this to the continuation of the pandemic's impact on the industry. Keong Hong had previously reported a net loss of S$16.9 million for FY2021. The company is finalising its first-half results, which will be released by May 15, 2022, advising shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open on easing Fed concerns
summary: European stocks surged at the open on May 5, driven by the Federal Reserve's downplaying of aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation. London's FTSE 100 jumped 1.6%, Frankfurt's DAX rose 2.3%, and Paris' CAC rallied 2.4%. The US central bank announced a half-point interest rate hike, but Fed boss Jerome Powell stated a 75-point rise was not being actively considered. This news boosted Asian and US markets, with stocks continuing their rally overnight.

site_title: Penny stock crash mastermind Soh and Quah found guilty of most charges
summary: Singaporean authorities have found John Soh Chee Wen and Quah Su-Ling guilty of masterminding the country's most serious case of stock market manipulation, worth $8 billion. The trial, which lasted 194 days, concluded with the duo being acquitted of 8 charges of deception. Soh was found guilty of 180 of 188 charges, while Quah was convicted of 169 of 177 charges. They could face up to 7 years in prison and fines of up to $250,000 for each of the 163 charges related to market manipulation and deception.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
MAS should publish outcome of every investigation and enforcement action related to the listed-companies space
John Soh, Quah Su Ling await verdict in penny stock crash trial
John Soh, Quah Su-Ling back in court in $8b penny stock trial

site_title: Category A COE premiums could rise but not for the reason you think
summary: Category A COE premiums may rise, but not due to increased demand from electric vehicles (EVs) entering the category. A new rule allowing more EVs to qualify for Category A has been implemented, but industry watchers expect prices to remain stable. Instead, factors such as overall demand and supply, as well as the impact of the recent drop in premiums, may drive prices up. The number of EVs entering Category A is expected to be limited, with only a handful of models qualifying.

site_title: Carsome acquires digital automotive content brands WapCar, AutoFun
summary: Carsome, a car e-commerce platform, has acquired digital automotive content brands WapCar and AutoFun from Tang Internet and its subsidiaries for an undisclosed sum. WapCar AutoFun, operating in Southeast Asia, has over 6 million average monthly active users and will become a fully-owned subsidiary of Carsome. The partnership aims to enhance customer experience and bring trust, transparency, and choice to car transactions. This move follows Carsome's recent appointments and acquisition of a 51% stake in CarTimes Group.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: UK business activity slows to 3-month low as inflation soars: PMI
summary: UK private-sector growth slowed to its weakest pace in 4 months in April, with businesses raising prices on the broadest basis since the late 1990s. The S&P Global/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 58.9, its lowest level since January. Inflation soars, with the official consumer price index hitting a 30-year high of 7.0% in March. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter-point to 1% to tame inflation.

site_title: US summer travellers can expect long lines, higher prices as Covid restrictions ease
summary: US travelers can expect long lines and higher prices as COVID restrictions ease this summer. Airlines, hotels, and rental car companies reported a surge in demand, while facing a tight labor market and limited supply. Flights are averaging $302 per traveler for round-trip domestic flights, a 3% increase from pre-pandemic levels. Hotel rates have risen 36.4% and car rental companies are struggling with limited supply, leading to higher prices. Booking now can help lock in better prices, but travelers should be prepared for inflation and potential delays.

images.alt_text: The group’s cargo division had a “record result” in the first quarter, Lufthansa said, as demand for freight remain high amid turmoil in global supply chains.

site_title: "Walking theatre" on the rise
summary: "Outdoor theatre, also known as 'walking theatre' or 'promenade theatre', has become a trend as audiences opt for experiential storytelling in public spaces. Shows like Singapore Repertory Theatre's 'C-O-N-T-A-C-T' and Sight Lines Entertainment's 'Time Heist: Civic District' take audiences on immersive journeys through the city, often incorporating the surroundings into the narrative. This format has been popularized during the pandemic and continues to attract audiences who value the unique, interactive experience. Other productions, such as Drama Box's 'Ubin', explore site-specific themes and encourage audience engagement with the environment."

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
At the 59th Venice Biennale, the Singapore Pavilion titled Pulp III: A Short History Of The Banished Book revels in its quietude.

site_title: Tesla fares well on environmental risks, not so great for social and governance issues: Phillip Capital
summary: Tesla scores well on environmental risks but falls short in social and governance issues, according to a report by Phillip Capital. The electric vehicle manufacturer has made efforts to reduce waste, energy, and water consumption, and has implemented recycling initiatives and electrified its heavy-duty trucks. However, the company lacks transparency in disclosing climate-related risks and opportunities, and has faced criticism for product safety, workplace discrimination, and environmental concerns at its manufacturing facilities. Tesla needs to improve its management of social and governance issues to align with its environmental efforts.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

TESLA is recalling 14,684 imported and locally made Model 3 cars in China on problems with software that could lead to collisions, the country's market regulator said, the second batch of recalls for the US car maker in April.
A BP Pulse EV charging point outside BP’s headquarters in Milton Keynes, UK.
Tesla gains on Musk's optimism about overcoming supply issues
Tesla reported another banner quarter of profit growth on Wednesday.

site_title: Shell posts record profit on high energy prices and trading boost
summary: Shell reported a record first-quarter profit of US$9.13 billion, driven by high energy prices and a strong trading performance. This surpasses analyst forecasts of US$8.67 billion. The company also announced US$5.4 billion in dividend payments and share repurchases, with plans to exceed 30% of cash flow for shareholder distributions in the second half. Shell wrote down US$3.9 billion due to exiting Russian operations following Ukraine's invasion.

images.alt_text: TOTALENERGIES will expand plans to buy back its own shares, the French energy group said on Thursday (Apr 28) after first-quarter core earnings rose sharply on soaring oil and gas prices.
BP has reported its strongest quarterly earnings  amid soaring oil and gas prices.
A BP Pulse EV charging point outside BP’s headquarters in Milton Keynes, UK.

site_title: China stocks’ weak return from break highlights growth concerns
summary: China's benchmark CSI 300 Index fell 0.2% on its return from a 3-day break, amid weak economic data and concerns over strict COVID lockdowns. Disappointing earnings from Contemporary Amperex Technology and Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology weighed on the market. Data showing a sharp contraction in China's economy, including weak services, factory activity, and domestic travel spending, further unsettled investors. The market's weak performance highlights concerns about the impact of lockdowns on the economy and investors' wait for policymakers to put words into action.

images.alt_text: Chinese travellers spent 43 per cent less over the five-day Labour Day holiday that ended on Wednesday than a year earlier, government data showed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed Thursday in negative territory, weighed by another weak reading on China's economy. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.36%, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.68%. The Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange also rose 0.68%.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises target price for Jiutian to S$0.17 on higher EPS estimates
summary: CGS-CIMB raised its target price for Jiutian Chemical Group to S$0.17 from S$0.09, citing higher EPS estimates of 7.4% for FY2022 to FY2024. The company's Q1 earnings exceeded expectations, with a 122.7% increase in net profit and 76% year-over-year revenue growth. CGS-CIMB maintains an "add" rating, citing a strong net cash position and favorable industry cycle. The target price implies a potential upside of 75.3% from Jiutian's closing price.

images.alt_text: Wilmar announced its first-quarter earnings last Friday, which saw its net profit climb 17.8 per cent to US$530.3 million (S$728.9 million) on the back of firm palm oil prices.

site_title: Inflation gains keeping South-east Asia central bankers on edge
summary: Consumer prices in the Philippines rose 4.9% year-over-year in April, the fastest pace in 3 years, and in Thailand, prices moderated to 4.65% in April, slightly below estimates. This has complicated central bankers' efforts to keep post-Covid recoveries on track, with some policymakers considering interest rate hikes. The Philippines' central bank governor has expressed urgency to address inflation, while the Bank of Thailand remains patient, but may reconsider its plans if price growth picks up again.

images.alt_text: For the first time in over a decade, traders are anticipating faster inflation in Europe than the US as the war in Ukraine drives up energy prices.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees US$600m hit from Bermuda court case
summary: Credit Suisse expects a US$600 million hit from a Bermuda court case related to damages from former Georgian Prime Minister Bidzina Ivanishvili's family. The bank's first-quarter net loss was 273 million Swiss francs (S$385.3 million), citing net litigation provisions of 703 million francs. Credit Suisse is also monitoring risks from Russia sanctions, China's economic slowdown, and liquidity concerns in China's property development sector.

Credit Suisse on Wednesday posted a 273 million Swiss franc (S$390.5 million) first-quarter loss.

site_title: Hatten Land, Focus Media to jointly invest 8m yuan in Melaka mall e-sports hub
summary: Hatten Land and Focus Media have agreed to jointly invest 8 million yuan (S$1.7 million) in an e-sports hub project at Hatten Land's Element X mall in Melaka. The immersive hub will occupy over 90,000 square feet of retail space and generate rental income through entry ticket sales. Hatten Land will fund its investment from share placement proceeds, with a 70% stake held by the company and 30% by Focus Media Sports. The joint venture aims to contribute positively to Hatten Land's financial performance by FY 2023.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Hatten Land rebrands Melaka mall into e-sports hub, raises S$5m via new shares

site_title: Oceanus unit sets up S$5m futurealistic studio, to boost headcount over  next 2 years
summary: Oceanus Media Global, a subsidiary of Singapore-listed Oceanus Group, has set up a S$5 million futurealistic studio to create customised immersive media productions using high-end virtual production technology. The studio aims to boost its staff size by at least 50% over the next two years. This first-of-its-kind studio in South-east Asia will cater to various markets, including concerts, corporate events, film, and TV production, offering "next-generation storytelling experiences".

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Oceanus exits SGX watch list after nearly six years
Oceanus sets up new unit in China; will work on watch list exit

site_title: See-through watches
summary: Several luxury watch brands have released see-through sapphire case timepieces, including Chanel, Zenith, Chopard, and Cvstos. Chanel's J12 X-Ray Red and Boy.Friend Skeleton X-Ray Red feature Caliber 3 movements, while Chopard's LUC Full Strike Sapphire minute repeater is the first built in solid sapphire, with a price tag of CHF 450,000. Zenith's Defy Zero-G and Defy 21 Double Tourbillon Sapphire showcase cutting-edge movements in a 46mm sapphire case, limited to 10 pieces each. Cvstos' Metropolitan PS Skeleton Sapphire is a more affordable option at S$58,050, limited to 50 pieces.

images.alt_text: Perfectly timed comeback for Watches And Wonders Geneva

site_title: Hong Kong's retail sales plunge again in March on virus curbs
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales declined 13.8% in March, the first back-to-back contraction in over a year, due to stringent virus restrictions. The decline was worse than expected, with sales volume falling 16.8% from the previous year. The city's economy contracted 4% in the first quarter, and the government has started easing curbs to boost growth, including handing out consumption vouchers. However, economists expect a potentially lengthy road to recovery, with DBS Group Holdings cutting its 2022 growth forecast to 1.7%.

site_title: UniCredit cheers investors with buyback as Russia hits profit
summary: UniCredit, one of Europe's banks most exposed to Russia, reported a 70% decline in first-quarter profit due to Russia-related provisions. Despite this, the bank plans to start a 1.6 billion euro share buyback program, surprising investors. The decision comes as UniCredit has been looking to sell its AO UniCredit Bank in Russia. Shares in UniCredit rose over 6% in early trade following the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Unicredit logo is seen displayed in this illustration taken, May 3, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 8.7% in March, reversing February’s decline
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 8.7% year-on-year in March, reversing the 3.5% decline in February. The increase was attributed to growth in industries like computer equipment, wearing apparel, and cosmetics. Retail sales growth is seen as a positive sign for the economy, with economists predicting 6% expansion in 2022. However, inflation concerns and global economic risks may impact retail sales momentum in the near term.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Singapore retail sales up 11.1% in 2021 after year-end rise in December
Pre-CNY shopping fuels rise in January retail sales of 11.8%
Singapore retail sales down 3.4% ending 5-month growth streak

site_title: Lufthansa optimistic for 2022 as tourist demand bounces back
summary: Lufthansa reported a net loss of 584 million euros in the first quarter of 2022, down from 1 billion euros in the same period last year. Passenger traffic more than quadrupled to 13 million, driven by a recovery in air travel as coronavirus restrictions were lifted. The airline expects to offer 75% of its pre-crisis capacity this year, with leisure travelers driving demand. The cargo division reported a "record result" in the first quarter, and the company expects its financial performance to improve in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: Airline chiefs want government aid to reduce carbon emissions

site_title: BMW profit beats estimates on strong demand for top-end cars
summary: BMW's profit for the first quarter rose 12% to 3.39 billion euros, beating analyst estimates of 2.9 billion euros, despite disruptions from the war in Ukraine and Covid-lockdowns in China. The automaker's auto revenue rose 17% year-over-year, driven by higher-margin models and the full consolidation of its China joint venture. BMW's operating return on automaking was 8.9%, slightly below analyst expectations of 7.8%. The company expects its automaking returns to pick up during the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The logo of German car manufacturer BMW is seen on the bonnet of a vehicle covered with water drops in Kiev March 27, 2012.   REUTERS/Str (UKRAINE  - Tags: TRANSPORT BUSINESS LOGO)
New 7 Series reveals BMW's changing mindset

site_title: Maximising value from waste
summary: Singapore's businesses must prioritize waste management as regulatory measures will increasingly be implemented. The country's Zero Waste Masterplan aims to reduce waste and extend the lifespan of its sole landfill. Businesses that fail to develop their capabilities in corporate sustainability risk losing financial support and business opportunities. Effective waste measurement and reporting can identify opportunities for cost savings and inform purchasing strategies and process flows. A study found that 44% of listed food and beverage companies in Singapore did not disclose waste-related information, highlighting the need for improved reporting practices.

images.alt_text: Cutting emissions isn't enough; the world needs to move to a circular economy

site_title: 'Top Gun' gets 'evolution' in sequel 36 years on, says Cruise
summary: Tom Cruise returns to his iconic role as Maverick in the long-awaited sequel to Top Gun, 36 years after the original film. The movie follows Maverick as he trains a new batch of pilots, including the son of his late friend Goose, for a deadly mission. The film incorporates technological advances such as fighter drones and features a group of relatively unknown young actors. Cruise, 59, said the movie is an "evolution" of the original and aims to capture the sense of romance and adventure in the world of aviation.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit ends first day of trading at S$0.395
summary: ESR-Logos Reit began trading on the Singapore Exchange at S$0.395, unchanged from its opening price, after a merger between ESR-Reit and Ara Logos Logistics Trust. The new entity, E-Log Reit, was formed with 8.7 million units changing hands, and its pro forma net asset value per unit for FY2021 was expected to be S$0.36. The merger consideration included 9.7 cents in cash and 1.7729 ESR-Reit units for every ALog Trust unit.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Manager discloses indicative timeline of ESR-Reit-Ara Logos Logistics Trust merger
ESR-Reit, ALog Trust unitholders vote in favour of merger to form ESR-Logos Reit
ESR-Reit chief Adrian Chui to be CEO of ESR-Logos manager, Alog Trust chief to be deputy CEO

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts maintain 'buy' on Wilmar as valuations look attractive
summary: Analysts have maintained a "buy" rating on Wilmar International, citing attractive valuations. The stock is trading at 10 times earnings estimates, compared to peers trading at 26-39 times. Despite lower earnings estimates due to China lockdowns and weak demand, analysts expect upside potential of 16.2% and 38.5% from target prices of S$5.10 and S$6.08, respectively. Wilmar's first-quarter earnings rose 17.8% to US$530.3 million, driven by firm palm oil prices.

images.alt_text: Commodity prices have surged since the onset of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which is expected to benefit Wilmar's Plantation and Sugar Milling segment.

site_title: Drone swarms can now fly autonomously through thick forest
summary: Scientists at Zhejiang University in China have successfully developed autonomous drone swarms that can fly through crowded forests without collisions. The swarms of 10 drones use a new flight path planning system and an algorithm that incorporates collision avoidance, flight efficiency, and coordination. The technology has real-world applications in aerial mapping for conservation and disaster relief, and could be used to survey damage after natural disasters or deliver heavy objects. While the technology has potential for civilian use, there is also a concern about its military applications, with the Pentagon reportedly interested in developing similar drones.

images.alt_text: Snap has a replacement for the cheap phone stands and awkward outstretched arms of modern self-filming: a yellow, square-shaped flying camera drone that costs US$230, weighs about a quarter of a pound and hovers around you to film you automatically.

site_title: A stackable house
summary: A unique, 576 sq m stackable house in Upper Thomson, Singapore, was designed by Studio Wills + Architects for Dawn Chin and her husband. The three-box structure, made of glass, concrete, and steel, maximizes living space despite a small buildable footprint due to setback regulations. The design incorporates a garden, basement garage, and entertainment area, while also providing natural light and views of the surrounding area. The architects balanced the client's needs with the constraints of the site, creating a sense of lightness in a congested neighborhood.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
A quiet but luxurious GCB

site_title: Placing a bet on Italian grapes in California
summary: Wine entrepreneur Kevin Harvey is pioneering the production of Italian grapes in California, specifically nebbiolo, carricante, and nerello mascalese, in his Centennial Mountain vineyard. Harvey's venture aims to prove that California can produce world-class wines of Italian origin, particularly in response to climate change. After years of research, he has found suitable sites for these grapes, using a combination of weather stations and soil analysis. His initial wines, released in 2018, show promise, with the carricante and nerello mascalese demonstrating unique site expressions and a high level of quality.

images.alt_text: Two bottles of the same wine can seem quite different depending on the context in which they are tasted or consumed.

site_title: Elon Musk and Cathie Wood say passive investing has gone too far
summary: Elon Musk and Cathie Wood criticized passive investing in a Twitter thread, saying it has "gone too far" and led to a "massive misallocation of capital." Their discussion was sparked by Marc Andreessen's comment that passive index trackers have outsized voices in corporations due to their voting power. Musk and Wood argued that active managers have missed out on significant gains, with Wood noting that her flagship ETF slumped almost 45% in 2022. The debate over active and passive funds has been ongoing for decades, with some arguing that active styles struggle to beat indexes consistently.

site_title: Asia's post-FOMC relief rally fizzles out on inflation, China's growth concerns
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed trading session following the US Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) policy statement, which ruled out a 75 basis point rate hike. The rally fizzled out as concerns over China's slowing growth and inflationary pressures took center stage, with key data showing a private gauge measuring China's services sector tumbled to its lowest level since the pandemic's onset. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index declined 0.4%, while Singapore's retail sales surprised on the upside with an 8.7% year-on-year increase in March.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Asian markets ride on post-FOMC momentum

Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose by more than 930 points on Wednesday after the Fed hiked interest rates by 50 basis points but said an even bigger 75-basis-point hike was not on the table.
Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Wednesday announced its biggest rate hike since 2000, with a half percentage point increase as it works to crush soaring US inflation.

site_title: China’s domestic spending on Labour Day holiday travel tumbles 43% over Covid-19 curbs
summary: China's domestic spending on Labour Day holiday travel plummeted 43% due to Covid-19 curbs, with 160 million trips made resulting in a 30.2% year-on-year decrease in revenue. The decline was attributed to measures to fight the outbreak, including lockdowns and movement curbs. Hotel occupancy rates were also low, with Sanya's rate at 20.6% during the holiday. This marks a significant drop from the previous year, with revenue falling to 64.7 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: epa09916197 People walk inside the Universal Studios in Beijing, China, 29 April 2022. Beijing continues its tough restrictions with mass testing and recently closing down more establishments such as malls, gyms, cinemas and apartment blocks to control the COVID-19 outbreak as the May Day holiday approaches over the weekend.  EPA-EFE/MARK R. CRISTINO

site_title: Bank of England set for fourth straight rate hike to fight inflation
summary: The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates for the fourth time since December to combat inflation, which has reached 7% and is expected to surpass 10% in April. The rate hike, a quarter-point increase, will bring the bank rate to 1.0%, its highest since 2009. The move aims to quell inflationary pressures, but economists warn of a potential recession and the need for careful balancing.

site_title: Briton charged with 2 more counts of abetting to falsify documents related to Wirecard scandal
summary: James Henry O'Sullivan, a 47-year-old British national, has been charged with two more counts of abetting the falsification of documents related to the Wirecard scandal. O'Sullivan allegedly instigated Citadelle Corporate Services director R Shanmugaratnam to issue false letters to Wirecard AG, claiming the company held large sums of money in escrow. This is in addition to the five counts of abetting Shanmugaratnam O'Sullivan was previously charged with.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Germany charges Wirecard's ex-CEO Braun with alleged fraud
Wirecard funds supposedly held in trust by Citadelle with OCBC confirmed to be just a fraction of initial claims
Briton allegedly linked to Wirecard case in Singapore face 4 more charges of abetting to falsify document
46-year-old man arrested in relation to Wirecard case

site_title: Axiata, YTL unlikely to see material contributions from digital banks in near term: Maybank
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group and YTL Power, owners of digital banking units Boost and a consortium partner respectively, are unlikely to see material contributions from these units in the near term, according to Maybank. Axiata's Boost, one of the top 3 e-wallets, is expected to drive business, while YTL Power's role will be limited to support. Maybank analyst Tan Chi Wei has a "buy" call on both companies, citing potential cost savings and regulatory expertise. The digital banks' licenses, won in April, offer a new value creation avenue.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
GRAB likely has an advantage over its other digital bank competitors in Malaysia given its e-wallet share in the country, Maybank said on Sunday (May 1).
Grab and Sea winning the Malaysia digital bank licence raises questions if attentions will be turned away from Singapore

The most pressing issue today is that the legacy core technology for many Asean banks has been in service for two decades, or even longer, and is coming to the end of its lifecycle. This has, understandably, made banks across the region nervous as they examine their options for what comes next.

site_title: US Fed hike causes gyrations in financial markets
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by half a percentage point, citing inflation concerns, and announced plans to shrink its bond holdings. Global stock markets fell 8% in April, and financial markets continue to adjust to tighter monetary conditions. The dollar has strengthened against major currencies, including the Japanese yen, and investors are pricing in higher rates and lower economic growth. The Fed's actions are expected to lead to higher borrowing costs and potentially slower economic growth, with inflation still above 5% on the Fed's preferred measure.

images.alt_text: The Fed needs to regain control of the policy narrative if it is to have any chance to land the economy softly.
The Fed is expected to keep raising short-term interest rates several times over the next year

site_title: Millions in Beijing urged to work from home to fight Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Millions in Beijing are urged to work from home to combat a surge in Covid-19 cases, with the city reporting 50 local virus cases. The measure follows a national holiday marked by lockdowns and mass testing. Some employees are seen returning to their buildings, scanning health codes to gain entry. The move comes after an extended lockdown in Shanghai, China's largest city, led to food shortages and public anger. The zero-Covid policy continues to be enforced, with entire neighborhoods sealed over handfuls of infections.

site_title: Mark Zuckerberg teases wearable tech with neural interface in Facebook post
summary: Mark Zuckerberg teased a new smart glasses project with EssilorLuxottica, posting a photo of EssilorLuxottica's chairman wearing a prototype neural interface wristband. The wristband is designed to control glasses and other devices, and Zuckerberg mentioned a collaboration with the eyewear company to develop augmented reality glasses. This project follows Meta Platforms' previous plans to develop a wristband that would control AR glasses, and comes as tech companies like Amazon, Apple, and Google invest in wearable tech and augmented reality.

site_title: Philippines' April inflation surges above 2022 target
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate surged to 4.9% in April, the highest level since December 2018, exceeding the central bank's target of 2-4% and prompting a potential interest rate hike to curb inflation. The increase was mainly attributed to food and energy costs. Despite this, the January-April average remained within the central bank's target range of 3.7%. The Monetary Board is set to review policy settings on May 19, considering the inflation outlook and macroeconomic prospects.

site_title: Ukraine, Russia production critical to restoring global food security, UN chief says
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres stated that restoring Ukrainian agricultural production and Russian food and fertilizer output is crucial to solving the global food security crisis. The ongoing war in Ukraine has added to financial market volatility, affecting commodity prices and logistics, potentially derailing economic recoveries in countries like Nigeria. Guterres warned that the crisis is devastating global food, energy, and financial systems for developing countries.

images.alt_text: Smoke rises above Kyiv after Russian strikes on the Ukrainian capital.

site_title: Powell strikes reassuring note as Fed takes worst-case scenarios off table
summary: The US Federal Reserve took a reassuring stance on interest rates, hiking by 50 basis points but ruling out a larger 75-basis-point hike. This decision halted concerns of a worst-case scenario, leading to a surge in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, with a gain of over 930 points and major indexes jumping by the most in 2 years. The Fed's move has provided a temporary reprieve for the stock market, which had been volatile due to interest rate concerns.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Wednesday announced its biggest rate hike since 2000, with a half percentage point increase as it works to crush soaring US inflation.
The Straits Times Index headed up 0.6 per cent or 19.91 points to 3,369.18 as at 9.02 am.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.53 points or 0.60% to 1,609.96 at 9:08 am on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume was 190.13 million lots worth RM103.99 million. Gainers beat losers 264 to 117.

site_title: Gold rises 1% after Fed flags inflation, tones down hawkish bets
summary: Gold prices rose 1% on Thursday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 50 basis points to combat inflation, with the US central bank ruling out larger hikes for the year. The move supported gold prices, which were also boosted by a decline in US Treasury yields and a stronger dollar. Spot gold climbed to $1,898.06 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 1.4% to $1,894.20. The Fed's decision was seen as a cautious approach to inflation, which was highlighted as a risk to the economy.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged lower on Wednesday (May 4), as an uptick in US Treasury yields and an impending hike in interest rates by the US Federal Reserve dented demand for zero-yield bullion.

site_title: Japan, South Korea, Indonesia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in Indonesia, Japan, and South Korea are closed on Thursday due to public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI rising 0.4% on Thursday. US markets also reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging past previous highs.

site_title: Coinbase's NFT marketplace opens to all, but users don't show up
summary: Coinbase's NFT marketplace, now open to all users, has experienced a slow start with fewer than 110 transactions and less than $60,000 in sales as of May 4. This contrasts with OpenSea's $124 million in transaction volume on May 3. Coinbase's NFT project attracted millions of signups, but experts expect it to take time to gain traction, with OpenSea likely to remain the leader in the market. The slow start is attributed to high expectations and the complexity of the new space.

site_title: ThaiBev resumes proposed spin-off, listing of 20% of BeerCo unit on SGX
summary: ThaiBev is resuming its proposed spin-off and listing of its brewery unit BeerCo on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), which was initially deferred due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company plans to list up to 20% of BeerCo's issued ordinary shares through a public offering. BeerCo has 3 breweries in Thailand and 26 in Vietnam, and posted a profit after tax of S$342.5 million in its financial year ended Sep 30, 2021. The listing is expected to unlock shareholder value and provide a transparent valuation benchmark for the beer business.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
ThaiBev to revive unit's US$2b Singapore IPO, sources say
ThaiBev defers potential spin-off and listing of BeerCo subsidiary
ThaiBev receives eligibility-to-list letter from SGX for potential listing of BeerCo
ThaiBev confirms intention to list 20% of Thai beer unit on SGX

site_title: China's services activity falls at second sharpest rate on record: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity contracted at the second-steepest rate on record in April, with the Caixin services purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 36.2, the second-lowest since 2005. The sector, accounting for 60% of the economy, saw a decline in new business and employment due to Covid-19 curbs, with a sub-index for new business hitting a record low of 38.4. Input costs rose, but services firms cut prices amid lacklustre demand, highlighting rising cost pressures.

images.alt_text: US services industry growth unexpectedly slowed in April, with employment contracting for the second time this year, while a measure of input prices raced to a record high.

CHINA'S central bank on Wednesday (May 4)  pledged monetary policy support to ensure ample liquidity, help businesses badly hit by the latest Covid-19 outbreak in the country and support a recovery in consumption.

site_title: Nadal wins on return from injury in Madrid
summary: Rafael Nadal made a successful return from a 6-week injury break, winning his first match at the Madrid tournament with a 6-1, 7-6(7/4) victory over Serbia's Miomir Kecmanovic. Nadal, sidelined with a rib injury since his Indian Wells final defeat in March, showed no signs of rust and praised his performance, calling it a "non-existent" preparation due to his injury.

images.alt_text: Tennis: Fritz credits high pain tolerance for Indian Wells success

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks started Thursday with a 1.41% climb, reaching 21,163.15, following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The move was seen as a relatively moderate adjustment, with traders playing down the possibility of a 75 basis-point increase. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.66%. Despite global market uncertainty, Hong Kong shares rallied, driven by investor optimism and a positive outlook for the region.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on mining, tech boost; NAB drops
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Thursday, driven by gains in miners and tech stocks. Iron ore futures jumped 4% on China demand hopes, lifting heavyweight miners BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue 1.6-2.6%. Energy stocks also surged 1.7% on rising oil prices, while tech stocks rose 2.3% following Wall Street gains. In contrast, National Australia Bank dropped 3.5% after warning of higher costs, and the financial sector skidded 1.3%.

images.alt_text: A man stands in front of an electronic board displaying stock information inside the Australian Securities Exchange, operated by ASX Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Sept. 9, 2013. The Australian dollar's strongest weekly advance since December 2011 is a reminder to Prime Minister-Elect Tony Abbott that his plans to revive a slowing economy will be hostage to currency markets. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong emerges as hub for Chinese firms seeking ESG loans
summary: Chinese companies are increasingly turning to Hong Kong for ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) loans, helping to offset the city's slowdown in corporate lending. In 2022, Hong Kong facilitated $6.7 billion of sustainability-linked loans, with nearly 40% of these loans syndicated in the city. The growth in ESG loans in Hong Kong is expected to continue, with Standard Chartered Bank predicting a strong pipeline of issuance this year. This trend is part of Hong Kong's efforts to establish itself as a top green-finance locale, with the government selling its first retail green bond and establishing a grant programme for sustainable financing.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong ranked 148 in the Reporters Without Borders 2022 World Press Freedom Index, representing a fall of 68 places from last year.

site_title: Australian dollar on a high after once-in-a-decade rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged 2.2% and 1.6% respectively, their biggest one-day jumps since 2011 and early 2020, respectively. The gains came after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell played down the chance of a 75-basis-point interest rate rise, forcing markets to scale back wagers and triggering a wave of stop-loss buying. This led to a sharp decline in US bond yields and the dollar, with the Aussie reaching a one-week high of US$0.7256. Investors also trimmed expectations for rate hikes from the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: Books for almost every type of Mum
summary: A Mother's Day guide to books for different types of moms has been released, featuring 6 books tailored to various personalities. For the Arty Mum, "Delayed Rays of A Star" by Amanda Lee Koe is a historical novel exploring the lives of three female icons of classic cinema. The Funny Mum will enjoy "Erotic Stories For Punjabi Widows" by Balli Kaur Jaswal, a humorous and lighthearted novel about a community centre class. Romantic Mums will appreciate "Foreverland: On The Divine Tedium Of Marriage" by Heather Havrilesky, a candid memoir about marriage. Eclectic Mums will like "The Formidable Miss Cassidy" by Meihan Boey, a quirky historical fiction novel. Clever Mums will enjoy "Pulp" by Shubigi Rao, a series examining the importance of books as symbols of knowledge and resistance. Fashionista Mums will enjoy "The Book Of Daniel: Adventures Of A Fashion Insider" by Daniel Boey, a coffee table book on Singapore's fashion history. Gourmand Mums will appreciate "How To Cook Everything Singaporean" by Denise Fletcher, an encyclopedia of Singaporean recipes.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Qantas buys Alliance Aviation in A$763m charter flight deal
summary: Qantas has agreed to buy Alliance Aviation Services in a deal valued at A$763 million, gaining a fleet of small aircraft for charter flights in Western Australia. The deal values Alliance at A$4.75 per share, with shareholders receiving Qantas shares. The acquisition will extend the working life of both companies' combined fleets, thanks to Alliance's large inventory of spare parts. This deal complements Qantas' existing ownership of Fokker aircraft, solidifying its presence in the charter flight market for the resources industry.

site_title: HDB resale prices continue upward trend in April as sales volumes flatten: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 1.1% month-on-month and 11.9% year-on-year in April, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co. The most expensive resale flat was a 5-room unit at Pinnacle@Duxton for S$1,228,000. Mature estate flats saw a 1% price gain, while non-mature estate flats rose 1.2%. Year-over-year, mature estate flat resale prices increased 9.8%, while non-mature estate flat prices rose 13.5%. The upward trend marks the 22nd consecutive month of price gains.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
HDB resale volumes recover in March as prices rise for 21 straight months: SRX, 99.co

site_title: Facebook parent Meta slows hiring in cost-cutting push
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is slowing or pausing hiring for mid- to senior-level positions as part of a cost-cutting push. The move follows a revised spending budget that takes into account a weaker revenue outlook due to the Ukraine war. Despite this, Meta plans to continue growing its workforce to focus on long-term impact. The company had previously added over 5,800 new hires in the first quarter, but is now re-evaluating its talent pipeline. Meta has over 77,800 employees, a 28% increase from last year.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open after US Fed's half-point hike; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% in early trade on May 5, 2022, following the US Federal Reserve's half-point interest rate hike, the largest since 2000. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 19.91 points to 3,369.18, with gains outnumbering losses 108 to 33. Key gainers included Jiutian Chemical, Sembcorp Marine, and Dyna-Mac Holdings, while banking stocks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose.

site_title: Facebook-owner Meta gives preview of its first physical store, enterprise tools
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has given a preview of its first physical store, featuring a floor-to-ceiling screen and rooms for testing virtual reality devices. The store, set to open on May 9, showcases Meta's hardware products, including Ray-Ban smart glasses and Oculus VR headsets, and demonstrates its enterprise tools, including virtual reality conferencing technology. The company sees opportunity in the "metaverse" business, despite growth slowing and a reliance on digital ads for revenue, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg warning it may take a decade for bets to pay off.

images.alt_text: Facebook parent company Meta Platforms is slowing or pausing hiring for some mid- to senior-level positions, part of a broader plan to cut costs and cope with the challenges facing the social media giant.

site_title: Twitter courts advertisers amid uncertain future under Musk
summary: Twitter is showcasing its advertising opportunities amid uncertainty about its future under Elon Musk, who is buying the platform for $44 billion.
