Despite Musk's tweet that Twitter should not have ads to control content moderation, the company has continued to promote its ad business. Most advertisers remain cautious but are watching closely for changes, with some, like E! News, launching new live-streamed shows on the platform. Twitter has also announced partnerships with media companies and expanded its live sports coverage, but the company's long-term plans under Musk remain unclear.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk said on Tuesday Twitter will always be free for casual users but may charge a slight fee for commercial and government users.
Activist groups called on Twitter advertisers on Tuesday to boycott the service if it opens the gates to abusive and misinformative posts with Elon Must as its owner.

site_title: UK office lending rose 48% last year after 2020's Covid crunch
summary: UK commercial real estate lending surged 48% in 2021, rebounding to pre-pandemic levels after a year of Covid-driven turbulence. Lending volume reached £49.8 billion, with margins for prime office loans increasing 25 basis points. However, pricing dropped for retail and industrial properties, narrowing the gap with office loans. The strong recovery is attributed to lenders' preparedness to weather the Covid storm and Brexit-related reluctance to invest in the market.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial Holding aims for CPF investment decision by mid-May: Board
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding aims to make a decision on whether Central Provident Fund (CPF) account funds can be used to buy its shares by mid-May. The company has applied for its shares to be included under the CPF Investment Scheme and is expecting the outcome to be known by the end of next week. If approved, shareholders will be able to use their CPF funds to purchase YZJFH shares traded on the Mainboard.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Crypto exchange Binance gets french regulatory nod in European push
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has secured regulatory approval from the French government, marking its first major approval from a G-7 member nation. The digital-asset service provider registration will boost the company's ambitions in Europe, following investments in Paris' blockchain ecosystem and confirmation of a base in the city. This approval is part of a trend of major crypto firms gaining regulatory nods in strategic markets, with Binance also securing approvals in Bahrain, Dubai, and Abu Dhabi.

site_title: Booking beats estimates, sees 'busy summer travel season ahead'
summary: Booking Holdings reported revenue of $2.7 billion in the first quarter, exceeding analysts' estimates of $2.54 billion, driven by pent-up demand for leisure travel. Gross bookings reached $27.3 billion, the highest quarterly amount ever, beating the average analyst estimate. The company expects a busy summer travel season ahead.

images.alt_text: Down and back again: how Booking.com could thrive post-pandemic

site_title: India mulls wheat export curbs in latest food supply squeeze: source
summary: India is considering restricting wheat exports amid severe heatwaves that damaged crops, exacerbating global food shortages. The country has enough supply to meet domestic demand, but curbing exports could boost domestic supply and keep prices in check. The move could worsen global food inflation, which is already at a record, and add to a wave of crop protectionism worldwide. The government is discussing the plan, which could include setting a minimum export price, and will recommend it to Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

images.alt_text: CHINA has stopped its weekly wheat auctions from state reserves, earlier than last year when stocks were higher, traders and analysts said.

site_title: National Australia Bank boosts dividend as profit meets expectations
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) met expectations for its first-half cash profit, with earnings reaching A$3.48 billion. The bank's net interest margin declined 11 basis points to 1.63%, but growth in loan volumes and fee income offset the impact. NAB increased its dividend by more than 20% to 73 cents per share. The bank's results follow a similar performance from smaller rival ANZ, which also beat profit estimates and forecast improved margins in the second half.

site_title: Brazil raises interest rates by 100 bps, flags smaller increase ahead
summary: Brazil's central bank raised its benchmark Selic interest rate to 12.75% for the tenth straight increase, a five-year high, to combat double-digit inflation. The decision was as expected and signals an ongoing rate hike cycle. Policymakers indicated a smaller increase next month, citing a lower magnitude adjustment. This move aims to bring inflation back to the 3.5% target for 2022, with consumer prices expected to rise 4.1% next year, above the official target.

site_title: Shareholder sues Netflix over subscriber slip
summary: A Netflix shareholder is seeking class action status for a lawsuit accusing the company of not disclosing that subscriber numbers were in peril. Despite a disclosed drop of 200,000 users, Netflix's shares plummeted after the company announced quarterly earnings in April. The suit claims top executives failed to inform investors that subscriber growth was slowing due to account sharing and increasing competition. The shareholder seeks unspecified cash damages and compensation for financial losses.

site_title: Biden signals campaign strategy against ‘extreme’ Republicans
summary: US President Joe Biden has signaled his campaign strategy for the midterm congressional elections, framing his opponents as part of the "most extreme" political group in American history, led by former President Donald Trump's "MAGA crowd." Biden aims to tie the election to the looming rollback of abortion rights and other issues, despite some critics labeling his approach as a failed playbook. The midterm elections are crucial for Biden's re-election prospects, with Democrats facing a possible loss of control of Congress.

site_title: Airbus to build 75 A320 jets a month by 2025 as travel rebounds
summary: Airbus plans to ramp up production of its A320 family of jets to 75 a month by 2025, a significant increase from its current rate of 50. The move comes as demand recovers from the coronavirus crisis, and the company will construct a new US assembly line to meet the goal. Despite challenges such as the war in Ukraine and Covid lockdowns in China, Airbus expects to deliver at least 720 jetliners this year, and its CEO has expressed confidence in the supply chain's ability to support the increased production.

images.alt_text: AIRBUS faces a months-long delay in the development of its A321XLR jet, pushing its arrival to 2024, as European regulators consider imposing changes to a lower-fuselage design to contain potential fire risks, industry sources said on Wednesday (May 4).

site_title: Lendlease Reit posts 99.9% occupancy; 313@somerset tenant sales close to 2020 levels
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit reported a 99.9% occupancy rate for its 313@somerset mall as of March 31, with tenant sales year-to-date recovering close to FY2020 levels. The weighted average lease expiry (WALE) stood at 8.2 years and 4.3 years by net lettable area (NLA) and gross rental income (GRI), respectively. The Reit's exposure to the suburban retail sector is expected to expand to about 47%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Lendlease Reit to raise at least S$573.8m to fund Jem acquisition

site_title: US: Stocks rally, dollar retreats as Fed lifts interest rates
summary: US stocks rallied, with major indices powering about 3% higher, following the Federal Reserve's 50 basis point interest rate hike and announcement to begin reducing bond holdings. The dollar retreated against the euro and other currencies. The decision was seen as meeting expectations but containing no "hawkish surprise." The Fed Chair expressed confidence in a "soft landing" that can tame inflation without sending the economy into recession, with stocks expected to push higher in the coming sessions.

images.alt_text: US stocks finished a choppy session modestly higher on Tuesday.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore banks have increased promotional rates for fixed deposits to 1.3% for 24-month tenures. Sembmarine and Keppel O&M are merging to form an offshore powerhouse valued at S$8.7 billion. PR veteran Lynn Yeow was declared bankrupt due to debts owed by a firm linked to her cousins. Grab-Singtel and Sea Group secured Malaysia digital bank licences. Indonesia will ban exports of palm oil from April 28. Malaysia's agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: JD.com, Pinduoduo added to Chinese companies facing delisting in US
summary: US regulators added over 80 Chinese companies, including JD.com and Pinduoduo, to a list of firms that face possible expulsion from American exchanges due to Beijing's refusal to allow access to financial audits. The Securities and Exchange Commission put these companies on a 3-year provisional list, starting a clock to comply with inspection requirements. The move comes after a 2020 law requiring public companies to grant audit access to American officials, which China refuses to comply with. Firms face delisting if they don't comply for 3 straight years, potentially removing them from the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq.

site_title: Dutch probe Google over Play Store app
summary: The Dutch consumer watchdog has launched a preliminary investigation into Google over its Play Store app, following a complaint from Match Group that Google only allows its own payment system. The investigation, which could take years, comes after the Netherlands fined Apple 50 million euros for similar conditions. The watchdog is considering a further fine against Apple, and the investigation may be faster due to the similarities with Apple's case. Google's dominance in the global market, along with its restrictions on app developers using alternative payment systems, are being scrutinized.

site_title: Hong Kong raises benchmark rate again after US Fed tightens
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), raised its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points to 1.25% following the US Federal Reserve's move to hike rates for the second time this year. This decision aims to control inflation and maintain the peg of the Hong Kong dollar to the US currency. Local banks are unlikely to raise lending rates, as the economy remains under strain due to virus restrictions and trade disruptions, and there's ample liquidity in the banking system.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Wednesday announced its biggest rate hike since 2000, with a half percentage point increase as it works to crush soaring US inflation.
FILE PHOTO: A general view of Two International Finance Centre (IFC), HSBC headquarters and Bank of China in Hong Kong, China July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, Ascendas Reit, Lendlease Reit, YZJFH, ESR-Logos Reit
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 4.6% positive rental reversion in its first quarter, with a 92.6% portfolio occupancy rate, down from 93.2% in the previous quarter. ThaiBev resumed its proposed spin-off of BeerCo, with a public offering of up to 20% of BeerCo shares. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: SGX Centre along Shenton Way on Feb 24, 2022.

site_title: Oil jumps US$5 a barrel as EU nears ban on Russian oil
summary: Oil prices jumped $5 a barrel as the European Union announced plans to phase out imports of Russian oil, citing market tightness. The EU aims to ban Russian oil imports within six months and refined products by the end of 2022. However, some countries, like Hungary and Slovakia, will continue to buy Russian oil until 2023. Russia may offset the loss by selling to other importers like India and China, and OPEC+ is expected to stick to its plan for a gradual ramp-up of production.

site_title: Changi Airport passenger volume close to 40% of pre-pandemic levels as at end-April: Iswaran
summary: Changi Airport's passenger volume has more than doubled to reach around 40% of pre-Covid levels in April, up from 18% in March, according to Transport Minister S Iswaran. The airport aims to restore passenger volumes to at least 50% of pre-Covid levels by the end of this year. Singapore's Vaccinated Travel Framework, which allows quarantine-free entry for fully-vaccinated travelers, has been in place since April 26, contributing to the increase in passenger volume.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
New framework will allow vaccinated travellers to enter Singapore quarantine-free from Apr 1
No more tests for vaccinated travellers to Singapore from Apr 26
Singapore Airlines is gradually restoring basic pay for pilots, after cuts that were in effect since October 2020.

site_title: Football: Real fight back from the brink to stun Man City
summary: Real Madrid staged an incredible comeback to defeat Manchester City 3-1 in the Champions League semi-final, overturning a 5-3 aggregate deficit to reach the final. The Spanish team fought back from the brink of elimination after Riyad Mahrez scored for City in the 73rd minute, with Real substitutes Rodrygo and Karim Benzema equalizing in the 90th and 101st minutes, respectively. Benzema then scored the winning penalty in extra time, sending Real Madrid to a repeat of the 2018 final against Liverpool on May 28 in Paris.

images.alt_text: The jersey that Argentina football legend Diego Maradona wore when scoring twice against England in the 1986 World Cup, including the infamous “hand of God” goal, was auctioned for US$9.3 million, a record for any item of sports memorabilia, Sotheby’s said on Wednesday.

MIGRANT labourers are working through the night near the World Cup clock that will start counting down 200 days to kick-off on Thursday (May 5), with hosts Qatar facing mounting questions over costs and conditions for fans.

site_title:
Manhattan Resources appoints former StarHub CEO Tan Tong Hai as non-exec,
non-independent director
summary: Manhattan Resources has appointed Tan Tong Hai, former CEO of StarHub, as a non-executive, non-independent director. Tan will join the audit and executive committees, and his appointments will take effect from May 4. Tan holds a 1.33% stake in Manhattan Resources and has previous experience in various director roles, including Taiwan Mobile and Nanyang Polytechnic. The move aims to contribute positively to the company based on his qualifications and experiences.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: US businesses struggle to hire in April amid low unemployment
summary: US private businesses reported weaker hiring in April, with 247,000 jobs added, less than expected. This undershoot may foreshadow weak hiring overall in the US economy, where unemployment is near pre-Covid levels. Small businesses struggled with competition for wages, while large businesses added 321,000 jobs. Service providers made up the bulk of job gains, with leisure and hospitality adding 77,000 positions. Despite this, economists remain optimistic about Friday's jobs report, citing positive labor market trends and ongoing job growth.

images.alt_text: A worker oversee molten iron during cookware production at a factory in South Pittsburg, Tennessee.

site_title: Death toll climbs to five in central China building collapse
summary: A building collapse in Changsha, Hunan province, China, has raised the death toll to five, with dozens still missing. The commercial building, housing apartments, a hotel, and a cinema, collapsed on April 29, sparking a massive rescue effort. Rescuers have found 10 survivors, including a 12th person discovered conscious at midnight. Authorities suspect surveyors falsified a safety audit, and President Xi Jinping has ordered a thorough investigation. The incident highlights China's weak safety and construction standards, and building collapses are not uncommon in the country.

site_title: US Fed's half-point  hike biggest since 2000; Powell signals more to come in inflation battle
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, the largest hike since 2000, to combat soaring inflation. Chair Jerome Powell signaled more rate increases to bring inflation under control, aiming for a "soft landing" without tipping into a recession. Inflation has surged 8.5% over the past year, the highest in four decades, and policymakers remain confident the economy can withstand higher rates. The move is expected to cool demand and business activity, but analysts warn of uncertain global factors that could undermine the goal.

images.alt_text: A surge in imports of goods and services in March drove the US trade gap to the highest level ever recorded, with huge increases in purchases of autos, computers, furniture and clothing, the government reported on Wednesday.
US services industry growth unexpectedly slowed in April, with employment contracting for the second time this year, while a measure of input prices raced to a record high.

site_title: Japan PM: Russia responsible over bilateral ties after entry ban
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida stated he couldn't accept Russia's decision to ban him and 62 other Japanese citizens from entry into Russia, attributing the move to Russia's responsibility for driving bilateral ties to a low. This comes after Russia imposed sanctions on 63 Japanese officials, journalists, and professors for criticizing Moscow's actions in Ukraine. Kishida vowed to respond appropriately while cooperating with the international community.

site_title: Ebay deepens e-commerce gloom with disappointing forecast
summary: Ebay's second-quarter revenue forecast fell short of analyst expectations, with projected earnings between $2.35 billion and $2.40 billion, down 6% from the previous quarter. The company cited a return to pre-pandemic shopping habits, high inflation, and the impact of the Ukraine conflict as factors contributing to the slowdown. This marks the latest gloomy forecast from an e-commerce retailer, following Amazon and Etsy, and highlights the challenges facing the sector. Ebay's shares dropped 6% in extended trading following the announcement.

site_title: Uber continues recovery but loses US$5.6b from investments
summary: Uber reported strong growth in its ride-hailing and delivery businesses, with revenue reaching $6.9 billion in the first quarter of 2022, up 136% from the same period last year. The company logged 1.7 billion trips and had 115 million users, with CEO Dara Khosrowshahi attributing the growth to people returning to offices and travel after the pandemic. Despite this, Uber lost $5.6 billion due to investments in other companies, primarily Didi, which has seen its value plummet. The company is drawing closer to profitability, excluding certain expenses.

images.alt_text: UBER Technologies on Wednesday (May 4) beat expected operating earnings and forecast a strong second quarter, saying it had no need to offer extra incentives to boost its driver supply, unlike its smaller rival Lyft.

site_title: Brussels bronze for Hollywood's Hepburn
summary: A new bronze statue of Audrey Hepburn has been unveiled in Brussels, the Belgian capital where she was born. The statue, unveiled on May 4, 2022, is located in a park near the house where she was born. Hepburn, a Hollywood icon, was born Audrey Ruston on May 4, 1929, and spent her childhood in Brussels before moving to the Netherlands during World War II. The statue is the second in Brussels, following a previous version by Dutch sculptor Kees Berkade in Arnhem.

site_title: Russian cheesemaker to snap up idled PepsiCo juice business
summary: Russia's Federal Antimonopoly Service has approved the purchase of PepsiCo's Wimm-Bill-Dann Beverages by local cheesemaker Multipro, following PepsiCo's decision to sell the business last year. The US food giant had suspended sales of its sodas in Russia due to the country's invasion of Ukraine, but will retain ownership of a separate dairy business. The sale includes a production site that has not functioned since 2015, and the new owner will take over administrative buildings, storage, and production facilities.

site_title: Labour talks at US West Coast ports could further stress supply chains
summary: US West Coast ports are set to face further supply chain disruptions as labour talks to negotiate a new contract begin on May 12. The International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) has changed its stance on port automation, rejecting the ability for terminal operators to automate container handling. This could lead to work stoppages, causing congestion and delays at critical times, such as the early peak season. Market watchers expect negotiations to continue past the expiration of the existing contract, with the US President Joe Biden prioritizing a resolution to avoid supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: LHN expects at least S$34m in H1 2022 net profit before tax
summary: LHN Limited, a real estate management services provider, expects to record a higher net profit before tax of at least S$34 million for the first half of 2022, up from approximately S$18.3 million in the same period last year. The increase is mainly attributed to gains from subleases, fair-value gains on investment properties, and an increase in profit from its co-living business.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Maradona's 'hand of God' World Cup jersey auctioned for US$9.3m: Sotheby's
summary: Diego Maradona's iconic "hand of God" World Cup jersey from 1986 was auctioned for a record-breaking US$9.3 million by Sotheby's, surpassing the previous record of US$5.6 million for a game-worn jersey. The jersey, which Maradona wore during the World Cup match against England, was owned by Steve Hodge, who swapped it with Maradona after England's loss. Maradona's daughter had initially cast doubt on the authenticity of the jersey, but Sotheby's insisted it was the correct item.

images.alt_text: Big-ticket items go unsold in auction of Maradona assets

site_title: Porsche leads US$400 million investment in EV battery startup Group14
summary: Porsche has led a US$400 million investment in EV battery startup Group14, boosting the firm's valuation to over a billion dollars. The investment will be used to build a second battery materials factory in eastern Washington state. Group14's silicon-carbon anode material is expected to enable EV batteries to charge more quickly and hold more energy, reducing the overall cost and size of battery packs. The technology has been tested by battery makers and could charge to 80% capacity in 10 minutes, with potential for fast charging in as little as 5 minutes.

site_title: US service sector slows; input prices measure at record high - ISM survey
summary: The US services industry experienced a surprise slowdown in April, with employment contracting for the second time this year, while input prices reached a record high. The Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing activity index fell to 57.1 from 58.3 in March, indicating a slowdown in the services sector, which accounts for over two-thirds of US economic activity. This comes after a record trade deficit contributed to the economy's 1.4% annualized contraction in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: A worker oversee molten iron during cookware production at a factory in South Pittsburg, Tennessee.

site_title: Europe: Shares slammed by lacklustre earnings, Fed jitters
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.1% on Wednesday, weighed by disappointing earnings and investor jitters ahead of the US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike. Retailers, including Boohoo and Pandora, suffered significant losses, while Swedish builder Skanska fell 9.8% after posting a profit drop. Investors are on edge ahead of the Fed's policy decision, with some predicting a surge in volatility. Despite rising first-quarter earnings expectations, analysts warn that global economic growth momentum may be dampened by factors such as China's Covid-19 lockdowns and the Ukraine conflict.

images.alt_text: European stocks rose on Tuesday after a string of upbeat earnings.

site_title: Singapore O&G takeover bid closes with offeror controlling 93.3% interest
summary: A takeover bid for Singapore O&G closed on May 4, with NewMedCo Group controlling 93.3% of shares, including acceptances. The deal values the healthcare provider at around S$140.4 million. The offeror, linked to private equity player Dymon Asia, does not intend to preserve the company's listing status. The counter shed 5.1% on the day, trading at S$0.28, below the offer price.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore to offer Novavax jab under national vaccination programme by end-May
summary: Singapore will start offering the Novavax Covid-19 vaccine by end-May, with the vaccine approved for primary series and booster doses under the national vaccination programme. The vaccine, known as Nuvaxovid, will be available at 20 selected clinics and Singapore's first joint testing and vaccination centre, located at the former Bishan Park Secondary School. The Ministry of Health notes that Novavax is an acceptable alternative to mRNA vaccines, but mRNA vaccines remain the preferred choice due to higher efficacy. 92% of Singapore's population has completed a full vaccination regimen, with 74% receiving booster shots.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
HSA grants interim authorisation for Novavax's Nuvaxovid Covid-19 vaccine
Vaccine maker Moderna to incorporate Singapore subsidiary
Singapore to lift most pandemic curbs from Apr 26

site_title: India’s biggest IPO starts retail orders as markets stay volatile
summary: India's largest initial public offering (IPO) sold 67% of the issue on its first day, fetching 210 billion rupees (S$3.8 billion) with anchor investors including sovereign funds from Norway and Singapore. Retail investors can place orders until May 9, with the company valued at around 6 trillion rupees. The milestone deal is crucial for Prime Minister Narendra Modi to achieve his fiscal deficit target, amid market volatility.

images.alt_text: THE initial public offering (IPO) of Life Insurance Corporation (LIC), India’s biggest insurer, has got off to a strong start, with 59.3 million shares that were set aside for anchor investors being subscribed at 949 rupees apiece, according to an exchange filing on Tuesday (May 3).

site_title: Amara shareholders would have benefited from more detailed disclosures
summary: Amara Holdings, a property developer and hotel group, experienced a decline in its list of independent directors after a resolution to re-elect Tan Tiong Cheng as an ID failed at its annual general meeting (AGM) on Apr 26, with 77.7% of shares voting against. A resolution to grant directors authority to issue shares under the Amara Performance Share Plan also failed, with 77.1% of shares voting against. Amara has since stated that the issue with an immediate family member of an executive director is still under discussion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Following the AGM, a bourse notification of Tan’s cessation as a director indicated that there were unresolved differences in opinion on material matters between him and the board.
Property developer and hotelier Amara Holdings responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX-ST) on Thursday (Apr 28).

site_title: Ferrari opts for top power V12 engine for new Purosangue SUV
summary: Ferrari has confirmed its new Purosangue SUV will be powered by its top power V12 engine, a departure from the brand's recent focus on hybrid models. The decision was made after testing several options, with CEO Benedetto Vigna citing the engine's performance and driving experience as the deciding factor. The move marks a shift towards a more traditional approach as Ferrari navigates the transition to electric mobility, with plans for a full electric car in 2025.

site_title: World hunger 'exploding' after 25% spike before Ukraine war
summary: The global hunger crisis is "exploding" due to a 25% spike in food insecurity, with 193 million people across 53 countries facing acute food insecurity in 2021. The Ukraine war has disrupted harvests and exports, driving up food prices by 75% since mid-2020. The crisis is expected to worsen further this year, with projections indicating 180 million people will face hunger in 41 countries, an additional 5 million across the remaining 12 nations. The war has severe consequences on global food security, exacerbating existing crises in countries like Ethiopia and Afghanistan.

site_title: Dollar just off 20-year highs, rally hinges on Fed signals
summary: The US dollar index has retreated from 20-year highs, priced in by markets expecting a half-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve later in the day and 250 basis points by year-end. The dollar index had surged to 103.93 in April, but has since slipped 0.3% to 103.40. Analysts attribute the dollar's strength to hawkish market pricing and the Fed's expected rate hikes, which may also include reducing its $9 trillion balance sheet.

site_title: Opec+ set to stick to existing deal despite demand concerns
summary: OPEC+ is set to agree on a small increase in production targets for June, raising output by 432,000 barrels per day, despite concerns over demand growth due to China's lockdowns and sanctions on Russia's oil output. The decision comes as the European Union proposes a phased oil embargo on Russia, causing oil prices to jump over 4% to nearly $110 a barrel. OPEC+ expects a surplus of 1.9 million barrels per day in 2022, down from a previous forecast.

images.alt_text: Opec+ sees a surplus of 1.9 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2022, 600,000 bpd higher from a previous forecast, amid expectations of slower demand growth this year, a report seen by Reuters showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Qatar faces World Cup questions as 200-day countdown looms
summary: Qatar is 200 days away from hosting the World Cup, with concerns over costs and conditions for fans mounting. The country has built eight air-conditioned stadiums, but migrant workers face issues with living conditions, and fans worry about the cost of travel and accommodation. FIFA has promised a "best ever" World Cup, but critics say there are concerns over human rights, including for migrant workers and LGBTQ+ fans. Despite assurances, many fans remain uncertain about ticket prices and accommodation options, with some countries expressing concerns about the policing of issues such as alcohol consumption and LGBTQ+ symbols.

site_title: IMF urges Nepal to tighten monetary policy to bolster forex reserves
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Nepal to tighten its monetary policy to bolster its dwindling foreign exchange reserves, without resorting to import curbs that could harm economic growth. The country's foreign exchange reserves have fallen 18% to $9.6 billion, and annual retail inflation has hit a five-year high of 7.14%. The IMF recommends addressing inflationary pressures and external imbalances through a prudent budget and monetary tightening, which could help safeguard economic recovery.

site_title: US: Wall Street inches higher at open ahead of Fed decision
summary: US stock indexes rose at open on Wednesday, driven by positive earnings from companies like Starbucks and Advanced Micro Devices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 43.01 points, or 0.13%, to 33,171.80. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 rising 5.70 points, or 0.14%, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 10.97 points, or 0.09%. Investors are bracing for the biggest US interest rate hike since May 2000.

site_title: Treasury cuts quarterly debt sale, may do so again even with Fed's quantitative tightening
summary: The US Treasury reduced its quarterly sale of longer-term debt for the third consecutive time, citing "strong" federal tax revenues. The reduction, to $103 billion, is expected to continue, with further cuts possible, despite the Federal Reserve's quantitative tightening plan. The Treasury aims to stabilize the share of inflation-linked debt and increase transparency in the trading of Treasury securities. The reduction in debt sales is seen as a positive sign for the US economy, with the Treasury well-positioned to meet future borrowing needs.

images.alt_text: THE US economy is expected to continue its expansion this year despite a surprise contraction in the first quarter, the US Treasury’s chief economist said on Monday (May 2), adding that inflation may be peaking.

site_title: Theatre hits the streets
summary: Theatre companies in Singapore are experimenting with "walking theatre" by staging plays in outdoor locations such as parks and forests. The genre has gained popularity since the pandemic, offering a unique way to appreciate the performing arts. Local theatre groups like Singapore Repertory Theatre, DramaBox, and Sight Line are leading the way, utilizing the island's natural scenery as backdrops. This new approach aims to capture new audiences and provide a fresh experience for drama enthusiasts.

site_title: Privacy concerns around CBDCs are misplaced
summary: A central bank digital currency (CBDC) is not an instrument of state surveillance, contrary to concerns raised by the UK House of Lords Committee and a European Union consultation paper. Citizens' transactions can be monitored in real-time by banks, and there is a framework balancing individual rights of privacy with authorities' needs for transparency. While some countries may have more restrictive views on citizens' rights, this is an intrinsic feature of their political system, not the CBDC. The threat posed by a CBDC is marginal compared to the pervasive intrusions into private spaces through CCTV cameras and other means.

images.alt_text: How central banks are moving into e-money

site_title: Singapore factory sentiment picks up in April, but cost, supply woes loom
summary: Singapore's factory activity bounced back in April, with headline readings rising to 50.3 points, up from 50.1 in March, according to the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management. The electronics industry saw a similar increase to 50.7 points. Despite the rebound, input prices continued to climb due to supply crunches and cost pressures. The expansionary sentiment remains, but concerns about industry woes persist.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

Industrial production (IP) last month slowed to 3.4 per cent year on year dragged by the biomedical cluster, following a 17.5 per cent jump in February, according to data from the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) on Tuesday (Apr 26).
China slowdown threatens trade growth as Singapore exports ease for 4th straight month in March
The services industries face an upside bias as the economy normalises, said UOB economist Barnabas Gan.

site_title: Kremlin dismisses speculation Putin to declare war on Ukraine on May 9
summary: The Kremlin has dismissed speculation that President Vladimir Putin plans to declare war against Ukraine on May 9, when Russia commemorates the Soviet Union's victory in World War II. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov stated there is "no chance" of such an announcement, calling it "nonsense." Putin has characterized Russia's actions in Ukraine as a "special military operation," not a war, amid ongoing tensions between Russia and the West over the conflict.

images.alt_text: epa09916521 Russian President Vladimir Putin chairs a meeting with members of the Russia's Security Council via a video conference at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia, 29 April 2022.  EPA-EFE/MIKHAIL KLIMENTYEV / KREMLIN POOL / SPUTNIK / POOL MANDATORY CREDIT

site_title: HSBC, Ping An executives to discuss breakup  proposal in mid-May
summary: HSBC and Ping An executives are set to meet in mid-May to discuss a potential breakup proposal by the Chinese insurer, which could involve spinning off the bank's Asian business. Ping An, the largest shareholder of HSBC, has suggested exploring strategic options to boost returns, amid growing geopolitical tensions between the West and China. The proposal has sparked concerns among investors, who question the feasibility of a split and its potential impact on the bank's value.

images.alt_text: SHARES in HSBC Holdings edged up in Hong Kong trade on Tuesday (May 3) after its largest shareholder, Chinese insurance giant Ping An, called for a break-up of the London-based bank.

site_title: Moderna sees higher Covid vaccine sales in second half of 2022
summary: Moderna posted nearly US$6 billion in sales of its Covid-19 vaccine in the first quarter, exceeding expectations. The company expects higher sales in the second half of 2022 than in the first six months. Despite this, Moderna maintains its full-year sales forecast of US$21 billion. The company's shares rose 5.4% following the announcement, driven by its mRNA-based vaccine technology and recent authorization for a second booster dose in the US.

site_title: 38 local brands receive Singapore Prestige Brand Award
summary: Thirty-eight Singaporean brands received the prestigious Singapore Prestige Brand Award, recognizing their effective and forward-looking branding efforts. The winners include 31 first-time recipients and are setting the pace for innovation and transformation. The award categories include Promising Brands, Established Brands, Heritage Brands, and a Special Merit award. Overall winners include elemen, a vegetarian restaurant chain, and Mulberry Learning, a preschool education service provider, while ECON Healthcare, a healthcare operator, emerged as the overall winner in the Heritage Brands category.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
37 local brands honoured at Singapore Prestige Brand Award 2020/21

site_title: Cisco unveils technology to predict network issues
summary: Cisco Systems unveiled a predictive technology to forecast network issues, enabling proactive prevention and increased reliability. The software engine gathers data from various sources, learning patterns to identify potential hardware issues, bandwidth spikes, and app configuration changes. Cisco tested the technology with 15 customers, including Phillips 66 and Schneider Electric, and plans to announce initial integrations at its Cisco Live conference in June. This proactive approach aims to improve user experience by detecting and resolving issues before they occur, according to CEO Chuck Robbins.

site_title: Volkswagen trains sights on US as profits jump
summary: Volkswagen's first-quarter net profit nearly doubled to €6.7 billion, driven by a resurgence in the North American market. The German automaker aims to more than double its market share in the region to 10% by 2030. Despite supply chain disruptions, Volkswagen showed "resilience" and was able to supply US and Chinese factories with unused semiconductors. The company plans to invest $7.1 billion in its North American production facilities and is focusing on battery-powered vehicles.

images.alt_text: VOLKSWAGEN (VW) is considering an expansion of its Chattanooga plant in the United States to produce an electric pick-up and the new ID.Buzz microbus, a source close to the matter told Reuters on Thursday (Apr 28)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.23% ahead of the FOMC decision on a rate hike. Temasek Holdings expects Chinese growth to rebound in the second half due to government stimulus. No Signboard Holdings terminated loan agreements with Q&M CEO and private investor. Grab is seen having an advantage in Malaysia's digital bank space, according to Maybank. Companies in the Chinese Internet space may gain clarity on policy in the coming months.

images.alt_text: A GrabFood delivery man walking past the company logo in the new Grab office at Marina One West Tower on May 28, 2018. Ride-hailing app Grab holds a media briefing to share about its plans and direction.

site_title: US trade deficit hits highest on record as imports soar
summary: The US trade deficit reached its highest level ever recorded, with a surge in imports of goods and services in March, driven by increases in purchases of autos, computers, furniture, and clothing. The deficit jumped 22% to $109.8 billion, with imports reaching a record $351.5 billion, outpacing modest export gains. Strong consumer demand and global supply chain snarls are expected to support continued import growth, while slower recoveries among US trading partners may hold down export growth.

images.alt_text: THE US economy is expected to continue its expansion this year despite a surprise contraction in the first quarter, the US Treasury’s chief economist said on Monday (May 2), adding that inflation may be peaking.

site_title: Uber says doesn't need to pay drivers more, forecasts profit ahead of Wall Street
summary: Uber Technologies reported beating expected operating earnings and forecasting a strong second quarter, despite not needing to offer extra incentives to boost driver supply, unlike rival Lyft. This comes after Lyft's shares sank 26% on Tuesday due to its need to pay more to attract drivers. Uber's shares were down 2.1% in pre-market trading, but the company's results brought forward from the afternoon.

site_title: China's PBOC pledges policy support to counter pandemic woes
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), pledged monetary policy support to counter the impact of the latest Covid-19 outbreak on the economy. The PBOC aims to ensure ample liquidity, help businesses affected by the outbreak, and support a recovery in consumption. The decision follows a top Communist Party decision-making body's vow to support the economy last week. The PBOC vowed to provide a fair monetary and financial environment to promote steady economic growth, stabilize employment, and prices.

site_title: Sembcorp bags S$1.2 billion green loan for corporate needs, sustainability projects
summary: Sembcorp Industries secured a S$1.2 billion sustainability-linked loan to support its "brown-to-green" transformation strategy. The 5-year loan is tied to sustainability performance targets and brings Sembcorp's green and sustainable financing to S$2.9 billion. This is the company's first and largest syndicated sustainability-linked loan facility, based on the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora). The loan is part of Sembcorp's efforts to reduce its environmental impact and align with its green financing framework.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
The road to net zero for corporate Singapore
Sembcorp furthers green pivot with latest acquisition in China; observers say risks present but surmountable

site_title: Maersk in talks with buyers for stake as quits Russia
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipper, is selling its 30.75% stake in Global Ports Investments, which operates ports in Russia, following its decision to quit the country due to the invasion of Ukraine. The company booked $718 million in impairment losses and writedowns due to the invasion. Maersk's CEO stated that the company will not return to Russia until it plays a constructive role in the world. Talks with potential buyers are underway, and the company does not expect to give up the stake.

site_title: EU plans phased oil ban on Russia, also targeting more banks
summary: The European Union is proposing a phased oil embargo on Russia, with a complete ban on all Russian oil imports by the end of 2022. The EU's President Ursula von der Leyen also plans to sanction Russia's top bank, Sberbank, and ban Russian broadcasters from European airwaves. The measures aim to deepen Moscow's isolation and address the EU's dependency on Russian energy. The proposals need approval from EU governments, with diplomats expecting a longer period for Hungary and Slovakia to stop oil imports due to their heavy reliance on Russian energy.

images.alt_text: THE European Union was preparing sanctions on Russian oil sales after a major shift on Monday (May 2) by Germany, Russia’s biggest energy customer, that could deprive Moscow of a large revenue stream within days.
India is trying to get deeper discounts on Russian oil to compensate for the risk of dealing with the Opec+ producer as other buyers turn away.

The Opec cartel - which has struggled for many months to revive oil supplies halted during the pandemic - effectively failed to increase output at all last month, as members remained plagued by capacity constraints.

site_title: Jim Ratcliffe's late Chelsea FC offer 'rejected out of hand'
summary: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe's £4.25 billion bid for Chelsea FC has been rejected by Raine Group, the US bank running the sale. Despite this, Ratcliffe's Ineos Group will continue to pursue the club, citing more "sensible" numbers. The bid comes as former Guggenheim Partners president Todd Boehly is the frontrunner for Chelsea, which is being sold by Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich. Chelsea is currently operating under a special UK government licence that expires on May 31. Ratcliffe's camp has engaged with the Chelsea Supporters' Trust, seeking to build momentum for his offer.

site_title: Duran Duran, Eminem, Dolly Parton among 2022 Rock Hall inductees
summary: Duran Duran, Eminem, Dolly Parton, Pat Benatar, Eurythmics, Lionel Richie, and Carly Simon were inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2022. Eminem, known for his controversy, expanded hip-hop's popularity, while Duran Duran's hits like "Rio" and "Girls on Film" defined the 1980s. Dolly Parton, despite initial hesitation, accepted the honor, joining previous inductees like country stars Hank Williams and Johnny Cash. The inductees were chosen through a combination of artist and historian ballots, as well as public votes.

site_title: Airbus may delay new jet to 2024 amid regulator talks over design
summary: Airbus may delay the development of its A321XLR jet to 2024 due to European regulator talks over design changes aimed at containing potential fire risks. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) is considering imposing significant changes to the plane's lower structure, which could add 6-9 months to the development timeline. The certification talks surround the question of whether extra protections are needed in the event of a crash.

site_title: Banker John d'Abo among 3 directors appointed in Rex International's board renewal
summary: Banker John d'Abo has joined Rex International as an independent director, along with accountant Mae Heng, who chairs the audit committee. The appointments, made as part of the company's board renewal, aim to enhance the board's diversity and strengths. Mathias Lidgren, a non-independent director with a 0.54% stake in the company, also joined the board. The new appointments are expected to guide the group in business sustainability, strategic direction, and growth, according to executive chairman Dan Broström.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Rex cranks up production volume
Rex International's unit to acquire 2 North Sea oil and gas licences
Rex International gets in-principle go-ahead to move to SGX mainboard

site_title: Vitol sends first shipment of Russian ESPO crude cargo to UAE, data shows
summary: Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trader, has loaded its first shipment of Russian ESPO Blend crude to the UAE, marking the first such voyage for the grade. The 740,000-barrel cargo is bound for the port of Fujairah, where it will be discharged in late May or early June. Vitol may supply the crude to its own refinery in Fujairah, taking advantage of the emirate's strategic location. The shipment is seen as a "creative" move, given the high spot discount required to make it work.

site_title: Climbing gyms reach new heights, but could hit a wall
summary: Singapore's indoor rock-climbing industry has experienced significant growth over the past two years, with an estimated 31 commercial climbing gyms now operating in the city-state, up from 13 in 2018. The rise in popularity can be attributed to the increased accessibility to climbing gyms, with many businesses taking up leases in shopping malls. Bouldering, a form of climbing without ropes or harnesses, has also gained popularity, with at least 7 new bouldering gyms opening since 2021. Industry players report brisk business and expansion plans, with some gyms offering amenities such as cafes and competition walls to differentiate themselves from competitors.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
plclimb5 - Wall building company Urban Ninja has seen a 50 per cent increase in interest in home climbing walls in the last 2 years, with over 35 enquiries since 2021, said owner Ivan Toh.

site_title: Leadership lessons from great CEOs
summary: A study of 200 top CEOs worldwide found that great leaders prioritize preparing themselves, surrounding themselves with diverse teams, and focusing on service. Despite their success, half of CEOs feel unprepared for the role, and many emphasize the importance of managing themselves to handle the demands of the job. Effective CEOs also demonstrate humility, groundedness, and a clear agenda, while being open and honest with their boards and stakeholders. These principles can be applied broadly to those working their way up the corporate ladder, and Singapore's focus on CEO leadership development aims to enhance its regional competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Maintaining humanity and purpose in a world digitally transformed

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.10% on May 4, 2022, in line with a broader Asia sell-off ahead of the expected Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Hang Seng Index closed at 20,869.52.

images.alt_text: The flags of China, right, and the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) fly near an electronic screen displaying the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, March 15, 2022. Chinese stocks suffered another deep selloff on Tuesday as concerns about the country’s ties with Russia and persistent regulatory pressure sent shares on a downward spiral. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: STI dips 0.23% ahead of FOMC rate move
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, snapping a two-day winning streak, ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee's rate decision. The Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 7.63 points to 3,349.27, with muted trading due to the 2-day public holiday break and anticipation of the FOMC's move. Markets have largely priced in a 50 basis point rate hike, and analysts expect further rate hikes in June, July, and September, with the Fed's statement and forward guidance being key to shaping market expectations.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
SGX Centre along Shenton Way on Feb 24, 2022.
Singapore stocks rose slightly in early trade on Wednesday tracking overnight gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Ascendas Reit posts 4.6% rental reversion in Q1 2022, expects positive low single-digit figure for full year
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 4.6% positive rental reversion in Q1 2022, with a portfolio occupancy of 92.6%. The Reit expects a positive low single-digit rental reversion for FY2022 due to market uncertainties. The company's Australian portfolio saw a 2% decline in occupancy to 96.8%, while the US portfolio remained stable at 94%. Leasing activity for business space properties in the US is expected to remain slow. Despite market uncertainties, the Reit's diversified portfolio and A3 Moody's credit rating are expected to help it withstand economic shocks and continue to grow.

SP Group to invest S$40-60m in new district cooling system

site_title: Global banks’ profits dented by China’s zero-Covid stance
summary: Global banks' profits have been dented by China's strict zero-Covid policy stance and "common prosperity" drive, according to official figures. The lockdowns and travel curbs have taken a toll on businesses and residents, with China's economy estimated to have lost about half its Western expatriates since Covid-19 started. Manufacturing and services sectors fell to their lowest points in over two years, with China's economy on course to decelerate to below 2% growth in the second quarter. Global banks, including UBS, Credit Suisse, and HSBC, have reported lower regional profits due to the restrictions.

site_title: India central bank raises key repo rate by 40 bps in off-cycle move
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised its key lending rate by 40 basis points to 4.40% on May 4, citing persistent inflationary pressures in the economy. The decision was made by the RBI's monetary policy committee (MPC), led by governor Shaktikanta Das. The move aims to curb inflation, which has been a concern for the Indian economy. The RBI's 10-Year benchmark bond yield rose to 7.41% following the rate hike.

site_title: The boulder, the better: More demand for home climbing walls
summary: Home climbing walls have gained popularity in Singapore, with a 50% increase in interest over the last two years, according to Urban Ninja, a wall building company. Over 35 enquiries have been received since 2021, with 21 home climbing walls built since then. Companies like Movement First have built about 10 home climbing walls for children since 2020, citing concerns over height limitations, weight loading, and safety. Home climbing walls are sought after by hardcore climbers, parents, and owners who want to hone their skills at home before visiting commercial gyms.

site_title: 5 Questions with VC venturer Helen Wong
summary: Venture capitalist Helen Wong shares her journey in China tech, having worked with high-profile investors GGV Capital and Qiming Venture Partners. She began her career in investment banking and later transitioned to VC after working in Silicon Valley. Wong has over 20 years of investment experience, advising companies on strategy, fundraising, and HR issues. Despite setbacks, she emphasizes the importance of trusting one's instinct and believing in oneself. Wong currently serves as a senior adviser and venture partner at AC Ventures, an Indonesia-focused early-stage fund.

site_title: Beyond diversity targets, companies' strategic plans are also helpful disclosures: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock's managing director Shinbo Won emphasizes that diversity targets should align with a company's ability to generate financial returns, rather than solely focusing on diversity. He suggests that investors should look for disclosures on strategic factors that impact financial performance, such as board skillsets, risks, and opportunities. This approach prioritizes the financial capabilities of the company over diversity targets alone, highlighting the importance of a company's financial returns over time.

site_title: Singapore landed homes see fastest price appreciation in a decade in 2021: ERA
summary: Singapore's landed homes saw the fastest price appreciation in a decade in 2021, with a 13.3% year-on-year surge. This surpassed the 1.2% growth in 2020. ERA Realty Network predicts 9-15% price appreciation for landed homes in 2022 due to rising demand and limited supply. In the first 3 months of 2022, landed housing prices expanded by 4.2% quarter-on-quarter. ERA expects 95% of transacted landed housing units to be resale homes, with rental rates potentially rising 10-16% this year.

Price growth of private homes slows in Q1 after cooling measures, even as levels hit new high

site_title: Oil jumps 3% as EU plans ban on Russian oil
summary: Oil prices surged 3% on Wednesday as the European Union proposed a phased ban on Russian oil imports, offsetting concerns about demand in top importer China. The EU's plan, which includes phasing out Russian crude within six months and refined products by end-2022, aims to deepen Moscow's isolation. Oil prices rose to $107.91 a barrel for Brent crude and $105.43 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate crude, amid thin trading volume and anticipation of US interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The Commission’s measures include phasing out supplies of Russian crude oil within 6 months and refined products by the end of 2022, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said.

site_title: Manulife US Reit promotes deputy CEO in succession planning move
summary: Manulife US Reit is promoting its deputy CEO, William David Gantt III, to the top job, succeeding outgoing CEO Jillian Smith, who is retiring as part of succession planning. Gantt, 52, joined the Reit in February 2022 and has professional qualifications and experience, according to the board. Smith, 68, has held the post since July 2015, and there are no unresolved differences in opinion between her and the directors, the board stated. The move aims to ensure continuity and stability for the Reit.

US office S-Reits set for continued growth with the return to office

site_title: Opec+ sees bigger 2022 surplus amid slower demand growth
summary: Opec+ expects a surplus of 1.9 million barrels per day in 2022, 600,000 bpd higher than a previous forecast, due to slower demand growth. This revision reflects a weaker oil demand growth forecast adopted by Opec in its April oil monthly report. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) also sees OECD oil stocks slightly exceeding the 2015-2019 average in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Private-debt risks are hiding in plain sight
summary: Emergency moratoria have ended, leaving vulnerable households and businesses with unaffordable loan repayments. The Covid-19 pandemic's uneven recovery has exacerbated existing private-debt risks, with per capita income reaching new highs in 37% of advanced economies, 27% of middle-income countries, and under 21% of low-income countries. As a result, countries are pushing toward similar crises, with the ongoing war in Ukraine further exacerbating economic disruptions.

images.alt_text: A food stall in front of commercial buildings in downtown Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, April 18, 2022. Sri Lanka has been thrust into uncertainty as protesters angered by sky-high inflation and lengthy power cuts called for the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his brother, Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. Photographer: Buddhika Weerasinghe/Bloomberg

site_title: Volvo Cars reports 25% sales drop in April as lockdowns, supply woes weigh
summary: Volvo Cars reported a 24.8% drop in April sales, primarily due to lockdowns in China and global supply chain issues. Demand remained strong, with the share of fully electric cars rising to 10%. Sales declined 47.8% in China, 9.2% in the US, and 23.2% in Europe. Despite the challenges, Volvo forecast-beat profits last week, citing higher costs due to the war in Ukraine and a global semiconductor shortage. The company aims to reach 50% of its sales as electric cars by the middle of this decade.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS cautious of ongoing headwinds for Micro-Mechanics, downgrades to 'hold'
summary: DBS downgraded Micro-Mechanics Holdings to "hold" from "buy", cutting its target price to S$3.42 from S$4.05 due to ongoing headwinds including higher raw material prices and risks in US and China operations. DBS trimmed its FY2022-23 earnings forecasts by 12-15% and adjusted revenue estimates downwards, with a revised net profit margin projection of around 22%. The group has a sound financial position with S$15 million in cash and no bank borrowings.

images.alt_text: SEMICONDUCTOR play Micro-Mechanics (Holdings) posted a 5.8 per cent rise in net profit to S$4.4 million for its third quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, from S$4.2 million a year ago.

site_title: Singapore companies in Malaysia do not expect big hit from minimum wage hike
summary: Singapore-based companies operating in Malaysia are unlikely to experience significant financial impact from the country's 25% minimum wage hike to RM1,500. Many workers are already earning above the threshold, and companies have been offering higher salaries to attract talent. While some companies, such as Aspen Holdings, anticipate increased costs, they expect these to be offset by other cost pressures and may need to pass on costs to consumers. Others, like Enviro-Hub and Riverstone Holdings, are implementing cost-saving measures, including automation, to mitigate the impact of the wage increase.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Malaysia companies to partially pass on higher wage costs to consumers: CGS-CIMB

site_title: Boxer battles poverty, misogyny to be Vietnam's first world champion
summary: Vietnam's 25-year-old boxer Nguyen Thi Thu Nhi has become the country's first world boxing champion, claiming the World Boxing Organization mini-flyweight belt in her fifth professional fight. Born into poverty, Nhi overcame sexist prejudice and struggled to find time for training amidst a tough upbringing. She credits boxing with transforming her life, earning a stable income and paving the way for her goal of saving enough to afford a house. Nhi faces a crossroads in her career, balancing professional bouts with amateur events, but remains determined to succeed.

site_title: Please don't croak: Scientists set mood to save Venezuelan frog
summary: Scientists in Venezuela have launched a breeding project to save the critically endangered Mucuchies Frog, which has lost 98% of its habitat due to deforestation. The project, led by biologist Enrique La Marca, has successfully released over 100 young frogs into the wild, nearly doubling the known population. The frogs require a specific environment, including plants, rocks, and simulated streams, and are fed a diet of insects and larvae. The project aims to increase the frog's population and help the species survive in the wild.

images.alt_text: A fossilised cervical vertebra of Maip macrothorax, the newly identified megaraptor dinosaur that inhabited the Argentinian Patagonian.

site_title: Grab may have advantage over other players in Malaysia digital bank space: Maybank
summary: Maybank predicts Grab has an advantage in Malaysia's digital bank space due to its largest e-wallet market share, allowing for better data analysis and risk management. Grab and Sea Limited, the parent company of Shopee, are seen as winners in the digital financial sector, with a strong e-wallet proposition and a gateway for new financial services adoption. However, immediate growth is expected to be small, with near-term constraints, before lifting after 3-5 years.

site_title: Securing Singapore’s supply chain for the future
summary: Singapore's reliance on trade and heavy reliance on supply chains necessitate regional cooperation to transform and make them more resilient. Despite a KPMG survey showing over three-quarters of Singapore's business leaders admitting their supply chains were under stress, fewer than half had implemented deep monitoring capabilities or diversified their sources. The government can catalyze cooperation between countries and enterprises by creating structures and platforms for data sharing, leveraging resources, and exchanging best practices. This can be achieved through free trade agreements and cognitive decision centers, enabling real-time data sharing and predictive supply chain tools to improve decision-making and agility in the face of disruptions.

images.alt_text: PHOTO: Tackling crippling supply chain challenges would require businesses to shift away from existing models that relied on lean inventories and just-in-time delivery.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall ahead of Fed decision; bond yield hits 8-year high
summary: South Korean stocks fell for a third straight session on May 4 as investors exercised caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision. The Kospi index closed down 0.11% at 2,677.57, while the benchmark bond yield rose to an 8-year high. The Fed is expected to hike rates aggressively to curb inflation, and South Korea's financial markets will be closed on Thursday for a local holiday. Foreigners were net buyers of 32.7 billion won worth of shares, and the won strengthened against the dollar.

images.alt_text: SOUTH Korean shares traded nearly flat on Tuesday (May 3) with investors taking a breather ahead of the US Federal Reserves’ monetary policy meeting, while neighbouring Asian markets were closed for holidays.

site_title: Soft power after Ukraine
summary: The article discusses the concept of soft power in international politics, particularly in the context of the Ukraine conflict. Despite the initial dominance of hard military power, soft power has already played a significant role in the conflict. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has successfully represented his country as an attractive and heroic nation through his informal attire and constant communication with Western media and parliaments. This has led to increased deliveries of military equipment and Western sympathy for Ukraine. Meanwhile, Russia's atrocities against civilians have reduced its soft power, while countries like China and India have refrained from criticizing Russia due to strategic interests.

images.alt_text: Big brands and oil ban punish Russia as Moscow makes new pledge on Ukraine refugees

site_title: Rocky ride ahead for Norway's US$1.2 trillion wealth fund
summary: Norway's $1.2 trillion sovereign wealth fund is bracing for a "rocky ride" amid significant geopolitical changes, its CEO Nicolai Tangen said. The fund faces growing frictions between superpowers, a potential reversal of globalization, and increased risk of stagflation, which could lead to a 40% decline in its value. Tangen warned that inflation is rising, interest rates remain low, and share prices are high, making it challenging to manage risk. The fund has already divested its Russian assets and is cautious about investing in renewables due to fierce competition.

images.alt_text: Australia's A$201 billion (S$197.7 billion) sovereign wealth fund plans to seek more local investments and trim exposure to listed companies as geopolitical tensions rise and markets get jittery over rate hikes.

site_title: Asia-Pacific sees US$911m net flows into sustainable funds in Q1: Morningstar
summary: Asia-Pacific saw a surge in US$911 million in net flows into sustainable funds in Q1 2022, with Taiwan and South Korea leading the way. This marked a significant increase from the US$34 million in net inflows in Q4 2021. The region's total sustainable fund assets held steady at US$71 billion, with equities representing 58% of assets and allocation funds comprising 37%. Despite a global slowdown, sustainable funds in Asia-Pacific outperformed the broader market, with most regions experiencing a slump in inflows except for Canada and Asia ex-Japan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open before Fed
summary: European stocks wavered on May 4, with London's FTSE 100 dipping 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX rising 0.2%. The Federal Reserve is expected to deliver its largest interest rate hike in over 20 years, aiming to combat inflation. Analysts predict a 50 basis point rate hike, which is the largest since 2000. The move is seen as a response to soaring inflation, with the Fed seeking to bring it down swiftly.

site_title: Hot stock: Dyna-Mac jumps as much as 17.1% on new contract win
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings' shares jumped 17.1% to a high of S$0.144 on May 4 after the company announced a S$180 million contract win from a long-time repeat customer, bringing its net order book to a record high of S$641.1 million. The new order win pushes deliveries into 2024, with the counter reaching a 2-year high of S$0.138 on April 27.

site_title: Recovery for some Asia-Pacific aviation players is taking off
summary: Asia-Pacific's aviation sector is recovering from the pandemic-induced slump, with many airlines and airports ramping up resources and rehiring to meet growing demand. Passenger traffic is soaring, driven by travel-starved corporate and leisure travelers. Some countries, like Singapore, are on track to restore at least 50% of pre-Covid airport traffic this year. However, airports and airlines are struggling to cope with the surge in travelers, with long queues and flight disruptions expected to persist. Experts predict that airfares will eventually stabilize as demand normalizes and airlines add more capacity.
