site_title: AIG profit beats estimates on strong underwriting gains
summary: American International Group (AIG) reported a nearly 17% rise in quarterly profit, topping market estimates, driven by strong underwriting gains and lower catastrophe losses. The company's gross premiums written rose 7% to $11.51 billion in the first quarter. AIG's results come as the insurance industry faces significant claims from the ongoing war in Ukraine.

site_title: All in the family: Philippine dynasties tighten grip on power
summary: The Philippines is facing a strong grip of elite families in power, with dynasties holding key positions for generations through favoritism, buying votes, or violence. Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr., the son of former dictator Ferdinand Marcos, is on the verge of winning the presidency, solidifying his family's hold on power. Analysts say the system has become more entrenched since the Marcos family was ousted in a popular uprising, stifling electoral competition and exacerbating inequality. Over 319 dynastic families have produced leaders in the country, with many holding multiple positions.

images.alt_text: THE Philippines' poll body on Wednesday (Apr 20) cleared a major legal hurdle in frontrunner Ferdinand Marcos Jr's path to the presidency when it dismissed the final petition calling for his disqualification from the May 9 election.

site_title: Biogen CEO to step down; drugmaker pulls back on Alzheimer's drug Aduhelm
summary: Biogen CEO Michel Vounatsos is stepping down amid the company's decision to substantially eliminate commercial infrastructure for its Alzheimer's drug Aduhelm, citing reduced sales potential. The US government's Medicare program severely limited Aduhelm's access, casting doubt on its sales. Biogen also plans to cut costs, saving US$500 million annually, as it pulls back on selling the drug. The move appears to be a final blow to Aduhelm's prospects as a blockbuster treatment.

images.alt_text: Biogen said the withdrawal follows interactions with the European Medicines Agency that suggested data provided so far would not be enough to support an approval.
Biogen says US FTC, SEC probing Alzheimer's disease drug

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH initiates coverage on AEM with ‘buy’
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) initiated coverage on AEM Holdings with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$5.60, valuing the company at 15.6 times its FY2022 earnings. The research team expects a "strong and sustained rebound" driven by Intel's aggressive capital expenditure and AEM's acquisition of component manufacturer CEI, leading to potential upside of 15.7% from the current share price.

images.alt_text: AEM Holdings records 47% higher H2 profit; proposes S$0.05 final dividend

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a 0.36% loss, easing 76.19 points to 21,025.70, following a mild positive lead from Wall Street ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate hike decision.

site_title: Hugo Boss sticks to 2022 outlook despite Covid restrictions, Ukraine war
summary: Hugo Boss reaffirmed its 2022 sales and profit outlook despite the ongoing Ukraine war and Covid-19 restrictions in China. The luxury fashion house reported a 52% growth in currency-adjusted group sales to €772 million (S$1.1 billion) in the first quarter, driven by momentum in the Americas and Europe. Hugo Boss expects 2022 sales to grow up to 15% and operating profit to rise up to 25%.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang Financial extends fall for third day after lacklustre trading debut
summary: Shares of Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH) plummeted for the third consecutive day, falling 16.5% to S$0.455 after its lackluster trading debut on April 28. The company, spun off from Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, initially closed at S$0.62, representing a 43% discount to its net tangible asset per share. Its shares have recovered slightly but remain down 14.7% from its opening price of S$0.69.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Vincent Toe, CEO, Yangzijiang Financial Holding said the group's offshore investment will go from zero to 20 per cent by 2023.
Immediately prior to the investment unit spin-off, YZJ Shipbuilding had a market capitalisation of around S$6.1 billion – ranking it as the 22nd-largest STI counter, according to Bloomberg data.
Vincent Toe is ceo of Yangzijiang Financial Holding.
Following the listing of YZJFH, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding will remain on the STI at an unchanged investable weight.

site_title: Maersk lost more than US$700m from Russia but posts new record profit in Q1
summary: AP Moller Maersk lost over $700 million in the first quarter due to the war in Ukraine, mainly from losses related to its terminals. The company stopped taking new cargo to Russia and put its Russian assets up for sale. Despite this, Maersk posted a record profit of $6.8 billion, more than doubling its previous quarterly high, driven by a 55% jump in sales. The company expects to regain some losses as it divests its Russian assets in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: SHIPPING group Maersk , often seen as a barometer for global trade, on Tuesday (Apr 26) cautioned the container market may normalise in the second half of the year, even as it raised full-year guidance driven by high container freight rates.

site_title: Shanghai residents turn to NFTs to record Covid lockdown, combat censorship
summary: Shanghai residents are using non-fungible tokens (NFTs) to preserve memories of the city's Covid-19 lockdown, which lasted for a month, and evade censorship. They are minting videos, photos, and artworks into NFTs, which can be shared and stored on the blockchain, making them unerasable. This has been done in response to the Chinese government's efforts to police the internet and suppress rumors about the lockdown. As of May 2, over 786 NFTs related to the lockdown have been created and shared on NFT marketplace OpenSea.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Venture Corp’s recovery amid upbeat outlook
summary: Venture Corporation posted a 28.6% increase in net profit to S$84 million in its first quarter, beating estimates. Analysts are positive on the company's steady demand outlook, citing growth momentum and order visibility. Phillip Securities Research upgraded its call to "buy" and raised its target price to S$20, while DBS Group Research lifted its target price to S$22.70. Despite concerns over supply chain disruptions and inflation, analysts expect Venture to recover towards pre-Covid levels in FY2022, with a "buy" call and target prices ranging from S$20 to S$22.80.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Venture Corp to halt Shanghai operations temporarily, sees no significant impact to business
Brokers' take: Analysts positive on Venture Corp's growth outlook for FY2022
Earnings per share climbed to 28.8 Singapore cents, from 22.4 cents a year ago.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 2.33 points to 3,359.23, with Golden Agri-Resources rising 1.5% and DBS trading 1% higher. Banking stocks also rose, while telecommunications and property trusts fell. The gains followed a choppy US session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% and the S&P 500 climbing 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Agribusiness giant Wilmar International saw its net profit climb 17.8 per cent to US$530.3 million for the first quarter ended March, on the back of firm palm oil prices

site_title: Housing starts in Canada's large cities lag population growth
summary: Housing starts in Canada's large cities, particularly Toronto, are struggling to keep pace with population growth, exacerbating affordability issues. The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) reports that Toronto, Montreal, and Ottawa have the lowest levels of residential construction per capita. Despite high overall housing starts in 2021, Toronto's gap between new construction and population growth is worsening. The CMHC attributes the housing shortage to supply not keeping pace with demand, with home prices more than doubling since 2015, making housing unaffordable in many large cities, especially Toronto.

site_title: Beijing curbs public transport as Covid-19 spreads in China
summary: Beijing has implemented strict measures to curb the spread of Covid-19, shutting over 40 metro stations and 158 bus routes, as the city battles a surge in new cases. The city of 22 million people has closed schools and businesses in high-risk areas, with mass testing and isolation efforts underway. Shanghai, which has been under lockdown for over a month, shows no signs of easing curbs, with new cases continuing to emerge. The zero-Covid policy is hurting China's growth and global supply chains, with major companies like Apple and Starbucks suspending operations or guidance due to restrictions.

site_title: India releases 2020 death data ahead of WHO Covid-19 mortality study it objects
summary: India released its 2020 death data, showing about 475,000 more total deaths than the previous year, with a total of 8.1 million reported deaths. This contradicts estimates by the World Health Organization (WHO), which expects to publish an excess mortality of at least 3 million globally for 2020. India's health official, Vinod Kumar Paul, disputed the WHO's methodology, stating that India's actual Covid death toll is not as high as estimated, and that actual data for 2020 and 2021 will be released in the future.

site_title: Soaring UK finance salaries ramp up inequality: study
summary: UK finance sector salaries surged 31% in February from 2019, widening inequality amid the cost-of-living crisis. This is the highest pay growth in the finance sector since the 2008 global financial crisis. The surge in pay is driven by regular hikes rather than bonuses, fuelling a "new rise in earnings inequality." The finance sector accounts for nearly a third of the top 1% of UK earners, leading to increased overall earnings inequality.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 11, 2020 The offices of banking giants Citi, HSBC and Barclays are pictured at the the secondary central business district of Canary Wharf on the Isle of Dogs, east London. - British bank Barclays on April 28, 2022 announced an 18-percent drop in net profit during the first quarter on litigation and bad debt charges. Profit after tax declined to £1.4 billion ($1.8 billion, 1.7 billion euros) compared with the first three months of 2021, Barclays said in an earnings statement. (Photo by Tolga AKMEN / AFP)

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB downgrades UOB to 'neutral', expects headwinds to moderate FY2022 growth
summary: RHB downgraded UOB to "neutral" from "buy" and lowered its target price to S$32.70 due to expected headwinds to moderate FY2022 growth, citing higher risk premiums and lower ESG scores. The bank also reduced its target prices for DBS to S$38.10 and OCBC to S$13.90. The downgrade comes after all three Singapore banks reported a 10% fall in net profit for the quarter, with UOB's Q1 results missing expectations.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Rising interest rates and improving lending momentum are expected to continue boosting margins this year.
DBS, OCBC and UOB all announced a 10 per cent drop in their net profit for the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022.
UOB reported earnings for its first-quarter ended March on Friday (Apr 29)
DBS reported a net profit of S$1.8 billion for the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022.
OCBC releases financial results .
SINGAPORE banks are expected to report weaker first quarter earnings from a year ago, as wealth and treasury income are weighed down by investors’ risk-off sentiment amid market volatility.

site_title: Recovery runway of carriers
summary: Singapore Airlines appears to be recovering faster than other pandemic-affected carriers, with its scheduled passenger flights in January-June 2022 only 27% lower than pre-pandemic levels. In contrast, China Eastern Airlines has recovered the fastest, with only a 13% decline, followed by Eva Air with an 11% decline in capacity. As Asian countries reopen their international borders, airlines are ramping up flights, with Singapore Airlines taking off quickly in the post-pandemic reopening.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: India wants Russia to discount its oil to less than US$70 a barrel: sources
summary: India is seeking deeper discounts on Russian oil, aiming for less than $70 a barrel, to compensate for the risks of dealing with Opec+ producer Russia as other buyers turn away. The country has bought over 40 million barrels of Russian crude since the Ukraine invasion, with the help of state and private refiners. India's state-run refiners could take an additional 15 million barrels a month if Russia agrees to the price demands, with the government resisting Western encouragement to scale back its relationship with Moscow.

site_title: Australian retail sales sped ahead in Q1, rate rise to be a drag
summary: Australian retail sales surged 1.6% in March to a record A$33.6 billion, beating forecasts and fueling expectations for economic growth despite a rise in interest rates. The strong spending performance, driven by a high savings rate, suggests the economy can weather the impact of inflation and interest rate hikes. The Reserve Bank of Australia has already raised rates by 25 basis points and is expected to hike further, but analysts believe the economy can withstand the challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong plunges below Singapore in world press freedom ranking
summary: Hong Kong dropped to 148th place in the Reporters Without Borders 2022 World Press Freedom Index, a 68-place decline from last year. The city's ranking fell amid a crackdown on free speech, including police raids, asset seizures, and the closure of independent news organizations. Thirteen journalists were in prison at the time of the report. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam denied claims of deteriorating press freedom, citing a "vibrant media environment" despite government control and censorship.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Two International Finance Centre (IFC), HSBC headquarters and Bank of China in Hong Kong, China July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
The Asian finance hub is now slowly starting to reopen, meaning the Q1 slump could mark the low point in the growth cycle.
HONG KONG will bring forward reopening plans as cases drop, easing mask-wearing rules and allowing more leisure venues to reopen from this week, chief executive Carrie Lam said.

site_title: Shell, BP face obstacles to gaining wider share of EV charging market
summary: Major oil and gas companies, Shell and BP, face challenges in gaining a wider share of the electric vehicle (EV) charging market. Despite acquiring charging companies and forming partnerships, they lag behind in public charging infrastructure, operating less than 1% of public chargers globally. To boost their shares, they aim to install 500,000 and 70,000 chargers globally by 2025 and 2030, respectively. However, experts question the effectiveness of retrofitting gas stations with chargers, citing the need for more convenient and efficient charging solutions, such as ultra-fast charging at supermarkets and shopping centers.

site_title: Mountbatten Road conservation bungalow up for sale with S$63.6m price tag
summary: A freehold conservation bungalow in Singapore's Mountbatten Road Bungalow Conservation Area is up for sale at S$63.6 million, with a land size of 31,820 sq ft. The property, 760 Mountbatten Road, is part of 15 conservation bungalows and features a 2-storey colonial Victorian style bungalow with a rear annex building. The sale comes after another similar property, 759 Mountbatten Road, was launched for sale just 3 weeks prior at S$27 million. The property has received numerous enquiries and is expected to close on May 10.

images.alt_text: Mountbatten Road conservation bungalow up for sale with S$27m guide price

site_title: Australia’s A$201 billion wealth fund to curb global investment
summary: Australia's A$201 billion Future Fund plans to reduce its global investment exposure and increase local investments amid rising geopolitical tensions and market volatility. The fund aims to seek more illiquid assets and adopt active strategies to generate returns as borrowing costs rise and economies face recession. Chief Executive Raphael Arndt warned that the world has changed, and traditional financial models are no longer applicable, requiring a new way of thinking. The fund will trim its emerging market exposure and exercise caution on China, with possible sanctions on the nation's economy if it supports Russia.

images.alt_text: AUSTRALIA'S central bank increased interest-rates by more than economists anticipated and signalled further hikes to come, sending the currency and bond yields higher.
Australian retail sales easily sped past forecasts for a third straight month in March.

site_title: Musk says Twitter may charge slight fee for commercial, government users
summary: Elon Musk announced on Tuesday that Twitter will remain free for casual users but may charge a small fee for commercial and government users. Musk aims to boost the platform's reach and make it more accessible to the general public. He also plans to enhance the platform with new features, including open-sourcing algorithms, defeating spam bots, and authenticating all humans. Musk previously suggested slashing the price of Twitter's premium subscription service and making the platform more transparent about promoted tweets.

site_title: Tokyo, China, Malaysia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in China, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, and Thailand are closed on May 4, 2022, for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have reached a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. US stocks also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Motion graphics platform LottieFiles raises US$37m Series B round
summary: LottieFiles, a motion graphics platform, has raised US$37 million in Series B funding led by Square Peg Capital. The platform, which provides a file format for motion graphics across platforms, has 135,000 global users, including major companies like Google and Netflix. The funds will be used to expand its operations and launch new products, including a design workflow and collaboration solution. LottieFiles has experienced 160% growth in net new registered users since its last funding round in 2021.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: How the future of banking is manifesting in Asean
summary: Southeast Asian banks are facing the end of their legacy core technology, which has been in service for two decades or longer, prompting a search for alternatives to extend its life. Digital transformation is a pressing issue in the region, with banks seeking to upgrade their systems to remain competitive. The shift towards modern technology is expected to bring about significant changes in the banking industry, with potential benefits including improved efficiency and customer experience.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Banks in Singapore have launched a series of fixed deposit promotions in the past month, with rates going up to 1.3 per cent for 24-month tenures, as of this week.

site_title: Avocados and durians help coffee farmers in Vietnam cope with surging costs
summary: Vietnam's coffee farmers are diversifying their crops to cope with soaring fertiliser and fuel costs caused by the war in Ukraine. They are planting more profitable crops like avocados, black pepper, and durians, but this may lead to a 10% drop in coffee production next season. Despite this, exports are expected to remain stable, with processed coffee products aiming to represent 25% of export revenue in the next 5 years. The country aims to standardize cultivation processes and increase irrigation to combat climate change.

images.alt_text: Robust sales in North America were offset by weakness in China as Starbucks reported a modest profit increase on Tuesday.
The acquisition of Club Coffee will expand OFI’s private label capabilities in North America.
Around 40 per cent of Vietnam’s total electricity supply today comes from coal-fired power stations.

site_title: Gold dips as Fed rate hike looms, US bond yields firm
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,865.31 per ounce on May 4 as US Treasury yields rose and the Federal Reserve is set to hike interest rates to combat inflation. The expected 50 basis-point rate hike increases the opportunity cost of holding bullion, making it less attractive for overseas buyers. Silver, platinum, and palladium also saw small price changes, while the dollar remained near 20-year peaks. The Fed's decision is expected to detail plans to reduce its $8.9 trillion balance sheet.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on banks, energy boost; Federal Reserve meeting in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by gains in banking and energy stocks ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate decision. Energy stocks jumped 1.6% on oil price increases, while financials rose 0.5% as Australia and New Zealand Banking Group beat estimates. Mining stocks also rose, with BHP and Rio Tinto gaining 0.7% and 0.8% respectively. Despite this, tech stocks fell 0.5%. The Fed is expected to hike rates by 0.5 basis points, its largest move since 2000, to tame inflation.

site_title: Elon Musk likens Apple pay to 30% tax on Internet
summary: Elon Musk criticized Apple's App Store, likening its 30% fee to a "30% tax on the Internet" that is "10 times higher than it should be". This comes after the European Union filed an antitrust complaint against Apple. Musk's former company, PayPal, played a role in bringing the suit to the European Commission. Musk's comments reflect his stance on the App Store's fees, which he believes are excessive.

site_title: Didi Global faces SEC probe related to US IPO
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Didi Global's 2021 IPO, which raised $4.4 billion, amid concerns over data security and regulatory issues. The investigation follows US lawmakers' calls for an investigation last year. Didi's shares have slid 85% since its IPO, and the company is cooperating with the probe. The company will likely see its stock traded over the counter on the pink-sheets market, and shareholders will vote on its delisting on May 23.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong hasn’t hosted any IPO larger than US$1 billion so far this year. Overall proceeds in the Asian financial hub have slumped, with the vast majority of newcomers plunging below the listing price after they debuted.

site_title: Tiger Global’s hedge fund posts 15% monthly drop, pushing year’s loss to 44%
summary: Tiger Global Management's hedge fund posted a 15% monthly drop in April, extending its 2022 loss to 44%, with the firm's assets declining from $35 billion to $19 billion. The decline is attributed to the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100's 13% drop in April, its largest monthly decline since 2008. This marks a significant downturn for the firm, which had previously been one of the hedge fund industry's top performers, and has taken a considerable bite out of its co-founders' fortunes.

images.alt_text: ADDX chief executive Choo Oi Yee estimates that at any given point, there could be trillions of dollars stuck in a system that is not being used productively.
The Newtonian revolution claimed that "all clouds are clocks -- even the most cloudy of clouds", as Karl Popper put it.

site_title: North Korea fires ‘unidentified projectile’: Seoul
summary: North Korea fired an "unidentified projectile" eastward, according to South Korea's military, in the latest in a series of military provocations. The launch comes ahead of South Korea's incoming president Yoon Suk Yeol's tougher stance on the North. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un warned of preemptively using nuclear force, amid a military modernization drive despite biting sanctions.

site_title: Temasek sees China growth reviving in second half
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state-owned investor, expects Chinese growth to rebound in the second half of 2022 as the government stimulates the economy. According to Temasek's chief investment officer Rohit Sipahimalani, the country is close to the trough of its economic cycle, leading to growth on the rise. Despite facing challenges in the Chinese technology and online education spaces, Temasek remains bullish on the broader market and some of its tech companies pending government policy clarity. The firm's investments in China, totaling 27% of its holdings, are expected to benefit from the government's stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: Ankiti Bose, co-founder and chief executive officer of Zilingo Pte, poses for a photograph in Singapore, on Monday, Feb. 11, 2019. Zilingo said it raised $226 million from investors including Sequoia Capital and Temasek Holdings Pte. The latest financing valued the fashion platform at $970 million, according to people familiar with the matter, who asked not to be named because the information is private. That makes 27-year-old Bose among the youngest female chief executives to lead a startup of the size in Asia. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

A man passes a logo of state investor Temasek Holdings at their office in Singapore July 8, 2014. Singapore sovereign investor Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd said on Tuesday it intends to keep investing in Chinese banks even as it reported a slowdown in its portfolio growth due to a drop in the value of some of its bank holdings. REUTERS/Edgar Su (SINGAPORE - Tags: BUSINESS LOGO)

site_title: Europe inflation seen surpassing US for first time in a decade
summary: European inflation is expected to surpass US levels for the first time in over a decade, driven by the war in Ukraine and rising energy prices. Market expectations show euro-area inflation at 3.02% over the next decade, surpassing the US rate of 3.00%. This poses a challenge for the European Central Bank, which must balance curbing inflation with economic growth concerns, including possible recession and energy rationing.

site_title: Pfizer sees high demand for Covid-19 pill as profits jump
summary: Pfizer reported strong first-quarter earnings, with profits jumping 61% to $7.9 billion, driven by a 77% surge in revenues to $25.7 billion. The company expects $22 billion in Paxlovid sales in 2022, with plans to produce 120 million courses of the treatment. Pfizer is confident in strong demand for its Covid-19 antiviral treatment as pandemic rules ease, and is also working on a vaccine booster that could provide immunity for a year.

site_title: ARA H-Trust Q1 net property income jumps to US$5.3m on recovery across portfolio
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust reported a net property income of US$5.3 million for its first quarter, jumping from US$0.4 million a year ago. Gross revenue increased 68% to US$32.8 million, driven by sustained recovery across its portfolio. Occupancy rose to 54.6%, with revenue per available room increasing 67.4% and average daily rate up 29.8%. The trust expects its recovery to exceed pre-pandemic levels, driven by improving hotel industry fundamentals and air travel volumes.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
ARA H-Trust to sell Chicago hotel asset for US$7.75m
ARA H-Trust posts US$2m distributable income

site_title: Dyna-Mac wins S$180m contract; net order book hits record high of S$641.1m
summary: DYNA-MAC Holdings has won an S$180 million contract for fabricating topside modules for a floating production storage offloading (FPSO) vessel. The contract brings the company's net order book to a record high of S$641.1 million, with deliveries set to stretch into 2024. The new order is expected to commence in Q4 2022 and complete in Q1 2024, with minimal impact on the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Did bearishness about the property sector prompt Northstar to divest Apac Realty at steep discount?
summary: Northstar Group sold a 59.8% stake in Apac Realty, a Singapore-based real estate agency, to Morgan Stanley Private Equity Asia at a discounted price of S$0.61 per share, representing a 30% discount to the market price. Apac Realty reported a stellar financial performance for FY2021, with a 87.2% increase in topline and 110% rise in earnings. The divestment suggests Northstar's bearish view on the property industry's near-term prospects, amid cooling measures and expected interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Singapore shares rose.
Singapore shares
APAC Realty is a real estate service provider, and the group has more than 20,000 advisors across 653 offices in Asia through its ERA franchisee network.
APAC Realty, which operates under the ERA brand name, is a real estate service provider. Through its ERA franchisee network, the group has more than 20,000 advisors across 653 offices in Asia.
Bumper dividends from pandemic winners in FY21
Can good times roll on for big property agencies?
Brokers' take: DBS lowers target on APAC Realty on lower earnings, near-term decline

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, SIA, Keppel Corp, Genting, StarHub, LMIRT
summary: Singapore stocks experienced fluctuations on Wednesday, with Wilmar International's 17.8% increase in net profit to US$530.3 million for the first quarter, driving shares 1.8% higher. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines reinstated pilots' basic pay, and Keppel Corp sold 46.68% of its Keppel Reit units. Genting Singapore appointed a new CEO, and StarHub's net profit slipped 2.6% to S$29.7 million. LMIRT's distribution per unit rose 12.5% to S$0.0009, while ARA US Hospitality Trust posted a 68% increase in gross revenue.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks rose slightly in early trade on Wednesday tracking overnight gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Fossils dating back 66 million years found outside Bangkok mall
summary: Thai experts have confirmed that 77 ammonite fossils, measuring up to 12 centimeters across, found in a footpath outside a Bangkok shopping mall are over 66 million years old. The fossils, which date back to the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods, were embedded in new pavement and differ from those usually found in Thailand. The discovery suggests that the fossils were inserted into the concrete as decoration by sub-contractors 2 years ago, before the footpath was repaired.

site_title: No Signboard terminates loan agreements with Q&M CEO, private investor
summary: No Signboard Holdings has terminated its conditional loan agreements with Q&M Dental CEO Ng Chin Siau and private investor Bryan Lim Soon Fang. The company cited timeline issues with the proposed investment structure and loan conditions. Ng had agreed to take a 29% stake in No Signboard for $1 and provide an interest-free loan of $2.6 million, while Lim had agreed to take a 22% stake for $1 and provide an interest-free loan of $1.9 million.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
No Signboard closes its Esplanade outlet just as Singapore reopens
No Signboard places beer subsidiary into creditors' voluntary liquidation
Deal with Q&M Dental CEO 'key part' of trading resumption proposal: No Signboard
Soup Restaurant, Jumbo, ABR show financial strength in weathering pandemic

site_title: Opec fails to increase oil output as capacity troubles persist
summary: The Opec cartel failed to increase oil output in April, with members struggling with capacity constraints. Iraq boosted output by 170,000 barrels a day, while Libya and Nigeria saw production fall due to operational disruptions. Saudi Arabia added just 70,000 barrels a day, below its target. The group's inability to meet its quota exacerbates the global oil supply shortage, driving up prices near $105 a barrel, and threatening growth and inflation. The Opec+ alliance is set to ratify a modest increase of 430,000 barrels a day.

site_title: Ultra-rich families racing to park wealth in Singapore under enhanced investment scheme
summary: Wealthy families from around the region are flocking to Singapore to secure permanent residency under the enhanced Global Investor Programme (GIP) scheme. The number of family applications has seen strong double-digit growth since 2020, driven by the pandemic and increased interest in Singapore's business-friendly environment. Ultra-high net worth families are seeking to park their wealth in Singapore, with professional service providers reporting a significant increase in family office applications. The EDB has not disclosed exact figures, but the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported 400 single family offices in Singapore as of end-2020.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Next-generation leaders must take the lead in driving digitalisation.
MAS tightens criteria for family offices to qualify for tax incentives
Next year's more substantial reopening seen boosting recovery

site_title: Aston Martin names ex-Ferrari boss Amedeo Felisa as CEO
summary: Aston Martin has named Amedeo Felisa, former Ferrari boss, as its new CEO, succeeding Tobias Moers with immediate effect. Felisa will also be appointed as executive director. The company reported a wider pretax loss of £111.6 million for the first quarter. Additionally, Roberto Fedeli, Ferrari's hybrid supercar creator, has been named as the company's chief technical officer. These appointments aim to strengthen Aston Martin's senior leadership team to deliver next-generation sports cars and lead the way to electrification.

site_title: ANZ sees improved margins on rising rates, cash profit grows
summary: ANZ Banking Group reported a 4.1% increase in cash profit from continuing operations to A$3.11 billion in the first half, beating estimates. The lender attributed the growth to a pandemic-fuelled housing boom and cost controls. Despite a 0.07% decrease in net interest margin to 1.58%, ANZ expects improved second-half margins as interest rates rise. The bank also announced plans to establish a new listed parent holding company and declared an interim dividend of 72 Australian cents per share.

site_title: Lyft offers lackluster profit goal, forecasts more driver spending; shares sink 27%
summary: Lyft Inc reported lackluster second-quarter earnings, with revenue and adjusted operating earnings below Wall Street expectations. The ride-hailing company forecast revenue of $950 million to $1 billion, shy of analyst estimates, and adjusted EBITDA of $10 million to $20 million. Shares plummeted 27% after-hours, while rival Uber Technologies Inc fell 5%. Lyft attributed the shortfall to increased spending on driver incentives to attract drivers back to its platform, particularly on the US West Coast.

site_title: KKR partly tokenises new US$4b tech fund on Singapore's ADDX
summary: KKR is targeting $4 billion for its third technology fund and plans to raise a portion through Singapore's ADDX platform. Accredited investors can access the fund with a minimum of $20,000, a fraction of the typical minimum of $250,000. This move is part of KKR's expansion into alternative channels to tap into private wealth. The tokenization aims to increase accessibility to the fund for a broader range of investors.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
KKR has already completed two deals on behalf of the new fund through its Mirastar platform.
The SLB will carry a US dollar fixed coupon rate of 4.56 per cent per annum and mature on Apr 27, 2027.
Exchanges looking to private arena as capital markets evolve

site_title: Coinbase is on other side of Goldman's first Bitcoin-backed loan
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched its first lending facility backed by Bitcoin, a move aimed at bringing Wall Street capital into the digital-asset space. The facility is a first step in recognizing crypto as collateral, deepening the bridge between fiat and crypto economies. Coinbase Global, a crypto exchange, collaborated with Goldman on the loan, which is collateralized by Bitcoin owned by a previously undisclosed borrower. This development marks a novel effort by Wall Street to engage with the crypto sector.

site_title: Tata Steel posts 47% jump on demand boom, announces stock split
summary: Tata Steel reports a 47% jump in quarterly profit to 97.6 billion rupees, driven by a demand boom for the alloy. The company also announces a 10:1 stock split to boost liquidity. Sales rose 39% to 693.2 billion rupees, while costs increased 44%. Tata Steel's share price has more than doubled since December 2020, and the company is poised to benefit from a supply gap created by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company aims to cut debt by 75 billion rupees this year.

site_title: UK shop prices rise at fastest rate since 2011: BRC
summary: UK shop prices rose at the fastest rate since 2011, with food prices increasing by 3.5% year-on-year in April, according to the British Retail Consortium. This marks the highest rate of inflation since September 2011. The surge in prices is attributed to rising energy costs and supply disruptions from China. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation, which has reached a 30-year high of 7% in March. Retailers are cutting prices on essential items, but warn of further price rises ahead.

site_title: Airbnb bets on summer of travel to drive revenue growth
summary: Airbnb Inc. has projected second-quarter revenue above market estimates, driven by pent-up demand for travel after Covid-19 curbs were eased globally. The San Francisco-based firm expects revenue between $2.03 billion and $2.13 billion, exceeding average analyst expectations. This growth is attributed to the rise of hybrid working, encouraging people to book longer stays in destinations away from cities. Shares rose over 4% in extended trading, and the company reported a 70% increase in revenue from last year, with 100 million nights and experiences booked for the first time.

site_title: US job openings rose unexpectedly to record 11.5 million
summary: US job openings reached a record 11.5 million in March, exceeding economists' forecasts of 11.2 million. This represents the highest number of available positions since the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey began tracking the data in 2000. Meanwhile, 4.5 million Americans quit their jobs in March, a series high, with the quits rate rising slightly to 3%. The labor market tightness is expected to continue, driving wage growth.

site_title: Activists urge ad boycott if Musk turns Twitter toxic
summary: Activist groups, including Media Matters and Access Now, have urged Twitter advertisers to boycott the platform if Elon Musk, its new owner, dials back content moderation to a legal minimum. The groups claim Musk's approach would lead to a "cesspool of misinformation" and risk associating the brand with hate and extremism. Twitter's ad revenue could be jeopardized by advertisers' reaction, with the platform generating $1.2 billion in ad revenue in the recently ended quarter. Musk has expressed a preference for making money from subscriptions, but analysts doubt users would pay for premium content.

site_title: ADDX seeks to make alternatives more accessible as private market interest grows
summary: ADDX, a private markets platform, aims to increase accessibility to alternative investments such as private equity and hedge funds. CEO Choo Oi Yee estimates trillions of dollars are stuck in a system not being used productively, and the company seeks to achieve "pure democratisation" by expanding to retail investors. ADDX uses blockchain technology to tokenise large assets, simplifying the investment process and increasing speed and efficiency. However, retail investors face challenges, including high minimum investment requirements, and the company plans to address these issues with safeguards such as restrictions on investment sizes. ADDX aims to hit a transaction volume of US$1 billion by 2023.

site_title: ‘Death shadow’ dinosaur unearthed in Argentina
summary: Paleontologists in Argentina have discovered a 70-million-year-old, six-ton megaraptor dinosaur, nicknamed "Maip macrothorax," which translates to "shadow of death" in Patagonian mythology. The 9-10m-long, three-story predator had sharp, curved claws and was likely an apex predator in its time. Its fossilized remains, including a cervical vertebra and rib, were found in the Santa Cruz province, making it the southernmost megaraptor ever discovered.

site_title: Universal Music's revenue beat estimates with subscription boost
summary: Universal Music Group's revenue exceeded estimates in the first quarter, driven by a 22% increase to 2.2 billion euros, largely due to a 18% rise in subscription sales to 900 million euros and a 38% increase in music publishing revenue to 375 million euros. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization grew 15% to 455 million euros. The company's publishing division benefited from recent acquisitions of Sting and Neil Diamond's catalogs, although downloads and other digital revenue declined 16%.

site_title: Oil slides as China lockdowns outweigh proposed EU Russia oil ban
summary: Oil prices fell by over 2% on Tuesday due to concerns over China's prolonged Covid-19 lockdowns outweighing a proposed EU ban on Russian crude. China's lockdowns, including mass-testing and sealed apartment blocks, have raised worries about Chinese demand, while the EU's planned sanctions on Russia are also affecting prices. Brent crude settled at $104.97 a barrel, down 2.4%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude ended at $102.41, down 2.6%. Prices remain high, with Brent crude reaching $139 in March due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: A photograph shows petrol nozzles at a gas station in Montgiscard, southwestern France, on January 24, 2022, as oil prices are at their highest in France since 2014. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: AMD soars after data-centre chip sales fuel upbeat forecast
summary: AMD has reported a strong sales forecast for the second quarter, with predicted sales of around $6.5 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The company's data-center chip sales are driving the growth, and its acquisition of Xilinx is contributing to its rapid expansion. AMD's CEO Lisa Su said the company's businesses are growing at a significant double-digit percentage year-over-year, with full-year expectations stronger than previously thought. The forecast suggests AMD is gaining momentum in the chip market, with the company poised to end 2022 with almost 4 times as much revenue as in 2019.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher ahead of Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks ended a choppy session modestly higher on Tuesday, awaiting the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.2%. Analysts predict uncertainty over the market's reaction to a potential half-point interest rate hike, with some anticipating a relief rally and others expecting a sell-off. The Dow finished at 33,128.79, while Pfizer and Biogen also saw significant price movements due to earnings reports.

site_title: Kim Kardashian, Marilyn Monroe and climate change at the Met Gala
summary: Kim Kardashian wore a replica of Marilyn Monroe's iconic dress from 1962 to John F. Kennedy's birthday party at the Met Gala, sparking a conversation about climate consciousness and reuse of clothing. The US generates 11.3 million tons of textile waste annually, and celebrities like Keira Knightley and Kate Middleton have been wearing outfits multiple times in public to make a point. Kardashian's move was seen as a nod to the growing trend of sustainable fashion.

site_title: Samsonite "well positioned" to reap travel rebound with new Singapore hub
summary: Samsonite, a 112-year-old luggage manufacturer, is well-positioned to capitalize on the travel rebound due to its new office in Singapore. The company's Asia-Pacific and Middle East president, Paul Melkebeke, attributes this to the office's proximity to key markets and factories, enabling better product development and quality control. With travel restrictions easing, Samsonite aims to grow its Asia regional team to 80 members, mostly based in Singapore, and expects a strong future despite surviving the initial stages of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Russian strikes kill 21 in east Ukraine: governor
summary: Russian strikes on eastern Ukraine killed 21 civilians and wounded 27, the highest daily death toll in nearly a month, according to Donetsk region Governor Pavlo Kyrylenko. The strikes targeted the Avdiivka coke plant and other areas, including Lyman, Vugledar, Velyka Novosilka, and Shandrygolove. This is the highest death toll since a Russian strike on a train station in Kramatorsk killed 59 people about a month ago. Kyrylenko vowed to hold Russia accountable for its actions, saying "For every crime committed on our land, the Russians will be punished."

site_title: Europe: Upbeat earnings, banks lift shares
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% on Tuesday after a string of upbeat earnings, rebounding from a "flash crash" the previous session. Banking shares gained as government bond yields hit fresh highs, anticipating quicker interest rate hikes to tackle inflation. Oil and gas sectors led gains, with BP rising 5.8% due to high oil and gas prices. The US 10-year Treasury yield hit 3% for the first time since December 2018, ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting.

site_title: SIA to roll back pilot pay cuts, with full restoration by end-2022
summary: Singapore Airlines is gradually restoring pilots' basic pay, following pandemic-era cuts, with the goal of full restoration by the start of 2023. The airline has signed a new agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association – Singapore, which will reduce additional pay cuts every quarter. For example, the wage cut for re-employed captains was reduced from 50% to 26.3% in April and will continue to decrease until full restoration is achieved.

site_title: M&A activity to pick up in H2, in tandem with economic rebound: industry players
summary: M&A activity in Southeast Asia is expected to rise in the second half of the year, driven by the easing of pandemic restrictions and a broader economic recovery. Key sectors to watch include renewables, semiconductors, electronics, and real estate. Singapore and Malaysia are likely to see more deals, particularly in healthcare, e-commerce, and logistics. Private equity funds may shift focus to bricks and mortar businesses, and companies in sunset sectors may restructure or consolidate. However, escalating geopolitical tensions and higher costs may also lead to increased distressed sales and bankruptcies.

site_title: German unemployment drops least in year amid war in Ukraine
summary: Germany's unemployment rate dropped by 13,000 in April, maintaining the jobless rate at 5%, the pre-pandemic level. This is the slowest pace in a year, amid war in Ukraine and surging inflation. Economists warn that a disruption to Russian natural gas supply could lead to recession. The European Central Bank is set to withdraw monetary stimulus due to labor-market strength, supporting stronger wage gains. Germany's economic outlook has darkened due to input shortages and price pressures, with the government slashing its growth forecast to 2.2% for 2022.

site_title: Mercedes, BMW go back to basics with retreat from urban rentals
summary: German luxury car manufacturers Mercedes-Benz and BMW are selling their urban car-sharing service, Share Now, to Stellantis NV for an undisclosed sum. The move follows over a decade of struggling to make money in the service, which aimed to offer city-dwellers car rentals by the minute. The companies will focus on their traditional business of selling expensive vehicles, while Stellantis plans to integrate Share Now into its Free2Move mobility unit, which will also include parking services and ride-sharing.

images.alt_text: MERCEDES-BENZ expects strong demand for high-end cars to allow it to offset rising raw material and transport costs with higher prices, forecasting a pick-up in deliveries once chip shortages ease.

site_title: Singapore data centre players worry about feasibility of new standards ahead of lifting of moratorium
summary: Singapore's new data centre standards, set to be implemented after a moratorium is lifted, have raised concerns among industry players. The proposed standards, which include a power usage effectiveness (PUE) target of 1.3, may be difficult to meet, particularly for smaller data centres. Industry leaders estimate that achieving this target would require significant investment, and some argue that other metrics, such as embedded carbon, should also be considered. The government's plan to allocate 60MW of capacity to three companies, with each having 10-30MW of capacity, has also been questioned, with some suggesting it could lead to less efficient facilities.

site_title: UK can't help everyone now over cost of living: Johnson
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that the government cannot help everyone through the current cost-of-living crisis due to concerns of fueling inflation. Johnson acknowledged the squeeze on household incomes but emphasized the government's need to remain prudent with spending. The government is working to address prices over the medium and long term, rather than providing immediate support.

site_title: Putin orders retaliatory sanctions against West: Kremlin
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a decree on retaliatory economic sanctions against Western countries in response to what he calls "unfriendly actions". The decree prohibits transactions with sanctioned entities and forbids the export of products and raw materials to those countries. The Russian government has 10 days to compile lists of foreign individuals and companies to be sanctioned. The move comes amid rising tensions between Russia and the West following the ongoing Ukraine war.

site_title: Constellar bets on digital transformation to win back business travellers
summary: Constellar, a Singapore-based company, aims to become one of the top 20 companies in the Mice (meetings, incentives, conferences, and exhibitions) industry in the next 3-5 years. CEO Jean-Francois Quentin plans to achieve this through acquisition opportunities and digital transformation, leveraging the company's developed digital capabilities during the pandemic. Constellar will offer personalized "omni-channel" solutions, including digital events and data analytics, to meet evolving customer needs and priorities. Despite uncertainty over the timing of Singapore's Mice industry recovery, Constellar is ready to recapture pent-up demand and capitalize on the shift towards quality over quantity in business travel.

site_title: Fed needs to do more than raise interest rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve must address four critical issues to regain credibility and stabilize the economy, according to Mohamed A El-Erian. These issues include regaining control of the policy narrative through credible forward policy guidance, establishing a pathway for quantitative tightening, switching from a reactive to a proactive monetary policy framework, and owning up to past mistakes. The Fed's failure to address these challenges could lead to another serious policy error, risking a costly recession or further deanchoring inflationary expectations.

site_title: Rare-earth metals: Rising demand from advanced technologies
summary: Rare-earth metals, crucial for advanced technologies such as electric vehicles and renewable energy, are expected to see significant growth due to increasing demand and limited supply. China dominates global REM production, but governments are encouraging self-reliance, with the US and Australia offering grants to develop domestic industries. Investors can consider REMs as part of their commodity portfolio, with higher prices potentially increasing revenues and margins of mining companies. Demand is set to grow by 7% annually to 2025, driven by emerging green technologies and established applications in electronics and catalytic converters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at start of the day
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day on a downward trend, slipping 0.8% or 161.77 points to 20,927.62. The losses follow a strong end to last week. Mainland Chinese markets are closed for a public holiday, contributing to the Hang Seng Index's decline.

site_title: BT Explains: How to price climate risks and opportunities
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to be the hardest hit globally if global warming reaches 3.2 degrees Celsius by mid-century, with a potential GDP shrinkage of up to 46.4%. A Swiss Re Institute study projects that Asia's economy will be disproportionately affected, with a 37.4% fall in GDP. Companies are struggling to measure climate risks and opportunities, with varying methods used to assess climate risk. Four methodologies were examined: scenario-based analysis, factor-based analysis, acute risk analysis, and chronic risk analysis. These methods, such as scenario-based analysis, factor-based analysis, and acute risk analysis, can help companies quantify the risks and opportunities of climate change and make informed decisions.

summary: Financial markets in China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, and Singapore are closed on May 3, 2022, for public holidays. This news does not appear to be relevant to the provided article from July 11, 2025.

site_title: After a two-year dip, evictions accelerate in New York
summary: Evictions in New York have accelerated after a two-year dip, with approximately 2,000 cases filed by landlords every week since March, a 40% increase from mid-January. This surge is attributed to the expiration of the state's eviction moratorium. As a result, over 500 tenants have been thrown out of their homes since February, doubling the number in the previous 20 months. Judges are struggling to keep up with the increased caseload, and lawyers representing both landlords and tenants are expressing frustration over the slow pace of proceedings.

site_title: Europe is its own enemy in Ukraine
summary: The EU can stop Russia's aggression in Ukraine by refusing to buy oil immediately, eliminating gas purchases over time, and prohibiting European ships from carrying Russian oil. This can be achieved by imposing sanctions on relevant financial services. Since the invasion, Russia has received over 50 billion euros from Europe, significantly more than what the West has provided to Ukraine. Allowing oil imports from Russia to resume under a properly structured system of sanctions is the only way to end the conflict. International Energy Agency has sufficient emergency fuel supplies to manage the transition.

summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as traders anticipated a US interest rate hike, which could lead to similar moves by other central banks to control inflation. The US Federal Reserve is expected to lift borrowing costs 0.5 percentage points, sparking concerns about a recession. China's Covid lockdowns and a stronger dollar also contributed to the market's downturn. The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted interest rates 25 basis points, while oil prices edged up due to fears about the impact of lockdowns on demand.

site_title: Hong Kong GDP falls more than expected on Covid curbs, trade
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 4% in Q1 2022, its first decline in over a year, due to local Covid restrictions and China's Omicron outbreak disrupting trade. The city's GDP drop was worse than expected, with the Asian finance hub now slowly reopening, potentially marking the low point in the growth cycle. The government attributed the contraction to "immense pressure" from the fifth coronavirus wave, moderating global demand growth, and transportation disruptions.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will shorten mandatory hotel quarantine for passenger flight crews to three days from seven, while cargo crews will be exempt, modest steps at unwinding coronavirus curbs that have turned the city into one of the world’s most isolated places.

site_title: Euro holds near 5-year low as potential Fed hike nears
summary: The euro holds near a 5-year low against the US dollar, trading at US$1.05040, due to concerns about inflation, growth, and energy insecurity resulting from sanctions on Russia. The Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates by 50 basis points, while European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde's comments on monetary policy plans will be closely watched. The euro has dropped 14% against the US dollar in 3 months, with market expectations for 90 basis points of interest rate hikes by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The dollar index gained 5 per cent in April, its best monthly performance since January 2015.

site_title: Swiss bank secrecy law has ‘chilling effect,’ UN expert warns
summary: A UN human rights expert, Irene Khan, has urged the Swiss government to review its banking secrecy laws, citing a "chilling effect" on whistle-blowers and journalists. The laws, which provide little to no protection for those revealing bank client information without justification, were highlighted in February's publication of the "Suisse Secrets" series. Khan warned that the lack of exceptions for journalists and whistle-blowers could breach the public's right to information, risking up to three years in prison for those who divulge information.

summary: Activist investor Ancora Holdings is urging Hasbro to consider selling its Entertainment One unit, citing potential debt reduction and tax benefits. The unit, which includes popular franchises like Peppa Pig and Magic: The Gathering, was acquired for $4 billion in 2019. Ancora estimates a sale could yield up to $2 billion and result in tax benefits. The move comes after Ancora's rival, Alta Fox Capital Management, pushed for changes at the company, including a spin-off of its Wizards of Coast unit.

This initiative aims to leverage local expertise and partnerships to enhance Singapore's global presence and competitiveness.

site_title: The Fed wants to cool the US housing market. Here’s what that feels like
summary: The US Federal Reserve aims to cool the housing market by raising interest rates, which will make borrowing more expensive. This move is part of efforts to combat 40-year high inflation. As a result, mortgage rates have risen by over 2 percentage points, with the average 30-year-fixed home loan rate now at 5.37%. This increase will lead to higher monthly mortgage payments, with buyers facing an additional $440 per month. Economists predict a slowdown in home sales and price growth, but some experts warn that factors such as low housing stock and high household savings may hinder this forecast.

site_title: Who wants to work at sea?
summary: The global shipping industry faces a seafarer supply crisis due to a lack of young recruits, with the number of third mates and fourth engineer officers decreasing significantly. Asian countries, particularly Singapore, have implemented initiatives to attract young people to the industry, including the SailMAP and Tripartite Maritime Scholarship programs. However, the industry's reliance on foreign seafarers and unpredictable disruptions, such as the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, pose challenges. A recent report found that seafarer happiness levels have reached an all-time low due to the lack of shore time, variable conditions, and perceived low wages, warning of a potential manning crisis unless governments and ship managers address these issues.

site_title: Biden needs to enhance his Asia strategy with a firm commitment to free trade
summary: US President Joe Biden has an opportunity to upgrade his Asia policy by promoting and liberalizing trade in the region. The Biden administration has strengthened US alliances with key countries, revitalized the "Quad" security dialogue, and announced a trilateral security pact with Australia and the UK. However, critics argue that the administration's focus on military aspects of US presence in Asia has overshadowed its commitment to free trade. The US has resisted rejoining the Trans-Pacific Partnership, instead launching the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework, which focuses on promoting "fair trade" rather than free trade.

site_title: Hong Kong to accelerate reopening from this week as cases fall
summary: Hong Kong is accelerating its reopening plans as COVID-19 cases drop. From May 5, mask-wearing rules will be eased, and leisure venues such as beaches and swimming pools will reopen. Dining-in at restaurants will be extended to midnight on May 19, and bars will stay open until 2 am with limited seating capacity. The move comes as infections fall to low triple digits, but Hong Kong remains behind regional rivals in terms of pandemic recovery.

Growth in earnings is expected to lag revenue development by a few quarters due to rising costs, particularly in the Norwegian fixed line business and intensified competition in Thailand. The damage has been done, and entrepreneurs are struggling to innovate due to government meddling. The companies' strategies now focus on defined areas of operation, with Alibaba moving downmarket into smaller cities, Tencent focusing on cloud operations, and Baidu leading AI and autonomous-driving businesses. The government's top-down delegation of entrepreneurial activity may eventually enhance underlying technologies, but growth rates are likely to fall short of the past decade's pace.

summary: BMW and Mercedes-Benz are selling their car-sharing joint venture Share Now to Stellantis for an undisclosed sum, shifting focus to the software leg of their mobility alliance. Stellantis aims to boost its mobility division Free2move, positioning itself as a global leader in shared mobility. summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia raised its cash rate by 25 basis points to 0.35% on May 3, defying expectations for a 15 basis point hike. The decision sent the Australian dollar higher and boosted bond yields, with 3-year yields jumping to 2.97% and 10-year yields climbing to 3.36%. The move is a blow to the centre-right government, which is campaigning for a rare fourth term in office at an election on May 21.

images.alt_text: ECB policymaker and hawk Robert Holzmann expects an initial interest rate increase this summer or autumn and for rates to rise gradually before settling next year around 1 per cent or 1.5 per cent.

The banks have tussled with increased competition in home lending amid record-low rates and borrowers changing to fixed-rate loans, while costs ramp up due to investment in digital capabilities and broader inflation.
Inflation, running near historic highs, has turned the Fed hawkish.

site_title: Poland Gangnam-style
summary: Poland's economy has been a success story, with GDP per capita rising to two-thirds the euro area average, despite being an underappreciated country. The country's manufacturing sector has driven growth, with a diverse range of industries. However, to move up the technology ladder, Poland needs to boost labor productivity and invest in research and development. The country also needs to diversify its exports beyond the EU, with a goal of exporting to China, the US, and Japan. Poland's tolerance of immigration will be tested by a flood of refugees from Ukraine, and the country should make the most of their skills and expertise to keep moving up the economic and technological ladder.

images.alt_text: Biden doubles down on transatlantic ties

site_title: Navigating market turbulence with a barbell approach
summary: Market turbulence in 1Q22 was driven by the Russia-Ukraine crisis, supply chain tension, and rising inflation, with both equities and bonds falling in tandem. This year's 4th worst start to the year since 1999, with a 50/50 portfolio of equities and bonds losing 5.8%. To navigate structurally higher inflation, investors should aim for a barbell approach, allocating to sectors like energy and real estate, maintaining exposure to growth equities, and maintaining a balance allocation to high-quality credit.

images.alt_text: DBS is offering retail investors in Singapore to buy into a new ready-made and professionally-managed portfolio, modelled after its private banking unit’s flagship “barbell” product.

site_title: BP boosts buybacks as profit soars to highest in over decade
summary: BP reported its strongest quarterly earnings in over a decade, with a net profit of $6.2 billion, driven by strong oil and gas trading results and higher oil prices. Despite a $24 billion writedown on Russia, the company boosted its share buyback program to $2.5 billion and maintained its dividend. The exit from Russia will not impact BP's plan to shift away from oil and gas towards renewables, according to CEO Bernard Looney.

images.alt_text: BP says will pull its capital from Russia's Rosneft
Anyone selling Russian assets faces few options, big losses

site_title: Seoul: Stocks little changed; 10-year treasury yield hits 8-year high
summary: South Korean stocks traded nearly flat on May 3, with investors taking a breather ahead of the US Federal Reserves' monetary policy meeting. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.2% to 2,692.14, while the 10-year treasury yield hit an 8-year high at 3.383%. Foreigners were net buyers of 32 billion won worth of shares. Consumer prices in South Korea rose 4.69% in April, the fastest pace in 13.5 years, with energy and food prices driving the increase.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened on the back foot Tuesday (May 3) morning as investors returned from a long weekend break to play catch-up with losses in Asia the previous day, and following a strong end to last week.
Financial markets in China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia and Singapore are closed on Tuesday (May 3) for public holidays.

site_title: US senators seek to loosen Google’s grip on digital ad market
summary: US senators are set to introduce legislation that would force Alphabet Inc's Google to sell off parts of its lucrative advertising technology business, citing concerns over the company's dominance in the digital ad market. The bill, led by Senator Mike Lee, would bar companies with over $20 billion in digital ad revenue from owning ad-buying and selling tools, and require those with over $5 billion in revenue to act in customers' best interests. This move aims to increase transparency and competition in the digital ad market.

images.alt_text: Alphabet's Google has begun entertaining people's requests to remove search results containing their home addresses, phone numbers and email accounts, the latest shift in its stance between personal privacy and access to information.
In its first-quarter earnings report, the company posted YouTube ad-revenue growth of 14 per cent, falling short of analyst expectations.
Alphabet sank on Tuesday after the internet giant reported that earnings in the recently ended quarter missed market expectations, with profit down from a year earlier.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on September 14, 2021 The Apple logo is seen at the entrance of an Apple store in Washington, DC. - Apple reported better-than-expected profits Thursday on robust consumer demand for its devices and services even as revenue growth slowed while it navigated an ongoing semiconductor supply crunch.
The technology giant reported quarterly earnings of $25 billion, up 5.8 percent from the year-ago period as revenues rose nine percent to $97.3 billion. (Photo by Nicholas Kamm / AFP)

site_title: France's BNP Paribas posts a 19.2% rise in first-quarter net profit
summary: France's BNP Paribas posted a 19.2% rise in first-quarter net profit to 2.1 billion euros, driven by a 47.9% increase in fixed-income, currency, and commodities trading and a 60.9% surge in equity trading revenue. The bank maintained its 2025 financial targets, including a return of 60% of net income to investors. Despite a 41% gain in 2021, BNP Paribas shares have lost nearly 20% so far this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BNP Paribas logo is seen at a branch in Paris, France, February 4, 2020. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Supply chains snarl Taiwan tech firms as some strive to meet demand
summary: Taiwanese tech suppliers are facing supply constraints despite soaring demand, with some struggling to secure inputs such as packing materials. The island nation is a key supplier to the global electronics ecosystem, providing components for products like refrigerators, smartphones, cars, and missiles. Companies in the industry face challenges in securing inputs from China, which is still recovering from Covid-19 lockdowns. This has created both opportunities and problems for Taiwanese tech firms, highlighting the complexities of the global supply chain.

images.alt_text: APPLE predicted that supply constraints would cost US$4 billion to US$8 billion in revenue during the current quarter, a warning that sent the shares tumbling and cast a pall on record-setting results that the company just reported.

TAIWAN'S economy grew at a slower pace in the first quarter compared with the previous 3 months but still performed better than expected, supported by strong tech exports and global demand for chips but affected by weaker consumer confidence.
Taiwan's strongest economic expansion in a decade likely cooled in the first quarter, and China's Covid lockdowns may pose challenges to growth in the months ahead.

site_title: Adverse patterns of interest
summary: The S&P 500 index is developing a head-and-shoulder reversal pattern, indicating a potential change from an uptrend to a downtrend. The pattern, confirmed by a retreat from the index's resistance feature in September 2021, a peak in January 2022, and a failure to rebound to previous highs, sets a downside target of 3650. The pattern is driven by rising interest rates and inflation, with oil prices contributing but not being the primary driver. Investors are advised to sell long positions and wait for the market to consolidate near the target level before opening new long positions.

images.alt_text: What do geopolitical turmoil and conflict do to markets?

site_title: Logitech quarterly sales fall 20%, cuts outlook for 2023
summary: Logitech reported a 20% drop in quarterly sales to $1.2 billion, down from $1.5 billion a year earlier. The decline was due to high comparables from the previous year, when sales were boosted by the Covid-19 pandemic. Logitech also reduced its fiscal year 2023 outlook, removing estimates for sales and profits in Ukraine and Russia.

site_title: Profiles of finance superstars and exploring the 'perfect portfolio'
summary: A book titled "In Pursuit of the Perfect Portfolio" by Andrew W. Lo and Stephen R. Foerster concludes that there is no perfect portfolio. The authors profile 10 finance superstars, including Harry Markowitz, William Sharpe, and Jeremy Siegel, who contributed to the development of various investing concepts. Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger, notable value investors, are noticeably absent, with only brief mentions due to Buffett's directive to prioritize a low-cost S&P 500 Index fund. The book highlights the complexities and uncertainties of investing, suggesting that no single portfolio can guarantee success.

images.alt_text: Index fund industry: Behind one of the greatest financial revolutions of the last 50 years

site_title: New York Amazon workers deal setback to union drive
summary: Amazon workers at a Staten Island facility in New York have rejected unionization efforts, voting 62% against the union push. The result follows a landmark win for the Amazon Labor Union (ALU) at a nearby warehouse just a month prior. The ALU acknowledged the setback, stating the fight has just begun and that organizing will continue. Amazon has been accused of aggressively campaigning to quash momentum from the earlier victory, and the company is challenging the ALU's previous win, which is set for a hearing on May 23.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen at an Amazon facility in Staten Island, New York City, U.S., April 24, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
