site_title: Musk seeks to put in less money in new Twitter deal financing: sources
summary: Elon Musk is in talks with large investment firms and high net-worth individuals to reduce his financial contribution to the $44 billion acquisition of Twitter. Musk, the world's richest person, has committed $21 billion in cash and secured a $12.5 billion margin loan against his Tesla shares. He may seek to trim the margin loan and secure preferred equity financing, which would pay a fixed dividend and appreciate in line with the equity value of the company. This move aims to reduce Musk's wealth contribution and ease concerns about his reliance on Tesla shares for the deal financing.

images.alt_text: TWITTER estimated in a filing on Monday (May 2) that false or spam accounts represented fewer than 5 per cent of its monetisable daily active users during the first quarter.
TWITTER'S US$44 billion deal to be acquired by Elon Musk means it risks losing advertisers and employees, who may be concerned about the company’s uncertain future.
Elon Musk disclosed an additional US$4.5b worth of Tesla stock sales in new regulatory filings on Friday, bringing his total this week to US$8.5 billion in the wake of his deal to buy Twitter.

site_title: In bid to boost Peacock, Universal sending 3 movies straight to streaming
summary: Universal Pictures is sending three new movies straight to streaming service Peacock when they debut in 2023, in a bid to boost the platform's growth. The films include a biopic about LeBron James, a remake of John Woo's 1989 crime drama The Killer, and a music-competition feature set in the world of youth choir. This move is part of Peacock's strategy to compete with other streaming services, as the platform has gained over 13 million paid subscribers and 28 million monthly active accounts in the US.

images.alt_text: Amazon's Prime Video launched a movie rental service in India on Thursday, promising to release more than forty original series and movies over the next 2 years in a key market.

The Asia-Pacific region was the lone bright spot in Netflix’s first-quarter earnings, in which the world’s dominant streaming service reported it lost subscribers for the first time in more than a decade.
Netflix plans lower-priced service with ads, marking big shift

site_title: Australia's Woolworths says inflation its main concern as Q3 sales jump
summary: Australia's largest supermarket chain, Woolworths Group, reported a 4.4% jump in food sales for the March quarter to A$11.4 billion, beating rival Coles Group. Despite rising inflation and input costs, Woolworths managed to keep food prices at 2.7% due to consumer stockpiling. The company's overall sales grew 9.7% to A$15.1 billion, but managing inflation remains a main concern for Woolworths.

images.alt_text: Investment merits shine through for AA Reit in 'transformational' acquisition of Woolworths HQ
Aims Apac Reit to acquire Woolsworth HQ in Sydney for A$463m

site_title: Twitter estimates spam, fake accounts comprise less than 5% of users: filing
summary: Twitter has estimated that less than 5% of its users are false or spam accounts, representing around 11.5 million accounts out of 229 million monetisable daily active users in the first quarter. The social media company faces risks until its deal with Elon Musk is closed, including uncertainty over advertisers' spending and the company's future plans. Musk has prioritized removing "spam bots" from the platform after inking a $44 billion deal to buy Twitter.

site_title: Legoland Malaysia: Keeping it fun even in bad times
summary: Legoland Malaysia has adapted to the pandemic by going online to engage with Lego fans and generating revenue through online sales. Despite the 2-year closure, the theme park has reset and refreshed itself, exploring new ideas to attract visitors. The park is now focusing on experiential dining, such as Sea Life Malaysia's "underwater" dining experience, and has seen increasing ticket sales and room bookings since Malaysia's borders reopened. Legoland Malaysia remains confident in its exclusivity and competitiveness, with a strong pipeline of activities to attract local and international tourists.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng

site_title: Singapore's Shopee authorised to operate as payment institution in Brazil
summary: Singaporean e-commerce app Shopee, owned by Sea, has been authorised by Brazil's central bank to operate as a payment institution. The approval allows Shopee to manage prepaid payment accounts, with funds deposited beforehand. This move comes as Shopee has become one of the most-downloaded e-commerce apps in Brazil, attracting users from local companies with its low-cost marketplace.

site_title: Activision’s Kotick could see US$520m on Microsoft deal
summary: Activision CEO Bobby Kotick could receive up to $520 million from Microsoft's $95-per-share purchase of the video game publishing giant. Kotick owns 4.3 million shares and has the right to acquire another 2.2 million through options, making his total potential payout over $520 million. This comes despite recent controversy over Kotick's leadership, including employee complaints over sexism and mismanagement of assault claims.

images.alt_text: The company’s quarterly adjusted sales stood at US1.48 billion, compared with analysts’ estimates of US$1.80 billion, according to Refinitiv IBES data.
Activision tells regulators it will cooperate with insider trading investigation

site_title: Enough nickel, lithium for 14m EVs in 2023: European climate group
summary: A European climate group, Transport and Environment (T&E), says there's enough nickel and lithium to produce up to 14 million electric vehicles globally in 2023, allowing Europe to shift away from oil faster. Excluding Russian nickel, there should be enough raw materials for 19 million EVs in 2025. T&E urges Europe to secure more raw materials and establish an agency to ensure sustainable sourcing of critical metals.

images.alt_text: TAIWAN'S Delta Electronics, a supplier of power components to companies such as Apple and Tesla, is expanding manufacturing "everywhere" on a boom in electric vehicles (EV) and servers, it said on Friday (Apr 29).

CATL, the world's largest electric vehicle (EV) battery manufacturer, reported a 23.6 per cent drop in the first quarter profit on Friday (Apr 29), its first fall in 2 years, as it battles soaring raw material costs and a resurgence of Covid-19 in China.
TATA Motors expects to aggressively ramp up annual production of electric vehicles (EVs) to more than 80,000 units this financial year, sources with knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Call of the wild: Singapore businesses still keen on emerging markets
summary: Singapore businesses remain keen on emerging markets, with 30% of overseas projects facilitated by Enterprise Singapore in 2020 involving the Middle East and Africa, Central and Eastern Europe, and Latin America. Despite the pandemic hiatus, overseas trips and trade fairs are set to resume, with Singapore biotech startup Stratificare planning to restart clinical studies in Mexico. Global uncertainties, however, continue to pose challenges for businesses, with ongoing trade tensions and economic uncertainty in countries like the UK and US.

site_title: Citi in 'active dialogue' to sell Russia consumer business, CEO says
summary: Citi CEO Jane Fraser confirmed the bank is in "active dialogue" to sell its Russia consumer business, announced a year ago, amid economic sanctions. The sale is part of Citi's efforts to shrink its exposures and stop soliciting new business in Russia. Fraser noted that western sanctions are prompting international clients to explore alternative trade and finance routes, potentially accelerating the recognition of emerging markets and their domestic capital markets.

site_title: Alibaba recovers after report on 'Ma' briefly erased US$26b
summary: Chinese authorities imposed "compulsory curbs" on an individual surnamed Ma, briefly sparking concern over Alibaba Group Holding co-founder Jack Ma's status, triggering a 9.4% plunge in Hong Kong shares and erasing about $26 billion of market value. The curbs were later clarified to involve a director of an IT company, and Alibaba's shares rebounded after a statement from Hangzhou police. The incident highlights ongoing investor anxiety toward China's tech sector amid a year-long crackdown.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signs of Alibaba Group and Ant Group are seen during the World Internet Conference (WIC) in Wuzhen, Zhejiang province, China, November 23, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Archegos indictment raises fresh questions over banks' risk management controls
summary: Archegos Capital Management founder Bill Hwang and CFO Patrick Halligan were arrested on charges of lying to banks to increase credit lines and manipulate stock prices. The indictment reveals red flags that banks could have acted on to reduce exposure, including the fund's lack of transparency and aggressive trading practices. Global lenders, including Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley, suffered losses of around $10 billion after Archegos defaulted in 2021. The incident raises questions about banks' risk management controls and potential civil regulator implications.

images.alt_text: Federal prosecutors said Hwang used Archegos as an “instrument of market manipulation and fraud,” inflating its portfolio from US$1.5 billion to US35 billion before it imploded and caused massive losses for banks, financial market investors and its own employees.
US Fed says banks must keep better tabs on risks after Archegos
SEC investigating Archegos for potential market manipulation

site_title: Oil settles up on distillate strength, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures gaining 44 US cents to settle at $107.58 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 48 cents to settle at $105.17 a barrel. A rally in the diesel market and concerns over a potential European Union ban on Russian crude drove the gains. However, the EU's plans to ban Russian oil imports by the end of the year may have weighed on prices, with Hungary and Slovakia potentially spared from the embargo.

site_title: Citi says trader error behind flash crash in European stocks
summary: Citi's London trading desk blamed a trader error for a flash crash in European stocks, which sent shares tumbling after a sudden 8% decline in Swedish stocks. The error caused a knee-jerk sell-off, toppling the main European index by as much as 3% and wiping out 300 billion euros. Citigroup is in talks with regulators and exchanges, and Nasdaq Stockholm has excluded technical issues and external attacks from its systems. The incident may cause monetary and reputational damage to Citi.

images.alt_text: European stocks closed lower on Monday (May 2), in a session that marked sharp losses after a sudden brief crash, while downbeat China factory data sparked worries of a sharp economic slowdown.

site_title: US Treasury sees economy still expanding in 2022 despite Q1 GDP drop
summary: The US Treasury expects the economy to continue expanding in 2022 despite a surprise 1.4% contraction in the first quarter. Assistant Secretary for Economic Policy Benjamin Harris stated that inflation may be peaking, citing waning fiscal and monetary stimulus and recovering labor supply. Downside risks remain to the outlook, but Harris said the economy is expected to continue growing, with potential downward revisions to private GDP forecasts for 2.3% growth on a fourth-quarter comparison.

images.alt_text: ALL tools are on the table to address rising inflation, including reductions of tariffs on Chinese imports, US Trade Representative Katherine Tai said on Monday (May 2), but she stressed that any policy shift needed to keep medium-term goals in mind.

Inflation, running near historic highs, has turned the Fed hawkish.

site_title: HSBC shares rise as markets warm up to break-up proposal by top shareholder
summary: HSBC shares rose 1.9% in Hong Kong trade on May 3 after its largest shareholder, Chinese insurance giant Ping An, called for a break-up of the London-based bank. Ping An urged HSBC to consider spinning off its Asian business, where it earns two-thirds of its pre-tax profits, or taking other steps to boost its valuation. HSBC has not commented on the proposal but defended its overall strategy, with Chief Executive Noel Quinn focusing on wealth management in Asia to drive growth.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings’ largest shareholder, Chinese insurance giant Ping An, has called for a break-up of the London-based bank.

Hong Kong stocks opened on the back foot Tuesday (May 3) morning as investors returned from a long weekend break to play catch-up with losses in Asia the previous day, and following a strong end to last week.

site_title: US trade chief Tai says all tools on table to beat inflation, tariffs not top of list
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai stated that all tools are on the table to address rising inflation, including potential reductions in tariffs on Chinese imports. However, she emphasized that any policy shift must align with the administration's medium-term goals, such as building a resilient global economy. Tai downplayed speculation about a larger-scale tariff reduction, citing a recent study that she challenged as either fictional or an academic exercise.

site_title: Rocket Lab catches, drops rocket booster with helicopter in key reusability test
summary: Rocket Lab successfully captured a falling rocket stage with a helicopter before dropping it in the ocean, achieving a partially successful test of its cost-saving approach to reusing used rockets. The test involved a 4-story-tall Electron booster stage deployed parachutes and deployed a capture line, which was latched onto by the helicopter. However, the rocket was released due to "different load characteristics" and splashed down safely in the Pacific Ocean. Rocket Lab CEO Peter Beck downplayed the incident, stating the rocket was recovered and the ship was loading it, but it's unclear if the booster will be reused.

images.alt_text: Small rocket builder Rocket Lab USA is gearing up for a mission that seems more appropriate for a big-budget action movie: catching a falling four-story-tall rocket booster with a helicopter.

site_title: EU prepares next Russia sanctions including German-backed oil ban
summary: The European Union is preparing to impose sanctions on Russian oil sales, including a possible embargo, following Germany's decision to stop buying Russian oil. The EU's energy policy chief, Kadri Simson, plans to present a plan to replace two-thirds of its Russian gas use by the end of 2022. The sanctions are part of a sixth package of EU sanctions against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Though seen as one of the most quintessential of Japanese foods - and eaten on New Year’s Eve for good luck - a good part of the buckwheat that goes into the noodles comes from Russia, globally the top buckwheat producer.
The European Union flags flutter ahead of the gas talks between the EU, Russia and Ukraine at the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium.
A European Union flag flutters outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium.

site_title: Barclays hires 18 from Credit Suisse in prime-brokerage push
summary: Barclays has hired 18 people from Credit Suisse's prime-brokerage unit, mostly in the US, as part of its push to expand in the business. The new hires include Tom Luglio and John Dlubac, who will join Barclays as managing directors. The move comes as Barclays continues to invest in its prime brokerage division, which saw financing income soar since 2018. The bank's prime brokerage ranked 5th globally last year, up from 9th five years earlier, and CEO CS Venkatakrishnan attributes the growth to investments in the division.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher ahead of Fed meeting
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, May 2, despite the 10-year Treasury note's yield hitting 3% for the first time in nearly 4 years ahead of the Federal Reserve's expected rate hike. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3%, the S&P 500 rose 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.6%. The Fed is expected to increase the benchmark lending rate by a half-point step, raising concerns of overdoing it and tipping the economy into recession.

images.alt_text: The pan-European STOXX 600 index dropped 0.8 per cent, set to snap a 3-day session of gains, with trading volumes thinned by a UK bank holiday.

A busy week of earnings that saw big swings in the equity market was capped off on Friday by a disappointing report from Amazon, whose shares tumbled 14 per cent and dragged the S&P500 down 3.6 per cent on the day.

site_title: Over 59m shares reserved for anchor investors in LIC IPO
summary: The Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) of India, the country's largest insurer, has successfully completed its initial public offering (IPO) with 59.3 million shares reserved for anchor investors being subscribed at 949 rupees apiece. The Indian government aims to raise up to $2.74 billion from the sale of a 3.5% stake in LIC, a third of its original target.

images.alt_text: LIC’s IPO, which had previously been touted as India’s Aramco moment in reference to Gulf oil giant Saudi Arabian Oil’s US$29.4 billion listing in 2019, will test the depth of India’s capital market.
INDIA chose to slash the size of its biggest initial public offering (IPO) by about 60 per cent and press ahead with the sale next week as investor demand wanes amid the war in Ukraine.
FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai, India, January 31, 2020. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo##########ipo11##########

site_title: Gold prices slide 2% as yields, dollar gain ahead of Fed meet
summary: Gold prices fell 2% to a near 3-month low on May 2 as the Federal Reserve's increased prospects of faster rate hikes lifted US Treasury yields and the dollar. This led to a 1.5% decline in spot gold to $1,867.24 per ounce and a 2.3% drop in US gold futures to $1,868.40. The stronger dollar and rising yields amid hawkish Fed expectations put pressure on the gold market, according to Phillip Streible, chief market strategist.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 0.3 per cent at US$1,890.69 per ounce, as of 0053 GMT. US gold futures dropped 1 per cent to US$1,893.40.

site_title: Energy Transfer to sell LNG to Singapore unit of trading house Gunvor
summary: US pipeline company Energy Transfer signed a 20-year deal to supply 2 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) per annum to Gunvor Group's Singapore unit, starting from 2026. The LNG will be sourced from Energy Transfer's Lake Charles project in Louisiana. This deal follows recent LNG supply agreements with China's ENN Natural Gas and ENN Energy Holdings, and NextDecade Corp's agreement with French energy group Engie. The surge in natural gas prices due to Western sanctions on Russian supply has prompted gas companies to rush into new deals.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mark bleak start to May, hit by brief crash
summary: European stocks closed lower on Monday, May 2, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index dropping 1.5% after a sudden brief crash. The decline followed downbeat China factory data, sparking concerns of a sharp economic slowdown. The crash was attributed to a "flash trade" or an erroneous trade, which led to a 3% drop in the Stoxx 600 earlier in the day. Trading volumes were thinned due to a UK bank holiday.

images.alt_text: Equities on Wall Street ended higher on Monday (May 2) even as the 10-year Treasury note’s yield hit 3 per cent for the first time in nearly 4 years ahead of the Federal Reserve’s expected rate hike.
The pan-European STOXX 600 index dropped 0.8 per cent, set to snap a 3-day session of gains, with trading volumes thinned by a UK bank holiday.

site_title: Civilians evacuated from Ukraine’s Mariupol but many remain trapped
summary: Russia continues its assault on Ukraine's south and eastern Donbas region, with Moscow stepping up its efforts to crush resistance. Civilians remain trapped in the besieged city of Mariupol, where hundreds are running out of food, water, and medicine. Meanwhile, the EU is set to discuss a response to Russia's demand that European buyers pay for Russian gas in roubles, amid concerns of a potential energy crisis. The conflict has already flattened cities, killed thousands of civilians, and displaced over 5 million people, with the international community calling for an end to the violence.

images.alt_text: Local resident Oksana Khvostenko, 47, stands near her house, which was heavily damaged during Ukraine-Russia conflict in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine, April 29, 2022.

site_title: Gokongwei-backed cloud kitchen startup raises US$3m to fight 'delivery fatigue'
summary: The Kraver's Group, a cloud kitchen startup backed by Lance Gokongwei and Christopher Po, has raised US$3 million in Series A funding led by Singapore's Quest Ventures. The 2-year-old startup plans to fight "delivery fatigue" by investing in its own virtual food concepts and gamifying the customer experience. Founded by entrepreneurs Eric Dee, Victor Lim, and Victor Mapua, Kraver's has built a network of 11 cloud kitchens and aims to expand to 100 by 2025. The funding will be used to further invest in its own online food brands and customer experience.

South-east Asian F&B startups raised record US$461m in 2021

site_title: Expedia results are in line as Omicron weights on pent-up demand
summary: Expedia reported a 80% revenue jump in its first quarter, exceeding analyst estimates, as pent-up travel demand surged after two years of COVID-19 restrictions. Revenue reached $2.25 billion, with gross bookings of $24.4 billion, and CEO Peter Kern signaled a strong summer travel season despite early Omicron impact and the war in Ukraine. Travel executives predict a busy summer, with airlines boosting capacity and Southwest Airlines expecting profitability despite high oil prices.

site_title: Lending startups face investor scrutiny as interest rates rise
summary: Lending startups are facing increased scrutiny as rising interest rates make capital more expensive. Industry observers believe these startups can pass on the increased costs to customers with minimal impact, but rising interest rates may lead to higher default rates. The unbanked segment these startups target is more likely to accept higher interest rates, but competition from "buy now, pay later" schemes may limit the rates fintechs can charge. The ability to attract cheap debt funding will be crucial for success, and credit scoring models may struggle to adapt to changing economic conditions, potentially leading to a profitability squeeze across the BNPL sector.

site_title: Apple faces EU antitrust charges over Apple Pay
summary: European Union regulators have charged Apple with breaking antitrust laws by unfairly undercutting rival payment services, including PayPal. Apple allegedly blocks access to near-field communication technology, or NFC, which enables in-store payments, to maintain its dominance in the market. The European Commission's preliminary judgment claims Apple has abused its position in the consumer electronics market, hindering the growth of competing payment services.

images.alt_text: Apple's Cook says circumventing app store would harm user privacy

site_title: Johnny Depp was to have earned US$22.5m for 'Pirates' 6: agent
summary: Johnny Depp was set to earn $22.5 million for a sixth Pirates of the Caribbean movie, but the project was scrapped by Disney after his ex-wife Amber Heard accused him of domestic abuse in a Washington Post op-ed. According to Depp's agent, Jack Whigham, the deal was verbal and there was no signed contract, but Disney decided to go in a "different direction" following the op-ed's publication in December 2018. The op-ed was "catastrophic" for Depp's Hollywood career, Whigham testified, and he was unable to secure another studio film.

images.alt_text: Johnny Depp calls Amber Heard accusations 'heinous', says he never struck ex-wife
Johnny Depp lawyers seek to discredit ex-wife domestic violence claims

site_title: Twitter says Musk deal risks costing employees, advertisers
summary: Twitter's $44 billion acquisition deal with Elon Musk risks losing advertisers and employees due to uncertainty about the company's future. The company has paused hiring and app updates, citing difficulties in attracting and retaining key people and potential productivity decline. Twitter may struggle to make changes to its business until the deal is completed, and any disruptions could affect the company's stock. The acquisition's outcome could also impact the company's relationships with business partners, further exacerbating potential losses.

site_title: Singapore companies pivot amid shifting sands in the Middle East
summary: Singapore companies are adapting to shifting opportunities in the Middle East, despite some operations being closed. Enterprise Singapore has two remaining locations in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Dubai, UAE, while others, such as CapitaLand and City Developments, continue to operate in the region through different ventures. These companies are focusing on greenfield markets like Qatar, where they see opportunities for growth and expansion, driven by technological advancements and a growing market.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

Of the overseas projects that Enterprise Singapore facilitated for 315 companies in 2020, some 30 per cent of the deals involved the Middle East and Africa; Central and Eastern Europe and Central Asia; and Latin America and the Caribbean.

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong addressing the Pacific Alliance presidential summit in Bahia Malaga, Colombia, on Jan 26, 2022.

site_title: Cheer returns for Malaysia theme park operators as borders reopen
summary: Malaysia's theme park operators are experiencing a surge in revenue as international borders reopen, with Sunway Theme Parks and Sim Leisure reporting a 90% and 10% recovery in revenue, respectively. The country expects 2 million international tourists this year, generating up to RM8.6 billion in tourism revenue. Theme parks were closed for 15 months, but pent-up demand has led to a significant increase in footfall, with some parks seeing record attendance. This growth momentum is expected to continue as international tourists seek to make up for lost travel time.

images.alt_text: As Malaysia reopens to the world, airlines see healthy pick-up in flight bookings
Malaysia's hoteliers report brisk business since borders reopened

site_title: Air travel bustles but Malaysia Airlines far from out of the woods
summary: Malaysia Airlines is showing signs of improvement after the pandemic, with its parent company, Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG), reversing a 2020 operating loss of RM1.8 billion to a positive Ebitda of RM433 million for 2021. The airline's restructuring and reduced costs contributed to the improved showing, with its cargo arm earning RM3 billion in revenue. However, challenges persist, including rising fuel prices and interest rates, which may impact the airline's ability to break even in 2023. The carrier's goal to restore its fortunes is still uncertain, with analysts questioning how management will grow the business and become profitable.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Oil falls on China growth concerns even as EU weighs Russia import ban
summary: Oil prices fell 1.1% to $105.93 a barrel, amid concerns about China's slowing economic growth, which is the world's top oil importer. The drop came despite fears of potential supply disruptions from a looming European Union ban on Russian crude. Markets were closed in Asia due to public holidays, with China's factory activity contracting for a second month to its lowest since February 2020 due to Covid-19 lockdowns. The EU ban is expected to be announced soon, adding to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The European Union flags flutter ahead of the gas talks between the EU, Russia and Ukraine at the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium.

site_title: War has not dimmed shine of Central and Eastern Europe
summary: Singapore companies remain interested in Central and Eastern Europe, citing opportunities in environmental sustainability, logistics, and emerging industries like fintech and edtech. Despite the war in Ukraine, which has caused disruptions in Russia and Belarus, the region's "young and tech-savvy clientele" and EU membership have not deterred investors. Singapore-based companies like Food Empire and Lesont Group continue to explore expansion plans in the region, with some anticipating minimal disruption to operations. The Central and Eastern European Chamber of Commerce notes that the war has not diminished trust in the region.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

Of the overseas projects that Enterprise Singapore facilitated for 315 companies in 2020, some 30 per cent of the deals involved the Middle East and Africa; Central and Eastern Europe and Central Asia; and Latin America and the Caribbean.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide in glum start to May, hit by brief crash
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% on Monday, snapping a 3-day gain, amid worries of a sharp economic slowdown sparked by China's factory data contraction and COVID-19 lockdowns. The pan-European STOXX 600 index dropped 0.8% and reached a 3% drop earlier, while trading volumes were thinned by a UK bank holiday. The decline was also driven by concerns over the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike and the conflict in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: European shares on Friday rose to their highest in a week.

site_title: Pacific trade deal gives greater access to Latin America
summary: Singapore and the Pacific Alliance countries of Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru signed the Pacific Alliance-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (PASFTA) in January, boosting access to multiple regional markets. Firms in the green economy, such as those in Chile and Colombia, may benefit from the agreement, while Singapore-based companies like Royal Golden Eagle have invested heavily in Brazil's infrastructure and commodities sectors. The pact is part of Singapore's efforts to strengthen ties with Latin America, including digital economy agreements and participation in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

Lee Hsien Loong, Singapore's prime minister, speaks virtually during the XVI Presidential Summit of the Pacific Alliance in Bahia Malaga, Colombia, on Wednesday, Jan. 26, 2022. site_title: Netflix drops Meghan Markle's animated series 'Pearl'
summary: Netflix has dropped Meghan Markle's animated series "Pearl" as part of its review of animated content. The decision comes after the company reported a loss of 200,000 subscribers in the first quarter, falling short of its forecast. Netflix will continue to work on projects with Archewell Productions, including the documentary series "Heart of Invictus". The company has also canceled two other animated children's series, "Dino Daycare" and "Boons and Curses".

images.alt_text: The Asia-Pacific region was the lone bright spot in Netflix’s first-quarter earnings, in which the world’s dominant streaming service reported it lost subscribers for the first time in more than a decade.

site_title: Amazon to get hearing that could overturn NY union vote, labor board official says
summary: Amazon is seeking a hearing to potentially overturn the unionization vote at its JFK8 warehouse in New York City, where 55% of employees voted to join the Amazon Labor Union. The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) official cited Amazon's 25 objections, including claims of labor organizer intimidation, as grounds for a hearing that could invalidate the election's outcome. The process could take weeks, but Amazon's attorney said the bar for a hearing is "very low" and the union remains confident its objections will be overruled.

images.alt_text: Amazon calls for election re-run after workers voted for first US union
For years, Amazon prohibited employees from having their phones on warehouse floors and required them to leave them in their vehicles or in lockers near breakrooms.

site_title: MGM Resorts offers to buy Sweden's LeoVegas for US$607m
summary: MGM Resorts International offered to acquire Swedish online gaming company LeoVegas AB for approximately $607 million, aiming to expand its presence in Europe. The recommended public tender offer represents a 44.2% premium to LeoVegas' last closing price. MGM has been capitalizing on the sports-betting arena through its joint venture BetMGM, which forecasts over $1.3 billion in revenue for 2022. The acquisition would allow MGM to strengthen its European presence and capitalize on growing demand for online gaming.

site_title: Dollar rises towards 20-year high, euro dips after weak data
summary: The US dollar rose towards a 20-year high, gaining 5% in April, its best monthly performance since January 2015. The euro struggled around the US$1.05 mark after weak data showed eurozone manufacturing output growth stalled. Investors await a busy week of central bank meetings, including a likely Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: The greenback gave back some gains on Friday as investors took profits, but still ended the month strong.

site_title: Wind turbine maker Vestas cuts margin outlook as Ukraine war bites
summary: Wind turbine maker Vestas slashed its full-year operating profit margin outlook due to the war in Ukraine and writedowns in its offshore business. The company reported a deeper-than-expected first-quarter operating loss, with costs related to the war totaling 401 million euros. Vestas now expects a margin of between minus 5% and 0% on earnings before interest and tax, down from a previous range of 0-4%. The company also reduced its sales forecast to 14.5-16 billion euros.

images.alt_text: The European Union flags flutter ahead of the gas talks between the EU, Russia and Ukraine at the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium.

site_title:
Deutsche Bank shareholders shouldn’t 
absolve leaders: adviser
summary: Proxy adviser Glass Lewis has recommended that Deutsche Bank shareholders abstain from voting on ratification proposals until the outcome of ongoing legal investigations into the lender's asset manager DWS Group and management board member are resolved. The investigations involve allegations of tax evasion and money laundering. Glass Lewis also criticized the bank's remuneration report, citing excessive base salaries and poor disclosure. Deutsche Bank's CEO Christian Sewing and departing Supervisory Board chairman Paul Achleitner will seek to highlight the bank's turnaround over the past three years at the upcoming AGM.

images.alt_text: INVESTIGATORS searched the offices of Germany’s biggest lender Deutsche Bank on Friday, prosecutors said, with the focus on the bank’s anti-money-laundering activities.

site_title: Australia home prices keep rising even as Sydney, Melbourne cool
summary: Australian home prices continued to rise in April, despite a cooling in Sydney and Melbourne, with a 0.6% national increase and a 16.7% year-over-year gain. Regional cities such as Brisbane, Perth, and Adelaide saw significant price growth, while the combined capital cities saw a 0.3% increase. Experts attribute the resilience to migration rates, low advertised stock levels, and strong economic conditions. However, the market faces headwinds as the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hike interest rates for the first time in a decade, potentially impacting affordability.

images.alt_text: Australia's annual inflation rate hit 5.1 per cent in the March quarter, the highest recorded since 2001, according to official data released on Wednesday.

site_title: Embattled UK PM Johnson faces mid-term test
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a mid-term test as voters go to the polls in local elections on May 5. The elections will gauge support for Johnson's Conservative government and the opposition Labour party, with Labour expected to win the most seats in England. Johnson's position has been fragile due to lockdown-breaking parties at Downing Street and an inflationary surge. A police investigation and damaging claims have led to calls for his resignation, but Russia's invasion of Ukraine has taken attention away from any mutiny. The outcome could determine Johnson's future and the long-term future of the UK.

images.alt_text: Boris Johnson to face MPs' fury over 'partygate'

site_title: Deliveroo suspends pay cut for UAE delivery riders after rare worker strike
summary: Deliveroo has suspended plans to cut rider earnings in the UAE after a rare strike by foreign delivery workers over working conditions. The strike, which disrupted services, prompted Deliveroo to pause plans and engage with riders to ensure a structure that works for everyone. The company will not implement the proposed 15% pay cut and 12-hour shifts, and will work with riders to ensure their "best interest is at heart." Authorities in the UAE did not respond to requests for comment, amid criticism of the treatment of low-paid migrant workers in the Gulf state.

images.alt_text: Deliveroo, FFTH deliver joy to the underprivileged

site_title: There can be life without Russian gas
summary: Chile successfully weaned itself off a key energy supply source, Argentine natural gas, in 2007, after 90% of deliveries stopped due to domestic supply difficulties. The country's emergency measures included building liquefied natural gas terminals, expanding solar and wind power, and launching an energy-efficiency campaign. Chile's experience offers lessons for European countries that may soon lose access to Russian gas, with the potential reward being freedom from energy blackmail and a greener, more resilient future. The cost may be significant, but Chile's example shows that it's possible to transition to alternative energy sources and reduce dependence on a single supplier.

images.alt_text: As they stop promoting coal and oil, governments must keep up the momentum behind renewables.

site_title: The extraordinary wealth created by the pandemic housing market
summary: The US housing market has experienced a significant wealth creation event over the past two years, with Americans gaining $6 trillion in housing wealth. This growth is largely due to the pandemic's high demand and low supply, resulting in record-breaking price increases. However, the wealthiest households have seen the largest gains, while the poorest fifth of households have added $600 million in home equity. Economists warn that this wealth is not evenly distributed and may exacerbate the housing affordability crisis, as rents and inflation continue to rise.

images.alt_text: THE average interest rate on the most popular US home loan rose to its highest level since June 2009 last week and demand for mortgages ebbed as the impact of rising costs began to bite, Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data showed on Wednesday (Apr 27).

site_title: China contagion threatens to derail world’s emerging markets
summary: China's COVID-19 outbreaks and strict policies are causing a global sell-off in emerging markets, threatening growth and disrupting supply chains. The offshore yuan has sunk to a 12-year worst monthly loss, and emerging markets have seen a 30% decline in the MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index. China's economic growth target of 5.5% is now in question, and analysts predict currency losses and lower growth rates in countries like South Africa and Brazil. Money managers have downgraded their currency outlook for emerging markets, citing China's economic travails and increased contagion risk.

images.alt_text: UBS said in a report in February that the revenue pool for private banking service providers in China is foreseen within a wide range between 224 billion yuan and 1.03 trillion yuan in 2030, as the common prosperity drive could bring more uncertainties to entrepreneurship.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip 1.1% in April; market cap falls to S$875b
summary: Singapore's stock market declined 1.1% in April, with a total market capitalisation of S$874.8 billion, snapping a 2-month growth streak due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict. Losers outnumbered gainers 259 to 227 among the 657 listed counters on the Singapore Exchange. The market capitalisation of SGX Mainboard counters fell 1% to S$864.4 billion, while Catalist-listed counters dropped 4.5% to S$10.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
A man wearing a protective face mask walks past the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in the central business district on 24 February 2022.

site_title: For Tottenham, a big win worth more than just 3 points
summary: Tottenham Hotspur defeated Leicester City 3-1 in the English Premier League on May 1, 2022, with goals from Son Heung-min and Harry Kane. The match drew a crowd of 59,482 fans from around the world, including 346 official supporters' clubs from 16 different nationalities. The win marked a significant step for Tottenham, currently fifth in the standings, as they vie for a spot in the Champions League. The match also raised funds for the Grant A Wish with AIA Better Lives Fund initiative, with match-worn jerseys to be auctioned off to support good causes in Singapore and the club's foundation.

Left to right: Dejan Kulusevski, Eric Dier, Harry Winks, Lucas Moura. Tottenham Hotspur players will wear jerseys with 'AIA Better Lives Fund' emblazoned on the front to raise funds for disadvantaged children during their EPL match on Sunday (May 1).

site_title: Ukraine on agenda as Indian PM Modi heads to Europe
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is visiting Europe, including Germany, Denmark, and France, amid the ongoing Ukraine crisis. India has refused to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine, walking a diplomatic tightrope between the West and Moscow. Modi will discuss strengthening bilateral partnerships in trade, energy, and sustainable development with European leaders. Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz plans to invite Modi to a G-7 summit to forge a broader alliance against Russia. India has increased oil imports from Russia, sparking concerns about Modi's refusal to condemn the invasion.

images.alt_text: Asia ex-Japan equities are looking oversold.

site_title: Berkshire shareholders look beyond Warren Buffett, Charlie Munger
summary: Warren Buffett, the world's greatest investor, is stepping down as CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, with succession plans in place. Vice chairman Greg Abel, 59, will replace Buffett, while Ajit Jain, 70, will lead insurance operations. Buffett's oldest son Howard will become non-executive chairman, and portfolio managers Todd Combs and Ted Weschler will take over investments. Despite Buffett's departure, loyal shareholders believe the company's values and ethics will remain unchanged, and Berkshire will continue to thrive.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Inc holds its hotly-anticipated annual shareholder meeting in person on Saturday for the first time since before the pandemic.
Warren Buffett, chairman and chief executive officer of Berkshire Hathaway, during the company's annual meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, US.

site_title: Tanker strike worsens fuel woes in crisis-hit Sri Lanka
summary: Sri Lanka's fuel crisis worsened as tanker strike led to queues for diesel and petrol, with pumps running dry. The strike, which began on Saturday, is demanding a 115% increase in fees, while the government offers a 95% increase. Energy minister Kanchana Wijesekera said it would take 3 more days to restore supplies, citing the need to hire alternative tankers. The crisis is part of Sri Lanka's economic freefall, with petrol prices increasing by 90% and diesel by 138% due to high costs and currency depreciation.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s President Gotabaya Rajapaksa is willing to drop his brother as prime minister, according to a top leader, as a fresh surge in inflation threatens to renew calls for the family to resign.
Sri  Lanka’s fractious opposition showed rare unity on Sunday (May 1), joining together to demand embattled President Gotabaya Rajapaksa resign over the country’s worst-ever economic crisis.

site_title: Rich nations scramble to seal coal transition deals before COP27
summary: Rich nations, including the UK, US, and European Union, are racing against time to finalize multibillion-dollar packages to help poor countries phase out coal. The efforts come ahead of the COP27 climate talks in November, following a landmark US$8.5 billion pledge made last year to support South Africa's transition away from fossil fuels. Negotiations are hindered by national politics and the lucrative coal trade fueled by Russia's war in Ukraine, with countries such as India, Indonesia, and Vietnam expected to be involved in the talks.

images.alt_text: Smoke rises from chimneys at Hwange Power station in Hwange, Zimbabwe, October 19, 2021. Picture taken October 19, 2021 REUTERS/Philimon Bulawayo

site_title: Creating a pathway for sustainable data centres in Singapore
summary: Singapore's data centre industry can support its sustainability goals without compromising digital ambitions by adapting international best practices. A "green growth" scenario, outlined in a report by AlphaBeta, shows a pathway to achieving economic success without compromising on sustainability. This scenario involves data centre operators focusing on sustainability performance through computing power, power usage effectiveness, renewable energy, and liquid cooling. The "green growth" scenario can lead to over 2.8 times increase in jobs and 8.9 times increase in economic contribution, while reducing carbon emissions by 90% compared to current levels.

images.alt_text: New data centres in Singapore to meet higher standards when moratorium lifts in Q2 2022

site_title: National Australia Bank agrees to rectify money laundering concerns by 2024
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has agreed to address money laundering concerns by 2024. The country's second-largest lender is required to complete a remedial action plan by December 2024 and appoint an external auditor to provide a final report by March 2025. NAB acknowledged it has taken longer than necessary to address the concerns raised by the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (Austrac), following a probe that started after a Royal Commission inquiry in 2018. The bank's CEO, Ross McEwan, said they welcome Austrac's acknowledgement of the work they've done and accept there's more to do.

site_title: Odds shift for global banks' Asia wealth bets in China's slower-growth reality
summary: Global banks' Asia wealth bets are shifting due to China's slower growth and regulatory crackdown, which has led to a decrease in client activity and a rise in cash holdings. Wealth managers have cut lending to rich clients and are advising clients to diversify their portfolios. The slowdown in wealth business was evident in earnings results from major banks such as Credit Suisse, HSBC, and UBS. Despite this, bankers believe Asia remains a key growth opportunity, but with muted appetite for investments and a wait-and-see pattern among clients.

images.alt_text: China investors learning how to profit from Xi's new capitalism

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Singapore, Taiwan, and Thailand are closed on May 2, 2022, for public holidays. No relevant news is provided in the given article excerpts.

site_title: Uneven earnings season providing little fuel for volatile US stock market
summary: US stocks ended the week with a decline, capped by Amazon's 14% drop in shares, which dragged the S&P500 down 3.6%. Despite a better-than-expected earnings season, the disappointing report from Amazon and other megacaps has failed to fuel the market, with the S&P500 down 13.3% in the first 4 months of the year. Concerns over inflation and the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening, as well as geopolitical worries, continue to weigh on investors, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq falling 13.3% in April.

site_title: Fed's planned 50bp hike risks continuation of bond, stock bloodbath
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to hike interest rates by 50 basis points, its most aggressive move in two decades, in an effort to combat near-historic inflation. This move is expected to trigger a bloodbath in stock and bond markets, with the S&P 500 experiencing its worst start to a year since 1939. The Fed aims to prevent war and post-pandemic disruptions from causing hardship for the US, but economists warn of the risk of monetary overkill and elevated inflation next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo##########dim1##########

The Fed chair and his colleagues want to lift rates expeditiously to a neutral level this year that neither stimulates nor restrains growth -- around 2.5 per cent -- and then slow the pace of tightening.

site_title: Opportunities amid uncertainty over impacts of Fed action
summary: The US Federal Reserve's monetary policy is expected to continue to impact the economy, with inflation at a 5.4% level in February, the highest since 1983. Analysts warn of a potential self-feeding wage-price inflation spiral, but also see reasons for optimism, including a growing economy, rising corporate profitability, and fixed-rate mortgages. Despite this, the Fed's rate hikes could still push the economy into recession. However, investors are encouraged to view recent market pullbacks as a buying opportunity, especially for Asian equities, which are looking oversold and cheap.

images.alt_text: Putin is threatening to halt gas shipments to Poland (pictured), but Poland's contract expires at year-end anyway.

site_title: Japan seeking to set global agenda
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is embarking on a crucial trip to Europe and Asia, seeking to set the global agenda. This is the most important trip of his prime ministership, coming before his hosting of the Quad powers in May and after German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's visit to Tokyo. Kishida, a former longest-serving foreign minister, aims to strengthen diplomatic ties and promote Japan's interests globally. The trip marks a significant test of his diplomatic skills and comes as the world navigates shifting global dynamics.

images.alt_text: JAPANESE Prime Minister Fumio Kishida kicked off his South-east Asia tour on Friday (Apr 29), meeting his Indonesian counterpart to discuss regional responses to the Ukraine crisis as well as counter China's growing assertiveness in the region.

site_title: Japan's ENEOS withdraws from Myanmar gas project
summary: Japanese energy conglomerate ENEOS Holdings has withdrawn from a gas project in Myanmar, following its Thai and Malaysian partners. The decision comes after the military crackdown on dissent in the country since the ousting of civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi. ENEOS, which held a 19.3% stake in the Yetagun project, cited the country's current situation and project economics as reasons for the withdrawal, effective after approval from the Myanmar government.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA'S state energy firm Petronas on Friday (Apr 29) said it has withdrawn from Blocks M12, M13 and M14 located in the Yetagun gas field off Myanmar, the latest exit by a major energy company since last year's military coup.

site_title: SMEs in Asia being challenged to rethink their supply chain strategy
summary: Small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Asia are facing significant challenges in their supply chain strategies due to the Ukraine conflict and a fragile global supply chain. The conflict has added to existing issues, including a shaky pandemic recovery. To address these challenges, businesses must rethink their supply chain models, shifting away from lean inventories and just-in-time delivery. The financial ecosystem in Asia must also provide alternative financing options to support the industry. This shift is necessary to ensure stability and meet industry demand.

images.alt_text: A fuss-free way for SMEs to scale up with on-demand working capital

site_title: The role ports play in the path to net zero
summary: Ports play a crucial role in achieving net-zero emissions, with 80% of global goods transported by sea. To transition to net-zero, ports must adopt automation, electrification, and digitalization. Countries like Singapore, with its Maritime Singapore Decarbonisation Blueprint, are setting ambitious goals to reduce emissions and achieve net-zero by 2050. Digitalization can help manage and control carbon emissions, deploy targeted measures, and implement carbon-offsets strategies. Partnerships between industry stakeholders, governments, and innovative technologies like AIoT will be key to achieving net-zero ports and promoting sustainable growth.

site_title: Is the Fed behind the curve?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is accused of being "behind the curve" due to rising inflation, with price hikes above expectations prompting investors to question the Fed's response. Despite the strong US labor market, inflation is running rampant, exceeding the Fed's 2% target, suggesting faster rate hikes are needed to curb price increases. The Fed's dual mandate to target both price stability and maximum sustainable employment is being questioned, with some arguing the Fed is prioritizing employment over inflation control.

images.alt_text: The Fed takes the red pill
Inflation, interest rates and the housing paradox

site_title: EU energy ministers hold crisis talks after Russian gas cuts
summary: European Union energy ministers held emergency talks on May 2, 2022, to address Russia's demand that European buyers pay for gas in roubles or face supply cuts. The talks come after Russia halted gas supplies to Bulgaria and Poland, which refused to comply. The EU is seeking a united response to the demand, with many countries facing gas payment deadlines. The European Commission has advised countries to make sanctions-compliant payments, while Russia claims its scheme is the only way to avoid breaching EU sanctions. The talks aim to clarify the situation and prevent a crack in the EU's united front against Russia.

images.alt_text: A European Union flag flutters outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium.

site_title: Western leaders must prepare public for a war economy
summary: Western leaders must prepare their public for a potential war economy, as the cost of living crisis is likely to worsen due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war. The crisis, compounded by war and supply chain disruptions, may distract citizens from the challenges of supporting Ukraine. To address this, Western politicians must explain the worsening economic situation, its causes, and the necessary measures to mitigate its effects, including rationing, increased taxes, and investment in a clean energy system.

images.alt_text: A view shows a tanker in front of a fuel depot of Aral at the Ruhr Oel petroleum refineries of BP Gelsenkirchen GmbH in Gelsenkirchen, western Germany on March 8, 2022.

site_title: Journalism's great resignation may be linked to a great repression
summary: Journalists are increasingly feeling pressured to work remotely due to the digital nature of newsgathering, leading to a "great resignation" in the industry. This shift has significant implications for the future of news, where site visits and in-person reporting are no longer as common. The author recalls working on a major story in 2008, where site visits were a norm, and notes the change in the industry's approach to reporting. This trend is likely to continue, altering the way news is gathered and presented to the public.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Making change work is harder than change itself

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall after Wall Street rout; won drops, yields jump
summary: South Korean stocks fell 17.02 points, or 0.63%, to 2,678.03, after a Wall Street rout and weaker-than-expected domestic exports data. The benchmark Kospi dropped 1.01% in early trade before recovering. The Korean won dropped, while bond yields surged, with the 10-year yield rising 12.3 basis points to 3.368%. Foreigners sold 34 billion won worth of shares, and the won was quoted at 1,264.5 per dollar, 0.68% lower than its previous close.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed up 27.56 points, or 1.03 per cent, at 2,695.05, marking the highest close since Apr 22.

site_title: Always buy in times of high uncertainty—as we are in now
summary: Ken Fisher, founder of Fisher Investments, advises investors to buy in times of high uncertainty, citing the current global market conditions. Despite the volatility and uncertainty caused by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, energy prices and uncertainty are expected to decrease. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is tightening monetary policies, while China's lockdowns are expected to have a short-term economic impact. Meanwhile, the US midterm congressional elections and the subsequent gridlock are likely to benefit stocks. Fisher notes that uncertainty never fully vanishes, but markets often rebound quickly when clarity arrives, making it a good time to invest.

images.alt_text: Oil's war-driven rise won't fuel a bear market or recession

site_title: Everton shock Chelsea to boost survival hopes
summary: Everton secured a 1-0 win over Chelsea, boosting their Premier League survival hopes. Richarlison scored the only goal in the second half, with Jordan Pickford making crucial saves to secure the victory. The win narrowed the gap on Burnley and Leeds to two points, giving Everton a game in hand to come. Chelsea's defeat leaves them still in need of securing a top-four finish, while Everton's victory could potentially prevent financial ruin for the club.

site_title: Private equity firms eyeing Toshiba buyout face nuclear dilemma
summary: Private equity firms are considering a buyout of Toshiba Corp, but face a significant hurdle: the nuclear power business, deemed crucial to Japan's national security. Toshiba had initially opposed a buyout but now plans to solicit proposals. To win government approval, PE firms must either allow a Japanese partner to take a majority stake or sell the nuclear unit, but both options are challenging due to market value and regulatory requirements. Experts suggest that Hitachi, another Japanese nuclear power company, may be the only realistic buyer, but it's uncertain if it would be interested in acquiring Toshiba's nuclear business.

images.alt_text: Toshiba's talk of privatisation leaves some analysts with doubts

site_title: Gold eases as US bond yields strengthen with Fed meet in focus
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,890.69 per ounce, as US Treasury yields strengthened ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting where interest rates are expected to be raised. US gold futures fell 1% to $1,893.40. The Fed's decision is anticipated to impact demand for zero-yield bullion, leading to lower gold prices. The central bank's 2-day meeting on interest rates is set to begin on May 3.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Sicpa Oasis validator system (bullion protect) is pictured on one kilogram bar of gold at Swiss refiner Metalor in Marin near Neuchatel, Switzerland July 5, 2019. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

Gold prices edged higher on Friday as lower US Treasury yields outweighed pressure from an elevated dollar, but bullion was still headed for its biggest monthly drop since September on fears of aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Australia: Shares decline over 1% ahead of central bank meeting
summary: Australian shares fell over 1% on Monday ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate meeting, where a hike is widely expected for the first time in over a decade. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 1.3% to 7,338.40, with technology and gold stocks leading the decline. The central bank's move is expected to tighten policies to tame surging inflation, which surged at its fastest annual pace in two decades last quarter.

images.alt_text: Australia's annual inflation rate hit 5.1 per cent in the March quarter, the highest recorded since 2001, according to official data released on Wednesday.

site_title: Powell's Fed set to go big and keep going until inflation tamed
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is expected to raise interest rates expeditiously to a neutral level of 2.5% this year, aiming to tame inflation without stifling growth. The Fed aims to slow the pace of tightening after lifting rates to a neutral level. Powell has expressed confidence in the Fed's ability to achieve a soft landing, but has also prioritized price stability. The market expects rates to peak above 3.4% this year, but economists argue the Fed may need to raise rates more aggressively to curb inflation, potentially leading to a deep recession next year.

images.alt_text: US economic growth unexpectedly contracted in the first quarter as a resurgence in Covid-19 cases disrupted activity.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open up with eyes on Fed
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Monday, drifting 0.52% down, ahead of three public holidays, as investors focused on the upcoming US Federal Reserve monetary policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 26,708.35, while the Topix index dropped to 1,894.73. Investors are expected to take a wait-and-see approach, with some focusing on corporate earnings to make investment decisions, as the US central bank is anticipated to raise interest rates by 50 basis points to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: Asian shares clung on to small gains on Friday thanks to a solid Wall Street session, but were still set for their worst month in 2 years, as China growth fears and looming US rate hikes dragged on sentiment and sent the safe-haven dollar soaring.

site_title: Singapore Reit ETFs holding up amid global Reits rout
summary: Singapore-listed Reit ETFs are outperforming amid a global Reits market rout. The Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF and CSOP iEdge S-Reit Leaders ETF, which track purely Singapore-listed Reits, saw returns of -2% and 0.2% respectively, while the NikkoAM-Straits Trading Asia Ex-Japan Reit ETF, with 76% allocation to S-Reits, posted a return of -1.1%. This contrasts with the UOB Asia Pacific Green Reit ETF, which declined 6.4% this year. Despite global Reits market declines, Singapore's Reit ETF market has seen strong retail interest, with total assets under management exceeding S$800 million.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Retail interest picks up in S-Reit ETFs
A watershed year for ETF markets

site_title: Canberra can match China's Pacific thrust
summary: Australia can potentially counter China's growing influence in the Pacific by establishing Compacts of Free Association with islander nations, allowing them to freely work in the country. The Australian parliamentary inquiry's suggestion has been met with skepticism from Solomon Islands' Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, who accused Australia of hypocrisy. In response, the US has reopened its embassy in the Solomon Islands and pledged to boost the country's Covid-19 vaccination program, signaling a shift in Washington's Pacific strategy. Canberra's general attitude towards Pacific island nations has been criticized for being condescending and indifferent.

images.alt_text: The US diplomatic team led by the National Security Council's Indo-Pacific coordinator Kurt Campbell and the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs Daniel Kritenbrink leaving the airport for talks with the Solomon's government in Honiara on April 22, 2022.

site_title: Over S$500,000 awarded to 24 students in Insead Singapore Scholarship's inaugural year
summary: Insead Singapore has awarded over S$500,000 in bond-free scholarships to 24 Singaporeans and permanent residents for their studies at the Insead Asia Campus in Singapore. Each recipient will receive approximately S$22,000, covering up to S$30,000 in tuition fees. The inaugural scholarship aims to support students in 4 Insead Master programmes, promoting diversity and equality in business education.

images.alt_text: SP Group donates S$1.35m to support 450 disadvantaged ITE students

site_title: Expanding trade and investment opportunities
summary: ASEAN and China have strengthened their ties since 1991, with bilateral trade increasing steadily. The Asean-China Free Trade Area, established in 2010, has played a key role in fostering cooperation. In 2021, ASEAN surpassed the EU as China's largest trading partner for the first time, with ASEAN's gross exports rising to 7.2% of GDP. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership signed in 2020 is expected to boost foreign direct investment into ASEAN, further solidifying the region's growing economic ties with China.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway reports drop in earnings, driven by investment losses
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, reported a 53% drop in earnings to $5.4 billion in the first quarter, driven by investment losses of $1.6 billion. The decline mirrored the stock market's worst month in two years due to inflation and uncertainty. Despite the drop, Berkshire's operating businesses saw sales and profits rise, with manufacturing and retail profits up 16% and railroad profits up 9%. Buffett's annual meeting, held in person for the first time since the pandemic, saw proposals to overhaul climate risk and remove him from his chair role, both of which were defeated.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Inc holds its hotly-anticipated annual shareholder meeting in person on Saturday for the first time since before the pandemic.

site_title: Qantas orders Airbus jets to begin non-stop flights from Sydney in late 2025
summary: Qantas Airways has ordered 12 Airbus A350-1000 planes for non-stop flights from Sydney to London, set to launch by late 2025. The airline also ordered 40 narrowbody jets to renew its domestic fleet. Market conditions are improving, with domestic travel demand returning more quickly than expected, allowing Qantas to reduce debt levels and forecast a return to profit. The deliveries of A350-1000 planes will begin in 2025 and complete by 2028, with option to buy another 94 aircrafts.

images.alt_text: Australia's Qantas aims to cut carbon emissions 25% by 2030

site_title: Violence erupts in May Day protests in Paris, marchers criticise re-elected Macron
summary: Violence erupted during May Day protests in Paris, where thousands marched against President Emmanuel Macron's policies, including a plan to raise the retirement age. Police fired tear gas to disperse black-clad anarchists who ransacked businesses and set fires. The protests, which drew around 116,500 people nationwide, focused on the cost of living and social rights. Macron won a new presidential term, but the protests highlight the challenges he faces in implementing his pro-business policies.

images.alt_text: German chancellor Scholz was the first foreign leader to congratulate the re-elected Macron

site_title: Australian banks' margin woes linger but rate hikes may lift view
summary: Australia's "Big Four" banks are expected to report further squeezes on interest margins due to growing competition, record-low rates, and increasing costs. Despite this, the prospect of central bank rate hikes may lift their outlook. Analysts predict weaker net interest margins and rising costs, but some banks, like Commonwealth Bank and National Australia Bank, may benefit from rising rates and new business. Reserve Bank of Australia's potential rate hikes are seen as a potential boost to banks, with the Australian property market showing signs of cooling.

images.alt_text: Aussie banks gravitate to June for rate rise; peak point unclear

site_title: HSBC's top shareholder calls for banking giant's break-up
summary: HSBC's largest shareholder, Chinese insurance giant Ping An, has called for the bank's break-up, proposing to split its Asia operations and other parts of its business to unlock greater value for shareholders. The plan comes amid escalating political tensions between China, Europe, and the US, with HSBC making most of its money in Asia. CEO Noel Quinn has doubled down on Asia, while analysts argue that the bank's global network adds costs without delivering enough benefit.

site_title: EU to propose phasing out Russian oil in new sanctions wave
summary: The European Union is set to propose a phased ban on Russian oil imports as part of its new sanctions against Russia for its invasion of Ukraine. The ban, which requires unanimous approval from EU member states, aims to dry up Russia's funding for the war effort. The proposed six-to-eight-month phase-in period is intended to give countries time to diversify their supply. However, Hungary is expected to oppose the measure due to its dependence on Russian oil, and other countries are concerned about the potential price increase at the pump.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Friday, reversing in volatile trade.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Millennials - how your retirement savings can make up for lost time (Ep 118)
summary: Millennials are facing a daunting challenge in securing their retirements due to the current environment, which is projected to inherit US$48 trillion of wealth over the next 25 years. To address this, Carol Fong, Group CEO of CGS-CIMB Securities, shared top 5 tips for millennials to jumpstart their retirement savings, including understanding their behavior and avoiding reliance on social media for advice. By taking proactive steps, millennials can make up for lost time and secure their financial futures.

site_title: I work best in flexible conditions, and your free stuff will not defeat me
summary: Employers should focus on what staff accomplish, not just their office attendance, to create purposeful presence. Companies are offering lavish perks, such as private concerts and luxury amenities, to lure workers back to the office. However, these incentives may be seen as manipulative and costly. Author Gayle Goh emphasizes the importance of creating the right conditions for in-person interactions, rather than just relying on perks.

images.alt_text: Gayle Goh
Working from home.
A love-hate letter to my ex, the office

SOME companies will require their staff to return to the workplace several times a week, after the authorities announced last week that all workers may do so from Tuesday (Apr 26) as part of the easing of Covid-19 measures.

site_title: DO NOT PUB: Tackling health and wealth concerns of a long life: WealthBT Ep 14
summary: WealthBT Ep 14 discusses the concerns of affluents living a long life, focusing on health and wealth management. Host Genevieve Cua explores this with Prudential's senior financial services director Kimi Oh. They discuss the benefits and challenges of living to a good senior age, including financial planning and investing strategies to protect and grow wealth. No specific conclusions or key events are mentioned in the provided article snippet.

site_title: iFAST chairman acquires more shares; UMS adds to JEP stake
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.4% over 5 trading sessions from Apr 22 to 28, with institutions net selling Singapore stocks, totaling S$53 million. Despite this, the STI generated an 8.0% total return in the 2022 year. DBS Group Holdings, UOB, OCBC, Yangzijiang Financial Holding, and Mapletree Logisitics Trust led the net institutional outflows.

images.alt_text: There were 10 primary-listed companies that filed notifications on share buybacks over the 4 sessions, with a total consideration of S$7.7 million.

site_title: Beijing tourist sites empty in Covid-stalked public holiday
summary: Major Beijing tourist venues were nearly empty on the Labour Day holiday due to China's ongoing Covid-19 outbreak, which has kept millions under lockdown nationwide. The city reported over 300 cases under the current wave, and authorities banned city-wide dining services to curb infections. Restaurants were only allowed to serve customers who had a negative Covid test, resulting in significant losses for businesses. The Temple of Heaven, a historic attraction, saw a significant decline in visitors, and the Universal Studios theme park was closed indefinitely due to the outbreak.

images.alt_text: In Beijing, authorities were in a race against time to detect Covid cases and isolate those who have been around them.

Beijing tightened Covid restrictions on Sunday (May 1) as it battled an outbreak, while Shanghai let some of its 25 million residents venture out for light and air after reporting a second day of zero infections.

site_title: Redfin settles suit by fair-housing groups over ‘minimum price policy’
summary: Redfin, a US-based online real estate brokerage, has agreed to settle a lawsuit with fair-housing groups over its "minimum price policy", which allegedly disadvantaged non-White buyers and sellers. The company will pay $4 million and make changes to ensure equitable access to real estate services, including establishing objective criteria to determine service areas and increasing racial diversity among its agents. Redfin did not admit liability, but acknowledged the need for change to make housing fair.

images.alt_text:

site_title: MAS should adopt higher-profile approach to enforcement - being feared is not a bad thing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) should adopt a higher-profile approach to enforcement in handling cases of financial market misconduct, such as the Noble Group, Hyflux, and Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) cases. MAS should publish the outcome of every investigation and enforcement action related to public-listed companies to boost investor confidence and deter wrongdoing. The regulator should also conduct thorough reviews of independent directors and external auditors to ensure they are protecting investors' interests. A tougher stance is necessary to prevent similar cases from occurring in the future.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
THE Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has provided updates on the investigation of ongoing high-profile cases in its bid to provide greater transparency on ongoing efforts.

site_title: Bonds are suddenly getting love from investors hedging recession
summary: Investors are flocking to US government bonds as a hedge against a potential recession, with $6 billion flowing into bond funds in April while $27 billion left equities. Despite the Treasury market's worst losses on record this year, yields remain high, and the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes are raising concerns about growth. Experts believe this shift in investor sentiment may limit further bond yield increases and provide a safety net for equities.

images.alt_text: A half-point interest rate increase “will be on the table” when the Federal Reserve meets on May 3-4 to approve the next in what are expected to be a series of rate increases this year, Fed Chair Jerome  Powell said on Thursday.
Eurozone government bond yields have fallen on Thursday (Apr 28) as investors focus on inflation data.

site_title: Dollar slips, but posts best month since 2015
summary: The US dollar ended its best month since 2015, posting a 4.76% gain, despite a brief slip on Friday as investors took profits. The dollar's strength was driven by concerns about the global economy and the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance. The yen reached a 20-year low, while the euro fell 4.51% to its lowest since 2017, due to concerns over energy security and inflation in Europe. The dollar index reached 103.93, its highest since December 2002.

site_title: Toyota reopens China plant as Covid curbs ease
summary: Toyota has reopened a joint-venture plant in Changchun, China, after the city's lockdown measures were eased. The plant, which was suspended since mid-March, will resume regular operations on Wednesday. The move comes as China's car sales plunged 11.7% in March due to strict lockdowns.

site_title: HP's quarterly revenue gains 3.9% on thriving business demand
summary: HP reported a 3.9% increase in quarterly revenue to $16.5 billion, beating analyst estimates, driven by steady demand from companies upgrading computer systems. However, consumer spending declined 6% and notebook units fell 23%. Despite this, HP's commercial sales remained strong, accounting for approximately 65% of the company's portfolio. The shares rose 2% in extended trading, marking a 3% year-to-date gain.

images.alt_text: Dell Technologies reported quarterly revenue that topped analysts estimates on strong demand for business PCs and networking services, a sign that companies have been modernizing their technology stacks as workers return to the office. The shares jumped in extended trading.

site_title: Russia says could seize 'hostile' nations' assets
summary: Russia's speaker of parliament, Vyacheslav Volodin, threatened to seize assets of countries deemed hostile, including the US, Lithuania, Latvia, and Poland, in retaliation for a US proposal to sell off Russian oligarchs' assets to Ukraine. Volodin accused these countries of flouting international law and urged them to "act in a civilised manner". The proposal aims to enhance seizure and forfeiture procedures, allowing Ukraine to benefit from the sale of seized assets.

site_title: As pandemic threat fades, IHH Healthcare readies for 'springboard year' with new growth strategy
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Singapore-listed medical services and facilities group, is preparing for a "springboard year" with a new growth strategy amid easing pandemic-related services. CEO Kelvin Loh expects a normalization of services and a decline in pandemic-related revenue, but the group will focus on new revenue streams from elective patients. IHH's new strategy, dubbed "Care. For Good," has four pillars, including delivering the right care to patients at an "appropriate price" and driving innovation and digital transformation. The company aims to make strategic acquisitions to accelerate growth and has submitted a proposal to buy Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care for RM5.67 billion.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
TPG nears US$300m deal to buy IHH's education arm

site_title: After 10% dip in Q1 profits, local lenders bank on rising rates to boost margins
summary: Singapore's banking trio, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, reported a 10% decline in net profits for the first quarter due to market volatility and geopolitical tensions. However, loans and net interest income rose, offering hopes of increasing profitability in the coming quarters. Rising interest rates and improving lending momentum are expected to continue boosting margins this year, with DBS likely to be the biggest beneficiary. The banks' chiefs have guided for full-year loan growth and incremental net interest income, despite acknowledging headwinds in the macro environment.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
OCBC releases financial results .
DBS reported a net profit of S$1.8 billion for the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022.
