site_title: KKR raising new European real estate fund for long-term bets
summary: KKR is raising a new European real estate fund focused on long-term investments, targeting core-plus properties. The fund, with an unlimited lifespan, has already completed two deals through its Mirastar platform. Core-plus funds invest in medium-risk real estate deals, sitting between opportunistic private equity funds and stable property investments favored by pension and sovereign investors. A spokesman for KKR declined to comment on the fund's details.

images.alt_text: THE first ever exchange-traded product (ETP) combining Bitcoin and gold has launched in Europe -- offering the twin prospect of long-term returns and inflation protection, at least in theory.

site_title: New Zealand house-price inflation slowed to 15-month low in May
summary: New Zealand's house-price inflation slowed to a 15-month low in May, with prices advancing 15.3% from a year earlier, according to CoreLogic. This is the weakest pace since February 2021. The Reserve Bank's interest rate hike has made housing credit more expensive, leading economists to predict a 10% decline in house prices this year and further decline in 2023. Higher mortgage costs may also weaken economic growth broadly, with CoreLogic forecasting 78,000 sales in 2022, down from a previous projection of 92,000.

images.alt_text: Speaking on a visit to Washington, Ardern said that the CPTPP was the “gold standard”, but New Zealand would continue to push for greater access to the US market even without it.

site_title: Sri Lankan leader faces May Day calls to step down
summary: Sri Lanka's opposition groups came together on May 1 to demand President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's resignation due to the country's worst-ever economic crisis. The opposition, led by the Samagi Jana Balawegaya party, staged a mass rally in Colombo, calling for Rajapaksa's ouster and criticizing his handling of the crisis. Former legislator Hirunika Premachandra stated that Rajapaksa has been "barricaded in his official residence" for over a month, prompting the opposition to "pull him by his ear and kick him out."

images.alt_text: INDIA, the world's second-biggest tea producer, will likely fail to take advantage of an export gap in the global market sparked by Sri Lanka's economic crisis, according to a top grower.
Sri Lanka’s President Gotabaya Rajapaksa is willing to drop his brother as prime minister, according to a top leader, as a fresh surge in inflation threatens to renew calls for the family to resign.

site_title: Slower gains for China's new home prices in April: private survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.02% in April, slower than the 0.03% gain in March, according to a private survey. The slowdown was partly due to Covid-19 outbreaks, particularly in Shanghai, which has been locked down since mid-April. Despite policy easing moves by local governments, buying sentiment remains subdued. Over 80 cities have implemented measures to boost demand, which has been a key driver of China's economic growth.

images.alt_text: China Evergrande Group is targeting sales of 1 billion yuan (S$211 million) during China’s Golden Week holiday.

site_title: Beijing tightens Covid curbs, hard-hit Shanghai sees signs of life
summary: China tightened COVID-19 restrictions in Beijing, battling an outbreak, while Shanghai, the hardest-hit city, reported zero new infections for a second day, allowing some residents to venture out. Shanghai's outbreak, which began in March, has been China's worst since 2020, infecting hundreds of thousands. Beijing's decision not to lock down amid the outbreak tests the government's zero-COVID approach ahead of President Xi Jinping's expected third term.

images.alt_text: In Beijing, authorities were in a race against time to detect Covid cases and isolate those who have been around them.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of April 29, 2022, highlights mixed market trends across various segments. In the Ultramax/Supramax market, healthy demand was seen from the US Gulf, but other areas experienced a lacklustre feel. The Capesize market showed a positive week, with the BCI and 5TC route average at 2,003 points and $16,609. The Panamax market returned a lacklustre week, with momentum lacking, while the Ultramax/Supramax market was positional, with strongest gains seen from the US Gulf. In the Handysize market, mainly positive sentiment in both basins led to gains. The Clean market saw upsweings in freight for the majority of CPP vessels, with rates increasing for LR2s, LR1s, and MRs. The VLCC sector experienced rates softening in all markets this week, while the Suezmax market declined further.

images.alt_text: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights

site_title: India seizes US$725m from China's Xiaomi over 'illegal' remittances
summary: India has seized $725 million from Xiaomi's local bank accounts, alleging the Chinese smartphone giant unlawfully sent money abroad in the guise of royalty payments. The Enforcement Directorate found Xiaomi made remittances to 3 foreign-based entities on the instructions of their Chinese parent group entities. Xiaomi India denies the allegations, stating its operations are compliant with local laws and regulations. The move comes amid strained relations between India and China since a deadly Himalayan border clash in 2020.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi beats profit estimates after holiday quarter sales gain

site_title: Make-A-Wish Singapore sets new milestone on its 20th anniversary
summary: Make-A-Wish Singapore has reached a milestone of 2,000 wishes to mark its 20th anniversary. The organization, established in 2002, has helped fulfill the wishes of over 1,700 children with the help of 84 corporate and hospital partners. To support its goal, digital media company SGAG has adopted Make-A-Wish Singapore as its charity of choice and will produce content highlighting the power of fulfilling wishes. This partnership aims to encourage Singaporeans to refer suitable children to the organization and spread joy and hope.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

Left to right: Dejan Kulusevski, Eric Dier, Harry Winks, Lucas Moura. Tottenham Hotspur players will wear jerseys with 'AIA Better Lives Fund' emblazoned on the front to raise funds for disadvantaged children during their EPL match on Sunday (May 1).

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits see higher RevPAR as borders reopen
summary: Hospitality S-Reits in Singapore reported higher RevPAR (revenue per available room) in Q1 2022, driven by growth in average daily rates and occupancy. Ascott Residence Trust, CDL Hospitality Trusts, Far East Hospitality Trust, and Frasers Hospitality Trust averaged 23.4% total returns in the year to date. These trusts expressed optimism for 2022, citing recovery and reopening across their operating markets, with longer-stay properties contributing to increased gross profit.

images.alt_text: Rendezvous Grand Hotel Singapore, one of the hotels under Far East Hospitality Trust

site_title: Singapore's next-decade roadmap to be charted in 'Forward Singapore' agenda: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's next decade roadmap will be outlined in a "Forward Singapore" agenda by its fourth-generation (4G) leaders, aiming to refresh the country's social compact. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, who is set to become the de facto prime minister-in-waiting, will engage stakeholders to hear their thoughts on various areas, including the economy, healthcare, and education. The agenda will focus on strengthening the country's tripartite partnership between the government, unions, and private sectors, and build on Singapore's model of tripartism.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the May Day Rally 2022.

site_title: US says committed to Pacific islands that rejected ‘opaque’ China pact
summary: The US has reaffirmed its commitment to Pacific island nations that rejected China's "opaque" proposal, citing concerns over Beijing's attempts to obscure its deals. Ten Pacific island states rebuffed China's offer, which included financial assistance and access to natural resources in exchange for greater Chinese influence. US State Department spokesman Ned Price stated the US will continue to deepen its relationship with Pacific Island partners and work together to counter China's growing influence in the region.

images.alt_text: Visiting Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi (R) holds talks with Tongan Prime Minister Hu’akavameiliku at the Prime Minister’s Office in Nuku’alofa on May 31, 2022. (Photo by Linny Folau / MatangiTonga / AFP)

site_title: Budgeting in a BNPL world
summary: Buy-Now-Pay-Later (BNPL) services have become increasingly popular, allowing consumers to break down large purchases into smaller monthly payments. However, this trend may lead to erosion of savings if not managed properly. To mitigate this, individuals need to adopt effective budgeting techniques. Providers like Atome and Grab offer discounts on various products and services, further encouraging the use of BNPL. As a result, consumers must be cautious of overspending and prioritize saving to avoid financial strain.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
'Buy now, pay later' schemes to come under industry code to protect consumers

site_title: Why tax needs to feature prominently on the ESG agenda
summary: Tax considerations are increasingly important within the Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) agenda, as companies face growing stakeholder emphasis on social issues and the need to assess ESG risks effectively. Tax is featured across various ESG components, including environmental sustainability activities, social considerations, and governance. Governments offer incentives and grants to accelerate the adoption of green technology, while companies must articulate their tax strategy and provide reliable tax information for ESG ratings. With no single set of standards for measuring and reporting ESG data, tax-related ESG reporting is becoming increasingly important, and companies must engage tax advisors to ensure they are well-covered to score highly on ESG-tax criteria.

site_title: Singapore must transform for 'troubled environment', with risk of global recession in next two years: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned Singapore to transform itself for a 'troubled environment' amid rising global risks, including a possible recession in the next two years. He cited soaring oil prices, high inflation, and tighter monetary policy as headwinds. Singapore faces an additional S$8 billion annual cost due to high oil prices, or 1.5% of GDP. The PM emphasized the need for Singapore to adapt and innovate to make a living in challenging circumstances, following its recovery from the Covid-19 crisis.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

The trade-related cluster, which led the recovery in 2021, is likely to see its contribution to GDP ease this year as it expands more slowly amid a weaker external environment, said MAS.
Instead, the recovery in the domestic-oriented and travel-related sectors is expected to gather pace now that Singapore has removed most of its Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Amid fuel prices surge in the Philippines, some respite could be on the way
summary: The Philippines may experience some respite from fuel price surges in the first week of May, according to a top official at the Department of Energy. Retail prices of fuel products, including liquefied petroleum gas, are likely to decrease due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The price increase, which was 18.45 pesos for gasoline, 31.45 pesos for diesel, and 25.05 pesos for kerosene, was the 14th price hike in 16 weeks. Senator Leila de Lima has proposed suspending import duties on fuel products to protect consumer interests.

images.alt_text: Petrol hikes spark criticism in the Philippines

site_title: Team led by Nordic Group’s executive chairman makes clean sweep at Singapore Recreation Club elections
summary: A team led by Chang Yeh Hong, executive chairman of Nordic Group, won all 12 management committee seats at Singapore Recreation Club (SRC) elections. The team, 12 Good Men, received 2,851 out of 6,115 votes cast, surpassing the previous management committee's handling of club affairs. This marks a watershed moment in the club's 140-year history, with 43 candidates vying for the positions, the highest number ever in an SRC election.

site_title: Bored Ape metaverse land frenzy raises millions, disrupts Ethereum
summary: Yuga Labs' sale of virtual land in its metaverse project Otherside raised approximately $320 million, with demand causing a ripple effect on the Ethereum blockchain, disrupting activity and raising transaction fees. The sale of 55,000 parcels of virtual land, priced at around $5,800 each, led to a surge in transaction costs, with fees reaching $123 million. The event highlights the growing interest in metaverse projects and the potential for blockchain-based transactions to impact the broader cryptocurrency market.

images.alt_text: Hacked owners cumulatively lost 4 Bored Apes, 6 Mutant Apes and 3 Bored Ape Kennel Club NFTs - together worth roughly US$3 million, Yuga Labs said.
The metaverse land boom: economy of the future or a bubble?

site_title: Israel signs major trade pact with Gulf state UAE
summary: Israel signed a free trade agreement with the United Arab Emirates, reducing or removing tariffs on 96% of goods, with the goal of boosting bilateral trade to over $10 billion annually within five years. The pact was signed by Israeli Minister of Economy Orna Barbivai and UAE Minister of Economy Abdulla bin Touq Al Marri, amid escalating Israeli-Palestinian violence. The agreement has been welcomed by Emirati trade minister Thani Al Zeyoudi, who sees it as a "new chapter in the history of the Middle East" and a step towards peace, stability, and prosperity in the region.

images.alt_text: UAE wealth funds behind US$10b investment push in Israel

site_title: Outspoken market analyst's Chinese social media accounts suspended
summary: Hong Kong-based market strategist Hong Hao's WeChat and Weibo accounts were suspended after downbeat commentaries on Covid-19 lockdowns and global tensions, which led to 2-year lows in mainland equities. WeChat cited unspecified rule violations for the suspension. This move follows Hong's critical commentary on China's economic performance, raising concerns about the government's ability to manage market expectations. The suspension is seen as a response to Hong's outspoken views, which may be perceived as a threat to the government's control over market sentiment.

images.alt_text: China censors Shanghai protest videos as lockdown anger grows

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks closed with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains, building on a recent rally, as traders reacted positively to data showing improvement in China's factory activity. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.38% to 21,415.20, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.19% to 3,186.43. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 1.57% to 2,006.95, following a similar trend in China's factory sector.

site_title: Taiwan will not 'cruelly' lock down like China: premier
summary: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang stated that the country will not impose "cruelly" lockdowns like China, as it shifts away from its zero-Covid strategy to live with the virus. Despite a surge in cases, Taiwan has reported only mild or asymptomatic infections, with over 99.7% of cases being mild. The government is considering relaxing quarantine rules and shortening home isolation periods for close contacts. Taiwan's decision marks a departure from its neighboring China, which continues to enforce a zero-tolerance policy.

images.alt_text: People line up at a testing centre for the Covid-19 in Keelung, Taiwan April 28, 2022.

site_title: Genting Singapore appoints new CEO
summary: Genting Singapore has appointed Tan Hee Teck, its president and COO, as the company's new CEO, effective immediately. Tan will oversee executing the board's strategies, managing businesses, and leading the management team. He has been with the group since 2004 and previously served as CEO of Resorts World at Sentosa. The appointment was approved by the Nominating Committee and the board, who deemed Tan qualified and experienced for the role.

images.alt_text: Investment opportunities abound as travel opens up
Brokers' take: RHB raises targets on Genting, sees potential upside in dividends

site_title: The Hour Glass posts 75% rise in H2 profit amid stronger demand for mechanical watches
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 75% increase in its net profit for the fiscal second half of 2022, reaching S$92.1 million, driven by stronger demand for mechanical watches. Revenue rose 23.8% to S$561 million, and earnings per share increased to 13.44 Singapore cents. The company attributed the growth to an "accelerating momentum" in customer demand, with interest in high-quality mechanical watches broadening among younger, discerning buyers. The Hour Glass expects to remain profitable in the next financial year, focusing on organic development in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Watch retailers could continue to enjoy boom time
There were 10 primary-listed companies that filed notifications on share buybacks over the 4 sessions, with a total consideration of S$7.7 million.

site_title: No-go for kampung chickens in export about-face
summary: Malaysian kampung chicken suppliers, who had received earlier approval to export the premium birds to Singapore, received a sudden ban on June 1, affecting all live chickens. The ban was initially implemented to address the chicken shortage in Malaysia, but the bulk of demand is for broiler chickens, allowing organic free-range birds to continue being exported to Singapore. Restaurants, including The Coconut Club and Labyrinth, will have to find alternative ingredients or adjust their menus, with chefs' creativity likely outlasting the ban.

images.alt_text: Free range or kampong chickens have been given special approval for import into Singapore

site_title: Elections Department looking to make voting easier for overseas Singaporeans, nursing home residents
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore is planning to implement a postal voting pilot for overseas Singaporeans and on-site polling stations for nursing home residents to improve voting accessibility. The pilot aims to address security and secrecy concerns with postal voting, and overseas Singaporeans will need to submit a specimen signature when registering as postal voters. The proposed arrangements are pending consultation with local political parties and overseas Singaporeans, and the results will be shared in July. For nursing homes, on-site polling stations and mobile teams will be deployed to bring ballot boxes and papers to residents.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Whether Lawrence Wong will lead PAP in next general election to be decided later: PM Lee

site_title: Thailand’s minimum wage hike to have limited impact on F&B companies: CGS-CIMB
summary: Thailand's minimum wage is expected to be increased to 492 baht (S$19.72) nationwide, but its impact on the food and beverage (F&B) sector is expected to be limited due to a gradual hike. Analysts predict a 5-9% downside to FY2023 earnings per share estimates for companies in the sector, with some, such as GFPT and MK Restaurant Group, expected to report above-industry earnings growth. A compensation mechanism may be introduced to alleviate the impact of the wage hike.

images.alt_text: THAILAND will try to keep inflation below 5 per cent this year, its prime minister said on Monday (May 23), amid surging fuel prices and a fragile economic recovery.

site_title: Will higher interest rates push eurozone to new debt crisis?
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing to act against a potential debt crisis in the eurozone, triggered by rising interest rates that are putting pressure on public finances. Higher borrowing costs mean governments must pay more to refinance debt, with France facing a 40 billion euro increase in annual costs. While the impact is gradual, soaring inflation boosts economic output and tax revenue, but also reduces the proportion of debt to the overall economy. Experts say the risk of a debt crisis is low, but the ECB's actions could mitigate potential issues.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Wednesday, lifted by resource-linked stocks and banks.

site_title: Healthtech platform SwipeRx raises US$27m
summary: SwipeRx, a healthtech platform connecting pharmacies in South-east Asia, has raised US$27 million in equity and borrowings in its Series B round. Led by MDI Ventures, the funding will be used to accelerate growth across the region, particularly in Indonesia. With over 235,000 registered pharmacy professionals and 45,000 pharmacies, SwipeRx aims to expand its digital platform and provide cost savings through bulk purchases and financing options. The company, which operates in Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, and Cambodia, plans to recruit talent and expand its specialised healthcare logistics.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

From left: Freshket chief of staff Komjak Rattakham, chief executive and co-founder Ponglada Paniangwet, and vice president of engineering Saran Chiwtanasuntorn. Komjak Rattakham, Freshket chief of staff said the funding round was part of the startup's strategy to achieve "rapid and progressive growth" in 2022.

site_title: A bumper crop of famed restaurant openings in June
summary: Several high-end restaurants are set to open in Singapore in June, including Pangium, Osteria Mozza, and Fiamma. Pangium, a 20-seat restaurant in the Botanic Gardens, will serve modern Peranakan cuisine with a focus on heritage and tradition. Osteria Mozza, a full-fledged Italian restaurant, will open for dinner only and feature a menu of Californian-Italian cuisine. Fiamma, an all-day-dining Italian restaurant at the Capella Singapore resort, will offer a menu of simple yet sustainable dishes. Additionally, Nobu Singapore will open in the Four Seasons Hotel, featuring Japanese-Peruvian cuisine and a unique outdoor Japanese garden.

site_title: Sharp slowdown in UK business activity rings recession alarm
summary: The UK private sector experienced a sharper-than-expected slowdown in May, with a Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 51.8, its lowest level since February 2022. This increase in pessimism adds to recession worries, as inflation pressures rose. Sterling fell 0.9% against the US dollar, and short-dated government bond prices jumped. Economists warn of a heightened risk of recession, with the Bank of England expected to double interest rates to control inflation.

site_title: A gourmet feast in June
summary: A plethora of big-name restaurants are set to open in June, including Restaurant Born by Zor Tan, a 2-Michelin-starred chef, and fine-dining restaurants from foreign chefs Nancy Silverton and Nobu Matsuhisa. Local talents such as Malcolm Lee of Michelin-starred Candlenut are also opening their first tasting-menu only restaurant. These new eateries join a growing list of notable restaurants in Singapore, including Forma and Odette, which recently ranked No. 25 on the World's 50 Best Restaurants list.

site_title: Australia urges China to drop trade tariffs
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers urged China to lift trade tariffs, which have damaged the Australian economy, as a condition for improving relations. China, Australia's largest trading partner, had imposed tariffs on key industries, including wine, barley, and coal, in response to Australia's stance on the coronavirus pandemic and Huawei's 5G ban. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang sent a congratulatory note to newly elected Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, signaling a willingness to work towards a "comprehensive strategic partnership." However, experts say a complete reset of relations is unlikely, citing Australia's "tough-on-China" stance.

images.alt_text: Australia's relations with China will remain challenging, Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said on Tuesday amid reports the Chinese premier had congratulated the new Labor government on its weekend election victory.

Chinese premier Li Keqiang has sent a congratulatory note to newly-elected Australian counterpart Anthony Albanese (pictured), Beijing’s state media reported, ending a year-long freeze in diplomatic contact between the 2 countries.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB expects rising inflation to boost Sheng Siong’s topline, upgrades to 'buy'
summary: RHB upgraded Sheng Siong to "buy" from "neutral" due to expected rising inflation boosting the supermarket operator's topline. The research team raised its target price to S$1.78, representing a 16.3% potential upside. Analysts believe Sheng Siong can maintain gross processing margins while widening net profit margins as it raises prices to pass on costs. This contrasts with UOB Kay Hian's downgrade of DFI Retail Group to "hold" due to uncertainty from government policies.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sheng Siong posted a 13.9 per cent rise in net profit to S$35.1 million for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, from S$30.8 million a year ago.

site_title: How to pair food and wine
summary: Wine and food pairing can be intimidating, but with a few essential truths, anyone can learn to pair wine and food. The first step is to buy wine at a good wine shop rather than a supermarket, as dedicated merchants can offer valuable advice. Perfection is not the goal, and even imperfect pairings can enhance each other. The simpler the recipe, the easier it is to find harmony. Experience overcomes fear, and each misstep is an opportunity to learn. With a willingness to try new things, many bottles can be the right choice, and few are wrong.

images.alt_text: The Conrad Maldives Rangali Island recently completed its revamp.
A dome is being built at the Fullerton Bay Hotel entrance

site_title: Singapore stocks open little changed on Tuesday; STI up 0.01%
summary: Singapore shares opened little changed on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.01% or 0.26 point to 3,213.91. Despite overnight gains on Wall Street, the local market was flat, with the most actively traded counter being Sembcorp Marine, which saw 25.2 million shares traded at 9:03 am. The merger of Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust and Mapletree Commercial Trust was approved by unitholders, and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC were down in early trade.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
THE leases of 3 properties belonging to CICT are being renewed with Temasek subsidiaries.
Jeffrey Halley, Oanda’s senior market analyst for Asia Pacific, said recessionary concerns continue to hold back the buy-the-dippers in Asia.

site_title: Modern take on seasonal traditions
summary: A modern take on traditional Japanese kaiseki cuisine is offered at kaiseki restaurant and bar GOHO, located in a handroll bar Rappu. The menu features seasonal seafood and dishes such as Spanish mackerel sashimi and firefly squid in a claypot rice dish. The bar also offers a range of cocktails, sake, and umeshu, with optional beverage pairings for its three kaiseki menus. The beverage program is designed to showcase Japanese flavors and techniques, with a focus on sophistication and variety.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
From day till night at Sol & Luna

site_title: Anti-trust chief to lead Philippines' economic planning agency
summary: Philippines' anti-trust agency chief Arsenio Balisacan has accepted an offer from incoming president Ferdinand Marcos Jr to be his economic planning chief. Balisacan, who previously served in the same role under President Benigno Aquino, will join the new administration's economics team to accelerate economic recovery and post-recovery development. Marcos has said he will not prioritize political affiliation in selecting his cabinet members. Balisacan will face challenges such as the pandemic, inflation, and massive government debt, as Marcos' economic team prepares to take office on June 30.

site_title: World Bank to provide additional US$12b to address global food crisis
summary: The World Bank has announced an additional $12 billion in funding to address the global food crisis, bringing the total to $30 billion over the next 15 months. The funding will support projects to boost food and fertilizer production, facilitate trade, and help vulnerable households and producers. The crisis is exacerbated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has disrupted supplies and pushed up fuel and diesel prices. The World Bank and other lenders are urging countries to increase food production and exports to alleviate the crisis.

images.alt_text: Farmers harvesting wheat in a field on the outskirts of Amritsar. The fact that food inflation could happen because India pulls back on its exports of the crop is surprising, given hat India is not a prominent exporter on the world stage. But it is because the Russia-Ukraine war has crippled Ukraine's exports, and bad weather has threatened output among other major producers.

site_title: How a trash-talking crypto founder caused a US$40b crash
summary: DO Kwon, the founder of Terraform Labs, created a cryptocurrency called Luna in 2018, which rose to a peak value of $40 billion. Kwon's trash-talking attitude and promises of a "modern financial system" drew in respected financiers, including Lightspeed Venture Partners and Galaxy Digital. However, the currency's collapse, along with its stablecoin TerraUSD, led to a domino effect in the cryptocurrency market, causing a $300 billion loss in value. Many investors, including Pantera Capital, made substantial profits by selling their Luna coins early. The collapse has devastated retail traders and startup founders who built businesses on Kwon's technology, with some losing millions.

images.alt_text: Terraform Labs co-founder Do Kwon (above) offered another proposal to revive its troubled Terra blockchain by getting rid of the failed TerraUSD stablecoin and revamping the project into a new network.

site_title: Snowless WEF meets with Spring in its step
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is hosting its first springtime meeting in Davos, Switzerland, marking a return to face-to-face events after two years of the pandemic. Delegates, including 50 heads of state or government, will focus on rebuilding trust and addressing key issues such as post-pandemic recovery, climate change, and the future of work. Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky will deliver a speech via videoconference, while WEF seeks to renew global cooperation and shared prosperity through initiatives like pandemic recovery and stakeholder capitalism.

images.alt_text: Globalisation isn't over, but we need to ditch the fantasies it ushered in
World Economic Forum to hold 2022 annual meeting in Davos in May

site_title: Broadcom in talks to acquire cloud company VMware: sources
summary: Broadcom, a leading electronics manufacturer, is in talks to acquire cloud-computing company VMware, valued at approximately US$40 billion. The discussions are ongoing, with no guarantee of a purchase. This potential deal would expand Broadcom's software focus and complement its existing chip business. CEO Hock Tan has a history of making strategic acquisitions, and VMware's virtualization software could help decrease Broadcom's reliance on chips. The transaction would mark a significant move for Broadcom, which has been expanding its software portfolio in recent years.

images.alt_text: Chipmaker GlobalFoundries prices US IPO at upper end to raise US$2.6b
Apple likely to cut iPhone 13 production due to chip crunch: sources

site_title: Google 'private browsing' mode not really private, Texas lawsuit says
summary: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton claims Google's "private browsing" mode, also known as Incognito mode, is not truly private, as the company allegedly collects data on users even when in this mode. Google disputes these claims, stating that they have built privacy features into their products and provided robust controls for location data. The lawsuit adds Google's Incognito mode to previous suits filed by Texas, Indiana, Washington State, and the District of Columbia over deceptive location-tracking practices that invade users' privacy.

images.alt_text: Schroders, Britain's biggest listed asset manager, said on Wednesday it would back a swathe of shareholder resolutions at Amazon, Meta and Google-owner Alphabet concerning workers' and digital rights.

Twitter and Facebook will be compelled to allow the dissemination of Russian propaganda as well as neo-Nazi and Ku Klux Klan screeds denying the Holocaust unless a Texas social media law is blocked, tech groups representing the companies told the US Supreme Court.

site_title: Asia: Markets up after Wall Street battering over recession fears
summary: Asian markets opened higher on Friday, capitalizing on Wall Street's decline amid recession fears. Decades-high inflation, rising interest rates, and China's Covid lockdowns heightened uncertainty. Leading indices saw volatility, with growth concerns rising and equities vulnerable to a negative feedback loop. China cut its 5-year loan prime rate, aiming to boost demand and stabilize the economy. Asian markets, including Seoul, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore, saw a 1% boost, as investors looked for relief from the battering Wall Street took the day before.

images.alt_text: Asian markets posted big early losses on Thursday.

site_title: Hot stock: Frencken down as much as 10.3% after release of Q1 results
summary: Frencken Group's shares fell 10.3% to S$1.13 in morning trading after releasing Q1 results, with net profit declining 12.6% year-over-year to S$12.8 million. Revenue rose 9.3% to S$198.4 million, driven by strong sales of its mechatronics division. Analysts downgraded their target prices, citing weak margins and anticipated margin pressures, with DBS Group Research lowering its target to S$1.36 from S$2.09.

images.alt_text: Frencken Group's net profit fell 12.6 per cent in Q1 due to higher costs.

site_title: Japan exports rise 12.5% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports rose 12.5% in April from a year ago, marking a 14th consecutive month of increase, exceeding economists' expectations. The rise was driven by a weaker yen, which boosted global commodity prices. Imports rose 28.2% due to the same yen depreciation, resulting in a trade deficit of 839.2 billion yen. This follows a 14.7% increase in March.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb for fourth day, Fortescue gains on leadership changes
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, with the benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index jumping 1.2% to 7,195.5. Mining and technology stocks led the gain, driven by higher iron ore prices and the return of Fortescue Metals' founder Andrew Forrest as executive chairman. Global markets also saw gains, with Japan's Nikkei up 1.4% and US growth stocks showing strength. However, US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted at interest rate hikes to combat inflation, a trend expected to follow in other geographies.

site_title: Singapore court freezes sale, transfer of a Bored Ape Yacht Club NFT
summary: A Singaporean court has frozen the sale and ownership transfer of a Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) non-fungible token (NFT), No. 2162, on behalf of a local investor, Janesh Rajkumar, against an unknown defendant, chefpierre.eth. Rajkumar claims wrongful conversion of the NFT and breach of contract after chefpierre repudiated a refinancing agreement and exercised the foreclosure option, transferring the NFT to his wallet. The court's injunction will remain in effect until after a trial, with Rajkumar seeking at least 150 ether (approximately $2,024) for the NFT, which he considers a "rare piece of art".

Yuga Labs, the creator of the popular Bored Apes Yacht Club collection of NFTs - the physical artworks of which are seen here at a show in Hong Kong - put up plots of virtual land in a highly anticipated metaverse event, raising about US$320 million.

Cryptocurrencies are property, Singapore court rules, as it freezes US$7m in 'stolen' crypto

site_title: Carbon credit crash course
summary: Carbon credits represent measurable amounts of greenhouse gases removed from the atmosphere, allowing climate mitigating projects to access funding from those who want to offset emissions. Credits are issued for projects such as reforestation, renewable energy, and energy efficiency. They have become a crucial tool in climate mitigation strategies, but their value has been impacted by a recent crash. The crash is attributed to a surge in credits being issued, leading to oversupply and decreased demand. This has resulted in a significant drop in credit prices, making it challenging for projects to secure funding.

site_title: Bamboo tissue makers are on a roll
summary: Bamboo tissue makers are gaining traction as a sustainable alternative to traditional wood pulp tissue. Cloversoft, a Singapore-based company, launched an unbleached bamboo tissue in 2014, initially facing skepticism over its natural brown color. However, the company's co-founders, Angela Sim and Lynn Yeo, saw this as an opportunity to promote the natural beauty of bamboo. Since then, other enterprises have followed suit, with bamboo tissue gaining popularity as a more environmentally friendly option.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Go green with these local brands

site_title: Saudi Arabia's wealth fund takes 5% Nintendo stake
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has taken a 5% stake in Nintendo, increasing its exposure to the Japanese video gaming industry. The investment was made for investment purposes and comes as PIF has also taken stakes in Nexon, Capcom, and Koei Tecmo. This move follows PIF's recent investment in Activision Blizzard, and the sovereign wealth fund's launch of its own video game and e-sports company, Savvy Gaming. The 5% stake in Nintendo is the latest addition to PIF's growing portfolio in the gaming industry.

images.alt_text: JAPAN’S Nintendo on Tuesday (May 10) made a play for the hearts of retail investors, announcing a 10-1 stock split effective Oct 1, a long-called-for move that aims to improve the liquidity of the videogame maker’s shares.

site_title: New Zealand housing prices unsustainable, inflation a challenge: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that New Zealand's housing prices are unsustainable and should decline by around 10% this year. The IMF's New Zealand division chief, Harald Finger, praised the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's (RBNZ) decision to aggressively raise interest rates to combat surging inflation, which has risen to 1.5%. The RBNZ has increased interest rates by a cumulative 125 basis points since late last year, with further rate hikes expected. This move aims to rein in inflation and stabilize the housing market.

images.alt_text: UK estate agents are preparing for the cost of living crisis and Bank of England rate increases to take some of the heat out of the housing market, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyor (RICS).
The Fed might have to send the US economy into a substantial recession with significantly higher-than-expected interest rates to return inflation to its target over the medium run.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Evans wants smaller US rate hikes by July or Sept
summary: Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans expressed support for a shallower rate-hike path by July or September to assess inflation and the job market. Evans believes front-loading rate hikes is crucial to tighten financial conditions and control inflation, but is concerned about pushing rates above neutral, which could impact growth. He wants to assess supply chain kinks and inflation dynamics before making further adjustments, aiming for a 50-basis point hike by December and a more gradual pace of rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans looks on during the Global Interdependence Center Members Delegation Event in Mexico City, Mexico, February 27, 2020. REUTERS/Edgard Garrido

site_title: Bold green dreams
summary: Singapore's largest automakers are setting ambitious electrification targets. According to a survey, popular car brands aim to transition to battery-powered vehicles. BYD, a leading EV battery maker, faces increased pressure to cut emissions. Singapore is also stepping up its efforts in sustainability, with Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments reaching S$46 billion in FY2025. The country is expected to introduce carbon offsetting legislation for airlines and has seen a significant increase in sustainable bond issuances, jumping 80% to S$13.3 billion in 2024.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars toppled by China data shock
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell on Monday after China's weak economic data sparked fears of a global recession, undermining risk assets and commodities. China's retail sales sank 11.1% in April, and industrial output fell 2.9% year-over-year, leading to a decline in the Aussie to US$0.6896 and the kiwi to US$0.6240. The data has raised concerns for the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on interest rates in June, with some analysts predicting a supersized rate hike.

images.alt_text: Japan’s Nikkei clung to gains of 0.6 per cent, having lost 2.1 per cent last week even as a weak yen offered some support to exporters.
Spot gold was up 0.3 per cent at US$1,815.69 per ounce, as of 12.57 am GMT on Monday.
The euro is on the verge of US dollar parity for the first time in 2 decades.

site_title: Spanish Cabinet approves paid 'menstrual leave'
summary: Spain's Cabinet approved a Bill granting paid medical leave for women experiencing severe period pain, making it the first in Europe. The law, which must still be approved by parliament, entitles workers to as much time off as needed, with the state social security system covering the costs. Equality Minister Irene Montero described the move as a recognition of a health problem that has been largely ignored and said it will "no more hiding our pain." The proposal is part of a broader reproductive health reform, which includes changes to abortion laws.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up after Wall Street dip on China’s Covid-bruised data
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday, despite a lukewarm lead from Wall Street, following weak Chinese economic data showing a slump in retail sales and industrial production. China's strict zero-Covid policy has added to inflation worries, but authorities have announced measures to help young people find jobs and lower mortgage rates. Markets were boosted by news that Shanghai will reopen in stages and Hong Kong's Hang Sang Index rose over 2%. Wheat prices surged to a record after India banned exports due to a heatwave, and oil prices also jumped.

site_title: Olivia Lum may face legal action as Hyflux group lodges pre-emptive lawsuit
summary: Hyflux group has lodged a pre-emptive lawsuit against Olivia Lum Ooi Lin, potentially leading to legal action and compensation. The lawsuit was filed by Hyflux and its liquidators after failed attempts to stave off liquidation. The High Court in Singapore has issued a writ of summons seeking a declaration against Lum with damages to be assessed.

site_title: Lab-grown diamonds: brilliant for the environment and the pocket
summary: Lab-grown diamonds have gained popularity among consumers due to their affordability and sustainability, with prices ranging from 40 to 80% lower than naturally-mined diamonds. The industry's growth can be attributed to technological advancements, which have enabled the production of higher-quality diamonds at a faster pace and lower cost. Key players, such as X Diamond Capital and SK Jewellery, have seen significant sales growth since entering the market. Analysts estimate that lab-grown diamond sales now form around 5-8% of the global diamond market, with some expecting this to reach 10% by 2023.

site_title: US dollar hits 2-decade high, rattled investors plump for safe haven
summary: The US dollar surged to a 2-decade high on May 12, driven by concerns over tightening monetary policies to combat inflation, which dampened risk sentiment and led investors to seek safe-haven currencies. The dollar index rose 0.4% to 104.45, while the euro fell 0.8% to its lowest since January 2017. Other safe-haven currencies, such as the yen and Chinese yuan, also rose, while the Aussie and kiwi dollar fell to their lowest since June 2020.

images.alt_text: THE US dollar held close to a two-decade high on Wednesday (May 11) as investors waited for the latest US inflation data to assess how aggressively the Federal Reserve will have to tighten monetary policy to keep rising prices in check.

site_title: Can investors find gems among waste management players in Singapore?
summary: Investors may find opportunities in Singapore's waste management sector, as three new companies have joined the Catalist board since August last year. These companies provide inelastic services to industrial customers and are mostly small, with room for growth. Despite differences in business segments, they share similar characteristics, making them comparable.

Shanaya debuts on Catalist, sees growth from new capacity in Tuas plant
LS 2, fresh from trading debut, unaware of reasons for trading activity after 'trade with caution' alert
This gives the company a market capitalisation of S$41.3 million as it trades at 15.6 times its earnings.

site_title: Campari plans new bars, including in Singapore, to whet aperitif appetites
summary: Campari plans to open several flagship bars, including in London, New York, and Singapore, to tap into the Italian aperitif culture. The company reported a 29% increase in like-for-like sales in the first quarter of the year, driven by demand for its Aperol and Campari bitters. CEO Bob Kunze-Concewitz aims to replicate the success of Milan's Camparino bar, which was purchased in 2018 and upgraded for 11.1 million euros. The initiative is expected to help the company collect data on consumption patterns and reinforce its brand identity.

images.alt_text: Cocktail bar scene bounces back

site_title: Return to Japan - a taste of Tokyo now
summary: Tokyo is reopening to tourists after a 2-year hiatus, with locals enjoying a city without foreign visitors. The city's economy is booming as domestic demand fuels "revenge eating" and spending. Travelers must navigate strict entry requirements, including a negative PCR test and on-arrival saliva test. Despite the challenges, Tokyo's food scene is thriving, with popular restaurants like Heichan and La Paix offering modern takes on traditional dishes. The city is also exploring new neighborhoods, such as Taito City, which offers hidden gems like the quirky fish and chips shop Kanejin and the old-school bakery Pelican.

site_title: Settlement curbs firm’s facial recognition database in US
summary: Clearview AI has agreed to limit access to its facial recognition database in the US, settling a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and rights groups. The deal, pending court approval, permanently bans the company from sharing its database with most businesses or private entities, effectively curbing its use of biometric data. Clearview will also stop offering free trial accounts to police officers without employer approval. The ban does not limit the company's work with federal or state agencies outside of Illinois, where the lawsuit was filed.

site_title: Inflation surge puts pressure on Bosch profits
summary: Bosch, the world's largest auto supplier, expects its profit margins to be squeezed due to rising energy costs, raw materials, and logistics. The company now forecasts an operating profit margin of 3-4%, down from 2021's 6.5%. The global car market is expected to grow 9% in 2022, but Bosch predicts this will not be met due to coronavirus lockdowns in China and semiconductor supply issues. The company attributed the rise in costs to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has driven up energy prices.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit near 1 1/2-year low on rising US yields, China lockdowns
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1.27% to their lowest in nearly 1.5 years, closing at 2,610.81, due to rising US Treasury yields and concerns over global economic slowdown amid China's extended lockdown measures and the Ukraine crisis. The benchmark Kospi fell for a fifth session, with heavyweights Samsung Electronics and LG Energy Solution also experiencing declines. The Korean won hit its lowest in over 2 years, and foreigners sold 226.5 billion won worth of shares on the main board.

images.alt_text: The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield dropped slightly.

site_title: Verstappen beats Leclerc to win first Miami Grand Prix
summary: Max Verstappen won the inaugural Miami Grand Prix for Red Bull, beating Charles Leclerc by 3.786 seconds to take his third win of the season. The victory narrowed Leclerc's lead from 27 to 19 points. Verstappen made a crucial overtake on Carlos Sainz at the start and then blasted past Leclerc on the ninth lap. The win marked a successful debut for the Miami Grand Prix, which drew a large and enthusiastic crowd.

images.alt_text: Jamie Chadwick of Great Britain in action during the W Series race.

site_title: Fertiliser buyers are eyeing Canada to fill global potash deficit
summary: Canada's ample potash deposits are drawing significant interest from global fertiliser buyers due to sanctions disrupting supplies from Belarus and Russia. Saskatchewan, with the world's largest potash deposits, expects a growing demand for new projects as the provincial government works with companies to encourage more production. The province has roughly 1.1 billion metric tons of potassium oxide, enough to supply the world for several hundred years, and produced a record 14.2 million tons of potash last year.

images.alt_text: Ukraine war: What explains the calm in global stock markets?
Fertiliser prices to stay high amid supply holdups from Russia-Ukraine war: analysts

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on commodities, tech boost after Fed softens stance
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.8% to 7,364.7, driven by gains in commodity and technology stocks, following the US Federal Reserve's less hawkish stance on interest rates. The Fed raised rates by 0.5 percentage points, but Chair Jerome Powell ruled out a 75-basis-point hike, tempering market expectations. Local miners advanced, while technology shares surged 2.5%, marking their best day in a month.

images.alt_text: Chinese investors monitor stock prices at a brokerage house in Beijing, Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Asian shares rose Friday as worries receded the United States and Iran might be stepping closer to the edge of war, and U.S. indexes hit records. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)
Australian shares climbed on Thursday, as miners advanced on strong underlying commodity prices and tech stocks tracked Wall Street higher.

site_title: CIMB hires ex-JPMorgan veteran as wholesale bank co-head: sources
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has hired Novan Amirudin, former head of South-east Asia equity capital markets at JPMorgan Chase, as co-chief of its global wholesale banking operations. Novan will work alongside Chu Kok Wei, current group head of treasury and markets, to fill the position left vacant by Omar Siddiq Amin Noer Rashid, who joined HSBC Holdings as CEO of the Malaysian unit in January. The appointments are expected to be announced in the coming weeks, according to sources.

site_title: Tenant sales back at pre-Covid levels for Retail S-Reits
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 8.7% in March 2022, reversing the 3.5% decrease in February, according to the Singapore Department of Statistics. Seven S-Reits, including CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, and Suntec Reit, reported year-on-year sales growth in March. Tenant sales for S-Reits maintained above pre-Covid levels, with some seeing improved occupancy rates and shopper traffic. The easing of Covid-19 measures and reopening of the economy are expected to boost the recovery of footfall and tenant sales.

images.alt_text: its lyf one-north, which obtained TOP in January 2022, also achieved strong occupancy of over 85 per cent in 1Q22.

site_title: Singapore teen golfer Shannon Tan buoyed by runner-up finish at Queen Sirikit Cup
summary: Singaporean teenager Shannon Tan finished runner-up at the Queen Sirikit Cup, a prestigious Asia-Pacific amateur women's golf tournament, held at Laguna National Golf Resort Club. Tan, 18, shot an 8-under 280 total, just one shot shy of Japan's Mizuki Hashimoto. The tournament has been a pathway for leading Asian female golfers to turn professional, and Tan's performance has reinforced her desire to pursue a golf career. She will attend Texas Tech University on a full scholarship, with plans to turn pro after graduation.

images.alt_text: Singapore's golfers head to SEA Games without star James Leow
Aerial view of the Laguna National Golf & Country Club. Photographed 14 January 2020.##########pic##########Alphonsus Chern

site_title: Homeownership: Buying a BTO flat is the optimal choice
summary: A first-time homebuyer in Singapore may benefit from buying a build-to-order (BTO) HDB flat instead of a private home, despite the longer waiting period. A simulation shows that buying a BTO unit can generate more net cash after 10 years, even when considering loan repayments, due to the subsidized nature of BTO flats and lower maintenance costs. However, buying an expensive private home with leverage can provide higher returns, but comes with risks such as interest rate fluctuations and loan servicing issues. The optimal approach may be to save and invest funds for BTO purchases while considering factors like location and developer reputation when buying a private home.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Fresh demand for older flats as frustration builds over BTO
HDB resale prices rise for 8th straight quarter, up 2.4% in Q1

site_title: No Signboard enters MOU to receive S$5 million investment
summary: Renewable biomass project developer Gazelle Ventures has entered into a non-binding MOU to invest up to S$5 million in Catalyst-listed restaurant operator No Signboard Holdings. The proposed investment includes a S$500,000 subscription of new shares and S$4.5 million in debt or equity instruments for working capital. Gazelle Ventures will hold a 75% stake in the enlarged share capital of No Signboard.

images.alt_text: No Signboard closes its Esplanade outlet as Singapore reopens
No Signboard places beer subsidiary into creditors' voluntary liquidation

site_title: Starbucks profits edge higher despite China weakness
summary: Starbucks reported a modest profit increase of 2.3% to $674.5 million in the quarter ending April 3, driven by robust sales in North America despite weakness in China due to a Covid-19 outbreak. The company's North America division saw lower profit margins due to higher material costs and employee wages. Starbucks is investing in US stores, including drive-thru stores and cafe renovations, amid a unionization campaign, with shares rising 1.8% in after-hours trading.

site_title: Japan's low-cost soba noodles may become casualty of Ukraine war
summary: Japan's low-cost soba noodles, a staple in the country, may become more expensive due to the ongoing Ukraine war. Rising costs of Russian buckwheat, the primary ingredient, and shipping disruptions have led to price increases for soba shop owners. Prices are expected to rise 10-15% for some shops, affecting the affordability of the traditional Japanese dish. The war has disrupted global commodity prices, and Japan's yen has plummeted to a 20-year low, exacerbating the issue.

images.alt_text: Less rice for the same price: inflation bites Asia's food stalls

site_title: Rouble jumps to around 2-year high vs US dollar, euro as EU ups sanctions
summary: The Russian rouble surged to a 2-year high against the US dollar and euro on May 4, 2022, amid the European Union's proposed sanctions against Russia for events in Ukraine. The rouble gained 0.7% against the US dollar and 1.2% against the euro, with the EU proposing a phased oil embargo, sanctions on Russia's top bank, and banning its broadcasters from European airwaves. Russian stocks were mixed, with Sberbank shares rising 0.3% after being removed from the Swift transaction system.

site_title: Japan household spending beats expectations, but inflation risks loom
summary: Japan's household spending fell 2.3% in March, the first decline in three months, as consumers remained cautious despite easing COVID-19 curbs. The drop was smaller than expected, but inflation risks loom due to rising living costs and energy bills. Analysts expect a 0.7% contraction in the first quarter, followed by a 5.1% rebound, but warn that consumption-led recovery may be crimped. Inflation remains a multi-year high, fueled by war in Ukraine and the yen's 20-year lows.

images.alt_text: In this picture taken on May 9, 2022, a customer looks the self of the Sony PlayStation 5 video games and accessories at the gaming section of a shop in Tokyo. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Stocks log best session in six weeks as cyclicals roar back
summary: European stocks rose 1.7% on Wednesday, their largest one-day gain in six weeks, driven by strong earnings and a surge in economically sensitive sectors. Miners, automakers, and oil & gas companies gained over 3% each, while Thyssenkrupp raised its 2022 sales and operating profit outlook, and Compass Group lifted its annual revenue forecast. The recovery follows a sharp selloff earlier this month due to concerns over inflation and economic slowdown.

site_title: Amazon's captive staff meetings on unions illegal, labour board official finds
summary: A US labour board official has found Amazon's mandatory staff meetings on unionizing to be illegal, potentially setting a new legal precedent. The meetings, held in New York City, were allegedly used to discourage workers from joining the Amazon Labor Union, with Amazon threatening to fire staff who joined the union. The National Labor Relations Board's Brooklyn region has found merit to the allegations, and a complaint against Amazon may be issued, which could be litigated up to the federal level.

images.alt_text: Workers at an Amazon facility in New York have roundly voted against unionisation -- dealing a setback to a burgeoning organized labour movement one month after a landmark win at a nearby warehouse.
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen at an Amazon facility in Staten Island, New York City, U.S., April 24, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower extending US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a decline on Wall Street due to concerns over rising US interest rates and inflation. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.69% and the Topix index fell 0.91%. This marks the latest extension of US stock market falls, which has investors worried about the global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past an electronic quotation board displaying the numbers of the Nikkei 225 Index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 20, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Roe vs Wade uproar unlikely to cause ripples in Nov midterm elections
summary: The US Supreme Court's potential ruling to overturn Roe v. Wade, a landmark decision enshrining abortion rights, may not significantly impact the 2024 midterm elections. According to a Pew Research Centre study, 71% of Americans support mostly legal or mostly illegal abortion, with nuanced views that allow for exceptions. The ruling's impact would be felt more in state-level laws and politics, with some states already passing abortion restrictions. While some Democrats may try to exploit the issue, most voters are unlikely to make their election decision based on abortion, instead focusing on the economy and other issues.

images.alt_text: U.S. Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts bangs the gavel to adjourn the first session as he begins presiding over the Senate impeachment trial of U.S. President Donald Trump in this frame grab from video shot in the U.S. Senate Chamber at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, U.S., January 16, 2020. REUTERS/U.S. Senate TV/Handout via Reuters

site_title: Jobseekers' market forces Singapore companies to shake up culture, hire abroad
summary: Singapore's job market is experiencing a record high in job vacancies, with 2 job openings for every unemployed person in December 2021. Companies are having to rethink their hiring and retention strategies due to the talent crunch. The pandemic has led to a shift in the nature of work, with younger jobseekers prioritizing meaning and work-life balance, and platforms enabling gig work sucking up workers. The competition for talent is expected to increase as borders reopen, with countries competing for workers. To address the issue, companies are adopting creative strategies such as offering modern programming languages, redesigning jobs, and leveraging remote work and borderless talent.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The bulk of the increase in first-quarter non-resident employment stemmed from work permit holders in construction, according to the Ministry of Manpower.

WORKER demands for more flexibility and security, bolstered by the pandemic and a tight labour market, are only growing more intense as the world economy reopens and some firms begin trying to pull employees back to offices, payroll provider ADP reported in a survey of nearly 33,000 people worldwide.

site_title: Ong Keng Sen returns to Sifa to challenge Salome myth
summary: Renowned artist Ong Keng Sen returns to Singapore's Sifa festival with a new work, "project SALOME," a radical reimagining of the femme fatale Salome from 1st-century mythology. The piece explores themes of women's power and politics, reframing Salome as a victim, victor, or complex figure with conflicting impulses. The work consists of three interconnected stories, including a stage performance, live projections, and a film, which draw inspiration from the MeToo movement and the queering of gender identities. "project SALOME" debuts on May 27 and 28 at the Singapore International Festival of Arts.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Caravaggio's famous painting of Salome with the severed head of Jokanaan on a platter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.03 points or 0.07% to 1,550.71. The index saw 209.43 million lots traded worth RM100.65 million, with losers beating gainers 369 to 59.

site_title: Hot stock: ThaiBev up 4.4% after resuming spin-off listing plans
summary: ThaiBev shares rose 4.4% after the company resumed its proposed spin-off and listing of its brewery unit BeerCo on the Singapore Exchange. The move follows a 2021 deferral due to uncertain market conditions. ThaiBev's wholly-owned subsidiary will conduct a public offering of up to 20% of BeerCo's shares. The shares were trading at a high of S$0.705, with 25.5 million shares traded. The resumption marks a significant development in ThaiBev's plan to separate its brewery business from its beverage unit.

site_title: Emirates bets on premium economy launch to hit demand sweet spot
summary: Emirates is launching a premium economy class, targeting a "sweet spot" in demand following the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline will install the new seats on over 100 Airbus A380 and Boeing 777 planes, with tickets going on sale next month. Emirates chairman Sheikh Ahmed Bin Saeed Al Maktoum is confident the carrier will break even by the end of this year, with the airline aiming to return to full capacity and rebuild its business. The move comes as the airline benefits from continued flights to Russia and is solid financially.
